name: The Man in the Iron Mask

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Since Aramis's singular transformation into a confessor of the order, Baisemeaux was no longer the same man. Up to that period, the place which Aramis had held in the worthy governor's estimation was that of a prelate whom he respected and a friend to whom he owed a debt of gratitude but now he felt himself an inferior, and that Aramis was his master. He himself lighted a lantern, summoned a turnkey, and said, returning to Aramis, I am at your orders, monseigneur. Aramis merely nodded his head, as much as to say, Very good and signed to him with his hand to lead the way. Baisemeaux advanced, and Aramis followed him. It was a calm and lovely starlit night the steps of three men resounded on the flags of the terraces, and the clinking of the keys hanging from the jailer's girdle made itself heard up to the stories of the towers, as if to remind the prisoners that the liberty of earth was a luxury beyond their reach. It might have been said that the alteration effected in Baisemeaux extended even to the prisoners. The turnkey, the same who, on Aramis's first arrival had shown himself so inquisitive and curious, was now not only silent, but impassible. He held his head down, and seemed afraid to keep his ears open. In this wise they reached the basement of the Bertaudiere, the two first stories of which were mounted silently and somewhat slowly for Baisemeaux, though far from disobeying, was far from exhibiting any eagerness to obey. On arriving at the door, Baisemeaux showed a disposition to enter the prisoner's chamber but Aramis, stopping him on the threshold, said, The rules do not allow the governor to hear the prisoner's confession.
children.prevalue: Since Aramis s singular transformation into a confessor of the order Baisemeaux was no longer the same man Up to that period the place which Aramis had held in the worthy governor s estimation was that of a prelate whom he respected and a friend to whom he owed a debt of gratitude but now he felt himself an inferior and that Aramis was his master He himself lighted a lantern summoned a turnkey and said returning to Aramis I am at your orders monseigneur Aramis merely nodded his head as much as to say Very good and signed to him with his hand to lead the way Baisemeaux advanced and Aramis followed him It was a calm and lovely starlit night the steps of three men resounded on the flags of the terraces and the clinking of the keys hanging from the jailer s girdle made itself heard up to the stories of the towers as if to remind the prisoners that the liberty of earth was a luxury beyond their reach It might have been said that the alteration effected in Baisemeaux extended even to the prisoners The turnkey the same who on Aramis s first arrival had shown himself so inquisitive and curious was now not only silent but impassible He held his head down and seemed afraid to keep his ears open In this wise they reached the basement of the Bertaudiere the two first stories of which were mounted silently and somewhat slowly for Baisemeaux though far from disobeying was far from exhibiting any eagerness to obey On arriving at the door Baisemeaux showed a disposition to enter the prisoner s chamber but Aramis stopping him on the threshold said The rules do not allow the governor to hear the prisoner s confession

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Baisemeaux bowed, and made way for Aramis, who took the lantern and entered and then signed to them to close the door behind him. For an instant he remained standing, listening whether Baisemeaux and the turnkey had retired but as soon as he was assured by the sound of their descending footsteps that they had left the tower, he put the lantern on the table and gazed around. On a bed of green serge, similar in all respect to the other beds in the Bastile, save that it was newer, and under curtains halfdrawn, reposed a young man, to whom we have already once before introduced Aramis. According to custom, the prisoner was without a light. At the hour of curfew, he was bound to extinguish his lamp, and we perceive how much he was favored, in being allowed to keep it burning even till then. Near the bed a large leathern armchair, with twisted legs, sustained his clothes. A little tablewithout pens, books, paper, or inkstood neglected in sadness near the window while several plates, still unemptied, showed that the prisoner had scarcely touched his evening meal. Aramis saw that the young man was stretched upon his bed, his face half concealed by his arms. The arrival of a visitor did not caused any change of position either he was waiting in expectation, or was asleep. Aramis lighted the candle from the lantern, pushed back the armchair, and approached the bed with an evident mixture of interest and respect. The young man raised his head. What is it? said he.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux bowed and made way for Aramis who took the lantern and entered and then signed to them to close the door behind him For an instant he remained standing listening whether Baisemeaux and the turnkey had retired but as soon as he was assured by the sound of their descending footsteps that they had left the tower he put the lantern on the table and gazed around On a bed of green serge similar in all respect to the other beds in the Bastile save that it was newer and under curtains halfdrawn reposed a young man to whom we have already once before introduced Aramis According to custom the prisoner was without a light At the hour of curfew he was bound to extinguish his lamp and we perceive how much he was favored in being allowed to keep it burning even till then Near the bed a large leathern armchair with twisted legs sustained his clothes A little tablewithout pens books paper or inkstood neglected in sadness near the window while several plates still unemptied showed that the prisoner had scarcely touched his evening meal Aramis saw that the young man was stretched upon his bed his face half concealed by his arms The arrival of a visitor did not caused any change of position either he was waiting in expectation or was asleep Aramis lighted the candle from the lantern pushed back the armchair and approached the bed with an evident mixture of interest and respect The young man raised his head What is it said he

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: You desired a confessor? replied Aramis.
children.prevalue: You desired a confessor replied Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Because you were ill?
children.prevalue: Because you were ill

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Very ill?
children.prevalue: Very ill

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The young man gave Aramis a piercing glance, and answered, I thank you. After a moment's silence, I have seen you before, he continued. Aramis bowed.
children.prevalue: The young man gave Aramis a piercing glance and answered I thank you After a moment s silence I have seen you before he continued Aramis bowed

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Doubtless the scrutiny the prisoner had just made of the cold, crafty, and imperious character stamped upon the features of the bishop of Vannes was little reassuring to one in his situation, for he added, I am better.
children.prevalue: Doubtless the scrutiny the prisoner had just made of the cold crafty and imperious character stamped upon the features of the bishop of Vannes was little reassuring to one in his situation for he added I am better

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: And so? said Aramis.
children.prevalue: And so said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Why, thenbeing better, I have no longer the same need of a confessor, I think.
children.prevalue: Why thenbeing better I have no longer the same need of a confessor I think

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Not even of the haircloth, which the note you found in your bread informed you of?
children.prevalue: Not even of the haircloth which the note you found in your bread informed you of

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The young man started but before he had either assented or denied, Aramis continued, Not even of the ecclesiastic from whom you were to hear an important revelation?
children.prevalue: The young man started but before he had either assented or denied Aramis continued Not even of the ecclesiastic from whom you were to hear an important revelation

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: If it be so, said the young man, sinking again on his pillow, it is different I am listening.
children.prevalue: If it be so said the young man sinking again on his pillow it is different I am listening

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Aramis then looked at him more closely, and was struck with the easy majesty of his mien, one which can never be acquired unless Heaven has implanted it in the blood or heart. Sit down, monsieur, said the prisoner.
children.prevalue: Aramis then looked at him more closely and was struck with the easy majesty of his mien one which can never be acquired unless Heaven has implanted it in the blood or heart Sit down monsieur said the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Aramis bowed and obeyed. How does the Bastile agree with you? asked the bishop.
children.prevalue: Aramis bowed and obeyed How does the Bastile agree with you asked the bishop

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Very well.
children.prevalue: Very well

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: You do not suffer?
children.prevalue: You do not suffer

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: You have nothing to regret?
children.prevalue: You have nothing to regret

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Nothing.
children.prevalue: Nothing

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Not even your liberty?
children.prevalue: Not even your liberty

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: What do you call liberty, monsieur? asked the prisoner, with the tone of a man who is preparing for a struggle.
children.prevalue: What do you call liberty monsieur asked the prisoner with the tone of a man who is preparing for a struggle

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I call liberty, the flowers, the air, light, the stars, the happiness of going whithersoever the sinewy limbs of oneandtwenty chance to wish to carry you.
children.prevalue: I call liberty the flowers the air light the stars the happiness of going whithersoever the sinewy limbs of oneandtwenty chance to wish to carry you

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The young man smiled, whether in resignation or contempt, it was difficult to tell. Look, said he, I have in that Japanese vase two roses gathered yesterday evening in the bud from the governor's garden this morning they have blown and spread their vermilion chalice beneath my gaze with every opening petal they unfold the treasures of their perfumes, filling my chamber with a fragrance that embalms it. Look now on these two roses even among roses these are beautiful, and the rose is the most beautiful of flowers. Why, then, do you bid me desire other flowers when I possess the loveliest of all?
children.prevalue: The young man smiled whether in resignation or contempt it was difficult to tell Look said he I have in that Japanese vase two roses gathered yesterday evening in the bud from the governor s garden this morning they have blown and spread their vermilion chalice beneath my gaze with every opening petal they unfold the treasures of their perfumes filling my chamber with a fragrance that embalms it Look now on these two roses even among roses these are beautiful and the rose is the most beautiful of flowers Why then do you bid me desire other flowers when I possess the loveliest of all

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Aramis gazed at the young man in surprise.
children.prevalue: Aramis gazed at the young man in surprise

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: If flowers constitute liberty, sadly resumed the captive, I am free, for I possess them.
children.prevalue: If flowers constitute liberty sadly resumed the captive I am free for I possess them

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: But the air! cried Aramis air is so necessary to life!
children.prevalue: But the air cried Aramis air is so necessary to life

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Well, monsieur, returned the prisoner draw near to the window it is open. Between high heaven and earth the wind whirls on its waftages of hail and lightning, exhales its torrid mist or breathes in gentle breezes. It caresses my face. When mounted on the back of this armchair, with my arm around the bars of the window to sustain myself, I fancy I am swimming the wide expanse before me. The countenance of Aramis darkened as the young man continued: Light I have! what is better than light? I have the sun, a friend who comes to visit me every day without the permission of the governor or the jailer's company. He comes in at the window, and traces in my room a square the shape of the window, which lights up the hangings of my bed and floods the very floor. This luminous square increases from ten o'clock till midday, and decreases from one till three slowly, as if, having hastened to my presence, it sorrowed at bidding me farewell. When its last ray disappears I have enjoyed its presence for five hours. Is not that sufficient? I have been told that there are unhappy beings who dig in quarries, and laborers who toil in mines, who never behold it at all. Aramis wiped the drops from his brow. As to the stars which are so delightful to view, continued the young man, they all resemble each other save in size and brilliancy. I am a favored mortal, for if you had not lighted that candle you would have been able to see the beautiful stars which I was gazing at from my couch before your arrival, whose silvery rays were stealing through my brain.
children.prevalue: Well monsieur returned the prisoner draw near to the window it is open Between high heaven and earth the wind whirls on its waftages of hail and lightning exhales its torrid mist or breathes in gentle breezes It caresses my face When mounted on the back of this armchair with my arm around the bars of the window to sustain myself I fancy I am swimming the wide expanse before me The countenance of Aramis darkened as the young man continued Light I have what is better than light I have the sun a friend who comes to visit me every day without the permission of the governor or the jailer s company He comes in at the window and traces in my room a square the shape of the window which lights up the hangings of my bed and floods the very floor This luminous square increases from ten o clock till midday and decreases from one till three slowly as if having hastened to my presence it sorrowed at bidding me farewell When its last ray disappears I have enjoyed its presence for five hours Is not that sufficient I have been told that there are unhappy beings who dig in quarries and laborers who toil in mines who never behold it at all Aramis wiped the drops from his brow As to the stars which are so delightful to view continued the young man they all resemble each other save in size and brilliancy I am a favored mortal for if you had not lighted that candle you would have been able to see the beautiful stars which I was gazing at from my couch before your arrival whose silvery rays were stealing through my brain

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Aramis lowered his head he felt himself overwhelmed with the bitter flow of that sinister philosophy which is the religion of the captive.
children.prevalue: Aramis lowered his head he felt himself overwhelmed with the bitter flow of that sinister philosophy which is the religion of the captive

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: So much, then, for the flowers, the air, the daylight, and the stars, tranquilly continued the young man there remains but exercise. Do I not walk all day in the governor's garden if it is finehere if it rains? in the fresh air if it is warm in perfect warmth, thanks to my winter stove, if it be cold? Ah! monsieur, do you fancy, continued the prisoner, not without bitterness, that men have not done everything for me that a man can hope for or desire?
children.prevalue: So much then for the flowers the air the daylight and the stars tranquilly continued the young man there remains but exercise Do I not walk all day in the governor s garden if it is finehere if it rains in the fresh air if it is warm in perfect warmth thanks to my winter stove if it be cold Ah monsieur do you fancy continued the prisoner not without bitterness that men have not done everything for me that a man can hope for or desire

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Men! said Aramis be it so but it seems to me you are forgetting Heaven.
children.prevalue: Men said Aramis be it so but it seems to me you are forgetting Heaven

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Indeed I have forgotten Heaven, murmured the prisoner, with emotion but why do you mention it? Of what use is it to talk to a prisoner of Heaven?
children.prevalue: Indeed I have forgotten Heaven murmured the prisoner with emotion but why do you mention it Of what use is it to talk to a prisoner of Heaven

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Aramis looked steadily at this singular youth, who possessed the resignation of a martyr with the smile of an atheist. Is not Heaven in everything? he murmured in a reproachful tone.
children.prevalue: Aramis looked steadily at this singular youth who possessed the resignation of a martyr with the smile of an atheist Is not Heaven in everything he murmured in a reproachful tone

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Say rather, at the end of everything, answered the prisoner, firmly.
children.prevalue: Say rather at the end of everything answered the prisoner firmly

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Be it so, said Aramis but let us return to our startingpoint.
children.prevalue: Be it so said Aramis but let us return to our startingpoint

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I ask nothing better, returned the young man.
children.prevalue: I ask nothing better returned the young man

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: I am your confessor.
children.prevalue: I am your confessor

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Well, then, you ought, as a penitent, to tell me the truth.
children.prevalue: Well then you ought as a penitent to tell me the truth

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: My whole desire is to tell it you.
children.prevalue: My whole desire is to tell it you

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Every prisoner has committed some crime for which he has been imprisoned. What crime, then, have you committed?
children.prevalue: Every prisoner has committed some crime for which he has been imprisoned What crime then have you committed

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: You asked me the same question the first time you saw me, returned the prisoner.
children.prevalue: You asked me the same question the first time you saw me returned the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: And then, as now you evaded giving me an answer.
children.prevalue: And then as now you evaded giving me an answer

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: And what reason have you for thinking that I shall now reply to you?
children.prevalue: And what reason have you for thinking that I shall now reply to you

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Because this time I am your confessor.
children.prevalue: Because this time I am your confessor

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Then if you wish me to tell what crime I have committed, explain to me in what a crime consists. For as my conscience does not accuse me, I aver that I am not a criminal.
children.prevalue: Then if you wish me to tell what crime I have committed explain to me in what a crime consists For as my conscience does not accuse me I aver that I am not a criminal

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: We are often criminals in the sight of the great of the earth, not alone for having ourselves committed crimes, but because we know that crimes have been committed.
children.prevalue: We are often criminals in the sight of the great of the earth not alone for having ourselves committed crimes but because we know that crimes have been committed

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: The prisoner manifested the deepest attention.
children.prevalue: The prisoner manifested the deepest attention

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Yes, I understand you, he said, after a pause yes, you are right, monsieur it is very possible that, in such a light, I am a criminal in the eyes of the great of the earth.
children.prevalue: Yes I understand you he said after a pause yes you are right monsieur it is very possible that in such a light I am a criminal in the eyes of the great of the earth

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Ah! then you know something, said Aramis, who thought he had pierced not merely through a defect in the harness, but through the joints of it.
children.prevalue: Ah then you know something said Aramis who thought he had pierced not merely through a defect in the harness but through the joints of it

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: No, I am not aware of anything, replied the young man but sometimes I thinkand I say to myself
children.prevalue: No I am not aware of anything replied the young man but sometimes I thinkand I say to myself

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: What do you say to yourself?
children.prevalue: What do you say to yourself

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: That if I were to think but a little more deeply I should either go mad or I should divine a great deal.
children.prevalue: That if I were to think but a little more deeply I should either go mad or I should divine a great deal

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: And thenand then? said Aramis, impatiently.
children.prevalue: And thenand then said Aramis impatiently

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Then I leave off.
children.prevalue: Then I leave off

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: You leave off?
children.prevalue: You leave off

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Yes my head becomes confused and my ideas melancholy I feel ennui overtaking me I wish
children.prevalue: Yes my head becomes confused and my ideas melancholy I feel ennui overtaking me I wish

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: I don't know but I do not like to give myself up to longing for things which I do not possess, when I am so happy with what I have.
children.prevalue: I don t know but I do not like to give myself up to longing for things which I do not possess when I am so happy with what I have

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: You are afraid of death? said Aramis, with a slight uneasiness.
children.prevalue: You are afraid of death said Aramis with a slight uneasiness

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Yes, said the young man, smiling.
children.prevalue: Yes said the young man smiling

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Aramis felt the chill of that smile, and shuddered. Oh, as you fear death, you know more about matters than you say, he cried.
children.prevalue: Aramis felt the chill of that smile and shuddered Oh as you fear death you know more about matters than you say he cried

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: And you, returned the prisoner, who bade me to ask to see you you, who, when I did ask to see you, came here promising a world of confidence how is it that, nevertheless, it is you who are silent, leaving it for me to speak? Since, then, we both wear masks, either let us both retain them or put them aside together.
children.prevalue: And you returned the prisoner who bade me to ask to see you you who when I did ask to see you came here promising a world of confidence how is it that nevertheless it is you who are silent leaving it for me to speak Since then we both wear masks either let us both retain them or put them aside together

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Aramis felt the force and justice of the remark, saying to himself, This is no ordinary man I must be cautious.Are you ambitious? said he suddenly to the prisoner, aloud, without preparing him for the alteration.
children.prevalue: Aramis felt the force and justice of the remark saying to himself This is no ordinary man I must be cautious Are you ambitious said he suddenly to the prisoner aloud without preparing him for the alteration

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: What do you mean by ambitious? replied the youth.
children.prevalue: What do you mean by ambitious replied the youth

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Ambition, replied Aramis, is the feeling which prompts a man to desire moremuch morethan he possesses.
children.prevalue: Ambition replied Aramis is the feeling which prompts a man to desire moremuch morethan he possesses

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: I said that I was contented, monsieur but, perhaps, I deceive myself. I am ignorant of the nature of ambition but it is not impossible I may have some. Tell me your mind that is all I ask.
children.prevalue: I said that I was contented monsieur but perhaps I deceive myself I am ignorant of the nature of ambition but it is not impossible I may have some Tell me your mind that is all I ask

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: An ambitious man, said Aramis, is one who covets that which is beyond his station.
children.prevalue: An ambitious man said Aramis is one who covets that which is beyond his station

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: I covet nothing beyond my station, said the young man, with an assurance of manner which for the second time made the bishop of Vannes tremble.
children.prevalue: I covet nothing beyond my station said the young man with an assurance of manner which for the second time made the bishop of Vannes tremble

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: He was silent. But to look at the kindling eye, the knitted brow, and the reflective attitude of the captive, it was evident that he expected something more than silence,a silence which Aramis now broke. You lied the first time I saw you, said he.
children.prevalue: He was silent But to look at the kindling eye the knitted brow and the reflective attitude of the captive it was evident that he expected something more than silence a silence which Aramis now broke You lied the first time I saw you said he

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Lied! cried the young man, starting up on his couch, with such a tone in his voice, and such a lightning in his eyes, that Aramis recoiled, in spite of himself.
children.prevalue: Lied cried the young man starting up on his couch with such a tone in his voice and such a lightning in his eyes that Aramis recoiled in spite of himself

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: I should say, returned Aramis, bowing, you concealed from me what you knew of your infancy.
children.prevalue: I should say returned Aramis bowing you concealed from me what you knew of your infancy

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: A man's secrets are his own, monsieur, retorted the prisoner, and not at the mercy of the first chancecomer.
children.prevalue: A man s secrets are his own monsieur retorted the prisoner and not at the mercy of the first chancecomer

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: True, said Aramis, bowing still lower than before, 'tis true pardon me, but today do I still occupy the place of a chancecomer? I beseech you to reply, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: True said Aramis bowing still lower than before tis true pardon me but today do I still occupy the place of a chancecomer I beseech you to reply monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: This title slightly disturbed the prisoner but nevertheless he did not appear astonished that it was given him. I do not know you, monsieur, said he.
children.prevalue: This title slightly disturbed the prisoner but nevertheless he did not appear astonished that it was given him I do not know you monsieur said he

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Oh, but if I dared, I would take your hand and kiss it!
children.prevalue: Oh but if I dared I would take your hand and kiss it

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: The young man seemed as if he were going to give Aramis his hand but the light which beamed in his eyes faded away, and he coldly and distrustfully withdrew his hand again. Kiss the hand of a prisoner, he said, shaking his head, to what purpose?
children.prevalue: The young man seemed as if he were going to give Aramis his hand but the light which beamed in his eyes faded away and he coldly and distrustfully withdrew his hand again Kiss the hand of a prisoner he said shaking his head to what purpose

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Why did you tell me, said Aramis, that you were happy here? Why, that you aspired to nothing? Why, in a word, by thus speaking, do you prevent me from being frank in my turn?
children.prevalue: Why did you tell me said Aramis that you were happy here Why that you aspired to nothing Why in a word by thus speaking do you prevent me from being frank in my turn

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: The same light shone a third time in the young man's eyes, but died ineffectually away as before.
children.prevalue: The same light shone a third time in the young man s eyes but died ineffectually away as before

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: You distrust me, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: You distrust me said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: And why say you so, monsieur?
children.prevalue: And why say you so monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Oh, for a very simple reason if you know what you ought to know, you ought to mistrust everybody.
children.prevalue: Oh for a very simple reason if you know what you ought to know you ought to mistrust everybody

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Then do not be astonished that I am mistrustful, since you suspect me of knowing what I do not know.
children.prevalue: Then do not be astonished that I am mistrustful since you suspect me of knowing what I do not know

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Aramis was struck with admiration at this energetic resistance. Oh, monseigneur! you drive me to despair, said he, striking the armchair with his fist.
children.prevalue: Aramis was struck with admiration at this energetic resistance Oh monseigneur you drive me to despair said he striking the armchair with his fist

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: And, on my part, I do not comprehend you, monsieur.
children.prevalue: And on my part I do not comprehend you monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Well, then, try to understand me. The prisoner looked fixedly at Aramis.
children.prevalue: Well then try to understand me The prisoner looked fixedly at Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Sometimes it seems to me, said the latter, that I have before me the man whom I seek, and then
children.prevalue: Sometimes it seems to me said the latter that I have before me the man whom I seek and then

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: And then your man disappears,is it not so? said the prisoner, smiling. So much the better.
children.prevalue: And then your man disappears is it not so said the prisoner smiling So much the better

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Aramis rose. Certainly, said he I have nothing further to say to a man who mistrusts me as you do.
children.prevalue: Aramis rose Certainly said he I have nothing further to say to a man who mistrusts me as you do

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: And I, monsieur, said the prisoner, in the same tone, have nothing to say to a man who will not understand that a prisoner ought to be mistrustful of everybody.
children.prevalue: And I monsieur said the prisoner in the same tone have nothing to say to a man who will not understand that a prisoner ought to be mistrustful of everybody

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Even of his old friends, said Aramis. Oh, monseigneur, you are too prudent!
children.prevalue: Even of his old friends said Aramis Oh monseigneur you are too prudent

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Of my old friends?you one of my old friends,you?
children.prevalue: Of my old friends you one of my old friends you

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Do you no longer remember, said Aramis, that you once saw, in the village where your early years were spent
children.prevalue: Do you no longer remember said Aramis that you once saw in the village where your early years were spent

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Do you know the name of the village? asked the prisoner.
children.prevalue: Do you know the name of the village asked the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: NoisyleSec, monseigneur, answered Aramis, firmly.
children.prevalue: NoisyleSec monseigneur answered Aramis firmly

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Go on, said the young man, with an immovable aspect.
children.prevalue: Go on said the young man with an immovable aspect

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Stay, monseigneur, said Aramis if you are positively resolved to carry on this game, let us break off. I am here to tell you many things, 'tis true but you must allow me to see that, on your side, you have a desire to know them. Before revealing the important matters I still withhold, be assured I am in need of some encouragement, if not candor a little sympathy, if not confidence. But you keep yourself intrenched in a pretended which paralyzes me. Oh, not for the reason you think for, ignorant as you may be, or indifferent as you feign to be, you are none the less what you are, monseigneur, and there is nothingnothing, mark me! which can cause you not to be so.
children.prevalue: Stay monseigneur said Aramis if you are positively resolved to carry on this game let us break off I am here to tell you many things tis true but you must allow me to see that on your side you have a desire to know them Before revealing the important matters I still withhold be assured I am in need of some encouragement if not candor a little sympathy if not confidence But you keep yourself intrenched in a pretended which paralyzes me Oh not for the reason you think for ignorant as you may be or indifferent as you feign to be you are none the less what you are monseigneur and there is nothingnothing mark me which can cause you not to be so

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: I promise you, replied the prisoner, to hear you without impatience. Only it appears to me that I have a right to repeat the question I have already asked, 'Who are you?'
children.prevalue: I promise you replied the prisoner to hear you without impatience Only it appears to me that I have a right to repeat the question I have already asked Who are you

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Do you remember, fifteen or eighteen years ago, seeing at NoisyleSec a cavalier, accompanied by a lady in black silk, with flamecolored ribbons in her hair?
children.prevalue: Do you remember fifteen or eighteen years ago seeing at NoisyleSec a cavalier accompanied by a lady in black silk with flamecolored ribbons in her hair

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Yes, said the young man I once asked the name of this cavalier, and they told me that he called himself the Abbe d'Herblay. I was astonished that the abbe had so warlike an air, and they replied that there was nothing singular in that, seeing that he was one of Louis XIII.'s musketeers.
children.prevalue: Yes said the young man I once asked the name of this cavalier and they told me that he called himself the Abbe d Herblay I was astonished that the abbe had so warlike an air and they replied that there was nothing singular in that seeing that he was one of Louis XIII s musketeers

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Well, said Aramis, that musketeer and abbe, afterwards bishop of Vannes, is your confessor now.
children.prevalue: Well said Aramis that musketeer and abbe afterwards bishop of Vannes is your confessor now

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: I know it I recognized you.
children.prevalue: I know it I recognized you

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Then, monseigneur, if you know that, I must further add a fact of which you are ignorantthat if the king were to know this evening of the presence of this musketeer, this abbe, this bishop, this confessor, herehe, who has risked everything to visit you, tomorrow would behold the steely glitter of the executioner's axe in a dungeon more gloomy, more obscure than yours.
children.prevalue: Then monseigneur if you know that I must further add a fact of which you are ignorantthat if the king were to know this evening of the presence of this musketeer this abbe this bishop this confessor herehe who has risked everything to visit you tomorrow would behold the steely glitter of the executioner s axe in a dungeon more gloomy more obscure than yours

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: While listening to these words, delivered with emphasis, the young man had raised himself on his couch, and was now gazing more and more eagerly at Aramis.
children.prevalue: While listening to these words delivered with emphasis the young man had raised himself on his couch and was now gazing more and more eagerly at Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: The result of his scrutiny was that he appeared to derive some confidence from it. Yes, he murmured, I remember perfectly. The woman of whom you speak came once with you, and twice afterwards with another. He hesitated.
children.prevalue: The result of his scrutiny was that he appeared to derive some confidence from it Yes he murmured I remember perfectly The woman of whom you speak came once with you and twice afterwards with another He hesitated

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: With another, who came to see you every monthis it not so, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: With another who came to see you every monthis it not so monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Do you know who this lady was?
children.prevalue: Do you know who this lady was

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: The light seemed ready to flash from the prisoner's eyes. I am aware that she was one of the ladies of the court, he said.
children.prevalue: The light seemed ready to flash from the prisoner s eyes I am aware that she was one of the ladies of the court he said

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: You remember that lady well, do you not?
children.prevalue: You remember that lady well do you not

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Oh, my recollection can hardly be very confused on this head, said the young prisoner. I saw that lady once with a gentleman about fortyfive years old. I saw her once with you, and with the lady dressed in black. I have seen her twice since then with the same person. These four people, with my master, and old Perronnette, my jailer, and the governor of the prison, are the only persons with whom I have ever spoken, and, indeed, almost the only persons I have ever seen.
children.prevalue: Oh my recollection can hardly be very confused on this head said the young prisoner I saw that lady once with a gentleman about fortyfive years old I saw her once with you and with the lady dressed in black I have seen her twice since then with the same person These four people with my master and old Perronnette my jailer and the governor of the prison are the only persons with whom I have ever spoken and indeed almost the only persons I have ever seen

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Then you were in prison?
children.prevalue: Then you were in prison

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: If I am a prisoner here, then I was comparatively free, although in a very narrow sensea house I never quitted, a garden surrounded with walls I could not climb, these constituted my residence, but you know it, as you have been there. In a word, being accustomed to live within these bounds, I never cared to leave them. And so you will understand, monsieur, that having never seen anything of the world, I have nothing left to care for and therefore, if you relate anything, you will be obliged to explain each item to me as you go along.
children.prevalue: If I am a prisoner here then I was comparatively free although in a very narrow sensea house I never quitted a garden surrounded with walls I could not climb these constituted my residence but you know it as you have been there In a word being accustomed to live within these bounds I never cared to leave them And so you will understand monsieur that having never seen anything of the world I have nothing left to care for and therefore if you relate anything you will be obliged to explain each item to me as you go along

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: And I will do so, said Aramis, bowing for it is my duty, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: And I will do so said Aramis bowing for it is my duty monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Well, then, begin by telling me who was my tutor.
children.prevalue: Well then begin by telling me who was my tutor

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: A worthy and, above all, an honorable gentleman, monseigneur fit guide for both body and soul. Had you ever any reason to complain of him?
children.prevalue: A worthy and above all an honorable gentleman monseigneur fit guide for both body and soul Had you ever any reason to complain of him

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Oh, no quite the contrary. But this gentleman of yours often used to tell me that my father and mother were dead. Did he deceive me, or did he speak the truth?
children.prevalue: Oh no quite the contrary But this gentleman of yours often used to tell me that my father and mother were dead Did he deceive me or did he speak the truth

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: He was compelled to comply with the orders given him.
children.prevalue: He was compelled to comply with the orders given him

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Then he lied?
children.prevalue: Then he lied

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: In one respect. Your father is dead.
children.prevalue: In one respect Your father is dead

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: And my mother?
children.prevalue: And my mother

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: She is dead for you.
children.prevalue: She is dead for you

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: But then she lives for others, does she not?
children.prevalue: But then she lives for others does she not

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: And Iand I, then (the young man looked sharply at Aramis) am compelled to live in the obscurity of a prison?
children.prevalue: And Iand I then the young man looked sharply at Aramis am compelled to live in the obscurity of a prison

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: Alas! I fear so.
children.prevalue: Alas I fear so

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: And that because my presence in the world would lead to the revelation of a great secret?
children.prevalue: And that because my presence in the world would lead to the revelation of a great secret

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: Certainly, a very great secret.
children.prevalue: Certainly a very great secret

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: My enemy must indeed be powerful, to be able to shut up in the Bastile a child such as I then was.
children.prevalue: My enemy must indeed be powerful to be able to shut up in the Bastile a child such as I then was

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: He is.
children.prevalue: He is

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: More powerful than my mother, then?
children.prevalue: More powerful than my mother then

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: And why do you ask that?
children.prevalue: And why do you ask that

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: Because my mother would have taken my part.
children.prevalue: Because my mother would have taken my part

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: Aramis hesitated. Yes, monseigneur more powerful than your mother.
children.prevalue: Aramis hesitated Yes monseigneur more powerful than your mother

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: Seeing, then, that my nurse and preceptor were carried off, and that I, also, was separated from themeither they were, or I am, very dangerous to my enemy?
children.prevalue: Seeing then that my nurse and preceptor were carried off and that I also was separated from themeither they were or I am very dangerous to my enemy

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: Yes but you are alluding to a peril from which he freed himself, by causing the nurse and preceptor to disappear, answered Aramis, quietly.
children.prevalue: Yes but you are alluding to a peril from which he freed himself by causing the nurse and preceptor to disappear answered Aramis quietly

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: Disappear! cried the prisoner, how did they disappear?
children.prevalue: Disappear cried the prisoner how did they disappear

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: In a very sure way, answered Aramisthey are dead.
children.prevalue: In a very sure way answered Aramisthey are dead

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: The young man turned pale, and passed his hand tremblingly over his face. Poison? he asked.
children.prevalue: The young man turned pale and passed his hand tremblingly over his face Poison he asked

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Poison.
children.prevalue: Poison

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: The prisoner reflected a moment. My enemy must indeed have been very cruel, or hard beset by necessity, to assassinate those two innocent people, my sole support for the worthy gentleman and the poor nurse had never harmed a living being.
children.prevalue: The prisoner reflected a moment My enemy must indeed have been very cruel or hard beset by necessity to assassinate those two innocent people my sole support for the worthy gentleman and the poor nurse had never harmed a living being

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: In your family, monseigneur, necessity is stern. And so it is necessity which compels me, to my great regret, to tell you that this gentleman and the unhappy lady have been assassinated.
children.prevalue: In your family monseigneur necessity is stern And so it is necessity which compels me to my great regret to tell you that this gentleman and the unhappy lady have been assassinated

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: Oh, you tell me nothing I am not aware of, said the prisoner, knitting his brows.
children.prevalue: Oh you tell me nothing I am not aware of said the prisoner knitting his brows

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: How?
children.prevalue: How

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: I suspected it.
children.prevalue: I suspected it

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: Why?
children.prevalue: Why

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: I will tell you.
children.prevalue: I will tell you

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: At this moment the young man, supporting himself on his two elbows, drew close to Aramis's face, with such an expression of dignity, of selfcommand and of defiance even, that the bishop felt the electricity of enthusiasm strike in devouring flashes from that great heart of his, into his brain of adamant.
children.prevalue: At this moment the young man supporting himself on his two elbows drew close to Aramis s face with such an expression of dignity of selfcommand and of defiance even that the bishop felt the electricity of enthusiasm strike in devouring flashes from that great heart of his into his brain of adamant

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: Speak, monseigneur. I have already told you that by conversing with you I endanger my life. Little value as it has, I implore you to accept it as the ransom of your own.
children.prevalue: Speak monseigneur I have already told you that by conversing with you I endanger my life Little value as it has I implore you to accept it as the ransom of your own

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: Well, resumed the young man, this is why I suspected they had killed my nurse and my preceptor
children.prevalue: Well resumed the young man this is why I suspected they had killed my nurse and my preceptor

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: Whom you used to call your father?
children.prevalue: Whom you used to call your father

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: Yes whom I called my father, but whose son I well knew I was not.
children.prevalue: Yes whom I called my father but whose son I well knew I was not

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: Who caused you to suppose so?
children.prevalue: Who caused you to suppose so

children.name: Paragraph_155
children.value: Just as you, monsieur, are too respectful for a friend, he was also too respectful for a father.
children.prevalue: Just as you monsieur are too respectful for a friend he was also too respectful for a father

children.name: Paragraph_156
children.value: I, however, said Aramis, have no intention to disguise myself.
children.prevalue: I however said Aramis have no intention to disguise myself

children.name: Paragraph_157
children.value: The young man nodded assent and continued: Undoubtedly, I was not destined to perpetual seclusion, said the prisoner and that which makes me believe so, above all, now, is the care that was taken to render me as accomplished a cavalier as possible. The gentleman attached to my person taught me everything he knew himselfmathematics, a little geometry, astronomy, fencing and riding. Every morning I went through military exercises, and practiced on horseback. Well, one morning during the summer, it being very hot, I went to sleep in the hall. Nothing, up to that period, except the respect paid me, had enlightened me, or even roused my suspicions. I lived as children, as birds, as plants, as the air and the sun do. I had just turned my fifteenth year
children.prevalue: The young man nodded assent and continued Undoubtedly I was not destined to perpetual seclusion said the prisoner and that which makes me believe so above all now is the care that was taken to render me as accomplished a cavalier as possible The gentleman attached to my person taught me everything he knew himselfmathematics a little geometry astronomy fencing and riding Every morning I went through military exercises and practiced on horseback Well one morning during the summer it being very hot I went to sleep in the hall Nothing up to that period except the respect paid me had enlightened me or even roused my suspicions I lived as children as birds as plants as the air and the sun do I had just turned my fifteenth year

children.name: Paragraph_158
children.value: This, then, is eight years ago?
children.prevalue: This then is eight years ago

children.name: Paragraph_159
children.value: Yes, nearly but I have ceased to reckon time.
children.prevalue: Yes nearly but I have ceased to reckon time

children.name: Paragraph_160
children.value: Excuse me but what did your tutor tell you, to encourage you to work?
children.prevalue: Excuse me but what did your tutor tell you to encourage you to work

children.name: Paragraph_161
children.value: He used to say that a man was bound to make for himself, in the world, that fortune which Heaven had refused him at his birth. He added that, being a poor, obscure orphan, I had no one but myself to look to and that nobody either did, or ever would, take any interest in me. I was, then, in the hall I have spoken of, asleep from fatigue with long fencing. My preceptor was in his room on the first floor, just over me. Suddenly I heard him exclaim, and then he called: 'Perronnette! Perronnette!' It was my nurse whom he called.
children.prevalue: He used to say that a man was bound to make for himself in the world that fortune which Heaven had refused him at his birth He added that being a poor obscure orphan I had no one but myself to look to and that nobody either did or ever would take any interest in me I was then in the hall I have spoken of asleep from fatigue with long fencing My preceptor was in his room on the first floor just over me Suddenly I heard him exclaim and then he called Perronnette Perronnette It was my nurse whom he called

children.name: Paragraph_162
children.value: Yes, I know it, said Aramis. Continue, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes I know it said Aramis Continue monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_163
children.value: Very likely she was in the garden for my preceptor came hastily downstairs. I rose, anxious at seeing him anxious. He opened the gardendoor, still crying out, 'Perronnette! Perronnette!' The windows of the hall looked into the court the shutters were closed but through a chink in them I saw my tutor draw near a large well, which was almost directly under the windows of his study. He stooped over the brim, looked into the well, and again cried out, and made wild and affrighted gestures. Where I was, I could not only see, but hearand see and hear I did.
children.prevalue: Very likely she was in the garden for my preceptor came hastily downstairs I rose anxious at seeing him anxious He opened the gardendoor still crying out Perronnette Perronnette The windows of the hall looked into the court the shutters were closed but through a chink in them I saw my tutor draw near a large well which was almost directly under the windows of his study He stooped over the brim looked into the well and again cried out and made wild and affrighted gestures Where I was I could not only see but hearand see and hear I did

children.name: Paragraph_164
children.value: Go on, I pray you, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Go on I pray you said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_165
children.value: Dame Perronnette came running up, hearing the governor's cries. He went to meet her, took her by the arm, and drew her quickly towards the edge after which, as they both bent over it together, 'Look, look,' cried he, 'what a misfortune!'
children.prevalue: Dame Perronnette came running up hearing the governor s cries He went to meet her took her by the arm and drew her quickly towards the edge after which as they both bent over it together Look look cried he what a misfortune

children.name: Paragraph_166
children.value: 'Calm yourself, calm yourself,' said Perronnette 'what is the matter?'
children.prevalue: Calm yourself calm yourself said Perronnette what is the matter

children.name: Paragraph_167
children.value: 'The letter!' he exclaimed 'do you see that letter?' pointing to the bottom of the well.
children.prevalue: The letter he exclaimed do you see that letter pointing to the bottom of the well

children.name: Paragraph_168
children.value: 'What letter?' she cried.
children.prevalue: What letter she cried

children.name: Paragraph_169
children.value: 'The letter you see down there the last letter from the queen.'
children.prevalue: The letter you see down there the last letter from the queen

children.name: Paragraph_170
children.value: At this word I trembled. My tutorhe who passed for my father, he who was continually recommending me modesty and humilityin correspondence with the queen!
children.prevalue: At this word I trembled My tutorhe who passed for my father he who was continually recommending me modesty and humilityin correspondence with the queen

children.name: Paragraph_171
children.value: 'The queen's last letter!' cried Perronnette, without showing more astonishment than at seeing this letter at the bottom of the well 'but how came it there?'
children.prevalue: The queen s last letter cried Perronnette without showing more astonishment than at seeing this letter at the bottom of the well but how came it there

children.name: Paragraph_172
children.value: 'A chance, Dame Perronnettea singular chance. I was entering my room, and on opening the door, the window, too, being open, a puff of air came suddenly and carried off this paperthis letter of her majesty's I darted after it, and gained the window just in time to see it flutter a moment in the breeze and disappear down the well.'
children.prevalue: A chance Dame Perronnettea singular chance I was entering my room and on opening the door the window too being open a puff of air came suddenly and carried off this paperthis letter of her majesty s I darted after it and gained the window just in time to see it flutter a moment in the breeze and disappear down the well

children.name: Paragraph_173
children.value: 'Well,' said Dame Perronnette 'and if the letter has fallen into the well, 'tis all the same as if it was burnt and as the queen burns all her letters every time she comes'
children.prevalue: Well said Dame Perronnette and if the letter has fallen into the well tis all the same as if it was burnt and as the queen burns all her letters every time she comes

children.name: Paragraph_174
children.value: And so you see this lady who came every month was the queen, said the prisoner.
children.prevalue: And so you see this lady who came every month was the queen said the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_175
children.value: 'Doubtless, doubtless,' continued the old gentleman 'but this letter contained instructionshow can I follow them?'
children.prevalue: Doubtless doubtless continued the old gentleman but this letter contained instructionshow can I follow them

children.name: Paragraph_176
children.value: 'Write immediately to her give her a plain account of the accident, and the queen will no doubt write you another letter in place of this.'
children.prevalue: Write immediately to her give her a plain account of the accident and the queen will no doubt write you another letter in place of this

children.name: Paragraph_177
children.value: 'Oh! the queen would never believe the story,' said the good gentleman, shaking his head 'she will imagine that I want to keep this letter instead of giving it up like the rest, so as to have a hold over her. She is so distrustful, and M. de Mazarin soYon devil of an Italian is capable of having us poisoned at the first breath of suspicion.'
children.prevalue: Oh the queen would never believe the story said the good gentleman shaking his head she will imagine that I want to keep this letter instead of giving it up like the rest so as to have a hold over her She is so distrustful and M de Mazarin soYon devil of an Italian is capable of having us poisoned at the first breath of suspicion

children.name: Paragraph_178
children.value: Aramis almost imperceptibly smiled.
children.prevalue: Aramis almost imperceptibly smiled

children.name: Paragraph_179
children.value: 'You know, Dame Perronnette, they are both so suspicious in all that concerns Philippe.'
children.prevalue: You know Dame Perronnette they are both so suspicious in all that concerns Philippe

children.name: Paragraph_180
children.value: Philippe was the name they gave me, said the prisoner.
children.prevalue: Philippe was the name they gave me said the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_181
children.value: 'Well, 'tis no use hesitating,' said Dame Perronnette, 'somebody must go down the well.'
children.prevalue: Well tis no use hesitating said Dame Perronnette somebody must go down the well

children.name: Paragraph_182
children.value: 'Of course so that the person who goes down may read the paper as he is coming up.'
children.prevalue: Of course so that the person who goes down may read the paper as he is coming up

children.name: Paragraph_183
children.value: 'But let us choose some villager who cannot read, and then you will be at ease.'
children.prevalue: But let us choose some villager who cannot read and then you will be at ease

children.name: Paragraph_184
children.value: 'Granted but will not any one who descends guess that a paper must be important for which we risk a man's life? However, you have given me an idea, Dame Perronnette somebody shall go down the well, but that somebody shall be myself.'
children.prevalue: Granted but will not any one who descends guess that a paper must be important for which we risk a man s life However you have given me an idea Dame Perronnette somebody shall go down the well but that somebody shall be myself

children.name: Paragraph_185
children.value: But at this notion Dame Perronnette lamented and cried in such a manner, and so implored the old nobleman, with tears in her eyes, that he promised her to obtain a ladder long enough to reach down, while she went in search of some stouthearted youth, whom she was to persuade that a jewel had fallen into the well, and that this jewel was wrapped in a paper. 'And as paper,' remarked my preceptor, 'naturally unfolds in water, the young man would not be surprised at finding nothing, after all, but the letter wide open.'
children.prevalue: But at this notion Dame Perronnette lamented and cried in such a manner and so implored the old nobleman with tears in her eyes that he promised her to obtain a ladder long enough to reach down while she went in search of some stouthearted youth whom she was to persuade that a jewel had fallen into the well and that this jewel was wrapped in a paper And as paper remarked my preceptor naturally unfolds in water the young man would not be surprised at finding nothing after all but the letter wide open

children.name: Paragraph_186
children.value: 'But perhaps the writing will be already effaced by that time,' said Dame Perronnette.
children.prevalue: But perhaps the writing will be already effaced by that time said Dame Perronnette

children.name: Paragraph_187
children.value: 'No consequence, provided we secure the letter. On returning it to the queen, she will see at once that we have not betrayed her and consequently, as we shall not rouse the distrust of Mazarin, we shall have nothing to fear from him.'
children.prevalue: No consequence provided we secure the letter On returning it to the queen she will see at once that we have not betrayed her and consequently as we shall not rouse the distrust of Mazarin we shall have nothing to fear from him

children.name: Paragraph_188
children.value: Having come to this resolution, they parted. I pushed back the shutter, and, seeing that my tutor was about to reenter, I threw myself on my couch, in a confusion of brain caused by all I had just heard. My governor opened the door a few moments after, and thinking I was asleep gently closed it again. As soon as ever it was shut, I rose, and, listening, heard the sound of retiring footsteps. Then I returned to the shutters, and saw my tutor and Dame Perronnette go out together. I was alone in the house. They had hardly closed the gate before I sprang from the window and ran to the well. Then, just as my governor had leaned over, so leaned I. Something white and luminous glistened in the green and quivering silence of the water. The brilliant disk fascinated and allured me my eyes became fixed, and I could hardly breathe. The well seemed to draw me downwards with its slimy mouth and icy breath and I thought I read, at the bottom of the water, characters of fire traced upon the letter the queen had touched. Then, scarcely knowing what I was about, and urged on by one of those instinctive impulses which drive men to destruction, I lowered the cord from the windlass of the well to within about three feet of the water, leaving the bucket dangling, at the same time taking infinite pains not to disturb that coveted letter, which was beginning to change its white tint for the hue of chrysoprase,proof enough that it was sinking,and then, with the rope weltering in my hands, slid down into the abyss. When I saw myself hanging over the dark pool, when I saw the sky lessening above my head, a cold shudder came over me, a chill fear got the better of me, I was seized with giddiness, and the hair rose on my head but my strong will still reigned supreme over all the terror and disquietude. I gained the water, and at once plunged into it, holding on by one hand, while I immersed the other and seized the dear letter, which, alas! came in two in my grasp. I concealed the two fragments in my bodycoat, and, helping myself with my feet against the sides of the pit, and clinging on with my hands, agile and vigorous as I was, and, above all, pressed for time, I regained the brink, drenching it as I touched it with the water that streamed off me. I was no sooner out of the well with my prize, than I rushed into the sunlight, and took refuge in a kind of shrubbery at the bottom of the garden. As I entered my hidingplace, the bell which resounded when the great gate was opened, rang. It was my preceptor come back again. I had but just time. I calculated that it would take ten minutes before he would gain my place of concealment, even if, guessing where I was, he came straight to it and twenty if he were obliged to look for me. But this was time enough to allow me to read the cherished letter, whose fragments I hastened to unite again. The writing was already fading, but I managed to decipher it all.
children.prevalue: Having come to this resolution they parted I pushed back the shutter and seeing that my tutor was about to reenter I threw myself on my couch in a confusion of brain caused by all I had just heard My governor opened the door a few moments after and thinking I was asleep gently closed it again As soon as ever it was shut I rose and listening heard the sound of retiring footsteps Then I returned to the shutters and saw my tutor and Dame Perronnette go out together I was alone in the house They had hardly closed the gate before I sprang from the window and ran to the well Then just as my governor had leaned over so leaned I Something white and luminous glistened in the green and quivering silence of the water The brilliant disk fascinated and allured me my eyes became fixed and I could hardly breathe The well seemed to draw me downwards with its slimy mouth and icy breath and I thought I read at the bottom of the water characters of fire traced upon the letter the queen had touched Then scarcely knowing what I was about and urged on by one of those instinctive impulses which drive men to destruction I lowered the cord from the windlass of the well to within about
