place of concealment even if guessing where I was he came straight to it and twenty if he were obliged to look for me But this was time enough to allow me to read the cherished letter whose fragments I hastened to unite again The writing was already fading but I managed to decipher it all

children.name: Paragraph_189
children.value: And will you tell me what you read therein, monseigneur? asked Aramis, deeply interested.
children.prevalue: And will you tell me what you read therein monseigneur asked Aramis deeply interested

children.name: Paragraph_190
children.value: Quite enough, monsieur, to see that my tutor was a man of noble rank, and that Perronnette, without being a lady of quality, was far better than a servant and also to perceived that I must myself be highborn, since the queen, Anne of Austria, and Mazarin, the prime minister, commended me so earnestly to their care. Here the young man paused, quite overcome.
children.prevalue: Quite enough monsieur to see that my tutor was a man of noble rank and that Perronnette without being a lady of quality was far better than a servant and also to perceived that I must myself be highborn since the queen Anne of Austria and Mazarin the prime minister commended me so earnestly to their care Here the young man paused quite overcome

children.name: Paragraph_191
children.value: And what happened? asked Aramis.
children.prevalue: And what happened asked Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_192
children.value: It happened, monsieur, answered he, that the workmen they had summoned found nothing in the well, after the closest search that my governor perceived that the brink was all watery that I was not so dried by the sun as to prevent Dame Perronnette spying that my garments were moist and, lastly, that I was seized with a violent fever, owing to the chill and the excitement of my discovery, an attack of delirium supervening, during which I related the whole adventure so that, guided by my avowal, my governor found the pieces of the queen's letter inside the bolster where I had concealed them.
children.prevalue: It happened monsieur answered he that the workmen they had summoned found nothing in the well after the closest search that my governor perceived that the brink was all watery that I was not so dried by the sun as to prevent Dame Perronnette spying that my garments were moist and lastly that I was seized with a violent fever owing to the chill and the excitement of my discovery an attack of delirium supervening during which I related the whole adventure so that guided by my avowal my governor found the pieces of the queen s letter inside the bolster where I had concealed them

children.name: Paragraph_193
children.value: Ah! said Aramis, now I understand.
children.prevalue: Ah said Aramis now I understand

children.name: Paragraph_194
children.value: Beyond this, all is conjecture. Doubtless the unfortunate lady and gentleman, not daring to keep the occurrence secret, wrote of all this to the queen and sent back the torn letter.
children.prevalue: Beyond this all is conjecture Doubtless the unfortunate lady and gentleman not daring to keep the occurrence secret wrote of all this to the queen and sent back the torn letter

children.name: Paragraph_195
children.value: After which, said Aramis, you were arrested and removed to the Bastile.
children.prevalue: After which said Aramis you were arrested and removed to the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_196
children.value: As you see.
children.prevalue: As you see

children.name: Paragraph_197
children.value: Your two attendants disappeared?
children.prevalue: Your two attendants disappeared

children.name: Paragraph_198
children.value: Alas!
children.prevalue: Alas

children.name: Paragraph_199
children.value: Let us not take up our time with the dead, but see what can be done with the living. You told me you were resigned.
children.prevalue: Let us not take up our time with the dead but see what can be done with the living You told me you were resigned

children.name: Paragraph_200
children.value: I repeat it.
children.prevalue: I repeat it

children.name: Paragraph_201
children.value: Without any desire for freedom?
children.prevalue: Without any desire for freedom

children.name: Paragraph_202
children.value: As I told you.
children.prevalue: As I told you

children.name: Paragraph_203
children.value: Without ambition, sorrow, or thought?
children.prevalue: Without ambition sorrow or thought

children.name: Paragraph_204
children.value: The young man made no answer.
children.prevalue: The young man made no answer

children.name: Paragraph_205
children.value: Well, asked Aramis, why are you silent?
children.prevalue: Well asked Aramis why are you silent

children.name: Paragraph_206
children.value: I think I have spoken enough, answered the prisoner, and that now it is your turn. I am weary.
children.prevalue: I think I have spoken enough answered the prisoner and that now it is your turn I am weary

children.name: Paragraph_207
children.value: Aramis gathered himself up, and a shade of deep solemnity spread itself over his countenance. It was evident that he had reached the crisis in the part he had come to the prison to play. One question, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Aramis gathered himself up and a shade of deep solemnity spread itself over his countenance It was evident that he had reached the crisis in the part he had come to the prison to play One question said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_208
children.value: What is it? speak.
children.prevalue: What is it speak

children.name: Paragraph_209
children.value: In the house you inhabited there were neither lookingglasses nor mirrors?
children.prevalue: In the house you inhabited there were neither lookingglasses nor mirrors

children.name: Paragraph_210
children.value: What are those two words, and what is their meaning? asked the young man I have no sort of knowledge of them.
children.prevalue: What are those two words and what is their meaning asked the young man I have no sort of knowledge of them

children.name: Paragraph_211
children.value: They designate two pieces of furniture which reflect objects so that, for instance, you may see in them your own lineaments, as you see mine now, with the naked eye.
children.prevalue: They designate two pieces of furniture which reflect objects so that for instance you may see in them your own lineaments as you see mine now with the naked eye

children.name: Paragraph_212
children.value: No there was neither a glass nor a mirror in the house, answered the young man.
children.prevalue: No there was neither a glass nor a mirror in the house answered the young man

children.name: Paragraph_213
children.value: Aramis looked round him. Nor is there anything of the kind here, either, he said they have again taken the same precaution.
children.prevalue: Aramis looked round him Nor is there anything of the kind here either he said they have again taken the same precaution

children.name: Paragraph_214
children.value: To what end?
children.prevalue: To what end

children.name: Paragraph_215
children.value: You will know directly. Now, you have told me that you were instructed in mathematics, astronomy, fencing, and riding but you have not said a word about history.
children.prevalue: You will know directly Now you have told me that you were instructed in mathematics astronomy fencing and riding but you have not said a word about history

children.name: Paragraph_216
children.value: My tutor sometimes related to me the principal deeds of the king, St. Louis, King Francis I., and King Henry IV.
children.prevalue: My tutor sometimes related to me the principal deeds of the king St Louis King Francis I and King Henry IV

children.name: Paragraph_217
children.value: Is that all?
children.prevalue: Is that all

children.name: Paragraph_218
children.value: Very nearly.
children.prevalue: Very nearly

children.name: Paragraph_219
children.value: This also was done by design, then just as they deprived you of mirrors, which reflect the present, so they left you in ignorance of history, which reflects the past. Since your imprisonment, books have been forbidden you so that you are unacquainted with a number of facts, by means of which you would be able to reconstruct the shattered mansion of your recollections and your hopes.
children.prevalue: This also was done by design then just as they deprived you of mirrors which reflect the present so they left you in ignorance of history which reflects the past Since your imprisonment books have been forbidden you so that you are unacquainted with a number of facts by means of which you would be able to reconstruct the shattered mansion of your recollections and your hopes

children.name: Paragraph_220
children.value: It is true, said the young man.
children.prevalue: It is true said the young man

children.name: Paragraph_221
children.value: Listen, then I will in a few words tell you what has passed in France during the last twentythree or twentyfour years that is, from the probable date of your birth in a word, from the time that interests you.
children.prevalue: Listen then I will in a few words tell you what has passed in France during the last twentythree or twentyfour years that is from the probable date of your birth in a word from the time that interests you

children.name: Paragraph_222
children.value: Say on. And the young man resumed his serious and attentive attitude.
children.prevalue: Say on And the young man resumed his serious and attentive attitude

children.name: Paragraph_223
children.value: Do you know who was the son of Henry IV.?
children.prevalue: Do you know who was the son of Henry IV

children.name: Paragraph_224
children.value: At least I know who his successor was.
children.prevalue: At least I know who his successor was

children.name: Paragraph_225
children.value: How?
children.prevalue: How

children.name: Paragraph_226
children.value: By means of a coin dated 1610, which bears the effigy of Henry IV. and another of 1612, bearing that of Louis XIII. So I presumed that, there being only two years between the two dates, Louis was Henry's successor.
children.prevalue: By means of a coin dated 1610 which bears the effigy of Henry IV and another of 1612 bearing that of Louis XIII So I presumed that there being only two years between the two dates Louis was Henry s successor

children.name: Paragraph_227
children.value: Then, said Aramis, you know that the last reigning monarch was Louis XIII.?
children.prevalue: Then said Aramis you know that the last reigning monarch was Louis XIII

children.name: Paragraph_228
children.value: I do, answered the youth, slightly reddening.
children.prevalue: I do answered the youth slightly reddening

children.name: Paragraph_229
children.value: Well, he was a prince full of noble ideas and great projects, always, alas! deferred by the trouble of the times and the dread struggle that his minister Richelieu had to maintain against the great nobles of France. The king himself was of a feeble character, and died young and unhappy.
children.prevalue: Well he was a prince full of noble ideas and great projects always alas deferred by the trouble of the times and the dread struggle that his minister Richelieu had to maintain against the great nobles of France The king himself was of a feeble character and died young and unhappy

children.name: Paragraph_230
children.value: I know it.
children.prevalue: I know it

children.name: Paragraph_231
children.value: He had been long anxious about having a heir a care which weighs heavily on princes, who desire to leave behind them more than one pledge that their best thoughts and works will be continued.
children.prevalue: He had been long anxious about having a heir a care which weighs heavily on princes who desire to leave behind them more than one pledge that their best thoughts and works will be continued

children.name: Paragraph_232
children.value: Did the king, then, die childless? asked the prisoner, smiling.
children.prevalue: Did the king then die childless asked the prisoner smiling

children.name: Paragraph_233
children.value: No, but he was long without one, and for a long while thought he should be the last of his race. This idea had reduced him to the depths of despair, when suddenly, his wife, Anne of Austria
children.prevalue: No but he was long without one and for a long while thought he should be the last of his race This idea had reduced him to the depths of despair when suddenly his wife Anne of Austria

children.name: Paragraph_234
children.value: The prisoner trembled.
children.prevalue: The prisoner trembled

children.name: Paragraph_235
children.value: Did you know, said Aramis, that Louis XIII.'s wife was called Anne of Austria?
children.prevalue: Did you know said Aramis that Louis XIII s wife was called Anne of Austria

children.name: Paragraph_236
children.value: Continue, said the young man, without replying to the question.
children.prevalue: Continue said the young man without replying to the question

children.name: Paragraph_237
children.value: When suddenly, resumed Aramis, the queen announced an interesting event. There was great joy at the intelligence, and all prayed for her happy delivery. On the 5th of September, 1638, she gave birth to a son.
children.prevalue: When suddenly resumed Aramis the queen announced an interesting event There was great joy at the intelligence and all prayed for her happy delivery On the 5th of September 1638 she gave birth to a son

children.name: Paragraph_238
children.value: Here Aramis looked at his companion, and thought he observed him turning pale. You are about to hear, said Aramis, an account which few indeed could now avouch for it refers to a secret which they imagined buried with the dead, entombed in the abyss of the confessional.
children.prevalue: Here Aramis looked at his companion and thought he observed him turning pale You are about to hear said Aramis an account which few indeed could now avouch for it refers to a secret which they imagined buried with the dead entombed in the abyss of the confessional

children.name: Paragraph_239
children.value: And you will tell me this secret? broke in the youth.
children.prevalue: And you will tell me this secret broke in the youth

children.name: Paragraph_240
children.value: Oh! said Aramis, with unmistakable emphasis, I do not know that I ought to risk this secret by intrusting it to one who has no desire to quit the Bastile.
children.prevalue: Oh said Aramis with unmistakable emphasis I do not know that I ought to risk this secret by intrusting it to one who has no desire to quit the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_241
children.value: I hear you, monsieur.
children.prevalue: I hear you monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_242
children.value: The queen, then, gave birth to a son. But while the court was rejoicing over the event, when the king had shown the newborn child to the nobility and people, and was sitting gayly down to table, to celebrate the event, the queen, who was alone in her room, was again taken ill and gave birth to a second son.
children.prevalue: The queen then gave birth to a son But while the court was rejoicing over the event when the king had shown the newborn child to the nobility and people and was sitting gayly down to table to celebrate the event the queen who was alone in her room was again taken ill and gave birth to a second son

children.name: Paragraph_243
children.value: Oh! said the prisoner, betraying a better acquaintance with affairs than he had owned to, I thought that Monsieur was only born in
children.prevalue: Oh said the prisoner betraying a better acquaintance with affairs than he had owned to I thought that Monsieur was only born in

children.name: Paragraph_244
children.value: Aramis raised his finger Permit me to continue, he said.
children.prevalue: Aramis raised his finger Permit me to continue he said

children.name: Paragraph_245
children.value: The prisoner sighed impatiently, and paused.
children.prevalue: The prisoner sighed impatiently and paused

children.name: Paragraph_246
children.value: Yes, said Aramis, the queen had a second son, whom Dame Perronnette, the midwife, received in her arms.
children.prevalue: Yes said Aramis the queen had a second son whom Dame Perronnette the midwife received in her arms

children.name: Paragraph_247
children.value: Dame Perronnette! murmured the young man.
children.prevalue: Dame Perronnette murmured the young man

children.name: Paragraph_248
children.value: They ran at once to the banquetingroom, and whispered to the king what had happened he rose and quitted the table. But this time it was no longer happiness that his face expressed, but something akin to terror. The birth of twins changed into bitterness the joy to which that of an only son had given rise, seeing that in France (a fact you are assuredly ignorant of) it is the oldest of the king's sons who succeeds his father.
children.prevalue: They ran at once to the banquetingroom and whispered to the king what had happened he rose and quitted the table But this time it was no longer happiness that his face expressed but something akin to terror The birth of twins changed into bitterness the joy to which that of an only son had given rise seeing that in France a fact you are assuredly ignorant of it is the oldest of the king s sons who succeeds his father

children.name: Paragraph_249
children.value: I know it.
children.prevalue: I know it

children.name: Paragraph_250
children.value: And that the doctors and jurists assert that there is ground for doubting whether the son that first makes his appearance is the elder by the law of heaven and of nature.
children.prevalue: And that the doctors and jurists assert that there is ground for doubting whether the son that first makes his appearance is the elder by the law of heaven and of nature

children.name: Paragraph_251
children.value: The prisoner uttered a smothered cry, and became whiter than the coverlet under which he hid himself.
children.prevalue: The prisoner uttered a smothered cry and became whiter than the coverlet under which he hid himself

children.name: Paragraph_252
children.value: Now you understand, pursued Aramis, that the king, who with so much pleasure saw himself repeated in one, was in despair about two fearing that the second might dispute the first's claim to seniority, which had been recognized only two hours before and so this second son, relying on party interests and caprices, might one day sow discord and engender civil war throughout the kingdom by these means destroying the very dynasty he should have strengthened.
children.prevalue: Now you understand pursued Aramis that the king who with so much pleasure saw himself repeated in one was in despair about two fearing that the second might dispute the first s claim to seniority which had been recognized only two hours before and so this second son relying on party interests and caprices might one day sow discord and engender civil war throughout the kingdom by these means destroying the very dynasty he should have strengthened

children.name: Paragraph_253
children.value: Oh, I understand!I understand! murmured the young man.
children.prevalue: Oh I understand I understand murmured the young man

children.name: Paragraph_254
children.value: Well, continued Aramis this is what they relate, what they declare this is why one of the queen's two sons, shamefully parted from his brother, shamefully sequestered, is buried in profound obscurity this is why that second son has disappeared, and so completely, that not a soul in France, save his mother, is aware of his existence.
children.prevalue: Well continued Aramis this is what they relate what they declare this is why one of the queen s two sons shamefully parted from his brother shamefully sequestered is buried in profound obscurity this is why that second son has disappeared and so completely that not a soul in France save his mother is aware of his existence

children.name: Paragraph_255
children.value: Yes! his mother, who has cast him off, cried the prisoner in a tone of despair.
children.prevalue: Yes his mother who has cast him off cried the prisoner in a tone of despair

children.name: Paragraph_256
children.value: Except, also, Aramis went on, the lady in the black dress and, finally, excepting
children.prevalue: Except also Aramis went on the lady in the black dress and finally excepting

children.name: Paragraph_257
children.value: Excepting yourselfis it not? You who come and relate all this you, who rouse in my soul curiosity, hatred, ambition, and, perhaps, even the thirst of vengeance except you, monsieur, who, if you are the man to whom I expect, whom the note I have received applies to, whom, in short, Heaven ought to send me, must possess about you
children.prevalue: Excepting yourselfis it not You who come and relate all this you who rouse in my soul curiosity hatred ambition and perhaps even the thirst of vengeance except you monsieur who if you are the man to whom I expect whom the note I have received applies to whom in short Heaven ought to send me must possess about you

children.name: Paragraph_258
children.value: What? asked Aramis.
children.prevalue: What asked Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_259
children.value: A portrait of the king, Louis XIV., who at this moment reigns upon the throne of France.
children.prevalue: A portrait of the king Louis XIV who at this moment reigns upon the throne of France

children.name: Paragraph_260
children.value: Here is the portrait, replied the bishop, handing the prisoner a miniature in enamel, on which Louis was depicted lifelike, with a handsome, lofty mien. The prisoner eagerly seized the portrait, and gazed at it with devouring eyes.
children.prevalue: Here is the portrait replied the bishop handing the prisoner a miniature in enamel on which Louis was depicted lifelike with a handsome lofty mien The prisoner eagerly seized the portrait and gazed at it with devouring eyes

children.name: Paragraph_261
children.value: And now, monseigneur, said Aramis, here is a mirror. Aramis left the prisoner time to recover his ideas.
children.prevalue: And now monseigneur said Aramis here is a mirror Aramis left the prisoner time to recover his ideas

children.name: Paragraph_262
children.value: So high!so high! murmured the young man, eagerly comparing the likeness of Louis with his own countenance reflected in the glass.
children.prevalue: So high so high murmured the young man eagerly comparing the likeness of Louis with his own countenance reflected in the glass

children.name: Paragraph_263
children.value: What do you think of it? at length said Aramis.
children.prevalue: What do you think of it at length said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_264
children.value: I think that I am lost, replied the captive the king will never set me free.
children.prevalue: I think that I am lost replied the captive the king will never set me free

children.name: Paragraph_265
children.value: And II demand to know, added the bishop, fixing his piercing eyes significantly upon the prisoner, I demand to know which of these two is king the one this miniature portrays, or whom the glass reflects?
children.prevalue: And II demand to know added the bishop fixing his piercing eyes significantly upon the prisoner I demand to know which of these two is king the one this miniature portrays or whom the glass reflects

children.name: Paragraph_266
children.value: The king, monsieur, sadly replied the young man, is he who is on the throne, who is not in prison and who, on the other hand, can cause others to be entombed there. Royalty means power and you behold how powerless I am.
children.prevalue: The king monsieur sadly replied the young man is he who is on the throne who is not in prison and who on the other hand can cause others to be entombed there Royalty means power and you behold how powerless I am

children.name: Paragraph_267
children.value: Monseigneur, answered Aramis, with a respect he had not yet manifested, the king, mark me, will, if you desire it, be the one that, quitting his dungeon, shall maintain himself upon the throne, on which his friends will place him.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur answered Aramis with a respect he had not yet manifested the king mark me will if you desire it be the one that quitting his dungeon shall maintain himself upon the throne on which his friends will place him

children.name: Paragraph_268
children.value: Tempt me not, monsieur, broke in the prisoner bitterly.
children.prevalue: Tempt me not monsieur broke in the prisoner bitterly

children.name: Paragraph_269
children.value: Be not weak, monseigneur, persisted Aramis I have brought you all the proofs of your birth consult them satisfy yourself that you are a king's son it is for us to act.
children.prevalue: Be not weak monseigneur persisted Aramis I have brought you all the proofs of your birth consult them satisfy yourself that you are a king s son it is for us to act

children.name: Paragraph_270
children.value: No, no it is impossible.
children.prevalue: No no it is impossible

children.name: Paragraph_271
children.value: Unless, indeed, resumed the bishop ironically, it be the destiny of your race, that the brothers excluded from the throne should be always princes void of courage and honesty, as was your uncle, M. Gaston d'Orleans, who ten times conspired against his brother Louis XIII.
children.prevalue: Unless indeed resumed the bishop ironically it be the destiny of your race that the brothers excluded from the throne should be always princes void of courage and honesty as was your uncle M Gaston d Orleans who ten times conspired against his brother Louis XIII

children.name: Paragraph_272
children.value: What! cried the prince, astonished my uncle Gaston 'conspired against his brother' conspired to dethrone him?
children.prevalue: What cried the prince astonished my uncle Gaston conspired against his brother conspired to dethrone him

children.name: Paragraph_273
children.value: Exactly, monseigneur for no other reason. I tell you the truth.
children.prevalue: Exactly monseigneur for no other reason I tell you the truth

children.name: Paragraph_274
children.value: And he had friendsdevoted friends?
children.prevalue: And he had friendsdevoted friends

children.name: Paragraph_275
children.value: As much so as I am to you.
children.prevalue: As much so as I am to you

children.name: Paragraph_276
children.value: And, after all, what did he do?Failed!
children.prevalue: And after all what did he do Failed

children.name: Paragraph_277
children.value: He failed, I admit but always through his own fault and, for the sake of purchasingnot his lifefor the life of the king's brother is sacred and inviolablebut his liberty, he sacrificed the lives of all his friends, one after another. And so, at this day, he is a very blot on history, the detestation of a hundred noble families in this kingdom.
children.prevalue: He failed I admit but always through his own fault and for the sake of purchasingnot his lifefor the life of the king s brother is sacred and inviolablebut his liberty he sacrificed the lives of all his friends one after another And so at this day he is a very blot on history the detestation of a hundred noble families in this kingdom

children.name: Paragraph_278
children.value: I understand, monsieur either by weakness or treachery, my uncle slew his friends.
children.prevalue: I understand monsieur either by weakness or treachery my uncle slew his friends

children.name: Paragraph_279
children.value: By weakness which, in princes, is always treachery.
children.prevalue: By weakness which in princes is always treachery

children.name: Paragraph_280
children.value: And cannot a man fail, then, from incapacity and ignorance? Do you really believe it possible that a poor captive such as I, brought up, not only at a distance from the court, but even from the worlddo you believe it possible that such a one could assist those of his friends who should attempt to serve him? And as Aramis was about to reply, the young man suddenly cried out, with a violence which betrayed the temper of his blood, We are speaking of friends but how can I have any friendsI, whom no one knows and have neither liberty, money, nor influence, to gain any?
children.prevalue: And cannot a man fail then from incapacity and ignorance Do you really believe it possible that a poor captive such as I brought up not only at a distance from the court but even from the worlddo you believe it possible that such a one could assist those of his friends who should attempt to serve him And as Aramis was about to reply the young man suddenly cried out with a violence which betrayed the temper of his blood We are speaking of friends but how can I have any friendsI whom no one knows and have neither liberty money nor influence to gain any

children.name: Paragraph_281
children.value: I fancy I had the honor to offer myself to your royal highness.
children.prevalue: I fancy I had the honor to offer myself to your royal highness

children.name: Paragraph_282
children.value: Oh, do not style me so, monsieur 'tis either treachery or cruelty. Bid me not think of aught beyond these prisonwalls, which so grimly confine me let me again love, or, at least, submit to my slavery and my obscurity.
children.prevalue: Oh do not style me so monsieur tis either treachery or cruelty Bid me not think of aught beyond these prisonwalls which so grimly confine me let me again love or at least submit to my slavery and my obscurity

children.name: Paragraph_283
children.value: Monseigneur, monseigneur if you again utter these desperate wordsif, after having received proof of your high birth, you still remain poorspirited in body and soul, I will comply with your desire, I will depart, and renounce forever the service of a master, to whom so eagerly I came to devote my assistance and my life!
children.prevalue: Monseigneur monseigneur if you again utter these desperate wordsif after having received proof of your high birth you still remain poorspirited in body and soul I will comply with your desire I will depart and renounce forever the service of a master to whom so eagerly I came to devote my assistance and my life

children.name: Paragraph_284
children.value: Monsieur, cried the prince, would it not have been better for you to have reflected, before telling me all that you have done, that you have broken my heart forever?
children.prevalue: Monsieur cried the prince would it not have been better for you to have reflected before telling me all that you have done that you have broken my heart forever

children.name: Paragraph_285
children.value: And so I desire to do, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: And so I desire to do monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_286
children.value: To talk to me about power, grandeur, eye, and to prate of thrones! Is a prison the fit place? You wish to make me believe in splendor, and we are lying lost in night you boast of glory, and we are smothering our words in the curtains of this miserable bed you give me glimpses of power absolute whilst I hear the footsteps of the everywatchful jailer in the corridorthat step which, after all, makes you tremble more than it does me. To render me somewhat less incredulous, free me from the Bastile let me breathe the fresh air give me my spurs and trusty sword, then we shall begin to understand each other.
children.prevalue: To talk to me about power grandeur eye and to prate of thrones Is a prison the fit place You wish to make me believe in splendor and we are lying lost in night you boast of glory and we are smothering our words in the curtains of this miserable bed you give me glimpses of power absolute whilst I hear the footsteps of the everywatchful jailer in the corridorthat step which after all makes you tremble more than it does me To render me somewhat less incredulous free me from the Bastile let me breathe the fresh air give me my spurs and trusty sword then we shall begin to understand each other

children.name: Paragraph_287
children.value: It is precisely my intention to give you all this, monseigneur, and more only, do you desire it?
children.prevalue: It is precisely my intention to give you all this monseigneur and more only do you desire it

children.name: Paragraph_288
children.value: A word more, said the prince. I know there are guards in every gallery, bolts to every door, cannon and soldiery at every barrier. How will you overcome the sentriesspike the guns? How will you break through the bolts and bars?
children.prevalue: A word more said the prince I know there are guards in every gallery bolts to every door cannon and soldiery at every barrier How will you overcome the sentriesspike the guns How will you break through the bolts and bars

children.name: Paragraph_289
children.value: Monseigneur,how did you get the note which announced my arrival to you?
children.prevalue: Monseigneur how did you get the note which announced my arrival to you

children.name: Paragraph_290
children.value: You can bribe a jailer for such a thing as a note.
children.prevalue: You can bribe a jailer for such a thing as a note

children.name: Paragraph_291
children.value: If we can corrupt one turnkey, we can corrupt ten.
children.prevalue: If we can corrupt one turnkey we can corrupt ten

children.name: Paragraph_292
children.value: Well I admit that it may be possible to release a poor captive from the Bastile possible so to conceal him that the king's people shall not again ensnare him possible, in some unknown retreat, to sustain the unhappy wretch in some suitable manner.
children.prevalue: Well I admit that it may be possible to release a poor captive from the Bastile possible so to conceal him that the king s people shall not again ensnare him possible in some unknown retreat to sustain the unhappy wretch in some suitable manner

children.name: Paragraph_293
children.value: Monseigneur! said Aramis, smiling.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur said Aramis smiling

children.name: Paragraph_294
children.value: I admit that, whoever would do this much for me, would seem more than mortal in my eyes but as you tell me I am a prince, brother of the king, how can you restore me the rank and power which my mother and my brother have deprived me of? And as, to effect this, I must pass a life of war and hatred, how can you cause me to prevail in those combatsrender me invulnerable by my enemies? Ah! monsieur, reflect on all this place me, tomorrow, in some dark cavern at a mountain's base yield me the delight of hearing in freedom sounds of the river, plain and valley, of beholding in freedom the sun of the blue heavens, or the stormy sky, and it is enough. Promise me no more than this, for, indeed, more you cannot give, and it would be a crime to deceive me, since you call yourself my friend.
children.prevalue: I admit that whoever would do this much for me would seem more than mortal in my eyes but as you tell me I am a prince brother of the king how can you restore me the rank and power which my mother and my brother have deprived me of And as to effect this I must pass a life of war and hatred how can you cause me to prevail in those combatsrender me invulnerable by my enemies Ah monsieur reflect on all this place me tomorrow in some dark cavern at a mountain s base yield me the delight of hearing in freedom sounds of the river plain and valley of beholding in freedom the sun of the blue heavens or the stormy sky and it is enough Promise me no more than this for indeed more you cannot give and it would be a crime to deceive me since you call yourself my friend

children.name: Paragraph_295
children.value: Aramis waited in silence. Monseigneur, he resumed, after a moment's reflection, I admire the firm, sound sense which dictates your words I am happy to have discovered my monarch's mind.
children.prevalue: Aramis waited in silence Monseigneur he resumed after a moment s reflection I admire the firm sound sense which dictates your words I am happy to have discovered my monarch s mind

children.name: Paragraph_296
children.value: Again, again! oh, God! for mercy's sake, cried the prince, pressing his icy hands upon his clammy brow, do not play with me! I have no need to be a king to be the happiest of men.
children.prevalue: Again again oh God for mercy s sake cried the prince pressing his icy hands upon his clammy brow do not play with me I have no need to be a king to be the happiest of men

children.name: Paragraph_297
children.value: But I, monseigneur, wish you to be a king for the good of humanity.
children.prevalue: But I monseigneur wish you to be a king for the good of humanity

children.name: Paragraph_298
children.value: Ah! said the prince, with fresh distrust inspired by the word ah! with what, then, has humanity to reproach my brother?
children.prevalue: Ah said the prince with fresh distrust inspired by the word ah with what then has humanity to reproach my brother

children.name: Paragraph_299
children.value: I forgot to say, monseigneur, that if you would allow me to guide you, and if you consent to become the most powerful monarch in Christendom, you will have promoted the interests of all the friends whom I devote to the success of your cause, and these friends are numerous.
children.prevalue: I forgot to say monseigneur that if you would allow me to guide you and if you consent to become the most powerful monarch in Christendom you will have promoted the interests of all the friends whom I devote to the success of your cause and these friends are numerous

children.name: Paragraph_300
children.value: Numerous?
children.prevalue: Numerous

children.name: Paragraph_301
children.value: Less numerous than powerful, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Less numerous than powerful monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_302
children.value: Explain yourself.
children.prevalue: Explain yourself

children.name: Paragraph_303
children.value: It is impossible I will explain, I swear before Heaven, on that day that I see you sitting on the throne of France.
children.prevalue: It is impossible I will explain I swear before Heaven on that day that I see you sitting on the throne of France

children.name: Paragraph_304
children.value: But my brother?
children.prevalue: But my brother

children.name: Paragraph_305
children.value: You shall decree his fate. Do you pity him?
children.prevalue: You shall decree his fate Do you pity him

children.name: Paragraph_306
children.value: Him, who leaves me to perish in a dungeon? No, no. For him I have no pity!
children.prevalue: Him who leaves me to perish in a dungeon No no For him I have no pity

children.name: Paragraph_307
children.value: So much the better.
children.prevalue: So much the better

children.name: Paragraph_308
children.value: He might have himself come to this prison, have taken me by the hand, and have said, 'My brother, Heaven created us to love, not to contend with one another. I come to you. A barbarous prejudice has condemned you to pass your days in obscurity, far from mankind, deprived of every joy. I will make you sit down beside me I will buckle round your waist our father's sword. Will you take advantage of this reconciliation to put down or restrain me? Will you employ that sword to spill my blood?' 'Oh! never,' I would have replied to him, 'I look on you as my preserver, I will respect you as my master. You give me far more than Heaven bestowed for through you I possess liberty and the privilege of loving and being loved in this world.'
children.prevalue: He might have himself come to this prison have taken me by the hand and have said My brother Heaven created us to love not to contend with one another I come to you A barbarous prejudice has condemned you to pass your days in obscurity far from mankind deprived of every joy I will make you sit down beside me I will buckle round your waist our father s sword Will you take advantage of this reconciliation to put down or restrain me Will you employ that sword to spill my blood Oh never I would have replied to him I look on you as my preserver I will respect you as my master You give me far more than Heaven bestowed for through you I possess liberty and the privilege of loving and being loved in this world

children.name: Paragraph_309
children.value: And you would have kept your word, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: And you would have kept your word monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_310
children.value: On my life! While nownow that I have guilty ones to punish
children.prevalue: On my life While nownow that I have guilty ones to punish

children.name: Paragraph_311
children.value: In what manner, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: In what manner monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_312
children.value: What do you say as to the resemblance that Heaven has given me to my brother?
children.prevalue: What do you say as to the resemblance that Heaven has given me to my brother

children.name: Paragraph_313
children.value: I say that there was in that likeness a providential instruction which the king ought to have heeded I say that your mother committed a crime in rendering those different in happiness and fortune whom nature created so startlingly alike, of her own flesh, and I conclude that the object of punishment should be only to restore the equilibrium.
children.prevalue: I say that there was in that likeness a providential instruction which the king ought to have heeded I say that your mother committed a crime in rendering those different in happiness and fortune whom nature created so startlingly alike of her own flesh and I conclude that the object of punishment should be only to restore the equilibrium

children.name: Paragraph_314
children.value: By which you mean
children.prevalue: By which you mean

children.name: Paragraph_315
children.value: That if I restore you to your place on your brother's throne, he shall take yours in prison.
children.prevalue: That if I restore you to your place on your brother s throne he shall take yours in prison

children.name: Paragraph_316
children.value: Alas! there's such infinity of suffering in prison, especially it would be so for one who has drunk so deeply of the cup of enjoyment.
children.prevalue: Alas there s such infinity of suffering in prison especially it would be so for one who has drunk so deeply of the cup of enjoyment

children.name: Paragraph_317
children.value: Your royal highness will always be free to act as you may desire and if it seems good to you, after punishment, you will have it in your power to pardon.
children.prevalue: Your royal highness will always be free to act as you may desire and if it seems good to you after punishment you will have it in your power to pardon

children.name: Paragraph_318
children.value: Good. And now, are you aware of one thing, monsieur?
children.prevalue: Good And now are you aware of one thing monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_319
children.value: Tell me, my prince.
children.prevalue: Tell me my prince

children.name: Paragraph_320
children.value: It is that I will hear nothing further from you till I am clear of the Bastile.
children.prevalue: It is that I will hear nothing further from you till I am clear of the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_321
children.value: I was going to say to your highness that I should only have the pleasure of seeing you once again.
children.prevalue: I was going to say to your highness that I should only have the pleasure of seeing you once again

children.name: Paragraph_322
children.value: And when?
children.prevalue: And when

children.name: Paragraph_323
children.value: The day when my prince leaves these gloomy walls.
children.prevalue: The day when my prince leaves these gloomy walls

children.name: Paragraph_324
children.value: Heavens! how will you give me notice of it?
children.prevalue: Heavens how will you give me notice of it

children.name: Paragraph_325
children.value: By myself coming to fetch you.
children.prevalue: By myself coming to fetch you

children.name: Paragraph_326
children.value: Yourself?
children.prevalue: Yourself

children.name: Paragraph_327
children.value: My prince, do not leave this chamber save with me, or if in my absence you are compelled to do so, remember that I am not concerned in it.
children.prevalue: My prince do not leave this chamber save with me or if in my absence you are compelled to do so remember that I am not concerned in it

children.name: Paragraph_328
children.value: And so I am not to speak a word of this to any one whatever, save to you?
children.prevalue: And so I am not to speak a word of this to any one whatever save to you

children.name: Paragraph_329
children.value: Save only to me. Aramis bowed very low. The prince offered his hand.
children.prevalue: Save only to me Aramis bowed very low The prince offered his hand

children.name: Paragraph_330
children.value: Monsieur, he said, in a tone that issued from his heart, one word more, my last. If you have sought me for my destruction if you are only a tool in the hands of my enemies if from our conference, in which you have sounded the depths of my mind, anything worse than captivity result, that is to say, if death befall me, still receive my blessing, for you will have ended my troubles and given me repose from the tormenting fever that has preyed on me for eight long, weary years.
children.prevalue: Monsieur he said in a tone that issued from his heart one word more my last If you have sought me for my destruction if you are only a tool in the hands of my enemies if from our conference in which you have sounded the depths of my mind anything worse than captivity result that is to say if death befall me still receive my blessing for you will have ended my troubles and given me repose from the tormenting fever that has preyed on me for eight long weary years

children.name: Paragraph_331
children.value: Monseigneur, wait the results ere you judge me, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur wait the results ere you judge me said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_332
children.value: I say that, in such a case, I bless and forgive you. If, on the other hand, you are come to restore me to that position in the sunshine of fortune and glory to which I was destined by Heaven if by your means I am enabled to live in the memory of man, and confer luster on my race by deeds of valor, or by solid benefits bestowed upon my people if, from my present depths of sorrow, aided by your generous hand, I raise myself to the very height of honor, then to you, whom I thank with blessings, to you will I offer half my power and my glory: though you would still be but partly recompensed, and your share must always remain incomplete, since I could not divide with you the happiness received at your hands.
children.prevalue: I say that in such a case I bless and forgive you If on the other hand you are come to restore me to that position in the sunshine of fortune and glory to which I was destined by Heaven if by your means I am enabled to live in the memory of man and confer luster on my race by deeds of valor or by solid benefits bestowed upon my people if from my present depths of sorrow aided by your generous hand I raise myself to the very height of honor then to you whom I thank with blessings to you will I offer half my power and my glory though you would still be but partly recompensed and your share must always remain incomplete since I could not divide with you the happiness received at your hands

children.name: Paragraph_333
children.value: Monseigneur, replied Aramis, moved by the pallor and excitement of the young man, the nobleness of your heart fills me with joy and admiration. It is not you who will have to thank me, but rather the nation whom you will render happy, the posterity whose name you will make glorious. Yes I shall indeed have bestowed upon you more than life, I shall have given you immortality.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur replied Aramis moved by the pallor and excitement of the young man the nobleness of your heart fills me with joy and admiration It is not you who will have to thank me but rather the nation whom you will render happy the posterity whose name you will make glorious Yes I shall indeed have bestowed upon you more than life I shall have given you immortality

children.name: Paragraph_334
children.value: The prince offered his hand to Aramis, who sank upon his knee and kissed it.
children.prevalue: The prince offered his hand to Aramis who sank upon his knee and kissed it

children.name: Paragraph_335
children.value: It is the first act of homage paid to our future king, said he. When I see you again, I shall say, 'Good day, sire.'
children.prevalue: It is the first act of homage paid to our future king said he When I see you again I shall say Good day sire

children.name: Paragraph_336
children.value: Till then, said the young man, pressing his wan and wasted fingers over his heart,till then, no more dreams, no more strain on my lifemy heart would break! Oh, monsieur, how small is my prisonhow low the windowhow narrow are the doors! To think that so much pride, splendor, and happiness, should be able to enter in and to remain here!
children.prevalue: Till then said the young man pressing his wan and wasted fingers over his heart till then no more dreams no more strain on my lifemy heart would break Oh monsieur how small is my prisonhow low the windowhow narrow are the doors To think that so much pride splendor and happiness should be able to enter in and to remain here

children.name: Paragraph_337
children.value: Your royal highness makes me proud, said Aramis, since you infer it is I who brought all this. And he rapped immediately on the door. The jailer came to open it with Baisemeaux, who, devoured by fear and uneasiness, was beginning, in spite of himself, to listen at the door. Happily, neither of the speakers had forgotten to smother his voice, even in the most passionate outbreaks.
children.prevalue: Your royal highness makes me proud said Aramis since you infer it is I who brought all this And he rapped immediately on the door The jailer came to open it with Baisemeaux who devoured by fear and uneasiness was beginning in spite of himself to listen at the door Happily neither of the speakers had forgotten to smother his voice even in the most passionate outbreaks

children.name: Paragraph_338
children.value: What a confessor! said the governor, forcing a laugh who would believe that a compulsory recluse, a man as though in the very jaws of death, could have committed crimes so numerous, and so long to tell of?
children.prevalue: What a confessor said the governor forcing a laugh who would believe that a compulsory recluse a man as though in the very jaws of death could have committed crimes so numerous and so long to tell of

children.name: Paragraph_339
children.value: Aramis made no reply. He was eager to leave the Bastile, where the secret which overwhelmed him seemed to double the weight of the walls. As soon as they reached Baisemeaux's quarters, Let us proceed to business, my dear governor, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Aramis made no reply He was eager to leave the Bastile where the secret which overwhelmed him seemed to double the weight of the walls As soon as they reached Baisemeaux s quarters Let us proceed to business my dear governor said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_340
children.value: Alas! replied Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: Alas replied Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_341
children.value: You have to ask me for my receipt for one hundred and fifty thousand livres, said the bishop.
children.prevalue: You have to ask me for my receipt for one hundred and fifty thousand livres said the bishop

children.name: Paragraph_342
children.value: And to pay over the first third of the sum, added the poor governor, with a sigh, taking three steps towards his iron strongbox.
children.prevalue: And to pay over the first third of the sum added the poor governor with a sigh taking three steps towards his iron strongbox

children.name: Paragraph_343
children.value: Here is the receipt, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Here is the receipt said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_344
children.value: And here is the money, returned Baisemeaux, with a threefold sigh.
children.prevalue: And here is the money returned Baisemeaux with a threefold sigh

children.name: Paragraph_345
children.value: The order instructed me only to give a receipt it said nothing about receiving the money, rejoined Aramis. Adieu, monsieur le governeur!
children.prevalue: The order instructed me only to give a receipt it said nothing about receiving the money rejoined Aramis Adieu monsieur le governeur

children.name: Paragraph_346
children.value: And he departed, leaving Baisemeaux almost more than stifled with joy and surprise at this regal present so liberally bestowed by the confessor extraordinary to the Bastile.
children.prevalue: And he departed leaving Baisemeaux almost more than stifled with joy and surprise at this regal present so liberally bestowed by the confessor extraordinary to the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Since the departure of Athos for Blois, Porthos and D'Artagnan were seldom together. One was occupied with harassing duties for the king, the other had been making many purchases of furniture which he intended to forward to his estate, and by aid of which he hoped to establish in his various residences something of the courtly luxury he had witnessed in all its dazzling brightness in his majesty's society. D'Artagnan, ever faithful, one morning during an interval of service thought about Porthos, and being uneasy at not having heard anything of him for a fortnight, directed his steps towards his hotel, and pounced upon him just as he was getting up. The worthy baron had a pensivenay, more than pensivemelancholy air. He was sitting on his bed, only halfdressed, and with legs dangling over the edge, contemplating a host of garments, which with their fringes, lace, embroidery, and slashes of illassorted hues, were strewed all over the floor. Porthos, sad and reflective as La Fontaine's hare, did not observe D'Artagnan's entrance, which was, moreover, screened at this moment by M. Mouston, whose personal corpulency, quite enough at any time to hide one man from another, was effectually doubled by a scarlet coat which the intendant was holding up for his master's inspection, by the sleeves, that he might the better see it all over. D'Artagnan stopped at the threshold and looked in at the pensive Porthos and then, as the sight of the innumerable garments strewing the floor caused mighty sighs to heave the bosom of that excellent gentleman, D'Artagnan thought it time to put an end to these dismal reflections, and coughed by way of announcing himself.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Ah! exclaimed Porthos, whose countenance brightened with joy ah! ah! Here is D'Artagnan. I shall then get hold of an idea!
children.prevalue: Ah exclaimed Porthos whose countenance brightened with joy ah ah Here is D Artagnan I shall then get hold of an idea

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: At these words Mouston, doubting what was going on behind him, got out of the way, smiling kindly at the friend of his master, who thus found himself freed from the material obstacle which had prevented his reaching D'Artagnan. Porthos made his sturdy knees crack again in rising, and crossing the room in two strides, found himself face to face with his friend, whom he folded to his breast with a force of affection that seemed to increase with every day. Ah! he repeated, you are always welcome, dear friend but just now you are more welcome than ever.
children.prevalue: At these words Mouston doubting what was going on behind him got out of the way smiling kindly at the friend of his master who thus found himself freed from the material obstacle which had prevented his reaching D Artagnan Porthos made his sturdy knees crack again in rising and crossing the room in two strides found himself face to face with his friend whom he folded to his breast with a force of affection that seemed to increase with every day Ah he repeated you are always welcome dear friend but just now you are more welcome than ever

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: But you seem to have the megrims here! exclaimed D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: But you seem to have the megrims here exclaimed D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Porthos replied by a look expressive of dejection. Well, then, tell me all about it, Porthos, my friend, unless it is a secret.
children.prevalue: Porthos replied by a look expressive of dejection Well then tell me all about it Porthos my friend unless it is a secret

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: In the first place, returned Porthos, you know I have no secrets from you. This, then, is what saddens me.
children.prevalue: In the first place returned Porthos you know I have no secrets from you This then is what saddens me

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Wait a minute, Porthos let me first get rid of all this litter of satin and velvet!
children.prevalue: Wait a minute Porthos let me first get rid of all this litter of satin and velvet

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Oh, never mind, said Porthos, contemptuously it is all trash.
children.prevalue: Oh never mind said Porthos contemptuously it is all trash

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Trash, Porthos! Cloth at twentyfive livres an ell! gorgeous satin! regal velvet!
children.prevalue: Trash Porthos Cloth at twentyfive livres an ell gorgeous satin regal velvet

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Then you think these clothes are
children.prevalue: Then you think these clothes are

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Splendid, Porthos, splendid! I'll wager that you alone in France have so many and suppose you never had any more made, and were to live to be a hundred years of age, which wouldn't astonish me in the very least, you could still wear a new dress the day of your death, without being obliged to see the nose of a single tailor from now till then.
children.prevalue: Splendid Porthos splendid I ll wager that you alone in France have so many and suppose you never had any more made and were to live to be a hundred years of age which wouldn t astonish me in the very least you could still wear a new dress the day of your death without being obliged to see the nose of a single tailor from now till then

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Porthos shook his head.
children.prevalue: Porthos shook his head

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Come, my friend, said D'Artagnan, this unnatural melancholy in you frightens me. My dear Porthos, pray get it out, then. And the sooner the better.
children.prevalue: Come my friend said D Artagnan this unnatural melancholy in you frightens me My dear Porthos pray get it out then And the sooner the better

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Yes, my friend, so I will: if, indeed, it is possible.
children.prevalue: Yes my friend so I will if indeed it is possible

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Perhaps you have received bad news from Bracieux?
children.prevalue: Perhaps you have received bad news from Bracieux

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: No: they have felled the wood, and it has yielded a third more than the estimate.
children.prevalue: No they have felled the wood and it has yielded a third more than the estimate

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Then there has been a fallingoff in the pools of Pierrefonds?
children.prevalue: Then there has been a fallingoff in the pools of Pierrefonds

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: No, my friend: they have been fished, and there is enough left to stock all the pools in the neighborhood.
children.prevalue: No my friend they have been fished and there is enough left to stock all the pools in the neighborhood

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Perhaps your estate at Vallon has been destroyed by an earthquake?
children.prevalue: Perhaps your estate at Vallon has been destroyed by an earthquake

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: No, my friend on the contrary, the ground was struck with lightning a hundred paces from the chateau, and a fountain sprung up in a place entirely destitute of water.
children.prevalue: No my friend on the contrary the ground was struck with lightning a hundred paces from the chateau and a fountain sprung up in a place entirely destitute of water

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: What in the world is the matter, then?
children.prevalue: What in the world is the matter then

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The fact is, I have received an invitation for the fete at Vaux, said Porthos, with a lugubrious expression.
children.prevalue: The fact is I have received an invitation for the fete at Vaux said Porthos with a lugubrious expression

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Well! do you complain of that? The king has caused a hundred mortal heartburnings among the courtiers by refusing invitations. And so, my dear friend, you are really going to Vaux?
children.prevalue: Well do you complain of that The king has caused a hundred mortal heartburnings among the courtiers by refusing invitations And so my dear friend you are really going to Vaux

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Indeed I am!
children.prevalue: Indeed I am

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: You will see a magnificent sight.
children.prevalue: You will see a magnificent sight

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Alas! I doubt it, though.
children.prevalue: Alas I doubt it though

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Everything that is grand in France will be brought together there!
children.prevalue: Everything that is grand in France will be brought together there

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Ah! cried Porthos, tearing out a lock of hair in his despair.
children.prevalue: Ah cried Porthos tearing out a lock of hair in his despair

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Eh! good heavens, are you ill? cried D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Eh good heavens are you ill cried D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I am as firm as the PontNeuf! It isn't that.
children.prevalue: I am as firm as the PontNeuf It isn t that

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: But what is it, then?
children.prevalue: But what is it then

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: 'Tis that I have no clothes!
children.prevalue: Tis that I have no clothes

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: D'Artagnan stood petrified. No clothes! Porthos, no clothes! he cried, when I see at least fifty suits on the floor.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan stood petrified No clothes Porthos no clothes he cried when I see at least fifty suits on the floor

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Fifty, truly but not one which fits me!
children.prevalue: Fifty truly but not one which fits me

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: What? not one that fits you? But are you not measured, then, when you give an order?
children.prevalue: What not one that fits you But are you not measured then when you give an order

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: To be sure he is, answered Mouston but unfortunately I have gotten stouter!
children.prevalue: To be sure he is answered Mouston but unfortunately I have gotten stouter

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: What! you stouter!
children.prevalue: What you stouter

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: So much so that I am now bigger than the baron. Would you believe it, monsieur?
children.prevalue: So much so that I am now bigger than the baron Would you believe it monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Parbleu! it seems to me that is quite evident.
children.prevalue: Parbleu it seems to me that is quite evident

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Do you see, stupid? said Porthos, that is quite evident!
children.prevalue: Do you see stupid said Porthos that is quite evident

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Be still, my dear Porthos, resumed D'Artagnan, becoming slightly impatient, I don't understand why your clothes should not fit you, because Mouston has grown stouter.
children.prevalue: Be still my dear Porthos resumed D Artagnan becoming slightly impatient I don t understand why your clothes should not fit you because Mouston has grown stouter

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I am going to explain it, said Porthos. You remember having related to me the story of the Roman general Antony, who had always seven wild boars kept roasting, each cooked up to a different point so that he might be able to have his dinner at any time of the day he chose to ask for it. Well, then, I resolved, as at any time I might be invited to court to spend a week, I resolved to have always seven suits ready for the occasion.
children.prevalue: I am going to explain it said Porthos You remember having related to me the story of the Roman general Antony who had always seven wild boars kept roasting each cooked up to a different point so that he might be able to have his dinner at any time of the day he chose to ask for it Well then I resolved as at any time I might be invited to court to spend a week I resolved to have always seven suits ready for the occasion

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Capitally reasoned, Porthosonly a man must have a fortune like yours to gratify such whims. Without counting the time lost in being measured, the fashions are always changing.
children.prevalue: Capitally reasoned Porthosonly a man must have a fortune like yours to gratify such whims Without counting the time lost in being measured the fashions are always changing

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: That is exactly the point, said Porthos, in regard to which I flattered myself I had hit on a very ingenious device.
children.prevalue: That is exactly the point said Porthos in regard to which I flattered myself I had hit on a very ingenious device

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Tell me what it is for I don't doubt your genius.
children.prevalue: Tell me what it is for I don t doubt your genius

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: You remember what Mouston once was, then?
children.prevalue: You remember what Mouston once was then

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Yes when he used to call himself Mousqueton.
children.prevalue: Yes when he used to call himself Mousqueton

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And you remember, too, the period when he began to grow fatter?
children.prevalue: And you remember too the period when he began to grow fatter

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: No, not exactly. I beg your pardon, my good Mouston.
children.prevalue: No not exactly I beg your pardon my good Mouston

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Oh! you are not in fault, monsieur, said Mouston, graciously. You were in Paris, and as for us, we were at Pierrefonds.
children.prevalue: Oh you are not in fault monsieur said Mouston graciously You were in Paris and as for us we were at Pierrefonds

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Well, well, my dear Porthos there was a time when Mouston began to grow fat. Is that what you wished to say?
children.prevalue: Well well my dear Porthos there was a time when Mouston began to grow fat Is that what you wished to say

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Yes, my friend and I greatly rejoice over the period.
children.prevalue: Yes my friend and I greatly rejoice over the period

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Indeed, I believe you do, exclaimed D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Indeed I believe you do exclaimed D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: You understand, continued Porthos, what a world of trouble it spared for me.
children.prevalue: You understand continued Porthos what a world of trouble it spared for me

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: No, I don'tby any means.
children.prevalue: No I don tby any means

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Look here, my friend. In the first place, as you have said, to be measured is a loss of time, even though it occur only once a fortnight. And then, one may be travelling and then you wish to have seven suits always with you. In short, I have a horror of letting any one take my measure. Confound it! either one is a nobleman or not. To be scrutinized and scanned by a fellow who completely analyzes you, by inch and line'tis degrading! Here, they find you too hollow there, too prominent. They recognize your strong and weak points. See, now, when we leave the measurer's hands, we are like those strongholds whose angles and different thicknesses have been ascertained by a spy.
children.prevalue: Look here my friend In the first place as you have said to be measured is a loss of time even though it occur only once a fortnight And then one may be travelling and then you wish to have seven suits always with you In short I have a horror of letting any one take my measure Confound it either one is a nobleman or not To be scrutinized and scanned by a fellow who completely analyzes you by inch and line tis degrading Here they find you too hollow there too prominent They recognize your strong and weak points See now when we leave the measurer s hands we are like those strongholds whose angles and different thicknesses have been ascertained by a spy

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: In truth, my dear Porthos, you possess ideas entirely original.
children.prevalue: In truth my dear Porthos you possess ideas entirely original

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Ah! you see when a man is an engineer
children.prevalue: Ah you see when a man is an engineer

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: And has fortified BelleIsle'tis natural, my friend.
children.prevalue: And has fortified BelleIsle tis natural my friend

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Well, I had an idea, which would doubtless have proved a good one, but for Mouston's carelessness.
children.prevalue: Well I had an idea which would doubtless have proved a good one but for Mouston s carelessness

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: D'Artagnan glanced at Mouston, who replied by a slight movement of his body, as if to say, You will see whether I am at all to blame in all this.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan glanced at Mouston who replied by a slight movement of his body as if to say You will see whether I am at all to blame in all this

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I congratulated myself, then, resumed Porthos, at seeing Mouston get fat and I did all I could, by means of substantial feeding, to make him stoutalways in the hope that he would come to equal myself in girth, and could then be measured in my stead.
children.prevalue: I congratulated myself then resumed Porthos at seeing Mouston get fat and I did all I could by means of substantial feeding to make him stoutalways in the hope that he would come to equal myself in girth and could then be measured in my stead

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Ah! cried D'Artagnan. I seethat spared you both time and humiliation.
children.prevalue: Ah cried D Artagnan I seethat spared you both time and humiliation

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Consider my joy when, after a year and a half's judicious feedingfor I used to feed him up myselfthe fellow
children.prevalue: Consider my joy when after a year and a half s judicious feedingfor I used to feed him up myselfthe fellow

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Oh! I lent a good hand myself, monsieur, said Mouston, humbly.
children.prevalue: Oh I lent a good hand myself monsieur said Mouston humbly

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: That's true. Consider my joy when, one morning, I perceived Mouston was obliged to squeeze in, as I once did myself, to get through the little secret door that those fools of architects had made in the chamber of the late Madame du Vallon, in the chateau of Pierrefonds. And, by the way, about that door, my friend, I should like to ask you, who know everything, why these wretches of architects, who ought to have the compasses run into them, just to remind them, came to make doorways through which nobody but thin people can pass?
children.prevalue: That s true Consider my joy when one morning I perceived Mouston was obliged to squeeze in as I once did myself to get through the little secret door that those fools of architects had made in the chamber of the late Madame du Vallon in the chateau of Pierrefonds And by the way about that door my friend I should like to ask you who know everything why these wretches of architects who ought to have the compasses run into them just to remind them came to make doorways through which nobody but thin people can pass

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Oh, those doors, answered D'Artagnan, were meant for gallants, and they have generally slight and slender figures.
children.prevalue: Oh those doors answered D Artagnan were meant for gallants and they have generally slight and slender figures

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Madame du Vallon had no gallant! answered Porthos, majestically.
children.prevalue: Madame du Vallon had no gallant answered Porthos majestically

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Perfectly true, my friend, resumed D'Artagnan but the architects were probably making their calculations on a basis of the probability of your marrying again.
children.prevalue: Perfectly true my friend resumed D Artagnan but the architects were probably making their calculations on a basis of the probability of your marrying again

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Ah! that is possible, said Porthos. And now I have received an explanation of how it is that doorways are made too narrow, let us return to the subject of Mouston's fatness. But see how the two things apply to each other. I have always noticed that people's ideas run parallel. And so, observe this phenomenon, D'Artagnan. I was talking to you of Mouston, who is fat, and it led us on to Madame du Vallon
children.prevalue: Ah that is possible said Porthos And now I have received an explanation of how it is that doorways are made too narrow let us return to the subject of Mouston s fatness But see how the two things apply to each other I have always noticed that people s ideas run parallel And so observe this phenomenon D Artagnan I was talking to you of Mouston who is fat and it led us on to Madame du Vallon

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Who was thin?
children.prevalue: Who was thin

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Hum! Is it not marvelous?
children.prevalue: Hum Is it not marvelous

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: My dear friend, a savant of my acquaintance, M. Costar, has made the same observation as you have, and he calls the process by some Greek name which I forget.
children.prevalue: My dear friend a savant of my acquaintance M Costar has made the same observation as you have and he calls the process by some Greek name which I forget

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: What! my remark is not then original? cried Porthos, astounded. I thought I was the discoverer.
children.prevalue: What my remark is not then original cried Porthos astounded I thought I was the discoverer

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: My friend, the fact was known before Aristotle's daysthat is to say, nearly two thousand years ago.
children.prevalue: My friend the fact was known before Aristotle s daysthat is to say nearly two thousand years ago

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Well, well, 'tis no less true, said Porthos, delighted at the idea of having jumped to a conclusion so closely in agreement with the greatest sages of antiquity.
children.prevalue: Well well tis no less true said Porthos delighted at the idea of having jumped to a conclusion so closely in agreement with the greatest sages of antiquity

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Wonderfullybut suppose we return to Mouston. It seems to me, we have left him fattening under our very eyes.
children.prevalue: Wonderfullybut suppose we return to Mouston It seems to me we have left him fattening under our very eyes

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Yes, monsieur, said Mouston.
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur said Mouston

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Well, said Porthos, Mouston fattened so well, that he gratified all my hopes, by reaching my standard a fact of which I was well able to convince myself, by seeing the rascal, one day, in a waistcoat of mine, which he had turned into a coata waistcoat, the mere embroidery of which was worth a hundred pistoles.
children.prevalue: Well said Porthos Mouston fattened so well that he gratified all my hopes by reaching my standard a fact of which I was well able to convince myself by seeing the rascal one day in a waistcoat of mine which he had turned into a coata waistcoat the mere embroidery of which was worth a hundred pistoles

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: 'Twas only to try it on, monsieur, said Mouston.
children.prevalue: Twas only to try it on monsieur said Mouston

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: From that moment I determined to put Mouston in communication with my tailors, and to have him measured instead of myself.
children.prevalue: From that moment I determined to put Mouston in communication with my tailors and to have him measured instead of myself

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: A capital idea, Porthos but Mouston is a foot and a half shorter than you.
children.prevalue: A capital idea Porthos but Mouston is a foot and a half shorter than you

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Exactly! They measured him down to the ground, and the end of the skirt came just below my knee.
children.prevalue: Exactly They measured him down to the ground and the end of the skirt came just below my knee

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: What a marvelous man you are, Porthos! Such a thing could happen only to you.
children.prevalue: What a marvelous man you are Porthos Such a thing could happen only to you

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Ah! yes pay your compliments you have ample grounds to go upon. It was exactly at that timethat is to say, nearly two years and a half agothat I set out for BelleIsle, instructing Mouston (so as always to have, in every event, a pattern of every fashion) to have a coat made for himself every month.
