children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: And did Mouston neglect complying with your instructions? Ah! that was anything but right, Mouston.
children.prevalue: And did Mouston neglect complying with your instructions Ah that was anything but right Mouston

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: No, monsieur, quite the contrary quite the contrary!
children.prevalue: No monsieur quite the contrary quite the contrary

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: No, he never forgot to have his coats made but he forgot to inform me that he had got stouter!
children.prevalue: No he never forgot to have his coats made but he forgot to inform me that he had got stouter

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: But it was not my fault, monsieur! your tailor never told me.
children.prevalue: But it was not my fault monsieur your tailor never told me

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: And this to such an extent, monsieur, continued Porthos, that the fellow in two years has gained eighteen inches in girth, and so my last dozen coats are all too large, from a foot to a foot and a half.
children.prevalue: And this to such an extent monsieur continued Porthos that the fellow in two years has gained eighteen inches in girth and so my last dozen coats are all too large from a foot to a foot and a half

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: But the rest those which were made when you were of the same size?
children.prevalue: But the rest those which were made when you were of the same size

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: They are no longer the fashion, my dear friend. Were I to put them on, I should look like a fresh arrival from Siam and as though I had been two years away from court.
children.prevalue: They are no longer the fashion my dear friend Were I to put them on I should look like a fresh arrival from Siam and as though I had been two years away from court

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: I understand your difficulty. You have how many new suits? nine? thirtysix? and yet not one to wear. Well, you must have a thirtyseventh made, and give the thirtysix to Mouston.
children.prevalue: I understand your difficulty You have how many new suits nine thirtysix and yet not one to wear Well you must have a thirtyseventh made and give the thirtysix to Mouston

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Ah! monsieur! said Mouston, with a gratified air. The truth is, that monsieur has always been very generous to me.
children.prevalue: Ah monsieur said Mouston with a gratified air The truth is that monsieur has always been very generous to me

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Do you mean to insinuate that I hadn't that idea, or that I was deterred by the expense? But it wants only two days to the fete I received the invitation yesterday made Mouston post hither with my wardrobe, and only this morning discovered my misfortune and from now till the day after tomorrow, there isn't a single fashionable tailor who will undertake to make me a suit.
children.prevalue: Do you mean to insinuate that I hadn t that idea or that I was deterred by the expense But it wants only two days to the fete I received the invitation yesterday made Mouston post hither with my wardrobe and only this morning discovered my misfortune and from now till the day after tomorrow there isn t a single fashionable tailor who will undertake to make me a suit

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: That is to say, one covered all over with gold, isn't it?
children.prevalue: That is to say one covered all over with gold isn t it

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: I wish it so! undoubtedly, all over.
children.prevalue: I wish it so undoubtedly all over

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Oh, we shall manage it. You won't leave for three days. The invitations are for Wednesday, and this is only Sunday morning.
children.prevalue: Oh we shall manage it You won t leave for three days The invitations are for Wednesday and this is only Sunday morning

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: 'Tis true but Aramis has strongly advised me to be at Vaux twentyfour hours beforehand.
children.prevalue: Tis true but Aramis has strongly advised me to be at Vaux twentyfour hours beforehand

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: How, Aramis?
children.prevalue: How Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Yes, it was Aramis who brought me the invitation.
children.prevalue: Yes it was Aramis who brought me the invitation

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Ah! to be sure, I see. You are invited on the part of M. Fouquet?
children.prevalue: Ah to be sure I see You are invited on the part of M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: By no means! by the king, dear friend. The letter bears the following as large as life: 'M. le Baron du Vallon is informed that the king has condescended to place him on the invitation list'
children.prevalue: By no means by the king dear friend The letter bears the following as large as life M le Baron du Vallon is informed that the king has condescended to place him on the invitation list

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Very good but you leave with M. Fouquet?
children.prevalue: Very good but you leave with M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: And when I think, cried Porthos, stamping on the floor, when I think I shall have no clothes, I am ready to burst with rage! I should like to strangle somebody or smash something!
children.prevalue: And when I think cried Porthos stamping on the floor when I think I shall have no clothes I am ready to burst with rage I should like to strangle somebody or smash something

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Neither strangle anybody nor smash anything, Porthos I will manage it all put on one of your thirtysix suits, and come with me to a tailor.
children.prevalue: Neither strangle anybody nor smash anything Porthos I will manage it all put on one of your thirtysix suits and come with me to a tailor

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Pooh! my agent has seen them all this morning.
children.prevalue: Pooh my agent has seen them all this morning

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Even M. Percerin?
children.prevalue: Even M Percerin

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Who is M. Percerin?
children.prevalue: Who is M Percerin

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Oh! only the king's tailor!
children.prevalue: Oh only the king s tailor

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Oh, ah, yes, said Porthos, who wished to appear to know the king's tailor, but now heard his name mentioned for the first time to M. Percerin's, by Jove! I was afraid he would be too busy.
children.prevalue: Oh ah yes said Porthos who wished to appear to know the king s tailor but now heard his name mentioned for the first time to M Percerin s by Jove I was afraid he would be too busy

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Doubtless he will be but be at ease, Porthos he will do for me what he wouldn't do for another. Only you must allow yourself to be measured!
children.prevalue: Doubtless he will be but be at ease Porthos he will do for me what he wouldn t do for another Only you must allow yourself to be measured

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Ah! said Porthos, with a sigh, 'tis vexatious, but what would you have me do?
children.prevalue: Ah said Porthos with a sigh tis vexatious but what would you have me do

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Do? As others do as the king does.
children.prevalue: Do As others do as the king does

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: What! do they measure the king, too? does he put up with it?
children.prevalue: What do they measure the king too does he put up with it

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: The king is a beau, my good friend, and so are you, too, whatever you may say about it.
children.prevalue: The king is a beau my good friend and so are you too whatever you may say about it

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Porthos smiled triumphantly. Let us go to the king's tailor, he said and since he measures the king, I think, by my faith, I may do worse than allow him to measure me!
children.prevalue: Porthos smiled triumphantly Let us go to the king s tailor he said and since he measures the king I think by my faith I may do worse than allow him to measure me

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The king's tailor, Messire Jean Percerin, occupied a rather large house in the Rue St. Honore, near the Rue de l'Arbre Sec. He was a man of great taste in elegant stuffs, embroideries, and velvets, being hereditary tailor to the king. The preferment of his house reached as far back as the time of Charles IX. from whose reign dated, as we know, fancy in bravery difficult enough to gratify. The Percerin of that period was a Huguenot, like Ambrose Pare, and had been spared by the Queen of Navarre, the beautiful Margot, as they used to write and say, too, in those days because, in sooth, he was the only one who could make for her those wonderful ridinghabits which she so loved to wear, seeing that they were marvelously well suited to hide certain anatomical defects, which the Queen of Navarre used very studiously to conceal. Percerin being saved, made, out of gratitude, some beautiful black bodices, very inexpensively indeed, for Queen Catherine, who ended by being pleased at the preservation of a Huguenot people, on whom she had long looked with detestation. But Percerin was a very prudent man and having heard it said that there was no more dangerous sign for a Protestant than to be smiled up on by Catherine, and having observed that her smiles were more frequent than usual, he speedily turned Catholic with all his family and having thus become irreproachable, attained the lofty position of master tailor to the Crown of France. Under Henry III., gay king as he was, this position was as grand as the height of one of the loftiest peaks of the Cordilleras. Now Percerin had been a clever man all his life, and by way of keeping up his reputation beyond the grave, took very good care not to make a bad death of it, and so contrived to die very skillfully and that at the very moment he felt his powers of invention declining. He left a son and a daughter, both worthy of the name they were called upon to bear the son, a cutter as unerring and exact as the square rule the daughter, apt at embroidery, and at designing ornaments. The marriage of Henry IV. and Marie de Medici, and the exquisite courtmourning for the aforementioned queen, together with a few words let fall by M. de Bassompiere, king of the beaux of the period, made the fortune of the second generation of Percerins. M. Concino Concini, and his wife Galligai, who subsequently shone at the French court, sought to Italianize the fashion, and introduced some Florentine tailors but Percerin, touched to the quick in his patriotism and his selfesteem, entirely defeated these foreigners, and that so well that Concino was the first to give up his compatriots, and held the French tailor in such esteem that he would never employ any other, and thus wore a doublet of his on the very day that Vitry blew out his brains with a pistol at the Pont du Louvre.
children.prevalue: The king s tailor Messire Jean Percerin occupied a rather large house in the Rue St Honore near the Rue de l Arbre Sec He was a man of great taste in elegant stuffs embroideries and velvets being hereditary tailor to the king The preferment of his house reached as far back as the time of Charles IX from whose reign dated as we know fancy in bravery difficult enough to gratify The Percerin of that period was a Huguenot like Ambrose Pare and had been spared by the Queen of Navarre the beautiful Margot as they used to write and say too in those days because in sooth he was the only one who could make for her those wonderful ridinghabits which she so loved to wear seeing that they were marvelously well suited to hide certain anatomical defects which the Queen of Navarre used very studiously to conceal Percerin being saved made out of gratitude some beautiful black bodices very inexpensively indeed for Queen Catherine who ended by being pleased at the preservation of a Huguenot people on whom she had long looked with detestation But Percerin was a very prudent man and having heard it said that there was no more dangerous sign for a Protestant than to be smiled up on by Catherine and having observed that her smiles were more frequent than usual he speedily turned Catholic with all his family and having thus become irreproachable attained the lofty position of master tailor to the Crown of France Under Henry III gay king as he was this position was as grand as the height of one of the loftiest peaks of the Cordilleras Now Percerin had been a clever man all his life and by way of keeping up his reputation beyond the grave took very good care not to make a bad death of it and so contrived to die very skillfully and that at the very moment he felt his powers of invention declining He left a son and a daughter both worthy of the name they were called upon to bear the son a cutter as unerring and exact as the square rule the daughter apt at embroidery and at designing ornaments The marriage of Henry IV and Marie de Medici and the exquisite courtmourning for the aforementioned queen together with a few words let fall by M de Bassompiere king of the beaux of the period made the fortune of the second generation of Percerins M Concino Concini and his wife Galligai who subsequently shone at the French court sought to Italianize the fashion and introduced some Florentine tailors but Percerin touched to the quick in his patriotism and his selfesteem entirely defeated these foreigners and that so well that Concino was the first to give up his compatriots and held the French tailor in such esteem that he would never employ any other and thus wore a doublet of his on the very day that Vitry blew out his brains with a pistol at the Pont du Louvre

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: And so it was a doublet issuing from M. Percerin's workshop, which the Parisians rejoiced in hacking into so many pieces with the living human body it contained. Notwithstanding the favor Concino Concini had shown Percerin, the king, Louis XIII., had the generosity to bear no malice to his tailor, and to retain him in his service. At the time that Louis the Just afforded this great example of equity, Percerin had brought up two sons, one of whom made his debut at the marriage of Anne of Austria, invented that admirable Spanish costume, in which Richelieu danced a saraband, made the costumes for the tragedy of Mirame, and stitched on to Buckingham's mantle those famous pearls which were destined to be scattered about the pavements of the Louvre. A man becomes easily notable who has made the dresses of a Duke of Buckingham, a M. de CinqMars, a Mademoiselle Ninon, a M. de Beaufort, and a Marion de Lorme. And thus Percerin the third had attained the summit of his glory when his father died. This same Percerin III., old, famous and wealthy, yet further dressed Louis XIV. and having no son, which was a great cause of sorrow to him, seeing that with himself his dynasty would end, he had brought up several hopeful pupils. He possessed a carriage, a country house, menservants the tallest in Paris and by special authority from Louis XIV., a pack of hounds. He worked for MM. de Lyonne and Letellier, under a sort of patronage but politic man as he was, and versed in state secrets, he never succeeded in fitting M. Colbert. This is beyond explanation it is a matter for guessing or for intuition. Great geniuses of every kind live on unseen, intangible ideas they act without themselves knowing why. The great Percerin (for, contrary to the rule of dynasties, it was, above all, the last of the Percerins who deserved the name of Great), the great Percerin was inspired when he cut a robe for the queen, or a coat for the king he could mount a mantle for Monsieur, the clock of a stocking for Madame but, in spite of his supreme talent, he could never hit off anything approaching a creditable fit for M. Colbert. That man, he used often to say, is beyond my art my needle can never dot him down. We need scarcely say that Percerin was M. Fouquet's tailor, and that the superintendent highly esteemed him. M. Percerin was nearly eighty years old, nevertheless still fresh, and at the same time so dry, the courtiers used to say, that he was positively brittle. His renown and his fortune were great enough for M. le Prince, that king of fops, to take his arm when talking over the fashions and for those least eager to pay never to dare to leave their accounts in arrear with him for Master Percerin would for the first time make clothes upon credit, but the second never, unless paid for the former order.

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It is easy to see at once that a tailor of such renown, instead of running after customers, made difficulties about obliging any fresh ones. And so Percerin declined to fit bourgeois, or those who had but recently obtained patents of nobility. A story used to circulate that even M. de Mazarin, in exchange for Percerin supplying him with a full suit of ceremonial vestments as cardinal, one fine day slipped letters of nobility into his pocket.
children.prevalue: It is easy to see at once that a tailor of such renown instead of running after customers made difficulties about obliging any fresh ones And so Percerin declined to fit bourgeois or those who had but recently obtained patents of nobility A story used to circulate that even M de Mazarin in exchange for Percerin supplying him with a full suit of ceremonial vestments as cardinal one fine day slipped letters of nobility into his pocket

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: It was to the house of this grand llama of tailors that D'Artagnan took the despairing Porthos who, as they were going along, said to his friend, Take care, my good D'Artagnan, not to compromise the dignity of a man such as I am with the arrogance of this Percerin, who will, I expect, be very impertinent for I give you notice, my friend, that if he is wanting in respect I will infallibly chastise him.
children.prevalue: It was to the house of this grand llama of tailors that D Artagnan took the despairing Porthos who as they were going along said to his friend Take care my good D Artagnan not to compromise the dignity of a man such as I am with the arrogance of this Percerin who will I expect be very impertinent for I give you notice my friend that if he is wanting in respect I will infallibly chastise him

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Presented by me, replied D'Artagnan, you have nothing to fear, even though you were what you are not.
children.prevalue: Presented by me replied D Artagnan you have nothing to fear even though you were what you are not

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Ah! 'tis because
children.prevalue: Ah tis because

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What? Have you anything against Percerin, Porthos?
children.prevalue: What Have you anything against Percerin Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: I think that I once sent Mouston to a fellow of that name.
children.prevalue: I think that I once sent Mouston to a fellow of that name

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: And then?
children.prevalue: And then

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The fellow refused to supply me.
children.prevalue: The fellow refused to supply me

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Oh, a misunderstanding, no doubt, which it will be now exceedingly easy to set right. Mouston must have made a mistake.
children.prevalue: Oh a misunderstanding no doubt which it will be now exceedingly easy to set right Mouston must have made a mistake

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Perhaps.
children.prevalue: Perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: He has confused the names.
children.prevalue: He has confused the names

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Possibly. That rascal Mouston never can remember names.
children.prevalue: Possibly That rascal Mouston never can remember names

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I will take it all upon myself.
children.prevalue: I will take it all upon myself

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Very good.
children.prevalue: Very good

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Stop the carriage, Porthos here we are.
children.prevalue: Stop the carriage Porthos here we are

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Here! how here? We are at the Halles and you told me the house was at the corner of the Rue de l'Arbre Sec.
children.prevalue: Here how here We are at the Halles and you told me the house was at the corner of the Rue de l Arbre Sec

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'Tis true, but look.
children.prevalue: Tis true but look

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Well, I do look, and I see
children.prevalue: Well I do look and I see

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Pardieu! that we are at the Halles!
children.prevalue: Pardieu that we are at the Halles

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: You do not, I suppose, want our horses to clamber up on the roof of the carriage in front of us?
children.prevalue: You do not I suppose want our horses to clamber up on the roof of the carriage in front of us

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Nor the carriage in front of us to mount on top of the one in front of it. Nor that the second should be driven over the roofs of the thirty or forty others which have arrived before us.
children.prevalue: Nor the carriage in front of us to mount on top of the one in front of it Nor that the second should be driven over the roofs of the thirty or forty others which have arrived before us

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: No, you are right, indeed. What a number of people! And what are they all about?
children.prevalue: No you are right indeed What a number of people And what are they all about

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'Tis very simple. They are waiting their turn.
children.prevalue: Tis very simple They are waiting their turn

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Bah! Have the comedians of the Hotel de Bourgogne shifted their quarters?
children.prevalue: Bah Have the comedians of the Hotel de Bourgogne shifted their quarters

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: No their turn to obtain an entrance to M. Percerin's house.
children.prevalue: No their turn to obtain an entrance to M Percerin s house

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: And we are going to wait too?
children.prevalue: And we are going to wait too

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Oh, we shall show ourselves prompter and not so proud.
children.prevalue: Oh we shall show ourselves prompter and not so proud

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: What are we to do, then?
children.prevalue: What are we to do then

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Get down, pass through the footmen and lackeys, and enter the tailor's house, which I will answer for our doing, if you go first.
children.prevalue: Get down pass through the footmen and lackeys and enter the tailor s house which I will answer for our doing if you go first

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Come along, then, said Porthos.
children.prevalue: Come along then said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: They accordingly alighted and made their way on foot towards the establishment. The cause of the confusion was that M. Percerin's doors were closed, while a servant, standing before them, was explaining to the illustrious customers of the illustrious tailor that just then M. Percerin could not receive anybody. It was bruited about outside still, on the authority of what the great lackey had told some great noble whom he favored, in confidence, that M. Percerin was engaged on five costumes for the king, and that, owing to the urgency of the case, he was meditating in his office on the ornaments, colors, and cut of these five suits. Some, contented with this reason, went away again, contented to repeat the tale to others, but others, more tenacious, insisted on having the doors opened, and among these last three Blue Ribbons, intended to take parts in a ballet, which would inevitably fail unless the said three had their costumes shaped by the very hand of the great Percerin himself. D'Artagnan, pushing on Porthos, who scattered the groups of people right and left, succeeded in gaining the counter, behind which the journeyman tailors were doing their best to answer queries. (We forgot to mention that at the door they wanted to put off Porthos like the rest, but D'Artagnan, showing himself, pronounced merely these words, The king's order, and was let in with his friend.) The poor fellows had enough to do, and did their best, to reply to the demands of the customers in the absence of their master, leaving off drawing a stitch to knit a sentence and when wounded pride, or disappointed expectation, brought down upon them too cutting a rebuke, he who was attacked made a dive and disappeared under the counter. The line of discontented lords formed a truly remarkable picture. Our captain of musketeers, a man of sure and rapid observation, took it all in at a glance and having run over the groups, his eye rested on a man in front of him. This man, seated upon a stool, scarcely showed his head above the counter that sheltered him. He was about forty years of age, with a melancholy aspect, pale face, and soft luminous eyes. He was looking at D'Artagnan and the rest, with his chin resting upon his hand, like a calm and inquiring amateur. Only on perceiving, and doubtless recognizing, our captain, he pulled his hat down over his eyes. It was this action, perhaps, that attracted D'Artagnan's attention. If so, the gentleman who had pulled down his hat produced an effect entirely different from what he had desired. In other respects his costume was plain, and his hair evenly cut enough for customers, who were not close observers, to take him for a mere tailor's apprentice, perched behind the board, and carefully stitching cloth or velvet. Nevertheless, this man held up his head too often to be very productively employed with his fingers. D'Artagnan was not deceived,not he and he saw at once that if this man was working at anything, it certainly was not at velvet.

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Eh! said he, addressing this man, and so you have become a tailor's boy, Monsieur Moliere!
children.prevalue: Eh said he addressing this man and so you have become a tailor s boy Monsieur Moliere

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Hush, M. d'Artagnan! replied the man, softly, you will make them recognize me.
children.prevalue: Hush M d Artagnan replied the man softly you will make them recognize me

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Well, and what harm?
children.prevalue: Well and what harm

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The fact is, there is no harm, but
children.prevalue: The fact is there is no harm but

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: You were going to say there is no good in doing it either, is it not so?
children.prevalue: You were going to say there is no good in doing it either is it not so

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Alas! no for I was occupied in examining some excellent figures.
children.prevalue: Alas no for I was occupied in examining some excellent figures

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Go ongo on, Monsieur Moliere. I quite understand the interest you take in the platesI will not disturb your studies.
children.prevalue: Go ongo on Monsieur Moliere I quite understand the interest you take in the platesI will not disturb your studies

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Thank you.
children.prevalue: Thank you

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: But on one condition that you tell me where M. Percerin really is.
children.prevalue: But on one condition that you tell me where M Percerin really is

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Oh! willingly in his own room. Only
children.prevalue: Oh willingly in his own room Only

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Only that one can't enter it?
children.prevalue: Only that one can t enter it

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Unapproachable.
children.prevalue: Unapproachable

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: For everybody?
children.prevalue: For everybody

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Everybody. He brought me here so that I might be at my ease to make my observations, and then he went away.
children.prevalue: Everybody He brought me here so that I might be at my ease to make my observations and then he went away

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Well, my dear Monsieur Moliere, but you will go and tell him I am here.
children.prevalue: Well my dear Monsieur Moliere but you will go and tell him I am here

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: I! exclaimed Moliere, in the tone of a courageous dog, from which you snatch the bone it has legitimately gained I disturb myself! Ah! Monsieur d'Artagnan, how hard you are upon me!
children.prevalue: I exclaimed Moliere in the tone of a courageous dog from which you snatch the bone it has legitimately gained I disturb myself Ah Monsieur d Artagnan how hard you are upon me

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: If you don't go directly and tell M. Percerin that I am here, my dear Moliere, said D'Artagnan, in a low tone, I warn you of one thing: that I won't exhibit to you the friend I have brought with me.
children.prevalue: If you don t go directly and tell M Percerin that I am here my dear Moliere said D Artagnan in a low tone I warn you of one thing that I won t exhibit to you the friend I have brought with me

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Moliere indicated Porthos by an imperceptible gesture, This gentleman, is it not?
children.prevalue: Moliere indicated Porthos by an imperceptible gesture This gentleman is it not

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Moliere fixed upon Porthos one of those looks which penetrate the minds and hearts of men. The subject doubtless appeared a very promising one, for he immediately rose and led the way into the adjoining chamber.
children.prevalue: Moliere fixed upon Porthos one of those looks which penetrate the minds and hearts of men The subject doubtless appeared a very promising one for he immediately rose and led the way into the adjoining chamber

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: During all this time the noble mob was slowly heaving away, leaving at every angle of the counter either a murmur or a menace, as the waves leave foam or scattered seaweed on the sands, when they retire with the ebbing tide. In about ten minutes Moliere reappeared, making another sign to D'Artagnan from under the hangings. The latter hurried after him, with Porthos in the rear, and after threading a labyrinth of corridors, introduced him to M. Percerin's room. The old man, with his sleeves turned up, was gathering up in folds a piece of goldflowered brocade, so as the better to exhibit its luster. Perceiving D'Artagnan, he put the silk aside, and came to meet him, by no means radiant with joy, and by no means courteous, but, take it altogether, in a tolerably civil manner.
children.prevalue: During all this time the noble mob was slowly heaving away leaving at every angle of the counter either a murmur or a menace as the waves leave foam or scattered seaweed on the sands when they retire with the ebbing tide In about ten minutes Moliere reappeared making another sign to D Artagnan from under the hangings The latter hurried after him with Porthos in the rear and after threading a labyrinth of corridors introduced him to M Percerin s room The old man with his sleeves turned up was gathering up in folds a piece of goldflowered brocade so as the better to exhibit its luster Perceiving D Artagnan he put the silk aside and came to meet him by no means radiant with joy and by no means courteous but take it altogether in a tolerably civil manner

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The captain of the king's musketeers will excuse me, I am sure, for I am engaged.
children.prevalue: The captain of the king s musketeers will excuse me I am sure for I am engaged

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Eh! yes, on the king's costumes I know that, my dear Monsieur Percerin. You are making three, they tell me.
children.prevalue: Eh yes on the king s costumes I know that my dear Monsieur Percerin You are making three they tell me

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Five, my dear sir, five.
children.prevalue: Five my dear sir five

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Three or five, 'tis all the same to me, my dear monsieur and I know that you will make them most exquisitely.
children.prevalue: Three or five tis all the same to me my dear monsieur and I know that you will make them most exquisitely

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Yes, I know. Once made they will be the most beautiful in the world, I do not deny it but that they may be the most beautiful in the word, they must first be made and to do this, captain, I am pressed for time.
children.prevalue: Yes I know Once made they will be the most beautiful in the world I do not deny it but that they may be the most beautiful in the word they must first be made and to do this captain I am pressed for time

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Oh, bah! there are two days yet 'tis much more than you require, Monsieur Percerin, said D'Artagnan, in the coolest possible manner.
children.prevalue: Oh bah there are two days yet tis much more than you require Monsieur Percerin said D Artagnan in the coolest possible manner

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Percerin raised his head with the air of a man little accustomed to be contradicted, even in his whims but D'Artagnan did not pay the least attention to the airs which the illustrious tailor began to assume.
children.prevalue: Percerin raised his head with the air of a man little accustomed to be contradicted even in his whims but D Artagnan did not pay the least attention to the airs which the illustrious tailor began to assume

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: My dear M. Percerin, he continued, I bring you a customer.
children.prevalue: My dear M Percerin he continued I bring you a customer

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Ah! ah! exclaimed Percerin, crossly.
children.prevalue: Ah ah exclaimed Percerin crossly

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: M. le Baron du Vallon de Bracieux de Pierrefonds, continued D'Artagnan. Percerin attempted a bow, which found no favor in the eyes of the terrible Porthos, who, from his first entry into the room, had been regarding the tailor askance.
children.prevalue: M le Baron du Vallon de Bracieux de Pierrefonds continued D Artagnan Percerin attempted a bow which found no favor in the eyes of the terrible Porthos who from his first entry into the room had been regarding the tailor askance

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: A very good friend of mine, concluded D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: A very good friend of mine concluded D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I will attend to monsieur, said Percerin, but later.
children.prevalue: I will attend to monsieur said Percerin but later

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Later? but when?
children.prevalue: Later but when

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: When I have time.
children.prevalue: When I have time

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: You have already told my valet as much, broke in Porthos, discontentedly.
children.prevalue: You have already told my valet as much broke in Porthos discontentedly

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Very likely, said Percerin I am nearly always pushed for time.
children.prevalue: Very likely said Percerin I am nearly always pushed for time

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: My friend, returned Porthos, sententiously, there is always time to be found when one chooses to seek it.
children.prevalue: My friend returned Porthos sententiously there is always time to be found when one chooses to seek it

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Percerin turned crimson an ominous sign indeed in old men blanched by age.
children.prevalue: Percerin turned crimson an ominous sign indeed in old men blanched by age

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Monsieur is quite at liberty to confer his custom elsewhere.
children.prevalue: Monsieur is quite at liberty to confer his custom elsewhere

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Come, come, Percerin, interposed D'Artagnan, you are not in a good temper today. Well, I will say one more word to you, which will bring you on your knees monsieur is not only a friend of mine, but more, a friend of M. Fouquet's.
children.prevalue: Come come Percerin interposed D Artagnan you are not in a good temper today Well I will say one more word to you which will bring you on your knees monsieur is not only a friend of mine but more a friend of M Fouquet s

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Ah! ah! exclaimed the tailor, that is another thing. Then turning to Porthos, Monsieur le baron is attached to the superintendent? he inquired.
children.prevalue: Ah ah exclaimed the tailor that is another thing Then turning to Porthos Monsieur le baron is attached to the superintendent he inquired

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I am attached to myself, shouted Porthos, at the very moment that the tapestry was raised to introduce a new speaker in the dialogue. Moliere was all observation, D'Artagnan laughed, Porthos swore.
children.prevalue: I am attached to myself shouted Porthos at the very moment that the tapestry was raised to introduce a new speaker in the dialogue Moliere was all observation D Artagnan laughed Porthos swore

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: My dear Percerin, said D'Artagnan, you will make a dress for the baron. 'Tis I who ask you.
children.prevalue: My dear Percerin said D Artagnan you will make a dress for the baron Tis I who ask you

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: To you I will not say nay, captain.
children.prevalue: To you I will not say nay captain

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: But that is not all you will make it for him at once.
children.prevalue: But that is not all you will make it for him at once

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: 'Tis impossible within eight days.
children.prevalue: Tis impossible within eight days

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: That, then, is as much as to refuse, because the dress is wanted for the fete at Vaux.
children.prevalue: That then is as much as to refuse because the dress is wanted for the fete at Vaux

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I repeat that it is impossible, returned the obstinate old man.
children.prevalue: I repeat that it is impossible returned the obstinate old man

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: By no means, dear Monsieur Percerin, above all if I ask you, said a mild voice at the door, a silvery voice which made D'Artagnan prick up his ears. It was the voice of Aramis.
children.prevalue: By no means dear Monsieur Percerin above all if I ask you said a mild voice at the door a silvery voice which made D Artagnan prick up his ears It was the voice of Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Monsieur d'Herblay! cried the tailor.
children.prevalue: Monsieur d Herblay cried the tailor

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Aramis, murmured D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Aramis murmured D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Ah! our bishop! said Porthos.
children.prevalue: Ah our bishop said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Good morning, D'Artagnan good morning, Porthos goodmorning, my dear friends, said Aramis. Come, come, M. Percerin, make the baron's dress and I will answer for it you will gratify M. Fouquet. And he accompanied the words with a sign, which seemed to say, Agree, and dismiss them.
children.prevalue: Good morning D Artagnan good morning Porthos goodmorning my dear friends said Aramis Come come M Percerin make the baron s dress and I will answer for it you will gratify M Fouquet And he accompanied the words with a sign which seemed to say Agree and dismiss them

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: It appeared that Aramis had over Master Percerin an influence superior even to D'Artagnan's, for the tailor bowed in assent, and turning round upon Porthos, said, Go and get measured on the other side.
children.prevalue: It appeared that Aramis had over Master Percerin an influence superior even to D Artagnan s for the tailor bowed in assent and turning round upon Porthos said Go and get measured on the other side

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Porthos colored in a formidable manner. D'Artagnan saw the storm coming, and addressing Moliere, said to him, in an undertone, You see before you, my dear monsieur, a man who considers himself disgraced, if you measure the flesh and bones that Heaven has given him study this type for me, Master Aristophanes, and profit by it.
children.prevalue: Porthos colored in a formidable manner D Artagnan saw the storm coming and addressing Moliere said to him in an undertone You see before you my dear monsieur a man who considers himself disgraced if you measure the flesh and bones that Heaven has given him study this type for me Master Aristophanes and profit by it

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Moliere had no need of encouragement, and his gaze dwelt long and keenly on the Baron Porthos. Monsieur, he said, if you will come with me, I will make them take your measure without touching you.
children.prevalue: Moliere had no need of encouragement and his gaze dwelt long and keenly on the Baron Porthos Monsieur he said if you will come with me I will make them take your measure without touching you

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Oh! said Porthos, how do you make that out, my friend?
children.prevalue: Oh said Porthos how do you make that out my friend

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I say that they shall apply neither line nor rule to the seams of your dress. It is a new method we have invented for measuring people of quality, who are too sensitive to allow lowborn fellows to touch them. We know some susceptible persons who will not put up with being measured, a process which, as I think, wounds the natural dignity of a man and if perchance monsieur should be one of these
children.prevalue: I say that they shall apply neither line nor rule to the seams of your dress It is a new method we have invented for measuring people of quality who are too sensitive to allow lowborn fellows to touch them We know some susceptible persons who will not put up with being measured a process which as I think wounds the natural dignity of a man and if perchance monsieur should be one of these

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Corboeuf! I believe I am too!
children.prevalue: Corboeuf I believe I am too

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Well, that is a capital and most consolatory coincidence, and you shall have the benefit of our invention.
children.prevalue: Well that is a capital and most consolatory coincidence and you shall have the benefit of our invention

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: But how in the world can it be done? asked Porthos, delighted.
children.prevalue: But how in the world can it be done asked Porthos delighted

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Monsieur, said Moliere, bowing, if you will deign to follow me, you will see.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said Moliere bowing if you will deign to follow me you will see

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Aramis observed this scene with all his eyes. Perhaps he fancied from D'Artagnan's liveliness that he would leave with Porthos, so as not to lose the conclusion of a scene well begun. But, clearsighted as he was, Aramis deceived himself. Porthos and Moliere left together: D'Artagnan remained with Percerin. Why? From curiosity, doubtless probably to enjoy a little longer the society of his good friend Aramis. As Moliere and Porthos disappeared, D'Artagnan drew near the bishop of Vannes, a proceeding which appeared particularly to disconcert him.
children.prevalue: Aramis observed this scene with all his eyes Perhaps he fancied from D Artagnan s liveliness that he would leave with Porthos so as not to lose the conclusion of a scene well begun But clearsighted as he was Aramis deceived himself Porthos and Moliere left together D Artagnan remained with Percerin Why From curiosity doubtless probably to enjoy a little longer the society of his good friend Aramis As Moliere and Porthos disappeared D Artagnan drew near the bishop of Vannes a proceeding which appeared particularly to disconcert him

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: A dress for you, also, is it not, my friend?
children.prevalue: A dress for you also is it not my friend

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Aramis smiled. No, said he.
children.prevalue: Aramis smiled No said he

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: You will go to Vaux, however?
children.prevalue: You will go to Vaux however

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: I shall go, but without a new dress. You forget, dear D'Artagnan, that a poor bishop of Vannes is not rich enough to have new dresses for every fete.
children.prevalue: I shall go but without a new dress You forget dear D Artagnan that a poor bishop of Vannes is not rich enough to have new dresses for every fete

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Bah! said the musketeer, laughing, and do we write no more poems now, either?
children.prevalue: Bah said the musketeer laughing and do we write no more poems now either

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Oh! D'Artagnan, exclaimed Aramis, I have long ago given up all such tomfoolery.
children.prevalue: Oh D Artagnan exclaimed Aramis I have long ago given up all such tomfoolery

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: True, repeated D'Artagnan, only half convinced. As for Percerin, he was once more absorbed in contemplation of the brocades.
children.prevalue: True repeated D Artagnan only half convinced As for Percerin he was once more absorbed in contemplation of the brocades

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Don't you perceive, said Aramis, smiling, that we are greatly boring this good gentleman, my dear D'Artagnan?
children.prevalue: Don t you perceive said Aramis smiling that we are greatly boring this good gentleman my dear D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Ah! ah! murmured the musketeer, aside that is, I am boring you, my friend. Then aloud, Well, then, let us leave I have no further business here, and if you are as disengaged as I, Aramis
children.prevalue: Ah ah murmured the musketeer aside that is I am boring you my friend Then aloud Well then let us leave I have no further business here and if you are as disengaged as I Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: No, not II wished
children.prevalue: No not II wished

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Ah! you had something particular to say to M. Percerin? Why did you not tell me so at once?
children.prevalue: Ah you had something particular to say to M Percerin Why did you not tell me so at once

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Something particular, certainly, repeated Aramis, but not for you, D'Artagnan. But, at the same time, I hope you will believe that I can never have anything so particular to say that a friend like you may not hear it.
children.prevalue: Something particular certainly repeated Aramis but not for you D Artagnan But at the same time I hope you will believe that I can never have anything so particular to say that a friend like you may not hear it

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Oh, no, no! I am going, said D'Artagnan, imparting to his voice an evident tone of curiosity for Aramis's annoyance, well dissembled as it was, had not a whit escaped him and he knew that, in that impenetrable mind, every thing, even the most apparently trivial, was designed to some end an unknown one, but an end that, from the knowledge he had of his friend's character, the musketeer felt must be important.
children.prevalue: Oh no no I am going said D Artagnan imparting to his voice an evident tone of curiosity for Aramis s annoyance well dissembled as it was had not a whit escaped him and he knew that in that impenetrable mind every thing even the most apparently trivial was designed to some end an unknown one but an end that from the knowledge he had of his friend s character the musketeer felt must be important

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: On his part, Aramis saw that D'Artagnan was not without suspicion, and pressed him. Stay, by all means, he said, this is what it is. Then turning towards the tailor, My dear Percerin, said he,I am even very happy that you are here, D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: On his part Aramis saw that D Artagnan was not without suspicion and pressed him Stay by all means he said this is what it is Then turning towards the tailor My dear Percerin said he I am even very happy that you are here D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Oh, indeed, exclaimed the Gascon, for the third time, even less deceived this time than before.
children.prevalue: Oh indeed exclaimed the Gascon for the third time even less deceived this time than before

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Percerin never moved. Aramis roused him violently, by snatching from his hands the stuff upon which he was engaged. My dear Percerin, said he, I have, near hand, M. Lebrun, one of M. Fouquet's painters.
children.prevalue: Percerin never moved Aramis roused him violently by snatching from his hands the stuff upon which he was engaged My dear Percerin said he I have near hand M Lebrun one of M Fouquet s painters

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Ah, very good, thought D'Artagnan but why Lebrun?
children.prevalue: Ah very good thought D Artagnan but why Lebrun

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Aramis looked at D'Artagnan, who seemed to be occupied with an engraving of Mark Antony. And you wish that I should make him a dress, similar to those of the Epicureans? answered Percerin. And while saying this, in an absent manner, the worthy tailor endeavored to recapture his piece of brocade.
children.prevalue: Aramis looked at D Artagnan who seemed to be occupied with an engraving of Mark Antony And you wish that I should make him a dress similar to those of the Epicureans answered Percerin And while saying this in an absent manner the worthy tailor endeavored to recapture his piece of brocade

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: An Epicurean's dress? asked D'Artagnan, in a tone of inquiry.
children.prevalue: An Epicurean s dress asked D Artagnan in a tone of inquiry

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: I see, said Aramis, with a most engaging smile, it is written that our dear D'Artagnan shall know all our secrets this evening. Yes, friend, you have surely heard speak of M. Fouquet's Epicureans, have you not?
children.prevalue: I see said Aramis with a most engaging smile it is written that our dear D Artagnan shall know all our secrets this evening Yes friend you have surely heard speak of M Fouquet s Epicureans have you not

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Undoubtedly. Is it not a kind of poetical society, of which La Fontaine, Loret, Pelisson, and Moliere are members, and which holds its sittings at SaintMande?
children.prevalue: Undoubtedly Is it not a kind of poetical society of which La Fontaine Loret Pelisson and Moliere are members and which holds its sittings at SaintMande

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Exactly so. Well, we are going to put our poets in uniform, and enroll them in a regiment for the king.
children.prevalue: Exactly so Well we are going to put our poets in uniform and enroll them in a regiment for the king

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Oh, very well, I understand a surprise M. Fouquet is getting up for the king. Be at ease if that is the secret about M. Lebrun, I will not mention it.
children.prevalue: Oh very well I understand a surprise M Fouquet is getting up for the king Be at ease if that is the secret about M Lebrun I will not mention it

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Always agreeable, my friend. No, Monsieur Lebrun has nothing to do with this part of it the secret which concerns him is far more important than the other.
children.prevalue: Always agreeable my friend No Monsieur Lebrun has nothing to do with this part of it the secret which concerns him is far more important than the other

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Then, if it is so important as all that, I prefer not to know it, said D'Artagnan, making a show of departure.
children.prevalue: Then if it is so important as all that I prefer not to know it said D Artagnan making a show of departure

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Come in, M. Lebrun, come in, said Aramis, opening a sidedoor with his right hand, and holding back D'Artagnan with his left.
children.prevalue: Come in M Lebrun come in said Aramis opening a sidedoor with his right hand and holding back D Artagnan with his left

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: I'faith, I too, am quite in the dark, quoth Percerin.
children.prevalue: I faith I too am quite in the dark quoth Percerin

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Aramis took an opportunity, as is said in theatrical matters.
children.prevalue: Aramis took an opportunity as is said in theatrical matters

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: My dear M. de Percerin, Aramis continued, you are making five dresses for the king, are you not? One in brocade one in huntingcloth one in velvet one in satin and one in Florentine stuffs.
children.prevalue: My dear M de Percerin Aramis continued you are making five dresses for the king are you not One in brocade one in huntingcloth one in velvet one in satin and one in Florentine stuffs

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Yes but howdo you know all that, monseigneur? said Percerin, astounded.
children.prevalue: Yes but howdo you know all that monseigneur said Percerin astounded

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: It is all very simple, my dear monsieur there will be a hunt, a banquet, concert, promenade and reception these five kinds of dress are required by etiquette.
children.prevalue: It is all very simple my dear monsieur there will be a hunt a banquet concert promenade and reception these five kinds of dress are required by etiquette

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: You know everything, monseigneur!
children.prevalue: You know everything monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: And a thing or two in addition, muttered D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: And a thing or two in addition muttered D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: But, cried the tailor, in triumph, what you do not know, monseigneurprince of the church though you arewhat nobody will knowwhat only the king, Mademoiselle de la Valliere, and myself do know, is the color of the materials and nature of the ornaments, and the cut, the ensemble, the finish of it all!
children.prevalue: But cried the tailor in triumph what you do not know monseigneurprince of the church though you arewhat nobody will knowwhat only the king Mademoiselle de la Valliere and myself do know is the color of the materials and nature of the ornaments and the cut the ensemble the finish of it all

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Well, said Aramis, that is precisely what I have come to ask you, dear Percerin.
children.prevalue: Well said Aramis that is precisely what I have come to ask you dear Percerin

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Ah, bah! exclaimed the tailor, terrified, though Aramis had pronounced these words in his softest and most honeyed tones. The request appeared, on reflection, so exaggerated, so ridiculous, so monstrous to M. Percerin that first he laughed to himself, then aloud, and finished with a shout. D'Artagnan followed his example, not because he found the matter so very funny, but in order not to allow Aramis to cool.
children.prevalue: Ah bah exclaimed the tailor terrified though Aramis had pronounced these words in his softest and most honeyed tones The request appeared on reflection so exaggerated so ridiculous so monstrous to M Percerin that first he laughed to himself then aloud and finished with a shout D Artagnan followed his example not because he found the matter so very funny but in order not to allow Aramis to cool

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: At the outset, I appear to be hazarding an absurd question, do I not? said Aramis. But D'Artagnan, who is incarnate wisdom itself, will tell you that I could not do otherwise than ask you this.
children.prevalue: At the outset I appear to be hazarding an absurd question do I not said Aramis But D Artagnan who is incarnate wisdom itself will tell you that I could not do otherwise than ask you this

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Let us see, said the attentive musketeer perceiving with his wonderful instinct that they had only been skirmishing till now, and that the hour of battle was approaching.
children.prevalue: Let us see said the attentive musketeer perceiving with his wonderful instinct that they had only been skirmishing till now and that the hour of battle was approaching

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Let us see, said Percerin, incredulously.
children.prevalue: Let us see said Percerin incredulously

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Why, now, continued Aramis, does M. Fouquet give the king a fete?Is it not to please him?
children.prevalue: Why now continued Aramis does M Fouquet give the king a fete Is it not to please him

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Assuredly, said Percerin. D'Artagnan nodded assent.
children.prevalue: Assuredly said Percerin D Artagnan nodded assent

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: By delicate attentions? by some happy device? by a succession of surprises, like that of which we were talking?the enrolment of our Epicureans.
children.prevalue: By delicate attentions by some happy device by a succession of surprises like that of which we were talking the enrolment of our Epicureans

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Admirable.
children.prevalue: Admirable

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Well, then this is the surprise we intend. M. Lebrun here is a man who draws most excellently.
children.prevalue: Well then this is the surprise we intend M Lebrun here is a man who draws most excellently

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Yes, said Percerin I have seen his pictures, and observed that his dresses were highly elaborated. That is why I at once agreed to make him a costumewhether to agree with those of the Epicureans, or an original one.
children.prevalue: Yes said Percerin I have seen his pictures and observed that his dresses were highly elaborated That is why I at once agreed to make him a costumewhether to agree with those of the Epicureans or an original one

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: My dear monsieur, we accept your offer, and shall presently avail ourselves of it but just now, M. Lebrun is not in want of the dresses you will make for himself, but of those you are making for the king.
children.prevalue: My dear monsieur we accept your offer and shall presently avail ourselves of it but just now M Lebrun is not in want of the dresses you will make for himself but of those you are making for the king

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Percerin made a bound backwards, which D'Artagnancalmest and most appreciative of men, did not consider overdone, so many strange and startling aspects wore the proposal which Aramis had just hazarded. The king's dresses! Give the king's dresses to any mortal whatever! Oh! for once, monseigneur, your grace is mad! cried the poor tailor in extremity.
children.prevalue: Percerin made a bound backwards which D Artagnancalmest and most appreciative of men did not consider overdone so many strange and startling aspects wore the proposal which Aramis had just hazarded The king s dresses Give the king s dresses to any mortal whatever Oh for once monseigneur your grace is mad cried the poor tailor in extremity

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Help me now, D'Artagnan, said Aramis, more and more calm and smiling. Help me now to persuade monsieur, for you understand do you not?
children.prevalue: Help me now D Artagnan said Aramis more and more calm and smiling Help me now to persuade monsieur for you understand do you not

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Eh! eh!not exactly, I declare.
children.prevalue: Eh eh not exactly I declare

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: What! you do not understand that M. Fouquet wishes to afford the king the surprise of finding his portrait on his arrival at Vaux and that the portrait, which be a striking resemblance, ought to be dressed exactly as the king will be on the day it is shown?
children.prevalue: What you do not understand that M Fouquet wishes to afford the king the surprise of finding his portrait on his arrival at Vaux and that the portrait which be a striking resemblance ought to be dressed exactly as the king will be on the day it is shown

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Oh! yes, yes, said the musketeer, nearly convinced, so plausible was this reasoning. Yes, my dear Aramis, you are right it is a happy idea. I will wager it is one of your own, Aramis.
children.prevalue: Oh yes yes said the musketeer nearly convinced so plausible was this reasoning Yes my dear Aramis you are right it is a happy idea I will wager it is one of your own Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Well, I don't know, replied the bishop either mine or M. Fouquet's. Then scanning Percerin, after noticing D'Artagnan's hesitation, Well, Monsieur Percerin, he asked, what do you say to this?
children.prevalue: Well I don t know replied the bishop either mine or M Fouquet s Then scanning Percerin after noticing D Artagnan s hesitation Well Monsieur Percerin he asked what do you say to this

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: I say, that
children.prevalue: I say that

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: That you are, doubtless, free to refuse. I know welland I by no means count upon compelling you, my dear monsieur. I will say more, I even understand all the delicacy you feel in taking up with M. Fouquet's idea you dread appearing to flatter the king. A noble spirit, M. Percerin, a noble spirit! The tailor stammered. It would, indeed, be a very pretty compliment to pay the young prince, continued Aramis but as the surintendant told me, 'if Percerin refuse, tell him that it will not at all lower him in my opinion, and I shall always esteem him, only'
children.prevalue: That you are doubtless free to refuse I know welland I by no means count upon compelling you my dear monsieur I will say more I even understand all the delicacy you feel in taking up with M Fouquet s idea you dread appearing to flatter the king A noble spirit M Percerin a noble spirit The tailor stammered It would indeed be a very pretty compliment to pay the young prince continued Aramis but as the surintendant told me if Percerin refuse tell him that it will not at all lower him in my opinion and I shall always esteem him only

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: 'Only?' repeated Percerin, rather troubled.
children.prevalue: Only repeated Percerin rather troubled

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: 'Only,' continued Aramis, 'I shall be compelled to say to the king,'you understand, my dear Monsieur Percerin, that these are M. Fouquet's words,'I shall be constrained to say to the king, Sire, I had intended to present your majesty with your portrait, but owing to a feeling of delicacy, slightly exaggerated perhaps, although creditable, M. Percerin opposed the project.'
children.prevalue: Only continued Aramis I shall be compelled to say to the king you understand my dear Monsieur Percerin that these are M Fouquet s words I shall be constrained to say to the king Sire I had intended to present your majesty with your portrait but owing to a feeling of delicacy slightly exaggerated perhaps although creditable M Percerin opposed the project

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Opposed! cried the tailor, terrified at the responsibility which would weigh upon him I to oppose the desire, the will of M. Fouquet when he is seeking to please the king! Oh, what a hateful word you have uttered, monseigneur. Oppose! Oh, 'tis not I who said it, Heaven have mercy on me. I call the captain of the musketeers to witness it! Is it not true, Monsieur d'Artagnan, that I have opposed nothing?
children.prevalue: Opposed cried the tailor terrified at the responsibility which would weigh upon him I to oppose the desire the will of M Fouquet when he is seeking to please the king Oh what a hateful word you have uttered monseigneur Oppose Oh tis not I who said it Heaven have mercy on me I call the captain of the musketeers to witness it Is it not true Monsieur d Artagnan that I have opposed nothing

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: D'Artagnan made a sign indicating that he wished to remain neutral. He felt that there was an intrigue at the bottom of it, whether comedy or tragedy he was at his wit's end at not being able to fathom it, but in the meanwhile wished to keep clear.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan made a sign indicating that he wished to remain neutral He felt that there was an intrigue at the bottom of it whether comedy or tragedy he was at his wit s end at not being able to fathom it but in the meanwhile wished to keep clear

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: But already Percerin, goaded by the idea that the king was to be told he stood in the way of a pleasant surprise, had offered Lebrun a chair, and proceeded to bring from a wardrobe four magnificent dresses, the fifth being still in the workmen's hands and these masterpieces he successively fitted upon four lay figures, which, imported into France in the time of Concini, had been given to Percerin II. by Marshal d'Onore, after the discomfiture of the Italian tailors ruined in their competition. The painter set to work to draw and then to paint the dresses. But Aramis, who was closely watching all the phases of his toil, suddenly stopped him.
children.prevalue: But already Percerin goaded by the idea that the king was to be told he stood in the way of a pleasant surprise had offered Lebrun a chair and proceeded to bring from a wardrobe four magnificent dresses the fifth being still in the workmen s hands and these masterpieces he successively fitted upon four lay figures which imported into France in the time of Concini had been given to Percerin II by Marshal d Onore after the discomfiture of the Italian tailors ruined in their competition The painter set to work to draw and then to paint the dresses But Aramis who was closely watching all the phases of his toil suddenly stopped him

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: I think you have not quite got it, my dear Lebrun, he said your colors will deceive you, and on canvas we shall lack that exact resemblance which is absolutely requisite. Time is necessary for attentively observing the finer shades.

children.value: Then the affair will fail, said Aramis, quietly, and that because of a want of precision in the colors.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: D'Artagnan found Porthos in the adjoining chamber but no longer an irritated Porthos, or a disappointed Porthos, but Porthos radiant, blooming, fascinating, and chattering with Moliere, who was looking upon him with a species of idolatry, and as a man would who had not only never seen anything greater, but not even ever anything so great. Aramis went straight up to Porthos and offered him his white hand, which lost itself in the gigantic clasp of his old friend,an operation which Aramis never hazarded without a certain uneasiness. But the friendly pressure having been performed not too painfully for him, the bishop of Vannes passed over to Moliere.
