children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Without a soul having touched me, my friend.
children.prevalue: Without a soul having touched me my friend

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Except the three garcons who supported you.
children.prevalue: Except the three garcons who supported you

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Doubtless but I have, I think, already explained to you the difference there is between supporting and measuring.
children.prevalue: Doubtless but I have I think already explained to you the difference there is between supporting and measuring

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: 'Tis true, answered D'Artagnan who said afterwards to himself, I'faith, I greatly deceive myself, or I have been the means of a good windfall to that rascal Moliere, and we shall assuredly see the scene hit off to the life in some comedy or other. Porthos smiled.
children.prevalue: Tis true answered D Artagnan who said afterwards to himself I faith I greatly deceive myself or I have been the means of a good windfall to that rascal Moliere and we shall assuredly see the scene hit off to the life in some comedy or other Porthos smiled

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: What are you laughing at? asked D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: What are you laughing at asked D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Must I confess? Well, I was laughing over my good fortune.
children.prevalue: Must I confess Well I was laughing over my good fortune

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Oh, that is true I don't know a happier man than you. But what is this last piece of luck that has befallen you?'
children.prevalue: Oh that is true I don t know a happier man than you But what is this last piece of luck that has befallen you

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Well, my dear fellow, congratulate me.
children.prevalue: Well my dear fellow congratulate me

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: I desire nothing better.
children.prevalue: I desire nothing better

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: It seems that I am the first who has had his measure taken in that manner.
children.prevalue: It seems that I am the first who has had his measure taken in that manner

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Are you so sure of it?'
children.prevalue: Are you so sure of it

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Nearly so. Certain signs of intelligence which passed between Voliere and the other garcons showed me the fact.
children.prevalue: Nearly so Certain signs of intelligence which passed between Voliere and the other garcons showed me the fact

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Well, my friend, that does not surprise me from Moliere, said D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Well my friend that does not surprise me from Moliere said D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Voliere, my friend.
children.prevalue: Voliere my friend

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Oh, no, no, indeed! I am very willing to leave you to go on saying Voliere but, as for me, I shall continued to say Moliere. Well, this, I was saying, does not surprise me, coming from Moliere, who is a very ingenious fellow, and inspired you with this grand idea.
children.prevalue: Oh no no indeed I am very willing to leave you to go on saying Voliere but as for me I shall continued to say Moliere Well this I was saying does not surprise me coming from Moliere who is a very ingenious fellow and inspired you with this grand idea

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: It will be of great use to him by and by, I am sure.
children.prevalue: It will be of great use to him by and by I am sure

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Won't it be of use to him, indeed? I believe you, it will, and that in the highest degreefor you see my friend Moliere is of all known tailors the man who best clothes our barons, comtes, and marquisesaccording to their measure.
children.prevalue: Won t it be of use to him indeed I believe you it will and that in the highest degreefor you see my friend Moliere is of all known tailors the man who best clothes our barons comtes and marquisesaccording to their measure

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: On this observation, neither the application nor depth of which we shall discuss, D'Artagnan and Porthos quitted M. de Percerin's house and rejoined their carriages, wherein we will leave them, in order to look after Moliere and Aramis at SaintMande.
children.prevalue: On this observation neither the application nor depth of which we shall discuss D Artagnan and Porthos quitted M de Percerin s house and rejoined their carriages wherein we will leave them in order to look after Moliere and Aramis at SaintMande

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The bishop of Vannes, much annoyed at having met D'Artagnan at M. Percerin's, returned to SaintMande in no very good humor. Moliere, on the other hand, quite delighted at having made such a capital rough sketch, and at knowing where to find his original again, whenever he should desire to convert his sketch into a picture, Moliere arrived in the merriest of moods. All the first story of the left wing was occupied by the most celebrated Epicureans in Paris, and those on the freest footing in the houseevery one in his compartment, like the bees in their cells, employed in producing the honey intended for that royal cake which M. Fouquet proposed to offer his majesty Louis XIV. during the fete at Vaux. Pelisson, his head leaning on his hand, was engaged in drawing out the plan of the prologue to the Facheux, a comedy in three acts, which was to be put on the stage by Poquelin de Moliere, as D'Artagnan called him, or Coquelin de Voliere, as Porthos styled him. Loret, with all the charming innocence of a gazetteer,the gazetteers of all ages have always been so artless!Loret was composing an account of the fetes at Vaux, before those fetes had taken place. La Fontaine sauntered about from one to the other, a peripatetic, absentminded, boring, unbearable dreamer, who kept buzzing and humming at everybody's elbow a thousand poetic abstractions. He so often disturbed Pelisson, that the latter, raising his head, crossly said, At least, La Fontaine, supply me with a rhyme, since you have the run of the gardens at Parnassus.
children.prevalue: The bishop of Vannes much annoyed at having met D Artagnan at M Percerin s returned to SaintMande in no very good humor Moliere on the other hand quite delighted at having made such a capital rough sketch and at knowing where to find his original again whenever he should desire to convert his sketch into a picture Moliere arrived in the merriest of moods All the first story of the left wing was occupied by the most celebrated Epicureans in Paris and those on the freest footing in the houseevery one in his compartment like the bees in their cells employed in producing the honey intended for that royal cake which M Fouquet proposed to offer his majesty Louis XIV during the fete at Vaux Pelisson his head leaning on his hand was engaged in drawing out the plan of the prologue to the Facheux a comedy in three acts which was to be put on the stage by Poquelin de Moliere as D Artagnan called him or Coquelin de Voliere as Porthos styled him Loret with all the charming innocence of a gazetteer the gazetteers of all ages have always been so artless Loret was composing an account of the fetes at Vaux before those fetes had taken place La Fontaine sauntered about from one to the other a peripatetic absentminded boring unbearable dreamer who kept buzzing and humming at everybody s elbow a thousand poetic abstractions He so often disturbed Pelisson that the latter raising his head crossly said At least La Fontaine supply me with a rhyme since you have the run of the gardens at Parnassus

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: What rhyme do you want? asked the Fabler as Madame de Sevigne used to call him.
children.prevalue: What rhyme do you want asked the Fabler as Madame de Sevigne used to call him

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: I want a rhyme to lumiere.
children.prevalue: I want a rhyme to lumiere

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Orniere, answered La Fontaine.
children.prevalue: Orniere answered La Fontaine

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Ah, but, my good friend, one cannot talk of wheelruts when celebrating the delights of Vaux, said Loret.
children.prevalue: Ah but my good friend one cannot talk of wheelruts when celebrating the delights of Vaux said Loret

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Besides, it doesn't rhyme, answered Pelisson.
children.prevalue: Besides it doesn t rhyme answered Pelisson

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What! doesn't rhyme! cried La Fontaine, in surprise.
children.prevalue: What doesn t rhyme cried La Fontaine in surprise

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Yes you have an abominable habit, my friend,a habit which will ever prevent your becoming a poet of the first order. You rhyme in a slovenly manner.
children.prevalue: Yes you have an abominable habit my friend a habit which will ever prevent your becoming a poet of the first order You rhyme in a slovenly manner

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Oh, oh, you think so, do you, Pelisson?
children.prevalue: Oh oh you think so do you Pelisson

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Yes, I do, indeed. Remember that a rhyme is never good so long as one can find a better.
children.prevalue: Yes I do indeed Remember that a rhyme is never good so long as one can find a better

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Then I will never write anything again save in prose, said La Fontaine, who had taken up Pelisson's reproach in earnest. Ah! I often suspected I was nothing but a rascally poet! Yes, 'tis the very truth.
children.prevalue: Then I will never write anything again save in prose said La Fontaine who had taken up Pelisson s reproach in earnest Ah I often suspected I was nothing but a rascally poet Yes tis the very truth

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Do not say so your remark is too sweeping, and there is much that is good in your 'Fables.'
children.prevalue: Do not say so your remark is too sweeping and there is much that is good in your Fables

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And to begin, continued La Fontaine, following up his idea, I will go and burn a hundred verses I have just made.
children.prevalue: And to begin continued La Fontaine following up his idea I will go and burn a hundred verses I have just made

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Where are your verses?
children.prevalue: Where are your verses

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: In my head.
children.prevalue: In my head

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Well, if they are in your head you cannot burn them.
children.prevalue: Well if they are in your head you cannot burn them

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: True, said La Fontaine but if I do not burn them
children.prevalue: True said La Fontaine but if I do not burn them

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Well, what will happen if you do not burn them?
children.prevalue: Well what will happen if you do not burn them

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: They will remain in my mind, and I shall never forget them!
children.prevalue: They will remain in my mind and I shall never forget them

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The deuce! cried Loret what a dangerous thing! One would go mad with it!
children.prevalue: The deuce cried Loret what a dangerous thing One would go mad with it

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The deuce! the deuce! repeated La Fontaine what can I do?
children.prevalue: The deuce the deuce repeated La Fontaine what can I do

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I have discovered the way, said Moliere, who had entered just at this point of the conversation.
children.prevalue: I have discovered the way said Moliere who had entered just at this point of the conversation

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: What way?
children.prevalue: What way

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Write them first and burn them afterwards.
children.prevalue: Write them first and burn them afterwards

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: How simple! Well, I should never have discovered that. What a mind that devil of a Moliere has! said La Fontaine. Then, striking his forehead, Oh, thou wilt never be aught but an ass, Jean La Fontaine! he added.
children.prevalue: How simple Well I should never have discovered that What a mind that devil of a Moliere has said La Fontaine Then striking his forehead Oh thou wilt never be aught but an ass Jean La Fontaine he added

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: What are you saying there, my friend? broke in Moliere, approaching the poet, whose aside he had heard.
children.prevalue: What are you saying there my friend broke in Moliere approaching the poet whose aside he had heard

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I say I shall never be aught but an ass, answered La Fontaine, with a heavy sigh and swimming eyes. Yes, my friend, he added, with increasing grief, it seems that I rhyme in a slovenly manner.
children.prevalue: I say I shall never be aught but an ass answered La Fontaine with a heavy sigh and swimming eyes Yes my friend he added with increasing grief it seems that I rhyme in a slovenly manner

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Oh, 'tis wrong to say so.
children.prevalue: Oh tis wrong to say so

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Nay, I am a poor creature!
children.prevalue: Nay I am a poor creature

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Who said so?
children.prevalue: Who said so

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Parbleu! 'twas Pelisson did you not, Pelisson?
children.prevalue: Parbleu twas Pelisson did you not Pelisson

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Pelisson, again absorbed in his work, took good care not to answer.
children.prevalue: Pelisson again absorbed in his work took good care not to answer

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: But if Pelisson said you were so, cried Moliere, Pelisson has seriously offended you.
children.prevalue: But if Pelisson said you were so cried Moliere Pelisson has seriously offended you

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Do you think so?
children.prevalue: Do you think so

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Ah! I advise you, as you are a gentleman, not to leave an insult like that unpunished.
children.prevalue: Ah I advise you as you are a gentleman not to leave an insult like that unpunished

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: What! exclaimed La Fontaine.
children.prevalue: What exclaimed La Fontaine

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Did you ever fight?
children.prevalue: Did you ever fight

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Once only, with a lieutenant in the light horse.
children.prevalue: Once only with a lieutenant in the light horse

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: What wrong had he done you?
children.prevalue: What wrong had he done you

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: It seems he ran away with my wife.
children.prevalue: It seems he ran away with my wife

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Ah, ah! said Moliere, becoming slightly pale but as, at La Fontaine's declaration, the others had turned round, Moliere kept upon his lips the rallying smile which had so nearly died away, and continuing to make La Fontaine speak
children.prevalue: Ah ah said Moliere becoming slightly pale but as at La Fontaine s declaration the others had turned round Moliere kept upon his lips the rallying smile which had so nearly died away and continuing to make La Fontaine speak

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: And what was the result of the duel?
children.prevalue: And what was the result of the duel

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: The result was, that on the ground my opponent disarmed me, and then made an apology, promising never again to set foot in my house.
children.prevalue: The result was that on the ground my opponent disarmed me and then made an apology promising never again to set foot in my house

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: And you considered yourself satisfied? said Moliere.
children.prevalue: And you considered yourself satisfied said Moliere

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Not at all! on the contrary, I picked up my sword. 'I beg your pardon, monsieur,' I said, 'I have not fought you because you were my wife's friend, but because I was told I ought to fight. So, as I have never known any peace save since you made her acquaintance, do me the pleasure to continue your visits as heretofore, or morbleu! let us set to again.' And so, continued La Fontaine, he was compelled to resume his friendship with madame, and I continue to be the happiest of husbands.
children.prevalue: Not at all on the contrary I picked up my sword I beg your pardon monsieur I said I have not fought you because you were my wife s friend but because I was told I ought to fight So as I have never known any peace save since you made her acquaintance do me the pleasure to continue your visits as heretofore or morbleu let us set to again And so continued La Fontaine he was compelled to resume his friendship with madame and I continue to be the happiest of husbands

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: All burst out laughing. Moliere alone passed his hand across his eyes. Why? Perhaps to wipe away a tear, perhaps to smother a sigh. Alas! we know that Moliere was a moralist, but he was not a philosopher. 'Tis all one, he said, returning to the topic of the conversation, Pelisson has insulted you.
children.prevalue: All burst out laughing Moliere alone passed his hand across his eyes Why Perhaps to wipe away a tear perhaps to smother a sigh Alas we know that Moliere was a moralist but he was not a philosopher Tis all one he said returning to the topic of the conversation Pelisson has insulted you

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Ah, truly! I had already forgotten it.
children.prevalue: Ah truly I had already forgotten it

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: And I am going to challenge him on your behalf.
children.prevalue: And I am going to challenge him on your behalf

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Well, you can do so, if you think it indispensable.
children.prevalue: Well you can do so if you think it indispensable

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I do think it indispensable, and I am going to
children.prevalue: I do think it indispensable and I am going to

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Stay, exclaimed La Fontaine, I want your advice.
children.prevalue: Stay exclaimed La Fontaine I want your advice

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Upon what? this insult?
children.prevalue: Upon what this insult

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: No tell me really now whether lumiere does not rhyme with orniere.
children.prevalue: No tell me really now whether lumiere does not rhyme with orniere

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: I should make them rhyme.
children.prevalue: I should make them rhyme

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Ah! I knew you would.
children.prevalue: Ah I knew you would

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: And I have made a hundred thousand such rhymes in my time.
children.prevalue: And I have made a hundred thousand such rhymes in my time

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: A hundred thousand! cried La Fontaine. Four times as many as 'La Pucelle,' which M. Chaplain is meditating. Is it also on this subject, too, that you have composed a hundred thousand verses?
children.prevalue: A hundred thousand cried La Fontaine Four times as many as La Pucelle which M Chaplain is meditating Is it also on this subject too that you have composed a hundred thousand verses

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Listen to me, you eternally absentminded creature, said Moliere.
children.prevalue: Listen to me you eternally absentminded creature said Moliere

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: It is certain, continued La Fontaine, that legume, for instance, rhymes with posthume.
children.prevalue: It is certain continued La Fontaine that legume for instance rhymes with posthume

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: In the plural, above all.
children.prevalue: In the plural above all

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Yes, above all in the plural, seeing that then it rhymes not with three letters, but with four as orniere does with lumiere.
children.prevalue: Yes above all in the plural seeing that then it rhymes not with three letters but with four as orniere does with lumiere

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: But give me ornieres and lumieres in the plural, my dear Pelisson, said La Fontaine, clapping his hand on the shoulder of his friend, whose insult he had quite forgotten, and they will rhyme.
children.prevalue: But give me ornieres and lumieres in the plural my dear Pelisson said La Fontaine clapping his hand on the shoulder of his friend whose insult he had quite forgotten and they will rhyme

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Hem! coughed Pelisson.
children.prevalue: Hem coughed Pelisson

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Moliere says so, and Moliere is a judge of such things he declares he has himself made a hundred thousand verses.
children.prevalue: Moliere says so and Moliere is a judge of such things he declares he has himself made a hundred thousand verses

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Come, said Moliere, laughing, he is off now.
children.prevalue: Come said Moliere laughing he is off now

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: It is like rivage, which rhymes admirably with herbage. I would take my oath of it.
children.prevalue: It is like rivage which rhymes admirably with herbage I would take my oath of it

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: But said Moliere.
children.prevalue: But said Moliere

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: I tell you all this, continued La Fontaine, because you are preparing a divertissement for Vaux, are you not?
children.prevalue: I tell you all this continued La Fontaine because you are preparing a divertissement for Vaux are you not

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Yes, the 'Facheux.'
children.prevalue: Yes the Facheux

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Ah, yes, the 'Facheux' yes, I recollect. Well, I was thinking a prologue would admirably suit your divertissement.
children.prevalue: Ah yes the Facheux yes I recollect Well I was thinking a prologue would admirably suit your divertissement

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Doubtless it would suit capitally.
children.prevalue: Doubtless it would suit capitally

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Ah! you are of my opinion?
children.prevalue: Ah you are of my opinion

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: So much so, that I have asked you to write this very prologue.
children.prevalue: So much so that I have asked you to write this very prologue

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: You asked me to write it?
children.prevalue: You asked me to write it

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Yes, you, and on your refusal begged you to ask Pelisson, who is engaged upon it at this moment.
children.prevalue: Yes you and on your refusal begged you to ask Pelisson who is engaged upon it at this moment

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Ah! that is what Pelisson is doing, then? I'faith, my dear Moliere, you are indeed often right.
children.prevalue: Ah that is what Pelisson is doing then I faith my dear Moliere you are indeed often right

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: When?
children.prevalue: When

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: When you call me absentminded. It is a monstrous defect I will cure myself of it, and do your prologue for you.
children.prevalue: When you call me absentminded It is a monstrous defect I will cure myself of it and do your prologue for you

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: But inasmuch as Pelisson is about it!
children.prevalue: But inasmuch as Pelisson is about it

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Ah, true, miserable rascal that I am! Loret was indeed right in saying I was a poor creature.
children.prevalue: Ah true miserable rascal that I am Loret was indeed right in saying I was a poor creature

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: It was not Loret who said so, my friend.
children.prevalue: It was not Loret who said so my friend

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Well, then, whoever said so, 'tis the same to me! And so your divertissement is called the 'Facheux?' Well, can you make heureux rhyme with facheux?
children.prevalue: Well then whoever said so tis the same to me And so your divertissement is called the Facheux Well can you make heureux rhyme with facheux

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: If obliged, yes.
children.prevalue: If obliged yes

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: And even with capriceux.
children.prevalue: And even with capriceux

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Oh, no, no.
children.prevalue: Oh no no

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: It would be hazardous, and yet why so?
children.prevalue: It would be hazardous and yet why so

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: There is too great a difference in the cadences.
children.prevalue: There is too great a difference in the cadences

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: I was fancying, said La Fontaine, leaving Moliere for LoretI was fancying
children.prevalue: I was fancying said La Fontaine leaving Moliere for LoretI was fancying

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: What were you fancying? said Loret, in the middle of a sentence. Make haste.
children.prevalue: What were you fancying said Loret in the middle of a sentence Make haste

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: You are writing the prologue to the 'Facheux,' are you not?
children.prevalue: You are writing the prologue to the Facheux are you not

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: No! mordieu! it is Pelisson.
children.prevalue: No mordieu it is Pelisson

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Ah, Pelisson, cried La Fontaine, going over to him, I was fancying, he continued, that the nymph of Vaux
children.prevalue: Ah Pelisson cried La Fontaine going over to him I was fancying he continued that the nymph of Vaux

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Ah, beautiful! cried Loret. The nymph of Vaux! thank you, La Fontaine you have just given me the two concluding verses of my paper.
children.prevalue: Ah beautiful cried Loret The nymph of Vaux thank you La Fontaine you have just given me the two concluding verses of my paper

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Well, if you can rhyme so well, La Fontaine, said Pelisson, tell me now in what way you would begin my prologue?
children.prevalue: Well if you can rhyme so well La Fontaine said Pelisson tell me now in what way you would begin my prologue

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: I should say, for instance, 'Oh! nymph, who' After 'who' I should place a verb in the second person singular of the present indicative and should go on thus: 'this grot profound.'
children.prevalue: I should say for instance Oh nymph who After who I should place a verb in the second person singular of the present indicative and should go on thus this grot profound

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: But the verb, the verb? asked Pelisson.
children.prevalue: But the verb the verb asked Pelisson

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: To admire the greatest king of all kings round, continued La Fontaine.
children.prevalue: To admire the greatest king of all kings round continued La Fontaine

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: But the verb, the verb, obstinately insisted Pelisson. This second person singular of the present indicative?
children.prevalue: But the verb the verb obstinately insisted Pelisson This second person singular of the present indicative

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Well, then quittest:
children.prevalue: Well then quittest

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Oh, nymph, who quittest now this grot profound, To admire the greatest king of all kings round.
children.prevalue: Oh nymph who quittest now this grot profound To admire the greatest king of all kings round

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: You would not put 'who quittest,' would you?
children.prevalue: You would not put who quittest would you

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Why not?
children.prevalue: Why not

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: 'Quittest,' after 'you who'?
children.prevalue: Quittest after you who

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Ah! my dear fellow, exclaimed La Fontaine, you are a shocking pedant!
children.prevalue: Ah my dear fellow exclaimed La Fontaine you are a shocking pedant

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Without counting, said Moliere, that the second verse, 'king of all kings round,' is very weak, my dear La Fontaine.
children.prevalue: Without counting said Moliere that the second verse king of all kings round is very weak my dear La Fontaine

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Then you see clearly I am nothing but a poor creature,a shuffler, as you said.
children.prevalue: Then you see clearly I am nothing but a poor creature a shuffler as you said

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: I never said so.
children.prevalue: I never said so

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Then, as Loret said.
children.prevalue: Then as Loret said

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: And it was not Loret either it was Pelisson.
children.prevalue: And it was not Loret either it was Pelisson

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Well, Pelisson was right a hundred times over. But what annoys me more than anything, my dear Moliere, is, that I fear we shall not have our Epicurean dresses.
children.prevalue: Well Pelisson was right a hundred times over But what annoys me more than anything my dear Moliere is that I fear we shall not have our Epicurean dresses

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: You expected yours, then, for the fete?
children.prevalue: You expected yours then for the fete

children.name: Paragraph_112

children.prevalue: Yes for the fete and then for after the fete My housekeeper told me that my own is rather faded

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Diable! your housekeeper is right rather more than faded.
children.prevalue: Diable your housekeeper is right rather more than faded

children.value: Ah, you see, resumed La Fontaine, the fact is, I left it on the floor in my room, and my cat

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Well, your cat
children.prevalue: Well your cat

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: She made her nest upon it, which has rather changed its color.
children.prevalue: She made her nest upon it which has rather changed its color

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: Moliere burst out laughing Pelisson and Loret followed his example. At this juncture, the bishop of Vannes appeared, with a roll of plans and parchments under his arm. As if the angel of death had chilled all gay and sprightly fanciesas if that wan form had scared away the Graces to whom Xenocrates sacrificedsilence immediately reigned through the study, and every one resumed his selfpossession and his pen. Aramis distributed the notes of invitation, and thanked them in the name of M. Fouquet. The superintendent, he said, being kept to his room by business, could not come and see them, but begged them to send him some of the fruits of their day's work, to enable him to forget the fatigue of his labor in the night.

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: At these words, all settled down to work. La Fontaine placed himself at a table, and set his rapid pen an endless dance across the smooth white vellum Pelisson made a fair copy of his prologue Moliere contributed fifty fresh verses, with which his visit to Percerin had inspired him Loret, an article on the marvelous fetes he predicted and Aramis, laden with his booty like the king of the bees, that great black drone, decked with purple and gold, reentered his apartment, silent and busy. But before departing, Remember, gentlemen, said he, we leave tomorrow evening.

As to Moliere, he had undertaken to order the horses, while Aramis went to exchange a parting word with the superintendent. Oh, how they are laughing there! said Fouquet, with a sigh.

children.value: Do you not laugh, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: Do you not laugh monseigneur

children.value: I laugh no longer now, M. d'Herblay. The fete is approaching money is departing.
children.prevalue: I laugh no longer now M d Herblay The fete is approaching money is departing

children.prevalue: Have I not told you that was my business

children.prevalue: Yes you promised me millions

children.name: Paragraph_135

children.prevalue: You shall have them the day after the king s entree into Vaux

children.value: Fouquet looked closely at Aramis, and passed the back of his icy hand across his moistened brow. Aramis perceived that the superintendent either doubted him, or felt he was powerless to obtain the money. How could Fouquet suppose that a poor bishop, exabbe, exmusketeer, could find any?

children.prevalue: Surprise

children.prevalue: Yes which you are going to give to the king

children.prevalue: And will it cost much

children.prevalue: Oh a hundred pistoles you will give Lebrun

children.value: A painting?Ah! all the better! And what is this painting to represent?
children.prevalue: A painting Ah all the better And what is this painting to represent

children.value: I will tell you then at the same time, whatever you may say or think of it, I went to see the dresses for our poets.

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: Bah! and they will be rich and elegant?
children.prevalue: Bah and they will be rich and elegant

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: Splendid! There will be few great monseigneurs with so good. People will see the difference there is between the courtiers of wealth and those of friendship.
children.prevalue: Splendid There will be few great monseigneurs with so good People will see the difference there is between the courtiers of wealth and those of friendship

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: Ever generous and grateful, dear prelate.
children.prevalue: Ever generous and grateful dear prelate

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: In your school.
children.prevalue: In your school

children.name: Paragraph_155
children.value: Fouquet grasped his hand. And where are you going? he said.
children.prevalue: Fouquet grasped his hand And where are you going he said

children.value: I am off to Paris, when you shall have given a certain letter.
children.prevalue: I am off to Paris when you shall have given a certain letter

children.name: Paragraph_157
children.value: For whom?
children.prevalue: For whom

children.value: M. de Lyonne.

children.value: And what do you want with Lyonne?
children.prevalue: And what do you want with Lyonne

children.prevalue: I wish to make him sign a lettre de cachet

children.prevalue: Lettre de cachet Do you desire to put somebody in the Bastile

children.prevalue: On the contraryto let somebody out

children.value: 'Two Latin verses!' and, for 'two Latin verses,' the miserable being has been in prison for ten years!
children.prevalue: Two Latin verses and for two Latin verses the miserable being has been in prison for ten years

children.prevalue: Yes

children.value: And has committed no other crime?
children.prevalue: And has committed no other crime

children.value: Beyond this, he is as innocent as you or I.
children.prevalue: Beyond this he is as innocent as you or I

children.name: Paragraph_169

children.prevalue: On your word

children.value: On my honor!
children.prevalue: On my honor

children.value: And his name is
children.prevalue: And his name is

children.prevalue: Seldon

children.name: Paragraph_173
children.value: Yes.But it is too bad. You knew this, and you never told me!
children.prevalue: Yes But it is too bad You knew this and you never told me

children.value: 'Twas only yesterday his mother applied to me, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Twas only yesterday his mother applied to me monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_175
children.value: And the woman is poor!
children.prevalue: And the woman is poor

children.value: In the deepest misery.
children.prevalue: In the deepest misery

children.name: Paragraph_177
children.value: Heaven, said Fouquet, sometimes bears with such injustice on earth, that I hardly wonder there are wretches who doubt of its existence. Stay, M. d'Herblay. And Fouquet, taking a pen, wrote a few rapid lines to his colleague Lyonne. Aramis took the letter and made ready to go.
children.prevalue: Heaven said Fouquet sometimes bears with such injustice on earth that I hardly wonder there are wretches who doubt of its existence Stay M d Herblay And Fouquet taking a pen wrote a few rapid lines to his colleague Lyonne Aramis took the letter and made ready to go

children.name: Paragraph_178
children.value: Wait, said Fouquet. He opened his drawer, and took out ten government notes which were there, each for a thousand francs. Stay, he said set the son at liberty, and give this to the mother but, above all, do not tell her
children.prevalue: Wait said Fouquet He opened his drawer and took out ten government notes which were there each for a thousand francs Stay he said set the son at liberty and give this to the mother but above all do not tell her

children.name: Paragraph_179
children.value: What, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: What monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_180
children.value: That she is ten thousand livres richer than I. She would say I am but a poor superintendent! Go! and I pray that God will bless those who are mindful of his poor!
children.prevalue: That she is ten thousand livres richer than I She would say I am but a poor superintendent Go and I pray that God will bless those who are mindful of his poor

children.name: Paragraph_181
children.value: So also do I pray, replied Aramis, kissing Fouquet's hand.
children.prevalue: So also do I pray replied Aramis kissing Fouquet s hand

children.name: Paragraph_182
children.value: And he went out quickly, carrying off the letter for Lyonne and the notes for Seldon's mother, and taking up Moliere, who was beginning to lose patience.
children.prevalue: And he went out quickly carrying off the letter for Lyonne and the notes for Seldon s mother and taking up Moliere who was beginning to lose patience

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Seven o'clock sounded from the great clock of the Bastile, that famous clock, which, like all the accessories of the state prison, the very use of which is a torture, recalled to the prisoners' minds the destination of every hour of their punishment. The timepiece of the Bastile, adorned with figures, like most of the clocks of the period, represented St. Peter in bonds. It was the supper hour of the unfortunate captives. The doors, grating on their enormous hinges, opened for the passage of the baskets and trays of provisions, the abundance and the delicacy of which, as M. de Baisemeaux has himself taught us, was regulated by the condition in life of the prisoner. We understand on this head the theories of M. de Baisemeaux, sovereign dispenser of gastronomic delicacies, head cook of the royal fortress, whose trays, fullladen, were ascending the steep staircases, carrying some consolation to the prisoners in the shape of honestly filled bottles of good vintages. This same hour was that of M. le gouverneur's supper also. He had a guest today, and the spit turned more heavily than usual. Roast partridges, flanked with quails and flanking a larded leveret boiled fowls hams, fried and sprinkled with white wine, cardons of Guipuzcoa and la bisque ecrevisses: these, together with soups and hors d'oeuvres, constituted the governor's bill of fare. Baisemeaux, seated at table, was rubbing his hands and looking at the bishop of Vannes, who, booted like a cavalier, dressed in gray and sword at side, kept talking of his hunger and testifying the liveliest impatience. M. de Baisemeaux de Montlezun was not accustomed to the unbending movements of his greatness my lord of Vannes, and this evening Aramis, becoming sprightly, volunteered confidence on confidence. The prelate had again a little touch of the musketeer about him. The bishop just trenched on the borders only of license in his style of conversation. As for M. de Baisemeaux, with the facility of vulgar people, he gave himself up entirely upon this point of his guest's freedom. Monsieur, said he, for indeed tonight I dare not call you monseigneur.

up entirely upon this point of his guest s freedom Monsieur said he for indeed tonight I dare not call you monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: By no means, said Aramis call me monsieur I am booted.
children.prevalue: By no means said Aramis call me monsieur I am booted

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Do you know, monsieur, of whom you remind me this evening?
children.prevalue: Do you know monsieur of whom you remind me this evening

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: No! faith, said Aramis, taking up his glass but I hope I remind you of a capital guest.
children.prevalue: No faith said Aramis taking up his glass but I hope I remind you of a capital guest

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: You remind me of two, monsieur. Francois, shut the window the wind may annoy his greatness.
children.prevalue: You remind me of two monsieur Francois shut the window the wind may annoy his greatness

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: And let him go, added Aramis. The supper is completely served, and we shall eat it very well without waiters. I like exceedingly to be teteatete when I am with a friend. Baisemeaux bowed respectfully.
children.prevalue: And let him go added Aramis The supper is completely served and we shall eat it very well without waiters I like exceedingly to be teteatete when I am with a friend Baisemeaux bowed respectfully

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I like exceedingly, continued Aramis, to help myself.
children.prevalue: I like exceedingly continued Aramis to help myself

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Retire, Francois, cried Baisemeaux. I was saying that your greatness puts me in mind of two persons one very illustrious, the late cardinal, the great Cardinal de la Rochelle, who wore boots like you.
children.prevalue: Retire Francois cried Baisemeaux I was saying that your greatness puts me in mind of two persons one very illustrious the late cardinal the great Cardinal de la Rochelle who wore boots like you

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Indeed, said Aramis and the other?
children.prevalue: Indeed said Aramis and the other

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The other was a certain musketeer, very handsome, very brave, very adventurous, very fortunate, who, from being abbe, turned musketeer, and from musketeer turned abbe. Aramis condescended to smile. From abbe, continued Baisemeaux, encouraged by Aramis's smilefrom abbe, bishopand from bishop
children.prevalue: The other was a certain musketeer very handsome very brave very adventurous very fortunate who from being abbe turned musketeer and from musketeer turned abbe Aramis condescended to smile From abbe continued Baisemeaux encouraged by Aramis s smilefrom abbe bishopand from bishop

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Ah! stay there, I beg, exclaimed Aramis.
children.prevalue: Ah stay there I beg exclaimed Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: I have just said, monsieur, that you gave me the idea of a cardinal.
children.prevalue: I have just said monsieur that you gave me the idea of a cardinal

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Enough, dear M. Baisemeaux. As you said, I have on the boots of a cavalier, but I do not intend, for all that, to embroil myself with the church this evening.
children.prevalue: Enough dear M Baisemeaux As you said I have on the boots of a cavalier but I do not intend for all that to embroil myself with the church this evening

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: But you have wicked intentions, nevertheless, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: But you have wicked intentions nevertheless monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Oh, yes, wicked, I own, as everything mundane is.
children.prevalue: Oh yes wicked I own as everything mundane is

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: You traverse the town and the streets in disguise?
children.prevalue: You traverse the town and the streets in disguise

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: In disguise, as you say.
children.prevalue: In disguise as you say

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: And you still make use of your sword?
children.prevalue: And you still make use of your sword

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Yes, I should think so but only when I am compelled. Do me the pleasure to summon Francois.
children.prevalue: Yes I should think so but only when I am compelled Do me the pleasure to summon Francois

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Have you no wine there?
children.prevalue: Have you no wine there

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: 'Tis not for wine, but because it is hot here, and the window is shut.
children.prevalue: Tis not for wine but because it is hot here and the window is shut

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I shut the windows at suppertime so as not to hear the sounds or the arrival of couriers.
children.prevalue: I shut the windows at suppertime so as not to hear the sounds or the arrival of couriers

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Ah, yes. You hear them when the window is open?
children.prevalue: Ah yes You hear them when the window is open

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: But too well, and that disturbs me. You understand?
children.prevalue: But too well and that disturbs me You understand

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Nevertheless I am suffocated. Francois. Francois entered. Open the windows, I pray you, Master Francois, said Aramis. You will allow him, dear M. Baisemeaux?
children.prevalue: Nevertheless I am suffocated Francois Francois entered Open the windows I pray you Master Francois said Aramis You will allow him dear M Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: You are at home here, answered the governor. The window was opened. Do you not think, said M. de Baisemeaux, that you will find yourself very lonely, now M. de la Fere has returned to his household gods at Blois? He is a very old friend, is he not?
children.prevalue: You are at home here answered the governor The window was opened Do you not think said M de Baisemeaux that you will find yourself very lonely now M de la Fere has returned to his household gods at Blois He is a very old friend is he not

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: You know it as I do, Baisemeaux, seeing that you were in the musketeers with us.
children.prevalue: You know it as I do Baisemeaux seeing that you were in the musketeers with us

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Bah! with my friends I reckon neither bottles of wine nor years.
children.prevalue: Bah with my friends I reckon neither bottles of wine nor years

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: And you are right. But I do more than love M. de la Fere, dear Baisemeaux I venerate him.
children.prevalue: And you are right But I do more than love M de la Fere dear Baisemeaux I venerate him

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Well, for my part, though 'tis singular, said the governor, I prefer M. d'Artagnan to him. There is a man for you, who drinks long and well! That kind of people allow you at least to penetrate their thoughts.
children.prevalue: Well for my part though tis singular said the governor I prefer M d Artagnan to him There is a man for you who drinks long and well That kind of people allow you at least to penetrate their thoughts

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Baisemeaux, make me tipsy tonight let us have a merry time of it as of old, and if I have a trouble at the bottom of my heart, I promise you, you shall see it as you would a diamond at the bottom of your glass.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux make me tipsy tonight let us have a merry time of it as of old and if I have a trouble at the bottom of my heart I promise you you shall see it as you would a diamond at the bottom of your glass

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Bravo! said Baisemeaux, and he poured out a great glass of wine and drank it off at a draught, trembling with joy at the idea of being, by hook or by crook, in the secret of some high archiepiscopal misdemeanor. While he was drinking he did not see with what attention Aramis was noting the sounds in the great court. A courier came in about eight o'clock as Francois brought in the fifth bottle, and, although the courier made a great noise, Baisemeaux heard nothing.
