children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The devil take him, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: The devil take him said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: What! who? asked Baisemeaux. I hope 'tis neither the wine you drank nor he who is the cause of your drinking it.
children.prevalue: What who asked Baisemeaux I hope tis neither the wine you drank nor he who is the cause of your drinking it

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: No it is a horse, who is making noise enough in the court for a whole squadron.
children.prevalue: No it is a horse who is making noise enough in the court for a whole squadron

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Pooh! some courier or other, replied the governor, redoubling his attention to the passing bottle. Yes and may the devil take him, and so quickly that we shall never hear him speak more. Hurrah! hurrah!
children.prevalue: Pooh some courier or other replied the governor redoubling his attention to the passing bottle Yes and may the devil take him and so quickly that we shall never hear him speak more Hurrah hurrah

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: You forget me, Baisemeaux! my glass is empty, said Aramis, lifting his dazzling Venetian goblet.
children.prevalue: You forget me Baisemeaux my glass is empty said Aramis lifting his dazzling Venetian goblet

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Upon my honor, you delight me. Francois, wine! Francois entered. Wine, fellow! and better.
children.prevalue: Upon my honor you delight me Francois wine Francois entered Wine fellow and better

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Yes, monsieur, yes but a courier has just arrived.
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur yes but a courier has just arrived

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Let him go to the devil, I say.
children.prevalue: Let him go to the devil I say

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Yes, monsieur, but
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur but

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Let him leave his news at the office we will see to it tomorrow. Tomorrow, there will be time tomorrow there will be daylight, said Baisemeaux, chanting the words.
children.prevalue: Let him leave his news at the office we will see to it tomorrow Tomorrow there will be time tomorrow there will be daylight said Baisemeaux chanting the words

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Ah, monsieur, grumbled the soldier Francois, in spite of himself, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Ah monsieur grumbled the soldier Francois in spite of himself monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Take care, said Aramis, take care!
children.prevalue: Take care said Aramis take care

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Of what? dear M. d'Herblay, said Baisemeaux, half intoxicated.
children.prevalue: Of what dear M d Herblay said Baisemeaux half intoxicated

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The letter which the courier brings to the governor of a fortress is sometimes an order.
children.prevalue: The letter which the courier brings to the governor of a fortress is sometimes an order

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Nearly always.
children.prevalue: Nearly always

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Do not orders issue from the ministers?
children.prevalue: Do not orders issue from the ministers

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Yes, undoubtedly but
children.prevalue: Yes undoubtedly but

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: And what to these ministers do but countersign the signature of the king?
children.prevalue: And what to these ministers do but countersign the signature of the king

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Perhaps you are right. Nevertheless, 'tis very tiresome when you are sitting before a good table, teteatete with a friendAh! I beg your pardon, monsieur I forgot it is I who engage you at supper, and that I speak to a future cardinal.
children.prevalue: Perhaps you are right Nevertheless tis very tiresome when you are sitting before a good table teteatete with a friendAh I beg your pardon monsieur I forgot it is I who engage you at supper and that I speak to a future cardinal

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Let us pass over that, dear Baisemeaux, and return to our soldier, to Francois.
children.prevalue: Let us pass over that dear Baisemeaux and return to our soldier to Francois

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Well, and what has Francois done?
children.prevalue: Well and what has Francois done

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: He has demurred!
children.prevalue: He has demurred

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: He was wrong, then?
children.prevalue: He was wrong then

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: However, he has demurred, you see 'tis because there is something extraordinary in this matter. It is very possible that it was not Francois who was wrong in demurring, but you, who are in the wrong in not listening to him.
children.prevalue: However he has demurred you see tis because there is something extraordinary in this matter It is very possible that it was not Francois who was wrong in demurring but you who are in the wrong in not listening to him

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Wrong? I to be wrong before Francois? that seems rather hard.
children.prevalue: Wrong I to be wrong before Francois that seems rather hard

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Pardon me, merely an irregularity. But I thought it my duty to make an observation which I deem important.
children.prevalue: Pardon me merely an irregularity But I thought it my duty to make an observation which I deem important

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Oh! perhaps you are right, stammered Baisemeaux. The king's order is sacred but as to orders that arrive when one is at supper, I repeat that the devil
children.prevalue: Oh perhaps you are right stammered Baisemeaux The king s order is sacred but as to orders that arrive when one is at supper I repeat that the devil

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: If you had said as much to the great cardinalhem! my dear Baisemeaux, and if his order had any importance.
children.prevalue: If you had said as much to the great cardinalhem my dear Baisemeaux and if his order had any importance

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: I do it that I may not disturb a bishop. Mordioux! am I not, then, excusable?
children.prevalue: I do it that I may not disturb a bishop Mordioux am I not then excusable

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Do not forget, Baisemeaux, that I have worn the soldier's coat, and I am accustomed to obedience everywhere.
children.prevalue: Do not forget Baisemeaux that I have worn the soldier s coat and I am accustomed to obedience everywhere

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: You wish, then
children.prevalue: You wish then

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: I wish that you would do your duty, my friend yes, at least before this soldier.
children.prevalue: I wish that you would do your duty my friend yes at least before this soldier

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: 'Tis mathematically true, exclaimed Baisemeaux. Francois still waited: Let them send this order of the king's up to me, he repeated, recovering himself. And he added in a low tone, Do you know what it is? I will tell you something about as interesting as this. 'Beware of fire near the powder magazine' or, 'Look close after such and such a one, who is clever at escaping,' Ah! if you only knew, monseigneur, how many times I have been suddenly awakened from the very sweetest, deepest slumber, by messengers arriving at full gallop to tell me, or rather, bring me a slip of paper containing these words: 'Monsieur de Baisemeaux, what news?' 'Tis clear enough that those who waste their time writing such orders have never slept in the Bastile. They would know better they have never considered the thickness of my walls, the vigilance of my officers, the number of rounds we go. But, indeed, what can you expect, monseigneur? It is their business to write and torment me when I am at rest, and to trouble me when I am happy, added Baisemeaux, bowing to Aramis. Then let them do their business.
children.prevalue: Tis mathematically true exclaimed Baisemeaux Francois still waited Let them send this order of the king s up to me he repeated recovering himself And he added in a low tone Do you know what it is I will tell you something about as interesting as this Beware of fire near the powder magazine or Look close after such and such a one who is clever at escaping Ah if you only knew monseigneur how many times I have been suddenly awakened from the very sweetest deepest slumber by messengers arriving at full gallop to tell me or rather bring me a slip of paper containing these words Monsieur de Baisemeaux what news Tis clear enough that those who waste their time writing such orders have never slept in the Bastile They would know better they have never considered the thickness of my walls the vigilance of my officers the number of rounds we go But indeed what can you expect monseigneur It is their business to write and torment me when I am at rest and to trouble me when I am happy added Baisemeaux bowing to Aramis Then let them do their business

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: And do you do yours, added the bishop, smiling.
children.prevalue: And do you do yours added the bishop smiling

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Francois reentered Baisemeaux took from his hands the minister's order. He slowly undid it, and as slowly read it. Aramis pretended to be drinking, so as to be able to watch his host through the glass. Then, Baisemeaux, having read it: What was I just saying? he exclaimed.
children.prevalue: Francois reentered Baisemeaux took from his hands the minister s order He slowly undid it and as slowly read it Aramis pretended to be drinking so as to be able to watch his host through the glass Then Baisemeaux having read it What was I just saying he exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: What is it? asked the bishop.
children.prevalue: What is it asked the bishop

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: An order of release! There, now excellent news indeed to disturb us!
children.prevalue: An order of release There now excellent news indeed to disturb us

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Excellent news for him whom it concerns, you will at least agree, my dear governor!
children.prevalue: Excellent news for him whom it concerns you will at least agree my dear governor

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: And at eight o'clock in the evening!
children.prevalue: And at eight o clock in the evening

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: It is charitable!
children.prevalue: It is charitable

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Oh! charity is all very well, but it is for that fellow who says he is so weary and tired, but not for me who am amusing myself, said Baisemeaux, exasperated.
children.prevalue: Oh charity is all very well but it is for that fellow who says he is so weary and tired but not for me who am amusing myself said Baisemeaux exasperated

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Will you lose by him, then? And is the prisoner who is to be set at liberty a good payer?
children.prevalue: Will you lose by him then And is the prisoner who is to be set at liberty a good payer

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Oh, yes, indeed! a miserable, fivefranc rat!
children.prevalue: Oh yes indeed a miserable fivefranc rat

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Let me see it, asked M. d'Herblay. It is no indiscretion?
children.prevalue: Let me see it asked M d Herblay It is no indiscretion

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: By no means read it.
children.prevalue: By no means read it

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: There is 'Urgent,' on the paper you have seen that, I suppose?
children.prevalue: There is Urgent on the paper you have seen that I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Oh, admirable! 'Urgent!'a man who has been there ten years! It is urgent to set him free today, this very evening, at eight o'clock!urgent! And Baisemeaux, shrugging his shoulders with an air of supreme disdain, flung the order on the table and began eating again.
children.prevalue: Oh admirable Urgent a man who has been there ten years It is urgent to set him free today this very evening at eight o clock urgent And Baisemeaux shrugging his shoulders with an air of supreme disdain flung the order on the table and began eating again

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: They are fond of these tricks! he said, with his mouth full they seize a man, some fine day, keep him under lock and key for ten years, and write to you, 'Watch this fellow well,' or 'Keep him very strictly.' And then, as soon as you are accustomed to look upon the prisoner as a dangerous man, all of a sudden, without rhyme or reason they write'Set him at liberty,' and actually add to their missive'urgent.' You will own, my lord, 'tis enough to make a man at dinner shrug his shoulders!
children.prevalue: They are fond of these tricks he said with his mouth full they seize a man some fine day keep him under lock and key for ten years and write to you Watch this fellow well or Keep him very strictly And then as soon as you are accustomed to look upon the prisoner as a dangerous man all of a sudden without rhyme or reason they write Set him at liberty and actually add to their missive urgent You will own my lord tis enough to make a man at dinner shrug his shoulders

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: What do you expect? It is for them to write, said Aramis, for you to execute the order.
children.prevalue: What do you expect It is for them to write said Aramis for you to execute the order

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Good! good! execute it! Oh, patience! You must not imagine that I am a slave.
children.prevalue: Good good execute it Oh patience You must not imagine that I am a slave

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Gracious Heaven! my very good M. Baisemeaux, who ever said so? Your independence is well known.
children.prevalue: Gracious Heaven my very good M Baisemeaux who ever said so Your independence is well known

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Thank Heaven!
children.prevalue: Thank Heaven

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: But your goodness of heart is also known.
children.prevalue: But your goodness of heart is also known

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Ah! don't speak of it!
children.prevalue: Ah don t speak of it

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: And your obedience to your superiors. Once a soldier, you see, Baisemeaux, always a soldier.
children.prevalue: And your obedience to your superiors Once a soldier you see Baisemeaux always a soldier

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: And I shall directly obey and tomorrow morning, at daybreak, the prisoner referred to shall be set free.
children.prevalue: And I shall directly obey and tomorrow morning at daybreak the prisoner referred to shall be set free

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Tomorrow?
children.prevalue: Tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: At dawn.
children.prevalue: At dawn

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Why not this evening, seeing that the lettre de cachet bears, both on the direction and inside, 'urgent'?
children.prevalue: Why not this evening seeing that the lettre de cachet bears both on the direction and inside urgent

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Because this evening we are at supper, and our affairs are urgent, too!
children.prevalue: Because this evening we are at supper and our affairs are urgent too

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Dear Baisemeaux, booted though I be, I feel myself a priest, and charity has higher claims upon me than hunger and thirst. This unfortunate man has suffered long enough, since you have just told me that he has been your prisoner these ten years. Abridge his suffering. His good time has come give him the benefit quickly. God will repay you in Paradise with years of felicity.
children.prevalue: Dear Baisemeaux booted though I be I feel myself a priest and charity has higher claims upon me than hunger and thirst This unfortunate man has suffered long enough since you have just told me that he has been your prisoner these ten years Abridge his suffering His good time has come give him the benefit quickly God will repay you in Paradise with years of felicity

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: You wish it?
children.prevalue: You wish it

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: I entreat you.
children.prevalue: I entreat you

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: What! in the very middle of our repast?
children.prevalue: What in the very middle of our repast

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: I implore you such an action is worth ten Benedicites.
children.prevalue: I implore you such an action is worth ten Benedicites

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: It shall be as you desire, only our supper will get cold.
children.prevalue: It shall be as you desire only our supper will get cold

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Oh! never heed that.
children.prevalue: Oh never heed that

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Baisemeaux leaned back to ring for Francois, and by a very natural motion turned round towards the door. The order had remained on the table Aramis seized the opportunity when Baisemeaux was not looking to change the paper for another, folded in the same manner, which he drew swiftly from his pocket. Francois, said the governor, let the major come up here with the turnkeys of the Bertaudiere. Francois bowed and quitted the room, leaving the two companions alone.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux leaned back to ring for Francois and by a very natural motion turned round towards the door The order had remained on the table Aramis seized the opportunity when Baisemeaux was not looking to change the paper for another folded in the same manner which he drew swiftly from his pocket Francois said the governor let the major come up here with the turnkeys of the Bertaudiere Francois bowed and quitted the room leaving the two companions alone

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: There was now a brief silence, during which Aramis never removed his eyes from Baisemeaux for a moment. The latter seemed only half decided to disturb himself thus in the middle of supper, and it was clear he was trying to invent some pretext, whether good or bad, for delay, at any rate till after dessert. And it appeared also that he had hit upon an excuse at last.
children.prevalue: There was now a brief silence during which Aramis never removed his eyes from Baisemeaux for a moment The latter seemed only half decided to disturb himself thus in the middle of supper and it was clear he was trying to invent some pretext whether good or bad for delay at any rate till after dessert And it appeared also that he had hit upon an excuse at last

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Eh! but it is impossible! he cried.
children.prevalue: Eh but it is impossible he cried

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: How impossible? said Aramis. Give me a glimpse of this impossibility.
children.prevalue: How impossible said Aramis Give me a glimpse of this impossibility

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: 'Tis impossible to set a prisoner at liberty at such an hour. Where can he go to, a man so unacquainted with Paris?
children.prevalue: Tis impossible to set a prisoner at liberty at such an hour Where can he go to a man so unacquainted with Paris

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: He will find a place wherever he can.
children.prevalue: He will find a place wherever he can

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: You see, now, one might as well set a blind man free!
children.prevalue: You see now one might as well set a blind man free

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I have a carriage, and will take him wherever he wishes.
children.prevalue: I have a carriage and will take him wherever he wishes

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: You have an answer for everything. Francois, tell monsieur le major to go and open the cell of M. Seldon, No. 3, Bertaudiere.
children.prevalue: You have an answer for everything Francois tell monsieur le major to go and open the cell of M Seldon No 3 Bertaudiere

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Seldon! exclaimed Aramis, very naturally. You said Seldon, I think?
children.prevalue: Seldon exclaimed Aramis very naturally You said Seldon I think

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I said Seldon, of course. 'Tis the name of the man they set free.
children.prevalue: I said Seldon of course Tis the name of the man they set free

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Oh! you mean to say Marchiali? said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Oh you mean to say Marchiali said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Marchiali? oh! yes, indeed. No, no, Seldon.
children.prevalue: Marchiali oh yes indeed No no Seldon

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I think you are making a mistake, Monsieur Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: I think you are making a mistake Monsieur Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I have read the order.
children.prevalue: I have read the order

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: And I also.
children.prevalue: And I also

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: And I saw 'Seldon' in letters as large as that, and Baisemeaux held up his finger.
children.prevalue: And I saw Seldon in letters as large as that and Baisemeaux held up his finger

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And I read 'Marchiali' in characters as large as this, said Aramis, also holding up two fingers.
children.prevalue: And I read Marchiali in characters as large as this said Aramis also holding up two fingers

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: To the proof let us throw a light on the matter, said Baisemeaux, confident he was right. There is the paper, you have only to read it.
children.prevalue: To the proof let us throw a light on the matter said Baisemeaux confident he was right There is the paper you have only to read it

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I read 'Marchiali,' returned Aramis, spreading out the paper. Look.
children.prevalue: I read Marchiali returned Aramis spreading out the paper Look

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Baisemeaux looked, and his arms dropped suddenly. Yes, yes, he said, quite overwhelmed yes, Marchiali. 'Tis plainly written Marchiali! Quite true!
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux looked and his arms dropped suddenly Yes yes he said quite overwhelmed yes Marchiali Tis plainly written Marchiali Quite true

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Ah!
children.prevalue: Ah

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: How? the man of whom we have talked so much? The man whom they are every day telling me to take such care of?
children.prevalue: How the man of whom we have talked so much The man whom they are every day telling me to take such care of

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: There is 'Marchiali,' repeated the inflexible Aramis.
children.prevalue: There is Marchiali repeated the inflexible Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I must own it, monseigneur. But I understand nothing about it.
children.prevalue: I must own it monseigneur But I understand nothing about it

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: You believe your eyes, at any rate.
children.prevalue: You believe your eyes at any rate

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: To tell me very plainly there is 'Marchiali.'
children.prevalue: To tell me very plainly there is Marchiali

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: And in a good handwriting, too.
children.prevalue: And in a good handwriting too

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: 'Tis a wonder! I still see this order and the name of Seldon, Irishman. I see it. Ah! I even recollect that under this name there was a blot of ink.
children.prevalue: Tis a wonder I still see this order and the name of Seldon Irishman I see it Ah I even recollect that under this name there was a blot of ink

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: No, there is no ink no, there is no blot.
children.prevalue: No there is no ink no there is no blot

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Oh! but there was, though I know it, because I rubbed my fingerthis very onein the powder that was over the blot.
children.prevalue: Oh but there was though I know it because I rubbed my fingerthis very onein the powder that was over the blot

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: In a word, be it how it may, dear M. Baisemeaux, said Aramis, and whatever you may have seen, the order is signed to release Marchiali, blot or no blot.
children.prevalue: In a word be it how it may dear M Baisemeaux said Aramis and whatever you may have seen the order is signed to release Marchiali blot or no blot

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The order is signed to release Marchiali, replied Baisemeaux, mechanically, endeavoring to regain his courage.
children.prevalue: The order is signed to release Marchiali replied Baisemeaux mechanically endeavoring to regain his courage

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: And you are going to release this prisoner. If your heart dictates you to deliver Seldon also, I declare to you I will not oppose it the least in the world. Aramis accompanied this remark with a smile, the irony of which effectually dispelled Baisemeaux's confusion of mind, and restored his courage.
children.prevalue: And you are going to release this prisoner If your heart dictates you to deliver Seldon also I declare to you I will not oppose it the least in the world Aramis accompanied this remark with a smile the irony of which effectually dispelled Baisemeaux s confusion of mind and restored his courage

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Monseigneur, he said, this Marchiali is the very same prisoner whom the other day a priest confessor of our order came to visit in so imperious and so secret a manner.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur he said this Marchiali is the very same prisoner whom the other day a priest confessor of our order came to visit in so imperious and so secret a manner

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I don't know that, monsieur, replied the bishop.
children.prevalue: I don t know that monsieur replied the bishop

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: 'Tis no such long time ago, dear Monsieur d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: Tis no such long time ago dear Monsieur d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: It is true. But with us, monsieur, it is good that the man of today should no longer know what the man of yesterday did.
children.prevalue: It is true But with us monsieur it is good that the man of today should no longer know what the man of yesterday did

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: In any case, said Baisemeaux, the visit of the Jesuit confessor must have given happiness to this man.
children.prevalue: In any case said Baisemeaux the visit of the Jesuit confessor must have given happiness to this man

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Aramis made no reply, but recommenced eating and drinking. As for Baisemeaux, no longer touching anything that was on the table, he again took up the order and examined it every way. This investigation, under ordinary circumstances, would have made the ears of the impatient Aramis burn with anger but the bishop of Vannes did not become incensed for so little, above all, when he had murmured to himself that to do so was dangerous. Are you going to release Marchiali? he said. What mellow, fragrant and delicious sherry this is, my dear governor.
children.prevalue: Aramis made no reply but recommenced eating and drinking As for Baisemeaux no longer touching anything that was on the table he again took up the order and examined it every way This investigation under ordinary circumstances would have made the ears of the impatient Aramis burn with anger but the bishop of Vannes did not become incensed for so little above all when he had murmured to himself that to do so was dangerous Are you going to release Marchiali he said What mellow fragrant and delicious sherry this is my dear governor

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Monseigneur, replied Baisemeaux, I shall release the prisoner Marchiali when I have summoned the courier who brought the order, and above all, when, by interrogating him, I have satisfied myself.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur replied Baisemeaux I shall release the prisoner Marchiali when I have summoned the courier who brought the order and above all when by interrogating him I have satisfied myself

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The order is sealed, and the courier is ignorant of the contents. What do you want to satisfy yourself about?
children.prevalue: The order is sealed and the courier is ignorant of the contents What do you want to satisfy yourself about

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Be it so, monseigneur but I shall send to the ministry, and M. de Lyonne will either confirm or withdraw the order.
children.prevalue: Be it so monseigneur but I shall send to the ministry and M de Lyonne will either confirm or withdraw the order

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: What is the good of all that? asked Aramis, coldly.
children.prevalue: What is the good of all that asked Aramis coldly

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: What good?
children.prevalue: What good

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Yes what is your object, I ask?
children.prevalue: Yes what is your object I ask

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The object of never deceiving oneself, monseigneur nor being wanting in the respect which a subaltern owes to his superior officers, nor infringing the duties of a service one has accepted of one's own free will.
children.prevalue: The object of never deceiving oneself monseigneur nor being wanting in the respect which a subaltern owes to his superior officers nor infringing the duties of a service one has accepted of one s own free will

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Very good you have just spoken so eloquently, that I cannot but admire you. It is true that a subaltern owes respect to his superiors he is guilty when he deceives himself, and he should be punished if he infringed either the duties or laws of his office.
children.prevalue: Very good you have just spoken so eloquently that I cannot but admire you It is true that a subaltern owes respect to his superiors he is guilty when he deceives himself and he should be punished if he infringed either the duties or laws of his office

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Baisemeaux looked at the bishop with astonishment.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux looked at the bishop with astonishment

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: It follows, pursued Aramis, that you are going to ask advice, to put your conscience at ease in the matter?
children.prevalue: It follows pursued Aramis that you are going to ask advice to put your conscience at ease in the matter

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: And if a superior officer gives you orders, you will obey?
children.prevalue: And if a superior officer gives you orders you will obey

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Never doubt it, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Never doubt it monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: You know the king's signature well, M. de Baisemeaux?
children.prevalue: You know the king s signature well M de Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Is it not on this order of release?
children.prevalue: Is it not on this order of release

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: It is true, but it may
children.prevalue: It is true but it may

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Be forged, you mean?
children.prevalue: Be forged you mean

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: That is evident, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: That is evident monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: You are right. And that of M. de Lyonne?
children.prevalue: You are right And that of M de Lyonne

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: I see it plain enough on the order but for the same reason that the king's signature may have been forged, so also, and with even greater probability, may M. de Lyonne's.
children.prevalue: I see it plain enough on the order but for the same reason that the king s signature may have been forged so also and with even greater probability may M de Lyonne s

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Your logic has the stride of a giant, M. de Baisemeaux, said Aramis and your reasoning is irresistible. But on what special grounds do you base your idea that these signatures are false?
children.prevalue: Your logic has the stride of a giant M de Baisemeaux said Aramis and your reasoning is irresistible But on what special grounds do you base your idea that these signatures are false

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: On this: the absence of countersignatures. Nothing checks his majesty's signature and M. de Lyonne is not there to tell me he has signed.
children.prevalue: On this the absence of countersignatures Nothing checks his majesty s signature and M de Lyonne is not there to tell me he has signed

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Well, Monsieur de Baisemeaux, said Aramis, bending an eagle glance on the governor, I adopt so frankly your doubts, and your mode of clearing them up, that I will take a pen, if you will give me one.
children.prevalue: Well Monsieur de Baisemeaux said Aramis bending an eagle glance on the governor I adopt so frankly your doubts and your mode of clearing them up that I will take a pen if you will give me one

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Baisemeaux gave him a pen.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux gave him a pen

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: And a sheet of white paper, added Aramis.
children.prevalue: And a sheet of white paper added Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Baisemeaux handed him some paper.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux handed him some paper

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Now, II, alsoI, here presentincontestably, Iam going to write an order to which I am certain you will give credence, incredulous as you are!
children.prevalue: Now II alsoI here presentincontestably Iam going to write an order to which I am certain you will give credence incredulous as you are

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Baisemeaux turned pale at this icy assurance of manner. It seemed to him that the voice of the bishop's, but just now so playful and gay, had become funereal and sad that the wax lights changed into the tapers of a mortuary chapel, the very glasses of wine into chalices of blood.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux turned pale at this icy assurance of manner It seemed to him that the voice of the bishop s but just now so playful and gay had become funereal and sad that the wax lights changed into the tapers of a mortuary chapel the very glasses of wine into chalices of blood

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Aramis took a pen and wrote. Baisemeaux, in terror, read over his shoulder.
children.prevalue: Aramis took a pen and wrote Baisemeaux in terror read over his shoulder

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: A. M. D. G., wrote the bishop and he drew a cross under these four letters, which signify ad majorem Dei gloriam, to the greater glory of God and thus he continued: It is our pleasure that the order brought to M. de Baisemeaux de Montlezun, governor, for the king, of the castle of the Bastile, be held by him good and effectual, and be immediately carried into operation.
children.prevalue: A M D G wrote the bishop and he drew a cross under these four letters which signify ad majorem Dei gloriam to the greater glory of God and thus he continued It is our pleasure that the order brought to M de Baisemeaux de Montlezun governor for the king of the castle of the Bastile be held by him good and effectual and be immediately carried into operation

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: (Signed) D'HERBLAY
children.prevalue: Signed D HERBLAY

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: General of the Order, by the grace of God.
children.prevalue: General of the Order by the grace of God

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Baisemeaux was so profoundly astonished, that his features remained contracted, his lips parted, and his eyes fixed. He did not move an inch, nor articulate a sound. Nothing could be heard in that large chamber but the wingwhisper of a little moth, which was fluttering to its death about the candles. Aramis, without even deigning to look at the man whom he had reduced to so miserable a condition, drew from his pocket a small case of black wax he sealed the letter, and stamped it with a seal suspended at his breast, beneath his doublet, and when the operation was concluded, presentedstill in silencethe missive to M. de Baisemeaux. The latter, whose hands trembled in a manner to excite pity, turned a dull and meaningless gaze upon the letter. A last gleam of feeling played over his features, and he fell, as if thunderstruck, on a chair.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux was so profoundly astonished that his features remained contracted his lips parted and his eyes fixed He did not move an inch nor articulate a sound Nothing could be heard in that large chamber but the wingwhisper of a little moth which was fluttering to its death about the candles Aramis without even deigning to look at the man whom he had reduced to so miserable a condition drew from his pocket a small case of black wax he sealed the letter and stamped it with a seal suspended at his breast beneath his doublet and when the operation was concluded presentedstill in silencethe missive to M de Baisemeaux The latter whose hands trembled in a manner to excite pity turned a dull and meaningless gaze upon the letter A last gleam of feeling played over his features and he fell as if thunderstruck on a chair

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Come, come, said Aramis, after a long silence, during which the governor of the Bastile had slowly recovered his senses, do not lead me to believe, dear Baisemeaux, that the presence of the general of the order is as terrible as His, and that men die merely from having seen Him. Take courage, rouse yourself give me your handobey.
children.prevalue: Come come said Aramis after a long silence during which the governor of the Bastile had slowly recovered his senses do not lead me to believe dear Baisemeaux that the presence of the general of the order is as terrible as His and that men die merely from having seen Him Take courage rouse yourself give me your handobey

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Baisemeaux, reassured, if not satisfied, obeyed, kissed Aramis's hand, and rose. Immediately? he murmured.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux reassured if not satisfied obeyed kissed Aramis s hand and rose Immediately he murmured

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Oh, there is no pressing haste, my host take your place again, and do the honors over this beautiful dessert.
children.prevalue: Oh there is no pressing haste my host take your place again and do the honors over this beautiful dessert

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Monseigneur, I shall never recover such a shock as this I who have laughed, who have jested with you! I who have dared to treat you on a footing of equality!
children.prevalue: Monseigneur I shall never recover such a shock as this I who have laughed who have jested with you I who have dared to treat you on a footing of equality

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Say nothing about it, old comrade, replied the bishop, who perceived how strained the cord was and how dangerous it would have been to break it say nothing about it. Let us each live in our own way to you, my protection and my friendship to me, your obedience. Having exactly fulfilled these two requirements, let us live happily.
children.prevalue: Say nothing about it old comrade replied the bishop who perceived how strained the cord was and how dangerous it would have been to break it say nothing about it Let us each live in our own way to you my protection and my friendship to me your obedience Having exactly fulfilled these two requirements let us live happily

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Baisemeaux reflected he perceived, at a glance, the consequence of this withdrawal of a prisoner by means of a forged order and, putting in the scale the guarantee offered him by the official order of the general, did not consider it of any value.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux reflected he perceived at a glance the consequence of this withdrawal of a prisoner by means of a forged order and putting in the scale the guarantee offered him by the official order of the general did not consider it of any value

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Aramis divined this. My dear Baisemeaux, said he, you are a simpleton. Lose this habit of reflection when I give myself the trouble to think for you.
children.prevalue: Aramis divined this My dear Baisemeaux said he you are a simpleton Lose this habit of reflection when I give myself the trouble to think for you

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: And at another gesture he made, Baisemeaux bowed again. How shall I set about it? he said.
children.prevalue: And at another gesture he made Baisemeaux bowed again How shall I set about it he said

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: What is the process for releasing a prisoner?
children.prevalue: What is the process for releasing a prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: I have the regulations.
children.prevalue: I have the regulations

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Well, then, follow the regulations, my friend.
children.prevalue: Well then follow the regulations my friend

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: I go with my major to the prisoner's room, and conduct him, if he is a personage of importance.
children.prevalue: I go with my major to the prisoner s room and conduct him if he is a personage of importance

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: But this Marchiali is not an important personage, said Aramis carelessly.
children.prevalue: But this Marchiali is not an important personage said Aramis carelessly

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: I don't know, answered the governor, as if he would have said, It is for you to instruct me.
children.prevalue: I don t know answered the governor as if he would have said It is for you to instruct me

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Then if you don't know it, I am right so act towards Marchiali as you act towards one of obscure station.
children.prevalue: Then if you don t know it I am right so act towards Marchiali as you act towards one of obscure station

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Good the regulations so provide. They are to the effect that the turnkey, or one of the lower officials, shall bring the prisoner before the governor, in the office.
children.prevalue: Good the regulations so provide They are to the effect that the turnkey or one of the lower officials shall bring the prisoner before the governor in the office

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Well, 'tis very wise, that and then?
children.prevalue: Well tis very wise that and then

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Then we return to the prisoner the valuables he wore at the time of his imprisonment, his clothes and papers, if the minister's orders have not otherwise dictated.
children.prevalue: Then we return to the prisoner the valuables he wore at the time of his imprisonment his clothes and papers if the minister s orders have not otherwise dictated

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: What was the minister's order as to this Marchiali?
children.prevalue: What was the minister s order as to this Marchiali

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Nothing for the unhappy man arrived here without jewels, without papers, and almost without clothes.
children.prevalue: Nothing for the unhappy man arrived here without jewels without papers and almost without clothes

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: See how simple, then, all is. Indeed, Baisemeaux, you make a mountain of everything. Remain here, and make them bring the prisoner to the governor's house.
children.prevalue: See how simple then all is Indeed Baisemeaux you make a mountain of everything Remain here and make them bring the prisoner to the governor s house

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Baisemeaux obeyed. He summoned his lieutenant, and gave him an order, which the latter passed on, without disturbing himself about it, to the next whom it concerned.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux obeyed He summoned his lieutenant and gave him an order which the latter passed on without disturbing himself about it to the next whom it concerned

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Half an hour afterwards they heard a gate shut in the court it was the door to the dungeon, which had just rendered up its prey to the free air. Aramis blew out all the candles which lighted the room but one, which he left burning behind the door. This flickering glare prevented the sight from resting steadily on any object. It multiplied tenfold the changing forms and shadows of the place, by its wavering uncertainty. Steps drew near.
children.prevalue: Half an hour afterwards they heard a gate shut in the court it was the door to the dungeon which had just rendered up its prey to the free air Aramis blew out all the candles which lighted the room but one which he left burning behind the door This flickering glare prevented the sight from resting steadily on any object It multiplied tenfold the changing forms and shadows of the place by its wavering uncertainty Steps drew near

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Go and meet your men, said Aramis to Baisemeaux.
children.prevalue: Go and meet your men said Aramis to Baisemeaux

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: The governor obeyed. The sergeant and turnkeys disappeared. Baisemeaux reentered, followed by a prisoner. Aramis had placed himself in the shade he saw without being seen. Baisemeaux, in an agitated tone of voice, made the young man acquainted with the order which set him at liberty. The prisoner listened, without making a single gesture or saying a word.
children.prevalue: The governor obeyed The sergeant and turnkeys disappeared Baisemeaux reentered followed by a prisoner Aramis had placed himself in the shade he saw without being seen Baisemeaux in an agitated tone of voice made the young man acquainted with the order which set him at liberty The prisoner listened without making a single gesture or saying a word

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: You will swear ('tis the regulation that requires it), added the governor, never to reveal anything that you have seen or heard in the Bastile.
children.prevalue: You will swear tis the regulation that requires it added the governor never to reveal anything that you have seen or heard in the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: The prisoner perceived a crucifix he stretched out his hands and swore with his lips. And now, monsieur, you are free. Whither do you intend going?
children.prevalue: The prisoner perceived a crucifix he stretched out his hands and swore with his lips And now monsieur you are free Whither do you intend going

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: The prisoner turned his head, as if looking behind him for some protection, on which he ought to rely. Then was it that Aramis came out of the shade: I am here, he said, to render the gentleman whatever service he may please to ask.
children.prevalue: The prisoner turned his head as if looking behind him for some protection on which he ought to rely Then was it that Aramis came out of the shade I am here he said to render the gentleman whatever service he may please to ask

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: The prisoner slightly reddened, and, without hesitation, passed his arm through that of Aramis. God have you in his holy keeping, he said, in a voice the firmness of which made the governor tremble as much as the form of the blessing astonished him.
children.prevalue: The prisoner slightly reddened and without hesitation passed his arm through that of Aramis God have you in his holy keeping he said in a voice the firmness of which made the governor tremble as much as the form of the blessing astonished him

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Aramis, on shaking hands with Baisemeaux, said to him Does my order trouble you? Do you fear their finding it here, should they come to search?
children.prevalue: Aramis on shaking hands with Baisemeaux said to him Does my order trouble you Do you fear their finding it here should they come to search

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: I desire to keep it, monseigneur, said Baisemeaux. If they found it here, it would be a certain indication I should be lost, and in that case you would be a powerful and a last auxiliary for me.
children.prevalue: I desire to keep it monseigneur said Baisemeaux If they found it here it would be a certain indication I should be lost and in that case you would be a powerful and a last auxiliary for me

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Being your accomplice, you mean? answered Aramis, shrugging his shoulders. Adieu, Baisemeaux, said he.
children.prevalue: Being your accomplice you mean answered Aramis shrugging his shoulders Adieu Baisemeaux said he

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: The horses were in waiting, making each rusty spring reverberate the carriage again with their impatience. Baisemeaux accompanied the bishop to the bottom of the steps. Aramis caused his companion to mount before him, then followed, and without giving the driver any further order, Go on, said he. The carriage rattled over the pavement of the courtyard. An officer with a torch went before the horses, and gave orders at every post to let them pass. During the time taken in opening all the barriers, Aramis barely breathed, and you might have heard his sealed heart knock against his ribs. The prisoner, buried in a corner of the carriage, made no more sign of life than his companion. At length, a jolt more sever than the others announced to them that they had cleared the last watercourse. Behind the carriage closed the last gate, that in the Rue St. Antoine. No more walls either on the right or the left heaven everywhere, liberty everywhere, and life everywhere. The horses, kept in check by a vigorous hand, went quietly as far as the middle of the faubourg. There they began to trot. Little by little, whether they were warming to their work, or whether they were urged, they gained in swiftness, and once past Bercy, the carriage seemed to fly, so great was the ardor of the coursers. The horses galloped thus as far as Villeneuve St. George's, where relays were waiting. Then four instead of two whirled the carriage away in the direction of Melun, and pulled up for a moment in the middle of the forest of Senart. No doubt the order had been given the postilion beforehand, for Aramis had no occasion even to make a sign.
children.prevalue: The horses were in waiting making each rusty spring reverberate the carriage again with their impatience Baisemeaux accompanied the bishop to the bottom of the steps Aramis caused his companion to mount before him then followed and without giving the driver any further order Go on said he The carriage rattled over the pavement of the courtyard An officer with a torch went before the horses and gave orders at every post to let them pass During the time taken in opening all the barriers Aramis barely breathed and you might have heard his sealed heart knock against his ribs The prisoner buried in a corner of the carriage made no more sign of life than his companion At length a jolt more sever than the others announced to them that they had cleared the last watercourse Behind the carriage closed the last gate that in the Rue St Antoine No more walls either on the right or the left heaven everywhere liberty everywhere and life everywhere The horses kept in check by a vigorous hand went quietly as far as the middle of the faubourg There they began to trot Little by little whether they were warming to their work or whether they were urged they gained in swiftness and once past Bercy the carriage seemed to fly so great was the ardor of the coursers The horses galloped thus as far as Villeneuve St George s where relays were waiting Then four instead of two whirled the carriage away in the direction of Melun and pulled up for a moment in the middle of the forest of Senart No doubt the order had been given the postilion beforehand for Aramis had no occasion even to make a sign

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: What is the matter? asked the prisoner, as if waking from a long dream.
children.prevalue: What is the matter asked the prisoner as if waking from a long dream

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: The matter is, monseigneur, said Aramis, that before going further, it is necessary your royal highness and I should converse.
children.prevalue: The matter is monseigneur said Aramis that before going further it is necessary your royal highness and I should converse

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: I will await an opportunity, monsieur, answered the young prince.
children.prevalue: I will await an opportunity monsieur answered the young prince

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: We could not have a better, monseigneur. We are in the middle of a forest, and no one can hear us.
children.prevalue: We could not have a better monseigneur We are in the middle of a forest and no one can hear us

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: The postilion?
children.prevalue: The postilion

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: The postilion of this relay is deaf and dumb, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: The postilion of this relay is deaf and dumb monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: I am at your service, M. d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: I am at your service M d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Is it your pleasure to remain in the carriage?
children.prevalue: Is it your pleasure to remain in the carriage

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Yes we are comfortably seated, and I like this carriage, for it has restored me to liberty.
children.prevalue: Yes we are comfortably seated and I like this carriage for it has restored me to liberty

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Wait, monseigneur there is yet a precaution to be taken.
children.prevalue: Wait monseigneur there is yet a precaution to be taken

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: What?
children.prevalue: What

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: We are here on the highway cavaliers or carriages traveling like ourselves might pass, and seeing us stopping, deem us in some difficulty. Let us avoid offers of assistance, which would embarrass us.
children.prevalue: We are here on the highway cavaliers or carriages traveling like ourselves might pass and seeing us stopping deem us in some difficulty Let us avoid offers of assistance which would embarrass us

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Give the postilion orders to conceal the carriage in one of the side avenues.
children.prevalue: Give the postilion orders to conceal the carriage in one of the side avenues

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: 'Tis exactly what I wished to do, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Tis exactly what I wished to do monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Aramis made a sign to the deaf and dumb driver of the carriage, whom he touched on the arm. The latter dismounted, took the leaders by the bridle, and led them over the velvet sward and the mossy grass of a winding alley, at the bottom of which, on this moonless night, the deep shades formed a curtain blacker than ink. This done, the man lay down on a slope near his horses, who, on either side, kept nibbling the young oak shoots.
children.prevalue: Aramis made a sign to the deaf and dumb driver of the carriage whom he touched on the arm The latter dismounted took the leaders by the bridle and led them over the velvet sward and the mossy grass of a winding alley at the bottom of which on this moonless night the deep shades formed a curtain blacker than ink This done the man lay down on a slope near his horses who on either side kept nibbling the young oak shoots

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: I am listening, said the young prince to Aramis but what are you doing there?
children.prevalue: I am listening said the young prince to Aramis but what are you doing there

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: I am disarming myself of my pistols, of which we have no further need, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: I am disarming myself of my pistols of which we have no further need monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: My prince, said Aramis, turning in the carriage towards his companion, weak creature as I am, so unpretending in genius, so low in the scale of intelligent beings, it has never yet happened to me to converse with a man without penetrating his thoughts through that living mask which has been thrown over our mind, in order to retain its expression. But tonight, in this darkness, in the reserve which you maintain, I can read nothing on your features, and something tells me that I shall have great difficulty in wresting from you a sincere declaration. I beseech you, then, not for love of me, for subjects should never weigh as anything in the balance which princes hold, but for love of yourself, to retain every syllable, every inflexion which, under the present most grave circumstances, will all have a sense and value as important as any every uttered in the world.
children.prevalue: My prince said Aramis turning in the carriage towards his companion weak creature as I am so unpretending in genius so low in the scale of intelligent beings it has never yet happened to me to converse with a man without penetrating his thoughts through that living mask which has been thrown over our mind in order to retain its expression But tonight in this darkness in the reserve which you maintain I can read nothing on your features and something tells me that I shall have great difficulty in wresting from you a sincere declaration I beseech you then not for love of me for subjects should never weigh as anything in the balance which princes hold but for love of yourself to retain every syllable every inflexion which under the present most grave circumstances will all have a sense and value as important as any every uttered in the world

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: I listen, replied the young prince, decidedly, without either eagerly seeking or fearing anything you are about to say to me. And he buried himself still deeper in the thick cushions of the carriage, trying to deprive his companion not only of the sight of him, but even of the very idea of his presence.
children.prevalue: I listen replied the young prince decidedly without either eagerly seeking or fearing anything you are about to say to me And he buried himself still deeper in the thick cushions of the carriage trying to deprive his companion not only of the sight of him but even of the very idea of his presence

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Black was the darkness which fell wide and dense from the summits of the intertwining trees. The carriage, covered in by this prodigious roof, would not have received a particle of light, not even if a ray could have struggled through the wreaths of mist that were already rising in the avenue.
children.prevalue: Black was the darkness which fell wide and dense from the summits of the intertwining trees The carriage covered in by this prodigious roof would not have received a particle of light not even if a ray could have struggled through the wreaths of mist that were already rising in the avenue

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Monseigneur, resumed Aramis, you know the history of the government which today controls France. The king issued from an infancy imprisoned like yours, obscure as yours, and confined as yours only, instead of ending, like yourself, this slavery in a prison, this obscurity in solitude, these straightened circumstances in concealment, he was fain to bear all these miseries, humiliations, and distresses, in full daylight, under the pitiless sun of royalty on an elevation flooded with light, where every stain appears a blemish, every glory a stain. The king has suffered it rankles in his mind and he will avenge himself. He will be a bad king. I say not that he will pour out his people's blood, like Louis XI., or Charles IX. for he has no mortal injuries to avenge but he will devour the means and substance of his people for he has himself undergone wrongs in his own interest and money. In the first place, then, I acquit my conscience, when I consider openly the merits and the faults of this great prince and if I condemn him, my conscience absolves me.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur resumed Aramis you know the history of the government which today controls France The king issued from an infancy imprisoned like yours obscure as yours and confined as yours only instead of ending like yourself this slavery in a prison this obscurity in solitude these straightened circumstances in concealment he was fain to bear all these miseries humiliations and distresses in full daylight under the pitiless sun of royalty on an elevation flooded with light where every stain appears a blemish every glory a stain The king has suffered it rankles in his mind and he will avenge himself He will be a bad king I say not that he will pour out his people s blood like Louis XI or Charles IX for he has no mortal injuries to avenge but he will devour the means and substance of his people for he has himself undergone wrongs in his own interest and money In the first place then I acquit my conscience when I consider openly the merits and the faults of this great prince and if I condemn him my conscience absolves me

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Aramis paused. It was not to listen if the silence of the forest remained undisturbed, but it was to gather up his thoughts from the very bottom of his soulto leave the thoughts he had uttered sufficient time to eat deeply into the mind of his companion.
children.prevalue: Aramis paused It was not to listen if the silence of the forest remained undisturbed but it was to gather up his thoughts from the very bottom of his soulto leave the thoughts he had uttered sufficient time to eat deeply into the mind of his companion

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: All that Heaven does, Heaven does well, continued the bishop of Vannes and I am so persuaded of it that I have long been thankful to have been chosen depositary of the secret which I have aided you to discover. To a just Providence was necessary an instrument, at once penetrating, persevering, and convinced, to accomplish a great work. I am this instrument. I possess penetration, perseverance, conviction I govern a mysterious people, who has taken for its motto, the motto of God, 'Patiens quia oeternus.' The prince moved. I divine, monseigneur, why you are raising your head, and are surprised at the people I have under my command. You did not know you were dealing with a kingoh! monseigneur, king of a people very humble, much disinherited humble because they have no force save when creeping disinherited, because never, almost never in this world, do my people reap the harvest they sow, nor eat the fruit they cultivate. They labor for an abstract idea they heap together all the atoms of their power, so from a single man and round this man, with the sweat of their labor, they create a misty halo, which his genius shall, in turn, render a glory gilded with the rays of all the crowns in Christendom. Such is the man you have beside you, monseigneur. It is to tell you that he has drawn you from the abyss for a great purpose, to raise you above the powers of the earthabove himself.

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The prince lightly touched Aramis's arm. You speak to me, he said, of that religious order whose chief you are. For me, the result of your words is, that the day you desire to hurl down the man you shall have raised, the event will be accomplished and that you will keep under your hand your creation of yesterday.
children.prevalue: The prince lightly touched Aramis s arm You speak to me he said of that religious order whose chief you are For me the result of your words is that the day you desire to hurl down the man you shall have raised the event will be accomplished and that you will keep under your hand your creation of yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Undeceive yourself, monseigneur, replied the bishop. I should not take the trouble to play this terrible game with your royal highness, if I had not a double interest in gaining it. The day you are elevated, you are elevated forever you will overturn the footstool, as you rise, and will send it rolling so far, that not even the sight of it will ever again recall to you its right to simple gratitude.
children.prevalue: Undeceive yourself monseigneur replied the bishop I should not take the trouble to play this terrible game with your royal highness if I had not a double interest in gaining it The day you are elevated you are elevated forever you will overturn the footstool as you rise and will send it rolling so far that not even the sight of it will ever again recall to you its right to simple gratitude

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Oh, monsieur!
children.prevalue: Oh monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Your movement, monseigneur, arises from an excellent disposition. I thank you. Be well assured, I aspire to more than gratitude! I am convinced that, when arrived at the summit, you will judge me still more worthy to be your friend and then, monseigneur, we two will do such great deeds, that ages hereafter shall long speak of them.
children.prevalue: Your movement monseigneur arises from an excellent disposition I thank you Be well assured I aspire to more than gratitude I am convinced that when arrived at the summit you will judge me still more worthy to be your friend and then monseigneur we two will do such great deeds that ages hereafter shall long speak of them

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Tell me plainly, monsieurtell me without disguisewhat I am today, and what you aim at my being tomorrow.
children.prevalue: Tell me plainly monsieurtell me without disguisewhat I am today and what you aim at my being tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: You are the son of King Louis XIII., brother of Louis XIV., natural and legitimate heir to the throne of France. In keeping you near him, as Monsieur has been keptMonsieur, your younger brotherthe king reserved to himself the right of being legitimate sovereign. The doctors only could dispute his legitimacy. But the doctors always prefer the king who is to the king who is not. Providence has willed that you should be persecuted this persecution today consecrates you king of France. You had, then, a right to reign, seeing that it is disputed you had a right to be proclaimed seeing that you have been concealed and you possess royal blood, since no one has dared to shed yours, as that of your servants has been shed. Now see, then, what this Providence, which you have so often accused of having in every way thwarted you, has done for you. It has given you the features, figure, age, and voice of your brother and the very causes of your persecution are about to become those of your triumphant restoration. Tomorrow, after tomorrowfrom the very first, regal phantom, living shade of Louis XIV., you will sit upon his throne, whence the will of Heaven, confided in execution to the arm of man, will have hurled him, without hope of return.
children.prevalue: You are the son of King Louis XIII brother of Louis XIV natural and legitimate heir to the throne of France In keeping you near him as Monsieur has been keptMonsieur your younger brotherthe king reserved to himself the right of being legitimate sovereign The doctors only could dispute his legitimacy But the doctors always prefer the king who is to the king who is not Providence has willed that you should be persecuted this persecution today consecrates you king of France You had then a right to reign seeing that it is disputed you had a right to be proclaimed seeing that you have been concealed and you possess royal blood since no one has dared to shed yours as that of your servants has been shed Now see then what this Providence which you have so often accused of having in every way thwarted you has done for you It has given you the features figure age and voice of your brother and the very causes of your persecution are about to become those of your triumphant restoration Tomorrow after tomorrowfrom the very first regal phantom living shade of Louis XIV you will sit upon his throne whence the will of Heaven confided in execution to the arm of man will have hurled him without hope of return

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I understand, said the prince, my brother's blood will not be shed, then.
children.prevalue: I understand said the prince my brother s blood will not be shed then

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: You will be sole arbiter of his fate.
children.prevalue: You will be sole arbiter of his fate

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The secret of which they made an evil use against me?
children.prevalue: The secret of which they made an evil use against me

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: You will employ it against him. What did he do to conceal it? He concealed you. Living image of himself, you will defeat the conspiracy of Mazarin and Anne of Austria. You, my prince, will have the same interest in concealing him, who will, as a prisoner, resemble you, as you will resemble him as a king.
children.prevalue: You will employ it against him What did he do to conceal it He concealed you Living image of himself you will defeat the conspiracy of Mazarin and Anne of Austria You my prince will have the same interest in concealing him who will as a prisoner resemble you as you will resemble him as a king

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: I fall back on what I was saying to you. Who will guard him?
children.prevalue: I fall back on what I was saying to you Who will guard him

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Who guarded you?
children.prevalue: Who guarded you

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: You know this secretyou have made use of it with regard to myself. Who else knows it?
children.prevalue: You know this secretyou have made use of it with regard to myself Who else knows it

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The queenmother and Madame de Chevreuse.
children.prevalue: The queenmother and Madame de Chevreuse

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: What will they do?
children.prevalue: What will they do

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Nothing, if you choose.
children.prevalue: Nothing if you choose

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: How is that?
children.prevalue: How is that

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: How can they recognize you, if you act in such a manner that no one can recognize you?
children.prevalue: How can they recognize you if you act in such a manner that no one can recognize you

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: 'Tis true but there are grave difficulties.
children.prevalue: Tis true but there are grave difficulties

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: State them, prince.
children.prevalue: State them prince

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: My brother is married I cannot take my brother's wife.
children.prevalue: My brother is married I cannot take my brother s wife

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I will cause Spain to consent to a divorce it is in the interest of your new policy it is human morality. All that is really noble and really useful in this world will find its account therein.
children.prevalue: I will cause Spain to consent to a divorce it is in the interest of your new policy it is human morality All that is really noble and really useful in this world will find its account therein

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The imprisoned king will speak.
children.prevalue: The imprisoned king will speak

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: To whom do you think he will speakto the walls?
children.prevalue: To whom do you think he will speakto the walls

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: You mean, by walls, the men in whom you put confidence.
children.prevalue: You mean by walls the men in whom you put confidence

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: If need be, yes. And besides, your royal highness
children.prevalue: If need be yes And besides your royal highness

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Besides?
children.prevalue: Besides

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I was going to say, that the designs of Providence do not stop on such a fair road. Every scheme of this caliber is completed by its results, like a geometrical calculation. The king, in prison, will not be for you the cause of embarrassment that you have been for the king enthroned. His soul is naturally proud and impatient it is, moreover, disarmed and enfeebled, by being accustomed to honors, and by the license of supreme power. The same Providence which has willed that the concluding step in the geometrical calculation I have had the honor of describing to your royal highness should be your ascension to the throne, and the destruction of him who is hurtful to you, has also determined that the conquered one shall soon end both his own and your sufferings. Therefore, his soul and body have been adapted for but a brief agony. Put into prison as a private individual, left alone with your doubts, deprived of everything, you have exhibited the most sublime, enduring principle of life in withstanding all this. But your brother, a captive, forgotten, and in bonds, will not long endure the calamity and Heaven will resume his soul at the appointed timethat is to say, soon.

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: At this point in Aramis's gloomy analysis, a bird of night uttered from the depths of the forest that prolonged and plaintive cry which makes every creature tremble.
children.prevalue: At this point in Aramis s gloomy analysis a bird of night uttered from the depths of the forest that prolonged and plaintive cry which makes every creature tremble

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I will exile the deposed king, said Philippe, shuddering 'twill be more human.
children.prevalue: I will exile the deposed king said Philippe shuddering twill be more human

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The king's good pleasure will decide the point, said Aramis. But has the problem been well put? Have I brought out of the solution according to the wishes or the foresight of your royal highness?
children.prevalue: The king s good pleasure will decide the point said Aramis But has the problem been well put Have I brought out of the solution according to the wishes or the foresight of your royal highness

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Yes, monsieur, yes you have forgotten nothingexcept, indeed, two things.
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur yes you have forgotten nothingexcept indeed two things

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The first?
children.prevalue: The first

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Let us speak of it at once, with the same frankness we have already conversed in. Let us speak of the causes which may bring about the ruin of all the hopes we have conceived. Let us speak of the risks we are running.
children.prevalue: Let us speak of it at once with the same frankness we have already conversed in Let us speak of the causes which may bring about the ruin of all the hopes we have conceived Let us speak of the risks we are running

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: They would be immense, infinite, terrific, insurmountable, if, as I have said, all things did not concur to render them of absolutely no account. There is no danger either for you or for me, if the constancy and intrepidity of your royal highness are equal to that perfection of resemblance to your brother which nature has bestowed upon you. I repeat it, there are no dangers, only obstacles a word, indeed, which I find in all languages, but have always illunderstood, and, were I king, would have obliterated as useless and absurd.
