children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: As for the king, his eyes filled with tears he dared not look at the queen. Anne of Austria, whose pride was superior to that of any creature breathing, overwhelmed her host by the contempt with which she treated everything handed to her. The young queen, kindhearted by nature and curious by disposition, praised Fouquet, ate with an exceedingly good appetite, and asked the names of the strange fruits as they were placed upon the table. Fouquet replied that he was not aware of their names. The fruits came from his own stores he had often cultivated them himself, having an intimate acquaintance with the cultivation of exotic fruits and plants. The king felt and appreciated the delicacy of the replies, but was only the more humiliated he thought the queen a little too familiar in her manners, and that Anne of Austria resembled Juno a little too much, in being too proud and haughty his chief anxiety, however, was himself, that he might remain cold and distant in his behavior, bordering lightly the limits of supreme disdain or simple admiration.
children.prevalue: As for the king his eyes filled with tears he dared not look at the queen Anne of Austria whose pride was superior to that of any creature breathing overwhelmed her host by the contempt with which she treated everything handed to her The young queen kindhearted by nature and curious by disposition praised Fouquet ate with an exceedingly good appetite and asked the names of the strange fruits as they were placed upon the table Fouquet replied that he was not aware of their names The fruits came from his own stores he had often cultivated them himself having an intimate acquaintance with the cultivation of exotic fruits and plants The king felt and appreciated the delicacy of the replies but was only the more humiliated he thought the queen a little too familiar in her manners and that Anne of Austria resembled Juno a little too much in being too proud and haughty his chief anxiety however was himself that he might remain cold and distant in his behavior bordering lightly the limits of supreme disdain or simple admiration

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: But Fouquet had foreseen all this he was, in fact, one of those men who foresee everything. The king had expressly declared that, so long as he remained under Fouquet's roof, he did not wish his own different repasts to be served in accordance with the usual etiquette, and that he would, consequently, dine with the rest of society but by the thoughtful attention of the surintendant, the king's dinner was served up separately, if one may so express it, in the middle of the general table the dinner, wonderful in every respect, from the dishes of which was composed, comprised everything the king liked and generally preferred to anything else. Louis had no excusehe, indeed, who had the keenest appetite in his kingdomfor saying that he was not hungry. Nay, M. Fouquet did even better still he certainly, in obedience to the king's expressed desire, seated himself at the table, but as soon as the soups were served, he arose and personally waited on the king, while Madame Fouquet stood behind the queenmother's armchair. The disdain of Juno and the sulky fits of temper of Jupiter could not resist this excess of kindly feeling and polite attention. The queen ate a biscuit dipped in a glass of SanLucar wine and the king ate of everything, saying to M. Fouquet: It is impossible, monsieur le surintendant, to dine better anywhere. Whereupon the whole court began, on all sides, to devour the dishes spread before them with such enthusiasm that it looked as though a cloud of Egyptian locusts was settling down on green and growing crops.

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: As soon, however, as his hunger was appeased, the king became morose and overgloomed again the more so in proportion to the satisfaction he fancied he had previously manifested, and particularly on account of the deferential manner which his courtiers had shown towards Fouquet. D'Artagnan, who ate a good deal and drank but little, without allowing it to be noticed, did not lose a single opportunity, but made a great number of observations which he turned to good profit.
children.prevalue: As soon however as his hunger was appeased the king became morose and overgloomed again the more so in proportion to the satisfaction he fancied he had previously manifested and particularly on account of the deferential manner which his courtiers had shown towards Fouquet D Artagnan who ate a good deal and drank but little without allowing it to be noticed did not lose a single opportunity but made a great number of observations which he turned to good profit

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: When the supper was finished, the king expressed a wish not to lose the promenade. The park was illuminated the moon, too, as if she had placed herself at the orders of the lord of Vaux, silvered the trees and lake with her own bright and quasiphosphorescent light. The air was strangely soft and balmy the daintily shellgravelled walks through the thickly set avenues yielded luxuriously to the feet. The fete was complete in every respect, for the king, having met La Valliere in one of the winding paths of the wood, was able to press her hand and say, I love you, without any one overhearing him except M. d'Artagnan, who followed, and M. Fouquet, who preceded him.

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The dreamy night of magical enchantments stole smoothly on. The king having requested to be shown to his room, there was immediately a movement in every direction. The queens passed to their own apartments, accompanied by them music of theorbos and lutes the king found his musketeers awaiting him on the grand flight of steps, for M. Fouquet had brought them on from Melun and had invited them to supper. D'Artagnan's suspicions at once disappeared. He was weary, he had supped well, and wished, for once in his life, thoroughly to enjoy a fete given by a man who was in every sense of the word a king. M. Fouquet, he said, is the man for me.

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The king was conducted with the greatest ceremony to the chamber of Morpheus, of which we owe some cursory description to our readers. It was the handsomest and largest in the palace. Lebrun had painted on the vaulted ceiling the happy as well as the unhappy dreams which Morpheus inflicts on kings as well as on other men. Everything that sleep gives birth to that is lovely, its fairy scenes, its flowers and nectar, the wild voluptuousness or profound repose of the senses, had the painter elaborated on his frescoes. It was a composition as soft and pleasing in one part as dark and gloomy and terrible in another. The poisoned chalice, the glittering dagger suspended over the head of the sleeper wizards and phantoms with terrific masks, those halfdim shadows more alarming than the approach of fire or the somber face of midnight, these, and such as these, he had made the companions of his more pleasing pictures. No sooner had the king entered his room than a cold shiver seemed to pass through him, and on Fouquet asking him the cause of it, the king replied, as pale as death:

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: D'Artagnan had determined to lose no time, and in fact he never was in the habit of doing so. After having inquired for Aramis, he had looked for him in every direction until he had succeeded in finding him. Besides, no sooner had the king entered Vaux, than Aramis had retired to his own room, meditating, doubtless, some new piece of gallant attention for his majesty's amusement. D'Artagnan desired the servants to announce him, and found on the second story (in a beautiful room called the Blue Chamber, on account of the color of its hangings) the bishop of Vannes in company with Porthos and several of the modern Epicureans. Aramis came forward to embrace his friend, and offered him the best seat. As it was after awhile generally remarked among those present that the musketeer was reserved, and wished for an opportunity for conversing secretly with Aramis, the Epicureans took their leave. Porthos, however, did not stir for true it is that, having dined exceedingly well, he was fast asleep in his armchair and the freedom of conversation therefore was not interrupted by a third person. Porthos had a deep, harmonious snore, and people might talk in the midst of its loud bass without fear of disturbing him. D'Artagnan felt that he was called upon to open the conversation.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan had determined to lose no time and in fact he never was in the habit of doing so After having inquired for Aramis he had looked for him in every direction until he had succeeded in finding him Besides no sooner had the king entered Vaux than Aramis had retired to his own room meditating doubtless some new piece of gallant attention for his majesty s amusement D Artagnan desired the servants to announce him and found on the second story in a beautiful room called the Blue Chamber on account of the color of its hangings the bishop of Vannes in company with Porthos and several of the modern Epicureans Aramis came forward to embrace his friend and offered him the best seat As it was after awhile generally remarked among those present that the musketeer was reserved and wished for an opportunity for conversing secretly with Aramis the Epicureans took their leave Porthos however did not stir for true it is that having dined exceedingly well he was fast asleep in his armchair and the freedom of conversation therefore was not interrupted by a third person Porthos had a deep harmonious snore and people might talk in the midst of its loud bass without fear of disturbing him D Artagnan felt that he was called upon to open the conversation

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Well, and so we have come to Vaux, he said.
children.prevalue: Well and so we have come to Vaux he said

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Why, yes, D'Artagnan. And how do you like the place?
children.prevalue: Why yes D Artagnan And how do you like the place

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Very much, and I like M. Fouquet, also.
children.prevalue: Very much and I like M Fouquet also

children.prevalue: Is he not a charming host

children.prevalue: No one could be more so

children.name: Paragraph_7

children.prevalue: I am told that the king began by showing great distance of manner towards M Fouquet but that his majesty grew much more cordial afterwards

children.prevalue: You did not notice it then since you say you have been told so

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: No I was engaged with the gentlemen who have just left the room about the theatrical performances and the tournaments which are to take place tomorrow.
children.prevalue: No I was engaged with the gentlemen who have just left the room about the theatrical performances and the tournaments which are to take place tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Ah, indeed! you are the comptrollergeneral of the fetes here, then?
children.prevalue: Ah indeed you are the comptrollergeneral of the fetes here then

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: You know I am a friend of all kinds of amusement where the exercise of the imagination is called into activity I have always been a poet in one way or another.
children.prevalue: You know I am a friend of all kinds of amusement where the exercise of the imagination is called into activity I have always been a poet in one way or another

children.prevalue: Yes I remember the verses you used to write they were charming

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I have forgotten them, but I am delighted to read the verses of others, when those others are known by the names of Moliere, Pelisson, La Fontaine, etc.

children.name: Paragraph_14

children.prevalue: Do you know what idea occurred to me this evening Aramis

children.prevalue: No tell me what it was for I should never be able to guess it you have so many

children.prevalue: Well the idea occurred to me that the true king of France is not Louis XIV

children.prevalue: Quite true

children.prevalue: When I think too added the bishop that that fellow will be your minister within four months and that you will serve him as blindly as you did Richelieu or Mazarin

children.prevalue: With this difference though that M Fouquet is not M Colbert

children.prevalue: True true said D Artagnan as he pretended to become sad and full of reflection and then a moment after he added Why do you tell me that M Colbert will be minister in four months

children.prevalue: Because M Fouquet will have ceased to be so replied Aramis

children.prevalue: He will be ruined you mean said D Artagnan

children.prevalue: Completely so

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Why does he give these fetes, then? said the musketeer, in a tone so full of thoughtful consideration, and so well assumed, that the bishop was for the moment deceived by it. Why did you not dissuade him from it?
children.prevalue: Why does he give these fetes then said the musketeer in a tone so full of thoughtful consideration and so well assumed that the bishop was for the moment deceived by it Why did you not dissuade him from it

children.prevalue: Yes by ruining himself for the king

children.prevalue: Necessity necessity my friend

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I don't see that, dear Aramis.
children.prevalue: I don t see that dear Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Do you not? Have you not remarked M. Colbert's daily increasing antagonism, and that he is doing his utmost to drive the king to get rid of the superintendent?
children.prevalue: Do you not Have you not remarked M Colbert s daily increasing antagonism and that he is doing his utmost to drive the king to get rid of the superintendent

children.value: One must be blind not to see it.
children.prevalue: One must be blind not to see it

children.prevalue: And that a cabal is already armed against M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: That is well known.
children.prevalue: That is well known

children.name: Paragraph_40

children.prevalue: What likelihood is there that the king would join a party formed against a man who will have spent everything he had to please him

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: True, true, said D'Artagnan, slowly, hardly convinced, yet curious to broach another phase of the conversation. There are follies, and follies, he resumed, and I do not like those you are committing.
children.prevalue: True true said D Artagnan slowly hardly convinced yet curious to broach another phase of the conversation There are follies and follies he resumed and I do not like those you are committing

children.name: Paragraph_42

children.prevalue: What do you allude to

children.value: As for the banquet, the ball, the concert, the theatricals, the tournaments, the cascades, the fireworks, the illuminations, and the presentsthese are well and good, I grant but why were not these expenses sufficient? Why was it necessary to have new liveries and costumes for your whole household?

children.value: You are quite right. I told M. Fouquet that myself he replied, that if he were rich enough he would offer the king a newly erected chateau, from the vanes at the houses to the very subcellars completely new inside and out and that, as soon as the king had left, he would burn the whole building and its contents, in order that it might not be made use of by any one else.

children.prevalue: How completely Spanish

children.prevalue: I told him so and he then added this Whoever advises me to spare expense I shall look upon as my enemy

children.prevalue: What surprise

children.value: The surprise you seem to have in view, and on account of which you took some specimens away, when I met you at Percerin's. D'Artagnan paused. The shaft was discharged, and all he had to do was to wait and watch its effect.
children.prevalue: The surprise you seem to have in view and on account of which you took some specimens away when I met you at Percerin s D Artagnan paused The shaft was discharged and all he had to do was to wait and watch its effect

children.prevalue: That is merely an act of graceful attention replied Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: D'Artagnan went up to his friend, took hold of both his hands, and looking him full in the eyes, said, Aramis, do you still care for me a very little?

children.prevalue: Very good One favor then Why did you take some patterns of the king s costumes at Percerin s

children.prevalue: Upon my word D Artagnan you astonish me

children.prevalue: Be a little considerate Tell me the exact truth you would not like anything disagreeable to happen to me would you

children.prevalue: My dear friend you are becoming quite incomprehensible What suspicion can you have possibly got hold of

children.value: Do you believe in my instinctive feelings? Formerly you used to have faith in them. Well, then, an instinct tells me that you have some concealed project on foot.

children.prevalue: I am not only sure of it but I would even swear it

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Indeed, D'Artagnan, you cause me the greatest pain. Is it likely, if I have any project in hand that I ought to keep secret from you, I should tell you about it? If I had one that I could and ought to have revealed, should I not have long ago divulged it?
children.prevalue: Indeed D Artagnan you cause me the greatest pain Is it likely if I have any project in hand that I ought to keep secret from you I should tell you about it If I had one that I could and ought to have revealed should I not have long ago divulged it

children.value: No, Aramis, no. There are certain projects which are never revealed until the favorable opportunity arrives.

children.value: In that case, my dear fellow, returned the bishop, laughing, the only thing now is, that the 'opportunity' has not yet arrived.

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: D'Artagnan shook his head with a sorrowful expression. Oh, friendship, friendship! he said, what an idle word you are! Here is a man who, if I were but to ask it, would suffer himself to be cut in pieces for my sake.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan shook his head with a sorrowful expression Oh friendship friendship he said what an idle word you are Here is a man who if I were but to ask it would suffer himself to be cut in pieces for my sake

children.value: You are right, said Aramis, nobly.
children.prevalue: You are right said Aramis nobly

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: And this man, who would shed every drop of blood in his veins for me, will not open up before me the least corner in his heart. Friendship, I repeat, is nothing but an unsubstantial shadowa lure, like everything else in this bright, dazzling world.
children.prevalue: And this man who would shed every drop of blood in his veins for me will not open up before me the least corner in his heart Friendship I repeat is nothing but an unsubstantial shadowa lure like everything else in this bright dazzling world

children.value: It is not thus you should speak of our friendship, replied the bishop, in a firm, assured voice for ours is not of the same nature as those of which you have been speaking.
children.prevalue: It is not thus you should speak of our friendship replied the bishop in a firm assured voice for ours is not of the same nature as those of which you have been speaking

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Look at us, Aramis three out of the old 'four.' You are deceiving me I suspect you and Porthos is fast asleep. An admirable trio of friends, don't you think so? What an affecting relic of the former dear old times!

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: I can only tell you one thing, D'Artagnan, and I swear it on the Bible: I love you just as I used to do. If I ever suspect you, it is on account of others, and not on account of either of us. In everything I may do, and should happen to succeed in, you will find your fourth. Will you promise me the same favor?

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Such a thing is very possible.
children.prevalue: Such a thing is very possible

children.value: You are conspiring against M. Colbert. If that be all, mordioux, tell me so at once. I have the instrument in my own hand, and will pull out the tooth easily enough.
children.prevalue: You are conspiring against M Colbert If that be all mordioux tell me so at once I have the instrument in my own hand and will pull out the tooth easily enough

children.value: Aramis could not conceal a smile of disdain that flitted over his haughty features. And supposing that I were conspiring against Colbert, what harm would there be in that?

Aramis, we are not enemies, rememberwe are brothers. Tell me what you wish to undertake, and, upon the word of a D'Artagnan, if I cannot help you, I will swear to remain neuter.

children.prevalue: I am undertaking nothing said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Aramis, a voice within me speaks and seems to trickle forth a rill of light within my darkness: it is a voice that has never yet deceived me. It is the king you are conspiring against.
children.prevalue: Aramis a voice within me speaks and seems to trickle forth a rill of light within my darkness it is a voice that has never yet deceived me It is the king you are conspiring against

children.prevalue: Aramis I will do more than help youI will do more than remain neuterI will save you

children.prevalue: You are mad D Artagnan

children.prevalue: You to suspect me of wishing to assassinate the king

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Well, let us understand one another. I do not see what any one can do to a legitimate king as ours is, if he does not assassinate him. D'Artagnan did not say a word. Besides, you have your guards and your musketeers here, said the bishop.

children.value: True.
children.prevalue: True

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: You are not in M. Fouquet's house, but in your own.
children.prevalue: You are not in M Fouquet s house but in your own

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: True but in spite of that, Aramis, grant me, for pity's sake, one single word of a true friend.
children.prevalue: True but in spite of that Aramis grant me for pity s sake one single word of a true friend

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: A true friend's word is ever truth itself. If I think of touching, even with my finger, the son of Anne of Austria, the true king of this realm of Franceif I have not the firm intention of prostrating myself before his throneif in every idea I may entertain tomorrow, here at Vaux, will not be the most glorious day my king ever enjoyedmay Heaven's lightning blast me where I stand! Aramis had pronounced these words with his face turned towards the alcove of his own bedroom, where D'Artagnan, seated with his back towards the alcove, could not suspect that any one was lying concealed. The earnestness of his words, the studied slowness with which he pronounced them, the solemnity of his oath, gave the musketeer the most complete satisfaction. He took hold of both Aramis's hands, and shook them cordially. Aramis had endured reproaches without turning pale, and had blushed as he listened to words of praise. D'Artagnan, deceived, did him honor but D'Artagnan, trustful and reliant, made him feel ashamed. Are you going away? he said, as he embraced him, in order to conceal the flush on his face.
children.prevalue: A true friend s word is ever truth itself If I think of touching even with my finger the son of Anne of Austria the true king of this realm of Franceif I have not the firm intention of prostrating myself before his throneif in every idea I may entertain tomorrow here at Vaux will not be the most glorious day my king ever enjoyedmay Heaven s lightning blast me where I stand Aramis had pronounced these words with his face turned towards the alcove of his own bedroom where D Artagnan seated with his back towards the alcove could not suspect that any one was lying concealed The earnestness of his words the studied slowness with which he pronounced them the solemnity of his oath gave the musketeer the most complete satisfaction He took hold of both Aramis s hands and shook them cordially Aramis had endured reproaches without turning pale and had blushed as he listened to words of praise D Artagnan deceived did him honor but D Artagnan trustful and reliant made him feel ashamed Are you going away he said as he embraced him in order to conceal the flush on his face

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Yes. Duty summons me. I have to get the watchword. It seems I am to be lodged in the king's anteroom. Where does Porthos sleep?
children.prevalue: Yes Duty summons me I have to get the watchword It seems I am to be lodged in the king s anteroom Where does Porthos sleep

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Take him away with you, if you like, for he rumbles through his sleepy nose like a park of artillery.
children.prevalue: Take him away with you if you like for he rumbles through his sleepy nose like a park of artillery

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Ah! he does not stay with you, then? said D'Artagnan.

children.value: Not the least in the world. He has a chamber to himself, but I don't know where.

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Very good! said the musketeer from whom this separation of the two associates removed his last suspicion, and he touched Porthos lightly on the shoulder the latter replied by a loud yawn. Come, said D'Artagnan.

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: What, D'Artagnan, my dear fellow, is that you? What a lucky chance! Oh, yestrue I have forgotten I am at the fete at Vaux.
children.prevalue: What D Artagnan my dear fellow is that you What a lucky chance Oh yestrue I have forgotten I am at the fete at Vaux

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Yes and your beautiful dress, too.
children.prevalue: Yes and your beautiful dress too

children.prevalue: Yes it was very attentive on the part of Monsieur Coquelin de Voliere was it not

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Hush! said Aramis. You are walking so heavily you will make the flooring give way.
children.prevalue: Hush said Aramis You are walking so heavily you will make the flooring give way

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: True, said the musketeer this room is above the dome, I think.
children.prevalue: True said the musketeer this room is above the dome I think

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: And I did not choose it for a fencingroom, I assure you, added the bishop. The ceiling of the king's room has all the lightness and calm of wholesome sleep. Do not forget, therefore, that my flooring is merely the covering of his ceiling. Good night, my friends, and in ten minutes I shall be asleep myself. And Aramis accompanied them to the door, laughing quietly all the while. As soon as they were outside, he bolted the door, hurriedly closed up the chinks of the windows, and then called out, Monseigneur!monseigneur! Philippe made his appearance from the alcove, as he pushed aside a sliding panel placed behind the bed.
children.prevalue: And I did not choose it for a fencingroom I assure you added the bishop The ceiling of the king s room has all the lightness and calm of wholesome sleep Do not forget therefore that my flooring is merely the covering of his ceiling Good night my friends and in ten minutes I shall be asleep myself And Aramis accompanied them to the door laughing quietly all the while As soon as they were outside he bolted the door hurriedly closed up the chinks of the windows and then called out Monseigneur monseigneur Philippe made his appearance from the alcove as he pushed aside a sliding panel placed behind the bed

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: M. d'Artagnan entertains a great many suspicions, it seems, he said.
children.prevalue: M d Artagnan entertains a great many suspicions it seems he said

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Ah!you recognized M. d'Artagnan, then?
children.prevalue: Ah you recognized M d Artagnan then

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Before you called him by his name, even.
children.prevalue: Before you called him by his name even

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: He is your captain of musketeers.
children.prevalue: He is your captain of musketeers

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: He is very devoted to me, replied Philippe, laying a stress upon the personal pronoun.
children.prevalue: He is very devoted to me replied Philippe laying a stress upon the personal pronoun

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: As faithful as a dog but he bites sometimes. If D'Artagnan does not recognize you before the other has disappeared, rely upon D'Artagnan to the end of the world for in that case, if he has seen nothing, he will keep his fidelity. If he sees, when it is too late, he is a Gascon, and will never admit that he has been deceived.
children.prevalue: As faithful as a dog but he bites sometimes If D Artagnan does not recognize you before the other has disappeared rely upon D Artagnan to the end of the world for in that case if he has seen nothing he will keep his fidelity If he sees when it is too late he is a Gascon and will never admit that he has been deceived

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: I thought so. What are we to do, now?
children.prevalue: I thought so What are we to do now

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Sit in this foldingchair. I am going to push aside a portion of the flooring you will look through the opening, which answers to one of the false windows made in the dome of the king's apartment. Can you see?
children.prevalue: Sit in this foldingchair I am going to push aside a portion of the flooring you will look through the opening which answers to one of the false windows made in the dome of the king s apartment Can you see

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Yes, said Philippe, starting as at the sight of an enemy I see the king!
children.prevalue: Yes said Philippe starting as at the sight of an enemy I see the king

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: What is he doing?
children.prevalue: What is he doing

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: He seems to wish some man to sit down close to him.
children.prevalue: He seems to wish some man to sit down close to him

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: M. Fouquet?
children.prevalue: M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: No, no wait a moment
children.prevalue: No no wait a moment

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Look at the notes and the portraits, my prince.
children.prevalue: Look at the notes and the portraits my prince

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: The man whom the king wishes to sit down in his presence is M. Colbert.
children.prevalue: The man whom the king wishes to sit down in his presence is M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Colbert sit down in the king's presence! exclaimed Aramis. It is impossible.
children.prevalue: Colbert sit down in the king s presence exclaimed Aramis It is impossible

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: Look.
children.prevalue: Look

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Aramis looked through the opening in the flooring. Yes, he said. Colbert himself. Oh, monseigneur! what can we be going to hearand what can result from this intimacy?
children.prevalue: Aramis looked through the opening in the flooring Yes he said Colbert himself Oh monseigneur what can we be going to hearand what can result from this intimacy

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Nothing good for M. Fouquet, at all events.
children.prevalue: Nothing good for M Fouquet at all events

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: The prince did not deceive himself.
children.prevalue: The prince did not deceive himself

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: We have seen that Louis XIV. had sent for Colbert, and Colbert had arrived. The conversation began between them by the king according to him one of the highest favors that he had ever done it was true the king was alone with his subject. Colbert, said he, sit down.
children.prevalue: We have seen that Louis XIV had sent for Colbert and Colbert had arrived The conversation began between them by the king according to him one of the highest favors that he had ever done it was true the king was alone with his subject Colbert said he sit down

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: The intendant, overcome with delight, for he feared he was about to be dismissed, refused this unprecedented honor.
children.prevalue: The intendant overcome with delight for he feared he was about to be dismissed refused this unprecedented honor

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Does he accept? said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Does he accept said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: No, he remains standing.
children.prevalue: No he remains standing

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: Let us listen, then. And the future king and the future pope listened eagerly to the simple mortals they held under their feet, ready to crush them when they liked.
children.prevalue: Let us listen then And the future king and the future pope listened eagerly to the simple mortals they held under their feet ready to crush them when they liked

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Colbert, said the king, you have annoyed me exceedingly today.
children.prevalue: Colbert said the king you have annoyed me exceedingly today

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: I know it, sire.
children.prevalue: I know it sire

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: Very good I like that answer.  Yes, you knew it, and there was courage in the doing of it.
children.prevalue: Very good I like that answer Yes you knew it and there was courage in the doing of it

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: I ran the risk of displeasing your majesty, but I risked, also, the concealment of your best interests.
children.prevalue: I ran the risk of displeasing your majesty but I risked also the concealment of your best interests

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: What! you were afraid of something on my account?
children.prevalue: What you were afraid of something on my account

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: I was, sire, even if it were nothing more than an indigestion, said Colbert for people do not give their sovereigns such banquets as the one of today, unless it be to stifle them beneath the burden of good living. Colbert awaited the effect this coarse jest would produce upon the king and Louis XIV., who was the vainest and the most fastidiously delicate man in his kingdom, forgave Colbert the joke.
children.prevalue: I was sire even if it were nothing more than an indigestion said Colbert for people do not give their sovereigns such banquets as the one of today unless it be to stifle them beneath the burden of good living Colbert awaited the effect this coarse jest would produce upon the king and Louis XIV who was the vainest and the most fastidiously delicate man in his kingdom forgave Colbert the joke

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: The truth is, he said, that M. Fouquet has given me too good a meal. Tell me, Colbert, where does he get all the money required for this enormous expenditure,can you tell?
children.prevalue: The truth is he said that M Fouquet has given me too good a meal Tell me Colbert where does he get all the money required for this enormous expenditure can you tell

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: Yes, I do know, sire.
children.prevalue: Yes I do know sire

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: Will you be able to prove it with tolerable certainty?
children.prevalue: Will you be able to prove it with tolerable certainty

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: Easily and to the utmost farthing.
children.prevalue: Easily and to the utmost farthing

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: I know you are very exact.
children.prevalue: I know you are very exact

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: Exactitude is the principal qualification required in an intendant of finances.
children.prevalue: Exactitude is the principal qualification required in an intendant of finances

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: But all are not so.
children.prevalue: But all are not so

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: I thank you majesty for so flattering a compliment from your own lips.
children.prevalue: I thank you majesty for so flattering a compliment from your own lips

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: M. Fouquet, therefore, is richvery rich, and I suppose every man knows he is so.
children.prevalue: M Fouquet therefore is richvery rich and I suppose every man knows he is so

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: Every one, sire the living as well as the dead.
children.prevalue: Every one sire the living as well as the dead

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: What does that mean, Monsieur Colbert?
children.prevalue: What does that mean Monsieur Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: The living are witnesses of M. Fouquet's wealth,they admire and applaud the result produced but the dead, wiser and better informed than we are, know how that wealth was obtainedand they rise up in accusation.
children.prevalue: The living are witnesses of M Fouquet s wealth they admire and applaud the result produced but the dead wiser and better informed than we are know how that wealth was obtainedand they rise up in accusation

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: So that M. Fouquet owes his wealth to some cause or other.
children.prevalue: So that M Fouquet owes his wealth to some cause or other

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: The occupation of an intendant very often favors those who practice it.
children.prevalue: The occupation of an intendant very often favors those who practice it

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: You have something to say to me more confidentially, I perceive do not be afraid, we are quite alone.
children.prevalue: You have something to say to me more confidentially I perceive do not be afraid we are quite alone

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: I am never afraid of anything under the shelter of my own conscience, and under the protection of your majesty, said Colbert, bowing.
children.prevalue: I am never afraid of anything under the shelter of my own conscience and under the protection of your majesty said Colbert bowing

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: If the dead, therefore, were to speak
children.prevalue: If the dead therefore were to speak

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: They do speak sometimes, sire,read.
children.prevalue: They do speak sometimes sire read

children.name: Paragraph_155
children.value: Ah! murmured Aramis, in the prince's ear, who, close beside him, listened without losing a syllable, since you are placed here, monseigneur, in order to learn your vocation of a king, listen to a piece of infamyof a nature truly royal. You are about to be a witness of one of those scenes which the foul fiend alone conceives and executes. Listen attentively,you will find your advantage in it.
children.prevalue: Ah murmured Aramis in the prince s ear who close beside him listened without losing a syllable since you are placed here monseigneur in order to learn your vocation of a king listen to a piece of infamyof a nature truly royal You are about to be a witness of one of those scenes which the foul fiend alone conceives and executes Listen attentively you will find your advantage in it

children.name: Paragraph_156
children.value: The prince redoubled his attention, and saw Louis XIV. take from Colbert's hands a letter the latter held out to him.
children.prevalue: The prince redoubled his attention and saw Louis XIV take from Colbert s hands a letter the latter held out to him

children.name: Paragraph_157
children.value: The late cardinal's handwriting, said the king.
children.prevalue: The late cardinal s handwriting said the king

children.name: Paragraph_158
children.value: Your majesty has an excellent memory, replied Colbert, bowing it is an immense advantage for a king who is destined for hard work to recognize handwritings at the first glance.
children.prevalue: Your majesty has an excellent memory replied Colbert bowing it is an immense advantage for a king who is destined for hard work to recognize handwritings at the first glance

children.name: Paragraph_159
children.value: The king read Mazarin's letter, and, as its contents are already known to the reader, in consequence of the misunderstanding between Madame de Chevreuse and Aramis, nothing further would be learned if we stated them here again.
children.prevalue: The king read Mazarin s letter and as its contents are already known to the reader in consequence of the misunderstanding between Madame de Chevreuse and Aramis nothing further would be learned if we stated them here again

children.name: Paragraph_160
children.value: I do not quite understand, said the king, greatly interested.
children.prevalue: I do not quite understand said the king greatly interested

children.name: Paragraph_161
children.value: Your majesty has not acquired the utilitarian habit of checking the public accounts.
children.prevalue: Your majesty has not acquired the utilitarian habit of checking the public accounts

children.name: Paragraph_162
children.value: I see that it refers to money that had been given to M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: I see that it refers to money that had been given to M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_163
children.value: Thirteen millions. A tolerably good sum.
children.prevalue: Thirteen millions A tolerably good sum

children.name: Paragraph_164
children.value: Yes. Well, these thirteen millions are wanting to balance the total of the account. That is what I do not very well understand. How was this deficit possible?
children.prevalue: Yes Well these thirteen millions are wanting to balance the total of the account That is what I do not very well understand How was this deficit possible

children.name: Paragraph_165
children.value: Possible I do not say but there is no doubt about fact that it is really so.
children.prevalue: Possible I do not say but there is no doubt about fact that it is really so

children.name: Paragraph_166
children.value: You say that these thirteen millions are found to be wanting in the accounts?
children.prevalue: You say that these thirteen millions are found to be wanting in the accounts

children.name: Paragraph_167
children.value: I do not say so, but the registry does.
children.prevalue: I do not say so but the registry does

children.name: Paragraph_168
children.value: And this letter of M. Mazarin indicates the employment of that sum and the name of the person with whom it was deposited?
children.prevalue: And this letter of M Mazarin indicates the employment of that sum and the name of the person with whom it was deposited

children.name: Paragraph_169
children.value: As your majesty can judge for yourself.
children.prevalue: As your majesty can judge for yourself

children.name: Paragraph_170
children.value: Yes and the result is, then, that M. Fouquet has not yet restored the thirteen millions.
children.prevalue: Yes and the result is then that M Fouquet has not yet restored the thirteen millions

children.name: Paragraph_171
children.value: That results from the accounts, certainly, sire.
children.prevalue: That results from the accounts certainly sire

children.name: Paragraph_172
children.value: Well, and, consequently
children.prevalue: Well and consequently

children.name: Paragraph_173
children.value: Well, sire, in that case, inasmuch as M. Fouquet has not yet given back the thirteen millions, he must have appropriated them to his own purpose and with those thirteen millions one could incur four times and a little more as much expense, and make four times as great a display, as your majesty was able to do at Fontainebleau, where we only spent three millions altogether, if you remember.
children.prevalue: Well sire in that case inasmuch as M Fouquet has not yet given back the thirteen millions he must have appropriated them to his own purpose and with those thirteen millions one could incur four times and a little more as much expense and make four times as great a display as your majesty was able to do at Fontainebleau where we only spent three millions altogether if you remember

children.name: Paragraph_174
children.value: For a blunderer, the souvenir he had evoked was a rather skillfully contrived piece of baseness for by the remembrance of his own fete he, for the first time, perceived its inferiority compared with that of Fouquet. Colbert received back again at Vaux what Fouquet had given him at Fontainebleau, and, as a good financier, returned it with the best possible interest. Having once disposed the king's mind in this artful way, Colbert had nothing of much importance to detain him. He felt that such was the case, for the king, too, had again sunk into a dull and gloomy state. Colbert awaited the first words from the king's lips with as much impatience as Philippe and Aramis did from their place of observation.

children.name: Paragraph_175
children.value: Are you aware what is the usual and natural consequence of all this, Monsieur Colbert? said the king, after a few moments' reflection.
children.prevalue: Are you aware what is the usual and natural consequence of all this Monsieur Colbert said the king after a few moments reflection

children.name: Paragraph_176
children.value: No, sire, I do not know.
children.prevalue: No sire I do not know

children.name: Paragraph_177
children.value: Well, then, the fact of the appropriation of the thirteen millions, if it can be proved
children.prevalue: Well then the fact of the appropriation of the thirteen millions if it can be proved

children.name: Paragraph_178
children.value: But it is so already.
children.prevalue: But it is so already

children.name: Paragraph_179
children.value: I mean if it were to be declared and certified, M. Colbert.
children.prevalue: I mean if it were to be declared and certified M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_180
children.value: I think it will be tomorrow, if your majesty
children.prevalue: I think it will be tomorrow if your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_181
children.value: Were we not under M. Fouquet's roof, you were going to say, perhaps, replied the king, with something of nobility in his demeanor.
children.prevalue: Were we not under M Fouquet s roof you were going to say perhaps replied the king with something of nobility in his demeanor

children.name: Paragraph_182
children.value: The king is in his own palace wherever he may beespecially in houses which the royal money has constructed.
children.prevalue: The king is in his own palace wherever he may beespecially in houses which the royal money has constructed

children.name: Paragraph_183
children.value: I think, said Philippe in a low tone to Aramis, that the architect who planned this dome ought, anticipating the use it could be put to at a future opportunity, so to have contrived that it might be made to fall upon the heads of scoundrels such as M. Colbert.
children.prevalue: I think said Philippe in a low tone to Aramis that the architect who planned this dome ought anticipating the use it could be put to at a future opportunity so to have contrived that it might be made to fall upon the heads of scoundrels such as M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_184
children.value: I think so too, replied Aramis but M. Colbert is so very near the king at this moment.
children.prevalue: I think so too replied Aramis but M Colbert is so very near the king at this moment

children.name: Paragraph_185
children.value: That is true, and that would open the succession.
children.prevalue: That is true and that would open the succession

children.name: Paragraph_186
children.value: Of which your younger brother would reap all the advantage, monseigneur. But stay, let us keep quiet, and go on listening.
children.prevalue: Of which your younger brother would reap all the advantage monseigneur But stay let us keep quiet and go on listening

children.name: Paragraph_187
children.value: We shall not have long to listen, said the young prince.
children.prevalue: We shall not have long to listen said the young prince

children.name: Paragraph_188
children.value: Why not, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: Why not monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_189
children.value: Because, if I were king, I should make no further reply.
children.prevalue: Because if I were king I should make no further reply

children.name: Paragraph_190
children.value: And what would you do?
children.prevalue: And what would you do

children.name: Paragraph_191
children.value: I should wait until tomorrow morning to give myself time for reflection.
children.prevalue: I should wait until tomorrow morning to give myself time for reflection

children.name: Paragraph_192
children.value: Louis XIV. at last raised his eyes, and finding Colbert attentively waiting for his next remarks, said, hastily, changing the conversation, M. Colbert, I perceive it is getting very late, and I shall now retire to bed. By tomorrow morning I shall have made up my mind.
children.prevalue: Louis XIV at last raised his eyes and finding Colbert attentively waiting for his next remarks said hastily changing the conversation M Colbert I perceive it is getting very late and I shall now retire to bed By tomorrow morning I shall have made up my mind

children.name: Paragraph_193
children.value: Very good, sire, returned Colbert, greatly incensed, although he restrained himself in the presence of the king.
children.prevalue: Very good sire returned Colbert greatly incensed although he restrained himself in the presence of the king

children.name: Paragraph_194
children.value: The king made a gesture of adieu, and Colbert withdrew with a respectful bow. My attendants! cried the king and, as they entered the apartment, Philippe was about to quit his post of observation.
children.prevalue: The king made a gesture of adieu and Colbert withdrew with a respectful bow My attendants cried the king and as they entered the apartment Philippe was about to quit his post of observation

children.name: Paragraph_195
children.value: A moment longer, said Aramis to him, with his accustomed gentleness of manner what has just now taken place is only a detail, and tomorrow we shall have no occasion to think anything more about it but the ceremony of the king's retiring to rest, the etiquette observed in addressing the king, that indeed is of the greatest importance. Learn, sire, and study well how you ought to go to bed of a night. Look! look!
children.prevalue: A moment longer said Aramis to him with his accustomed gentleness of manner what has just now taken place is only a detail and tomorrow we shall have no occasion to think anything more about it but the ceremony of the king s retiring to rest the etiquette observed in addressing the king that indeed is of the greatest importance Learn sire and study well how you ought to go to bed of a night Look look

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: History will tell us, or rather history has told us, of the various events of the following day, of the splendid fetes given by the surintendant to his sovereign. Nothing but amusement and delight was allowed to prevail throughout the whole of the following day there was a promenade, a banquet, a comedy to be acted, and a comedy, too, in which, to his great amazement, Porthos recognized M. Coquelin de Voliere as one of the actors, in the piece called Les Facheux. Full of preoccupation, however, from the scene of the previous evening, and hardly recovered from the effects of the poison which Colbert had then administered to him, the king, during the whole of the day, so brilliant in its effects, so full of unexpected and startling novelties, in which all the wonders of the Arabian Night's Entertainments seemed to be reproduced for his especial amusementthe king, we say, showed himself cold, reserved, and taciturn. Nothing could smooth the frowns upon his face every one who observed him noticed that a deep feeling of resentment, of remote origin, increased by slow degrees, as the source becomes a river, thanks to the thousand threads of water that increase its body, was keenly alive in the depths of the king's heart. Towards the middle of the day only did he begin to resume a little serenity of manner, and by that time he had, in all probability, made up his mind. Aramis, who followed him step by step in his thoughts, as in his walk, concluded that the event he was expecting would not be long before it was announced. This time Colbert seemed to walk in concert with the bishop of Vannes, and had he received for every annoyance which he inflicted on the king a word of direction from Aramis, he could not have done better. During the whole of the day the king, who, in all probability, wished to free himself from some of the thoughts which disturbed his mind, seemed to seek La Valliere's society as actively as he seemed to show his anxiety to flee that of M. Colbert or M. Fouquet. The evening came. The king had expressed a wish not to walk in the park until after cards in the evening. In the interval between supper and the promenade, cards and dice were introduced. The king won a thousand pistoles, and, having won them, put them in his pocket, and then rose, saying, And now, gentlemen, to the park. He found the ladies of the court were already there. The king, we have before observed, had won a thousand pistoles, and had put them in his pocket but M. Fouquet had somehow contrived to lose ten thousand, so that among the courtiers there was still left a hundred and ninety thousand francs' profit to divide, a circumstance which made the countenances of the courtiers and the officers of the king's household the most joyous countenances in the world. It was not the same, however, with the king's face for, notwithstanding his success at play, to which he was by no means insensible, there still remained a slight shade of dissatisfaction. Colbert was waiting for or upon him at the corner of one of the avenues he was most probably waiting there in consequence of a rendezvous which had been given him by the king, as Louis XIV., who had avoided him, or who had seemed to avoid him, suddenly made him a sign, and they then struck into the depths of the park together. But La Valliere, too, had observed the king's gloomy aspect and kindling glances she had remarked thisand as nothing which lay hidden or smoldering in his heart was hidden from the gaze of her affection, she understood that this repressed wrath menaced some one she prepared to withstand the current of his vengeance, and intercede like an angel of mercy. Overcome by sadness, nervously agitated, deeply distressed at having been so long separated from her lover, disturbed at the sight of the emotion she had divined, she accordingly presented herself to the king with an embarrassed aspect, which in his then disposition of mind the king interpreted unfavorably. Then, as they were alonenearly alone, inasmuch as Colbert, as soon as he perceived the young girl approaching, had stopped and drawn back a dozen pacesthe king advanced towards La Valliere and took her by the hand. Mademoiselle, he said to her, should I be guilty of an indiscretion if I were to inquire if you were indisposed? for you seem to breathe as if you were oppressed by some secret cause of uneasiness, and your eyes are filled with tears.

face for notwithstanding his success at play to which he was by no means insensible there still remained a slight shade of dissatisfaction Colbert was waiting for or upon him at the corner of one of the avenues he was most probably waiting there in consequence of a rendezvous which had been given him by the king as Louis XIV who had avoided him or who had seemed to avoid him suddenly made him a sign and they then struck into the depths of the park together But La Valliere too had observed the king s gloomy aspect and kindling glances she had remarked thisand as nothing which lay hidden or smoldering in his heart was hidden from the gaze of her affection she understood that this repressed wrath menaced some one she prepared to withstand the current of his vengeance and intercede like an angel of mercy Overcome by sadness nervously agitated deeply distressed at having been so long separated from her lover disturbed at the sight of the emotion she had divined she accordingly presented herself to the king with an embarrassed aspect which in his then disposition of mind the king interpreted unfavorably Then as they were alonenearly alone inasmuch as Colbert as soon as he perceived the young girl approaching had stopped and drawn back a dozen pacesthe king advanced towards La Valliere and took her by the hand Mademoiselle he said to her should I be guilty of an indiscretion if I were to inquire if you were indisposed for you seem to breathe as if you were oppressed by some secret cause of uneasiness and your eyes are filled with tears

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Oh! sire, if I be indeed so, and if my eyes are indeed full of tears, I am sorrowful only at the sadness which seems to oppress your majesty.
children.prevalue: Oh sire if I be indeed so and if my eyes are indeed full of tears I am sorrowful only at the sadness which seems to oppress your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: My sadness? You are mistaken, mademoiselle no, it is not sadness I experience.
children.prevalue: My sadness You are mistaken mademoiselle no it is not sadness I experience

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: What is it, then, sire?
children.prevalue: What is it then sire

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Humiliation.
children.prevalue: Humiliation

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Humiliation? oh! sire, what a word for you to use!
children.prevalue: Humiliation oh sire what a word for you to use

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I mean, mademoiselle, that wherever I may happen to be, no one else ought to be the master. Well, then, look round you on every side, and judge whether I am not eclipsedI, the king of Francebefore the monarch of these wide domains. Oh! he continued, clenching his hands and teeth, when I think that this king
children.prevalue: I mean mademoiselle that wherever I may happen to be no one else ought to be the master Well then look round you on every side and judge whether I am not eclipsedI the king of Francebefore the monarch of these wide domains Oh he continued clenching his hands and teeth when I think that this king

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Well, sire? said Louise, terrified.
children.prevalue: Well sire said Louise terrified

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: That this king is a faithless, unworthy servant, who grows proud and selfsufficient upon the strength of property that belongs to me, and which he has stolen. And therefore I am about to change this impudent minister's fete into sorrow and mourning, of which the nymph of Vaux, as the poets say, shall not soon lose the remembrance.
children.prevalue: That this king is a faithless unworthy servant who grows proud and selfsufficient upon the strength of property that belongs to me and which he has stolen And therefore I am about to change this impudent minister s fete into sorrow and mourning of which the nymph of Vaux as the poets say shall not soon lose the remembrance

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Oh! your majesty
children.prevalue: Oh your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Well, mademoiselle, are you about to take M. Fouquet's part? said Louis, impatiently.
children.prevalue: Well mademoiselle are you about to take M Fouquet s part said Louis impatiently

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: No, sire I will only ask whether you are well informed. Your majesty has more than once learned the value of accusations made at court.
children.prevalue: No sire I will only ask whether you are well informed Your majesty has more than once learned the value of accusations made at court

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Louis XIV. made a sign for Colbert to approach. Speak, Monsieur Colbert, said the young prince, for I almost believe that Mademoiselle de la Valliere has need of your assistance before she can put any faith in the king's word. Tell mademoiselle what M. Fouquet has done and you, mademoiselle, will perhaps have the kindness to listen. It will not be long.
children.prevalue: Louis XIV made a sign for Colbert to approach Speak Monsieur Colbert said the young prince for I almost believe that Mademoiselle de la Valliere has need of your assistance before she can put any faith in the king s word Tell mademoiselle what M Fouquet has done and you mademoiselle will perhaps have the kindness to listen It will not be long

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Why did Louis XIV. insist upon it in such a manner? A very simple reasonhis heart was not at rest, his mind was not thoroughly convinced he imagined there lay some dark, hidden, tortuous intrigue behind these thirteen millions of francs and he wished that the pure heart of La Valliere, which had revolted at the idea of theft or robbery, should approveeven were it only by a single wordthe resolution he had taken, and which, nevertheless, he hesitated before carrying into execution.
children.prevalue: Why did Louis XIV insist upon it in such a manner A very simple reasonhis heart was not at rest his mind was not thoroughly convinced he imagined there lay some dark hidden tortuous intrigue behind these thirteen millions of francs and he wished that the pure heart of La Valliere which had revolted at the idea of theft or robbery should approveeven were it only by a single wordthe resolution he had taken and which nevertheless he hesitated before carrying into execution

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Speak, monsieur, said La Valliere to Colbert, who had advanced speak, since the king wishes me to listen to you. Tell me, what is the crime with which M. Fouquet is charged?
children.prevalue: Speak monsieur said La Valliere to Colbert who had advanced speak since the king wishes me to listen to you Tell me what is the crime with which M Fouquet is charged

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Oh! not very heinous, mademoiselle, he returned, a mere abuse of confidence.
children.prevalue: Oh not very heinous mademoiselle he returned a mere abuse of confidence

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Speak, speak, Colbert and when you have related it, leave us, and go and inform M. d'Artagnan that I have certain orders to give him.
children.prevalue: Speak speak Colbert and when you have related it leave us and go and inform M d Artagnan that I have certain orders to give him

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: M. d'Artagnan, sire! exclaimed La Valliere but why send for M. d'Artagnan? I entreat you to tell me.
children.prevalue: M d Artagnan sire exclaimed La Valliere but why send for M d Artagnan I entreat you to tell me

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Pardieu! in order to arrest this haughty, arrogant Titan who, true to his menace, threatens to scale my heaven.
children.prevalue: Pardieu in order to arrest this haughty arrogant Titan who true to his menace threatens to scale my heaven

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Arrest M. Fouquet, do you say?
children.prevalue: Arrest M Fouquet do you say

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Ah! does that surprise you?
children.prevalue: Ah does that surprise you

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: In his own house!
children.prevalue: In his own house

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Why not? If he be guilty, he is as guilty in his own house as anywhere else.
children.prevalue: Why not If he be guilty he is as guilty in his own house as anywhere else

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: M. Fouquet, who at this moment is ruining himself for his sovereign.
children.prevalue: M Fouquet who at this moment is ruining himself for his sovereign

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: In plain truth, mademoiselle, it seems as if you were defending this traitor.
children.prevalue: In plain truth mademoiselle it seems as if you were defending this traitor

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Colbert began to chuckle silently. The king turned round at the sound of this suppressed mirth.
children.prevalue: Colbert began to chuckle silently The king turned round at the sound of this suppressed mirth

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Sire, said La Valliere, it is not M. Fouquet I am defending it is yourself.
children.prevalue: Sire said La Valliere it is not M Fouquet I am defending it is yourself

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Me! you are defending me?
children.prevalue: Me you are defending me

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Sire, you would dishonor yourself if you were to give such an order.
children.prevalue: Sire you would dishonor yourself if you were to give such an order

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Dishonor myself! murmured the king, turning pale with anger. In plain truth, mademoiselle, you show a strange persistence in what you say.
children.prevalue: Dishonor myself murmured the king turning pale with anger In plain truth mademoiselle you show a strange persistence in what you say

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: If I do, sire, my only motive is that of serving your majesty, replied the noblehearted girl: for that I would risk, I would sacrifice my very life, without the least reserve.
children.prevalue: If I do sire my only motive is that of serving your majesty replied the noblehearted girl for that I would risk I would sacrifice my very life without the least reserve

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Colbert seemed inclined to grumble and complain. La Valliere, that timid, gentle lamb, turned round upon him, and with a glance like lightning imposed silence upon him. Monsieur, she said, when the king acts well, whether, in doing so, he does either myself or those who belong to me an injury, I have nothing to say but were the king to confer a benefit either upon me or mine, and if he acted badly, I should tell him so.
children.prevalue: Colbert seemed inclined to grumble and complain La Valliere that timid gentle lamb turned round upon him and with a glance like lightning imposed silence upon him Monsieur she said when the king acts well whether in doing so he does either myself or those who belong to me an injury I have nothing to say but were the king to confer a benefit either upon me or mine and if he acted badly I should tell him so

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: But it appears to me, mademoiselle, Colbert ventured to say, that I too love the king.
children.prevalue: But it appears to me mademoiselle Colbert ventured to say that I too love the king

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Yes, monseigneur, we both love him, but each in a different manner, replied La Valliere, with such an accent that the heart of the young king was powerfully affected by it. I love him so deeply, that the whole world is aware of it so purely, that the king himself does not doubt my affection. He is my king and my master I am the least of all his servants. But whoso touches his honor assails my life. Therefore, I repeat, that they dishonor the king who advise him to arrest M. Fouquet under his own roof.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur we both love him but each in a different manner replied La Valliere with such an accent that the heart of the young king was powerfully affected by it I love him so deeply that the whole world is aware of it so purely that the king himself does not doubt my affection He is my king and my master I am the least of all his servants But whoso touches his honor assails my life Therefore I repeat that they dishonor the king who advise him to arrest M Fouquet under his own roof

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Colbert hung down his head, for he felt that the king had abandoned him. However, as he bent his head, he murmured, Mademoiselle, I have only one word to say.
children.prevalue: Colbert hung down his head for he felt that the king had abandoned him However as he bent his head he murmured Mademoiselle I have only one word to say

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Do not say it, then, monsieur for I would not listen to it. Besides, what could you have to tell me? That M. Fouquet has been guilty of certain crimes? I believe he has, because the king has said so and, from the moment the king said, 'I think so,' I have no occasion for other lips to say, 'I affirm it.' But, were M. Fouquet the vilest of men, I should say aloud, 'M. Fouquet's person is sacred to the king because he is the guest of M. Fouquet. Were his house a den of thieves, were Vaux a cave of coiners or robbers, his home is sacred, his palace is inviolable, since his wife is living in it and that is an asylum which even executioners would not dare to violate.'
children.prevalue: Do not say it then monsieur for I would not listen to it Besides what could you have to tell me That M Fouquet has been guilty of certain crimes I believe he has because the king has said so and from the moment the king said I think so I have no occasion for other lips to say I affirm it But were M Fouquet the vilest of men I should say aloud M Fouquet s person is sacred to the king because he is the guest of M Fouquet Were his house a den of thieves were Vaux a cave of coiners or robbers his home is sacred his palace is inviolable since his wife is living in it and that is an asylum which even executioners would not dare to violate

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: La Valliere paused, and was silent. In spite of himself the king could not but admire her he was overpowered by the passionate energy of her voice by the nobleness of the cause she advocated. Colbert yielded, overcome by the inequality of the struggle. At last the king breathed again more freely, shook his head, and held out his hand to La Valliere. Mademoiselle, he said, gently, why do you decide against me? Do you know what this wretched fellow will do, if I give him time to breathe again?
children.prevalue: La Valliere paused and was silent In spite of himself the king could not but admire her he was overpowered by the passionate energy of her voice by the nobleness of the cause she advocated Colbert yielded overcome by the inequality of the struggle At last the king breathed again more freely shook his head and held out his hand to La Valliere Mademoiselle he said gently why do you decide against me Do you know what this wretched fellow will do if I give him time to breathe again

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Is he not a prey which will always be within your grasp?
children.prevalue: Is he not a prey which will always be within your grasp

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Should he escape, and take to flight? exclaimed Colbert.
children.prevalue: Should he escape and take to flight exclaimed Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Well, monsieur, it will always remain on record, to the king's eternal honor, that he allowed M. Fouquet to flee and the more guilty he may have been, the greater will the king's honor and glory appear, compared with such unnecessary misery and shame.
children.prevalue: Well monsieur it will always remain on record to the king s eternal honor that he allowed M Fouquet to flee and the more guilty he may have been the greater will the king s honor and glory appear compared with such unnecessary misery and shame

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Louis kissed La Valliere's hand, as he knelt before her.
children.prevalue: Louis kissed La Valliere s hand as he knelt before her

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I am lost, thought Colbert then suddenly his face brightened up again. Oh! no, no, aha, old fox!not yet, he said to himself.
children.prevalue: I am lost thought Colbert then suddenly his face brightened up again Oh no no aha old fox not yet he said to himself

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: And while the king, protected from observation by the thick covert of an enormous lime, pressed La Valliere to his breast, with all the ardor of ineffable affection, Colbert tranquilly fumbled among the papers in his pocketbook and drew out of it a paper folded in the form of a letter, somewhat yellow, perhaps, but one that must have been most precious, since the intendant smiled as he looked at it he then bent a look, full of hatred, upon the charming group which the young girl and the king formed togethera group revealed but for a moment, as the light of the approaching torches shone upon it. Louis noticed the light reflected upon La Valliere's white dress. Leave me, Louise, he said, for some one is coming.
children.prevalue: And while the king protected from observation by the thick covert of an enormous lime pressed La Valliere to his breast with all the ardor of ineffable affection Colbert tranquilly fumbled among the papers in his pocketbook and drew out of it a paper folded in the form of a letter somewhat yellow perhaps but one that must have been most precious since the intendant smiled as he looked at it he then bent a look full of hatred upon the charming group which the young girl and the king formed togethera group revealed but for a moment as the light of the approaching torches shone upon it Louis noticed the light reflected upon La Valliere s white dress Leave me Louise he said for some one is coming

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Mademoiselle, mademoiselle, some one is coming, cried Colbert, to expedite the young girl's departure.
children.prevalue: Mademoiselle mademoiselle some one is coming cried Colbert to expedite the young girl s departure

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Louise disappeared rapidly among the trees and then, as the king, who had been on his knees before the young girl, was rising from his humble posture, Colbert exclaimed, Ah! Mademoiselle de la Valliere has let something fall.
children.prevalue: Louise disappeared rapidly among the trees and then as the king who had been on his knees before the young girl was rising from his humble posture Colbert exclaimed Ah Mademoiselle de la Valliere has let something fall

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: What is it? inquired the king.
children.prevalue: What is it inquired the king

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: A papera lettersomething white look there, sire.
children.prevalue: A papera lettersomething white look there sire

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The king stooped down immediately and picked up the letter, crumpling it in his hand, as he did so and at the same moment the torches arrived, inundating the blackness of the scene with a flood of light as bight as day.
children.prevalue: The king stooped down immediately and picked up the letter crumpling it in his hand as he did so and at the same moment the torches arrived inundating the blackness of the scene with a flood of light as bight as day

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The torches we have just referred to, the eager attention every one displayed, and the new ovation paid to the king by Fouquet, arrived in time to suspend the effect of a resolution which La Valliere had already considerably shaken in Louis XIV.'s heart. He looked at Fouquet with a feeling almost of gratitude for having given La Valliere an opportunity of showing herself so generously disposed, so powerful in the influence she exercised over his heart. The moment of the last and greatest display had arrived. Hardly had Fouquet conducted the king towards the chateau, when a mass of fire burst from the dome of Vaux, with a prodigious uproar, pouring a flood of dazzling cataracts of rays on every side, and illumining the remotest corners of the gardens. The fireworks began. Colbert, at twenty paces from the king, who was surrounded and feted by the owner of Vaux, seemed, by the obstinate persistence of his gloomy thoughts, to do his utmost to recall Louis's attention, which the magnificence of the spectacle was already, in his opinion, too easily diverting. Suddenly, just as Louis was on the point of holding it out to Fouquet, he perceived in his hand the paper which, as he believed, La Valliere had dropped at his feet as she hurried away. The still stronger magnet of love drew the young prince's attention towards the souvenir of his idol and, by the brilliant light, which increased momentarily in beauty, and drew from the neighboring villages loud cheers of admiration, the king read the letter, which he supposed was a loving and tender epistle La Valliere had destined for him. But as he read it, a deathlike pallor stole over his face, and an expression of deepseated wrath, illumined by the manycolored fire which gleamed so brightly, soaringly around the scene, produced a terrible spectacle, which every one would have shuddered at, could they only have read into his heart, now torn by the most stormy and most bitter passions. There was no truce for him now, influenced as he was by jealousy and mad passion. From the very moment when the dark truth was revealed to him, every gentler feeling seemed to disappear pity, kindness of consideration, the religion of hospitality, all were forgotten. In the bitter pang which wrung his heart, he, still too weak to hide his sufferings, was almost on the point of uttering a cry of alarm, and calling his guards to gather round him. This letter which Colbert had thrown down at the king's feet, the reader has doubtlessly guessed, was the same that had disappeared with the porter Toby at Fontainebleau, after the attempt which Fouquet had made upon La Valliere's heart. Fouquet saw the king's pallor, and was far from guessing the evil Colbert saw the king's anger, and rejoiced inwardly at the approach of the storm. Fouquet's voice drew the young prince from his wrathful reverie.
