children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: And then, really, said Baisemeaux to his next in command, an ordinary prisoner is already unhappy enough in being a prisoner he suffers quite enough, indeed, to induce one to hope, charitably enough, that his death may not be far distant. With still greater reason, accordingly, when the prisoner has gone mad, and might bite and make a terrible disturbance in the Bastile why, in such a case, it is not simply an act of mere charity to wish him dead it would be almost a good and even commendable action, quietly to have him put out of his misery.
children.prevalue: And then really said Baisemeaux to his next in command an ordinary prisoner is already unhappy enough in being a prisoner he suffers quite enough indeed to induce one to hope charitably enough that his death may not be far distant With still greater reason accordingly when the prisoner has gone mad and might bite and make a terrible disturbance in the Bastile why in such a case it is not simply an act of mere charity to wish him dead it would be almost a good and even commendable action quietly to have him put out of his misery

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: And the goodnatured governor thereupon sat down to his late breakfast.
children.prevalue: And the goodnatured governor thereupon sat down to his late breakfast

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: D'Artagnan, still confused and oppressed by the conversation he had just had with the king, could not resist asking himself if he were really in possession of his senses, if he were really and truly at Vaux if he, D'Artagnan, were really the captain of the musketeers, and M. Fouquet the owner of the chateau in which Louis XIV. was at that moment partaking of his hospitality. These reflections were not those of a drunken man, although everything was in prodigal profusion at Vaux, and the surintendant's wines had met with a distinguished reception at the fete. The Gascon, however, was a man of calm selfpossession and no sooner did he touch his bright steel blade, than he knew how to adopt morally the cold, keen weapon as his guide of action.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan still confused and oppressed by the conversation he had just had with the king could not resist asking himself if he were really in possession of his senses if he were really and truly at Vaux if he D Artagnan were really the captain of the musketeers and M Fouquet the owner of the chateau in which Louis XIV was at that moment partaking of his hospitality These reflections were not those of a drunken man although everything was in prodigal profusion at Vaux and the surintendant s wines had met with a distinguished reception at the fete The Gascon however was a man of calm selfpossession and no sooner did he touch his bright steel blade than he knew how to adopt morally the cold keen weapon as his guide of action

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Well, he said, as he quitted the royal apartment, I seem now to be mixed up historically with the destinies of the king and of the minister it will be written, that M. d'Artagnan, a younger son of a Gascon family, placed his hand on the shoulder of M. Nicolas Fouquet, the surintendant of the finances of France. My descendants, if I have any, will flatter themselves with the distinction which this arrest will confer, just as the members of the De Luynes family have done with regard to the estates of the poor Marechal d'Ancre. But the thing is, how best to execute the king's directions in a proper manner. Any man would know how to say to M. Fouquet, 'Your sword, monsieur.' But it is not every one who would be able to take care of M. Fouquet without others knowing anything about it. How am I to manage, then, so that M. le surintendant pass from the height of favor to the direst disgrace that Vaux be turned into a dungeon for him that after having been steeped to his lips, as it were, in all the perfumes and incense of Ahasuerus, he is transferred to the gallows of Haman in other words, of Enguerrand de Marigny? And at this reflection, D'Artagnan's brow became clouded with perplexity. The musketeer had certain scruples on the matter, it must be admitted. To deliver up to death (for not a doubt existed that Louis hated Fouquet mortally) the man who had just shown himself so delightful and charming a host in every way, was a real insult to one's conscience. It almost seems, said D'Artagnan to himself, that if I am not a poor, mean, miserable fellow, I should let M. Fouquet know the opinion the king has about him. Yet, if I betray my master's secret, I shall be a falsehearted, treacherous knave, a traitor, too, a crime provided for and punishable by military lawsso much so, indeed, that twenty times, in former days when wars were rife, I have seen many a miserable fellow strung up to a tree for doing, in but a small degree, what my scruples counsel me to undertake upon a great scale now. No, I think that a man of true readiness of wit ought to get out of this difficulty with more skill than that. And now, let us admit that I do possess a little readiness of invention it is not at all certain, though, for, after having for forty years absorbed so large a quantity, I shall be lucky if there were to be a pistole'sworth left. D'Artagnan buried his head in his hands, tore at his mustache in sheer vexation, and added, What can be the reason of M. Fouquet's disgrace? There seem to be three good ones: the first, because M. Colbert doesn't like him the second, because he wished to fall in love with Mademoiselle de la Valliere and lastly, because the king likes M. Colbert and loves Mademoiselle de la Valliere. Oh! he is lost! But shall I put my foot on his neck, I, of all men, when he is falling a prey to the intrigues of a pack of women and clerks? For shame! If he be dangerous, I will lay him low enough if, however, he be only persecuted, I will look on. I have come to such a decisive determination, that neither king nor living man shall change my mind. If Athos were here, he would do as I have done. Therefore, instead of going, in cold blood, up to M. Fouquet, and arresting him offhand and shutting him up altogether, I will try and conduct myself like a man who understands what good manners are. People will talk about it, of course but they shall talk well of it, I am determined. And D'Artagnan, drawing by a gesture peculiar to himself his shoulderbelt over his shoulder, went straight off to M. Fouquet, who, after he had taken leave of his guests, was preparing to retire for the night and to sleep tranquilly after the triumphs of the day. The air was still perfumed, or infected, whichever way it may be considered, with the odors of the torches and the fireworks. The waxlights were dying away in their sockets, the flowers fell unfastened from the garlands, the groups of dancers and courtiers were separating in the salons. Surrounded by his friends, who complimented him and received his flattering remarks in return, the surintendant halfclosed his wearied eyes. He longed for rest and quiet he sank upon the bed of laurels which had been heaped up for him for so many days past it might almost have been said that he seemed bowed beneath the weight of the new debts which he had incurred for the purpose of giving the greatest possible honor to this fete. Fouquet had just retired to his room, still smiling, but more than halfasleep. He could listen to nothing more, he could hardly keep his eyes open his bed seemed to possess a fascinating and irresistible attraction for him. The god Morpheus, the presiding deity of the dome painted by Lebrun, had extended his influence over the adjoining rooms, and showered down his most sleepinducing poppies upon the master of the house. Fouquet, almost entirely alone, was being assisted by his valet de chambre to undress, when M. d'Artagnan appeared at the entrance of the room. D'Artagnan had never been able to succeed in making himself common at the court and notwithstanding he was seen everywhere and on all occasions, he never failed to produce an effect wherever and whenever he made his appearance. Such is the happy privilege of certain natures, which in that respect resemble either thunder or lightning every one recognizes them but their appearance never fails to arouse surprise and astonishment, and whenever they occur, the impression is always left that the last was the most conspicuous or most important.

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: What! M. d'Artagnan? said Fouquet, who had already taken his right arm out of the sleeve of his doublet.
children.prevalue: What M d Artagnan said Fouquet who had already taken his right arm out of the sleeve of his doublet

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: At your service, replied the musketeer.
children.prevalue: At your service replied the musketeer

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Come in, my dear M. d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Come in my dear M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Thank you.
children.prevalue: Thank you

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Have you come to criticise the fete? You are ingenious enough in your criticisms, I know.
children.prevalue: Have you come to criticise the fete You are ingenious enough in your criticisms I know

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: By no means.
children.prevalue: By no means

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Are not your men looked after properly?
children.prevalue: Are not your men looked after properly

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: In every way.
children.prevalue: In every way

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: You are not comfortably lodged, perhaps?
children.prevalue: You are not comfortably lodged perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Nothing could be better.
children.prevalue: Nothing could be better

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: In that case, I have to thank you for being so amiably disposed, and I must not fail to express my obligations to you for all your flattering kindness.
children.prevalue: In that case I have to thank you for being so amiably disposed and I must not fail to express my obligations to you for all your flattering kindness

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: These words were as much as to say, My dear D'Artagnan, pray go to bed, since you have a bed to lie down on, and let me do the same.
children.prevalue: These words were as much as to say My dear D Artagnan pray go to bed since you have a bed to lie down on and let me do the same

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: D'Artagnan did not seem to understand it.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan did not seem to understand it

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Are you going to bed already? he said to the superintendent.
children.prevalue: Are you going to bed already he said to the superintendent

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Yes have you anything to say to me?
children.prevalue: Yes have you anything to say to me

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Nothing, monsieur, nothing at all. You sleep in this room, then?
children.prevalue: Nothing monsieur nothing at all You sleep in this room then

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Yes as you see.
children.prevalue: Yes as you see

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: You have given a most charming fete to the king.
children.prevalue: You have given a most charming fete to the king

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Do you think so?
children.prevalue: Do you think so

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Oh! beautiful!
children.prevalue: Oh beautiful

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Is the king pleased?
children.prevalue: Is the king pleased

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Enchanted.
children.prevalue: Enchanted

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Did he desire you to say as much to me?
children.prevalue: Did he desire you to say as much to me

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: He would not choose so unworthy a messenger, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: He would not choose so unworthy a messenger monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: You do not do yourself justice, Monsieur d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: You do not do yourself justice Monsieur d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Is that your bed, there?
children.prevalue: Is that your bed there

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Yes but why do you ask? Are you not satisfied with your own?
children.prevalue: Yes but why do you ask Are you not satisfied with your own

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: My I speak frankly to you?
children.prevalue: My I speak frankly to you

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Most assuredly.
children.prevalue: Most assuredly

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Well, then, I am not.
children.prevalue: Well then I am not

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Fouquet started and then replied, Will you take my room, Monsieur d'Artagnan?
children.prevalue: Fouquet started and then replied Will you take my room Monsieur d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: What! deprive you of it, monseigneur? never!
children.prevalue: What deprive you of it monseigneur never

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: What am I to do, then?
children.prevalue: What am I to do then

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Allow me to share yours with you.
children.prevalue: Allow me to share yours with you

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Fouquet looked at the musketeer fixedly. Ah! ah! he said, you have just left the king.
children.prevalue: Fouquet looked at the musketeer fixedly Ah ah he said you have just left the king

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: I have, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: I have monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: And the king wishes you to pass the night in my room?
children.prevalue: And the king wishes you to pass the night in my room

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Monseigneur
children.prevalue: Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Very well, Monsieur d'Artagnan, very well. You are the master here.
children.prevalue: Very well Monsieur d Artagnan very well You are the master here

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: I assure you, monseigneur, that I do not wish to abuse
children.prevalue: I assure you monseigneur that I do not wish to abuse

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Fouquet turned to his valet, and said, Leave us. When the man had left, he said to D'Artagnan, You have something to say to me?
children.prevalue: Fouquet turned to his valet and said Leave us When the man had left he said to D Artagnan You have something to say to me

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I?
children.prevalue: I

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: A man of your superior intelligence cannot have come to talk with a man like myself, at such an hour as the present, without grave motives.
children.prevalue: A man of your superior intelligence cannot have come to talk with a man like myself at such an hour as the present without grave motives

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Do not interrogate me.
children.prevalue: Do not interrogate me

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: On the contrary. What do you want with me?
children.prevalue: On the contrary What do you want with me

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Nothing more than the pleasure of your society.
children.prevalue: Nothing more than the pleasure of your society

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Come into the garden, then, said the superintendent suddenly, or into the park.
children.prevalue: Come into the garden then said the superintendent suddenly or into the park

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: No, replied the musketeer, hastily, no.
children.prevalue: No replied the musketeer hastily no

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Why?
children.prevalue: Why

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The fresh air
children.prevalue: The fresh air

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Come, admit at once that you arrest me, said the superintendent to the captain.
children.prevalue: Come admit at once that you arrest me said the superintendent to the captain

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Never! said the latter.
children.prevalue: Never said the latter

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: You intend to look after me, then?
children.prevalue: You intend to look after me then

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Yes, monseigneur, I do, upon my honor.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur I do upon my honor

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Upon your honorah! that is quite another thing! So I am to be arrested in my own house.
children.prevalue: Upon your honorah that is quite another thing So I am to be arrested in my own house

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Do not say such a thing.
children.prevalue: Do not say such a thing

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: On the contrary, I will proclaim it aloud.
children.prevalue: On the contrary I will proclaim it aloud

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: If you do so, I shall be compelled to request you to be silent.
children.prevalue: If you do so I shall be compelled to request you to be silent

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Very good! Violence towards me, and in my own house, too.
children.prevalue: Very good Violence towards me and in my own house too

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: We do not seem to understand one another at all. Stay a moment there is a chessboard there we will have a game, if you have no objections.
children.prevalue: We do not seem to understand one another at all Stay a moment there is a chessboard there we will have a game if you have no objections

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Monsieur d'Artagnan, I am in disgrace, then?
children.prevalue: Monsieur d Artagnan I am in disgrace then

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Not at all but
children.prevalue: Not at all but

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: I am prohibited, I suppose, from withdrawing from your sight.
children.prevalue: I am prohibited I suppose from withdrawing from your sight

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: I do not understand a word you are saying, monseigneur and if you wish me to withdraw, tell me so.
children.prevalue: I do not understand a word you are saying monseigneur and if you wish me to withdraw tell me so

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: My dear Monsieur d'Artagnan, your mode of action is enough to drive me mad I was almost sinking for want of sleep, but you have completely awakened me.
children.prevalue: My dear Monsieur d Artagnan your mode of action is enough to drive me mad I was almost sinking for want of sleep but you have completely awakened me

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: I shall never forgive myself, I am sure and if you wish to reconcile me with myself, why, go to sleep in your bed in my presence and I shall be delighted.
children.prevalue: I shall never forgive myself I am sure and if you wish to reconcile me with myself why go to sleep in your bed in my presence and I shall be delighted

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: I am under surveillance, I see.
children.prevalue: I am under surveillance I see

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: I will leave the room if you say any such thing.
children.prevalue: I will leave the room if you say any such thing

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: You are beyond my comprehension.
children.prevalue: You are beyond my comprehension

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Good night, monseigneur, said D'Artagnan, as he pretended to withdraw.
children.prevalue: Good night monseigneur said D Artagnan as he pretended to withdraw

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Fouquet ran after him. I will not lie down, he said. Seriously, and since you refuse to treat me as a man, and since you finesse with me, I will try and set you at bay, as a hunter does a wild boar.
children.prevalue: Fouquet ran after him I will not lie down he said Seriously and since you refuse to treat me as a man and since you finesse with me I will try and set you at bay as a hunter does a wild boar

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Bah! cried D'Artagnan, pretending to smile.
children.prevalue: Bah cried D Artagnan pretending to smile

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I shall order my horses, and set off for Paris, said Fouquet, sounding the captain of the musketeers.
children.prevalue: I shall order my horses and set off for Paris said Fouquet sounding the captain of the musketeers

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: If that be the case, monseigneur, it is very difficult.
children.prevalue: If that be the case monseigneur it is very difficult

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: You will arrest me, then?
children.prevalue: You will arrest me then

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: No, but I shall go along with you.
children.prevalue: No but I shall go along with you

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: That is quite sufficient, Monsieur d'Artagnan, returned Fouquet, coldly. It was not for nothing you acquired your reputation as a man of intelligence and resource but with me all this is quite superfluous. Let us come to the point. Do me a service. Why do you arrest me? What have I done?
children.prevalue: That is quite sufficient Monsieur d Artagnan returned Fouquet coldly It was not for nothing you acquired your reputation as a man of intelligence and resource but with me all this is quite superfluous Let us come to the point Do me a service Why do you arrest me What have I done

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Oh! I know nothing about what you may have done but I do not arrest youthis evening, at least!
children.prevalue: Oh I know nothing about what you may have done but I do not arrest youthis evening at least

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: This evening! said Fouquet, turning pale, but tomorrow?
children.prevalue: This evening said Fouquet turning pale but tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: It is not tomorrow just yet, monseigneur. Who can ever answer for the morrow?
children.prevalue: It is not tomorrow just yet monseigneur Who can ever answer for the morrow

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Quick, quick, captain! let me speak to M. d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: Quick quick captain let me speak to M d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Alas! that is quite impossible, monseigneur. I have strict orders to see that you hold no communication with any one.
children.prevalue: Alas that is quite impossible monseigneur I have strict orders to see that you hold no communication with any one

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: With M. d'Herblay, captainwith your friend!
children.prevalue: With M d Herblay captainwith your friend

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Monseigneur, is M. d'Herblay the only person with whom you ought to be prevented holding any communication?
children.prevalue: Monseigneur is M d Herblay the only person with whom you ought to be prevented holding any communication

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Fouquet colored, and then assuming an air of resignation, he said: You are right, monsieur you have taught me a lesson I ought not to have evoked. A fallen man cannot assert his right to anything, even from those whose fortunes he may have made for a still stronger reason, he cannot claim anything from those to whom he may never have had the happiness of doing a service.
children.prevalue: Fouquet colored and then assuming an air of resignation he said You are right monsieur you have taught me a lesson I ought not to have evoked A fallen man cannot assert his right to anything even from those whose fortunes he may have made for a still stronger reason he cannot claim anything from those to whom he may never have had the happiness of doing a service

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Monseigneur!
children.prevalue: Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: It is perfectly true, Monsieur d'Artagnan you have always acted in the most admirable manner towards mein such a manner, indeed, as most becomes the man who is destined to arrest me. You, at least, have never asked me anything.
children.prevalue: It is perfectly true Monsieur d Artagnan you have always acted in the most admirable manner towards mein such a manner indeed as most becomes the man who is destined to arrest me You at least have never asked me anything

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Monsieur, replied the Gascon, touched by his eloquent and noble tone of grief, will youI ask it as a favorpledge me your word as a man of honor that you will not leave this room?
children.prevalue: Monsieur replied the Gascon touched by his eloquent and noble tone of grief will youI ask it as a favorpledge me your word as a man of honor that you will not leave this room

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: What is the use of it, dear Monsieur d'Artagnan, since you keep watch and ward over me? Do you suppose I should contend against the most valiant sword in the kingdom?
children.prevalue: What is the use of it dear Monsieur d Artagnan since you keep watch and ward over me Do you suppose I should contend against the most valiant sword in the kingdom

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: It is not that, at all, monseigneur but that I am going to look for M. d'Herblay, and, consequently, to leave you alone.
children.prevalue: It is not that at all monseigneur but that I am going to look for M d Herblay and consequently to leave you alone

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Fouquet uttered a cry of delight and surprise.
children.prevalue: Fouquet uttered a cry of delight and surprise

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: To look for M. d'Herblay! to leave me alone! he exclaimed, clasping his hands together.
children.prevalue: To look for M d Herblay to leave me alone he exclaimed clasping his hands together

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Which is M. d'Herblay's room? The blue room is it not?
children.prevalue: Which is M d Herblay s room The blue room is it not

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Yes, my friend, yes.
children.prevalue: Yes my friend yes

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Your friend! thank you for that word, monseigneur you confer it upon me today, at least, if you have never done so before.
children.prevalue: Your friend thank you for that word monseigneur you confer it upon me today at least if you have never done so before

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Ah! you have saved me.
children.prevalue: Ah you have saved me

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: It will take a good ten minutes to go from hence to the blue room, and to return? said D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: It will take a good ten minutes to go from hence to the blue room and to return said D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Nearly so.
children.prevalue: Nearly so

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: And then to wake Aramis, who sleeps very soundly, when he is asleep, I put that down at another five minutes making a total of fifteen minutes' absence. And now, monseigneur, give me your word that you will not in any way attempt to make your escape, and that when I return I shall find you here again.
children.prevalue: And then to wake Aramis who sleeps very soundly when he is asleep I put that down at another five minutes making a total of fifteen minutes absence And now monseigneur give me your word that you will not in any way attempt to make your escape and that when I return I shall find you here again

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: I give it, monsieur, replied Fouquet, with an expression of the warmest and deepest gratitude.
children.prevalue: I give it monsieur replied Fouquet with an expression of the warmest and deepest gratitude

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: D'Artagnan disappeared. Fouquet looked at him as he quitted the room, waited with a feverish impatience until the door was closed behind him, and as soon as it was shut, flew to his keys, opened two or three secret doors concealed in various articles of furniture in the room, looked vainly for certain papers, which doubtless he had left at SaintMande, and which he seemed to regret not having found in them then hurriedly seizing hold of letters, contracts, papers, writings, he heaped them up into a pile, which he burnt in the extremest haste upon the marble hearth of the fireplace, not even taking time to draw from the interior of it the vases and pots of flowers with which it was filled. As soon as he had finished, like a man who has just escaped an imminent danger, and whose strength abandons him as soon as the danger is past, he sank down, completely overcome, on a couch. When D'Artagnan returned, he found Fouquet in the same position the worthy musketeer had not the slightest doubt that Fouquet, having given his word, would not even think of failing to keep it, but he had thought it most likely that Fouquet would turn his (D'Artagnan's) absence to the best advantage in getting rid of all the papers, memorandums, and contracts, which might possibly render his position, which was even now serious enough, more dangerous than ever. And so, lifting up his head like a dog who has regained the scent, he perceived an odor resembling smoke he had relied on finding in the atmosphere, and having found it, made a movement of his head in token of satisfaction. As D'Artagnan entered, Fouquet, on his side, raised his head, and not one of D'Artagnan's movements escaped him. And then the looks of the two men met, and they both saw that they had understood each other without exchanging a syllable.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan disappeared Fouquet looked at him as he quitted the room waited with a feverish impatience until the door was closed behind him and as soon as it was shut flew to his keys opened two or three secret doors concealed in various articles of furniture in the room looked vainly for certain papers which doubtless he had left at SaintMande and which he seemed to regret not having found in them then hurriedly seizing hold of letters contracts papers writings he heaped them up into a pile which he burnt in the extremest haste upon the marble hearth of the fireplace not even taking time to draw from the interior of it the vases and pots of flowers with which it was filled As soon as he had finished like a man who has just escaped an imminent danger and whose strength abandons him as soon as the danger is past he sank down completely overcome on a couch When D Artagnan returned he found Fouquet in the same position the worthy musketeer had not the slightest doubt that Fouquet having given his word would not even think of failing to keep it but he had thought it most likely that Fouquet would turn his D Artagnan s absence to the best advantage in getting rid of all the papers memorandums and contracts which might possibly render his position which was even now serious enough more dangerous than ever And so lifting up his head like a dog who has regained the scent he perceived an odor resembling smoke he had relied on finding in the atmosphere and having found it made a movement of his head in token of satisfaction As D Artagnan entered Fouquet on his side raised his head and not one of D Artagnan s movements escaped him And then the looks of the two men met and they both saw that they had understood each other without exchanging a syllable

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Well! asked Fouquet, the first to speak, and M. d'Herblay?
children.prevalue: Well asked Fouquet the first to speak and M d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Upon my word, monseigneur, replied D'Artagnan, M. d'Herblay must be desperately fond of walking out at night, and composing verses by moonlight in the park of Vaux, with some of your poets, in all probability, for he is not in his own room.
children.prevalue: Upon my word monseigneur replied D Artagnan M d Herblay must be desperately fond of walking out at night and composing verses by moonlight in the park of Vaux with some of your poets in all probability for he is not in his own room

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: What! not in his own room? cried Fouquet, whose last hope thus escaped him for unless he could ascertain in what way the bishop of Vannes could assist him, he perfectly well knew that he could expect assistance from no other quarter.
children.prevalue: What not in his own room cried Fouquet whose last hope thus escaped him for unless he could ascertain in what way the bishop of Vannes could assist him he perfectly well knew that he could expect assistance from no other quarter

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Or, indeed, continued D'Artagnan, if he is in his own room, he has very good reasons for not answering.
children.prevalue: Or indeed continued D Artagnan if he is in his own room he has very good reasons for not answering

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: But surely you did not call him in such a manner that he could have heard you?
children.prevalue: But surely you did not call him in such a manner that he could have heard you

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: You can hardly suppose, monseigneur, that having already exceeded my orders, which forbade me leaving you a single momentyou can hardly suppose, I say, that I should have been mad enough to rouse the whole house and allow myself to be seen in the corridor of the bishop of Vannes, in order that M. Colbert might state with positive certainty that I gave you time to burn your papers.
children.prevalue: You can hardly suppose monseigneur that having already exceeded my orders which forbade me leaving you a single momentyou can hardly suppose I say that I should have been mad enough to rouse the whole house and allow myself to be seen in the corridor of the bishop of Vannes in order that M Colbert might state with positive certainty that I gave you time to burn your papers

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: My papers?
children.prevalue: My papers

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Of course at least that is what I should have done in your place. When any one opens a door for me I always avail myself of it.
children.prevalue: Of course at least that is what I should have done in your place When any one opens a door for me I always avail myself of it

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Yes, yes, and I thank you, for I have availed myself of it.
children.prevalue: Yes yes and I thank you for I have availed myself of it

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: And you have done perfectly right. Every man has his own peculiar secrets with which others have nothing to do. But let us return to Aramis, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: And you have done perfectly right Every man has his own peculiar secrets with which others have nothing to do But let us return to Aramis monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Well, then, I tell you, you could not have called loud enough, or Aramis would have heard you.
children.prevalue: Well then I tell you you could not have called loud enough or Aramis would have heard you

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: However softly any one may call Aramis, monseigneur, Aramis always hears when he has an interest in hearing. I repeat what I said beforeAramis was not in his own room, or Aramis had certain reasons for not recognizing my voice, of which I am ignorant, and of which you may be even ignorant yourself, notwithstanding your liegeman is His Greatness the Lord Bishop of Vannes.
children.prevalue: However softly any one may call Aramis monseigneur Aramis always hears when he has an interest in hearing I repeat what I said beforeAramis was not in his own room or Aramis had certain reasons for not recognizing my voice of which I am ignorant and of which you may be even ignorant yourself notwithstanding your liegeman is His Greatness the Lord Bishop of Vannes

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Fouquet drew a deep sigh, rose from his seat, took three or four turns in his room, and finished by seating himself, with an expression of extreme dejection, upon his magnificent bed with velvet hangings, and costliest lace. D'Artagnan looked at Fouquet with feelings of the deepest and sincerest pity.
children.prevalue: Fouquet drew a deep sigh rose from his seat took three or four turns in his room and finished by seating himself with an expression of extreme dejection upon his magnificent bed with velvet hangings and costliest lace D Artagnan looked at Fouquet with feelings of the deepest and sincerest pity

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: I have seen a good many men arrested in my life, said the musketeer, sadly I have seen both M. de CinqMars and M. de Chalais arrested, though I was very young then. I have seen M. de Conde arrested with the princes I have seen M. de Retz arrested I have seen M. Broussel arrested. Stay a moment, monseigneur, it is disagreeable to have to say, but the very one of all those whom you most resemble at this moment was that poor fellow Broussel. You were very near doing as he did, putting your dinner napkin in your portfolio, and wiping your mouth with your papers. Mordioux! Monseigneur Fouquet, a man like you ought not to be dejected in this manner. Suppose your friends saw you?
children.prevalue: I have seen a good many men arrested in my life said the musketeer sadly I have seen both M de CinqMars and M de Chalais arrested though I was very young then I have seen M de Conde arrested with the princes I have seen M de Retz arrested I have seen M Broussel arrested Stay a moment monseigneur it is disagreeable to have to say but the very one of all those whom you most resemble at this moment was that poor fellow Broussel You were very near doing as he did putting your dinner napkin in your portfolio and wiping your mouth with your papers Mordioux Monseigneur Fouquet a man like you ought not to be dejected in this manner Suppose your friends saw you

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Monsieur d'Artagnan, returned the surintendant, with a smile full of gentleness, you do not understand me it is precisely because my friends are not looking on, that I am as you see me now. I do not live, exist even, isolated from others I am nothing when left to myself. Understand that throughout my whole life I have passed every moment of my time in making friends, whom I hoped to render my stay and support. In times of prosperity, all these cheerful, happy voicesrendered so through and by my meansformed in my honor a concert of praise and kindly actions. In the least disfavor, these humbler voices accompanied in harmonious accents the murmur of my own heart. Isolation I have never yet known. Poverty (a phantom I have sometimes beheld, clad in rags, awaiting me at the end of my journey through life)poverty has been the specter with which many of my own friends have trifled for years past, which they poetize and caress, and which has attracted me towards them. Poverty! I accept it, acknowledge it, receive it, as a disinherited sister for poverty is neither solitude, nor exile, nor imprisonment. Is it likely I shall ever be poor, with such friends as Pelisson, as La Fontaine, as Moliere? with such a mistress asOh! if you knew how utterly lonely and desolate I feel at this moment, and how you, who separate me from all I love, seem to resemble the image of solitude, of annihilationdeath itself.
children.prevalue: Monsieur d Artagnan returned the surintendant with a smile full of gentleness you do not understand me it is precisely because my friends are not looking on that I am as you see me now I do not live exist even isolated from others I am nothing when left to myself Understand that throughout my whole life I have passed every moment of my time in making friends whom I hoped to render my stay and support In times of prosperity all these cheerful happy voicesrendered so through and by my meansformed in my honor a concert of praise and kindly actions In the least disfavor these humbler voices accompanied in harmonious accents the murmur of my own heart Isolation I have never yet known Poverty a phantom I have sometimes beheld clad in rags awaiting me at the end of my journey through life poverty has been the specter with which many of my own friends have trifled for years past which they poetize and caress and which has attracted me towards them Poverty I accept it acknowledge it receive it as a disinherited sister for poverty is neither solitude nor exile nor imprisonment Is it likely I shall ever be poor with such friends as Pelisson as La Fontaine as Moliere with such a mistress asOh if you knew how utterly lonely and desolate I feel at this moment and how you who separate me from all I love seem to resemble the image of solitude of annihilationdeath itself

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: But I have already told you, Monsieur Fouquet, replied D'Artagnan, moved to the depths of his soul, that you are woefully exaggerating. The king likes you.
children.prevalue: But I have already told you Monsieur Fouquet replied D Artagnan moved to the depths of his soul that you are woefully exaggerating The king likes you

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: No, no, said Fouquet, shaking his head.
children.prevalue: No no said Fouquet shaking his head

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: M. Colbert hates you.
children.prevalue: M Colbert hates you

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: M. Colbert! What does that matter to me?
children.prevalue: M Colbert What does that matter to me

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: He will ruin you.
children.prevalue: He will ruin you

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Ah! I defy him to do that, for I am ruined already.
children.prevalue: Ah I defy him to do that for I am ruined already

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: At this singular confession of the superintendent, D'Artagnan cast his glance all round the room and although he did not open his lips, Fouquet understood him so thoroughly, that he added: What can be done with such wealth of substance as surrounds us, when a man can no longer cultivate his taste for the magnificent? Do you know what good the greater part of the wealth and the possessions which we rich enjoy, confer upon us? merely to disgust us, by their very splendor even, with everything which does not equal it! Vaux! you will say, and the wonders of Vaux! What of it? What boot these wonders? If I am ruined, how shall I fill with water the urns which my Naiads bear in their arms, or force the air into the lungs of my Tritons? To be rich enough, Monsieur d'Artagnan, a man must be too rich.
children.prevalue: At this singular confession of the superintendent D Artagnan cast his glance all round the room and although he did not open his lips Fouquet understood him so thoroughly that he added What can be done with such wealth of substance as surrounds us when a man can no longer cultivate his taste for the magnificent Do you know what good the greater part of the wealth and the possessions which we rich enjoy confer upon us merely to disgust us by their very splendor even with everything which does not equal it Vaux you will say and the wonders of Vaux What of it What boot these wonders If I am ruined how shall I fill with water the urns which my Naiads bear in their arms or force the air into the lungs of my Tritons To be rich enough Monsieur d Artagnan a man must be too rich

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: D'Artagnan shook his head.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan shook his head

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: Oh! I know very well what you think, replied Fouquet, quickly. If Vaux were yours, you would sell it, and would purchase an estate in the country an estate which should have woods, orchards, and land attached, so that the estate should be made to support its master. With forty millions you might
children.prevalue: Oh I know very well what you think replied Fouquet quickly If Vaux were yours you would sell it and would purchase an estate in the country an estate which should have woods orchards and land attached so that the estate should be made to support its master With forty millions you might

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Ten millions, interrupted D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Ten millions interrupted D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: Not a million, my dear captain. No one in France is rich enough to give two millions for Vaux, and to continue to maintain it as I have done no one could do it, no one would know how.
children.prevalue: Not a million my dear captain No one in France is rich enough to give two millions for Vaux and to continue to maintain it as I have done no one could do it no one would know how

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: Well, said D'Artagnan, in any case, a million is not abject misery.
children.prevalue: Well said D Artagnan in any case a million is not abject misery

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: It is not far from it, my dear monsieur. But you do not understand me. No I will not sell my residence at Vaux I will give it to you, if you like and Fouquet accompanied these words with a movement of the shoulders to which it would be impossible to do justice.
children.prevalue: It is not far from it my dear monsieur But you do not understand me No I will not sell my residence at Vaux I will give it to you if you like and Fouquet accompanied these words with a movement of the shoulders to which it would be impossible to do justice

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: Give it to the king you will make a better bargain.
children.prevalue: Give it to the king you will make a better bargain

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: The king does not require me to give it to him, said Fouquet he will take it away from me with the most absolute ease and grace, if it pleases him to do so and that is the very reason I should prefer to see it perish. Do you know, Monsieur d'Artagnan, that if the king did not happen to be under my roof, I would take this candle, go straight to the dome, and set fire to a couple of huge chests of fusees and fireworks which are in reserve there, and would reduce my palace to ashes.
children.prevalue: The king does not require me to give it to him said Fouquet he will take it away from me with the most absolute ease and grace if it pleases him to do so and that is the very reason I should prefer to see it perish Do you know Monsieur d Artagnan that if the king did not happen to be under my roof I would take this candle go straight to the dome and set fire to a couple of huge chests of fusees and fireworks which are in reserve there and would reduce my palace to ashes

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: Bah! said the musketeer, negligently. At all events, you would not be able to burn the gardens, and that is the finest feature of the place.
children.prevalue: Bah said the musketeer negligently At all events you would not be able to burn the gardens and that is the finest feature of the place

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: And yet, resumed Fouquet, thoughtfully, what was I saying? Great heavens! burn Vaux! destroy my palace! But Vaux is not mine these wonderful creations are, it is true, the property, as far as sense of enjoyment goes, of the man who has paid for them but as far as duration is concerned, they belong to those who created them. Vaux belongs to Lebrun, to Lenotre, to Pelisson, to Levau, to La Fontaine, to Moliere Vaux belongs to posterity, in fact. You see, Monsieur d'Artagnan, that my very house has ceased to be my own.
children.prevalue: And yet resumed Fouquet thoughtfully what was I saying Great heavens burn Vaux destroy my palace But Vaux is not mine these wonderful creations are it is true the property as far as sense of enjoyment goes of the man who has paid for them but as far as duration is concerned they belong to those who created them Vaux belongs to Lebrun to Lenotre to Pelisson to Levau to La Fontaine to Moliere Vaux belongs to posterity in fact You see Monsieur d Artagnan that my very house has ceased to be my own

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: That is all well and good, said D'Artagnan the idea is agreeable enough, and I recognize M. Fouquet himself in it. That idea, indeed, makes me forget that poor fellow Broussel altogether and I now fail to recognize in you the whining complaints of that old Frondeur. If you are ruined, monsieur, look at the affair manfully, for you too, mordioux! belong to posterity, and have no right to lessen yourself in any way. Stay a moment look at me, I who seem to exercise in some degree a kind of superiority over you, because I am arresting you fate, which distributes their different parts to the comedians of this world, accorded me a less agreeable and less advantageous part to fill than yours has been. I am one of those who think that the parts which kings and powerful nobles are called upon to act are infinitely of more worth than the parts of beggars or lackeys. It is far better on the stageon the stage, I mean, of another theater than the theater of this worldit is far better to wear a fine coat and to talk a fine language, than to walk the boards shod with a pair of old shoes, or to get one's backbone gently polished by a hearty dressing with a stick. In one word, you have been a prodigal with money, you have ordered and been obeyedhave been steeped to the lips in enjoyment while I have dragged my tether after me, have been commanded and have obeyed, and have drudged my life away. Well, although I may seem of such trifling importance beside you, monseigneur, I do declare to you, that the recollection of what I have done serves me as a spur, and prevents me from bowing my old head too soon. I shall remain unto the very end a trooper and when my turn comes, I shall fall perfectly straight, all in a heap, still alive, after having selected my place beforehand. Do as I do, Monsieur Fouquet, you will not find yourself the worse for it a fall happens only once in a lifetime to men like yourself, and the chief thing is, to take it gracefully when the chance presents itself. There is a Latin proverbthe words have escaped me, but I remember the sense of it very well, for I have thought over it more than oncewhich says, 'The end crowns the work!'

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: Fouquet rose from his seat, passed his arm round D'Artagnan's neck, and clasped him in a close embrace, whilst with the other hand he pressed his hand. An excellent homily, he said, after a moment's pause.
children.prevalue: Fouquet rose from his seat passed his arm round D Artagnan s neck and clasped him in a close embrace whilst with the other hand he pressed his hand An excellent homily he said after a moment s pause

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: A soldier's, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: A soldier s monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: You have a regard for me, in telling me all that.
children.prevalue: You have a regard for me in telling me all that

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: Perhaps.
children.prevalue: Perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Fouquet resumed his pensive attitude once more, and then, a moment after, he said: Where can M. d'Herblay be? I dare not ask you to send for him.
children.prevalue: Fouquet resumed his pensive attitude once more and then a moment after he said Where can M d Herblay be I dare not ask you to send for him

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: You would not ask me, because I would not do it, Monsieur Fouquet. People would learn it, and Aramis, who is not mixed up with the affair, might possibly be compromised and included in your disgrace.
children.prevalue: You would not ask me because I would not do it Monsieur Fouquet People would learn it and Aramis who is not mixed up with the affair might possibly be compromised and included in your disgrace

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: I will wait here till daylight, said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: I will wait here till daylight said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: Yes that is best.
children.prevalue: Yes that is best

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: What shall we do when daylight comes?
children.prevalue: What shall we do when daylight comes

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: I know nothing at all about it, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: I know nothing at all about it monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: Monsieur d'Artagnan, will you do me a favor?
children.prevalue: Monsieur d Artagnan will you do me a favor

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: Most willingly.
children.prevalue: Most willingly

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: You guard me, I remain you are acting in the full discharge of your duty, I suppose?
children.prevalue: You guard me I remain you are acting in the full discharge of your duty I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: Very good, then remain as close to me as my shadow if you like and I infinitely prefer such a shadow to any one else.
children.prevalue: Very good then remain as close to me as my shadow if you like and I infinitely prefer such a shadow to any one else

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: D'Artagnan bowed to the compliment.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan bowed to the compliment

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: But, forget that you are Monsieur d'Artagnan, captain of the musketeers forget that I am Monsieur Fouquet, surintendant of the finances and let us talk about my affairs.
children.prevalue: But forget that you are Monsieur d Artagnan captain of the musketeers forget that I am Monsieur Fouquet surintendant of the finances and let us talk about my affairs

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: That is rather a delicate subject.
children.prevalue: That is rather a delicate subject

children.name: Paragraph_155
children.value: Indeed?
children.prevalue: Indeed

children.name: Paragraph_156
children.value: Yes but, for your sake, Monsieur Fouquet, I will do what may almost be regarded as an impossibility.
children.prevalue: Yes but for your sake Monsieur Fouquet I will do what may almost be regarded as an impossibility

children.name: Paragraph_157
children.value: Thank you. What did the king say to you?
children.prevalue: Thank you What did the king say to you

children.name: Paragraph_158
children.value: Nothing.
children.prevalue: Nothing

children.name: Paragraph_159
children.value: Ah! is that the way you talk?
children.prevalue: Ah is that the way you talk

children.name: Paragraph_160
children.value: The deuce!
children.prevalue: The deuce

children.name: Paragraph_161
children.value: What do you think of my situation?
children.prevalue: What do you think of my situation

children.name: Paragraph_162
children.value: I do not know.
children.prevalue: I do not know

children.name: Paragraph_163
children.value: However, unless you have some ill feeling against me
children.prevalue: However unless you have some ill feeling against me

children.name: Paragraph_164
children.value: Your position is a difficult one.
children.prevalue: Your position is a difficult one

children.name: Paragraph_165
children.value: In what respect?
children.prevalue: In what respect

children.name: Paragraph_166
children.value: Because you are under your own roof.
children.prevalue: Because you are under your own roof

children.name: Paragraph_167
children.value: However difficult it may be, I understand it very well.
children.prevalue: However difficult it may be I understand it very well

children.name: Paragraph_168
children.value: Do you suppose that, with any one else but yourself, I should have shown so much frankness?
children.prevalue: Do you suppose that with any one else but yourself I should have shown so much frankness

children.name: Paragraph_169
children.value: What! so much frankness, do you say? you, who refuse to tell me the slightest thing?
children.prevalue: What so much frankness do you say you who refuse to tell me the slightest thing

children.name: Paragraph_170
children.value: At all events, then, so much ceremony and consideration.
children.prevalue: At all events then so much ceremony and consideration

children.name: Paragraph_171
children.value: Ah! I have nothing to say in that respect.
children.prevalue: Ah I have nothing to say in that respect

children.name: Paragraph_172
children.value: One moment, monseigneur: let me tell you how I should have behaved towards any one but yourself. It might be that I happened to arrive at your door just as your guests or your friends had left youor, if they had not gone yet, I should wait until they were leaving, and should then catch them one after the other, like rabbits I should lock them up quietly enough, I should steal softly along the carpet of your corridor, and with one hand upon you, before you suspected the slightest thing amiss, I should keep you safely until my master's breakfast in the morning. In this way, I should just the same have avoided all publicity, all disturbance, all opposition but there would also have been no warning for M. Fouquet, no consideration for his feelings, none of those delicate concessions which are shown by persons who are essentially courteous in their natures, whenever the decisive moment may arrive. Are you satisfied with the plan?
children.prevalue: One moment monseigneur let me tell you how I should have behaved towards any one but yourself It might be that I happened to arrive at your door just as your guests or your friends had left youor if they had not gone yet I should wait until they were leaving and should then catch them one after the other like rabbits I should lock them up quietly enough I should steal softly along the carpet of your corridor and with one hand upon you before you suspected the slightest thing amiss I should keep you safely until my master s breakfast in the morning In this way I should just the same have avoided all publicity all disturbance all opposition but there would also have been no warning for M Fouquet no consideration for his feelings none of those delicate concessions which are shown by persons who are essentially courteous in their natures whenever the decisive moment may arrive Are you satisfied with the plan

children.name: Paragraph_173
children.value: It makes me shudder.
children.prevalue: It makes me shudder

children.name: Paragraph_174
children.value: I thought you would not like it. It would have been very disagreeable to have made my appearance tomorrow, without any preparation, and to have asked you to deliver up your sword.
children.prevalue: I thought you would not like it It would have been very disagreeable to have made my appearance tomorrow without any preparation and to have asked you to deliver up your sword

children.name: Paragraph_175
children.value: Oh! monsieur, I should have died of shame and anger.
children.prevalue: Oh monsieur I should have died of shame and anger

children.name: Paragraph_176
children.value: Your gratitude is too eloquently expressed. I have not done enough to deserve it, I assure you.
children.prevalue: Your gratitude is too eloquently expressed I have not done enough to deserve it I assure you

children.name: Paragraph_177
children.value: Most certainly, monsieur, you will never get me to believe that.
children.prevalue: Most certainly monsieur you will never get me to believe that

children.name: Paragraph_178
children.value: Well, then, monseigneur, if you are satisfied with what I have done, and have somewhat recovered from the shock which I prepared you for as much as I possibly could, let us allow the few hours that remain to pass away undisturbed. You are harassed, and should arrange your thoughts I beg you, therefore, go to sleep, or pretend to go to sleep, either on your bed, or in your bed I will sleep in this armchair and when I fall asleep, my rest is so sound that a cannon would not wake me.
children.prevalue: Well then monseigneur if you are satisfied with what I have done and have somewhat recovered from the shock which I prepared you for as much as I possibly could let us allow the few hours that remain to pass away undisturbed You are harassed and should arrange your thoughts I beg you therefore go to sleep or pretend to go to sleep either on your bed or in your bed I will sleep in this armchair and when I fall asleep my rest is so sound that a cannon would not wake me

children.name: Paragraph_179
children.value: Fouquet smiled. I expect, however, continued the musketeer, the case of a door being opened, whether a secret door, or any other or the case of any one going out of, or coming into, the roomfor anything like that my ear is as quick and sensitive as the ear of a mouse. Creaking noises make me start. It arises, I suppose, from a natural antipathy to anything of the kind. Move about as much as you like walk up and down in any part of the room, write, efface, destroy, burn,nothing like that will prevent me from going to sleep or even prevent me from snoring, but do not touch either the key or the handle of the door, for I should start up in a moment, and that would shake my nerves and make me ill.

children.name: Paragraph_180
children.value: Monsieur d'Artagnan, said Fouquet, you are certainly the most witty and the most courteous man I ever met with and you will leave me only one regret, that of having made your acquaintance so late.
children.prevalue: Monsieur d Artagnan said Fouquet you are certainly the most witty and the most courteous man I ever met with and you will leave me only one regret that of having made your acquaintance so late

children.name: Paragraph_181
children.value: D'Artagnan drew a deep sigh, which seemed to say, Alas! you have perhaps made it too soon. He then settled himself in his armchair, while Fouquet, half lying on his bed and leaning on his arm, was meditating on his misadventures. In this way, both of them, leaving the candles burning, awaited the first dawn of the day and when Fouquet happened to sigh too loudly, D'Artagnan only snored the louder. Not a single visit, not even from Aramis, disturbed their quietude: not a sound even was heard throughout the whole vast palace. Outside, however, the guards of honor on duty, and the patrol of musketeers, paced up and down and the sound of their feet could be heard on the gravel walks. It seemed to act as an additional soporific for the sleepers, while the murmuring of the wind through the trees, and the unceasing music of the fountains whose waters tumbled in the basin, still went on uninterruptedly, without being disturbed at the slight noises and items of little moment that constitute the life and death of human nature.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: In vivid contrast to the sad and terrible destiny of the king imprisoned in the Bastile, and tearing, in sheer despair, the bolts and bars of his dungeon, the rhetoric of the chroniclers of old would not fail to present, as a complete antithesis, the picture of Philippe lying asleep beneath the royal canopy. We do not pretend to say that such rhetoric is always bad, and always scatters, in places where they have no right to grow, the flowers with which it embellishes and enlivens history. But we shall, on the present occasion, carefully avoid polishing the antithesis in question, but shall proceed to draw another picture as minutely as possible, to serve as foil and counterfoil to the one in the preceding chapter. The young prince alighted from Aramis's room, in the same way the king had descended from the apartment dedicated to Morpheus. The dome gradually and slowly sank down under Aramis's pressure, and Philippe stood beside the royal bed, which had ascended again after having deposited its prisoner in the secret depths of the subterranean passage. Alone, in the presence of all the luxury which surrounded him alone, in the presence of his power alone, with the part he was about to be forced to act, Philippe for the first time felt his heart, and mind, and soul expand beneath the influence of a thousand mutable emotions, which are the vital throbs of a king's heart. He could not help changing color when he looked upon the empty bed, still tumbled by his brother's body. This mute accomplice had returned, after having completed the work it had been destined to perform it returned with the traces of the crime it spoke to the guilty author of that crime, with the frank and unreserved language which an accomplice never fears to use in the company of his companion in guilt for it spoke the truth. Philippe bent over the bed, and perceived a pockethandkerchief lying on it, which was still damp from the cold sweat which had poured from Louis XIV.'s face. This sweatbestained handkerchief terrified Philippe, as the gore of Abel frightened Cain.
