children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: I am face to face with my destiny, said Philippe, his eyes on fire, and his face a livid white. Is it likely to be more terrifying than my captivity has been sad and gloomy? Though I am compelled to follow out, at every moment, the sovereign power and authority I have usurped, shall I cease to listen to the scruples of my heart? Yes! the king has lain on this bed it is indeed his head that has left its impression on this pillow his bitter tears that have stained this handkerchief: and yet, I hesitate to throw myself on the bed, or to press in my hand the handkerchief which is embroidered with my brother's arms. Away with such weakness let me imitate M. d'Herblay, who asserts that a man's action should be always one degree above his thoughts let me imitate M. d'Herblay, whose thoughts are of and for himself alone, who regards himself as a man of honor, so long as he injures or betrays his enemies only. I, I alone, should have occupied this bed, if Louis XIV. had not, owing to my mother's criminal abandonment, stood in my way and this handkerchief, embroidered with the arms of France, would in right and justice belong to me alone, if, as M. d'Herblay observes, I had been left my royal cradle. Philippe, son of France, take your place on that bed Philippe, sole king of France, resume the blazonry that is yours! Philippe, sole heir presumptive to Louis XIII., your father, show yourself without pity or mercy for the usurper who, at this moment, has not even to suffer the agony of the remorse of all that you have had to submit to.
children.prevalue: I am face to face with my destiny said Philippe his eyes on fire and his face a livid white Is it likely to be more terrifying than my captivity has been sad and gloomy Though I am compelled to follow out at every moment the sovereign power and authority I have usurped shall I cease to listen to the scruples of my heart Yes the king has lain on this bed it is indeed his head that has left its impression on this pillow his bitter tears that have stained this handkerchief and yet I hesitate to throw myself on the bed or to press in my hand the handkerchief which is embroidered with my brother s arms Away with such weakness let me imitate M d Herblay who asserts that a man s action should be always one degree above his thoughts let me imitate M d Herblay whose thoughts are of and for himself alone who regards himself as a man of honor so long as he injures or betrays his enemies only I I alone should have occupied this bed if Louis XIV had not owing to my mother s criminal abandonment stood in my way and this handkerchief embroidered with the arms of France would in right and justice belong to me alone if as M d Herblay observes I had been left my royal cradle Philippe son of France take your place on that bed Philippe sole king of France resume the blazonry that is yours Philippe sole heir presumptive to Louis XIII your father show yourself without pity or mercy for the usurper who at this moment has not even to suffer the agony of the remorse of all that you have had to submit to

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: With these words, Philippe, notwithstanding an instinctive repugnance of feeling, and in spite of the shudder of terror which mastered his will, threw himself on the royal bed, and forced his muscles to press the still warm place where Louis XIV. had lain, while he buried his burning face in the handkerchief still moistened by his brother's tears. With his head thrown back and buried in the soft down of his pillow, Philippe perceived above him the crown of France, suspended, as we have stated, by angels with outspread golden wings.
children.prevalue: With these words Philippe notwithstanding an instinctive repugnance of feeling and in spite of the shudder of terror which mastered his will threw himself on the royal bed and forced his muscles to press the still warm place where Louis XIV had lain while he buried his burning face in the handkerchief still moistened by his brother s tears With his head thrown back and buried in the soft down of his pillow Philippe perceived above him the crown of France suspended as we have stated by angels with outspread golden wings

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: A man may be ambitious of lying in a lion's den, but can hardly hope to sleep there quietly. Philippe listened attentively to every sound his heart panted and throbbed at the very suspicion of approaching terror and misfortune but confident in his own strength, which was confirmed by the force of an overpoweringly resolute determination, he waited until some decisive circumstance should permit him to judge for himself. He hoped that imminent danger might be revealed to him, like those phosphoric lights of the tempest which show the sailors the altitude of the waves against which they have to struggle. But nothing approached. Silence, that mortal enemy of restless hearts, and of ambitious minds, shrouded in the thickness of its gloom during the remainder of the night the future king of France, who lay there sheltered beneath his stolen crown. Towards the morning a shadow, rather than a body, glided into the royal chamber Philippe expected his approach and neither expressed nor exhibited any surprise.
children.prevalue: A man may be ambitious of lying in a lion s den but can hardly hope to sleep there quietly Philippe listened attentively to every sound his heart panted and throbbed at the very suspicion of approaching terror and misfortune but confident in his own strength which was confirmed by the force of an overpoweringly resolute determination he waited until some decisive circumstance should permit him to judge for himself He hoped that imminent danger might be revealed to him like those phosphoric lights of the tempest which show the sailors the altitude of the waves against which they have to struggle But nothing approached Silence that mortal enemy of restless hearts and of ambitious minds shrouded in the thickness of its gloom during the remainder of the night the future king of France who lay there sheltered beneath his stolen crown Towards the morning a shadow rather than a body glided into the royal chamber Philippe expected his approach and neither expressed nor exhibited any surprise

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Well, M. d'Herblay?
children.prevalue: Well M d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Well, sire, all is accomplished.
children.prevalue: Well sire all is accomplished

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: How?
children.prevalue: How

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Exactly as we expected.
children.prevalue: Exactly as we expected

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Did he resist?
children.prevalue: Did he resist

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Terribly! tears and entreaties.
children.prevalue: Terribly tears and entreaties

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: And then?
children.prevalue: And then

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: A perfect stupor.
children.prevalue: A perfect stupor

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: But at last?
children.prevalue: But at last

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Oh! at last, a complete victory, and absolute silence.
children.prevalue: Oh at last a complete victory and absolute silence

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Did the governor of the Bastile suspect anything?
children.prevalue: Did the governor of the Bastile suspect anything

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Nothing.
children.prevalue: Nothing

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: The resemblance, however
children.prevalue: The resemblance however

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Was the cause of the success.
children.prevalue: Was the cause of the success

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: But the prisoner cannot fail to explain himself. Think well of that. I have myself been able to do as much as that, on former occasion.
children.prevalue: But the prisoner cannot fail to explain himself Think well of that I have myself been able to do as much as that on former occasion

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: I have already provided for every chance. In a few days, sooner if necessary, we will take the captive out of his prison, and will send him out of the country, to a place of exile so remote
children.prevalue: I have already provided for every chance In a few days sooner if necessary we will take the captive out of his prison and will send him out of the country to a place of exile so remote

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: People can return from their exile, Monsieur d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: People can return from their exile Monsieur d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: To a place of exile so distant, I was going to say, that human strength and the duration of human life would not be enough for his return.
children.prevalue: To a place of exile so distant I was going to say that human strength and the duration of human life would not be enough for his return

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Once more a cold look of intelligence passed between Aramis and the young king.
children.prevalue: Once more a cold look of intelligence passed between Aramis and the young king

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: And M. du Vallon? asked Philippe in order to change the conversation.
children.prevalue: And M du Vallon asked Philippe in order to change the conversation

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: He will be presented to you today, and confidentially will congratulate you on the danger which that conspirator has made you run.
children.prevalue: He will be presented to you today and confidentially will congratulate you on the danger which that conspirator has made you run

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: What is to be done with him?
children.prevalue: What is to be done with him

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: With M. du Vallon?
children.prevalue: With M du Vallon

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Yes confer a dukedom on him, I suppose.
children.prevalue: Yes confer a dukedom on him I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: A dukedom, replied Aramis, smiling in a significant manner.
children.prevalue: A dukedom replied Aramis smiling in a significant manner

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Why do you laugh, Monsieur d'Herblay?
children.prevalue: Why do you laugh Monsieur d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I laugh at the extreme caution of your idea.
children.prevalue: I laugh at the extreme caution of your idea

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Cautious, why so?
children.prevalue: Cautious why so

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Your majesty is doubtless afraid that poor Porthos may possible become a troublesome witness, and you wish to get rid of him.
children.prevalue: Your majesty is doubtless afraid that poor Porthos may possible become a troublesome witness and you wish to get rid of him

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: What! in making him a duke?
children.prevalue: What in making him a duke

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Certainly you would assuredly kill him, for he would die from joy, and the secret would die with him.
children.prevalue: Certainly you would assuredly kill him for he would die from joy and the secret would die with him

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Good heavens!
children.prevalue: Good heavens

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Yes, said Aramis, phlegmatically I should lose a very good friend.
children.prevalue: Yes said Aramis phlegmatically I should lose a very good friend

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: At this moment, and in the middle of this idle conversation, under the light tone of which the two conspirators concealed their joy and pride at their mutual success, Aramis heard something which made him prick up his ears.
children.prevalue: At this moment and in the middle of this idle conversation under the light tone of which the two conspirators concealed their joy and pride at their mutual success Aramis heard something which made him prick up his ears

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: What is that? said Philippe.
children.prevalue: What is that said Philippe

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: The dawn, sire.
children.prevalue: The dawn sire

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Well?
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Well, before you retired to bed last night, you probably decided to do something this morning at break of day.
children.prevalue: Well before you retired to bed last night you probably decided to do something this morning at break of day

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Yes, I told my captain of the musketeers, replied the young man hurriedly, that I should expect him.
children.prevalue: Yes I told my captain of the musketeers replied the young man hurriedly that I should expect him

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: If you told him that, he will certainly be here, for he is a most punctual man.
children.prevalue: If you told him that he will certainly be here for he is a most punctual man

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: I hear a step in the vestibule.
children.prevalue: I hear a step in the vestibule

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: It must be he.
children.prevalue: It must be he

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Come, let us begin the attack, said the young king resolutely.
children.prevalue: Come let us begin the attack said the young king resolutely

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Be cautious for Heaven's sake. To begin the attack, and with D'Artagnan, would be madness. D'Artagnan knows nothing, he has seen nothing he is a hundred miles from suspecting our mystery in the slightest degree, but if he comes into this room the first this morning, he will be sure to detect something of what has taken place, and which he would imagine it his business to occupy himself about. Before we allow D'Artagnan to penetrate into this room, we must air the room thoroughly, or introduce so many people into it, that the keenest scent in the whole kingdom may be deceived by the traces of twenty different persons.
children.prevalue: Be cautious for Heaven s sake To begin the attack and with D Artagnan would be madness D Artagnan knows nothing he has seen nothing he is a hundred miles from suspecting our mystery in the slightest degree but if he comes into this room the first this morning he will be sure to detect something of what has taken place and which he would imagine it his business to occupy himself about Before we allow D Artagnan to penetrate into this room we must air the room thoroughly or introduce so many people into it that the keenest scent in the whole kingdom may be deceived by the traces of twenty different persons

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: But how can I send him away, since I have given him a rendezvous? observed the prince, impatient to measure swords with so redoubtable an antagonist.
children.prevalue: But how can I send him away since I have given him a rendezvous observed the prince impatient to measure swords with so redoubtable an antagonist

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I will take care of that, replied the bishop, and in order to begin, I am going to strike a blow which will completely stupefy our man.
children.prevalue: I will take care of that replied the bishop and in order to begin I am going to strike a blow which will completely stupefy our man

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: He, too, is striking a blow, for I hear him at the door, added the prince, hurriedly.
children.prevalue: He too is striking a blow for I hear him at the door added the prince hurriedly

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: And, in fact, a knock at the door was heard at that moment. Aramis was not mistaken for it was indeed D'Artagnan who adopted that mode of announcing himself.
children.prevalue: And in fact a knock at the door was heard at that moment Aramis was not mistaken for it was indeed D Artagnan who adopted that mode of announcing himself

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: We have seen how he passed the night in philosophizing with M. Fouquet, but the musketeer was very weary even of feigning to fall asleep, and as soon as earliest dawn illumined with its gloomy gleams of light the sumptuous cornices of the superintendent's room, D'Artagnan rose from his armchair, arranged his sword, brushed his coat and hat with his sleeve, like a private soldier getting ready for inspection.
children.prevalue: We have seen how he passed the night in philosophizing with M Fouquet but the musketeer was very weary even of feigning to fall asleep and as soon as earliest dawn illumined with its gloomy gleams of light the sumptuous cornices of the superintendent s room D Artagnan rose from his armchair arranged his sword brushed his coat and hat with his sleeve like a private soldier getting ready for inspection

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Are you going out? said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Are you going out said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Yes, monseigneur. And you?
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur And you

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: I shall remain.
children.prevalue: I shall remain

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: You pledge your word?
children.prevalue: You pledge your word

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Very good. Besides, my only reason for going out is to try and get that reply,you know what I mean?
children.prevalue: Very good Besides my only reason for going out is to try and get that reply you know what I mean

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: That sentence, you mean
children.prevalue: That sentence you mean

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Stay, I have something of the old Roman in me. This morning, when I got up, I remarked that my sword had got caught in one of the aiguillettes, and that my shoulderbelt had slipped quite off. That is an infallible sign.
children.prevalue: Stay I have something of the old Roman in me This morning when I got up I remarked that my sword had got caught in one of the aiguillettes and that my shoulderbelt had slipped quite off That is an infallible sign

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Of prosperity?
children.prevalue: Of prosperity

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Yes, be sure of it for every time that that confounded belt of mine stuck fast to my back, it always signified a punishment from M. de Treville, or a refusal of money by M. de Mazarin. Every time my sword hung fast to my shoulderbelt, it always predicted some disagreeable commission or another for me to execute, and I have had showers of them all my life through. Every time, too, my sword danced about in its sheath, a duel, fortunate in its result, was sure to follow: whenever it dangled about the calves of my legs, it signified a slight wound every time it fell completely out of the scabbard, I was booked, and made up my mind that I should have to remain on the field of battle, with two or three months under surgical bandages into the bargain.
children.prevalue: Yes be sure of it for every time that that confounded belt of mine stuck fast to my back it always signified a punishment from M de Treville or a refusal of money by M de Mazarin Every time my sword hung fast to my shoulderbelt it always predicted some disagreeable commission or another for me to execute and I have had showers of them all my life through Every time too my sword danced about in its sheath a duel fortunate in its result was sure to follow whenever it dangled about the calves of my legs it signified a slight wound every time it fell completely out of the scabbard I was booked and made up my mind that I should have to remain on the field of battle with two or three months under surgical bandages into the bargain

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: I did not know your sword kept you so well informed, said Fouquet, with a faint smile, which showed how he was struggling against his own weakness. Is your sword bewitched, or under the influence of some imperial charm?
children.prevalue: I did not know your sword kept you so well informed said Fouquet with a faint smile which showed how he was struggling against his own weakness Is your sword bewitched or under the influence of some imperial charm

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Why, you must know that my sword may almost be regarded as part of my own body. I have heard that certain men seem to have warnings given them by feeling something the matter with their legs, or a throbbing of their temples. With me, it is my sword that warns me. Well, it told me of nothing this morning. But, stay a momentlook here, it has just fallen of its own accord into the last hole of the belt. Do you know what that is a warning of?
children.prevalue: Why you must know that my sword may almost be regarded as part of my own body I have heard that certain men seem to have warnings given them by feeling something the matter with their legs or a throbbing of their temples With me it is my sword that warns me Well it told me of nothing this morning But stay a momentlook here it has just fallen of its own accord into the last hole of the belt Do you know what that is a warning of

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: No.
children.prevalue: No

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Well, that tells me of an arrest that will have to be made this very day.
children.prevalue: Well that tells me of an arrest that will have to be made this very day

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Well, said the surintendant, more astonished than annoyed by this frankness, if there is nothing disagreeable predicted to you by your sword, I am to conclude that it is not disagreeable for you to arrest me.
children.prevalue: Well said the surintendant more astonished than annoyed by this frankness if there is nothing disagreeable predicted to you by your sword I am to conclude that it is not disagreeable for you to arrest me

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: You! arrest you!
children.prevalue: You arrest you

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Of course. The warning
children.prevalue: Of course The warning

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Does not concern you, since you have been arrested ever since yesterday. It is not you I shall have to arrest, be assured of that. That is the reason why I am delighted, and also the reason why I said that my day will be a happy one.
children.prevalue: Does not concern you since you have been arrested ever since yesterday It is not you I shall have to arrest be assured of that That is the reason why I am delighted and also the reason why I said that my day will be a happy one

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: And with these words, pronounced with the most affectionate graciousness of manner, the captain took leave of Fouquet in order to wait upon the king. He was on the point of leaving the room, when Fouquet said to him, One last mark of kindness.
children.prevalue: And with these words pronounced with the most affectionate graciousness of manner the captain took leave of Fouquet in order to wait upon the king He was on the point of leaving the room when Fouquet said to him One last mark of kindness

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: What is it, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: What is it monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: M. d'Herblay let me see Monsieur d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: M d Herblay let me see Monsieur d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I am going to try and get him to come to you.
children.prevalue: I am going to try and get him to come to you

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: D'Artagnan did not think himself so good a prophet. It was written that the day would pass away and realize all the predictions that had been made in the morning. He had accordingly knocked, as we have seen, at the king's door. The door opened. The captain thought that it was the king who had just opened it himself and this supposition was not altogether inadmissible, considering the state of agitation in which he had left Louis XIV. the previous evening but instead of his royal master, whom he was on the point of saluting with the greatest respect, he perceived the long, calm features of Aramis. So extreme was his surprise that he could hardly refrain from uttering a loud exclamation. Aramis! he said.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan did not think himself so good a prophet It was written that the day would pass away and realize all the predictions that had been made in the morning He had accordingly knocked as we have seen at the king s door The door opened The captain thought that it was the king who had just opened it himself and this supposition was not altogether inadmissible considering the state of agitation in which he had left Louis XIV the previous evening but instead of his royal master whom he was on the point of saluting with the greatest respect he perceived the long calm features of Aramis So extreme was his surprise that he could hardly refrain from uttering a loud exclamation Aramis he said

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Good morning, dear D'Artagnan, replied the prelate, coldly.
children.prevalue: Good morning dear D Artagnan replied the prelate coldly

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: You here! stammered out the musketeer.
children.prevalue: You here stammered out the musketeer

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: His majesty desires you to report that he is still sleeping, after having been greatly fatigued during the whole night.
children.prevalue: His majesty desires you to report that he is still sleeping after having been greatly fatigued during the whole night

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Ah! said D'Artagnan, who could not understand how the bishop of Vannes, who had been so indifferent a favorite the previous evening, had become in half a dozen hours the most magnificent mushroom of fortune that had ever sprung up in a sovereign's bedroom. In fact, to transmit the orders of the king even to the mere threshold of that monarch's room, to serve as an intermediary of Louis XIV. so as to be able to give a single order in his name at a couple paces from him, he must have become more than Richelieu had ever been to Louis XIII. D'Artagnan's expressive eye, halfopened lips, his curling mustache, said as much indeed in the plainest language to the chief favorite, who remained calm and perfectly unmoved.
children.prevalue: Ah said D Artagnan who could not understand how the bishop of Vannes who had been so indifferent a favorite the previous evening had become in half a dozen hours the most magnificent mushroom of fortune that had ever sprung up in a sovereign s bedroom In fact to transmit the orders of the king even to the mere threshold of that monarch s room to serve as an intermediary of Louis XIV so as to be able to give a single order in his name at a couple paces from him he must have become more than Richelieu had ever been to Louis XIII D Artagnan s expressive eye halfopened lips his curling mustache said as much indeed in the plainest language to the chief favorite who remained calm and perfectly unmoved

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Moreover, continued the bishop, you will be good enough, monsieur le capitaine des mousquetaires, to allow those only to pass into the king's room this morning who have special permission. His majesty does not wish to be disturbed just yet.
children.prevalue: Moreover continued the bishop you will be good enough monsieur le capitaine des mousquetaires to allow those only to pass into the king s room this morning who have special permission His majesty does not wish to be disturbed just yet

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: But, objected D'Artagnan, almost on the point of refusing to obey this order, and particularly of giving unrestrained passage to the suspicions which the king's silence had arousedbut, monsieur l'eveque, his majesty gave me a rendezvous for this morning.
children.prevalue: But objected D Artagnan almost on the point of refusing to obey this order and particularly of giving unrestrained passage to the suspicions which the king s silence had arousedbut monsieur l eveque his majesty gave me a rendezvous for this morning

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Later, later, said the king's voice, from the bottom of the alcove a voice which made a cold shudder pass through the musketeer's veins. He bowed, amazed, confused, and stupefied by the smile with which Aramis seemed to overwhelm him, as soon as these words had been pronounced.
children.prevalue: Later later said the king s voice from the bottom of the alcove a voice which made a cold shudder pass through the musketeer s veins He bowed amazed confused and stupefied by the smile with which Aramis seemed to overwhelm him as soon as these words had been pronounced

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: And then, continued the bishop, as an answer to what you were coming to ask the king, my dear D'Artagnan, here is an order of his majesty, which you will be good enough to attend to forthwith, for it concerns M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: And then continued the bishop as an answer to what you were coming to ask the king my dear D Artagnan here is an order of his majesty which you will be good enough to attend to forthwith for it concerns M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: D'Artagnan took the order which was held out to him. To be set at liberty! he murmured. Ah! and he uttered a second ah! still more full of intelligence than the former for this order explained Aramis's presence with the king, and that Aramis, in order to have obtained Fouquet's pardon, must have made considerable progress in the royal favor, and that this favor explained, in its tenor, the hardly conceivable assurance with which M. d'Herblay issued the order in the king's name. For D'Artagnan it was quite sufficient to have understood something of the matter in hand to order to understand the rest. He bowed and withdrew a couple of paces, as though he were about to leave.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan took the order which was held out to him To be set at liberty he murmured Ah and he uttered a second ah still more full of intelligence than the former for this order explained Aramis s presence with the king and that Aramis in order to have obtained Fouquet s pardon must have made considerable progress in the royal favor and that this favor explained in its tenor the hardly conceivable assurance with which M d Herblay issued the order in the king s name For D Artagnan it was quite sufficient to have understood something of the matter in hand to order to understand the rest He bowed and withdrew a couple of paces as though he were about to leave

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: I am going with you, said the bishop.
children.prevalue: I am going with you said the bishop

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Where to?
children.prevalue: Where to

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: To M. Fouquet I wish to be a witness of his delight.
children.prevalue: To M Fouquet I wish to be a witness of his delight

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Ah! Aramis, how you puzzled me just now! said D'Artagnan again.
children.prevalue: Ah Aramis how you puzzled me just now said D Artagnan again

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: But you understand now, I suppose?
children.prevalue: But you understand now I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Of course I understand, he said aloud but added in a low tone to himself, almost hissing the words between his teeth, No, no, I do not understand yet. But it is all the same, for here is the order for it. And then he added, I will lead the way, monseigneur, and he conducted Aramis to Fouquet's apartments.
children.prevalue: Of course I understand he said aloud but added in a low tone to himself almost hissing the words between his teeth No no I do not understand yet But it is all the same for here is the order for it And then he added I will lead the way monseigneur and he conducted Aramis to Fouquet s apartments

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Fouquet was waiting with anxiety he had already sent away many of his servants and friends, who, anticipating the usual hour of his ordinary receptions, had called at his door to inquire after him. Preserving the utmost silence respecting the danger which hung suspended by a hair above his head, he only asked them, as he did every one, indeed, who came to the door, where Aramis was. When he saw D'Artagnan return, and when he perceived the bishop of Vannes behind him, he could hardly restrain his delight it was fully equal to his previous uneasiness. The mere sight of Aramis was a complete compensation to the surintendant for the unhappiness he had undergone in his arrest. The prelate was silent and grave D'Artagnan completely bewildered by such an accumulation of events.
children.prevalue: Fouquet was waiting with anxiety he had already sent away many of his servants and friends who anticipating the usual hour of his ordinary receptions had called at his door to inquire after him Preserving the utmost silence respecting the danger which hung suspended by a hair above his head he only asked them as he did every one indeed who came to the door where Aramis was When he saw D Artagnan return and when he perceived the bishop of Vannes behind him he could hardly restrain his delight it was fully equal to his previous uneasiness The mere sight of Aramis was a complete compensation to the surintendant for the unhappiness he had undergone in his arrest The prelate was silent and grave D Artagnan completely bewildered by such an accumulation of events

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Well, captain, so you have brought M. d'Herblay to me.
children.prevalue: Well captain so you have brought M d Herblay to me

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: And something better still, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: And something better still monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: What is that?
children.prevalue: What is that

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Liberty.
children.prevalue: Liberty

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I am free!
children.prevalue: I am free

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Yes by the king's order.
children.prevalue: Yes by the king s order

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Fouquet resumed his usual serenity, that he might interrogate Aramis with a look.
children.prevalue: Fouquet resumed his usual serenity that he might interrogate Aramis with a look

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Oh! yes, you can thank M. l'eveque de Vannes, pursued D'Artagnan, for it is indeed to him that you owe the change that has taken place in the king.
children.prevalue: Oh yes you can thank M l eveque de Vannes pursued D Artagnan for it is indeed to him that you owe the change that has taken place in the king

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Oh! said Fouquet, more humiliated at the service than grateful at its success.
children.prevalue: Oh said Fouquet more humiliated at the service than grateful at its success

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: But you, continued D'Artagnan, addressing Aramisyou, who have become M. Fouquet's protector and patron, can you not do something for me?
children.prevalue: But you continued D Artagnan addressing Aramisyou who have become M Fouquet s protector and patron can you not do something for me

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Anything in the wide world you like, my friend, replied the bishop, in his calmest tones.
children.prevalue: Anything in the wide world you like my friend replied the bishop in his calmest tones

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: One thing only, then, and I shall be perfectly satisfied. How on earth did you manage to become the favorite of the king, you who have never spoken to him more than twice in your life?
children.prevalue: One thing only then and I shall be perfectly satisfied How on earth did you manage to become the favorite of the king you who have never spoken to him more than twice in your life

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: From a friend such as you are, said Aramis, I cannot conceal anything.
children.prevalue: From a friend such as you are said Aramis I cannot conceal anything

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Ah! very good, tell me, then.
children.prevalue: Ah very good tell me then

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Very well. You think that I have seen the king only twice, whilst the fact is I have seen him more than a hundred times only we have kept it very secret, that is all. And without trying to remove the color which at this revelation made D'Artagnan's face flush scarlet, Aramis turned towards M. Fouquet, who was as much surprised as the musketeer. Monseigneur, he resumed, the king desires me to inform you that he is more than ever your friend, and that your beautiful fete, so generously offered by you on his behalf, has touched him to the very heart.
children.prevalue: Very well You think that I have seen the king only twice whilst the fact is I have seen him more than a hundred times only we have kept it very secret that is all And without trying to remove the color which at this revelation made D Artagnan s face flush scarlet Aramis turned towards M Fouquet who was as much surprised as the musketeer Monseigneur he resumed the king desires me to inform you that he is more than ever your friend and that your beautiful fete so generously offered by you on his behalf has touched him to the very heart

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: And thereupon he saluted M. Fouquet with so much reverence of manner, that the latter, incapable of understanding a man whose diplomacy was of so prodigious a character, remained incapable of uttering a single syllable, and equally incapable of thought or movement. D'Artagnan fancied he perceived that these two men had something to say to each other, and he was about to yield to that feeling of instinctive politeness which in such a case hurries a man towards the door, when he feels his presence is an inconvenience for others but his eager curiosity, spurred on by so many mysteries, counseled him to remain.
children.prevalue: And thereupon he saluted M Fouquet with so much reverence of manner that the latter incapable of understanding a man whose diplomacy was of so prodigious a character remained incapable of uttering a single syllable and equally incapable of thought or movement D Artagnan fancied he perceived that these two men had something to say to each other and he was about to yield to that feeling of instinctive politeness which in such a case hurries a man towards the door when he feels his presence is an inconvenience for others but his eager curiosity spurred on by so many mysteries counseled him to remain

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Aramis thereupon turned towards him, and said, in a quiet tone, You will not forget, my friend, the king's order respecting those whom he intends to receive this morning on rising. These words were clear enough, and the musketeer understood them he therefore bowed to Fouquet, and then to Aramis,to the latter with a slight admixture of ironical respect,and disappeared.
children.prevalue: Aramis thereupon turned towards him and said in a quiet tone You will not forget my friend the king s order respecting those whom he intends to receive this morning on rising These words were clear enough and the musketeer understood them he therefore bowed to Fouquet and then to Aramis to the latter with a slight admixture of ironical respect and disappeared

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: No sooner had he left, than Fouquet, whose impatience had hardly been able to wait for that moment, darted towards the door to close it, and then returning to the bishop, he said, My dear D'Herblay, I think it now high time you should explain all that has passed, for, in plain and honest truth, I do not understand anything.
children.prevalue: No sooner had he left than Fouquet whose impatience had hardly been able to wait for that moment darted towards the door to close it and then returning to the bishop he said My dear D Herblay I think it now high time you should explain all that has passed for in plain and honest truth I do not understand anything

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: We will explain all that to you, said Aramis, sitting down, and making Fouquet sit down also. Where shall I begin?
children.prevalue: We will explain all that to you said Aramis sitting down and making Fouquet sit down also Where shall I begin

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: With this first of all. Why does the king set me at liberty?
children.prevalue: With this first of all Why does the king set me at liberty

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: You ought rather to ask me what his reason was for having you arrested.
children.prevalue: You ought rather to ask me what his reason was for having you arrested

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Since my arrest, I have had time to think over it, and my idea is that it arises out of some slight feeling of jealousy. My fete put M. Colbert out of temper, and M. Colbert discovered some cause of complaint against me BelleIsle, for instance.
children.prevalue: Since my arrest I have had time to think over it and my idea is that it arises out of some slight feeling of jealousy My fete put M Colbert out of temper and M Colbert discovered some cause of complaint against me BelleIsle for instance

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: No there is no question at all just now of BelleIsle.
children.prevalue: No there is no question at all just now of BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: What is it, then?
children.prevalue: What is it then

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Do you remember those receipts for thirteen millions which M. de Mazarin contrived to steal from you?
children.prevalue: Do you remember those receipts for thirteen millions which M de Mazarin contrived to steal from you

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Yes, of course!
children.prevalue: Yes of course

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Well, you are pronounced a public robber.
children.prevalue: Well you are pronounced a public robber

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Good heavens!
children.prevalue: Good heavens

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Oh! that is not all. Do you also remember that letter you wrote to La Valliere?
children.prevalue: Oh that is not all Do you also remember that letter you wrote to La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Alas! yes.
children.prevalue: Alas yes

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: And that proclaims you a traitor and a suborner.
children.prevalue: And that proclaims you a traitor and a suborner

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Why should he have pardoned me, then?
children.prevalue: Why should he have pardoned me then

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: We have not yet arrived at that part of our argument. I wish you to be quite convinced of the fact itself. Observe this well: the king knows you to be guilty of an appropriation of public funds. Oh! of course I know that you have done nothing of the kind but, at all events, the king has seen the receipts, and he can do no other than believe you are incriminated.
children.prevalue: We have not yet arrived at that part of our argument I wish you to be quite convinced of the fact itself Observe this well the king knows you to be guilty of an appropriation of public funds Oh of course I know that you have done nothing of the kind but at all events the king has seen the receipts and he can do no other than believe you are incriminated

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I beg your pardon, I do not see
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon I do not see

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: You will see presently, though. The king, moreover, having read your loveletter to La Valliere, and the offers you there made her, cannot retain any doubt of your intentions with regard to that young lady you will admit that, I suppose?
children.prevalue: You will see presently though The king moreover having read your loveletter to La Valliere and the offers you there made her cannot retain any doubt of your intentions with regard to that young lady you will admit that I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Certainly. Pray conclude.
children.prevalue: Certainly Pray conclude

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: In the fewest words. The king, we may henceforth assume, is your powerful, implacable, and eternal enemy.
children.prevalue: In the fewest words The king we may henceforth assume is your powerful implacable and eternal enemy

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Agreed. But am I, then, so powerful, that he has not dared to sacrifice me, notwithstanding his hatred, with all the means which my weakness, or my misfortunes, may have given him as a hold upon me?
children.prevalue: Agreed But am I then so powerful that he has not dared to sacrifice me notwithstanding his hatred with all the means which my weakness or my misfortunes may have given him as a hold upon me

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: It is clear, beyond all doubt, pursued Aramis, coldly, that the king has quarreled with youirreconcilably.
children.prevalue: It is clear beyond all doubt pursued Aramis coldly that the king has quarreled with youirreconcilably

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: But, since he has absolved me
children.prevalue: But since he has absolved me

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Do you believe it likely? asked the bishop, with a searching look.
children.prevalue: Do you believe it likely asked the bishop with a searching look

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Without believing in his sincerity, I believe it in the accomplished fact.
children.prevalue: Without believing in his sincerity I believe it in the accomplished fact

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Aramis slightly shrugged his shoulders.
children.prevalue: Aramis slightly shrugged his shoulders

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: But why, then, should Louis XIV. have commissioned you to tell me what you have just stated?
children.prevalue: But why then should Louis XIV have commissioned you to tell me what you have just stated

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: The king charged me with no message for you.
children.prevalue: The king charged me with no message for you

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: With nothing! said the superintendent, stupefied. But, that order
children.prevalue: With nothing said the superintendent stupefied But that order

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Oh! yes. You are quite right. There is an order, certainly and these words were pronounced by Aramis in so strange a tone, that Fouquet could not resist starting.
children.prevalue: Oh yes You are quite right There is an order certainly and these words were pronounced by Aramis in so strange a tone that Fouquet could not resist starting

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: You are concealing something from me, I see. What is it?
children.prevalue: You are concealing something from me I see What is it

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Aramis softly rubbed his white fingers over his chin, but said nothing.
children.prevalue: Aramis softly rubbed his white fingers over his chin but said nothing

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Does the king exile me?
children.prevalue: Does the king exile me

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Do not act as if you were playing at the game children play at when they have to try and guess where a thing has been hidden, and are informed, by a bell being rung, when they are approaching near to it, or going away from it.
children.prevalue: Do not act as if you were playing at the game children play at when they have to try and guess where a thing has been hidden and are informed by a bell being rung when they are approaching near to it or going away from it

children.prevalue: Speak then

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Guess.
children.prevalue: Guess

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: You alarm me.
children.prevalue: You alarm me

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Bah! that is because you have not guessed, then.
children.prevalue: Bah that is because you have not guessed then

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: What did the king say to you? In the name of our friendship, do not deceive me.
children.prevalue: What did the king say to you In the name of our friendship do not deceive me

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: The king has not said one word to me.
children.prevalue: The king has not said one word to me

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: You are killing me with impatience, D'Herblay. Am I still superintendent?
children.prevalue: You are killing me with impatience D Herblay Am I still superintendent

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: As long as you like.
children.prevalue: As long as you like

children.name: Paragraph_61

children.prevalue: But what extraordinary empire have you so suddenly acquired over his majesty s mind

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Ah! that's the point.
children.prevalue: Ah that s the point

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: He does your bidding?
children.prevalue: He does your bidding

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: I believe so.
children.prevalue: I believe so

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: It is hardly credible.
children.prevalue: It is hardly credible

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: So any one would say.
children.prevalue: So any one would say

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: D'Herblay, by our alliance, by our friendship, by everything you hold dearest in the world, speak openly, I implore you. By what means have you succeeded in overcoming Louis XIV.'s prejudices, for he did not like you, I am certain.
children.prevalue: D Herblay by our alliance by our friendship by everything you hold dearest in the world speak openly I implore you By what means have you succeeded in overcoming Louis XIV s prejudices for he did not like you I am certain

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: The king will like me now, said Aramis, laying stress upon the last word.
children.prevalue: The king will like me now said Aramis laying stress upon the last word

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: You have something particular, then, between you?
children.prevalue: You have something particular then between you

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: A secret, perhaps?
children.prevalue: A secret perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: A secret.
children.prevalue: A secret

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: A secret of such a nature as to change his majesty's interests?
children.prevalue: A secret of such a nature as to change his majesty s interests

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: You are, indeed, a man of superior intelligence, monseigneur, and have made a particularly accurate guess. I have, in fact, discovered a secret, of a nature to change the interests of the king of France.
children.prevalue: You are indeed a man of superior intelligence monseigneur and have made a particularly accurate guess I have in fact discovered a secret of a nature to change the interests of the king of France

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Ah! said Fouquet, with the reserve of a man who does not wish to ask any more questions.
children.prevalue: Ah said Fouquet with the reserve of a man who does not wish to ask any more questions

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: And you shall judge of it yourself, pursued Aramis and you shall tell me if I am mistaken with regard to the importance of this secret.
children.prevalue: And you shall judge of it yourself pursued Aramis and you shall tell me if I am mistaken with regard to the importance of this secret

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: I am listening, since you are good enough to unbosom yourself to me only do not forget that I have asked you about nothing which it may be indiscreet in you to communicate.
children.prevalue: I am listening since you are good enough to unbosom yourself to me only do not forget that I have asked you about nothing which it may be indiscreet in you to communicate

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Aramis seemed, for a moment, as if he were collecting himself.
children.prevalue: Aramis seemed for a moment as if he were collecting himself

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Do not speak! said Fouquet: there is still time enough.
children.prevalue: Do not speak said Fouquet there is still time enough

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Do you remember, said the bishop, casting down his eyes, the birth of Louis XIV.?
children.prevalue: Do you remember said the bishop casting down his eyes the birth of Louis XIV

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: As if it were yesterday.
children.prevalue: As if it were yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_82

children.prevalue: Have you ever heard anything particular respecting his birth

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Nothing except that the king was not really the son of Louis XIII.
children.prevalue: Nothing except that the king was not really the son of Louis XIII

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: That does not matter to us, or the kingdom either he is the son of his father, says the French law, whose father is recognized by law.
children.prevalue: That does not matter to us or the kingdom either he is the son of his father says the French law whose father is recognized by law

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: True but it is a grave matter, when the quality of races is called into question.
children.prevalue: True but it is a grave matter when the quality of races is called into question

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: A merely secondary question, after all. So that, in fact, you have never learned or heard anything in particular?
children.prevalue: A merely secondary question after all So that in fact you have never learned or heard anything in particular

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Nothing.
children.prevalue: Nothing

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: That is where my secret begins. The queen, you must know, instead of being delivered of a son, was delivered of twins.
children.prevalue: That is where my secret begins The queen you must know instead of being delivered of a son was delivered of twins

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Fouquet looked up suddenly as he replied:
children.prevalue: Fouquet looked up suddenly as he replied

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: And the second is dead?
children.prevalue: And the second is dead

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: You will see. These twins seemed likely to be regarded as the pride of their mother, and the hope of France but the weak nature of the king, his superstitious feelings, made him apprehend a series of conflicts between two children whose rights were equal so he put out of the wayhe suppressedone of the twins.
children.prevalue: You will see These twins seemed likely to be regarded as the pride of their mother and the hope of France but the weak nature of the king his superstitious feelings made him apprehend a series of conflicts between two children whose rights were equal so he put out of the wayhe suppressedone of the twins

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Suppressed, do you say?
children.prevalue: Suppressed do you say

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Have patience. Both the children grew up the one on the throne, whose minister you arethe other, who is my friend, in gloom and isolation.
children.prevalue: Have patience Both the children grew up the one on the throne whose minister you arethe other who is my friend in gloom and isolation

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Good heavens! What are you saying, Monsieur d'Herblay? And what is this poor prince doing?
children.prevalue: Good heavens What are you saying Monsieur d Herblay And what is this poor prince doing

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Ask me, rather, what has he done.
children.prevalue: Ask me rather what has he done

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Yes, yes.
children.prevalue: Yes yes

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: He was brought up in the country, and then thrown into a fortress which goes by the name of the Bastile.
children.prevalue: He was brought up in the country and then thrown into a fortress which goes by the name of the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Is it possible? cried the surintendant, clasping his hands.
children.prevalue: Is it possible cried the surintendant clasping his hands

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: The one was the most fortunate of men: the other the most unhappy and miserable of all living beings.
children.prevalue: The one was the most fortunate of men the other the most unhappy and miserable of all living beings

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Does his mother not know this?
children.prevalue: Does his mother not know this

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Anne of Austria knows it all.
children.prevalue: Anne of Austria knows it all

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: And the king?
children.prevalue: And the king

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Knows absolutely nothing.
children.prevalue: Knows absolutely nothing

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: So much the better, said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: So much the better said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: This remark seemed to make a great impression on Aramis he looked at Fouquet with the most anxious expression of countenance.
children.prevalue: This remark seemed to make a great impression on Aramis he looked at Fouquet with the most anxious expression of countenance

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: I beg your pardon I interrupted you, said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: I beg your pardon I interrupted you said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: I was saying, resumed Aramis, that this poor prince was the unhappiest of human beings, when Heaven, whose thoughts are over all His creatures, undertook to come to his assistance.
children.prevalue: I was saying resumed Aramis that this poor prince was the unhappiest of human beings when Heaven whose thoughts are over all His creatures undertook to come to his assistance

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Oh! in what way? Tell me.
children.prevalue: Oh in what way Tell me

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: You will see. The reigning kingI say the reigning kingyou can guess very well why?
children.prevalue: You will see The reigning kingI say the reigning kingyou can guess very well why

children.value: No. Why?
children.prevalue: No Why

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Because both of them, being legitimate princes, ought to have been kings. Is not that your opinion?
children.prevalue: Because both of them being legitimate princes ought to have been kings Is not that your opinion

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: It is, certainly.
children.prevalue: It is certainly

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Unreservedly?
children.prevalue: Unreservedly

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Most unreservedly twins are one person in two bodies.
children.prevalue: Most unreservedly twins are one person in two bodies

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: I am pleased that a legist of your learning and authority should have pronounced such an opinion. It is agreed, then, that each of them possessed equal rights, is it not?
children.prevalue: I am pleased that a legist of your learning and authority should have pronounced such an opinion It is agreed then that each of them possessed equal rights is it not

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Incontestably! but, gracious heavens, what an extraordinary circumstance!
children.prevalue: Incontestably but gracious heavens what an extraordinary circumstance

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: We are not at the end of it yet.Patience.
children.prevalue: We are not at the end of it yet Patience

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Oh! I shall find 'patience' enough.
children.prevalue: Oh I shall find patience enough

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Heaven wished to raise up for that oppressed child an avenger, or a supporter, or vindicator, if you prefer it. It happened that the reigning king, the usurperyou are quite of my opinion, I believe, that it is an act of usurpation quietly to enjoy, and selfishly to assume the right over, an inheritance to which a man has only half a right?
children.prevalue: Heaven wished to raise up for that oppressed child an avenger or a supporter or vindicator if you prefer it It happened that the reigning king the usurperyou are quite of my opinion I believe that it is an act of usurpation quietly to enjoy and selfishly to assume the right over an inheritance to which a man has only half a right

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Yes, usurpation is the word.
children.prevalue: Yes usurpation is the word

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: In that case, I continue. It was Heaven's will that the usurper should possess, in the person of his first minister, a man of great talent, of large and generous nature.
children.prevalue: In that case I continue It was Heaven s will that the usurper should possess in the person of his first minister a man of great talent of large and generous nature

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: Well, well, said Fouquet, I understand you you have relied upon me to repair the wrong which has been done to this unhappy brother of Louis XIV. You have thought well I will help you. I thank you, D'Herblay, I thank you.
children.prevalue: Well well said Fouquet I understand you you have relied upon me to repair the wrong which has been done to this unhappy brother of Louis XIV You have thought well I will help you I thank you D Herblay I thank you

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Oh, no, it is not that at all you have not allowed me to finish, said Aramis, perfectly unmoved.
children.prevalue: Oh no it is not that at all you have not allowed me to finish said Aramis perfectly unmoved

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: I will not say another word, then.
children.prevalue: I will not say another word then

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: M. Fouquet, I was observing, the minister of the reigning sovereign, was suddenly taken into the greatest aversion, and menaced with the ruin of his fortune, loss of liberty, loss of life even, by intrigue and personal hatred, to which the king gave too readily an attentive ear. But Heaven permits (still, however, out of consideration for the unhappy prince who had been sacrificed) that M. Fouquet should in his turn have a devoted friend who knew this state secret, and felt that he possessed strength and courage enough to divulge this secret, after having had the strength to carry it locked up in his own heart for twenty years.
children.prevalue: M Fouquet I was observing the minister of the reigning sovereign was suddenly taken into the greatest aversion and menaced with the ruin of his fortune loss of liberty loss of life even by intrigue and personal hatred to which the king gave too readily an attentive ear But Heaven permits still however out of consideration for the unhappy prince who had been sacrificed that M Fouquet should in his turn have a devoted friend who knew this state secret and felt that he possessed strength and courage enough to divulge this secret after having had the strength to carry it locked up in his own heart for twenty years

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Go no farther, said Fouquet, full of generous feelings. I understand you, and can guess everything now. You went to see the king when the intelligence of my arrest reached you you implored him, he refused to listen to you then you threatened him with that secret, threatened to reveal it, and Louis XIV., alarmed at the risk of its betrayal, granted to the terror of your indiscretion what he refused to your generous intercession. I understand, I understand you have the king in your power I understand.
children.prevalue: Go no farther said Fouquet full of generous feelings I understand you and can guess everything now You went to see the king when the intelligence of my arrest reached you you implored him he refused to listen to you then you threatened him with that secret threatened to reveal it and Louis XIV alarmed at the risk of its betrayal granted to the terror of your indiscretion what he refused to your generous intercession I understand I understand you have the king in your power I understand

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: You understand nothingas yet, replied Aramis, and again you interrupt me. Then, too, allow me to observe that you pay no attention to logical reasoning, and seem to forget what you ought most to remember.
children.prevalue: You understand nothingas yet replied Aramis and again you interrupt me Then too allow me to observe that you pay no attention to logical reasoning and seem to forget what you ought most to remember

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: You know upon what I laid the greatest stress at the beginning of our conversation?
children.prevalue: You know upon what I laid the greatest stress at the beginning of our conversation

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: Yes, his majesty's hate, invincible hate for me yes, but what feeling of hate could resist the threat of such a revelation?
children.prevalue: Yes his majesty s hate invincible hate for me yes but what feeling of hate could resist the threat of such a revelation

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: Such a revelation, do you say? that is the very point where your logic fails you. What! do you suppose that if I had made such a revelation to the king, I should have been alive now?
children.prevalue: Such a revelation do you say that is the very point where your logic fails you What do you suppose that if I had made such a revelation to the king I should have been alive now

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: It is not ten minutes ago that you were with the king.
children.prevalue: It is not ten minutes ago that you were with the king

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: That may be. He might not have had the time to get me killed outright, but he would have had the time to get me gagged and thrown in a dungeon. Come, come, show a little consistency in your reasoning, mordieu!
children.prevalue: That may be He might not have had the time to get me killed outright but he would have had the time to get me gagged and thrown in a dungeon Come come show a little consistency in your reasoning mordieu

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: And by the mere use of this word, which was so thoroughly his old musketeer's expression, forgotten by one who never seemed to forget anything, Fouquet could not but understand to what a pitch of exaltation the calm, impenetrable bishop of Vannes had wrought himself. He shuddered.
children.prevalue: And by the mere use of this word which was so thoroughly his old musketeer s expression forgotten by one who never seemed to forget anything Fouquet could not but understand to what a pitch of exaltation the calm impenetrable bishop of Vannes had wrought himself He shuddered

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: And then, replied the latter, after having mastered his feelings, should I be the man I really am, should I be the true friend you believe me, if I were to expose you, whom the king already hates so bitterly, to a feeling more than ever to be dreaded in that young man? To have robbed him, is nothing to have addressed the woman he loves, is not much but to hold in your keeping both his crown and his honor, why, he would pluck out your heart with his own hands.
children.prevalue: And then replied the latter after having mastered his feelings should I be the man I really am should I be the true friend you believe me if I were to expose you whom the king already hates so bitterly to a feeling more than ever to be dreaded in that young man To have robbed him is nothing to have addressed the woman he loves is not much but to hold in your keeping both his crown and his honor why he would pluck out your heart with his own hands

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: You have not allowed him to penetrate your secret, then?
children.prevalue: You have not allowed him to penetrate your secret then

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: I would sooner, far sooner, have swallowed at one draught all the poisons that Mithridates drank in twenty years, in order to try and avoid death, than have betrayed my secret to the king.
children.prevalue: I would sooner far sooner have swallowed at one draught all the poisons that Mithridates drank in twenty years in order to try and avoid death than have betrayed my secret to the king

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: What have you done, then?
children.prevalue: What have you done then

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: Ah! now we are coming to the point, monseigneur. I think I shall not fail to excite in you a little interest. You are listening, I hope.
children.prevalue: Ah now we are coming to the point monseigneur I think I shall not fail to excite in you a little interest You are listening I hope

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: How can you ask me if I am listening? Go on.
children.prevalue: How can you ask me if I am listening Go on

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Aramis walked softly all round the room, satisfied himself that they were alone, and that all was silent, and then returned and placed himself close to the armchair in which Fouquet was seated, awaiting with the deepest anxiety the revelation he had to make.
children.prevalue: Aramis walked softly all round the room satisfied himself that they were alone and that all was silent and then returned and placed himself close to the armchair in which Fouquet was seated awaiting with the deepest anxiety the revelation he had to make

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: I forgot to tell you, resumed Aramis, addressing himself to Fouquet, who listened to him with the most absorbed attentionI forgot to mention a most remarkable circumstance respecting these twins, namely, that God had formed them so startlingly, so miraculously, like each other, that it would be utterly impossible to distinguish the one from the other. Their own mother would not be able to distinguish them.
children.prevalue: I forgot to tell you resumed Aramis addressing himself to Fouquet who listened to him with the most absorbed attentionI forgot to mention a most remarkable circumstance respecting these twins namely that God had formed them so startlingly so miraculously like each other that it would be utterly impossible to distinguish the one from the other Their own mother would not be able to distinguish them

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: Is it possible? exclaimed Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Is it possible exclaimed Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: The same noble character in their features, the same carriage, the same stature, the same voice.
children.prevalue: The same noble character in their features the same carriage the same stature the same voice

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: But their thoughts? degree of intelligence? their knowledge of human life?
children.prevalue: But their thoughts degree of intelligence their knowledge of human life

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: There is inequality there, I admit, monseigneur. Yes for the prisoner of the Bastile is, most incontestably, superior in every way to his brother and if, from his prison, this unhappy victim were to pass to the throne, France would not, from the earliest period of its history, perhaps, have had a master more powerful in genius and nobility of character.
children.prevalue: There is inequality there I admit monseigneur Yes for the prisoner of the Bastile is most incontestably superior in every way to his brother and if from his prison this unhappy victim were to pass to the throne France would not from the earliest period of its history perhaps have had a master more powerful in genius and nobility of character

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: Fouquet buried his face in his hands, as if he were overwhelmed by the weight of this immense secret. Aramis approached him.
children.prevalue: Fouquet buried his face in his hands as if he were overwhelmed by the weight of this immense secret Aramis approached him

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: There is a further inequality, he said, continuing his work of temptation, an inequality which concerns yourself, monseigneur, between the twins, both sons of Louis XIII., namely, the last comer does not know M. Colbert.
children.prevalue: There is a further inequality he said continuing his work of temptation an inequality which concerns yourself monseigneur between the twins both sons of Louis XIII namely the last comer does not know M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: Fouquet raised his head immediatelyhis features were pale and distorted. The bolt had hit its marknot his heart, but his mind and comprehension.
children.prevalue: Fouquet raised his head immediatelyhis features were pale and distorted The bolt had hit its marknot his heart but his mind and comprehension

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: I understand you, he said to Aramis you are proposing a conspiracy to me?
children.prevalue: I understand you he said to Aramis you are proposing a conspiracy to me

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: Something like it.
children.prevalue: Something like it

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: One of those attempts which, as you said at the beginning of this conversation, alters the fate of empires?
children.prevalue: One of those attempts which as you said at the beginning of this conversation alters the fate of empires

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: And of superintendents, too yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: And of superintendents too yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: In a word, you propose that I should agree to the substitution of the son of Louis XIII., who is now a prisoner in the Bastile, for the son of Louis XIII., who is at this moment asleep in the Chamber of Morpheus?
children.prevalue: In a word you propose that I should agree to the substitution of the son of Louis XIII who is now a prisoner in the Bastile for the son of Louis XIII who is at this moment asleep in the Chamber of Morpheus

children.name: Paragraph_155
children.value: Aramis smiled with the sinister expression of the sinister thought which was passing through his brain. Exactly, he said.
children.prevalue: Aramis smiled with the sinister expression of the sinister thought which was passing through his brain Exactly he said

children.name: Paragraph_156
children.value: Have you thought, continued Fouquet, becoming animated with that strength of talent which in a few seconds originates, and matures the conception of a plan, and with that largeness of view which foresees all consequences, and embraces every result at a glancehave you thought that we must assemble the nobility, the clergy, and the third estate of the realm that we shall have to depose the reigning sovereign, to disturb by so frightful a scandal the tomb of their dead father, to sacrifice the life, the honor of a woman, Anne of Austria, the life and peace of mind and heart of another woman, Maria Theresa and suppose that it were all done, if we were to succeed in doing it
children.prevalue: Have you thought continued Fouquet becoming animated with that strength of talent which in a few seconds originates and matures the conception of a plan and with that largeness of view which foresees all consequences and embraces every result at a glancehave you thought that we must assemble the nobility the clergy and the third estate of the realm that we shall have to depose the reigning sovereign to disturb by so frightful a scandal the tomb of their dead father to sacrifice the life the honor of a woman Anne of Austria the life and peace of mind and heart of another woman Maria Theresa and suppose that it were all done if we were to succeed in doing it

children.name: Paragraph_157
children.value: I do not understand you, continued Aramis, coldly. There is not a single syllable of sense in all you have just said.
children.prevalue: I do not understand you continued Aramis coldly There is not a single syllable of sense in all you have just said

children.name: Paragraph_158
children.value: What! said the superintendent, surprised, a man like you refuse to view the practical bearing of the case! Do you confine yourself to the childish delight of a political illusion, and neglect the chances of its being carried into execution in other words, the reality itself, is it possible?
children.prevalue: What said the superintendent surprised a man like you refuse to view the practical bearing of the case Do you confine yourself to the childish delight of a political illusion and neglect the chances of its being carried into execution in other words the reality itself is it possible

children.name: Paragraph_159
children.value: My friend, said Aramis, emphasizing the word with a kind of disdainful familiarity, what does Heaven do in order to substitute one king for another?
children.prevalue: My friend said Aramis emphasizing the word with a kind of disdainful familiarity what does Heaven do in order to substitute one king for another

children.name: Paragraph_160
children.value: Heaven! exclaimed FouquetHeaven gives directions to its agent, who seizes upon the doomed victim, hurries him away, and seats the triumphant rival on the empty throne. But you forget that this agent is called death. Oh! Monsieur d'Herblay, in Heaven's name, tell me if you have had the idea
