children.prevalue: Heaven exclaimed FouquetHeaven gives directions to its agent who seizes upon the doomed victim hurries him away and seats the triumphant rival on the empty throne But you forget that this agent is called death Oh Monsieur d Herblay in Heaven s name tell me if you have had the idea

children.name: Paragraph_161
children.value: There is no question of that, monseigneur you are going beyond the object in view. Who spoke of Louis XIV.'s death? who spoke of adopting the example which Heaven sets in following out the strict execution of its decrees? No, I wish you to understand that Heaven effects its purposes without confusion or disturbance, without exciting comment or remark, without difficulty or exertion and that men, inspired by Heaven, succeed like Heaven itself, in all their undertakings, in all they attempt, in all they do.
children.prevalue: There is no question of that monseigneur you are going beyond the object in view Who spoke of Louis XIV s death who spoke of adopting the example which Heaven sets in following out the strict execution of its decrees No I wish you to understand that Heaven effects its purposes without confusion or disturbance without exciting comment or remark without difficulty or exertion and that men inspired by Heaven succeed like Heaven itself in all their undertakings in all they attempt in all they do

children.name: Paragraph_162
children.value: What do you mean?
children.prevalue: What do you mean

children.name: Paragraph_163
children.value: I mean, my friend, returned Aramis, with the same intonation on the word friend that he had applied to it the first timeI mean that if there has been any confusion, scandal, and even effort in the substitution of the prisoner for the king, I defy you to prove it.
children.prevalue: I mean my friend returned Aramis with the same intonation on the word friend that he had applied to it the first timeI mean that if there has been any confusion scandal and even effort in the substitution of the prisoner for the king I defy you to prove it

children.name: Paragraph_164
children.value: What! cried Fouquet, whiter than the handkerchief with which he wiped his temples, what do you say?
children.prevalue: What cried Fouquet whiter than the handkerchief with which he wiped his temples what do you say

children.name: Paragraph_165
children.value: Go to the king's apartment, continued Aramis, tranquilly, and you who know the mystery, I defy even you to perceive that the prisoner of the Bastile is lying in his brother's bed.
children.prevalue: Go to the king s apartment continued Aramis tranquilly and you who know the mystery I defy even you to perceive that the prisoner of the Bastile is lying in his brother s bed

children.name: Paragraph_166
children.value: But the king, stammered Fouquet, seized with horror at the intelligence.
children.prevalue: But the king stammered Fouquet seized with horror at the intelligence

children.name: Paragraph_167
children.value: What king? said Aramis, in his gentlest tone the one who hates you, or the one who likes you?
children.prevalue: What king said Aramis in his gentlest tone the one who hates you or the one who likes you

children.name: Paragraph_168
children.value: The kingofyesterday.
children.prevalue: The kingofyesterday

children.name: Paragraph_169
children.value: The king of yesterday! be quite easy on that score he has gone to take the place in the Bastile which his victim occupied for so many years.
children.prevalue: The king of yesterday be quite easy on that score he has gone to take the place in the Bastile which his victim occupied for so many years

children.name: Paragraph_170
children.value: Great God! And who took him there?
children.prevalue: Great God And who took him there

children.name: Paragraph_171
children.value: I.
children.prevalue: I

children.name: Paragraph_172
children.value: You?
children.prevalue: You

children.name: Paragraph_173
children.value: Yes, and in the simplest way. I carried him away last night. While he was descending into midnight, the other was ascending into day. I do not think there has been any disturbance whatever. A flash of lightning without thunder awakens nobody.
children.prevalue: Yes and in the simplest way I carried him away last night While he was descending into midnight the other was ascending into day I do not think there has been any disturbance whatever A flash of lightning without thunder awakens nobody

children.name: Paragraph_174
children.value: Fouquet uttered a thick, smothered cry, as if he had been struck by some invisible blow, and clasping his head between his clenched hands, he murmured: You did that?
children.prevalue: Fouquet uttered a thick smothered cry as if he had been struck by some invisible blow and clasping his head between his clenched hands he murmured You did that

children.name: Paragraph_175
children.value: Cleverly enough, too what do you think of it?
children.prevalue: Cleverly enough too what do you think of it

children.name: Paragraph_176
children.value: You dethroned the king? imprisoned him, too?
children.prevalue: You dethroned the king imprisoned him too

children.name: Paragraph_177
children.value: Yes, that has been done.
children.prevalue: Yes that has been done

children.name: Paragraph_178
children.value: And such an action was committed here, at Vaux?
children.prevalue: And such an action was committed here at Vaux

children.name: Paragraph_179
children.value: Yes, here, at Vaux, in the Chamber of Morpheus. It would almost seem that it had been built in anticipation of such an act.
children.prevalue: Yes here at Vaux in the Chamber of Morpheus It would almost seem that it had been built in anticipation of such an act

children.name: Paragraph_180
children.value: And at what time did it occur?
children.prevalue: And at what time did it occur

children.name: Paragraph_181
children.value: Last night, between twelve and one o'clock.
children.prevalue: Last night between twelve and one o clock

children.name: Paragraph_182
children.value: Fouquet made a movement as if he were on the point of springing upon Aramis he restrained himself. At Vaux under my roof! he said, in a halfstrangled voice.
children.prevalue: Fouquet made a movement as if he were on the point of springing upon Aramis he restrained himself At Vaux under my roof he said in a halfstrangled voice

children.name: Paragraph_183
children.value: I believe so! for it is still your house, and it is likely to continue so, since M. Colbert cannot rob you of it now.
children.prevalue: I believe so for it is still your house and it is likely to continue so since M Colbert cannot rob you of it now

children.name: Paragraph_184
children.value: It was under my roof, then, monsieur, that you committed this crime?
children.prevalue: It was under my roof then monsieur that you committed this crime

children.name: Paragraph_185
children.value: This crime? said Aramis, stupefied.
children.prevalue: This crime said Aramis stupefied

children.name: Paragraph_186
children.value: This abominable crime! pursued Fouquet, becoming more and more excited this crime more execrable than an assassination! this crime which dishonors my name forever, and entails upon me the horror of posterity.
children.prevalue: This abominable crime pursued Fouquet becoming more and more excited this crime more execrable than an assassination this crime which dishonors my name forever and entails upon me the horror of posterity

children.name: Paragraph_187
children.value: You are not in your senses, monsieur, replied Aramis, in an irresolute tone of voice you are speaking too loudly take care!
children.prevalue: You are not in your senses monsieur replied Aramis in an irresolute tone of voice you are speaking too loudly take care

children.name: Paragraph_188
children.value: I will call out so loudly, that the whole world shall hear me.
children.prevalue: I will call out so loudly that the whole world shall hear me

children.name: Paragraph_189
children.value: Monsieur Fouquet, take care!
children.prevalue: Monsieur Fouquet take care

children.name: Paragraph_190
children.value: Fouquet turned round towards the prelate, whom he looked at full in the face. You have dishonored me, he said, in committing so foul an act of treason, so heinous a crime upon my guest, upon one who was peacefully reposing beneath my roof. Oh! woe, woe is me!
children.prevalue: Fouquet turned round towards the prelate whom he looked at full in the face You have dishonored me he said in committing so foul an act of treason so heinous a crime upon my guest upon one who was peacefully reposing beneath my roof Oh woe woe is me

children.name: Paragraph_191
children.value: Woe to the man, rather, who beneath your roof meditated the ruin of your fortune, your life. Do you forget that?
children.prevalue: Woe to the man rather who beneath your roof meditated the ruin of your fortune your life Do you forget that

children.name: Paragraph_192
children.value: He was my guest, my sovereign.
children.prevalue: He was my guest my sovereign

children.name: Paragraph_193
children.value: Aramis rose, his eyes literally bloodshot, his mouth trembling convulsively. Have I a man out of his senses to deal with? he said.
children.prevalue: Aramis rose his eyes literally bloodshot his mouth trembling convulsively Have I a man out of his senses to deal with he said

children.name: Paragraph_194
children.value: You have an honorable man to deal with.
children.prevalue: You have an honorable man to deal with

children.name: Paragraph_195
children.value: You are mad.
children.prevalue: You are mad

children.name: Paragraph_196
children.value: A man who will prevent you consummating your crime.
children.prevalue: A man who will prevent you consummating your crime

children.name: Paragraph_197
children.value: You are mad, I say.
children.prevalue: You are mad I say

children.name: Paragraph_198
children.value: A man who would sooner, oh! far sooner, die who would kill you even, rather than allow you to complete his dishonor.
children.prevalue: A man who would sooner oh far sooner die who would kill you even rather than allow you to complete his dishonor

children.name: Paragraph_199
children.value: And Fouquet snatched up his sword, which D'Artagnan had placed at the head of his bed, and clenched it resolutely in his hand. Aramis frowned, and thrust his hand into his breast as if in search of a weapon. This movement did not escape Fouquet, who, full of nobleness and pride in his magnanimity, threw his sword to a distance from him, and approached Aramis so close as to touch his shoulder with his disarmed hand. Monsieur, he said, I would sooner die here on the spot than survive this terrible disgrace and if you have any pity left for me, I entreat you to take my life.
children.prevalue: And Fouquet snatched up his sword which D Artagnan had placed at the head of his bed and clenched it resolutely in his hand Aramis frowned and thrust his hand into his breast as if in search of a weapon This movement did not escape Fouquet who full of nobleness and pride in his magnanimity threw his sword to a distance from him and approached Aramis so close as to touch his shoulder with his disarmed hand Monsieur he said I would sooner die here on the spot than survive this terrible disgrace and if you have any pity left for me I entreat you to take my life

children.name: Paragraph_200
children.value: Aramis remained silent and motionless.
children.prevalue: Aramis remained silent and motionless

children.name: Paragraph_201
children.value: You do not reply? said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: You do not reply said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_202
children.value: Aramis raised his head gently, and a glimmer of hope might be seen once more to animate his eyes. Reflect, monseigneur, he said, upon everything we have to expect. As the matter now stands, the king is still alive, and his imprisonment saves your life.
children.prevalue: Aramis raised his head gently and a glimmer of hope might be seen once more to animate his eyes Reflect monseigneur he said upon everything we have to expect As the matter now stands the king is still alive and his imprisonment saves your life

children.name: Paragraph_203
children.value: Yes, replied Fouquet, you may have been acting on my behalf, but I will not, do not, accept your services. But, first of all, I do not wish your ruin. You will leave this house.
children.prevalue: Yes replied Fouquet you may have been acting on my behalf but I will not do not accept your services But first of all I do not wish your ruin You will leave this house

children.name: Paragraph_204
children.value: Aramis stifled the exclamation which almost escaped his broken heart.
children.prevalue: Aramis stifled the exclamation which almost escaped his broken heart

children.name: Paragraph_205
children.value: I am hospitable towards all who are dwellers beneath my roof, continued Fouquet, with an air of inexpressible majesty you will not be more fatally lost than he whose ruin you have consummated.
children.prevalue: I am hospitable towards all who are dwellers beneath my roof continued Fouquet with an air of inexpressible majesty you will not be more fatally lost than he whose ruin you have consummated

children.name: Paragraph_206
children.value: You will be so, said Aramis, in a hoarse, prophetic voice, you will be so, believe me.
children.prevalue: You will be so said Aramis in a hoarse prophetic voice you will be so believe me

children.name: Paragraph_207
children.value: I accept the augury, Monsieur d'Herblay but nothing shall prevent me, nothing shall stop me. You will leave Vauxyou must leave France I give you four hours to place yourself out of the king's reach.
children.prevalue: I accept the augury Monsieur d Herblay but nothing shall prevent me nothing shall stop me You will leave Vauxyou must leave France I give you four hours to place yourself out of the king s reach

children.name: Paragraph_208
children.value: Four hours? said Aramis, scornfully and incredulously.
children.prevalue: Four hours said Aramis scornfully and incredulously

children.name: Paragraph_209
children.value: Upon the word of Fouquet, no one shall follow you before the expiration of that time. You will therefore have four hours' advance of those whom the king may wish to dispatch after you.
children.prevalue: Upon the word of Fouquet no one shall follow you before the expiration of that time You will therefore have four hours advance of those whom the king may wish to dispatch after you

children.name: Paragraph_210
children.value: Four hours! repeated Aramis, in a thick, smothered voice.
children.prevalue: Four hours repeated Aramis in a thick smothered voice

children.name: Paragraph_211
children.value: It is more than you will need to get on board a vessel and flee to BelleIsle, which I give you as a place of refuge.
children.prevalue: It is more than you will need to get on board a vessel and flee to BelleIsle which I give you as a place of refuge

children.name: Paragraph_212
children.value: Ah! murmured Aramis.
children.prevalue: Ah murmured Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_213
children.value: BelleIsle is as much mine for you, as Vaux is mine for the king. Go, D'Herblay, go! as long as I live, not a hair of your head shall be injured.
children.prevalue: BelleIsle is as much mine for you as Vaux is mine for the king Go D Herblay go as long as I live not a hair of your head shall be injured

children.name: Paragraph_214
children.value: Thank you, said Aramis, with a cold irony of manner.
children.prevalue: Thank you said Aramis with a cold irony of manner

children.name: Paragraph_215
children.value: Go at once, then, and give me your hand, before we both hasten away you to save your life, I to save my honor.
children.prevalue: Go at once then and give me your hand before we both hasten away you to save your life I to save my honor

children.name: Paragraph_216
children.value: Aramis withdrew from his breast the hand he had concealed there it was stained with his blood. He had dug his nails into his flesh, as if in punishment for having nursed so many projects, more vain, insensate, and fleeting than the life of the man himself. Fouquet was horrorstricken, and then his heart smote him with pity. He threw open his arms as if to embrace him.
children.prevalue: Aramis withdrew from his breast the hand he had concealed there it was stained with his blood He had dug his nails into his flesh as if in punishment for having nursed so many projects more vain insensate and fleeting than the life of the man himself Fouquet was horrorstricken and then his heart smote him with pity He threw open his arms as if to embrace him

children.name: Paragraph_217
children.value: I had no arms, murmured Aramis, as wild and terrible in his wrath as the shade of Dido. And then, without touching Fouquet's hand, he turned his head aside, and stepped back a pace or two. His last word was an imprecation, his last gesture a curse, which his bloodstained hand seemed to invoke, as it sprinkled on Fouquet's face a few drops of blood which flowed from his breast. And both of them darted out of the room by the secret staircase which led down to the inner courtyard. Fouquet ordered his best horses, while Aramis paused at the foot of the staircase which led to Porthos's apartment. He reflected profoundly and for some time, while Fouquet's carriage left the courtyard at full gallop.
children.prevalue: I had no arms murmured Aramis as wild and terrible in his wrath as the shade of Dido And then without touching Fouquet s hand he turned his head aside and stepped back a pace or two His last word was an imprecation his last gesture a curse which his bloodstained hand seemed to invoke as it sprinkled on Fouquet s face a few drops of blood which flowed from his breast And both of them darted out of the room by the secret staircase which led down to the inner courtyard Fouquet ordered his best horses while Aramis paused at the foot of the staircase which led to Porthos s apartment He reflected profoundly and for some time while Fouquet s carriage left the courtyard at full gallop

children.name: Paragraph_218
children.value: Shall I go alone? said Aramis to himself, or warn the prince? Oh! fury! Warn the prince, and thendo what? Take him with me? To carry this accusing witness about with me everywhere? War, too, would followcivil war, implacable in its nature! And without any resource save myselfit is impossible! What could he do without me? Oh! without me he will be utterly destroyed. Yet who knowslet destiny be fulfilledcondemned he was, let him remain so then! Good or evil Spiritgloomy and scornful Power, whom men call the genius of humanity, thou art a power more restlessly uncertain, more baselessly useless, than wild mountain wind! Chance, thou term'st thyself, but thou art nothing thou inflamest everything with thy breath, crumblest mountains at thy approach, and suddenly art thyself destroyed at the presence of the Cross of dead wood behind which stand another Power invisible like thyselfwhom thou deniest, perhaps, but whose avenging hand is on thee, and hurls thee in the dust dishonored and unnamed! Lost!I am lost! What can be done? Flee to BelleIsle? Yes, and leave Porthos behind me, to talk and relate the whole affair to every one! Porthos, too, who will have to suffer for what he has done. I will not let poor Porthos suffer. He seems like one of the members of my own frame and his grief or misfortune would be mine as well. Porthos shall leave with me, and shall follow my destiny. It must be so.
children.prevalue: Shall I go alone said Aramis to himself or warn the prince Oh fury Warn the prince and thendo what Take him with me To carry this accusing witness about with me everywhere War too would followcivil war implacable in its nature And without any resource save myselfit is impossible What could he do without me Oh without me he will be utterly destroyed Yet who knowslet destiny be fulfilledcondemned he was let him remain so then Good or evil Spiritgloomy and scornful Power whom men call the genius of humanity thou art a power more restlessly uncertain more baselessly useless than wild mountain wind Chance thou term st thyself but thou art nothing thou inflamest everything with thy breath crumblest mountains at thy approach and suddenly art thyself destroyed at the presence of the Cross of dead wood behind which stand another Power invisible like thyselfwhom thou deniest perhaps but whose avenging hand is on thee and hurls thee in the dust dishonored and unnamed Lost I am lost What can be done Flee to BelleIsle Yes and leave Porthos behind me to talk and relate the whole affair to every one Porthos too who will have to suffer for what he has done I will not let poor Porthos suffer He seems like one of the members of my own frame and his grief or misfortune would be mine as well Porthos shall leave with me and shall follow my destiny It must be so

children.name: Paragraph_219
children.value: And Aramis, apprehensive of meeting any one to whom his hurried movements might appear suspicious, ascended the staircase without being perceived. Porthos, so recently returned from Paris, was already in a profound sleep his huge body forgot its fatigue, as his mind forgot its thoughts. Aramis entered, light as a shadow, and placed his nervous grasp on the giant's shoulder. Come, Porthos, he cried, come.
children.prevalue: And Aramis apprehensive of meeting any one to whom his hurried movements might appear suspicious ascended the staircase without being perceived Porthos so recently returned from Paris was already in a profound sleep his huge body forgot its fatigue as his mind forgot its thoughts Aramis entered light as a shadow and placed his nervous grasp on the giant s shoulder Come Porthos he cried come

children.name: Paragraph_220
children.value: Porthos obeyed, rose from his bed, opened his eyes, even before his intelligence seemed to be aroused.
children.prevalue: Porthos obeyed rose from his bed opened his eyes even before his intelligence seemed to be aroused

children.name: Paragraph_221
children.value: We leave immediately, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: We leave immediately said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_222
children.value: Ah! returned Porthos.
children.prevalue: Ah returned Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_223
children.value: We shall go mounted, and faster than we have ever gone in our lives.
children.prevalue: We shall go mounted and faster than we have ever gone in our lives

children.name: Paragraph_224
children.value: Ah! repeated Porthos.
children.prevalue: Ah repeated Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_225
children.value: Dress yourself, my friend.
children.prevalue: Dress yourself my friend

children.name: Paragraph_226
children.value: And he helped the giant to dress himself, and thrust his gold and diamonds into his pocket. Whilst he was thus engaged, a slight noise attracted his attention, and on looking up, he saw D'Artagnan watching them through the halfopened door. Aramis started.
children.prevalue: And he helped the giant to dress himself and thrust his gold and diamonds into his pocket Whilst he was thus engaged a slight noise attracted his attention and on looking up he saw D Artagnan watching them through the halfopened door Aramis started

children.name: Paragraph_227
children.value: What the devil are you doing there in such an agitated manner? said the musketeer.
children.prevalue: What the devil are you doing there in such an agitated manner said the musketeer

children.name: Paragraph_228
children.value: Hush! said Porthos.
children.prevalue: Hush said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_229
children.value: We are going off on a mission of great importance, added the bishop.
children.prevalue: We are going off on a mission of great importance added the bishop

children.name: Paragraph_230
children.value: You are very fortunate, said the musketeer.
children.prevalue: You are very fortunate said the musketeer

children.name: Paragraph_231
children.value: Oh, dear me! said Porthos, I feel so wearied I would far sooner have been fast asleep. But the service of the king....
children.prevalue: Oh dear me said Porthos I feel so wearied I would far sooner have been fast asleep But the service of the king

children.name: Paragraph_232
children.value: Have you seen M. Fouquet? said Aramis to D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Have you seen M Fouquet said Aramis to D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_233
children.value: Yes, this very minute, in a carriage.
children.prevalue: Yes this very minute in a carriage

children.name: Paragraph_234
children.value: What did he say to you?
children.prevalue: What did he say to you

children.name: Paragraph_235
children.value: 'Adieu' nothing more.
children.prevalue: Adieu nothing more

children.name: Paragraph_236
children.value: Was that all?
children.prevalue: Was that all

children.name: Paragraph_237
children.value: What else do you think he could say? Am I worth anything now, since you have got into such high favor?
children.prevalue: What else do you think he could say Am I worth anything now since you have got into such high favor

children.name: Paragraph_238
children.value: Listen, said Aramis, embracing the musketeer your good times are returning again. You will have no occasion to be jealous of any one.
children.prevalue: Listen said Aramis embracing the musketeer your good times are returning again You will have no occasion to be jealous of any one

children.name: Paragraph_239
children.value: Ah! bah!
children.prevalue: Ah bah

children.name: Paragraph_240
children.value: I predict that something will happen to you today which will increase your importance more than ever.
children.prevalue: I predict that something will happen to you today which will increase your importance more than ever

children.name: Paragraph_241
children.value: Really?
children.prevalue: Really

children.name: Paragraph_242
children.value: You know that I know all the news?
children.prevalue: You know that I know all the news

children.name: Paragraph_243
children.value: Oh, yes!
children.prevalue: Oh yes

children.name: Paragraph_244
children.value: Come, Porthos, are you ready? Let us go.
children.prevalue: Come Porthos are you ready Let us go

children.name: Paragraph_245
children.value: I am quite ready, Aramis.
children.prevalue: I am quite ready Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_246
children.value: Let us embrace D'Artagnan first.
children.prevalue: Let us embrace D Artagnan first

children.name: Paragraph_247
children.value: Most certainly.
children.prevalue: Most certainly

children.name: Paragraph_248
children.value: But the horses?
children.prevalue: But the horses

children.name: Paragraph_249
children.value: Oh! there is no want of them here. Will you have mine?
children.prevalue: Oh there is no want of them here Will you have mine

children.name: Paragraph_250
children.value: No Porthos has his own stud. So adieu! adieu!
children.prevalue: No Porthos has his own stud So adieu adieu

children.name: Paragraph_251
children.value: The fugitives mounted their horses beneath the very eyes of the captain of the musketeers, who held Porthos's stirrup for him, and gazed after them until they were out of sight.
children.prevalue: The fugitives mounted their horses beneath the very eyes of the captain of the musketeers who held Porthos s stirrup for him and gazed after them until they were out of sight

children.name: Paragraph_252
children.value: On any other occasion, thought the Gascon, I should say that those gentlemen were making their escape but in these days politics seem so changed that such an exit is termed going on a mission. I have no objection let me attend to my own affairs, that is more than enough for me,and he philosophically entered his apartments.
children.prevalue: On any other occasion thought the Gascon I should say that those gentlemen were making their escape but in these days politics seem so changed that such an exit is termed going on a mission I have no objection let me attend to my own affairs that is more than enough for me and he philosophically entered his apartments

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Fouquet tore along as fast as his horses could drag him. On his way he trembled with horror at the idea of what had just been revealed to him.
children.prevalue: Fouquet tore along as fast as his horses could drag him On his way he trembled with horror at the idea of what had just been revealed to him

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: What must have been, he thought, the youth of those extraordinary men, who, even as age is stealing fast upon them, are still able to conceive such gigantic plans, and carry them through without a tremor?
children.prevalue: What must have been he thought the youth of those extraordinary men who even as age is stealing fast upon them are still able to conceive such gigantic plans and carry them through without a tremor

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: At one moment he could not resist the idea that all Aramis had just been recounting to him was nothing more than a dream, and whether the fable itself was not the snare so that when Fouquet arrived at the Bastile, he might possibly find an order of arrest, which would send him to join the dethroned king. Strongly impressed with this idea, he gave certain sealed orders on his route, while fresh horses were being harnessed to his carriage. These orders were addressed to M. d'Artagnan and to certain others whose fidelity to the king was far above suspicion.
children.prevalue: At one moment he could not resist the idea that all Aramis had just been recounting to him was nothing more than a dream and whether the fable itself was not the snare so that when Fouquet arrived at the Bastile he might possibly find an order of arrest which would send him to join the dethroned king Strongly impressed with this idea he gave certain sealed orders on his route while fresh horses were being harnessed to his carriage These orders were addressed to M d Artagnan and to certain others whose fidelity to the king was far above suspicion

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: In this way, said Fouquet to himself, prisoner or not, I shall have performed the duty that I owe my honor. The orders will not reach them until after my return, if I should return free, and consequently they will not have been unsealed. I shall take them back again. If I am delayed it will be because some misfortune will have befallen me and in that case assistance will be sent for me as well as for the king.
children.prevalue: In this way said Fouquet to himself prisoner or not I shall have performed the duty that I owe my honor The orders will not reach them until after my return if I should return free and consequently they will not have been unsealed I shall take them back again If I am delayed it will be because some misfortune will have befallen me and in that case assistance will be sent for me as well as for the king

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Prepared in this manner, the superintendent arrived at the Bastile he had traveled at the rate of five leagues and a half the hour. Every circumstance of delay which Aramis had escaped in his visit to the Bastile befell Fouquet. It was useless giving his name, equally useless his being recognized he could not succeed in obtaining an entrance. By dint of entreaties, threats, commands, he succeeded in inducing a sentinel to speak to one of the subalterns, who went and told the major. As for the governor they did not even dare disturb him. Fouquet sat in his carriage, at the outer gate of the fortress, chafing with rage and impatience, awaiting the return of the officers, who at last reappeared with a sufficiently sulky air.
children.prevalue: Prepared in this manner the superintendent arrived at the Bastile he had traveled at the rate of five leagues and a half the hour Every circumstance of delay which Aramis had escaped in his visit to the Bastile befell Fouquet It was useless giving his name equally useless his being recognized he could not succeed in obtaining an entrance By dint of entreaties threats commands he succeeded in inducing a sentinel to speak to one of the subalterns who went and told the major As for the governor they did not even dare disturb him Fouquet sat in his carriage at the outer gate of the fortress chafing with rage and impatience awaiting the return of the officers who at last reappeared with a sufficiently sulky air

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Well, said Fouquet, impatiently, what did the major say?
children.prevalue: Well said Fouquet impatiently what did the major say

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Well, monsieur, replied the soldier, the major laughed in my face. He told me that M. Fouquet was at Vaux, and that even were he at Paris, M. Fouquet would not get up at so early an hour as the present.
children.prevalue: Well monsieur replied the soldier the major laughed in my face He told me that M Fouquet was at Vaux and that even were he at Paris M Fouquet would not get up at so early an hour as the present

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Mordieu! you are an absolute set of fools, cried the minister, darting out of the carriage and before the subaltern had time to shut the gate, Fouquet sprang through it, and ran forward in spite of the soldier, who cried out for assistance. Fouquet gained ground, regardless of the cries of the man, who, however, having at last come up with Fouquet, called out to the sentinel of the second gate, Look out, look out, sentinel! The man crossed his pike before the minister but the latter, robust and active, and hurried away, too, by his passion, wrested the pike from the soldier and struck him a violent blow on the shoulder with it. The subaltern, who approached too closely, received a share of the blows as well. Both of them uttered loud and furious cries, at the sound of which the whole of the first body of the advanced guard poured out of the guardhouse. Among them there was one, however, who recognized the superintendent, and who called, Monseigneur, ah! monseigneur. Stop, stop, you fellows! And he effectually checked the soldiers, who were on the point of revenging their companions. Fouquet desired them to open the gate, but they refused to do so without the countersign he desired them to inform the governor of his presence but the latter had already heard the disturbance at the gate. He ran forward, followed by his major, and accompanied by a picket of twenty men, persuaded that an attack was being made on the Bastile. Baisemeaux also recognized Fouquet immediately, and dropped the sword he bravely had been brandishing.
children.prevalue: Mordieu you are an absolute set of fools cried the minister darting out of the carriage and before the subaltern had time to shut the gate Fouquet sprang through it and ran forward in spite of the soldier who cried out for assistance Fouquet gained ground regardless of the cries of the man who however having at last come up with Fouquet called out to the sentinel of the second gate Look out look out sentinel The man crossed his pike before the minister but the latter robust and active and hurried away too by his passion wrested the pike from the soldier and struck him a violent blow on the shoulder with it The subaltern who approached too closely received a share of the blows as well Both of them uttered loud and furious cries at the sound of which the whole of the first body of the advanced guard poured out of the guardhouse Among them there was one however who recognized the superintendent and who called Monseigneur ah monseigneur Stop stop you fellows And he effectually checked the soldiers who were on the point of revenging their companions Fouquet desired them to open the gate but they refused to do so without the countersign he desired them to inform the governor of his presence but the latter had already heard the disturbance at the gate He ran forward followed by his major and accompanied by a picket of twenty men persuaded that an attack was being made on the Bastile Baisemeaux also recognized Fouquet immediately and dropped the sword he bravely had been brandishing

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Ah! monseigneur, he stammered, how can I excuse
children.prevalue: Ah monseigneur he stammered how can I excuse

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Monsieur, said the superintendent, flushed with anger, and heated by his exertions, I congratulate you. Your watch and ward are admirably kept.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said the superintendent flushed with anger and heated by his exertions I congratulate you Your watch and ward are admirably kept

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Baisemeaux turned pale, thinking that this remark was made ironically, and portended a furious burst of anger. But Fouquet had recovered his breath, and, beckoning the sentinel and the subaltern, who were rubbing their shoulders, towards him, he said, There are twenty pistoles for the sentinel, and fifty for the officer. Pray receive my compliments, gentlemen. I will not fail to speak to his majesty about you. And now, M. Baisemeaux, a word with you.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux turned pale thinking that this remark was made ironically and portended a furious burst of anger But Fouquet had recovered his breath and beckoning the sentinel and the subaltern who were rubbing their shoulders towards him he said There are twenty pistoles for the sentinel and fifty for the officer Pray receive my compliments gentlemen I will not fail to speak to his majesty about you And now M Baisemeaux a word with you

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: And he followed the governor to his official residence, accompanied by a murmur of general satisfaction. Baisemeaux was already trembling with shame and uneasiness. Aramis's early visit, from that moment, seemed to possess consequences, which a functionary such as he (Baisemeaux) was, was perfectly justified in apprehending. It was quite another thing, however, when Fouquet in a sharp tone of voice, and with an imperious look, said, You have seen M. d'Herblay this morning?
children.prevalue: And he followed the governor to his official residence accompanied by a murmur of general satisfaction Baisemeaux was already trembling with shame and uneasiness Aramis s early visit from that moment seemed to possess consequences which a functionary such as he Baisemeaux was was perfectly justified in apprehending It was quite another thing however when Fouquet in a sharp tone of voice and with an imperious look said You have seen M d Herblay this morning

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: And are you not horrified at the crime of which you have made yourself an accomplice?
children.prevalue: And are you not horrified at the crime of which you have made yourself an accomplice

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Well, thought Baisemeaux, good so far and then he added, aloud, But what crime, monseigneur, do you allude to?
children.prevalue: Well thought Baisemeaux good so far and then he added aloud But what crime monseigneur do you allude to

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: That for which you can be quartered alive, monsieurdo not forget that! But this is not a time to show anger. Conduct me immediately to the prisoner.
children.prevalue: That for which you can be quartered alive monsieurdo not forget that But this is not a time to show anger Conduct me immediately to the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: To what prisoner? said Baisemeaux, trembling.
children.prevalue: To what prisoner said Baisemeaux trembling

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: You pretend to be ignorant? Very goodit is the best plan for you, perhaps for if, in fact, you were to admit your participation in such a crime, it would be all over with you. I wish, therefore, to seem to believe in your assumption of ignorance.
children.prevalue: You pretend to be ignorant Very goodit is the best plan for you perhaps for if in fact you were to admit your participation in such a crime it would be all over with you I wish therefore to seem to believe in your assumption of ignorance

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I entreat you, monseigneur
children.prevalue: I entreat you monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: That will do. Lead me to the prisoner.
children.prevalue: That will do Lead me to the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: To Marchiali?
children.prevalue: To Marchiali

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Who is Marchiali?
children.prevalue: Who is Marchiali

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The prisoner who was brought back this morning by M. d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: The prisoner who was brought back this morning by M d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: He is called Marchiali? said the superintendent, his conviction somewhat shaken by Baisemeaux's cool manner.
children.prevalue: He is called Marchiali said the superintendent his conviction somewhat shaken by Baisemeaux s cool manner

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Yes, monseigneur that is the name under which he was inscribed here.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur that is the name under which he was inscribed here

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Fouquet looked steadily at Baisemeaux, as if he would read his very heart and perceived, with that clearsightedness most men possess who are accustomed to the exercise of power, that the man was speaking with perfect sincerity. Besides, in observing his face for a few moments, he could not believe that Aramis would have chosen such a confidant.
children.prevalue: Fouquet looked steadily at Baisemeaux as if he would read his very heart and perceived with that clearsightedness most men possess who are accustomed to the exercise of power that the man was speaking with perfect sincerity Besides in observing his face for a few moments he could not believe that Aramis would have chosen such a confidant

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: It is the prisoner, said the superintendent to him, whom M. d'Herblay carried away the day before yesterday?
children.prevalue: It is the prisoner said the superintendent to him whom M d Herblay carried away the day before yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: And whom he brought back this morning? added Fouquet, quickly: for he understood immediately the mechanism of Aramis's plan.
children.prevalue: And whom he brought back this morning added Fouquet quickly for he understood immediately the mechanism of Aramis s plan

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Precisely, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Precisely monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: And his name is Marchiali, you say?
children.prevalue: And his name is Marchiali you say

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Yes, Marchiali. If monseigneur has come here to remove him, so much the better, for I was going to write about him.
children.prevalue: Yes Marchiali If monseigneur has come here to remove him so much the better for I was going to write about him

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: What has he done, then?
children.prevalue: What has he done then

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Ever since this morning he has annoyed me extremely. He has had such terrible fits of passion, as almost to make me believe that he would bring the Bastile itself down about our ears.
children.prevalue: Ever since this morning he has annoyed me extremely He has had such terrible fits of passion as almost to make me believe that he would bring the Bastile itself down about our ears

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I will soon relieve you of his possession, said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: I will soon relieve you of his possession said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Ah! so much the better.
children.prevalue: Ah so much the better

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Conduct me to his prison.
children.prevalue: Conduct me to his prison

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Will monseigneur give me the order?
children.prevalue: Will monseigneur give me the order

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: What order?
children.prevalue: What order

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: An order from the king.
children.prevalue: An order from the king

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Wait until I sign you one.
children.prevalue: Wait until I sign you one

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: That will not be sufficient, monseigneur. I must have an order from the king.
children.prevalue: That will not be sufficient monseigneur I must have an order from the king

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Fouquet assumed an irritated expression. As you are so scrupulous, he said, with regard to allowing prisoners to leave, show me the order by which this one was set at liberty.
children.prevalue: Fouquet assumed an irritated expression As you are so scrupulous he said with regard to allowing prisoners to leave show me the order by which this one was set at liberty

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Baisemeaux showed him the order to release Seldon.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux showed him the order to release Seldon

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Very good, said Fouquet but Seldon is not Marchiali.
children.prevalue: Very good said Fouquet but Seldon is not Marchiali

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: But Marchiali is not at liberty, monseigneur he is here.
children.prevalue: But Marchiali is not at liberty monseigneur he is here

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: But you said that M. d'Herblay carried him away and brought him back again.
children.prevalue: But you said that M d Herblay carried him away and brought him back again

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: I did not say so.
children.prevalue: I did not say so

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: So surely did you say it, that I almost seem to hear it now.
children.prevalue: So surely did you say it that I almost seem to hear it now

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: It was a slip of my tongue, then, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: It was a slip of my tongue then monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Take care, M. Baisemeaux, take care.
children.prevalue: Take care M Baisemeaux take care

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: I have nothing to fear, monseigneur I am acting according to the very strictest regulation.
children.prevalue: I have nothing to fear monseigneur I am acting according to the very strictest regulation

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Do you dare to say so?
children.prevalue: Do you dare to say so

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: I would say so in the presence of one of the apostles. M. d'Herblay brought me an order to set Seldon at liberty. Seldon is free.
children.prevalue: I would say so in the presence of one of the apostles M d Herblay brought me an order to set Seldon at liberty Seldon is free

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I tell you that Marchiali has left the Bastile.
children.prevalue: I tell you that Marchiali has left the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: You must prove that, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: You must prove that monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Let me see him.
children.prevalue: Let me see him

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: You, monseigneur, who govern this kingdom, know very well that no one can see any of the prisoners without an express order from the king.
children.prevalue: You monseigneur who govern this kingdom know very well that no one can see any of the prisoners without an express order from the king

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: M. d'Herblay has entered, however.
children.prevalue: M d Herblay has entered however

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: That remains to be proved, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: That remains to be proved monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: M. de Baisemeaux, once more I warn you to pay particular attention to what you are saying.
children.prevalue: M de Baisemeaux once more I warn you to pay particular attention to what you are saying

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: All the documents are there, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: All the documents are there monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: M. d'Herblay is overthrown.
children.prevalue: M d Herblay is overthrown

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Overthrown?M. d'Herblay! Impossible!
children.prevalue: Overthrown M d Herblay Impossible

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: You see that he has undoubtedly influenced you.
children.prevalue: You see that he has undoubtedly influenced you

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: No, monseigneur what does, in fact, influence me, is the king's service. I am doing my duty. Give me an order from him, and you shall enter.
children.prevalue: No monseigneur what does in fact influence me is the king s service I am doing my duty Give me an order from him and you shall enter

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Stay, M. le gouverneur, I give you my word that if you allow me to see the prisoner, I will give you an order from the king at once.
children.prevalue: Stay M le gouverneur I give you my word that if you allow me to see the prisoner I will give you an order from the king at once

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Give it to me now, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Give it to me now monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: And that, if you refuse me, I will have you and all your officers arrested on the spot.
children.prevalue: And that if you refuse me I will have you and all your officers arrested on the spot

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Before you commit such an act of violence, monseigneur, you will reflect, said Baisemeaux, who had turned very pale, that we will only obey an order signed by the king and that it will be just as easy for you to obtain one to see Marchiali as to obtain one to do me so much injury me, too, who am perfectly innocent.
children.prevalue: Before you commit such an act of violence monseigneur you will reflect said Baisemeaux who had turned very pale that we will only obey an order signed by the king and that it will be just as easy for you to obtain one to see Marchiali as to obtain one to do me so much injury me too who am perfectly innocent

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: True. True! cried Fouquet, furiously perfectly true. M. de Baisemeaux, he added, in a sonorous voice, drawing the unhappy governor towards him, do you know why I am so anxious to speak to the prisoner?
children.prevalue: True True cried Fouquet furiously perfectly true M de Baisemeaux he added in a sonorous voice drawing the unhappy governor towards him do you know why I am so anxious to speak to the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: No, monseigneur and allow me to observe that you are terrifying me out of my senses I am trembling all overin fact, I feel as though I were about to faint.
children.prevalue: No monseigneur and allow me to observe that you are terrifying me out of my senses I am trembling all overin fact I feel as though I were about to faint

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: You will stand a better chance of fainting outright, Monsieur Baisemeaux, when I return here at the head of ten thousand men and thirty pieces of cannon.
children.prevalue: You will stand a better chance of fainting outright Monsieur Baisemeaux when I return here at the head of ten thousand men and thirty pieces of cannon

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Good heavens, monseigneur, you are losing your senses.
children.prevalue: Good heavens monseigneur you are losing your senses

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: When I have roused the whole population of Paris against you and your accursed towers, and have battered open the gates of this place, and hanged you to the topmost tree of yonder pinnacle!
children.prevalue: When I have roused the whole population of Paris against you and your accursed towers and have battered open the gates of this place and hanged you to the topmost tree of yonder pinnacle

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Monseigneur! monseigneur! for pity's sake!
children.prevalue: Monseigneur monseigneur for pity s sake

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: I give you ten minutes to make up your mind, added Fouquet, in a calm voice. I will sit down here, in this armchair, and wait for you if, in ten minutes' time, you still persist, I leave this place, and you may think me as mad as you like. Thenyou shall see!
children.prevalue: I give you ten minutes to make up your mind added Fouquet in a calm voice I will sit down here in this armchair and wait for you if in ten minutes time you still persist I leave this place and you may think me as mad as you like Thenyou shall see

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Baisemeaux stamped his foot on the ground like a man in a state of despair, but he did not reply a single syllable whereupon Fouquet seized a pen and ink, and wrote:
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux stamped his foot on the ground like a man in a state of despair but he did not reply a single syllable whereupon Fouquet seized a pen and ink and wrote

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Order for M. le Prevot des Marchands to assemble the municipal guard and to march upon the Bastile on the king's immediate service.
children.prevalue: Order for M le Prevot des Marchands to assemble the municipal guard and to march upon the Bastile on the king s immediate service

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Baisemeaux shrugged his shoulders. Fouquet wrote:
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux shrugged his shoulders Fouquet wrote

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Order for the Duc de Bouillon and M. le Prince de Conde to assume the command of the Swiss guards, of the king's guards, and to march upon the Bastile on the king's immediate service.
children.prevalue: Order for the Duc de Bouillon and M le Prince de Conde to assume the command of the Swiss guards of the king s guards and to march upon the Bastile on the king s immediate service

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Baisemeaux reflected. Fouquet still wrote:
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux reflected Fouquet still wrote

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Order for every soldier, citizen, or gentleman to seize and apprehend, wherever he may be found, le Chevalier d'Herblay, Eveque de Vannes, and his accomplices, who are: first, M. de Baisemeaux, governor of the Bastile, suspected of the crimes of high treason and rebellion
children.prevalue: Order for every soldier citizen or gentleman to seize and apprehend wherever he may be found le Chevalier d Herblay Eveque de Vannes and his accomplices who are first M de Baisemeaux governor of the Bastile suspected of the crimes of high treason and rebellion

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Stop, monseigneur! cried Baisemeaux I do not understand a single jot of the whole matter but so many misfortunes, even were it madness itself that had set them at their awful work, might happen here in a couple of hours, that the king, by whom I must be judged, will see whether I have been wrong in withdrawing the countersign before this flood of imminent catastrophes. Come with me to the keep, monseigneur, you shall see Marchiali.
children.prevalue: Stop monseigneur cried Baisemeaux I do not understand a single jot of the whole matter but so many misfortunes even were it madness itself that had set them at their awful work might happen here in a couple of hours that the king by whom I must be judged will see whether I have been wrong in withdrawing the countersign before this flood of imminent catastrophes Come with me to the keep monseigneur you shall see Marchiali

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Fouquet darted out of the room, followed by Baisemeaux as he wiped the perspiration from his face. What a terrible morning! he said what a disgrace for me!
children.prevalue: Fouquet darted out of the room followed by Baisemeaux as he wiped the perspiration from his face What a terrible morning he said what a disgrace for me

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Walk faster, replied Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Walk faster replied Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Baisemeaux made a sign to the jailer to precede them. He was afraid of his companion, which the latter could not fail to perceive.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux made a sign to the jailer to precede them He was afraid of his companion which the latter could not fail to perceive

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: A truce to this child's play, he said, roughly. Let the man remain here take the keys yourself, and show me the way. Not a single person, do you understand, must hear what is going to take place here.
children.prevalue: A truce to this child s play he said roughly Let the man remain here take the keys yourself and show me the way Not a single person do you understand must hear what is going to take place here

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Ah! said Baisemeaux, undecided.
children.prevalue: Ah said Baisemeaux undecided

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Again! cried M. Fouquet. Ah! say 'no' at once, and I will leave the Bastile and will myself carry my own dispatches.
children.prevalue: Again cried M Fouquet Ah say no at once and I will leave the Bastile and will myself carry my own dispatches

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Baisemeaux bowed his head, took the keys, and unaccompanied, except by the minister, ascended the staircase. The higher they advanced up the spiral staircase, the more clearly did certain muffled murmurs become distinct appeals and fearful imprecations.
children.prevalue: Baisemeaux bowed his head took the keys and unaccompanied except by the minister ascended the staircase The higher they advanced up the spiral staircase the more clearly did certain muffled murmurs become distinct appeals and fearful imprecations

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: What is that? asked Fouquet.
children.prevalue: What is that asked Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: That is your Marchiali, said the governor this is the way these madmen scream.
children.prevalue: That is your Marchiali said the governor this is the way these madmen scream

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: And he accompanied that reply with a glance more pregnant with injurious allusion, as far as Fouquet was concerned, than politeness. The latter trembled he had just recognized in one cry more terrible than any that had preceded it, the king's voice. He paused on the staircase, snatching the bunch of keys from Baisemeaux, who thought this new madman was going to dash out his brains with one of them. Ah! he cried, M. d'Herblay did not say a word about that.
children.prevalue: And he accompanied that reply with a glance more pregnant with injurious allusion as far as Fouquet was concerned than politeness The latter trembled he had just recognized in one cry more terrible than any that had preceded it the king s voice He paused on the staircase snatching the bunch of keys from Baisemeaux who thought this new madman was going to dash out his brains with one of them Ah he cried M d Herblay did not say a word about that

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Give me the keys at once! cried Fouquet, tearing them from his hand. Which is the key of the door I am to open?
children.prevalue: Give me the keys at once cried Fouquet tearing them from his hand Which is the key of the door I am to open

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: That one.
children.prevalue: That one

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: A fearful cry, followed by a violent blow against the door, made the whole staircase resound with the echo.
children.prevalue: A fearful cry followed by a violent blow against the door made the whole staircase resound with the echo

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Leave this place, said Fouquet to Baisemeaux, in a threatening tone.
children.prevalue: Leave this place said Fouquet to Baisemeaux in a threatening tone

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: I ask nothing better, murmured the latter, to himself. There will be a couple of madmen face to face, and the one will kill the other, I am sure.
children.prevalue: I ask nothing better murmured the latter to himself There will be a couple of madmen face to face and the one will kill the other I am sure

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Go! repeated Fouquet. If you place your foot on this staircase before I call you, remember that you shall take the place of the meanest prisoner in the Bastile.
children.prevalue: Go repeated Fouquet If you place your foot on this staircase before I call you remember that you shall take the place of the meanest prisoner in the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: This job will kill me, I am sure it will, muttered Baisemeaux, as he withdrew with tottering steps.
children.prevalue: This job will kill me I am sure it will muttered Baisemeaux as he withdrew with tottering steps

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: The prisoner's cries became more and more terrible. When Fouquet had satisfied himself that Baisemeaux had reached the bottom of the staircase, he inserted the key in the first lock. It was then that he heard the hoarse, choking voice of the king, crying out, in a frenzy of rage, Help, help! I am the king. The key of the second door was not the same as the first, and Fouquet was obliged to look for it on the bunch. The king, however, furious and almost mad with rage and passion, shouted at the top of his voice, It was M. Fouquet who brought me here. Help me against M. Fouquet! I am the king! Help the king against M. Fouquet! These cries filled the minister's heart with terrible emotions. They were followed by a shower of blows leveled against the door with a part of the broken chair with which the king had armed himself. Fouquet at last succeeded in finding the key. The king was almost exhausted he could hardly articulate distinctly as he shouted, Death to Fouquet! death to the traitor Fouquet! The door flew open.
children.prevalue: The prisoner s cries became more and more terrible When Fouquet had satisfied himself that Baisemeaux had reached the bottom of the staircase he inserted the key in the first lock It was then that he heard the hoarse choking voice of the king crying out in a frenzy of rage Help help I am the king The key of the second door was not the same as the first and Fouquet was obliged to look for it on the bunch The king however furious and almost mad with rage and passion shouted at the top of his voice It was M Fouquet who brought me here Help me against M Fouquet I am the king Help the king against M Fouquet These cries filled the minister s heart with terrible emotions They were followed by a shower of blows leveled against the door with a part of the broken chair with which the king had armed himself Fouquet at last succeeded in finding the key The king was almost exhausted he could hardly articulate distinctly as he shouted Death to Fouquet death to the traitor Fouquet The door flew open

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The two men were on the point of darting towards each other when they suddenly and abruptly stopped, as a mutual recognition took place, and each uttered a cry of horror.
children.prevalue: The two men were on the point of darting towards each other when they suddenly and abruptly stopped as a mutual recognition took place and each uttered a cry of horror

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Have you come to assassinate me, monsieur? said the king, when he recognized Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Have you come to assassinate me monsieur said the king when he recognized Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The king in this state! murmured the minister.
children.prevalue: The king in this state murmured the minister

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Nothing could be more terrible indeed than the appearance of the young prince at the moment Fouquet had surprised him his clothes were in tatters his shirt, open and torn to rags, was stained with sweat and with the blood which streamed from his lacerated breast and arms. Haggard, ghastly pale, his hair in disheveled masses, Louis XIV. presented the most perfect picture of despair, distress, anger and fear combined that could possibly be united in one figure. Fouquet was so touched, so affected and disturbed by it, that he ran towards him with his arms stretched out and his eyes filled with tears. Louis held up the massive piece of wood of which he had made such a furious use.
children.prevalue: Nothing could be more terrible indeed than the appearance of the young prince at the moment Fouquet had surprised him his clothes were in tatters his shirt open and torn to rags was stained with sweat and with the blood which streamed from his lacerated breast and arms Haggard ghastly pale his hair in disheveled masses Louis XIV presented the most perfect picture of despair distress anger and fear combined that could possibly be united in one figure Fouquet was so touched so affected and disturbed by it that he ran towards him with his arms stretched out and his eyes filled with tears Louis held up the massive piece of wood of which he had made such a furious use

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Sire, said Fouquet, in a voice trembling with emotion, do you not recognize the most faithful of your friends?
children.prevalue: Sire said Fouquet in a voice trembling with emotion do you not recognize the most faithful of your friends

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: A friendyou! repeated Louis, gnashing his teeth in a manner which betrayed his hate and desire for speedy vengeance.
children.prevalue: A friendyou repeated Louis gnashing his teeth in a manner which betrayed his hate and desire for speedy vengeance

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The most respectful of your servants, added Fouquet, throwing himself on his knees. The king let the rude weapon fall from his grasp. Fouquet approached him, kissed his knees, and took him in his arms with inconceivable tenderness.
children.prevalue: The most respectful of your servants added Fouquet throwing himself on his knees The king let the rude weapon fall from his grasp Fouquet approached him kissed his knees and took him in his arms with inconceivable tenderness

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: My king, my child, he said, how you must have suffered!
children.prevalue: My king my child he said how you must have suffered

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Louis, recalled to himself by the change of situation, looked at himself, and ashamed of the disordered state of his apparel, ashamed of his conduct, and ashamed of the air of pity and protection that was shown towards him, drew back. Fouquet did not understand this movement he did not perceive that the king's feeling of pride would never forgive him for having been a witness of such an exhibition of weakness.
children.prevalue: Louis recalled to himself by the change of situation looked at himself and ashamed of the disordered state of his apparel ashamed of his conduct and ashamed of the air of pity and protection that was shown towards him drew back Fouquet did not understand this movement he did not perceive that the king s feeling of pride would never forgive him for having been a witness of such an exhibition of weakness

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Come, sire, he said, you are free.
children.prevalue: Come sire he said you are free

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Free? repeated the king. Oh! you set me at liberty, then, after having dared to lift up your hand against me.
children.prevalue: Free repeated the king Oh you set me at liberty then after having dared to lift up your hand against me

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: You do not believe that! exclaimed Fouquet, indignantly you cannot believe me to be guilty of such an act.
children.prevalue: You do not believe that exclaimed Fouquet indignantly you cannot believe me to be guilty of such an act

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And rapidly, warmly even, he related the whole particulars of the intrigue, the details of which are already known to the reader. While the recital continued, Louis suffered the most horrible anguish of mind and when it was finished, the magnitude of the danger he had run struck him far more than the importance of the secret relative to his twin brother.
children.prevalue: And rapidly warmly even he related the whole particulars of the intrigue the details of which are already known to the reader While the recital continued Louis suffered the most horrible anguish of mind and when it was finished the magnitude of the danger he had run struck him far more than the importance of the secret relative to his twin brother

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Monsieur, he said, suddenly to Fouquet, this double birth is a falsehood it is impossibleyou cannot have been the dupe of it.
children.prevalue: Monsieur he said suddenly to Fouquet this double birth is a falsehood it is impossibleyou cannot have been the dupe of it

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Sire!
children.prevalue: Sire

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It is impossible, I tell you, that the honor, the virtue of my mother can be suspected, and my first minister has not yet done justice on the criminals!
children.prevalue: It is impossible I tell you that the honor the virtue of my mother can be suspected and my first minister has not yet done justice on the criminals

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Reflect, sire, before you are hurried away by anger, replied Fouquet. The birth of your brother
children.prevalue: Reflect sire before you are hurried away by anger replied Fouquet The birth of your brother

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I have only one brotherand that is Monsieur. You know it as well as myself. There is a plot, I tell you, beginning with the governor of the Bastile.
children.prevalue: I have only one brotherand that is Monsieur You know it as well as myself There is a plot I tell you beginning with the governor of the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Be careful, sire, for this man has been deceived as every one else has by the prince's likeness to yourself.
children.prevalue: Be careful sire for this man has been deceived as every one else has by the prince s likeness to yourself

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Likeness? Absurd!
children.prevalue: Likeness Absurd

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: This Marchiali must be singularly like your majesty, to be able to deceive every one's eye, Fouquet persisted.
children.prevalue: This Marchiali must be singularly like your majesty to be able to deceive every one s eye Fouquet persisted

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Ridiculous!
children.prevalue: Ridiculous

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Do not say so, sire those who had prepared everything in order to face and deceive your ministers, your mother, your officers of state, the members of your family, must be quite confident of the resemblance between you.
children.prevalue: Do not say so sire those who had prepared everything in order to face and deceive your ministers your mother your officers of state the members of your family must be quite confident of the resemblance between you

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: But where are these persons, then? murmured the king.
children.prevalue: But where are these persons then murmured the king

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: At Vaux.
children.prevalue: At Vaux

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: At Vaux! and you suffer them to remain there!
children.prevalue: At Vaux and you suffer them to remain there

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: My most instant duty appeared to me to be your majesty's release. I have accomplished that duty and now, whatever your majesty may command, shall be done. I await your orders.
children.prevalue: My most instant duty appeared to me to be your majesty s release I have accomplished that duty and now whatever your majesty may command shall be done I await your orders

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Louis reflected for a few moments.
children.prevalue: Louis reflected for a few moments

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Muster all the troops in Paris, he said.
children.prevalue: Muster all the troops in Paris he said

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: All the necessary orders are given for that purpose, replied Fouquet.
children.prevalue: All the necessary orders are given for that purpose replied Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: You have given orders! exclaimed the king.
children.prevalue: You have given orders exclaimed the king

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: For that purpose, yes, sire your majesty will be at the head of ten thousand men in less than an hour.
children.prevalue: For that purpose yes sire your majesty will be at the head of ten thousand men in less than an hour

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The only reply the king made was to take hold of Fouquet's hand with such an expression of feeling, that it was very easy to perceive how strongly he had, until that remark, maintained his suspicions of the minister, notwithstanding the latter's intervention.
children.prevalue: The only reply the king made was to take hold of Fouquet s hand with such an expression of feeling that it was very easy to perceive how strongly he had until that remark maintained his suspicions of the minister notwithstanding the latter s intervention

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: And with these troops, he said, we shall go at once and besiege in your house the rebels who by this time will have established and intrenched themselves therein.
children.prevalue: And with these troops he said we shall go at once and besiege in your house the rebels who by this time will have established and intrenched themselves therein

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I should be surprised if that were the case, replied Fouquet.
children.prevalue: I should be surprised if that were the case replied Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Why?
children.prevalue: Why

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Because their chiefthe very soul of the enterprisehaving been unmasked by me, the whole plan seems to me to have miscarried.
children.prevalue: Because their chiefthe very soul of the enterprisehaving been unmasked by me the whole plan seems to me to have miscarried

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: You have unmasked this false prince also?
children.prevalue: You have unmasked this false prince also

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: No, I have not seen him.
children.prevalue: No I have not seen him

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Whom have you seen, then?
children.prevalue: Whom have you seen then

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The leader of the enterprise, not that unhappy young man the latter is merely an instrument, destined through his whole life to wretchedness, I plainly perceive.
children.prevalue: The leader of the enterprise not that unhappy young man the latter is merely an instrument destined through his whole life to wretchedness I plainly perceive

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Most certainly.
children.prevalue: Most certainly

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: It is M. l'Abbe d'Herblay, Eveque de Vannes.
children.prevalue: It is M l Abbe d Herblay Eveque de Vannes

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Your friend?
children.prevalue: Your friend

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: He was my friend, sire, replied Fouquet, nobly.
children.prevalue: He was my friend sire replied Fouquet nobly

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: An unfortunate circumstance for you, said the king, in a less generous tone of voice.
children.prevalue: An unfortunate circumstance for you said the king in a less generous tone of voice

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Such friendships, sire, had nothing dishonorable in them so long as I was ignorant of the crime.
children.prevalue: Such friendships sire had nothing dishonorable in them so long as I was ignorant of the crime

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: You should have foreseen it.
children.prevalue: You should have foreseen it

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: If I am guilty, I place myself in your majesty's hands.
children.prevalue: If I am guilty I place myself in your majesty s hands

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Ah! Monsieur Fouquet, it was not that I meant, returned the king, sorry to have shown the bitterness of his thought in such a manner. Well! I assure you that, notwithstanding the mask with which the villain covered his face, I had something like a vague suspicion that he was the very man. But with this chief of the enterprise there was a man of prodigious strength, the one who menaced me with a force almost herculean what is he?
children.prevalue: Ah Monsieur Fouquet it was not that I meant returned the king sorry to have shown the bitterness of his thought in such a manner Well I assure you that notwithstanding the mask with which the villain covered his face I had something like a vague suspicion that he was the very man But with this chief of the enterprise there was a man of prodigious strength the one who menaced me with a force almost herculean what is he

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: It must be his friend the Baron du Vallon, formerly one of the musketeers.
children.prevalue: It must be his friend the Baron du Vallon formerly one of the musketeers

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The friend of D'Artagnan? the friend of the Comte de la Fere? Ah! exclaimed the king, as he paused at the name of the latter, we must not forget the connection that existed between the conspirators and M. de Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: The friend of D Artagnan the friend of the Comte de la Fere Ah exclaimed the king as he paused at the name of the latter we must not forget the connection that existed between the conspirators and M de Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Sire, sire, do not go too far. M. de la Fere is the most honorable man in France. Be satisfied with those whom I deliver up to you.
children.prevalue: Sire sire do not go too far M de la Fere is the most honorable man in France Be satisfied with those whom I deliver up to you

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: With those whom you deliver up to me, you say? Very good, for you will deliver up those who are guilty to me.
