children.prevalue: With those whom you deliver up to me you say Very good for you will deliver up those who are guilty to me

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: What does your majesty understand by that? inquired Fouquet.
children.prevalue: What does your majesty understand by that inquired Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: I understand, replied the king, that we shall soon arrive at Vaux with a large body of troops, that we will lay violent hands upon that nest of vipers, and that not a soul shall escape.
children.prevalue: I understand replied the king that we shall soon arrive at Vaux with a large body of troops that we will lay violent hands upon that nest of vipers and that not a soul shall escape

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Your majesty will put these men to death! cried Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Your majesty will put these men to death cried Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: To the very meanest of them.
children.prevalue: To the very meanest of them

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Oh! sire.
children.prevalue: Oh sire

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Let us understand one another, Monsieur Fouquet, said the king, haughtily. We no longer live in times when assassination was the only and the last resource kings held in reservation at extremity. No, Heaven be praised! I have parliaments who sit and judge in my name, and I have scaffolds on which supreme authority is carried out.
children.prevalue: Let us understand one another Monsieur Fouquet said the king haughtily We no longer live in times when assassination was the only and the last resource kings held in reservation at extremity No Heaven be praised I have parliaments who sit and judge in my name and I have scaffolds on which supreme authority is carried out

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Fouquet turned pale. I will take the liberty of observing to your majesty, that any proceedings instituted respecting these matters would bring down the greatest scandal upon the dignity of the throne. The august name of Anne of Austria must never be allowed to pass the lips of the people accompanied by a smile.
children.prevalue: Fouquet turned pale I will take the liberty of observing to your majesty that any proceedings instituted respecting these matters would bring down the greatest scandal upon the dignity of the throne The august name of Anne of Austria must never be allowed to pass the lips of the people accompanied by a smile

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Justice must be done, however, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Justice must be done however monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Good, sire but royal blood must not be shed upon a scaffold.
children.prevalue: Good sire but royal blood must not be shed upon a scaffold

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: The royal blood! you believe that! cried the king with fury in his voice, stamping his foot on the ground. This double birth is an invention and in that invention, particularly, do I see M. d'Herblay's crime. It is the crime I wish to punish rather than the violence, or the insult.
children.prevalue: The royal blood you believe that cried the king with fury in his voice stamping his foot on the ground This double birth is an invention and in that invention particularly do I see M d Herblay s crime It is the crime I wish to punish rather than the violence or the insult

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: And punish it with death, sire?
children.prevalue: And punish it with death sire

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: With death yes, monsieur, I have said it.
children.prevalue: With death yes monsieur I have said it

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Sire, said the surintendant, with firmness, as he raised his head proudly, your majesty will take the life, if you please, of your brother Philippe of France that concerns you alone, and you will doubtless consult the queenmother upon the subject. Whatever she may command will be perfectly correct. I do not wish to mix myself up in it, not even for the honor of your crown, but I have a favor to ask of you, and I beg to submit it to you.
children.prevalue: Sire said the surintendant with firmness as he raised his head proudly your majesty will take the life if you please of your brother Philippe of France that concerns you alone and you will doubtless consult the queenmother upon the subject Whatever she may command will be perfectly correct I do not wish to mix myself up in it not even for the honor of your crown but I have a favor to ask of you and I beg to submit it to you

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Speak, said the king, in no little degree agitated by his minister's last words. What do you require?
children.prevalue: Speak said the king in no little degree agitated by his minister s last words What do you require

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: The pardon of M. d'Herblay and of M. du Vallon.
children.prevalue: The pardon of M d Herblay and of M du Vallon

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: My assassins?
children.prevalue: My assassins

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Two rebels, sire, that is all.
children.prevalue: Two rebels sire that is all

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Oh! I understand, then, you ask me to forgive your friends.
children.prevalue: Oh I understand then you ask me to forgive your friends

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: My friends! said Fouquet, deeply wounded.
children.prevalue: My friends said Fouquet deeply wounded

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Your friends, certainly but the safety of the state requires that an exemplary punishment should be inflicted on the guilty.
children.prevalue: Your friends certainly but the safety of the state requires that an exemplary punishment should be inflicted on the guilty

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I will not permit myself to remind your majesty that I have just restored you to liberty, and have saved your life.
children.prevalue: I will not permit myself to remind your majesty that I have just restored you to liberty and have saved your life

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Monsieur!
children.prevalue: Monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: I will not allow myself to remind your majesty that had M. d'Herblay wished to carry out his character of an assassin, he could very easily have assassinated your majesty this morning in the forest of Senart, and all would have been over. The king started.
children.prevalue: I will not allow myself to remind your majesty that had M d Herblay wished to carry out his character of an assassin he could very easily have assassinated your majesty this morning in the forest of Senart and all would have been over The king started

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: A pistolbullet through the head, pursued Fouquet, and the disfigured features of Louis XIV., which no one could have recognized, would be M. d'Herblay's complete and entire justification.
children.prevalue: A pistolbullet through the head pursued Fouquet and the disfigured features of Louis XIV which no one could have recognized would be M d Herblay s complete and entire justification

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: The king turned pale and giddy at the bare idea of the danger he had escaped.
children.prevalue: The king turned pale and giddy at the bare idea of the danger he had escaped

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: If M. d'Herblay, continued Fouquet, had been an assassin, he had no occasion to inform me of his plan in order to succeed. Freed from the real king, it would have been impossible in all futurity to guess the false. And if the usurper had been recognized by Anne of Austria, he would still have beenher son. The usurper, as far as Monsieur d'Herblay's conscience was concerned, was still a king of the blood of Louis XIII. Moreover, the conspirator, in that course, would have had security, secrecy, impunity. A pistolbullet would have procured him all that. For the sake of Heaven, sire, grant me his forgiveness.
children.prevalue: If M d Herblay continued Fouquet had been an assassin he had no occasion to inform me of his plan in order to succeed Freed from the real king it would have been impossible in all futurity to guess the false And if the usurper had been recognized by Anne of Austria he would still have beenher son The usurper as far as Monsieur d Herblay s conscience was concerned was still a king of the blood of Louis XIII Moreover the conspirator in that course would have had security secrecy impunity A pistolbullet would have procured him all that For the sake of Heaven sire grant me his forgiveness

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: The king, instead of being touched by the picture, so faithfully drawn in all details, of Aramis's generosity, felt himself most painfully and cruelly humiliated. His unconquerable pride revolted at the idea that a man had held suspended at the end of his finger the thread of his royal life. Every word that fell from Fouquet's lips, and which he thought most efficacious in procuring his friend's pardon, seemed to pour another drop of poison into the already ulcerated heart of Louis XIV. Nothing could bend or soften him. Addressing himself to Fouquet, he said, I really don't know, monsieur, why you should solicit the pardon of these men. What good is there in asking that which can be obtained without solicitation?
children.prevalue: The king instead of being touched by the picture so faithfully drawn in all details of Aramis s generosity felt himself most painfully and cruelly humiliated His unconquerable pride revolted at the idea that a man had held suspended at the end of his finger the thread of his royal life Every word that fell from Fouquet s lips and which he thought most efficacious in procuring his friend s pardon seemed to pour another drop of poison into the already ulcerated heart of Louis XIV Nothing could bend or soften him Addressing himself to Fouquet he said I really don t know monsieur why you should solicit the pardon of these men What good is there in asking that which can be obtained without solicitation

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: I do not understand you, sire.
children.prevalue: I do not understand you sire

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: It is not difficult, either. Where am I now?
children.prevalue: It is not difficult either Where am I now

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: In the Bastile, sire.
children.prevalue: In the Bastile sire

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Yes in a dungeon. I am looked upon as a madman, am I not?
children.prevalue: Yes in a dungeon I am looked upon as a madman am I not

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Yes, sire.
children.prevalue: Yes sire

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: And no one is known here but Marchiali?
children.prevalue: And no one is known here but Marchiali

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Well change nothing in the position of affairs. Let the poor madman rot between the slimy walls of the Bastile, and M. d'Herblay and M. du Vallon will stand in no need of my forgiveness. Their new king will absolve them.
children.prevalue: Well change nothing in the position of affairs Let the poor madman rot between the slimy walls of the Bastile and M d Herblay and M du Vallon will stand in no need of my forgiveness Their new king will absolve them

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Your majesty does me a great injustice, sire and you are wrong, replied Fouquet, dryly I am not child enough, nor is M. d'Herblay silly enough, to have omitted to make all these reflections and if I had wished to make a new king, as you say, I had no occasion to have come here to force open the gates and doors of the Bastile, to free you from this place. That would show a want of even common sense. Your majesty's mind is disturbed by anger otherwise you would be far from offending, groundlessly, the very one of your servants who has rendered you the most important service of all.
children.prevalue: Your majesty does me a great injustice sire and you are wrong replied Fouquet dryly I am not child enough nor is M d Herblay silly enough to have omitted to make all these reflections and if I had wished to make a new king as you say I had no occasion to have come here to force open the gates and doors of the Bastile to free you from this place That would show a want of even common sense Your majesty s mind is disturbed by anger otherwise you would be far from offending groundlessly the very one of your servants who has rendered you the most important service of all

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Louis perceived that he had gone too far that the gates of the Bastile were still closed upon him, whilst, by degrees, the floodgates were gradually being opened, behind which the generoushearted Fouquet had restrained his anger. I did not say that to humiliate you, Heaven knows, monsieur, he replied. Only you are addressing yourself to me in order to obtain a pardon, and I answer according to my conscience. And so, judging by my conscience, the criminals we speak of are not worthy of consideration or forgiveness.
children.prevalue: Louis perceived that he had gone too far that the gates of the Bastile were still closed upon him whilst by degrees the floodgates were gradually being opened behind which the generoushearted Fouquet had restrained his anger I did not say that to humiliate you Heaven knows monsieur he replied Only you are addressing yourself to me in order to obtain a pardon and I answer according to my conscience And so judging by my conscience the criminals we speak of are not worthy of consideration or forgiveness

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Fouquet was silent.
children.prevalue: Fouquet was silent

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: What I do is as generous, added the king, as what you have done, for I am in your power. I will even say it is more generous, inasmuch as you place before me certain conditions upon which my liberty, my life, may depend and to reject which is to make a sacrifice of both.
children.prevalue: What I do is as generous added the king as what you have done for I am in your power I will even say it is more generous inasmuch as you place before me certain conditions upon which my liberty my life may depend and to reject which is to make a sacrifice of both

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: I was wrong, certainly, replied Fouquet. Yes,I had the appearance of extorting a favor I regret it, and entreat your majesty's forgiveness.
children.prevalue: I was wrong certainly replied Fouquet Yes I had the appearance of extorting a favor I regret it and entreat your majesty s forgiveness

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: And you are forgiven, my dear Monsieur Fouquet, said the king, with a smile, which restored the serene expression of his features, which so many circumstances had altered since the preceding evening.
children.prevalue: And you are forgiven my dear Monsieur Fouquet said the king with a smile which restored the serene expression of his features which so many circumstances had altered since the preceding evening

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: I have my own forgiveness, replied the minister, with some degree of persistence but M. d'Herblay, and M. du Vallon?
children.prevalue: I have my own forgiveness replied the minister with some degree of persistence but M d Herblay and M du Vallon

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: They will never obtain theirs, as long as I live, replied the inflexible king. Do me the kindness not to speak of it again.
children.prevalue: They will never obtain theirs as long as I live replied the inflexible king Do me the kindness not to speak of it again

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Your majesty shall be obeyed.
children.prevalue: Your majesty shall be obeyed

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: And you will bear me no illwill for it?
children.prevalue: And you will bear me no illwill for it

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Oh! no, sire for I anticipated the event.
children.prevalue: Oh no sire for I anticipated the event

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: You had 'anticipated' that I should refuse to forgive those gentlemen?
children.prevalue: You had anticipated that I should refuse to forgive those gentlemen

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Certainly and all my measures were taken in consequence.
children.prevalue: Certainly and all my measures were taken in consequence

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: What do you mean to say? cried the king, surprised.
children.prevalue: What do you mean to say cried the king surprised

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: M. d'Herblay came, as may be said, to deliver himself into my hands. M. d'Herblay left to me the happiness of saving my king and my country. I could not condemn M. d'Herblay to death nor could I, on the other hand, expose him to your majesty's justifiable wrath it would have been just the same as if I had killed him myself.
children.prevalue: M d Herblay came as may be said to deliver himself into my hands M d Herblay left to me the happiness of saving my king and my country I could not condemn M d Herblay to death nor could I on the other hand expose him to your majesty s justifiable wrath it would have been just the same as if I had killed him myself

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Well! and what have you done?
children.prevalue: Well and what have you done

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Sire, I gave M. d'Herblay the best horses in my stables and four hours' start over all those your majesty might, probably, dispatch after him.
children.prevalue: Sire I gave M d Herblay the best horses in my stables and four hours start over all those your majesty might probably dispatch after him

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Be it so! murmured the king. But still, the world is wide enough and large enough for those whom I may send to overtake your horses, notwithstanding the 'four hours' start' which you have given to M. d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: Be it so murmured the king But still the world is wide enough and large enough for those whom I may send to overtake your horses notwithstanding the four hours start which you have given to M d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: In giving him these four hours, sire, I knew I was giving him his life, and he will save his life.
children.prevalue: In giving him these four hours sire I knew I was giving him his life and he will save his life

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: In what way?
children.prevalue: In what way

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: After having galloped as hard as possible, with the four hours' start, before your musketeers, he will reach my chateau of BelleIsle, where I have given him a safe asylum.
children.prevalue: After having galloped as hard as possible with the four hours start before your musketeers he will reach my chateau of BelleIsle where I have given him a safe asylum

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: That may be! But you forget that you have made me a present of BelleIsle.
children.prevalue: That may be But you forget that you have made me a present of BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: But not for you to arrest my friends.
children.prevalue: But not for you to arrest my friends

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: You take it back again, then?
children.prevalue: You take it back again then

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: As far as that goesyes, sire.
children.prevalue: As far as that goesyes sire

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: My musketeers shall capture it, and the affair will be at an end.
children.prevalue: My musketeers shall capture it and the affair will be at an end

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Neither your musketeers, nor your whole army could take BelleIsle, said Fouquet, coldly. BelleIsle is impregnable.
children.prevalue: Neither your musketeers nor your whole army could take BelleIsle said Fouquet coldly BelleIsle is impregnable

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: The king became perfectly livid a lightning flash seemed to dart from his eyes. Fouquet felt that he was lost, but he as not one to shrink when the voice of honor spoke loudly within him. He bore the king's wrathful gaze the latter swallowed his rage, and after a few moments' silence, said, Are we going to return to Vaux?
children.prevalue: The king became perfectly livid a lightning flash seemed to dart from his eyes Fouquet felt that he was lost but he as not one to shrink when the voice of honor spoke loudly within him He bore the king s wrathful gaze the latter swallowed his rage and after a few moments silence said Are we going to return to Vaux

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: I am at your majesty's orders, replied Fouquet, with a low bow but I think that your majesty can hardly dispense with changing your clothes previous to appearing before your court.
children.prevalue: I am at your majesty s orders replied Fouquet with a low bow but I think that your majesty can hardly dispense with changing your clothes previous to appearing before your court

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: We shall pass by the Louvre, said the king. Come. And they left the prison, passing before Baisemeaux, who looked completely bewildered as he saw Marchiali once more leave and, in his helplessness, tore out the major portion of his few remaining hairs. It was perfectly true, however, that Fouquet wrote and gave him an authority for the prisoner's release, and that the king wrote beneath it, Seen and approved, Louis a piece of madness that Baisemeaux, incapable of putting two ideas together, acknowledged by giving himself a terrible blow on the forehead with his own fist.
children.prevalue: We shall pass by the Louvre said the king Come And they left the prison passing before Baisemeaux who looked completely bewildered as he saw Marchiali once more leave and in his helplessness tore out the major portion of his few remaining hairs It was perfectly true however that Fouquet wrote and gave him an authority for the prisoner s release and that the king wrote beneath it Seen and approved Louis a piece of madness that Baisemeaux incapable of putting two ideas together acknowledged by giving himself a terrible blow on the forehead with his own fist

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: In the meantime, usurped royalty was playing out its part bravely at Vaux. Philippe gave orders that for his petit lever the grandes entrees, already prepared to appear before the king, should be introduced. He determined to give this order notwithstanding the absence of M. d'Herblay, who did not returnour readers know the reason. But the prince, not believing that absence could be prolonged, wished, as all rash spirits do, to try his valor and his fortune far from all protection and instruction. Another reason urged him to thisAnne of Austria was about to appear the guilty mother was about to stand in the presence of her sacrificed son. Philippe was not willing, if he had a weakness, to render the man a witness of it before whom he was bound thenceforth to display so much strength. Philippe opened his folding doors, and several persons entered silently. Philippe did not stir whilst his valets de chambre dressed him. He had watched, the evening before, all the habits of his brother, and played the king in such a manner as to awaken no suspicion. He was thus completely dressed in hunting costume when he received his visitors. His own memory and the notes of Aramis announced everybody to him, first of all Anne of Austria, to whom Monsieur gave his hand, and then Madame with M. de SaintAignan. He smiled at seeing these countenances, but trembled on recognizing his mother. That still so noble and imposing figure, ravaged by pain, pleaded in his heart the cause of the famous queen who had immolated a child to reasons of state. He found his mother still handsome. He knew that Louis XIV. loved her, and he promised himself to love her likewise, and not to prove a scourge to her old age. He contemplated his brother with a tenderness easily to be understood. The latter had usurped nothing, had cast no shades athwart his life. A separate tree, he allowed the stem to rise without heeding its elevation or majestic life. Philippe promised himself to be a kind brother to this prince, who required nothing but gold to minister to his pleasures. He bowed with a friendly air to SaintAignan, who was all reverences and smiles, and trembling held out his hand to Henrietta, his sisterinlaw, whose beauty struck him but he saw in the eyes of that princess an expression of coldness which would facilitate, as he thought, their future relations.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: How much more easy, thought he, it will be to be the brother of that woman than her gallant, if she evinces towards me a coldness that my brother could not have for her, but which is imposed upon me as a duty. The only visit he dreaded at this moment was that of the queen his hearthis mindhad just been shaken by so violent a trial, that, in spite of their firm temperament, they would not, perhaps, support another shock. Happily the queen did not come. Then commenced, on the part of Anne of Austria, a political dissertation upon the welcome M. Fouquet had given to the house of France. She mixed up hostilities with compliments addressed to the king, and questions as to his health, with little maternal flatteries and diplomatic artifices.

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Well, my son, said she, are you convinced with regard to M. Fouquet?
children.prevalue: Well my son said she are you convinced with regard to M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: SaintAignan, said Philippe, have the goodness to go and inquire after the queen.
children.prevalue: SaintAignan said Philippe have the goodness to go and inquire after the queen

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: At these words, the first Philippe had pronounced aloud, the slight difference that there was between his voice and that of the king was sensible to maternal ears, and Anne of Austria looked earnestly at her son. SaintAignan left the room, and Philippe continued:
children.prevalue: At these words the first Philippe had pronounced aloud the slight difference that there was between his voice and that of the king was sensible to maternal ears and Anne of Austria looked earnestly at her son SaintAignan left the room and Philippe continued

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Madame, I do not like to hear M. Fouquet illspoken of, you know I do notand you have even spoken well of him yourself.
children.prevalue: Madame I do not like to hear M Fouquet illspoken of you know I do notand you have even spoken well of him yourself

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: That is true therefore I only question you on the state of your sentiments with respect to him.
children.prevalue: That is true therefore I only question you on the state of your sentiments with respect to him

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Sire, said Henrietta, I, on my part, have always liked M. Fouquet. He is a man of good taste,a superior man.
children.prevalue: Sire said Henrietta I on my part have always liked M Fouquet He is a man of good taste a superior man

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: A superintendent who is never sordid or niggardly, added Monsieur and who pays in gold all the orders I have on him.
children.prevalue: A superintendent who is never sordid or niggardly added Monsieur and who pays in gold all the orders I have on him

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Every one in this thinks too much of himself, and nobody for the state, said the old queen. M. Fouquet, it is a fact, M. Fouquet is ruining the state.
children.prevalue: Every one in this thinks too much of himself and nobody for the state said the old queen M Fouquet it is a fact M Fouquet is ruining the state

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Well, mother! replied Philippe, in rather a lower key, do you likewise constitute yourself the buckler of M. Colbert?
children.prevalue: Well mother replied Philippe in rather a lower key do you likewise constitute yourself the buckler of M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: How is that? replied the old queen, rather surprised.
children.prevalue: How is that replied the old queen rather surprised

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Why, in truth, replied Philippe, you speak that just as your old friend Madame de Chevreuse would speak.
children.prevalue: Why in truth replied Philippe you speak that just as your old friend Madame de Chevreuse would speak

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Why do you mention Madame de Chevreuse to me? said she, and what sort of humor are you in today towards me?
children.prevalue: Why do you mention Madame de Chevreuse to me said she and what sort of humor are you in today towards me

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Philippe continued: Is not Madame de Chevreuse always in league against somebody? Has not Madame de Chevreuse been to pay you a visit, mother?
children.prevalue: Philippe continued Is not Madame de Chevreuse always in league against somebody Has not Madame de Chevreuse been to pay you a visit mother

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Monsieur, you speak to me now in such a manner that I can almost fancy I am listening to your father.
children.prevalue: Monsieur you speak to me now in such a manner that I can almost fancy I am listening to your father

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: My father did not like Madame de Chevreuse, and had good reason for not liking her, said the prince. For my part, I like her no better than he did, and if she thinks proper to come here as she formerly did, to sow divisions and hatreds under the pretext of begging moneywhy
children.prevalue: My father did not like Madame de Chevreuse and had good reason for not liking her said the prince For my part I like her no better than he did and if she thinks proper to come here as she formerly did to sow divisions and hatreds under the pretext of begging moneywhy

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Well! what? said Anne of Austria, proudly, herself provoking the storm.
children.prevalue: Well what said Anne of Austria proudly herself provoking the storm

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Well! replied the young man firmly, I will drive Madame de Chevreuse out of my kingdomand with her all who meddle with its secrets and mysteries.
children.prevalue: Well replied the young man firmly I will drive Madame de Chevreuse out of my kingdomand with her all who meddle with its secrets and mysteries

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: He had not calculated the effect of this terrible speech, or perhaps he wished to judge the effect of it, like those who, suffering from a chronic pain, and seeking to break the monotony of that suffering, touch their wound to procure a sharper pang. Anne of Austria was nearly fainting her eyes, open but meaningless, ceased to see for several seconds she stretched out her arms towards her other son, who supported and embraced her without fear of irritating the king.
children.prevalue: He had not calculated the effect of this terrible speech or perhaps he wished to judge the effect of it like those who suffering from a chronic pain and seeking to break the monotony of that suffering touch their wound to procure a sharper pang Anne of Austria was nearly fainting her eyes open but meaningless ceased to see for several seconds she stretched out her arms towards her other son who supported and embraced her without fear of irritating the king

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Sire, murmured she, you are treating your mother very cruelly.
children.prevalue: Sire murmured she you are treating your mother very cruelly

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: In what respect, madame? replied he. I am only speaking of Madame de Chevreuse does my mother prefer Madame de Chevreuse to the security of the state and of my person? Well, then, madame, I tell you Madame de Chevreuse has returned to France to borrow money, and that she addressed herself to M. Fouquet to sell him a certain secret.
children.prevalue: In what respect madame replied he I am only speaking of Madame de Chevreuse does my mother prefer Madame de Chevreuse to the security of the state and of my person Well then madame I tell you Madame de Chevreuse has returned to France to borrow money and that she addressed herself to M Fouquet to sell him a certain secret

children.value: A certain secret! cried Anne of Austria.
children.prevalue: A certain secret cried Anne of Austria

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Concerning pretended robberies that monsieur le surintendant had committed, which is false, added Philippe. M. Fouquet rejected her offers with indignation, preferring the esteem of the king to complicity with such intriguers. Then Madame de Chevreuse sold the secret to M. Colbert, and as she is insatiable, and was not satisfied with having extorted a hundred thousand crowns from a servant of the state, she has taken a still bolder flight, in search of surer sources of supply. Is that true, madame?

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: You know all, sire, said the queen, more uneasy than irritated.
children.prevalue: You know all sire said the queen more uneasy than irritated

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Now, continued Philippe, I have good reason to dislike this fury, who comes to my court to plan the shame of some and the ruin of others. If Heaven has suffered certain crimes to be committed, and has concealed them in the shadow of its clemency, I will not permit Madame de Chevreuse to counteract the just designs of fate.
children.prevalue: Now continued Philippe I have good reason to dislike this fury who comes to my court to plan the shame of some and the ruin of others If Heaven has suffered certain crimes to be committed and has concealed them in the shadow of its clemency I will not permit Madame de Chevreuse to counteract the just designs of fate

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The latter part of this speech had so agitated the queenmother, that her son had pity on her. He took her hand and kissed it tenderly she did not feel that in that kiss, given in spite of repulsion and bitterness of the heart, there was a pardon for eight years of suffering. Philippe allowed the silence of a moment to swallow the emotions that had just developed themselves. Then, with a cheerful smile:

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: We will not go today, said he, I have a plan. And, turning towards the door, he hoped to see Aramis, whose absence began to alarm him. The queenmother wished to leave the room.
children.prevalue: We will not go today said he I have a plan And turning towards the door he hoped to see Aramis whose absence began to alarm him The queenmother wished to leave the room

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Remain where you are, mother, said he, I wish you to make your peace with M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Remain where you are mother said he I wish you to make your peace with M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I bear M. Fouquet no illwill I only dreaded his prodigalities.
children.prevalue: I bear M Fouquet no illwill I only dreaded his prodigalities

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: We will put that to rights, and will take nothing of the superintendent but his good qualities.
children.prevalue: We will put that to rights and will take nothing of the superintendent but his good qualities

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: What is your majesty looking for? said Henrietta, seeing the king's eyes constantly turned towards the door, and wishing to let fly a little poisoned arrow at his heart, supposing he was so anxiously expecting either La Valliere or a letter from her.
children.prevalue: What is your majesty looking for said Henrietta seeing the king s eyes constantly turned towards the door and wishing to let fly a little poisoned arrow at his heart supposing he was so anxiously expecting either La Valliere or a letter from her

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: My sister, said the young man, who had divined her thought, thanks to that marvelous perspicuity of which fortune was from that time about to allow him the exercise, my sister, I am expecting a most distinguished man, a most able counselor, whom I wish to present to you all, recommending him to your good graces. Ah! come in, then, D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: My sister said the young man who had divined her thought thanks to that marvelous perspicuity of which fortune was from that time about to allow him the exercise my sister I am expecting a most distinguished man a most able counselor whom I wish to present to you all recommending him to your good graces Ah come in then D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: What does your majesty wish? said D'Artagnan, appearing.
children.prevalue: What does your majesty wish said D Artagnan appearing

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Where is monsieur the bishop of Vannes, your friend?
children.prevalue: Where is monsieur the bishop of Vannes your friend

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Why, sire
children.prevalue: Why sire

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I am waiting for him, and he does not come. Let him be sought for.
children.prevalue: I am waiting for him and he does not come Let him be sought for

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: D'Artagnan remained for an instant stupefied but soon, reflecting that Aramis had left Vaux privately on a mission from the king, he concluded that the king wished to preserve the secret. Sire, replied he, does your majesty absolutely require M. d'Herblay to be brought to you?
children.prevalue: D Artagnan remained for an instant stupefied but soon reflecting that Aramis had left Vaux privately on a mission from the king he concluded that the king wished to preserve the secret Sire replied he does your majesty absolutely require M d Herblay to be brought to you

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Absolutely is not the word, said Philippe I do not want him so particularly as that but if he can be found
children.prevalue: Absolutely is not the word said Philippe I do not want him so particularly as that but if he can be found

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I thought so, said D'Artagnan to himself.
children.prevalue: I thought so said D Artagnan to himself

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Is this M. d'Herblay the bishop of Vannes?
children.prevalue: Is this M d Herblay the bishop of Vannes

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Yes, madame.
children.prevalue: Yes madame

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: A friend of M. Fouquet?
children.prevalue: A friend of M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Yes, madame an old musketeer.
children.prevalue: Yes madame an old musketeer

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Anne of Austria blushed.
children.prevalue: Anne of Austria blushed

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: One of the four braves who formerly performed such prodigies.
children.prevalue: One of the four braves who formerly performed such prodigies

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: The old queen repented of having wished to bite she broke off the conversation, in order to preserve the rest of her teeth. Whatever may be your choice, sire, said she, I have no doubt it will be excellent.
children.prevalue: The old queen repented of having wished to bite she broke off the conversation in order to preserve the rest of her teeth Whatever may be your choice sire said she I have no doubt it will be excellent

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: All bowed in support of that sentiment.
children.prevalue: All bowed in support of that sentiment

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: You will find in him, continued Philippe, the depth and penetration of M. de Richelieu, without the avarice of M. de Mazarin!
children.prevalue: You will find in him continued Philippe the depth and penetration of M de Richelieu without the avarice of M de Mazarin

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: A prime minister, sire? said Monsieur, in a fright.
children.prevalue: A prime minister sire said Monsieur in a fright

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: I will tell you all about that, brother but it is strange that M. d'Herblay is not here!
children.prevalue: I will tell you all about that brother but it is strange that M d Herblay is not here

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: He called out:
children.prevalue: He called out

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Let M. Fouquet be informed that I wish to speak to himoh! before you, before you do not retire!
children.prevalue: Let M Fouquet be informed that I wish to speak to himoh before you before you do not retire

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: M. de SaintAignan returned, bringing satisfactory news of the queen, who only kept her bed from precaution, and to have strength to carry out the king's wishes. Whilst everybody was seeking M. Fouquet and Aramis, the new king quietly continued his experiments, and everybody, family, officers, servants, had not the least suspicion of his identity, his air, his voice, and manners were so like the king's. On his side, Philippe, applying to all countenances the accurate descriptions and keynotes of character supplied by his accomplice Aramis, conducted himself so as not to give birth to a doubt in the minds of those who surrounded him. Nothing from that time could disturb the usurper. With what strange facility had Providence just reversed the loftiest fortune of the world to substitute the lowliest in its stead! Philippe admired the goodness of God with regard to himself, and seconded it with all the resources of his admirable nature. But he felt, at times, something like a specter gliding between him and the rays of his new glory. Aramis did not appear. The conversation had languished in the royal family Philippe, preoccupied, forgot to dismiss his brother and Madame Henrietta. The latter were astonished, and began, by degrees, to lose all patience. Anne of Austria stooped towards her son's ear and addressed some words to him in Spanish. Philippe was completely ignorant of that language, and grew pale at this unexpected obstacle. But, as if the spirit of the imperturbable Aramis had covered him with his infallibility, instead of appearing disconcerted, Philippe rose. Well! what? said Anne of Austria.

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: What is all that noise? said Philippe, turning round towards the door of the second staircase.
children.prevalue: What is all that noise said Philippe turning round towards the door of the second staircase

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: And a voice was heard saying, This way, this way! A few steps more, sire!
children.prevalue: And a voice was heard saying This way this way A few steps more sire

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The voice of M. Fouquet, said D'Artagnan, who was standing close to the queenmother.
children.prevalue: The voice of M Fouquet said D Artagnan who was standing close to the queenmother

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Then M. d'Herblay cannot be far off, added Philippe.
children.prevalue: Then M d Herblay cannot be far off added Philippe

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: But he then saw what he little thought to have beheld so near to him. All eyes were turned towards the door at which M. Fouquet was expected to enter but it was not M. Fouquet who entered. A terrible cry resounded from all corners of the chamber, a painful cry uttered by the king and all present. It is given to but few men, even those whose destiny contains the strangest elements, and accidents the most wonderful, to contemplate such a spectacle similar to that which presented itself in the royal chamber at that moment. The halfclosed shutters only admitted the entrance of an uncertain light passing through thick violet velvet curtains lined with silk. In this soft shade, the eyes were by degrees dilated, and every one present saw others rather with imagination than with actual sight. There could not, however, escape, in these circumstances, one of the surrounding details and the new object which presented itself appeared as luminous as though it shone out in full sunlight. So it happened with Louis XIV., when he showed himself, pale and frowning, in the doorway of the secret stairs. The face of Fouquet appeared behind him, stamped with sorrow and determination. The queenmother, who perceived Louis XIV., and who held the hand of Philippe, uttered a cry of which we have spoken, as if she beheld a phantom. Monsieur was bewildered, and kept turning his head in astonishment from one to the other. Madame made a step forward, thinking she was looking at the form of her brotherinlaw reflected in a mirror. And, in fact, the illusion was possible. The two princes, both pale as deathfor we renounce the hope of being able to describe the fearful state of Philippetrembling, clenching their hands convulsively, measured each other with looks, and darted their glances, sharp as poniards, at each other. Silent, panting, bending forward, they appeared as if about to spring upon an enemy. The unheardof resemblance of countenance, gesture, shape, height, even to the resemblance of costume, produced by chancefor Louis XIV. had been to the Louvre and put on a violetcolored dressthe perfect analogy of the two princes, completed the consternation of Anne of Austria. And yet she did not at once guess the truth. There are misfortunes in life so truly dreadful that no one will at first accept them people rather believe in the supernatural and the impossible. Louis had not reckoned on these obstacles. He expected that he had only to appear to be acknowledged. A living sun, he could not endure the suspicion of equality with any one. He did not admit that every torch should not become darkness at the instant he shone out with his conquering ray. At the aspect of Philippe, then, he was perhaps more terrified than any one round him, and his silence, his immobility were, this time, a concentration and a calm which precede the violent explosions of concentrated passion.

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: But Fouquet! who shall paint his emotion and stupor in presence of this living portrait of his master! Fouquet thought Aramis was right, that this newlyarrived was a king as pure in his race as the other, and that, for having repudiated all participation in this coup d'etat, so skillfully got up by the General of the Jesuits, he must be a mad enthusiast, unworthy of ever dipping his hands in political grand strategy work. And then it was the blood of Louis XIII. which Fouquet was sacrificing to the blood of Louis XIII. it was to a selfish ambition he was sacrificing a noble ambition to the right of keeping he sacrificed the right of having. The whole extent of his fault was revealed to him at simple sight of the pretender. All that passed in the mind of Fouquet was lost upon the persons present. He had five minutes to focus meditation on this point of conscience five minutes, that is to say five ages, during which the two kings and their family scarcely found energy to breathe after so terrible a shock. D'Artagnan, leaning against the wall, in front of Fouquet, with his hand to his brow, asked himself the cause of such a wonderful prodigy. He could not have said at once why he doubted, but he knew assuredly that he had reason to doubt, and that in this meeting of the two Louis XIV.s lay all the doubt and difficulty that during late days had rendered the conduct of Aramis so suspicious to the musketeer. These ideas were, however, enveloped in a haze, a veil of mystery. The actors in this assembly seemed to swim in the vapors of a confused waking. Suddenly Louis XIV., more impatient and more accustomed to command, ran to one of the shutters, which he opened, tearing the curtains in his eagerness. A flood of living light entered the chamber, and made Philippe draw back to the alcove. Louis seized upon this movement with eagerness, and addressing himself to the queen:
