children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: My mother, said he, do you not acknowledge your son, since every one here has forgotten his king! Anne of Austria started, and raised her arms towards Heaven, without being able to articulate a single word.
children.prevalue: My mother said he do you not acknowledge your son since every one here has forgotten his king Anne of Austria started and raised her arms towards Heaven without being able to articulate a single word

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: My mother, said Philippe, with a calm voice, do you not acknowledge your son? And this time, in his turn, Louis drew back.
children.prevalue: My mother said Philippe with a calm voice do you not acknowledge your son And this time in his turn Louis drew back

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: As to Anne of Austria, struck suddenly in head and heart with fell remorse, she lost her equilibrium. No one aiding her, for all were petrified, she sank back in her fauteuil, breathing a weak, trembling sigh. Louis could not endure the spectacle and the affront. He bounded towards D'Artagnan, over whose brain a vertigo was stealing and who staggered as he caught at the door for support.
children.prevalue: As to Anne of Austria struck suddenly in head and heart with fell remorse she lost her equilibrium No one aiding her for all were petrified she sank back in her fauteuil breathing a weak trembling sigh Louis could not endure the spectacle and the affront He bounded towards D Artagnan over whose brain a vertigo was stealing and who staggered as he caught at the door for support

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: A moi! mousquetaire! said he. Look us in the face and say which is the paler, he or I!
children.prevalue: A moi mousquetaire said he Look us in the face and say which is the paler he or I

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: This cry roused D'Artagnan, and stirred in his heart the fibers of obedience. He shook his head, and, without more hesitation, he walked straight up to Philippe, on whose shoulder he laid his hand, saying, Monsieur, you are my prisoner!
children.prevalue: This cry roused D Artagnan and stirred in his heart the fibers of obedience He shook his head and without more hesitation he walked straight up to Philippe on whose shoulder he laid his hand saying Monsieur you are my prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Philippe did not raise his eyes towards Heaven, nor stir from the spot, where he seemed nailed to the floor, his eye intently fixed upon the king his brother. He reproached him with a sublime silence for all misfortunes past, all tortures to come. Against this language of the soul the king felt he had no power he cast down his eyes, dragging away precipitately his brother and sister, forgetting his mother, sitting motionless within three paces of the son whom she left a second time to be condemned to death. Philippe approached Anne of Austria, and said to her, in a soft and nobly agitated voice:
children.prevalue: Philippe did not raise his eyes towards Heaven nor stir from the spot where he seemed nailed to the floor his eye intently fixed upon the king his brother He reproached him with a sublime silence for all misfortunes past all tortures to come Against this language of the soul the king felt he had no power he cast down his eyes dragging away precipitately his brother and sister forgetting his mother sitting motionless within three paces of the son whom she left a second time to be condemned to death Philippe approached Anne of Austria and said to her in a soft and nobly agitated voice

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: If I were not your son, I should curse you, my mother, for having rendered me so unhappy.
children.prevalue: If I were not your son I should curse you my mother for having rendered me so unhappy

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: D'Artagnan felt a shudder pass through the marrow of his bones. He bowed respectfully to the young prince, and said as he bent, Excuse me, monseigneur, I am but a soldier, and my oaths are his who has just left the chamber.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan felt a shudder pass through the marrow of his bones He bowed respectfully to the young prince and said as he bent Excuse me monseigneur I am but a soldier and my oaths are his who has just left the chamber

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Thank you, M. d'Artagnan.... What has become of M. d'Herblay?
children.prevalue: Thank you M d Artagnan What has become of M d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: M. d'Herblay is in safety, monseigneur, said a voice behind them and no one, while I live and am free, shall cause a hair to fall from his head.
children.prevalue: M d Herblay is in safety monseigneur said a voice behind them and no one while I live and am free shall cause a hair to fall from his head

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Monsieur Fouquet! said the prince, smiling sadly.
children.prevalue: Monsieur Fouquet said the prince smiling sadly

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Pardon me, monseigneur, said Fouquet, kneeling, but he who is just gone out from hence was my guest.
children.prevalue: Pardon me monseigneur said Fouquet kneeling but he who is just gone out from hence was my guest

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Here are, murmured Philippe, with a sigh, brave friends and good hearts. They make me regret the world. On, M. d'Artagnan, I follow you.
children.prevalue: Here are murmured Philippe with a sigh brave friends and good hearts They make me regret the world On M d Artagnan I follow you

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: At the moment the captain of the musketeers was about to leave the room with his prisoner, Colbert appeared, and, after remitting an order from the king to D'Artagnan, retired. D'Artagnan read the paper, and then crushed it in his hand with rage.
children.prevalue: At the moment the captain of the musketeers was about to leave the room with his prisoner Colbert appeared and after remitting an order from the king to D Artagnan retired D Artagnan read the paper and then crushed it in his hand with rage

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: What is it? asked the prince.
children.prevalue: What is it asked the prince

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Read, monseigneur, replied the musketeer.
children.prevalue: Read monseigneur replied the musketeer

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Philippe read the following words, hastily traced by the hand of the king:
children.prevalue: Philippe read the following words hastily traced by the hand of the king

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: M. d'Artagnan will conduct the prisoner to the Ile SainteMarguerite. He will cover his face with an iron vizor, which the prisoner shall never raise except at peril of his life.
children.prevalue: M d Artagnan will conduct the prisoner to the Ile SainteMarguerite He will cover his face with an iron vizor which the prisoner shall never raise except at peril of his life

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: That is just, said Philippe, with resignation I am ready.
children.prevalue: That is just said Philippe with resignation I am ready

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Aramis was right, said Fouquet, in a low voice, to the musketeer, this one is every whit as much a king as the other.
children.prevalue: Aramis was right said Fouquet in a low voice to the musketeer this one is every whit as much a king as the other

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: More so! replied D'Artagnan. He wanted only you and me.
children.prevalue: More so replied D Artagnan He wanted only you and me

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Aramis and Porthos, having profited by the time granted them by Fouquet, did honor to the French cavalry by their speed. Porthos did not clearly understand on what kind of mission he was forced to display so much velocity but as he saw Aramis spurring on furiously, he, Porthos, spurred on in the same way. They had soon, in this manner, placed twelve leagues between them and Vaux they were then obliged to change horses, and organize a sort of post arrangement. It was during a relay that Porthos ventured to interrogate Aramis discreetly.
children.prevalue: Aramis and Porthos having profited by the time granted them by Fouquet did honor to the French cavalry by their speed Porthos did not clearly understand on what kind of mission he was forced to display so much velocity but as he saw Aramis spurring on furiously he Porthos spurred on in the same way They had soon in this manner placed twelve leagues between them and Vaux they were then obliged to change horses and organize a sort of post arrangement It was during a relay that Porthos ventured to interrogate Aramis discreetly

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Hush! replied the latter, know only that our fortune depends on our speed.
children.prevalue: Hush replied the latter know only that our fortune depends on our speed

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: As if Porthos had still been the musketeer, without a sou or a maille of 1626, he pushed forward. That magic word fortune always means something in the human ear. It means enough for those who have nothing it means too much for those who have enough.
children.prevalue: As if Porthos had still been the musketeer without a sou or a maille of 1626 he pushed forward That magic word fortune always means something in the human ear It means enough for those who have nothing it means too much for those who have enough

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I shall be made a duke! said Porthos, aloud. He was speaking to himself.
children.prevalue: I shall be made a duke said Porthos aloud He was speaking to himself

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: That is possible, replied Aramis, smiling after his own fashion, as Porthos's horse passed him. Aramis felt, notwithstanding, as though his brain were on fire the activity of the body had not yet succeeded in subduing that of the mind. All there is of raging passion, mental toothache or mortal threat, raged, gnawed and grumbled in the thoughts of the unhappy prelate. His countenance exhibited visible traces of this rude combat. Free on the highway to abandon himself to every impression of the moment, Aramis did not fail to swear at every start of his horse, at every inequality in the road. Pale, at times inundated with boiling sweats, then again dry and icy, he flogged his horses till the blood streamed from their sides. Porthos, whose dominant fault was not sensibility, groaned at this. Thus traveled they on for eight long hours, and then arrived at Orleans. It was four o'clock in the afternoon. Aramis, on observing this, judged that nothing showed pursuit to be a possibility. It would be without example that a troop capable of taking him and Porthos should be furnished with relays sufficient to perform forty leagues in eight hours. Thus, admitting pursuit, which was not at all manifest, the fugitives were five hours in advance of their pursuers.
children.prevalue: That is possible replied Aramis smiling after his own fashion as Porthos s horse passed him Aramis felt notwithstanding as though his brain were on fire the activity of the body had not yet succeeded in subduing that of the mind All there is of raging passion mental toothache or mortal threat raged gnawed and grumbled in the thoughts of the unhappy prelate His countenance exhibited visible traces of this rude combat Free on the highway to abandon himself to every impression of the moment Aramis did not fail to swear at every start of his horse at every inequality in the road Pale at times inundated with boiling sweats then again dry and icy he flogged his horses till the blood streamed from their sides Porthos whose dominant fault was not sensibility groaned at this Thus traveled they on for eight long hours and then arrived at Orleans It was four o clock in the afternoon Aramis on observing this judged that nothing showed pursuit to be a possibility It would be without example that a troop capable of taking him and Porthos should be furnished with relays sufficient to perform forty leagues in eight hours Thus admitting pursuit which was not at all manifest the fugitives were five hours in advance of their pursuers

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Aramis thought that there might be no imprudence in taking a little rest, but that to continue would make the matter more certain. Twenty leagues more, performed with the same rapidity, twenty more leagues devoured, and no one, not even D'Artagnan, could overtake the enemies of the king. Aramis felt obliged, therefore, to inflict upon Porthos the pain of mounting on horseback again. They rode on till seven o'clock in the evening, and had only one post more between them and Blois. But here a diabolical accident alarmed Aramis greatly. There were no horses at the post. The prelate asked himself by what infernal machination his enemies had succeeded in depriving him of the means of going further,he who never recognized chance as a deity, who found a cause for every accident, preferred believing that the refusal of the postmaster, at such an hour, in such a country, was the consequence of an order emanating from above: an order given with a view of stopping short the kingmaker in the midst of his flight. But at the moment he was about to fly into a passion, so as to procure either a horse or an explanation, he was struck with the recollection that the Comte de la Fere lived in the neighborhood.
children.prevalue: Aramis thought that there might be no imprudence in taking a little rest but that to continue would make the matter more certain Twenty leagues more performed with the same rapidity twenty more leagues devoured and no one not even D Artagnan could overtake the enemies of the king Aramis felt obliged therefore to inflict upon Porthos the pain of mounting on horseback again They rode on till seven o clock in the evening and had only one post more between them and Blois But here a diabolical accident alarmed Aramis greatly There were no horses at the post The prelate asked himself by what infernal machination his enemies had succeeded in depriving him of the means of going further he who never recognized chance as a deity who found a cause for every accident preferred believing that the refusal of the postmaster at such an hour in such a country was the consequence of an order emanating from above an order given with a view of stopping short the kingmaker in the midst of his flight But at the moment he was about to fly into a passion so as to procure either a horse or an explanation he was struck with the recollection that the Comte de la Fere lived in the neighborhood

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I am not traveling, said he I do not want horses for a whole stage. Find me two horses to go and pay a visit to a nobleman of my acquaintance who resides near this place.
children.prevalue: I am not traveling said he I do not want horses for a whole stage Find me two horses to go and pay a visit to a nobleman of my acquaintance who resides near this place

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: What nobleman? asked the postmaster.
children.prevalue: What nobleman asked the postmaster

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: M. le Comte de la Fere.
children.prevalue: M le Comte de la Fere

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Oh! replied the postmaster, uncovering with respect, a very worthy nobleman. But, whatever may be my desire to make myself agreeable to him, I cannot furnish you with horses, for all mine are engaged by M. le Duc de Beaufort.
children.prevalue: Oh replied the postmaster uncovering with respect a very worthy nobleman But whatever may be my desire to make myself agreeable to him I cannot furnish you with horses for all mine are engaged by M le Duc de Beaufort

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Indeed! said Aramis, much disappointed.
children.prevalue: Indeed said Aramis much disappointed

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Only, continued the postmaster, if you will put up with a little carriage I have, I will harness an old blind horse who has still his legs left, and peradventure will draw you to the house of M. le Comte de la Fere.
children.prevalue: Only continued the postmaster if you will put up with a little carriage I have I will harness an old blind horse who has still his legs left and peradventure will draw you to the house of M le Comte de la Fere

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: It is worth a louis, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: It is worth a louis said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: No, monsieur, such a ride is worth no more than a crown that is what M. Grimaud, the comte's intendant, always pays me when he makes use of that carriage and I should not wish the Comte de la Fere to have to reproach me with having imposed on one of his friends.
children.prevalue: No monsieur such a ride is worth no more than a crown that is what M Grimaud the comte s intendant always pays me when he makes use of that carriage and I should not wish the Comte de la Fere to have to reproach me with having imposed on one of his friends

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: As you please, said Aramis, particularly as regards disobliging the Comte de la Fere only I think I have a right to give you a louis for your idea.
children.prevalue: As you please said Aramis particularly as regards disobliging the Comte de la Fere only I think I have a right to give you a louis for your idea

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Oh! doubtless, replied the postmaster with delight. And he himself harnessed the ancient horse to the creaking carriage. In the meantime Porthos was curious to behold. He imagined he had discovered a clew to the secret, and he felt pleased, because a visit to Athos, in the first place, promised him much satisfaction, and, in the next, gave him the hope of finding at the same time a good bed and good supper. The master, having got the carriage ready, ordered one of his men to drive the strangers to La Fere. Porthos took his seat by the side of Aramis, whispering in his ear, I understand.
children.prevalue: Oh doubtless replied the postmaster with delight And he himself harnessed the ancient horse to the creaking carriage In the meantime Porthos was curious to behold He imagined he had discovered a clew to the secret and he felt pleased because a visit to Athos in the first place promised him much satisfaction and in the next gave him the hope of finding at the same time a good bed and good supper The master having got the carriage ready ordered one of his men to drive the strangers to La Fere Porthos took his seat by the side of Aramis whispering in his ear I understand

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Aha! said Aramis, and what do you understand, my friend?
children.prevalue: Aha said Aramis and what do you understand my friend

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: We are going, on the part of the king, to make some great proposal to Athos.
children.prevalue: We are going on the part of the king to make some great proposal to Athos

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Pooh! said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Pooh said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: You need tell me nothing about it, added the worthy Porthos, endeavoring to reseat himself so as to avoid the jolting, you need tell me nothing, I shall guess.
children.prevalue: You need tell me nothing about it added the worthy Porthos endeavoring to reseat himself so as to avoid the jolting you need tell me nothing I shall guess

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Well! do, my friend guess away.
children.prevalue: Well do my friend guess away

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: They arrived at Athos's dwelling about nine o'clock in the evening, favored by a splendid moon. This cheerful light rejoiced Porthos beyond expression but Aramis appeared annoyed by it in an equal degree. He could not help showing something of this to Porthos, who repliedAy! ay! I guess how it is! the mission is a secret one.
children.prevalue: They arrived at Athos s dwelling about nine o clock in the evening favored by a splendid moon This cheerful light rejoiced Porthos beyond expression but Aramis appeared annoyed by it in an equal degree He could not help showing something of this to Porthos who repliedAy ay I guess how it is the mission is a secret one

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: These were his last words in the carriage. The driver interrupted him by saying, Gentlemen, we have arrived.
children.prevalue: These were his last words in the carriage The driver interrupted him by saying Gentlemen we have arrived

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Porthos and his companion alighted before the gate of the little chateau, where we are about to meet again our old acquaintances Athos and Bragelonne, the latter of whom had disappeared since the discovery of the infidelity of La Valliere. If there be one saying truer than another, it is this: great griefs contain within themselves the germ of consolation. This painful wound, inflicted upon Raoul, had drawn him nearer to his father again and God knows how sweet were the consolations which flowed from the eloquent mouth and generous heart of Athos. The wound was not cicatrized, but Athos, by dint of conversing with his son and mixing a little more of his life with that of the young man, had brought him to understand that this pang of a first infidelity is necessary to every human existence and that no one has loved without encountering it. Raoul listened, again and again, but never understood. Nothing replaces in the deeply afflicted heart the remembrance and thought of the beloved object. Raoul then replied to the reasoning of his father:
children.prevalue: Porthos and his companion alighted before the gate of the little chateau where we are about to meet again our old acquaintances Athos and Bragelonne the latter of whom had disappeared since the discovery of the infidelity of La Valliere If there be one saying truer than another it is this great griefs contain within themselves the germ of consolation This painful wound inflicted upon Raoul had drawn him nearer to his father again and God knows how sweet were the consolations which flowed from the eloquent mouth and generous heart of Athos The wound was not cicatrized but Athos by dint of conversing with his son and mixing a little more of his life with that of the young man had brought him to understand that this pang of a first infidelity is necessary to every human existence and that no one has loved without encountering it Raoul listened again and again but never understood Nothing replaces in the deeply afflicted heart the remembrance and thought of the beloved object Raoul then replied to the reasoning of his father

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Monsieur, all that you tell me is true I believe that no one has suffered in the affections of the heart so much as you have but you are a man too great by reason of intelligence, and too severely tried by adverse fortune not to allow for the weakness of the soldier who suffers for the first time. I am paying a tribute that will not be paid a second time permit me to plunge myself so deeply in my grief that I may forget myself in it, that I may drown even my reason in it.
children.prevalue: Monsieur all that you tell me is true I believe that no one has suffered in the affections of the heart so much as you have but you are a man too great by reason of intelligence and too severely tried by adverse fortune not to allow for the weakness of the soldier who suffers for the first time I am paying a tribute that will not be paid a second time permit me to plunge myself so deeply in my grief that I may forget myself in it that I may drown even my reason in it

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Raoul! Raoul!
children.prevalue: Raoul Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Listen, monsieur. Never shall I accustom myself to the idea that Louise, the chastest and most innocent of women, has been able to so basely deceive a man so honest and so true a lover as myself. Never can I persuade myself that I see that sweet and noble mask change into a hypocritical lascivious face. Louise lost! Louise infamous! Ah! monseigneur, that idea is much more cruel to me than Raoul abandonedRaoul unhappy!
children.prevalue: Listen monsieur Never shall I accustom myself to the idea that Louise the chastest and most innocent of women has been able to so basely deceive a man so honest and so true a lover as myself Never can I persuade myself that I see that sweet and noble mask change into a hypocritical lascivious face Louise lost Louise infamous Ah monseigneur that idea is much more cruel to me than Raoul abandonedRaoul unhappy

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Athos then employed the heroic remedy. He defended Louise against Raoul, and justified her perfidy by her love. A woman who would have yielded to a king because he is a king, said he, would deserve to be styled infamous but Louise loves Louis. Young, both, they have forgotten, he his rank, she her vows. Love absolves everything, Raoul. The two young people love each other with sincerity.
children.prevalue: Athos then employed the heroic remedy He defended Louise against Raoul and justified her perfidy by her love A woman who would have yielded to a king because he is a king said he would deserve to be styled infamous but Louise loves Louis Young both they have forgotten he his rank she her vows Love absolves everything Raoul The two young people love each other with sincerity

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: And when he had dealt this severe poniardthrust, Athos, with a sigh, saw Raoul bound away beneath the rankling wound, and fly to the thickest recesses of the wood, or the solitude of his chamber, whence, an hour after, he would return, pale, trembling, but subdued. Then, coming up to Athos with a smile, he would kiss his hand, like the dog who, having been beaten, caresses a respected master, to redeem his fault. Raoul redeemed nothing but his weakness, and only confessed his grief. Thus passed away the days that followed that scene in which Athos had so violently shaken the indomitable pride of the king. Never, when conversing with his son, did he make any allusion to that scene never did he give him the details of that vigorous lecture, which might, perhaps, have consoled the young man, by showing him his rival humbled. Athos did not wish that the offended lover should forget the respect due to his king. And when Bragelonne, ardent, angry, and melancholy, spoke with contempt of royal words, of the equivocal faith which certain madmen draw from promises that emanate from thrones, when, passing over two centuries, with that rapidity of a bird that traverses a narrow strait to go from one continent to the other, Raoul ventured to predict the time in which kings would be esteemed as less than other men, Athos said to him, in his serene, persuasive voice, You are right, Raoul all that you say will happen kings will lose their privileges, as stars which have survived their aeons lose their splendor. But when that moment comes, Raoul, we shall be dead. And remember well what I say to you. In this world, all, men, women, and kings, must live for the present. We can only live for the future for God.
children.prevalue: And when he had dealt this severe poniardthrust Athos with a sigh saw Raoul bound away beneath the rankling wound and fly to the thickest recesses of the wood or the solitude of his chamber whence an hour after he would return pale trembling but subdued Then coming up to Athos with a smile he would kiss his hand like the dog who having been beaten caresses a respected master to redeem his fault Raoul redeemed nothing but his weakness and only confessed his grief Thus passed away the days that followed that scene in which Athos had so violently shaken the indomitable pride of the king Never when conversing with his son did he make any allusion to that scene never did he give him the details of that vigorous lecture which might perhaps have consoled the young man by showing him his rival humbled Athos did not wish that the offended lover should forget the respect due to his king And when Bragelonne ardent angry and melancholy spoke with contempt of royal words of the equivocal faith which certain madmen draw from promises that emanate from thrones when passing over two centuries with that rapidity of a bird that traverses a narrow strait to go from one continent to the other Raoul ventured to predict the time in which kings would be esteemed as less than other men Athos said to him in his serene persuasive voice You are right Raoul all that you say will happen kings will lose their privileges as stars which have survived their aeons lose their splendor But when that moment comes Raoul we shall be dead And remember well what I say to you In this world all men women and kings must live for the present We can only live for the future for God

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: This was the manner in which Athos and Raoul were, as usual, conversing, and walking backwards and forwards in the long alley of limes in the park, when the bell which served to announce to the comte either the hour of dinner or the arrival of a visitor, was rung and, without attaching any importance to it, he turned towards the house with his son and at the end of the alley they found themselves in the presence of Aramis and Porthos.
children.prevalue: This was the manner in which Athos and Raoul were as usual conversing and walking backwards and forwards in the long alley of limes in the park when the bell which served to announce to the comte either the hour of dinner or the arrival of a visitor was rung and without attaching any importance to it he turned towards the house with his son and at the end of the alley they found themselves in the presence of Aramis and Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Raoul uttered a cry, and affectionately embraced Porthos. Aramis and Athos embraced like old men and this embrace itself being a question for Aramis, he immediately said, My friend, we have not long to remain with you.
children.prevalue: Raoul uttered a cry and affectionately embraced Porthos Aramis and Athos embraced like old men and this embrace itself being a question for Aramis he immediately said My friend we have not long to remain with you

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Ah! said the comte.
children.prevalue: Ah said the comte

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Only time to tell you of my good fortune, interrupted Porthos.
children.prevalue: Only time to tell you of my good fortune interrupted Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Ah! said Raoul.
children.prevalue: Ah said Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Athos looked silently at Aramis, whose somber air had already appeared to him very little in harmony with the good news Porthos hinted.
children.prevalue: Athos looked silently at Aramis whose somber air had already appeared to him very little in harmony with the good news Porthos hinted

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: What is the good fortune that has happened to you? Let us hear it, said Raoul, with a smile.
children.prevalue: What is the good fortune that has happened to you Let us hear it said Raoul with a smile

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The king has made me a duke, said the worthy Porthos, with an air of mystery, in the ear of the young man, a duke by brevet.
children.prevalue: The king has made me a duke said the worthy Porthos with an air of mystery in the ear of the young man a duke by brevet

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: But the asides of Porthos were always loud enough to be heard by everybody. His murmurs were in the diapason of ordinary roaring. Athos heard him, and uttered an exclamation which made Aramis start. The latter took Athos by the arm, and, after having asked Porthos's permission to say a word to his friend in private, My dear Athos, he began, you see me overwhelmed with grief and trouble.
children.prevalue: But the asides of Porthos were always loud enough to be heard by everybody His murmurs were in the diapason of ordinary roaring Athos heard him and uttered an exclamation which made Aramis start The latter took Athos by the arm and after having asked Porthos s permission to say a word to his friend in private My dear Athos he began you see me overwhelmed with grief and trouble

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: With grief and trouble, my dear friend? cried the comte oh, what?
children.prevalue: With grief and trouble my dear friend cried the comte oh what

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: In two words. I have conspired against the king that conspiracy has failed, and, at this moment, I am doubtless pursued.
children.prevalue: In two words I have conspired against the king that conspiracy has failed and at this moment I am doubtless pursued

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: You are pursued!a conspiracy! Eh! my friend, what do you tell me?
children.prevalue: You are pursued a conspiracy Eh my friend what do you tell me

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The saddest truth. I am entirely ruined.
children.prevalue: The saddest truth I am entirely ruined

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Well, but Porthosthis title of dukewhat does all that mean?
children.prevalue: Well but Porthosthis title of dukewhat does all that mean

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: That is the subject of my severest pain that is the deepest of my wounds. I have, believing in infallible success, drawn Porthos into my conspiracy. He threw himself into it, as you know he would do, with all his strength, without knowing what he was about and now he is as much compromised as myselfas completely ruined as I am.
children.prevalue: That is the subject of my severest pain that is the deepest of my wounds I have believing in infallible success drawn Porthos into my conspiracy He threw himself into it as you know he would do with all his strength without knowing what he was about and now he is as much compromised as myselfas completely ruined as I am

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Good God! And Athos turned towards Porthos, who was smiling complacently.
children.prevalue: Good God And Athos turned towards Porthos who was smiling complacently

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: I must make you acquainted with the whole. Listen to me, continued Aramis and he related the history as we know it. Athos, during the recital, several times felt the sweat break from his forehead. It was a great idea, said he, but a great error.
children.prevalue: I must make you acquainted with the whole Listen to me continued Aramis and he related the history as we know it Athos during the recital several times felt the sweat break from his forehead It was a great idea said he but a great error

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: For which I am punished, Athos.
children.prevalue: For which I am punished Athos

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Therefore, I will not tell you my entire thought.
children.prevalue: Therefore I will not tell you my entire thought

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Tell it, nevertheless.
children.prevalue: Tell it nevertheless

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: It is a crime.
children.prevalue: It is a crime

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: A capital crime I know it is. Lese majeste.
children.prevalue: A capital crime I know it is Lese majeste

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Porthos! poor Porthos!
children.prevalue: Porthos poor Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: What would you advise me to do? Success, as I have told you, was certain.
children.prevalue: What would you advise me to do Success as I have told you was certain

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: M. Fouquet is an honest man.
children.prevalue: M Fouquet is an honest man

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: And I a fool for having so illjudged him, said Aramis. Oh, the wisdom of man! Oh, millstone that grinds the world! and which is one day stopped by a grain of sand which has fallen, no one knows how, between its wheels.
children.prevalue: And I a fool for having so illjudged him said Aramis Oh the wisdom of man Oh millstone that grinds the world and which is one day stopped by a grain of sand which has fallen no one knows how between its wheels

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Say by a diamond, Aramis. But the thing is done. How do you think of acting?
children.prevalue: Say by a diamond Aramis But the thing is done How do you think of acting

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I am taking away Porthos. The king will never believe that that worthy man has acted innocently. He never can believe that Porthos has thought he was serving the king, whilst acting as he has done. His head would pay my fault. It shall not, must not, be so.
children.prevalue: I am taking away Porthos The king will never believe that that worthy man has acted innocently He never can believe that Porthos has thought he was serving the king whilst acting as he has done His head would pay my fault It shall not must not be so

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: You are taking him away, whither?
children.prevalue: You are taking him away whither

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: To BelleIsle, at first. That is an impregnable place of refuge. Then, I have the sea, and a vessel to pass over into England, where I have many relations.
children.prevalue: To BelleIsle at first That is an impregnable place of refuge Then I have the sea and a vessel to pass over into England where I have many relations

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: You? in England?
children.prevalue: You in England

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Yes, or else in Spain, where I have still more.
children.prevalue: Yes or else in Spain where I have still more

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: But, our excellent Porthos! you ruin him, for the king will confiscate all his property.
children.prevalue: But our excellent Porthos you ruin him for the king will confiscate all his property

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: All is provided for. I know how, when once in Spain, to reconcile myself with Louis XIV., and restore Porthos to favor.
children.prevalue: All is provided for I know how when once in Spain to reconcile myself with Louis XIV and restore Porthos to favor

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: You have credit, seemingly, Aramis! said Athos, with a discreet air.
children.prevalue: You have credit seemingly Aramis said Athos with a discreet air

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Much and at the service of my friends.
children.prevalue: Much and at the service of my friends

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: These words were accompanied by a warm pressure of the hand.
children.prevalue: These words were accompanied by a warm pressure of the hand

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Thank you, replied the comte.
children.prevalue: Thank you replied the comte

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: And while we are on this head, said Aramis, you also are a malcontent you also, Raoul, have griefs to lay to the king. Follow our example pass over into BelleIsle. Then we shall see, I guarantee upon my honor, that in a month there will be war between France and Spain on the subject of this son of Louis XIII., who is an Infante likewise, and whom France detains inhumanly. Now, as Louis XIV. would have no inclination for a war on that subject, I will answer for an arrangement, the result of which must bring greatness to Porthos and to me, and a duchy in France to you, who are already a grandee of Spain. Will you join us?
children.prevalue: And while we are on this head said Aramis you also are a malcontent you also Raoul have griefs to lay to the king Follow our example pass over into BelleIsle Then we shall see I guarantee upon my honor that in a month there will be war between France and Spain on the subject of this son of Louis XIII who is an Infante likewise and whom France detains inhumanly Now as Louis XIV would have no inclination for a war on that subject I will answer for an arrangement the result of which must bring greatness to Porthos and to me and a duchy in France to you who are already a grandee of Spain Will you join us

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: No for my part I prefer having something to reproach the king with it is a pride natural to my race to pretend to a superiority over royal races. Doing what you propose, I should become the obliged of the king I should certainly be the gainer on that ground, but I should be a loser in my conscience.No, thank you!
children.prevalue: No for my part I prefer having something to reproach the king with it is a pride natural to my race to pretend to a superiority over royal races Doing what you propose I should become the obliged of the king I should certainly be the gainer on that ground but I should be a loser in my conscience No thank you

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Then give me two things, Athos,your absolution.
children.prevalue: Then give me two things Athos your absolution

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Oh! I give it you if you really wished to avenge the weak and oppressed against the oppressor.
children.prevalue: Oh I give it you if you really wished to avenge the weak and oppressed against the oppressor

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: That is sufficient for me, said Aramis, with a blush which was lost in the obscurity of the night. And now, give me your two best horses to gain the second post, as I have been refused any under the pretext of the Duc de Beaufort being traveling in this country.
children.prevalue: That is sufficient for me said Aramis with a blush which was lost in the obscurity of the night And now give me your two best horses to gain the second post as I have been refused any under the pretext of the Duc de Beaufort being traveling in this country

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: You shall have the two best horses, Aramis and again I recommend poor Porthos strongly to your care.
children.prevalue: You shall have the two best horses Aramis and again I recommend poor Porthos strongly to your care

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Oh! I have no fear on that score. One word more: do you think I am maneuvering for him as I ought?
children.prevalue: Oh I have no fear on that score One word more do you think I am maneuvering for him as I ought

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: The evil being committed, yes for the king would not pardon him, and you have, whatever may be said, always a supporter in M. Fouquet, who will not abandon you, he being himself compromised, notwithstanding his heroic action.
children.prevalue: The evil being committed yes for the king would not pardon him and you have whatever may be said always a supporter in M Fouquet who will not abandon you he being himself compromised notwithstanding his heroic action

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: You are right. And that is why, instead of gaining the sea at once, which would proclaim my fear and guilt, that is why I remain upon French ground. But BelleIsle will be for me whatever ground I wish it to be, English, Spanish, or Roman all will depend, with me, on the standard I shall think proper to unfurl.
children.prevalue: You are right And that is why instead of gaining the sea at once which would proclaim my fear and guilt that is why I remain upon French ground But BelleIsle will be for me whatever ground I wish it to be English Spanish or Roman all will depend with me on the standard I shall think proper to unfurl

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: How so?
children.prevalue: How so

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: It was I who fortified BelleIsle and, so long as I defend it, nobody can take BelleIsle from me. And then, as you have said just now, M. Fouquet is there. BelleIsle will not be attacked without the signature of M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: It was I who fortified BelleIsle and so long as I defend it nobody can take BelleIsle from me And then as you have said just now M Fouquet is there BelleIsle will not be attacked without the signature of M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: That is true. Nevertheless, be prudent. The king is both cunning and strong. Aramis smiled.
children.prevalue: That is true Nevertheless be prudent The king is both cunning and strong Aramis smiled

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I again recommend Porthos to you, repeated the count, with a sort of cold persistence.
children.prevalue: I again recommend Porthos to you repeated the count with a sort of cold persistence

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Whatever becomes of me, count, replied Aramis, in the same tone, our brother Porthos will fare as I door better.
children.prevalue: Whatever becomes of me count replied Aramis in the same tone our brother Porthos will fare as I door better

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Athos bowed whilst pressing the hand of Aramis, and turned to embrace Porthos with emotion.
children.prevalue: Athos bowed whilst pressing the hand of Aramis and turned to embrace Porthos with emotion

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: I was born lucky, was I not? murmured the latter, transported with happiness, as he folded his cloak round him.
children.prevalue: I was born lucky was I not murmured the latter transported with happiness as he folded his cloak round him

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Come, my dear friend, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Come my dear friend said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Raoul had gone out to give orders for the saddling of the horses. The group was already divided. Athos saw his two friends on the point of departure, and something like a mist passed before his eyes and weighed upon his heart.
children.prevalue: Raoul had gone out to give orders for the saddling of the horses The group was already divided Athos saw his two friends on the point of departure and something like a mist passed before his eyes and weighed upon his heart

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: It is strange, thought he, whence comes the inclination I feel to embrace Porthos once more? At that moment Porthos turned round, and he came towards his old friend with open arms. This last endearment was tender as in youth, as in times when hearts were warmlife happy. And then Porthos mounted his horse. Aramis came back once more to throw his arms round the neck of Athos. The latter watched them along the highroad, elongated by the shade, in their white cloaks. Like phantoms they seemed to enlarge on their departure from the earth, and it was not in the mist, but in the declivity of the ground that they disappeared. At the end of the perspective, both seemed to have given a spring with their feet, which made them vanish as if evaporated into cloudland.
children.prevalue: It is strange thought he whence comes the inclination I feel to embrace Porthos once more At that moment Porthos turned round and he came towards his old friend with open arms This last endearment was tender as in youth as in times when hearts were warmlife happy And then Porthos mounted his horse Aramis came back once more to throw his arms round the neck of Athos The latter watched them along the highroad elongated by the shade in their white cloaks Like phantoms they seemed to enlarge on their departure from the earth and it was not in the mist but in the declivity of the ground that they disappeared At the end of the perspective both seemed to have given a spring with their feet which made them vanish as if evaporated into cloudland

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Then Athos, with a very heavy heart, returned towards the house, saying to Bragelonne, Raoul, I don't know what it is that has just told me that I have seen those two for the last time.
children.prevalue: Then Athos with a very heavy heart returned towards the house saying to Bragelonne Raoul I don t know what it is that has just told me that I have seen those two for the last time

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: It does not astonish me, monsieur, that you should have such a thought, replied the young man, for I have at this moment the same, and think also that I shall never see Messieurs du Vallon and d'Herblay again.
children.prevalue: It does not astonish me monsieur that you should have such a thought replied the young man for I have at this moment the same and think also that I shall never see Messieurs du Vallon and d Herblay again

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Oh! you, replied the count, you speak like a man rendered sad by a different cause you see everything in black you are young, and if you chance never to see those old friends again, it will because they no longer exist in the world in which you have yet many years to pass. But I
children.prevalue: Oh you replied the count you speak like a man rendered sad by a different cause you see everything in black you are young and if you chance never to see those old friends again it will because they no longer exist in the world in which you have yet many years to pass But I

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Raoul shook his head sadly, and leaned upon the shoulder of the count, without either of them finding another word in their hearts, which were ready to overflow.
children.prevalue: Raoul shook his head sadly and leaned upon the shoulder of the count without either of them finding another word in their hearts which were ready to overflow

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: All at once a noise of horses and voices, from the extremity of the road to Blois, attracted their attention that way. Flambeauxbearers shook their torches merrily among the trees of their route, and turned round, from time to time, to avoid distancing the horsemen who followed them. These flames, this noise, this dust of a dozen richly caparisoned horses, formed a strange contrast in the middle of the night with the melancholy and almost funereal disappearance of the two shadows of Aramis and Porthos. Athos went towards the house but he had hardly reached the parterre, when the entrance gate appeared in a blaze all the flambeaux stopped and appeared to enflame the road. A cry was heard of M. le Duc de Beaufortand Athos sprang towards the door of his house. But the duke had already alighted from his horse, and was looking around him.
children.prevalue: All at once a noise of horses and voices from the extremity of the road to Blois attracted their attention that way Flambeauxbearers shook their torches merrily among the trees of their route and turned round from time to time to avoid distancing the horsemen who followed them These flames this noise this dust of a dozen richly caparisoned horses formed a strange contrast in the middle of the night with the melancholy and almost funereal disappearance of the two shadows of Aramis and Porthos Athos went towards the house but he had hardly reached the parterre when the entrance gate appeared in a blaze all the flambeaux stopped and appeared to enflame the road A cry was heard of M le Duc de Beaufortand Athos sprang towards the door of his house But the duke had already alighted from his horse and was looking around him

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I am here, monseigneur, said Athos.
children.prevalue: I am here monseigneur said Athos

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Ah! good evening, dear count, said the prince, with that frank cordiality which won him so many hearts. Is it too late for a friend?
children.prevalue: Ah good evening dear count said the prince with that frank cordiality which won him so many hearts Is it too late for a friend

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Ah! my dear prince, come in! said the count.
children.prevalue: Ah my dear prince come in said the count

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: And, M. de Beaufort leaning on the arm of Athos, they entered the house, followed by Raoul, who walked respectfully and modestly among the officers of the prince, with several of whom he was acquainted.
children.prevalue: And M de Beaufort leaning on the arm of Athos they entered the house followed by Raoul who walked respectfully and modestly among the officers of the prince with several of whom he was acquainted

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The prince turned round at the moment when Raoul, in order to leave him alone with Athos, was shutting the door, and preparing to go with the other officers into an adjoining apartment.
children.prevalue: The prince turned round at the moment when Raoul in order to leave him alone with Athos was shutting the door and preparing to go with the other officers into an adjoining apartment

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Is that the young man I have heard M. le Prince speak so highly of? asked M. de Beaufort.
children.prevalue: Is that the young man I have heard M le Prince speak so highly of asked M de Beaufort

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It is, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: It is monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: He is quite the soldier let him stay, count, we cannot spare him.
children.prevalue: He is quite the soldier let him stay count we cannot spare him

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Remain, Raoul, since monseigneur permits it, said Athos.
children.prevalue: Remain Raoul since monseigneur permits it said Athos

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Ma foi! he is tall and handsome! continued the duke. Will you give him to me, monseigneur, if I ask him of you?
children.prevalue: Ma foi he is tall and handsome continued the duke Will you give him to me monseigneur if I ask him of you

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: How am I to understand you, monseigneur? said Athos.
children.prevalue: How am I to understand you monseigneur said Athos

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Why, I call upon you to bid you farewell.
children.prevalue: Why I call upon you to bid you farewell

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Farewell!
children.prevalue: Farewell

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Yes, in good truth. Have you no idea of what I am about to become?
children.prevalue: Yes in good truth Have you no idea of what I am about to become

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Why, I suppose, what you have always been, monseigneur,a valiant prince, and an excellent gentleman.
children.prevalue: Why I suppose what you have always been monseigneur a valiant prince and an excellent gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: I am going to become an African prince,a Bedouin gentleman. The king is sending me to make conquests among the Arabs.
children.prevalue: I am going to become an African prince a Bedouin gentleman The king is sending me to make conquests among the Arabs

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: What is this you tell me, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: What is this you tell me monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Strange, is it not? I, the Parisian par essence, I who have reigned in the faubourgs, and have been called King of the Halles,I am going to pass from the Place Maubert to the minarets of Gigelli from a Frondeur I am becoming an adventurer!
children.prevalue: Strange is it not I the Parisian par essence I who have reigned in the faubourgs and have been called King of the Halles I am going to pass from the Place Maubert to the minarets of Gigelli from a Frondeur I am becoming an adventurer

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Oh, monseigneur, if you did not yourself tell me that
children.prevalue: Oh monseigneur if you did not yourself tell me that

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It would not be credible, would it? Believe me, nevertheless, and we have but to bid each other farewell. This is what comes of getting into favor again.
children.prevalue: It would not be credible would it Believe me nevertheless and we have but to bid each other farewell This is what comes of getting into favor again

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Into favor?
children.prevalue: Into favor

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Yes. You smile. Ah, my dear count, do you know why I have accepted this enterprise, can you guess?
children.prevalue: Yes You smile Ah my dear count do you know why I have accepted this enterprise can you guess

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Because your highness loves glory aboveeverything.
children.prevalue: Because your highness loves glory aboveeverything

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Oh! no there is no glory in firing muskets at savages. I see no glory in that, for my part, and it is more probable that I shall there meet with something else. But I have wished, and still wish earnestly, my dear count, that my life should have that last facet, after all the whimsical exhibitions I have seen myself make during fifty years. For, in short, you must admit that it is sufficiently strange to be born the grandson of a king, to have made war against kings, to have been reckoned among the powers of the age, to have maintained my rank, to feel Henry IV. within me, to be great admiral of Franceand then to go and get killed at Gigelli, among all those Turks, Saracens, and Moors.
children.prevalue: Oh no there is no glory in firing muskets at savages I see no glory in that for my part and it is more probable that I shall there meet with something else But I have wished and still wish earnestly my dear count that my life should have that last facet after all the whimsical exhibitions I have seen myself make during fifty years For in short you must admit that it is sufficiently strange to be born the grandson of a king to have made war against kings to have been reckoned among the powers of the age to have maintained my rank to feel Henry IV within me to be great admiral of Franceand then to go and get killed at Gigelli among all those Turks Saracens and Moors

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Monseigneur, you harp with strange persistence on that theme, said Athos, in an agitated voice. How can you suppose that so brilliant a destiny will be extinguished in that remote and miserable scene?
children.prevalue: Monseigneur you harp with strange persistence on that theme said Athos in an agitated voice How can you suppose that so brilliant a destiny will be extinguished in that remote and miserable scene

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: And can you believe, upright and simple as you are, that if I go into Africa for this ridiculous motive, I will not endeavor to come out of it without ridicule? Shall I not give the world cause to speak of me? And to be spoken of, nowadays, when there are Monsieur le Prince, M. de Turenne, and many others, my contemporaries, I, admiral of France, grandson of Henry IV., king of Paris, have I anything left but to get myself killed? Cordieu! I will be talked of, I tell you I shall be killed whether or not if not there, somewhere else.
children.prevalue: And can you believe upright and simple as you are that if I go into Africa for this ridiculous motive I will not endeavor to come out of it without ridicule Shall I not give the world cause to speak of me And to be spoken of nowadays when there are Monsieur le Prince M de Turenne and many others my contemporaries I admiral of France grandson of Henry IV king of Paris have I anything left but to get myself killed Cordieu I will be talked of I tell you I shall be killed whether or not if not there somewhere else

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Why, monseigneur, this is mere exaggeration and hitherto you have shown nothing exaggerated save in bravery.
children.prevalue: Why monseigneur this is mere exaggeration and hitherto you have shown nothing exaggerated save in bravery

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Peste! my dear friend, there is bravery in facing scurvy, dysentery, locusts, poisoned arrows, as my ancestor St. Louis did. Do you know those fellows still use poisoned arrows? And then, you know me of old, I fancy, and you know that when I once make up my mind to a thing, I perform it in grim earnest.
children.prevalue: Peste my dear friend there is bravery in facing scurvy dysentery locusts poisoned arrows as my ancestor St Louis did Do you know those fellows still use poisoned arrows And then you know me of old I fancy and you know that when I once make up my mind to a thing I perform it in grim earnest

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Yes, you made up your mind to escape from Vincennes.
children.prevalue: Yes you made up your mind to escape from Vincennes

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Ay, but you aided me in that, my master and, a propos, I turn this way and that, without seeing my old friend, M. Vaugrimaud. How is he?
children.prevalue: Ay but you aided me in that my master and a propos I turn this way and that without seeing my old friend M Vaugrimaud How is he

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: M. Vaugrimaud is still your highness's most respectful servant, said Athos, smiling.
children.prevalue: M Vaugrimaud is still your highness s most respectful servant said Athos smiling

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I have a hundred pistoles here for him, which I bring as a legacy. My will is made, count.
children.prevalue: I have a hundred pistoles here for him which I bring as a legacy My will is made count

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Ah! monseigneur! monseigneur!
children.prevalue: Ah monseigneur monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: And you may understand that if Grimaud's name were to appear in my will The duke began to laugh then addressing Raoul, who, from the commencement of this conversation, had sunk into a profound reverie, Young man, said he, I know there is to be found here a certain De Vouvray wine, and I believe Raoul left the room precipitately to order the wine. In the meantime M. de Beaufort took the hand of Athos.
children.prevalue: And you may understand that if Grimaud s name were to appear in my will The duke began to laugh then addressing Raoul who from the commencement of this conversation had sunk into a profound reverie Young man said he I know there is to be found here a certain De Vouvray wine and I believe Raoul left the room precipitately to order the wine In the meantime M de Beaufort took the hand of Athos

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: What do you mean to do with him? asked he.
children.prevalue: What do you mean to do with him asked he

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Nothing at present, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Nothing at present monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Ah! yes, I know since the passion of the king for La Valliere.
children.prevalue: Ah yes I know since the passion of the king for La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: That is all true, then, is it? I think I know her, that little La Valliere. She is not particularly handsome, if I remember right?
children.prevalue: That is all true then is it I think I know her that little La Valliere She is not particularly handsome if I remember right

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: No, monseigneur, said Athos.
children.prevalue: No monseigneur said Athos

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Do you know whom she reminds me of?
children.prevalue: Do you know whom she reminds me of

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Does she remind your highness of any one?
children.prevalue: Does she remind your highness of any one

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: She reminds me of a very agreeable girl, whose mother lived in the Halles.
children.prevalue: She reminds me of a very agreeable girl whose mother lived in the Halles

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Ah! ah! said Athos, smiling.
children.prevalue: Ah ah said Athos smiling

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Oh! the good old times, added M. de Beaufort. Yes, La Valliere reminds me of that girl.
children.prevalue: Oh the good old times added M de Beaufort Yes La Valliere reminds me of that girl

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Who had a son, had she not?
children.prevalue: Who had a son had she not

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: I believe she had, replied the duke, with careless naivete and a complaisant forgetfulness, of which no words could translate the tone and the vocal expression. Now, here is poor Raoul, who is your son, I believe.
children.prevalue: I believe she had replied the duke with careless naivete and a complaisant forgetfulness of which no words could translate the tone and the vocal expression Now here is poor Raoul who is your son I believe

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Yes, he is my son, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes he is my son monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: And the poor lad has been cut out by the king, and he frets.
children.prevalue: And the poor lad has been cut out by the king and he frets

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Still better, monseigneur, he abstains.
children.prevalue: Still better monseigneur he abstains

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: You are going to let the boy rust in idleness it is a mistake. Come, give him to me.
children.prevalue: You are going to let the boy rust in idleness it is a mistake Come give him to me

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: My wish is to keep him at home, monseigneur. I have no longer anything in the world but him, and as long as he likes to remain
children.prevalue: My wish is to keep him at home monseigneur I have no longer anything in the world but him and as long as he likes to remain

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Well, well, replied the duke. I could, nevertheless, have soon put matters to rights again. I assure you, I think he has in him the stuff of which marechals of France are made I have seen more than one produced from less likely rough material.
children.prevalue: Well well replied the duke I could nevertheless have soon put matters to rights again I assure you I think he has in him the stuff of which marechals of France are made I have seen more than one produced from less likely rough material

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: That is very possible, monseigneur but it is the king who makes marechals of France, and Raoul will never accept anything of the king.
children.prevalue: That is very possible monseigneur but it is the king who makes marechals of France and Raoul will never accept anything of the king

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Raoul interrupted this conversation by his return. He preceded Grimaud, whose still steady hands carried the plateau with one glass and a bottle of the duke's favorite wine. On seeing his old protege, the duke uttered an exclamation of pleasure.
children.prevalue: Raoul interrupted this conversation by his return He preceded Grimaud whose still steady hands carried the plateau with one glass and a bottle of the duke s favorite wine On seeing his old protege the duke uttered an exclamation of pleasure

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Grimaud! Good evening, Grimaud! said he how goes it?
children.prevalue: Grimaud Good evening Grimaud said he how goes it

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The servant bowed profoundly, as much gratified as his noble interlocutor.
children.prevalue: The servant bowed profoundly as much gratified as his noble interlocutor

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Two old friends! said the duke, shaking honest Grimaud's shoulder after a vigorous fashion which was followed by another still more profound and delighted bow from Grimaud.
children.prevalue: Two old friends said the duke shaking honest Grimaud s shoulder after a vigorous fashion which was followed by another still more profound and delighted bow from Grimaud

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: But what is this, count, only one glass?
children.prevalue: But what is this count only one glass

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: I should not think of drinking with your highness, unless your highness permitted me, replied Athos, with noble humility.
children.prevalue: I should not think of drinking with your highness unless your highness permitted me replied Athos with noble humility

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Cordieu! you were right to bring only one glass, we will both drink out of it, like two brothers in arms. Begin, count.
children.prevalue: Cordieu you were right to bring only one glass we will both drink out of it like two brothers in arms Begin count

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Do me the honor, said Athos, gently putting back the glass.
children.prevalue: Do me the honor said Athos gently putting back the glass

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: You are a charming friend, replied the Duc de Beaufort, who drank, and passed the goblet to his companion. But that is not all, continued he, I am still thirsty, and I wish to do honor to this handsome young man who stands here. I carry good luck with me, vicomte, said he to Raoul wish for something while drinking out of my glass, and may the black plague grab me if what you wish does not come to pass! He held the goblet to Raoul, who hastily moistened his lips, and replied with the same promptitude:
children.prevalue: You are a charming friend replied the Duc de Beaufort who drank and passed the goblet to his companion But that is not all continued he I am still thirsty and I wish to do honor to this handsome young man who stands here I carry good luck with me vicomte said he to Raoul wish for something while drinking out of my glass and may the black plague grab me if what you wish does not come to pass He held the goblet to Raoul who hastily moistened his lips and replied with the same promptitude

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: I have wished for something, monseigneur. His eyes sparkled with a gloomy fire, and the blood mounted to his cheeks he terrified Athos, if only with his smile.
children.prevalue: I have wished for something monseigneur His eyes sparkled with a gloomy fire and the blood mounted to his cheeks he terrified Athos if only with his smile

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: And what have you wished for? replied the duke, sinking back into his fauteuil, whilst with one hand he returned the bottle to Grimaud, and with the other gave him a purse.
children.prevalue: And what have you wished for replied the duke sinking back into his fauteuil whilst with one hand he returned the bottle to Grimaud and with the other gave him a purse

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Will you promise me, monseigneur, to grant me what I wish for?
children.prevalue: Will you promise me monseigneur to grant me what I wish for

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Pardieu! That is agreed upon.
children.prevalue: Pardieu That is agreed upon

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: I wished, monsieur le duc, to go with you to Gigelli.
children.prevalue: I wished monsieur le duc to go with you to Gigelli

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Athos became pale, and was unable to conceal his agitation. The duke looked at his friend, as if desirous to assist him to parry this unexpected blow.
children.prevalue: Athos became pale and was unable to conceal his agitation The duke looked at his friend as if desirous to assist him to parry this unexpected blow

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: That is difficult, my dear vicomte, very difficult, added he, in a lower tone of voice.
children.prevalue: That is difficult my dear vicomte very difficult added he in a lower tone of voice

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Pardon me, monseigneur, I have been indiscreet, replied Raoul, in a firm voice but as you yourself invited me to wish
children.prevalue: Pardon me monseigneur I have been indiscreet replied Raoul in a firm voice but as you yourself invited me to wish

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: To wish to leave me? said Athos.
children.prevalue: To wish to leave me said Athos

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Oh! monsieurcan you imagine
children.prevalue: Oh monsieurcan you imagine

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Well, mordieu! cried the duke, the young vicomte is right! What can he do here? He will go moldy with grief.
children.prevalue: Well mordieu cried the duke the young vicomte is right What can he do here He will go moldy with grief

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Raoul blushed, and the excitable prince continued: War is a distraction: we gain everything by it we can only lose one thing by itlifethen so much the worse!
children.prevalue: Raoul blushed and the excitable prince continued War is a distraction we gain everything by it we can only lose one thing by itlifethen so much the worse

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: That is to say, memory, said Raoul, eagerly and that is to say, so much the better!
children.prevalue: That is to say memory said Raoul eagerly and that is to say so much the better

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: He repented of having spoken so warmly when he saw Athos rise and open the window which was, doubtless, to conceal his emotion. Raoul sprang towards the comte, but the latter had already overcome his emotion, and turned to the lights with a serene and impassible countenance. Well, come, said the duke, let us see! Shall he go, or shall he not? If he goes, comte, he shall be my aidedecamp, my son.

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Par la corbleu! said the prince in his turn, it is neither the comte nor the vicomte that shall have his way, it is I. I will take him away. The marine offers a superb fortune, my friend.

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Raoul smiled again so sadly, that this time Athos felt his heart penetrated by it, and replied to him by a severe look. Raoul comprehended it all he recovered his calmness, and was so guarded, that not another word escaped him. The duke at length rose, on observing the advanced hour, and said, with animation, I am in great haste, but if I am told I have lost time in talking with a friend, I will reply I have gainedon the balancea most excellent recruit.

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Pardon me, monsieur le duc, interrupted Raoul, do not tell the king so, for it is not the king I wish to serve.
children.prevalue: Pardon me monsieur le duc interrupted Raoul do not tell the king so for it is not the king I wish to serve

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Eh! my friend, whom, then, will you serve? The times are past when you might have said, 'I belong to M. de Beaufort.' No, nowadays, we all belong to the king, great or small. Therefore, if you serve on board my vessels, there can be nothing equivocal about it, my dear vicomte it will be the king you will serve.
children.prevalue: Eh my friend whom then will you serve The times are past when you might have said I belong to M de Beaufort No nowadays we all belong to the king great or small Therefore if you serve on board my vessels there can be nothing equivocal about it my dear vicomte it will be the king you will serve

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Athos waited with a kind of impatient joy for the reply about to be made to this embarrassing question by Raoul, the intractable enemy of the king, his rival. The father hoped that the obstacle would overcome the desire. He was thankful to M. de Beaufort, whose lightness or generous reflection had thrown an impediment in the way of the departure of a son, now his only joy. But Raoul, still firm and tranquil, replied: Monsieur le duc, the objection you make I have already considered in my mind. I will serve on board your vessels, because you do me the honor to take me with you but I shall there serve a more powerful master than the king: I shall serve God!
