children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: How! said Athos. And is the gentleman who fired at us the governor of the fortress?
children.prevalue: How said Athos And is the gentleman who fired at us the governor of the fortress

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: In person.
children.prevalue: In person

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: And why did he fire at us? What have we done to him?
children.prevalue: And why did he fire at us What have we done to him

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Pardieu! You received what the prisoner threw to you?
children.prevalue: Pardieu You received what the prisoner threw to you

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: That is true.
children.prevalue: That is true

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: That platethe prisoner has written something on it, has he not?
children.prevalue: That platethe prisoner has written something on it has he not

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Good heavens! I was afraid he had.
children.prevalue: Good heavens I was afraid he had

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: And D'Artagnan, with all the marks of mortal disquietude, seized the plate, to read the inscription. When he had read it, a fearful pallor spread across his countenance. Oh! good heavens! repeated he. Silence!Here is the governor.
children.prevalue: And D Artagnan with all the marks of mortal disquietude seized the plate to read the inscription When he had read it a fearful pallor spread across his countenance Oh good heavens repeated he Silence Here is the governor

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: And what will he do to us? Is it our fault?
children.prevalue: And what will he do to us Is it our fault

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: It is true, then? said Athos, in a subdued voice. It is true?
children.prevalue: It is true then said Athos in a subdued voice It is true

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Silence! I tell yousilence! If he only believes you can read if he only suspects you have understood I love you, my dear friends, I would willingly be killed for you, but
children.prevalue: Silence I tell yousilence If he only believes you can read if he only suspects you have understood I love you my dear friends I would willingly be killed for you but

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: But said Athos and Raoul.
children.prevalue: But said Athos and Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: But I could not save you from perpetual imprisonment if I saved you from death. Silence, then! Silence again!
children.prevalue: But I could not save you from perpetual imprisonment if I saved you from death Silence then Silence again

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: The governor came up, having crossed the ditch upon a plank bridge.
children.prevalue: The governor came up having crossed the ditch upon a plank bridge

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Well! said he to D'Artagnan, what stops us?
children.prevalue: Well said he to D Artagnan what stops us

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: You are Spaniardsyou do not understand a word of French, said the captain, eagerly, to his friends in a low voice.
children.prevalue: You are Spaniardsyou do not understand a word of French said the captain eagerly to his friends in a low voice

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Well! replied he, addressing the governor, I was right these gentlemen are two Spanish captains with whom I was acquainted at Ypres, last year they don't know a word of French.
children.prevalue: Well replied he addressing the governor I was right these gentlemen are two Spanish captains with whom I was acquainted at Ypres last year they don t know a word of French

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Ah! said the governor, sharply. And yet they were trying to read the inscription on the plate.
children.prevalue: Ah said the governor sharply And yet they were trying to read the inscription on the plate

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: D'Artagnan took it out of his hands, effacing the characters with the point of his sword.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan took it out of his hands effacing the characters with the point of his sword

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: How! cried the governor, what are you doing? I cannot read them now!
children.prevalue: How cried the governor what are you doing I cannot read them now

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: It is a state secret, replied D'Artagnan, bluntly and as you know that, according to the king's orders, it is under the penalty of death any one should penetrate it, I will, if you like, allow you to read it, and have you shot immediately afterwards.
children.prevalue: It is a state secret replied D Artagnan bluntly and as you know that according to the king s orders it is under the penalty of death any one should penetrate it I will if you like allow you to read it and have you shot immediately afterwards

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: During this apostrophehalf serious, half ironicalAthos and Raoul preserved the coolest, most unconcerned silence.
children.prevalue: During this apostrophehalf serious half ironicalAthos and Raoul preserved the coolest most unconcerned silence

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: But, is it possible, said the governor, that these gentlemen do not comprehend at least some words?
children.prevalue: But is it possible said the governor that these gentlemen do not comprehend at least some words

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Suppose they do! If they do understand a few spoken words, it does not follow that they should understand what is written. They cannot even read Spanish. A noble Spaniard, remember, ought never to know how to read.
children.prevalue: Suppose they do If they do understand a few spoken words it does not follow that they should understand what is written They cannot even read Spanish A noble Spaniard remember ought never to know how to read

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: The governor was obliged to be satisfied with these explanations, but he was still tenacious. Invite these gentlemen to come to the fortress, said he.
children.prevalue: The governor was obliged to be satisfied with these explanations but he was still tenacious Invite these gentlemen to come to the fortress said he

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: That I will willingly do. I was about to propose it to you. The fact is, the captain had quite another idea, and would have wished his friends a hundred leagues off. But he was obliged to make the best of it. He addressed the two gentlemen in Spanish, giving them a polite invitation, which they accepted. They all turned towards the entrance of the fort, and, the incident being at an end, the eight soldiers returned to their delightful leisure, for a moment disturbed by this unexpected adventure.
children.prevalue: That I will willingly do I was about to propose it to you The fact is the captain had quite another idea and would have wished his friends a hundred leagues off But he was obliged to make the best of it He addressed the two gentlemen in Spanish giving them a polite invitation which they accepted They all turned towards the entrance of the fort and the incident being at an end the eight soldiers returned to their delightful leisure for a moment disturbed by this unexpected adventure

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: When they had entered the fort, and whilst the governor was making some preparations for the reception of his guests, Come, said Athos, let us have a word of explanation whilst we are alone.
children.prevalue: When they had entered the fort and whilst the governor was making some preparations for the reception of his guests Come said Athos let us have a word of explanation whilst we are alone

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: It is simply this, replied the musketeer. I have conducted hither a prisoner, who the king commands shall not be seen. You came here, he has thrown something to you through the lattice of his window I was at dinner with the governor, I saw the object thrown, and I saw Raoul pick it up. It does not take long to understand this. I understood it, and I thought you in intelligence with my prisoner. And then
children.prevalue: It is simply this replied the musketeer I have conducted hither a prisoner who the king commands shall not be seen You came here he has thrown something to you through the lattice of his window I was at dinner with the governor I saw the object thrown and I saw Raoul pick it up It does not take long to understand this I understood it and I thought you in intelligence with my prisoner And then

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: And thenyou commanded us to be shot.
children.prevalue: And thenyou commanded us to be shot

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Ma foi! I admit it but, if I was the first to seize a musket, fortunately, I was the last to take aim at you.
children.prevalue: Ma foi I admit it but if I was the first to seize a musket fortunately I was the last to take aim at you

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: If you had killed me, D'Artagnan, I should have had the good fortune to die for the royal house of France, and it would be an honor to die by your handyou, its noblest and most loyal defender.
children.prevalue: If you had killed me D Artagnan I should have had the good fortune to die for the royal house of France and it would be an honor to die by your handyou its noblest and most loyal defender

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: What the devil, Athos, do you mean by the royal house? stammered D'Artagnan. You don't mean that you, a wellinformed and sensible man, can place any faith in the nonsense written by an idiot?
children.prevalue: What the devil Athos do you mean by the royal house stammered D Artagnan You don t mean that you a wellinformed and sensible man can place any faith in the nonsense written by an idiot

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I do believe in it.
children.prevalue: I do believe in it

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: With so much the more reason, my dear chevalier, from your having orders to kill all those who do believe in it, said Raoul.
children.prevalue: With so much the more reason my dear chevalier from your having orders to kill all those who do believe in it said Raoul

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: That is because, replied the captain of the musketeersbecause every calumny, however absurd it may be, has the almost certain chance of becoming popular.
children.prevalue: That is because replied the captain of the musketeersbecause every calumny however absurd it may be has the almost certain chance of becoming popular

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: No, D'Artagnan, replied Athos, promptly but because the king is not willing that the secret of his family should transpire among the people, and cover with shame the executioners of the son of Louis XIII.
children.prevalue: No D Artagnan replied Athos promptly but because the king is not willing that the secret of his family should transpire among the people and cover with shame the executioners of the son of Louis XIII

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Do not talk in such a childish manner, Athos, or I shall begin to think you have lost your senses. Besides, explain to me how it is possible Louis XIII. should have a son in the Isle of SainteMarguerite.
children.prevalue: Do not talk in such a childish manner Athos or I shall begin to think you have lost your senses Besides explain to me how it is possible Louis XIII should have a son in the Isle of SainteMarguerite

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: A son whom you have brought hither masked, in a fishingboat, said Athos. Why not?
children.prevalue: A son whom you have brought hither masked in a fishingboat said Athos Why not

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: D'Artagnan was brought to a pause.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan was brought to a pause

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Oh! said he whence do you know that a fishingboat?
children.prevalue: Oh said he whence do you know that a fishingboat

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Brought you to SainteMarguerite's with the carriage containing the prisonerwith a prisoner whom you styled monseigneur. Oh! I am acquainted with all that, resumed the comte. D'Artagnan bit his mustache.
children.prevalue: Brought you to SainteMarguerite s with the carriage containing the prisonerwith a prisoner whom you styled monseigneur Oh I am acquainted with all that resumed the comte D Artagnan bit his mustache

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: If it were true, said he, that I had brought hither in a boat and with a carriage a masked prisoner, nothing proves that this prisoner must be a princea prince of the house of France.
children.prevalue: If it were true said he that I had brought hither in a boat and with a carriage a masked prisoner nothing proves that this prisoner must be a princea prince of the house of France

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Ask Aramis such riddles, replied Athos, coolly.
children.prevalue: Ask Aramis such riddles replied Athos coolly

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Aramis, cried the musketeer, quite at a stand. Have you seen Aramis?
children.prevalue: Aramis cried the musketeer quite at a stand Have you seen Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: After his discomfiture at Vaux, yes I have seen Aramis, a fugitive, pursued, bewildered, ruined and Aramis has told me enough to make me believe in the complaints this unfortunate young prince cut upon the bottom of the plate.
children.prevalue: After his discomfiture at Vaux yes I have seen Aramis a fugitive pursued bewildered ruined and Aramis has told me enough to make me believe in the complaints this unfortunate young prince cut upon the bottom of the plate

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: D'Artagnan's head sunk on his breast in some confusion. This is the way, said he, in which God turns to nothing that which men call wisdom! A fine secret must that be of which twelve or fifteen persons hold the tattered fragments! Athos, cursed be the chance which has brought you face to face with me in this affair! for now
children.prevalue: D Artagnan s head sunk on his breast in some confusion This is the way said he in which God turns to nothing that which men call wisdom A fine secret must that be of which twelve or fifteen persons hold the tattered fragments Athos cursed be the chance which has brought you face to face with me in this affair for now

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Well, said Athos, with his customary mild severity, is your secret lost because I know it? Consult your memory, my friend. Have I not borne secrets heavier than this?
children.prevalue: Well said Athos with his customary mild severity is your secret lost because I know it Consult your memory my friend Have I not borne secrets heavier than this

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: You have never borne one so dangerous, replied D'Artagnan, in a tone of sadness. I have something like a sinister idea that all who are concerned with this secret will die, and die unhappily.
children.prevalue: You have never borne one so dangerous replied D Artagnan in a tone of sadness I have something like a sinister idea that all who are concerned with this secret will die and die unhappily

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The will of God be done! said Athos, but here is your governor.
children.prevalue: The will of God be done said Athos but here is your governor

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: D'Artagnan and his friends immediately resumed their parts. The governor, suspicious and hard, behaved towards D'Artagnan with a politeness almost amounting to obsequiousness. With respect to the travelers, he contented himself with offering good cheer, and never taking his eye from them. Athos and Raoul observed that he often tried to embarrass them by sudden attacks, or to catch them off their guard but neither the one nor the other gave him the least advantage. What D'Artagnan had said was probable, if the governor did not believe it to be quite true. They rose from the table to repose awhile.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan and his friends immediately resumed their parts The governor suspicious and hard behaved towards D Artagnan with a politeness almost amounting to obsequiousness With respect to the travelers he contented himself with offering good cheer and never taking his eye from them Athos and Raoul observed that he often tried to embarrass them by sudden attacks or to catch them off their guard but neither the one nor the other gave him the least advantage What D Artagnan had said was probable if the governor did not believe it to be quite true They rose from the table to repose awhile

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: What is this man's name? I don't like the looks of him, said Athos to D'Artagnan in Spanish.
children.prevalue: What is this man s name I don t like the looks of him said Athos to D Artagnan in Spanish

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: De SaintMars, replied the captain.
children.prevalue: De SaintMars replied the captain

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: He is, then, I suppose, the prince's jailer?
children.prevalue: He is then I suppose the prince s jailer

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Eh! how can I tell? I may be kept at SainteMarguerite forever.
children.prevalue: Eh how can I tell I may be kept at SainteMarguerite forever

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Oh! no, not you!
children.prevalue: Oh no not you

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: My friend, I am in the situation of a man who finds a treasure in the midst of a desert. He would like to carry it away, but he cannot he would like to leave it, but he dares not. The king will not dare to recall me, for no one else would serve him as faithfully as I do he regrets not having me near him, from being aware that no one would be of so much service near his person as myself. But it will happen as it may please God.
children.prevalue: My friend I am in the situation of a man who finds a treasure in the midst of a desert He would like to carry it away but he cannot he would like to leave it but he dares not The king will not dare to recall me for no one else would serve him as faithfully as I do he regrets not having me near him from being aware that no one would be of so much service near his person as myself But it will happen as it may please God

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: But, observed Raoul, your not being certain proves that your situation here is provisional, and you will return to Paris?
children.prevalue: But observed Raoul your not being certain proves that your situation here is provisional and you will return to Paris

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Ask these gentlemen, interrupted the governor, what was their purpose in coming to SaintMarguerite?
children.prevalue: Ask these gentlemen interrupted the governor what was their purpose in coming to SaintMarguerite

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: They came from learning there was a convent of Benedictines at SainteHonnorat which is considered curious and from being told there was excellent shooting in the island.
children.prevalue: They came from learning there was a convent of Benedictines at SainteHonnorat which is considered curious and from being told there was excellent shooting in the island

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: That is quite at their service, as well as yours, replied SaintMars.
children.prevalue: That is quite at their service as well as yours replied SaintMars

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: D'Artagnan politely thanked him.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan politely thanked him

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: When will they depart? added the governor.
children.prevalue: When will they depart added the governor

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Tomorrow, replied D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Tomorrow replied D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: M. de SaintMars went to make his rounds, and left D'Artagnan alone with the pretended Spaniards.
children.prevalue: M de SaintMars went to make his rounds and left D Artagnan alone with the pretended Spaniards

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Oh! exclaimed the musketeer, here is a life and a society that suits me very little. I command this man, and he bores me, mordioux! Come, let us have a shot or two at the rabbits the walk will be beautiful, and not fatiguing. The whole island is but a league and a half in length, with the breadth of a league a real park. Let us try to amuse ourselves.
children.prevalue: Oh exclaimed the musketeer here is a life and a society that suits me very little I command this man and he bores me mordioux Come let us have a shot or two at the rabbits the walk will be beautiful and not fatiguing The whole island is but a league and a half in length with the breadth of a league a real park Let us try to amuse ourselves

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: As you please, D'Artagnan not for the sake of amusing ourselves, but to gain an opportunity for talking freely.
children.prevalue: As you please D Artagnan not for the sake of amusing ourselves but to gain an opportunity for talking freely

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: D'Artagnan made a sign to a soldier, who brought the gentlemen some guns, and then returned to the fort.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan made a sign to a soldier who brought the gentlemen some guns and then returned to the fort

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: And now, said the musketeer, answer me the question put to you by that blacklooking SaintMars: what did you come to do at the Lerin Isles?
children.prevalue: And now said the musketeer answer me the question put to you by that blacklooking SaintMars what did you come to do at the Lerin Isles

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: To bid you farewell.
children.prevalue: To bid you farewell

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Bid me farewell! What do you mean by that? Is Raoul going anywhere?
children.prevalue: Bid me farewell What do you mean by that Is Raoul going anywhere

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Then I will lay a wager it is with M. de Beaufort.
children.prevalue: Then I will lay a wager it is with M de Beaufort

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: With M. de Beaufort it is, my dear friend. You always guess correctly.
children.prevalue: With M de Beaufort it is my dear friend You always guess correctly

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: From habit.
children.prevalue: From habit

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Whilst the two friends were commencing their conversation, Raoul, with his head hanging down and his heart oppressed, seated himself on a mossy rock, his gun across his knees, looking at the sealooking at the heavens, and listening to the voice of his soul he allowed the sportsmen to attain a considerable distance from him. D'Artagnan remarked his absence.
children.prevalue: Whilst the two friends were commencing their conversation Raoul with his head hanging down and his heart oppressed seated himself on a mossy rock his gun across his knees looking at the sealooking at the heavens and listening to the voice of his soul he allowed the sportsmen to attain a considerable distance from him D Artagnan remarked his absence

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: He has not recovered the blow? said he to Athos.
children.prevalue: He has not recovered the blow said he to Athos

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: He is struck to death.
children.prevalue: He is struck to death

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Oh! your fears exaggerate, I hope. Raoul is of a tempered nature. Around all hearts as noble as his, there is a second envelope that forms a cuirass. The first bleeds, the second resists.
children.prevalue: Oh your fears exaggerate I hope Raoul is of a tempered nature Around all hearts as noble as his there is a second envelope that forms a cuirass The first bleeds the second resists

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: No, replied Athos, Raoul will die of it.
children.prevalue: No replied Athos Raoul will die of it

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Mordioux! said D'Artagnan, in a melancholy tone. And he did not add a word to this exclamation. Then, a minute after, Why do you let him go?
children.prevalue: Mordioux said D Artagnan in a melancholy tone And he did not add a word to this exclamation Then a minute after Why do you let him go

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Because he insists on going.
children.prevalue: Because he insists on going

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: And why do you not go with him?
children.prevalue: And why do you not go with him

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Because I could not bear to see him die.
children.prevalue: Because I could not bear to see him die

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: D'Artagnan looked his friend earnestly in the face. You know one thing, continued the comte, leaning upon the arm of the captain you know that in the course of my life I have been afraid of but few things. Well! I have an incessant gnawing, insurmountable fear that an hour will come in which I shall hold the dead body of that boy in my arms.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan looked his friend earnestly in the face You know one thing continued the comte leaning upon the arm of the captain you know that in the course of my life I have been afraid of but few things Well I have an incessant gnawing insurmountable fear that an hour will come in which I shall hold the dead body of that boy in my arms

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Oh! murmured D'Artagnan oh!
children.prevalue: Oh murmured D Artagnan oh

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: He will die, I know, I have a perfect conviction of that but I would not see him die.
children.prevalue: He will die I know I have a perfect conviction of that but I would not see him die

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: How is this, Athos? you come and place yourself in the presence of the bravest man, you say you have ever seen, of your own D'Artagnan, of that man without an equal, as you formerly called him, and you come and tell him, with your arms folded, that you are afraid of witnessing the death of your son, you who have seen all that can be seen in this world! Why have you this fear, Athos? Man upon this earth must expect everything, and ought to face everything.
children.prevalue: How is this Athos you come and place yourself in the presence of the bravest man you say you have ever seen of your own D Artagnan of that man without an equal as you formerly called him and you come and tell him with your arms folded that you are afraid of witnessing the death of your son you who have seen all that can be seen in this world Why have you this fear Athos Man upon this earth must expect everything and ought to face everything

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Listen to me, my friend. After having worn myself out upon this earth of which you speak, I have preserved but two religions: that of life, friendship, my duty as a fatherthat of eternity, love, and respect for God. Now, I have within me the revelation that if God should decree that my friend or my son should render up his last sigh in my presenceoh! no, I cannot even tell you, D'Artagnan!
children.prevalue: Listen to me my friend After having worn myself out upon this earth of which you speak I have preserved but two religions that of life friendship my duty as a fatherthat of eternity love and respect for God Now I have within me the revelation that if God should decree that my friend or my son should render up his last sigh in my presenceoh no I cannot even tell you D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Speak, speak, tell me!
children.prevalue: Speak speak tell me

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: I am strong against everything, except against the death of those I love. For that only there is no remedy. He who dies, gains he who sees others die, loses. No, this is itto know that I should no more meet on earth him whom I now behold with joy to know that there would nowhere be a D'Artagnan any more, nowhere again be a Raoul, oh! I am old, look you, I have no longer courage I pray God to spare me in my weakness but if he struck me so plainly and in that fashion, I should curse him. A Christian gentleman ought not to curse his God, D'Artagnan it is enough to once have cursed a king!
children.prevalue: I am strong against everything except against the death of those I love For that only there is no remedy He who dies gains he who sees others die loses No this is itto know that I should no more meet on earth him whom I now behold with joy to know that there would nowhere be a D Artagnan any more nowhere again be a Raoul oh I am old look you I have no longer courage I pray God to spare me in my weakness but if he struck me so plainly and in that fashion I should curse him A Christian gentleman ought not to curse his God D Artagnan it is enough to once have cursed a king

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Humph! sighed D'Artagnan, a little confused by this violent tempest of grief.
children.prevalue: Humph sighed D Artagnan a little confused by this violent tempest of grief

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Let me speak to him, Athos. Who knows?
children.prevalue: Let me speak to him Athos Who knows

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Try, if you please, but I am convinced you will not succeed.
children.prevalue: Try if you please but I am convinced you will not succeed

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: I will not attempt to console him. I will serve him.
children.prevalue: I will not attempt to console him I will serve him

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: You will?
children.prevalue: You will

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Doubtless, I will. Do you think this would be the first time a woman had repented of an infidelity? I will go to him, I tell you.
children.prevalue: Doubtless I will Do you think this would be the first time a woman had repented of an infidelity I will go to him I tell you

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Athos shook his head, and continued his walk alone, D'Artagnan, cutting across the brambles, rejoined Raoul and held out his hand to him. Well, Raoul! You have something to say to me?
children.prevalue: Athos shook his head and continued his walk alone D Artagnan cutting across the brambles rejoined Raoul and held out his hand to him Well Raoul You have something to say to me

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: I have a kindness to ask of you, replied Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: I have a kindness to ask of you replied Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Ask it, then.
children.prevalue: Ask it then

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: You will some day return to France?
children.prevalue: You will some day return to France

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I hope so.
children.prevalue: I hope so

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Ought I to write to Mademoiselle de la Valliere?
children.prevalue: Ought I to write to Mademoiselle de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: No, you must not.
children.prevalue: No you must not

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: But I have many things to say to her.
children.prevalue: But I have many things to say to her

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Go and say them to her, then.
children.prevalue: Go and say them to her then

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Never!
children.prevalue: Never

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Pray, what virtue do you attribute to a letter, which your speech might not possess?
children.prevalue: Pray what virtue do you attribute to a letter which your speech might not possess

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Perhaps you are right.
children.prevalue: Perhaps you are right

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: She loves the king, said D'Artagnan, bluntly and she is an honest girl. Raoul started. And you, you whom she abandons, she, perhaps, loves better than she does the king, but after another fashion.
children.prevalue: She loves the king said D Artagnan bluntly and she is an honest girl Raoul started And you you whom she abandons she perhaps loves better than she does the king but after another fashion

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: D'Artagnan, do you believe she loves the king?
children.prevalue: D Artagnan do you believe she loves the king

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: To idolatry. Her heart is inaccessible to any other feeling. You might continue to live near her, and would be her best friend.
children.prevalue: To idolatry Her heart is inaccessible to any other feeling You might continue to live near her and would be her best friend

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Ah! exclaimed Raoul, with a passionate burst of repugnance at such a hideous hope.
children.prevalue: Ah exclaimed Raoul with a passionate burst of repugnance at such a hideous hope

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Will you do so?
children.prevalue: Will you do so

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: It would be base.
children.prevalue: It would be base

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: That is a very absurd word, which would lead me to think slightly of your understanding. Please to understand, Raoul, that it is never base to do that which is imposed upon us by a superior force. If your heart says to you, 'Go there, or die,' why go, Raoul. Was she base or brave, she whom you loved, in preferring the king to you, the king whom her heart commanded her imperiously to prefer to you? No, she was the bravest of women. Do, then, as she has done. Oblige yourself. Do you know one thing of which I am sure, Raoul?

children.value: This is what I wish, my friend. You will see her again, and you will give her a letter which, if you think proper, will explain to her, as to yourself, what is passing in my heart. Read it I drew it up last night. Something told me I should see you today. He held the letter out, and D'Artagnan read:

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: MADEMOISELLE,You are not wrong in my eyes in not loving me. You have only been guilty of one fault towards me, that of having left me to believe you loved me. This error will cost me my life. I pardon you, but I cannot pardon myself. It is said that happy lovers are deaf to the sorrows of rejected lovers. It will not be so with you, who did not love me, save with anxiety. I am sure that if I had persisted in endeavoring to change that friendship into love, you would have yielded out of a fear of bringing about my death, or lessening the esteem I had for you. It is much more delightful to me to die, knowing that you are free and satisfied. How much, then, will you love me, when you will no longer fear either my presence or reproaches? You will love me, because, however charming a new love may appear to you, God has not made me in anything inferior to him you have chosen, and because my devotedness, my sacrifice, and my painful end will assure me, in your eyes, a certain superiority over him. I have allowed to escape, in the candid credulity of my heart, the treasure I possessed. Many people tell me that you loved me enough to lead me to hope you would have loved me much. That idea takes from my mind all bitterness, and leads me only to blame myself. You will accept this last farewell, and you will bless me for having taken refuge in the inviolable asylum where hatred is extinguished, and where all love endures forever. Adieu, mademoiselle. If your happiness could be purchased by the last drop of my blood, I would shed that drop. I willingly make the sacrifice of it to my misery!

children.value: As they were passing over the ramparts to a gallery of which D'Artagnan had the key, they saw M. de SaintMars directing his steps towards the chamber inhabited by the prisoner. Upon a sign from D'Artagnan, they concealed themselves in an angle of the staircase.

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: And they saw, by the red flashes of lightning against the violet fog which the wind stamped upon the bankward sky, they saw pass gravely, at six paces behind the governor, a man clothed in black and masked by a vizor of polished steel, soldered to a helmet of the same nature, which altogether enveloped the whole of his head. The fire of the heavens cast red reflections on the polished surface, and these reflections, flying off capriciously, seemed to be angry looks launched by the unfortunate, instead of imprecations. In the middle of the gallery, the prisoner stopped for a moment, to contemplate the infinite horizon, to respire the sulphurous perfumes of the tempest, to drink in thirstily the hot rain, and to breathe a sigh resembling a smothered groan.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Scarcely had D'Artagnan reentered his apartment with his two friends, when one of the soldiers of the fort came to inform him that the governor was seeking him. The bark which Raoul had perceived at sea, and which appeared so eager to gain the port, came to SainteMarguerite with an important dispatch for the captain of the musketeers. On opening it, D'Artagnan recognized the writing of the king: I should think, said Louis XIV., you will have completed the execution of my orders, Monsieur d'Artagnan return, then, immediately to Paris, and join me at the Louvre.

children.prevalue: Yes but to meet again dear friend seeing that Raoul is old enough now to go alone with M de Beaufort and will prefer his father going back in company with M d Artagnan to forcing him to travel two hundred leagues solitarily to reach home at La Fere will you not Raoul

children.value: No, no, my friend, interrupted Athos, I will never quit Raoul till the day his vessel disappears on the horizon. As long as he remains in France he shall not be separated from me.

children.value: With all my heart we cannot too soon be at a distance from this fort, and from the spectacle that shocked us so just now.

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The three friends quitted the little isle, after paying their respects to the governor, and by the last flashes of the departing tempest they took their farewell of the white walls of the fort. D'Artagnan parted from his friend that same night, after having seen fire set to the carriage upon the shore by the orders of SaintMars, according to the advice the captain had given him. Before getting on horseback, and after leaving the arms of Athos: My friends, said he, you bear too much resemblance to two soldiers who are abandoning their post. Something warns me that Raoul will require being supported by you in his rank. Will you allow me to ask permission to go over into Africa with a hundred good muskets? The king will not refuse me, and I will take you with me.

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Monsieur d'Artagnan, replied Raoul, pressing his hand with emotion, thanks for that offer, which would give us more than we wish, either monsieur le comte or I. I, who am young, stand in need of labor of mind and fatigue of body monsieur le comte wants the profoundest repose. You are his best friend. I recommend him to your care. In watching over him, you are holding both our souls in your hands.
children.prevalue: Monsieur d Artagnan replied Raoul pressing his hand with emotion thanks for that offer which would give us more than we wish either monsieur le comte or I I who am young stand in need of labor of mind and fatigue of body monsieur le comte wants the profoundest repose You are his best friend I recommend him to your care In watching over him you are holding both our souls in your hands

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I must go my horse is all in a fret, said D'Artagnan, with whom the most manifest sign of a lively emotion was the change of ideas in conversation. Come, comte, how many days longer has Raoul to stay here?
children.prevalue: I must go my horse is all in a fret said D Artagnan with whom the most manifest sign of a lively emotion was the change of ideas in conversation Come comte how many days longer has Raoul to stay here

children.value: Three days at most.
children.prevalue: Three days at most

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: And how long will it take you to reach home?
children.prevalue: And how long will it take you to reach home

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Oh! a considerable time, replied Athos. I shall not like the idea of being separated too quickly from Raoul. Time will travel too fast of itself to require me to aid it by distance. I shall only make halfstages.
children.prevalue: Oh a considerable time replied Athos I shall not like the idea of being separated too quickly from Raoul Time will travel too fast of itself to require me to aid it by distance I shall only make halfstages

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: And why so, my friend? Nothing is more dull than traveling slowly and hostelry life does not become a man like you.
children.prevalue: And why so my friend Nothing is more dull than traveling slowly and hostelry life does not become a man like you

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: My friend, I came hither on posthorses but I wish to purchase two animals of a superior kind. Now, to take them home fresh, it would not be prudent to make them travel more than seven or eight leagues a day.
children.prevalue: My friend I came hither on posthorses but I wish to purchase two animals of a superior kind Now to take them home fresh it would not be prudent to make them travel more than seven or eight leagues a day

children.prevalue: Where is Grimaud

children.value: That is, never to come back again, D'Artagnan suffered to escape him. Till we meet again, then, dear Athosand if you are diligent, I shall embrace you the sooner. So saying, he put his foot in the stirrup, which Raoul held.
children.prevalue: That is never to come back again D Artagnan suffered to escape him Till we meet again then dear Athosand if you are diligent I shall embrace you the sooner So saying he put his foot in the stirrup which Raoul held

children.prevalue: Farewell said the young man embracing him

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Farewell! said D'Artagnan, as he got into his saddle.
children.prevalue: Farewell said D Artagnan as he got into his saddle

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: His horse made a movement which divided the cavalier from his friends. This scene had taken place in front of the house chosen by Athos, near the gates of Antibes, whither D'Artagnan, after his supper, had ordered his horses to be brought. The road began to branch off there, white and undulating in the vapors of the night. The horse eagerly respired the salt, sharp perfume of the marshes. D'Artagnan put him to a trot and Athos and Raoul sadly turned towards the house. All at once they heard the rapid approach of a horse's steps, and first believed it to be one of those singular repercussions which deceive the ear at every turn in a road. But it was really the return of the horseman. They uttered a cry of joyous surprise and the captain, springing to the ground like a young man, seized within his arms the two beloved heads of Athos and Raoul. He held them long embraced thus, without speaking a word, or suffering the sigh which was bursting his breast to escape him. Then, as rapidly as he had come back, he set off again, with a sharp application of his spurs to the sides of his fiery horse.

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Alas! said the comte, in a low voice, alas! alas!
children.prevalue: Alas said the comte in a low voice alas alas

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: An evil omen! on his side, said D'Artagnan to himself, making up for lost time. I could not smile upon them. An evil omen!
children.prevalue: An evil omen on his side said D Artagnan to himself making up for lost time I could not smile upon them An evil omen

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The next day Grimaud was on foot again. The service commanded by M. de Beaufort was happily accomplished. The flotilla, sent to Toulon by the exertions of Raoul, had set out, dragging after it in little nutshells, almost invisible, the wives and friends of the fishermen and smugglers put in requisition for the service of the fleet. The time, so short, which remained for father and son to live together, appeared to go by with double rapidity, like some swift stream that flows towards eternity. Athos and Raoul returned to Toulon, which began to be filled with the noise of carriages, with the noise of arms, the noise of neighing horses. The trumpeters sounded their spirited marches the drummers signalized their strength the streets were overflowing with soldiers, servants, and tradespeople. The Duc de Beaufort was everywhere, superintending the embarkation with the zeal and interest of a good captain. He encouraged the humblest of his companions he scolded his lieutenants, even those of the highest rank. Artillery, provisions, baggage, he insisted upon seeing all himself. He examined the equipment of every soldier assured himself of the health and soundness of every horse. It was plain that, light, boastful, egotistical, in his hotel, the gentleman became the soldier againthe high noble, a captainin face of the responsibility he had accepted. And yet, it must be admitted that, whatever was the care with which he presided over the preparations for departure, it was easy to perceive careless precipitation, and the absence of all the precaution that make the French soldier the first soldier in the world, because, in that world, he is the one most abandoned to his own physical and moral resources. All things having satisfied, or appearing to have satisfied, the admiral, he paid his compliments to Raoul, and gave the last orders for sailing, which was ordered the next morning at daybreak. He invited the comte had his son to dine with him but they, under a pretext of service, kept themselves apart. Gaining their hostelry, situated under the trees of the great Place, they took their repast in haste, and Athos led Raoul to the rocks which dominate the city, vast gray mountains, whence the view is infinite and embraces a liquid horizon which appears, so remote is it, on a level with the rocks themselves. The night was fine, as it always is in these happy climes. The moon, rising behind the rocks, unrolled a silver sheet on the cerulean carpet of the sea. In the roadsteads maneuvered silently the vessels which had just taken their rank to facilitate the embarkation. The sea, loaded with phosphoric light, opened beneath the hulls of the barks that transported the baggage and munitions every dip of the prow plowed up this gulf of white flames from every oar dropped liquid diamonds. The sailors, rejoicing in the largesses of the admiral, were heard murmuring their slow and artless songs. Sometimes the grinding of the chains was mixed with the dull noise of shot falling into the holds. Such harmonies, such a spectacle, oppress the heart like fear, and dilate it like hope. All this life speaks of death. Athos had seated himself with his son, upon the moss, among the brambles of the promontory. Around their heads passed and repassed large bats, carried along by the fearful whirl of their blind chase. The feet of Raoul were over the edge of the cliff, bathed in that void which is peopled by vertigo, and provokes to selfannihilation. When the moon had risen to its fullest height, caressing with light the neighboring peaks, when the watery mirror was illumined in its full extent, and the little red fires had made their openings in the black masses of every ship, Athos, collecting all his ideas and all his courage, said:
