children.value: Neither, thank you both, said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Neither thank you both said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Your attack? said D'Artagnan, in his turn are you unwell, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: Your attack said D Artagnan in his turn are you unwell monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I have a tertian fever, which seized me after the fete at Vaux.
children.prevalue: I have a tertian fever which seized me after the fete at Vaux

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Caught cold in the grottos, at night, perhaps?
children.prevalue: Caught cold in the grottos at night perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: No, no nothing but agitation, that was all.
children.prevalue: No no nothing but agitation that was all

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The too much heart you displayed in your reception of the king, said La Fontaine, quietly, without suspicion that he was uttering a sacrilege.
children.prevalue: The too much heart you displayed in your reception of the king said La Fontaine quietly without suspicion that he was uttering a sacrilege

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: We cannot devote too much heart to the reception of our king, said Fouquet, mildly, to his poet.
children.prevalue: We cannot devote too much heart to the reception of our king said Fouquet mildly to his poet

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Monsieur meant to say the too great ardor, interrupted D'Artagnan, with perfect frankness and much amenity. The fact is, monseigneur, that hospitality was never practiced as at Vaux.
children.prevalue: Monsieur meant to say the too great ardor interrupted D Artagnan with perfect frankness and much amenity The fact is monseigneur that hospitality was never practiced as at Vaux

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Madame Fouquet permitted her countenance to show clearly that if Fouquet had conducted himself well towards the king, the king had hardly done the like to the minister. But D'Artagnan knew the terrible secret. He alone with Fouquet knew it those two men had not, the one the courage to complain, the other the right to accuse. The captain, to whom the two hundred pistoles were brought, was about to take his leave, when Fouquet, rising, took a glass of wine, and ordered one to be given to D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Madame Fouquet permitted her countenance to show clearly that if Fouquet had conducted himself well towards the king the king had hardly done the like to the minister But D Artagnan knew the terrible secret He alone with Fouquet knew it those two men had not the one the courage to complain the other the right to accuse The captain to whom the two hundred pistoles were brought was about to take his leave when Fouquet rising took a glass of wine and ordered one to be given to D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Monsieur, said he, to the health of the king, whatever may happen.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said he to the health of the king whatever may happen

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: And to your health, monseigneur, whatever may happen, said D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: And to your health monseigneur whatever may happen said D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: He bowed, with these words of evil omen, to all the company, who rose as soon as they heard the sound of his spurs and boots at the bottom of the stairs.
children.prevalue: He bowed with these words of evil omen to all the company who rose as soon as they heard the sound of his spurs and boots at the bottom of the stairs

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I, for a moment, thought it was I and not my money he wanted, said Fouquet, endeavoring to laugh.
children.prevalue: I for a moment thought it was I and not my money he wanted said Fouquet endeavoring to laugh

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: You! cried his friends and what for, in the name of Heaven!
children.prevalue: You cried his friends and what for in the name of Heaven

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Oh! do not deceive yourselves, my dear brothers in Epicurus, said the superintendent I do not wish to make a comparison between the most humble sinner on the earth, and the God we adore, but remember, he gave one day to his friends a repast which is called the Last Supper, and which was nothing but a farewell dinner, like that which we are making at this moment.
children.prevalue: Oh do not deceive yourselves my dear brothers in Epicurus said the superintendent I do not wish to make a comparison between the most humble sinner on the earth and the God we adore but remember he gave one day to his friends a repast which is called the Last Supper and which was nothing but a farewell dinner like that which we are making at this moment

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: A painful cry of denial arose from all parts of the table. Shut the doors, said Fouquet, and the servants disappeared. My friends, continued Fouquet, lowering his voice, what was I formerly? What am I now? Consult among yourselves and reply. A man like me sinks when he does not continue to rise. What shall we say, then, when he really sinks? I have no more money, no more credit I have no longer anything but powerful enemies, and powerless friends.
children.prevalue: A painful cry of denial arose from all parts of the table Shut the doors said Fouquet and the servants disappeared My friends continued Fouquet lowering his voice what was I formerly What am I now Consult among yourselves and reply A man like me sinks when he does not continue to rise What shall we say then when he really sinks I have no more money no more credit I have no longer anything but powerful enemies and powerless friends

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Quick! cried Pelisson. Since you explain yourself with such frankness, it is our duty to be frank, likewise. Yes, you are ruinedyes, you are hastening to your ruinstop. And, in the first place, what money have we left?
children.prevalue: Quick cried Pelisson Since you explain yourself with such frankness it is our duty to be frank likewise Yes you are ruinedyes you are hastening to your ruinstop And in the first place what money have we left

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Seven hundred thousand livres, said the intendant.
children.prevalue: Seven hundred thousand livres said the intendant

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Bread, murmured Madame Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Bread murmured Madame Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Relays, said Pelisson, relays, and fly!
children.prevalue: Relays said Pelisson relays and fly

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Whither?
children.prevalue: Whither

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: To Switzerlandto Savoybut fly!
children.prevalue: To Switzerlandto Savoybut fly

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: If monseigneur flies, said Madame Belliere, it will be said that he was guiltywas afraid.
children.prevalue: If monseigneur flies said Madame Belliere it will be said that he was guiltywas afraid

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: More than that, it will be said that I have carried away twenty millions with me.
children.prevalue: More than that it will be said that I have carried away twenty millions with me

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: We will draw up memoirs to justify you, said La Fontaine. Fly!
children.prevalue: We will draw up memoirs to justify you said La Fontaine Fly

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I will remain, said Fouquet. And, besides, does not everything serve me?
children.prevalue: I will remain said Fouquet And besides does not everything serve me

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: You have BelleIsle, cried the Abbe Fouquet.
children.prevalue: You have BelleIsle cried the Abbe Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: And I am naturally going there, when going to Nantes, replied the superintendent. Patience, then, patience!
children.prevalue: And I am naturally going there when going to Nantes replied the superintendent Patience then patience

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Before arriving at Nantes, what a distance! said Madame Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Before arriving at Nantes what a distance said Madame Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Yes, I know that well, replied Fouquet. But what is to be done there? The king summons me to the States. I know well it is for the purpose of ruining me but to refuse to go would be to evince uneasiness.
children.prevalue: Yes I know that well replied Fouquet But what is to be done there The king summons me to the States I know well it is for the purpose of ruining me but to refuse to go would be to evince uneasiness

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Well, I have discovered the means of reconciling everything, cried Pelisson. You are going to set out for Nantes.
children.prevalue: Well I have discovered the means of reconciling everything cried Pelisson You are going to set out for Nantes

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Fouquet looked at him with an air of surprise.
children.prevalue: Fouquet looked at him with an air of surprise

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: But with friends but in your own carriage as far as Orleans in your own barge as far as Nantes always ready to defend yourself, if you are attacked to escape, if you are threatened. In fact, you will carry your money against all chances and, whilst flying, you will only have obeyed the king then, reaching the sea, when you like, you will embark for BelleIsle, and from BelleIsle you will shoot out wherever it may please you, like the eagle that leaps into space when it has been driven from its eyrie.
children.prevalue: But with friends but in your own carriage as far as Orleans in your own barge as far as Nantes always ready to defend yourself if you are attacked to escape if you are threatened In fact you will carry your money against all chances and whilst flying you will only have obeyed the king then reaching the sea when you like you will embark for BelleIsle and from BelleIsle you will shoot out wherever it may please you like the eagle that leaps into space when it has been driven from its eyrie

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: A general assent followed Pelisson's words. Yes, do so, said Madame Fouquet to her husband.
children.prevalue: A general assent followed Pelisson s words Yes do so said Madame Fouquet to her husband

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Do so, said Madame de Belliere.
children.prevalue: Do so said Madame de Belliere

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Do it! do it! cried all his friends.
children.prevalue: Do it do it cried all his friends

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: I will do so, replied Fouquet.
children.prevalue: I will do so replied Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: This very evening?
children.prevalue: This very evening

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: In an hour?
children.prevalue: In an hour

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Instantly.
children.prevalue: Instantly

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: With seven hundred thousand livres you can lay the foundation of another fortune, said the Abbe Fouquet.
children.prevalue: With seven hundred thousand livres you can lay the foundation of another fortune said the Abbe Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: What is there to prevent our arming corsairs at BelleIsle?
children.prevalue: What is there to prevent our arming corsairs at BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: And, if necessary, we will go and discover a new world, added La Fontaine, intoxicated with fresh projects and enthusiasm.
children.prevalue: And if necessary we will go and discover a new world added La Fontaine intoxicated with fresh projects and enthusiasm

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: A knock at the door interrupted this concert of joy and hope. A courier from the king, said the master of the ceremonies.
children.prevalue: A knock at the door interrupted this concert of joy and hope A courier from the king said the master of the ceremonies

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: A profound silence immediately ensued, as if the message brought by this courier was nothing but a reply to all the projects given birth to a moment before. Every one waited to see what the master would do. His brow was streaming with perspiration, and he was really suffering from his fever at that instant. He passed into his cabinet, to receive the king's message. There prevailed, as we have said, such a silence in the chambers, and throughout the attendance, that from the diningroom could be heard the voice of Fouquet, saying, That is well, monsieur. This voice was, however, broken by fatigue, and trembled with emotion. An instant after, Fouquet called Gourville, who crossed the gallery amidst the universal expectation. At length, he himself reappeared among his guests but it was no longer the same pale, spiritless countenance they had beheld when he left them from pale he had become livid and from spiritless, annihilated. A breathing, living specter, he advanced with his arms stretched out, his mouth parched, like a shade that comes to salute the friends of former days. On seeing him thus, every one cried out, and every one rushed towards Fouquet. The latter, looking at Pelisson, leaned upon his wife, and pressed the icy hand of the Marquise de Belliere.
children.prevalue: A profound silence immediately ensued as if the message brought by this courier was nothing but a reply to all the projects given birth to a moment before Every one waited to see what the master would do His brow was streaming with perspiration and he was really suffering from his fever at that instant He passed into his cabinet to receive the king s message There prevailed as we have said such a silence in the chambers and throughout the attendance that from the diningroom could be heard the voice of Fouquet saying That is well monsieur This voice was however broken by fatigue and trembled with emotion An instant after Fouquet called Gourville who crossed the gallery amidst the universal expectation At length he himself reappeared among his guests but it was no longer the same pale spiritless countenance they had beheld when he left them from pale he had become livid and from spiritless annihilated A breathing living specter he advanced with his arms stretched out his mouth parched like a shade that comes to salute the friends of former days On seeing him thus every one cried out and every one rushed towards Fouquet The latter looking at Pelisson leaned upon his wife and pressed the icy hand of the Marquise de Belliere

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Well, said he, in a voice which had nothing human in it.
children.prevalue: Well said he in a voice which had nothing human in it

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: What has happened, my God! said some one to him.
children.prevalue: What has happened my God said some one to him

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Fouquet opened his right hand, which was clenched, but glistening with perspiration, and displayed a paper, upon which Pelisson cast a terrified glance. He read the following lines, written by the king's hand:
children.prevalue: Fouquet opened his right hand which was clenched but glistening with perspiration and displayed a paper upon which Pelisson cast a terrified glance He read the following lines written by the king s hand

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: 'DEAR AND WELLBELOVED MONSIEUR FOUQUET,Give us, upon that which you have left of ours, the sum of seven hundred thousand livres, of which we stand in need to prepare for our departure.
children.prevalue: DEAR AND WELLBELOVED MONSIEUR FOUQUET Give us upon that which you have left of ours the sum of seven hundred thousand livres of which we stand in need to prepare for our departure

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: 'And, as we know your health is not good, we pray God to restore you, and to have you in His holy keeping. 'LOUIS.
children.prevalue: And as we know your health is not good we pray God to restore you and to have you in His holy keeping LOUIS

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: 'The present letter is to serve as a receipt.'
children.prevalue: The present letter is to serve as a receipt

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: A murmur of terror circulated through the apartment.
children.prevalue: A murmur of terror circulated through the apartment

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Well, cried Pelisson, in his turn, you have received that letter?
children.prevalue: Well cried Pelisson in his turn you have received that letter

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Received it, yes!
children.prevalue: Received it yes

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: What will you do, then?
children.prevalue: What will you do then

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Nothing, since I have received it.
children.prevalue: Nothing since I have received it

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: But
children.prevalue: But

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: If I have received it, Pelisson, I have paid it, said the surintendant, with a simplicity that went to the heart of all present.
children.prevalue: If I have received it Pelisson I have paid it said the surintendant with a simplicity that went to the heart of all present

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: You have paid it! cried Madame Fouquet. Then we are ruined!
children.prevalue: You have paid it cried Madame Fouquet Then we are ruined

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Come, no useless words, interrupted Pelisson. Next to money, life. Monseigneur, to horse! to horse!
children.prevalue: Come no useless words interrupted Pelisson Next to money life Monseigneur to horse to horse

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: What, leave us! at once cried both the women, wild with grief.
children.prevalue: What leave us at once cried both the women wild with grief

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Eh! monseigneur, in saving yourself, you save us all. To horse!
children.prevalue: Eh monseigneur in saving yourself you save us all To horse

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: But he cannot hold himself on. Look at him.
children.prevalue: But he cannot hold himself on Look at him

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Oh! if he takes time to reflect said the intrepid Pelisson.
children.prevalue: Oh if he takes time to reflect said the intrepid Pelisson

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: He is right, murmured Fouquet.
children.prevalue: He is right murmured Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Monseigneur! Monseigneur! cried Gourville, rushing up the stairs, four steps at once. Monseigneur!
children.prevalue: Monseigneur Monseigneur cried Gourville rushing up the stairs four steps at once Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Well! what?
children.prevalue: Well what

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: I escorted, as you desired, the king's courier with the money.
children.prevalue: I escorted as you desired the king s courier with the money

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Well! when I arrived at the Palais Royal, I saw
children.prevalue: Well when I arrived at the Palais Royal I saw

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Take breath, my poor friend, take breath you are suffocating.
children.prevalue: Take breath my poor friend take breath you are suffocating

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: What did you see? cried the impatient friends.
children.prevalue: What did you see cried the impatient friends

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: I saw the musketeers mounting on horseback, said Gourville.
children.prevalue: I saw the musketeers mounting on horseback said Gourville

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: There, then! cried every voice at once there, then! is there an instant to be lost?
children.prevalue: There then cried every voice at once there then is there an instant to be lost

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: Madame Fouquet rushed downstairs, calling for her horses Madame de Belliere flew after her, catching her in her arms, and saying: Madame, in the name of his safety, do not betray anything, do not manifest alarm.
children.prevalue: Madame Fouquet rushed downstairs calling for her horses Madame de Belliere flew after her catching her in her arms and saying Madame in the name of his safety do not betray anything do not manifest alarm

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Pelisson ran to have the horses put to the carriages. And, in the meantime, Gourville gathered in his hat all that the weeping friends were able to throw into it of gold and silverthe last offering, the pious alms made to misery by poverty. The surintendant, dragged along by some, carried by others, was shut up in his carriage. Gourville took the reins, and mounted the box. Pelisson supported Madame Fouquet, who had fainted. Madame de Belliere had more strength, and was well paid for it she received Fouquet's last kiss. Pelisson easily explained this precipitate departure by saying that an order from the king had summoned the minister to Nantes.
children.prevalue: Pelisson ran to have the horses put to the carriages And in the meantime Gourville gathered in his hat all that the weeping friends were able to throw into it of gold and silverthe last offering the pious alms made to misery by poverty The surintendant dragged along by some carried by others was shut up in his carriage Gourville took the reins and mounted the box Pelisson supported Madame Fouquet who had fainted Madame de Belliere had more strength and was well paid for it she received Fouquet s last kiss Pelisson easily explained this precipitate departure by saying that an order from the king had summoned the minister to Nantes

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: As Gourville had seen, the king's musketeers were mounting and following their captain. The latter, who did not like to be confined in his proceedings, left his brigade under the orders of a lieutenant, and set off on post horses, recommending his men to use all diligence. However rapidly they might travel, they could not arrive before him. He had time, in passing along the Rue des PetitsChamps, to see something which afforded him plenty of food for thought and conjecture. He saw M. Colbert coming out from his house to get into his carriage, which was stationed before the door. In this carriage D'Artagnan perceived the hoods of two women, and being rather curious, he wished to know the names of the ladies hid beneath these hoods. To get a glimpse at them, for they kept themselves closely covered up, he urged his horse so near the carriage, that he drove him against the step with such force as to shake everything containing and contained. The terrified women uttered, the one a faint cry, by which D'Artagnan recognized a young woman, the other an imprecation, in which he recognized the vigor and aplomb that half a century bestows. The hoods were thrown back: one of the women was Madame Vanel, the other the Duchesse de Chevreuse. D'Artagnan's eyes were quicker than those of the ladies he had seen and known them, whilst they did not recognize him and as they laughed at their fright, pressing each other's hands,
children.prevalue: As Gourville had seen the king s musketeers were mounting and following their captain The latter who did not like to be confined in his proceedings left his brigade under the orders of a lieutenant and set off on post horses recommending his men to use all diligence However rapidly they might travel they could not arrive before him He had time in passing along the Rue des PetitsChamps to see something which afforded him plenty of food for thought and conjecture He saw M Colbert coming out from his house to get into his carriage which was stationed before the door In this carriage D Artagnan perceived the hoods of two women and being rather curious he wished to know the names of the ladies hid beneath these hoods To get a glimpse at them for they kept themselves closely covered up he urged his horse so near the carriage that he drove him against the step with such force as to shake everything containing and contained The terrified women uttered the one a faint cry by which D Artagnan recognized a young woman the other an imprecation in which he recognized the vigor and aplomb that half a century bestows The hoods were thrown back one of the women was Madame Vanel the other the Duchesse de Chevreuse D Artagnan s eyes were quicker than those of the ladies he had seen and known them whilst they did not recognize him and as they laughed at their fright pressing each other s hands

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Humph! said D'Artagnan, the old duchesse is no more inaccessible to friendship than formerly. She paying her court to the mistress of M. Colbert! Poor M. Fouquet! that presages you nothing good!
children.prevalue: Humph said D Artagnan the old duchesse is no more inaccessible to friendship than formerly She paying her court to the mistress of M Colbert Poor M Fouquet that presages you nothing good

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: He rode on. M. Colbert got into his carriage and the distinguished trio commenced a sufficiently slow pilgrimage toward the wood of Vincennes. Madame de Chevreuse set down Madame Vanel at her husband's house, and, left alone with M. Colbert, chatted upon affairs whilst continuing her ride. She had an inexhaustible fund of conversation, that dear duchesse, and as she always talked for the ill of others, though ever with a view to her own good, her conversation amused her interlocutor, and did not fail to leave a favorable impression.
children.prevalue: He rode on M Colbert got into his carriage and the distinguished trio commenced a sufficiently slow pilgrimage toward the wood of Vincennes Madame de Chevreuse set down Madame Vanel at her husband s house and left alone with M Colbert chatted upon affairs whilst continuing her ride She had an inexhaustible fund of conversation that dear duchesse and as she always talked for the ill of others though ever with a view to her own good her conversation amused her interlocutor and did not fail to leave a favorable impression

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: She taught Colbert, who, poor man! was ignorant of the fact, how great a minister he was, and how Fouquet would soon become a cipher. She promised to rally around him, when he should become surintendant, all the old nobility of the kingdom, and questioned him as to the preponderance it would be proper to allow La Valliere. She praised him, she blamed him, she bewildered him. She showed him the secret of so many secrets that, for a moment, Colbert thought he was doing business with the devil. She proved to him that she held in her hand the Colbert of today, as she had held the Fouquet of yesterday and as he asked her very simply the reason of her hatred for the surintendant: Why do you yourself hate him? said she.
children.prevalue: She taught Colbert who poor man was ignorant of the fact how great a minister he was and how Fouquet would soon become a cipher She promised to rally around him when he should become surintendant all the old nobility of the kingdom and questioned him as to the preponderance it would be proper to allow La Valliere She praised him she blamed him she bewildered him She showed him the secret of so many secrets that for a moment Colbert thought he was doing business with the devil She proved to him that she held in her hand the Colbert of today as she had held the Fouquet of yesterday and as he asked her very simply the reason of her hatred for the surintendant Why do you yourself hate him said she

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Madame, in politics, replied he, the differences of system oft bring about dissentions between men. M. Fouquet always appeared to me to practice a system opposed to the true interests of the king.
children.prevalue: Madame in politics replied he the differences of system oft bring about dissentions between men M Fouquet always appeared to me to practice a system opposed to the true interests of the king

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: She interrupted him.I will say no more to you about M. Fouquet. The journey the king is about to take to Nantes will give a good account of him. M. Fouquet, for me, is a man gone byand for you also.
children.prevalue: She interrupted him I will say no more to you about M Fouquet The journey the king is about to take to Nantes will give a good account of him M Fouquet for me is a man gone byand for you also

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Colbert made no reply. On his return from Nantes, continued the duchesse, the king, who is only anxious for a pretext, will find that the States have not behaved wellthat they have made too few sacrifices. The States will say that the imposts are too heavy, and that the surintendant has ruined them. The king will lay all the blame on M. Fouquet, and then
children.prevalue: Colbert made no reply On his return from Nantes continued the duchesse the king who is only anxious for a pretext will find that the States have not behaved wellthat they have made too few sacrifices The States will say that the imposts are too heavy and that the surintendant has ruined them The king will lay all the blame on M Fouquet and then

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: And then? said Colbert.
children.prevalue: And then said Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Oh! he will be disgraced. Is not that your opinion?
children.prevalue: Oh he will be disgraced Is not that your opinion

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Colbert darted a glance at the duchesse, which plainly said: If M. Fouquet be only disgraced, you will not be the cause of it.
children.prevalue: Colbert darted a glance at the duchesse which plainly said If M Fouquet be only disgraced you will not be the cause of it

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Your place, M. Colbert, the duchesse hastened to say, must be a high place. Do you perceive any one between the king and yourself, after the fall of M. Fouquet?
children.prevalue: Your place M Colbert the duchesse hastened to say must be a high place Do you perceive any one between the king and yourself after the fall of M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: I do not understand, said he.
children.prevalue: I do not understand said he

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: You will understand. To what does your ambition aspire?
children.prevalue: You will understand To what does your ambition aspire

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I have none.
children.prevalue: I have none

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: It was useless, then, to overthrow the superintendent, Monsieur Colbert. It was idle.
children.prevalue: It was useless then to overthrow the superintendent Monsieur Colbert It was idle

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: I had the honor to tell you, madame
children.prevalue: I had the honor to tell you madame

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Oh! yes, I know, all about the interest of the kingbut, if you please, we will speak of your own.
children.prevalue: Oh yes I know all about the interest of the kingbut if you please we will speak of your own

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Mine! that is to say, the affairs of his majesty.
children.prevalue: Mine that is to say the affairs of his majesty

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: In short, are you, or are you not endeavoring to ruin M. Fouquet? Answer without evasion.
children.prevalue: In short are you or are you not endeavoring to ruin M Fouquet Answer without evasion

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Madame, I ruin nobody.
children.prevalue: Madame I ruin nobody

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I am endeavoring to comprehend, then, why you purchased from me the letters of M. Mazarin concerning M. Fouquet. Neither can I conceive why you have laid those letters before the king.
children.prevalue: I am endeavoring to comprehend then why you purchased from me the letters of M Mazarin concerning M Fouquet Neither can I conceive why you have laid those letters before the king

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Colbert, half stupefied, looked at the duchesse with an air of constraint.
children.prevalue: Colbert half stupefied looked at the duchesse with an air of constraint

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Madame, said he, I can less easily conceive how you, who received the money, can reproach me on that head
children.prevalue: Madame said he I can less easily conceive how you who received the money can reproach me on that head

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: That is, said the old duchesse, because we must will that which we wish for, unless we are not able to obtain what we wish.
children.prevalue: That is said the old duchesse because we must will that which we wish for unless we are not able to obtain what we wish

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Will! said Colbert, quite confounded by such coarse logic.
children.prevalue: Will said Colbert quite confounded by such coarse logic

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: You are not able, hein! Speak.
children.prevalue: You are not able hein Speak

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I am not able, I allow, to destroy certain influences near the king.
children.prevalue: I am not able I allow to destroy certain influences near the king

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: That fight in favor of M. Fouquet? What are they? Stop, let me help you.
children.prevalue: That fight in favor of M Fouquet What are they Stop let me help you

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Do, madame.
children.prevalue: Do madame

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: La Valliere?
children.prevalue: La Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Oh! very little influence no knowledge of business, and small means. M. Fouquet has paid his court to her.
children.prevalue: Oh very little influence no knowledge of business and small means M Fouquet has paid his court to her

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: To defend him would be to accuse herself, would it not?
children.prevalue: To defend him would be to accuse herself would it not

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I think it would.
children.prevalue: I think it would

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: There is still another influence, what do you say to that?
children.prevalue: There is still another influence what do you say to that

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Is it considerable?
children.prevalue: Is it considerable

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The queenmother, perhaps?
children.prevalue: The queenmother perhaps

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Her majesty, the queenmother, has a weakness for M. Fouquet very prejudicial to her son.
children.prevalue: Her majesty the queenmother has a weakness for M Fouquet very prejudicial to her son

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Never believe that, said the old duchesse, smiling.
children.prevalue: Never believe that said the old duchesse smiling

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Oh! said Colbert, with incredulity, I have often experienced it.
children.prevalue: Oh said Colbert with incredulity I have often experienced it

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Formerly?
children.prevalue: Formerly

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Very recently, madame, at Vaux. It was she who prevented the king from having M. Fouquet arrested.
children.prevalue: Very recently madame at Vaux It was she who prevented the king from having M Fouquet arrested

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: People do not forever entertain the same opinions, my dear monsieur. That which the queen may have wished recently, she would not wish, perhaps, today.
children.prevalue: People do not forever entertain the same opinions my dear monsieur That which the queen may have wished recently she would not wish perhaps today

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: And why not? said Colbert, astonished.
children.prevalue: And why not said Colbert astonished

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Oh! the reason is of very little consequence.
children.prevalue: Oh the reason is of very little consequence

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: On the contrary, I think it is of great consequence for, if I were certain of not displeasing her majesty, the queenmother, my scruples would be all removed.
children.prevalue: On the contrary I think it is of great consequence for if I were certain of not displeasing her majesty the queenmother my scruples would be all removed

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Well! have you never heard talk of a certain secret?
children.prevalue: Well have you never heard talk of a certain secret

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: A secret?
children.prevalue: A secret

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Call it what you like. In short, the queenmother has conceived a bitter hatred for all those who have participated, in one fashion or another, in the discovery of this secret, and M. Fouquet I believe is one of these.
children.prevalue: Call it what you like In short the queenmother has conceived a bitter hatred for all those who have participated in one fashion or another in the discovery of this secret and M Fouquet I believe is one of these

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Then, said Colbert, we may be sure of the assent of the queenmother?
children.prevalue: Then said Colbert we may be sure of the assent of the queenmother

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I have just left her majesty, and she assures me so.
children.prevalue: I have just left her majesty and she assures me so

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: So be it, then, madame.
children.prevalue: So be it then madame

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: But there is something further do you happen to know a man who was the intimate friend of M. Fouquet, M. d'Herblay, a bishop, I believe?
children.prevalue: But there is something further do you happen to know a man who was the intimate friend of M Fouquet M d Herblay a bishop I believe

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Bishop of Vannes.
children.prevalue: Bishop of Vannes

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Well! this M. d'Herblay, who also knew the secret, the queenmother is pursuing with the utmost rancor.
children.prevalue: Well this M d Herblay who also knew the secret the queenmother is pursuing with the utmost rancor

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Indeed!
children.prevalue: Indeed

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: So hotly pursued, that if he were dead, she would not be satisfied with anything less than his head, to satisfy her he would never speak again.
children.prevalue: So hotly pursued that if he were dead she would not be satisfied with anything less than his head to satisfy her he would never speak again

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: And is that the desire of the queenmother?
children.prevalue: And is that the desire of the queenmother

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: An order is given for it.
children.prevalue: An order is given for it

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: This Monsieur d'Herblay shall be sought for, madame.
children.prevalue: This Monsieur d Herblay shall be sought for madame

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Oh! it is well known where he is.
children.prevalue: Oh it is well known where he is

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Colbert looked at the duchesse.
children.prevalue: Colbert looked at the duchesse

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Say where, madame.
children.prevalue: Say where madame

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: He is at BelleIleenMer.
children.prevalue: He is at BelleIleenMer

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: At the residence of M. Fouquet?
children.prevalue: At the residence of M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: At the residence of M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: At the residence of M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: He shall be taken.
children.prevalue: He shall be taken

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: It was now the duchesse's turn to smile. Do not fancy the capture so easy, said she do not promise it so lightly.
children.prevalue: It was now the duchesse s turn to smile Do not fancy the capture so easy said she do not promise it so lightly

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Why not, madame?
children.prevalue: Why not madame

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Because M. d'Herblay is not one of those people who can be taken when and where you please.
children.prevalue: Because M d Herblay is not one of those people who can be taken when and where you please

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: He is a rebel, then?
children.prevalue: He is a rebel then

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Oh! Monsieur Colbert, we have passed all our lives in making rebels, and yet you see plainly, that so far from being taken, we take others.
children.prevalue: Oh Monsieur Colbert we have passed all our lives in making rebels and yet you see plainly that so far from being taken we take others

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Colbert fixed upon the old duchesse one of those fierce looks of which no words can convey the expression, accompanied by a firmness not altogether wanting in grandeur. The times are gone, said he, in which subjects gained duchies by making war against the king of France. If M. d'Herblay conspires, he will perish on the scaffold. That will give, or will not give, pleasure to his enemies,a matter, by the way, of little importance to us.
children.prevalue: Colbert fixed upon the old duchesse one of those fierce looks of which no words can convey the expression accompanied by a firmness not altogether wanting in grandeur The times are gone said he in which subjects gained duchies by making war against the king of France If M d Herblay conspires he will perish on the scaffold That will give or will not give pleasure to his enemies a matter by the way of little importance to us

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: And this us, a strange word in the mouth of Colbert, made the duchesse thoughtful for a moment. She caught herself reckoning inwardly with this manColbert had regained his superiority in the conversation, and he meant to keep it.
children.prevalue: And this us a strange word in the mouth of Colbert made the duchesse thoughtful for a moment She caught herself reckoning inwardly with this manColbert had regained his superiority in the conversation and he meant to keep it

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: You ask me, madame, he said, to have this M. d'Herblay arrested?
children.prevalue: You ask me madame he said to have this M d Herblay arrested

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I?I ask you nothing of the kind!
children.prevalue: I I ask you nothing of the kind

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: I thought you did, madame. But as I have been mistaken, we will leave him alone the king has said nothing about him.
children.prevalue: I thought you did madame But as I have been mistaken we will leave him alone the king has said nothing about him

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: The duchesse bit her nails.
children.prevalue: The duchesse bit her nails

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Besides, continued Colbert, what a poor capture would this bishop be! A bishop game for a king! Oh! no, no I will not even take the slightest notice of him.
children.prevalue: Besides continued Colbert what a poor capture would this bishop be A bishop game for a king Oh no no I will not even take the slightest notice of him

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: The hatred of the duchesse now discovered itself.
children.prevalue: The hatred of the duchesse now discovered itself

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Game for a woman! said she. Is not the queen a woman? If she wishes M. d'Herblay arrested, she has her reasons. Besides, is not M. d'Herblay the friend of him who is doomed to fall?
children.prevalue: Game for a woman said she Is not the queen a woman If she wishes M d Herblay arrested she has her reasons Besides is not M d Herblay the friend of him who is doomed to fall

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Oh! never mind that, said Colbert. This man shall be spared, if he is not the enemy of the king. Is that displeasing to you?
children.prevalue: Oh never mind that said Colbert This man shall be spared if he is not the enemy of the king Is that displeasing to you

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: I say nothing.
children.prevalue: I say nothing

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Yesyou wish to see him in prison, in the Bastile, for instance.
children.prevalue: Yesyou wish to see him in prison in the Bastile for instance

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: I believe a secret better concealed behind the walls of the Bastile than behind those of BelleIsle.
children.prevalue: I believe a secret better concealed behind the walls of the Bastile than behind those of BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: I will speak to the king about it he will clear up the point.
children.prevalue: I will speak to the king about it he will clear up the point

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: And whilst waiting for that enlightenment, Monsieur l'Eveque de Vannes will have escaped. I would do so.
children.prevalue: And whilst waiting for that enlightenment Monsieur l Eveque de Vannes will have escaped I would do so

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Escaped! he! and whither should he escape? Europe is ours, in will, if not in fact.
children.prevalue: Escaped he and whither should he escape Europe is ours in will if not in fact

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: He will always find an asylum, monsieur. It is evident you know nothing of the man you have to do with. You do not know D'Herblay you do not know Aramis. He was one of those four musketeers who, under the late king, made Cardinal de Richelieu tremble, and who, during the regency, gave so much trouble to Monseigneur Mazarin.
children.prevalue: He will always find an asylum monsieur It is evident you know nothing of the man you have to do with You do not know D Herblay you do not know Aramis He was one of those four musketeers who under the late king made Cardinal de Richelieu tremble and who during the regency gave so much trouble to Monseigneur Mazarin

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: But, madame, what can he do, unless he has a kingdom to back him?
children.prevalue: But madame what can he do unless he has a kingdom to back him

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: He has one, monsieur.
children.prevalue: He has one monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: A kingdom, he! what, Monsieur d'Herblay?
children.prevalue: A kingdom he what Monsieur d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: I repeat to you, monsieur, that if he wants a kingdom, he either has it or will have it.
children.prevalue: I repeat to you monsieur that if he wants a kingdom he either has it or will have it

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Well, as you are so earnest that this rebel should not escape, madame, I promise you he shall not escape.
children.prevalue: Well as you are so earnest that this rebel should not escape madame I promise you he shall not escape

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: BelleIsle is fortified, M. Colbert, and fortified by him.
children.prevalue: BelleIsle is fortified M Colbert and fortified by him

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: If BelleIsle were also defended by him, BelleIsle is not impregnable and if Monsieur l'Eveque de Vannes is shut up in BelleIsle, well, madame, the place shall be besieged, and he will be taken.
children.prevalue: If BelleIsle were also defended by him BelleIsle is not impregnable and if Monsieur l Eveque de Vannes is shut up in BelleIsle well madame the place shall be besieged and he will be taken

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: You may be very certain, monsieur, that the zeal you display in the interest of the queenmother will please her majesty mightily, and you will be magnificently rewarded but what shall I tell her of your projects respecting this man?
children.prevalue: You may be very certain monsieur that the zeal you display in the interest of the queenmother will please her majesty mightily and you will be magnificently rewarded but what shall I tell her of your projects respecting this man

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: That when once taken, he shall be shut up in a fortress from which her secret shall never escape.
children.prevalue: That when once taken he shall be shut up in a fortress from which her secret shall never escape

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Very well, Monsieur Colbert, and we may say, that, dating from this instant, we have formed a solid alliance, that is, you and I, and that I am absolutely at your service.
children.prevalue: Very well Monsieur Colbert and we may say that dating from this instant we have formed a solid alliance that is you and I and that I am absolutely at your service

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: It is I, madame, who place myself at yours. This Chevalier d'Herblay is a kind of Spanish spy, is he not?
children.prevalue: It is I madame who place myself at yours This Chevalier d Herblay is a kind of Spanish spy is he not

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Much more.
children.prevalue: Much more

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: A secret ambassador?
children.prevalue: A secret ambassador

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Higher still.
children.prevalue: Higher still

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: StopKing Phillip III. of Spain is a bigot. He is, perhaps, the confessor of Phillip III.
children.prevalue: StopKing Phillip III of Spain is a bigot He is perhaps the confessor of Phillip III

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: You must go higher even than that.
children.prevalue: You must go higher even than that

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Mordieu! cried Colbert, who forgot himself so far as to swear in the presence of this great lady, of this old friend of the queenmother. He must then be the general of the Jesuits.
children.prevalue: Mordieu cried Colbert who forgot himself so far as to swear in the presence of this great lady of this old friend of the queenmother He must then be the general of the Jesuits

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: I believe you have guessed it at last, replied the duchesse.
children.prevalue: I believe you have guessed it at last replied the duchesse

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Ah! then, madame, this man will ruin us all if we do not ruin him and we must make haste, too.
children.prevalue: Ah then madame this man will ruin us all if we do not ruin him and we must make haste too

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Such was my opinion, monsieur, but I did not dare to give it you.
children.prevalue: Such was my opinion monsieur but I did not dare to give it you

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: And it was lucky for us he has attacked the throne, and not us.
children.prevalue: And it was lucky for us he has attacked the throne and not us

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: But, mark this well, M. Colbert. M. d'Herblay is never discouraged if he has missed one blow, he will be sure to make another he will begin again. If he has allowed an opportunity to escape of making a king for himself, sooner or later, he will make another, of whom, to a certainty, you will not be prime minister.
children.prevalue: But mark this well M Colbert M d Herblay is never discouraged if he has missed one blow he will be sure to make another he will begin again If he has allowed an opportunity to escape of making a king for himself sooner or later he will make another of whom to a certainty you will not be prime minister

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Colbert knitted his brow with a menacing expression. I feel assured that a prison will settle this affair for us, madame, in a manner satisfactory for both.
children.prevalue: Colbert knitted his brow with a menacing expression I feel assured that a prison will settle this affair for us madame in a manner satisfactory for both

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: The duchesse smiled again.
children.prevalue: The duchesse smiled again

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Oh! if you knew, said she, how many times Aramis has got out of prison!
children.prevalue: Oh if you knew said she how many times Aramis has got out of prison

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Oh! replied Colbert, we will take care that he shall not get out this time.
children.prevalue: Oh replied Colbert we will take care that he shall not get out this time

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: But you were not attending to what I said to you just now. Do you remember that Aramis was one of the four invincibles whom Richelieu so dreaded? And at that period the four musketeers were not in possession of that which they have nowmoney and experience.
children.prevalue: But you were not attending to what I said to you just now Do you remember that Aramis was one of the four invincibles whom Richelieu so dreaded And at that period the four musketeers were not in possession of that which they have nowmoney and experience

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Colbert bit his lips.
children.prevalue: Colbert bit his lips

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: We will renounce the idea of the prison, said he, in a lower tone: we will find a little retreat from which the invincible cannot possibly escape.
children.prevalue: We will renounce the idea of the prison said he in a lower tone we will find a little retreat from which the invincible cannot possibly escape

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: That was well spoken, our ally! replied the duchesse. But it is getting late had we not better return?
children.prevalue: That was well spoken our ally replied the duchesse But it is getting late had we not better return

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: The more willingly, madame, from my having my preparations to make for setting out with the king.
children.prevalue: The more willingly madame from my having my preparations to make for setting out with the king

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: To Paris! cried the duchesse to the coachman.
children.prevalue: To Paris cried the duchesse to the coachman

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: And the carriage returned towards the Faubourg Saint Antoine, after the conclusion of the treaty that gave to death the last friend of Fouquet, the last defender of BelleIsle, the former friend of Marie Michon, the new foe of the old duchesse.
children.prevalue: And the carriage returned towards the Faubourg Saint Antoine after the conclusion of the treaty that gave to death the last friend of Fouquet the last defender of BelleIsle the former friend of Marie Michon the new foe of the old duchesse

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: D'Artagnan had set off Fouquet likewise was gone, and with a rapidity which doubled the tender interest of his friends. The first moments of this journey, or better say, this flight, were troubled by a ceaseless dread of every horse and carriage to be seen behind the fugitive. It was not natural, in fact, if Louis XIV. was determined to seize this prey, that he should allow it to escape the young lion was already accustomed to the chase, and he had bloodhounds sufficiently clever to be trusted. But insensibly all fears were dispersed the surintendant, by hard traveling, placed such a distance between himself and his persecutors, that no one of them could reasonably be expected to overtake him. As to his position, his friends had made it excellent for him. Was he not traveling to join the king at Nantes, and what did the rapidity prove but his zeal to obey? He arrived, fatigued, but reassured, at Orleans, where he found, thanks to the care of a courier who had preceded him, a handsome lighter of eight oars. These lighters, in the shape of gondolas, somewhat wide and heavy, containing a small chamber, covered by the deck, and a chamber in the poop, formed by a tent, then acted as passageboats from Orleans to Nantes, by the Loire, and this passage, a long one in our days, appeared then more easy and convenient than the highroad, with its posthacks and its illhung carriages. Fouquet went on board this lighter, which set out immediately. The rowers, knowing they had the honor of conveying the surintendant of the finances, pulled with all their strength, and that magic word, the finances, promised them a liberal gratification, of which they wished to prove themselves worthy. The lighter seemed to leap the mimic waves of the Loire. Magnificent weather, a sunrise that empurpled all the landscape, displayed the river in all its limpid serenity. The current and the rowers carried Fouquet along as wings carry a bird, and he arrived before Beaugency without the slightest accident having signalized the voyage. Fouquet hoped to be the first to arrive at Nantes there he would see the notables and gain support among the principal members of the States he would make himself a necessity, a thing very easy for a man of his merit, and would delay the catastrophe, if he did not succeed in avoiding it entirely. Besides, said Gourville to him, at Nantes, you will make out, or we will make out, the intentions of your enemies we will have horses always ready to convey you to Poitou, a bark in which to gain the sea, and when once upon the open sea, BelleIsle is your inviolable port. You see, besides, that no one is watching you, no one is following. He had scarcely finished when they discovered at a distance, behind an elbow formed by the river, the masts of a huge lighter coming down. The rowers of Fouquet's boat uttered a cry of surprise on seeing this galley.
