children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: What is the matter? asked Fouquet.
children.prevalue: What is the matter asked Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The matter is, monseigneur, replied the patron of the bark, that it is a truly remarkable thingthat lighter comes along like a hurricane.
children.prevalue: The matter is monseigneur replied the patron of the bark that it is a truly remarkable thingthat lighter comes along like a hurricane

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Gourville started, and mounted to the deck, in order to obtain a better view.
children.prevalue: Gourville started and mounted to the deck in order to obtain a better view

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Fouquet did not go up with him, but said to Gourville, with restrained mistrust: See what it is, dear friend.
children.prevalue: Fouquet did not go up with him but said to Gourville with restrained mistrust See what it is dear friend

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The lighter had just passed the elbow. It came on so fast, that behind it might be plainly seen the white wake illumined with the fires of the day.
children.prevalue: The lighter had just passed the elbow It came on so fast that behind it might be plainly seen the white wake illumined with the fires of the day

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: How they go, repeated the skipper, how they go! They must be well paid! I did not think, he added, that oars of wood could behave better than ours, but yonder oarsmen prove the contrary.
children.prevalue: How they go repeated the skipper how they go They must be well paid I did not think he added that oars of wood could behave better than ours but yonder oarsmen prove the contrary

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Well they may, said one of the rowers, they are twelve, and we but eight.
children.prevalue: Well they may said one of the rowers they are twelve and we but eight

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Twelve rowers! replied Gourville, twelve! impossible.
children.prevalue: Twelve rowers replied Gourville twelve impossible

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: The number of eight rowers for a lighter had never been exceeded, even for the king. This honor had been paid to monsieur le surintendant, more for the sake of haste than of respect.
children.prevalue: The number of eight rowers for a lighter had never been exceeded even for the king This honor had been paid to monsieur le surintendant more for the sake of haste than of respect

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: What does it mean? said Gourville, endeavoring to distinguish beneath the tent, which was already apparent, travelers which the most piercing eye could not yet have succeeded in discovering.
children.prevalue: What does it mean said Gourville endeavoring to distinguish beneath the tent which was already apparent travelers which the most piercing eye could not yet have succeeded in discovering

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: They must be in a hurry, for it is not the king, said the patron.
children.prevalue: They must be in a hurry for it is not the king said the patron

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Fouquet shuddered.
children.prevalue: Fouquet shuddered

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: By what sign do you know that it is not the king? said Gourville.
children.prevalue: By what sign do you know that it is not the king said Gourville

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: In the first place, because there is no white flag with fleursdelis, which the royal lighter always carries.
children.prevalue: In the first place because there is no white flag with fleursdelis which the royal lighter always carries

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: And then, said Fouquet, because it is impossible it should be the king, Gourville, as the king was still in Paris yesterday.
children.prevalue: And then said Fouquet because it is impossible it should be the king Gourville as the king was still in Paris yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Gourville replied to the surintendant by a look which said: You were there yourself yesterday.
children.prevalue: Gourville replied to the surintendant by a look which said You were there yourself yesterday

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: And by what sign do you make out they are in such haste? added he, for the sake of gaining time.
children.prevalue: And by what sign do you make out they are in such haste added he for the sake of gaining time

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: By this, monsieur, said the patron these people must have set out a long while after us, and they have already nearly overtaken us.
children.prevalue: By this monsieur said the patron these people must have set out a long while after us and they have already nearly overtaken us

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Bah! said Gourville, who told you that they do not come from Beaugency or from Moit even?
children.prevalue: Bah said Gourville who told you that they do not come from Beaugency or from Moit even

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: We have seen no lighter of that shape, except at Orleans. It comes from Orleans, monsieur, and makes great haste.
children.prevalue: We have seen no lighter of that shape except at Orleans It comes from Orleans monsieur and makes great haste

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Fouquet and Gourville exchanged a glance. The captain remarked their uneasiness, and, to mislead him, Gourville immediately said:
children.prevalue: Fouquet and Gourville exchanged a glance The captain remarked their uneasiness and to mislead him Gourville immediately said

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Some friend, who has laid a wager he would catch us let us win the wager, and not allow him to come up with us.
children.prevalue: Some friend who has laid a wager he would catch us let us win the wager and not allow him to come up with us

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The patron opened his mouth to say that it was quite impossible, but Fouquet said with much hauteur,If it is any one who wishes to overtake us, let him come.
children.prevalue: The patron opened his mouth to say that it was quite impossible but Fouquet said with much hauteur If it is any one who wishes to overtake us let him come

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: We can try, monseigneur, said the man, timidly. Come, you fellows, put out your strength row, row!
children.prevalue: We can try monseigneur said the man timidly Come you fellows put out your strength row row

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: No, said Fouquet, on the contrary stop short.
children.prevalue: No said Fouquet on the contrary stop short

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Monseigneur! what folly! interrupted Gourville, stooping towards his ear.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur what folly interrupted Gourville stooping towards his ear

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Pull up! repeated Fouquet. The eight oars stopped, and resisting the water, created a retrograde motion. It stopped. The twelve rowers in the other did not, at first, perceive this maneuver, for they continued to urge on their boat so vigorously that it arrived quickly within musketshot. Fouquet was shortsighted, Gourville was annoyed by the sun, now full in his eyes the skipper alone, with that habit and clearness which are acquired by a constant struggle with the elements, perceived distinctly the travelers in the neighboring lighter.
children.prevalue: Pull up repeated Fouquet The eight oars stopped and resisting the water created a retrograde motion It stopped The twelve rowers in the other did not at first perceive this maneuver for they continued to urge on their boat so vigorously that it arrived quickly within musketshot Fouquet was shortsighted Gourville was annoyed by the sun now full in his eyes the skipper alone with that habit and clearness which are acquired by a constant struggle with the elements perceived distinctly the travelers in the neighboring lighter

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I can see them! cried he there are two.
children.prevalue: I can see them cried he there are two

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I can see nothing, said Gourville.
children.prevalue: I can see nothing said Gourville

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: You will not be long before you distinguish them in twenty strokes of their oars they will be within ten paces of us.
children.prevalue: You will not be long before you distinguish them in twenty strokes of their oars they will be within ten paces of us

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: But what the patron announced was not realized the lighter imitated the movement commanded by Fouquet, and instead of coming to join its pretended friends, it stopped short in the middle of the river.
children.prevalue: But what the patron announced was not realized the lighter imitated the movement commanded by Fouquet and instead of coming to join its pretended friends it stopped short in the middle of the river

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I cannot comprehend this, said the captain.
children.prevalue: I cannot comprehend this said the captain

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Nor I, cried Gourville.
children.prevalue: Nor I cried Gourville

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: You who can see so plainly the people in that lighter, resumed Fouquet, try to describe them to us, before we are too far off.
children.prevalue: You who can see so plainly the people in that lighter resumed Fouquet try to describe them to us before we are too far off

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I thought I saw two, replied the boatman. I can only see one now, under the tent.
children.prevalue: I thought I saw two replied the boatman I can only see one now under the tent

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: What sort of man is he?
children.prevalue: What sort of man is he

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: He is a dark man, broadshouldered, bullnecked.
children.prevalue: He is a dark man broadshouldered bullnecked

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: A little cloud at that moment passed across the azure, darkening the sun. Gourville, who was still looking, with one hand over his eyes, became able to see what he sought, and all at once, jumping from the deck into the chamber where Fouquet awaited him: Colbert! said he, in a voice broken by emotion.
children.prevalue: A little cloud at that moment passed across the azure darkening the sun Gourville who was still looking with one hand over his eyes became able to see what he sought and all at once jumping from the deck into the chamber where Fouquet awaited him Colbert said he in a voice broken by emotion

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Colbert! repeated Fouquet. Too strange! but no, it is impossible!
children.prevalue: Colbert repeated Fouquet Too strange but no it is impossible

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I tell you I recognized him, and he, at the same time, so plainly recognized me, that he is just gone into the chamber on the poop. Perhaps the king has sent him on our track.
children.prevalue: I tell you I recognized him and he at the same time so plainly recognized me that he is just gone into the chamber on the poop Perhaps the king has sent him on our track

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: In that case he would join us, instead of lying by. What is he doing there?
children.prevalue: In that case he would join us instead of lying by What is he doing there

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: He is watching us, without a doubt.
children.prevalue: He is watching us without a doubt

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: I do not like uncertainty, said Fouquet let us go straight up to him.
children.prevalue: I do not like uncertainty said Fouquet let us go straight up to him

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Oh! monseigneur, do not do that, the lighter is full of armed men.
children.prevalue: Oh monseigneur do not do that the lighter is full of armed men

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: He wishes to arrest me, then, Gourville? Why does he not come on?
children.prevalue: He wishes to arrest me then Gourville Why does he not come on

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Monseigneur, it is not consistent with your dignity to go to meet even your ruin.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur it is not consistent with your dignity to go to meet even your ruin

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: But to allow them to watch me like a malefactor!
children.prevalue: But to allow them to watch me like a malefactor

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Nothing yet proves that they are watching you, monseigneur be patient!
children.prevalue: Nothing yet proves that they are watching you monseigneur be patient

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: What is to be done, then?
children.prevalue: What is to be done then

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Do not stop you were only going so fast to appear to obey the king's order with zeal. Redouble the speed. He who lives will see!
children.prevalue: Do not stop you were only going so fast to appear to obey the king s order with zeal Redouble the speed He who lives will see

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: That is better. Come! cried Fouquet since they remain stockstill yonder, let us go on.
children.prevalue: That is better Come cried Fouquet since they remain stockstill yonder let us go on

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The captain gave the signal, and Fouquet's rowers resumed their task with all the success that could be looked for from men who had rested. Scarcely had the lighter made a hundred fathoms, than the other, that with the twelve rowers, resumed its rapid course. This position lasted all day, without any increase or diminution of distance between the two vessels. Towards evening Fouquet wished to try the intentions of his persecutor. He ordered his rowers to pull towards the shore, as if to effect a landing. Colbert's lighter imitated this maneuver, and steered towards the shore in a slanting direction. By the merest chance, at the spot where Fouquet pretended to wish to land, a stableman, from the chateau of Langeais, was following the flowery banks leading three horses in halters. Without doubt the people of the twelveoared lighter fancied that Fouquet was directing his course to these horses ready for flight, for four or five men, armed with muskets, jumped from the lighter on to the shore, and marched along the banks, as if to gain ground on the horseman. Fouquet, satisfied of having forced the enemy to a demonstration, considered his intention evident, and put his boat in motion again. Colbert's people returned likewise to theirs, and the course of the two vessels was resumed with fresh perseverance. Upon seeing this, Fouquet felt himself threatened closely, and in a prophetic voiceWell, Gourville, said he, whisperingly, what did I say at our last repast, at my house? Am I going, or not, to my ruin?
children.prevalue: The captain gave the signal and Fouquet s rowers resumed their task with all the success that could be looked for from men who had rested Scarcely had the lighter made a hundred fathoms than the other that with the twelve rowers resumed its rapid course This position lasted all day without any increase or diminution of distance between the two vessels Towards evening Fouquet wished to try the intentions of his persecutor He ordered his rowers to pull towards the shore as if to effect a landing Colbert s lighter imitated this maneuver and steered towards the shore in a slanting direction By the merest chance at the spot where Fouquet pretended to wish to land a stableman from the chateau of Langeais was following the flowery banks leading three horses in halters Without doubt the people of the twelveoared lighter fancied that Fouquet was directing his course to these horses ready for flight for four or five men armed with muskets jumped from the lighter on to the shore and marched along the banks as if to gain ground on the horseman Fouquet satisfied of having forced the enemy to a demonstration considered his intention evident and put his boat in motion again Colbert s people returned likewise to theirs and the course of the two vessels was resumed with fresh perseverance Upon seeing this Fouquet felt himself threatened closely and in a prophetic voiceWell Gourville said he whisperingly what did I say at our last repast at my house Am I going or not to my ruin

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Oh! monseigneur!
children.prevalue: Oh monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: These two boats, which follow each other with so much emulation, as if we were disputing, M. Colbert and I, a prize for swiftness on the Loire, do they not aptly represent our fortunes and do you not believe, Gourville, that one of the two will be wrecked at Nantes?
children.prevalue: These two boats which follow each other with so much emulation as if we were disputing M Colbert and I a prize for swiftness on the Loire do they not aptly represent our fortunes and do you not believe Gourville that one of the two will be wrecked at Nantes

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: At least, objected Gourville, there is still uncertainty you are about to appear at the States you are about to show what sort of man you are your eloquence and genius for business are the buckler and sword that will serve to defend you, if not to conquer with. The Bretons do not know you and when they become acquainted with you your cause is won! Oh! let M. Colbert look to it well, for his lighter is as much exposed as yours to being upset. Both go quickly, his faster than yours, it is true we shall see which will be wrecked first.
children.prevalue: At least objected Gourville there is still uncertainty you are about to appear at the States you are about to show what sort of man you are your eloquence and genius for business are the buckler and sword that will serve to defend you if not to conquer with The Bretons do not know you and when they become acquainted with you your cause is won Oh let M Colbert look to it well for his lighter is as much exposed as yours to being upset Both go quickly his faster than yours it is true we shall see which will be wrecked first

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Fouquet, taking Gourville's handMy friend, said he, everything considered, remember the proverb, 'First come, first served!' Well! M. Colbert takes care not to pass me. He is a prudent man is M. Colbert.
children.prevalue: Fouquet taking Gourville s handMy friend said he everything considered remember the proverb First come first served Well M Colbert takes care not to pass me He is a prudent man is M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: He was right the two lighters held their course as far as Nantes, watching each other. When the surintendant landed, Gourville hoped he should be able to seek refuge at once, and have the relays prepared. But, at the landing, the second lighter joined the first, and Colbert, approaching Fouquet, saluted him on the quay with marks of the profoundest respectmarks so significant, so public, that their result was the bringing of the whole population upon La Fosse. Fouquet was completely selfpossessed he felt that in his last moments of greatness he had obligations towards himself. He wished to fall from such a height that his fall should crush some of his enemies. Colbert was thereso much the worse for Colbert. The surintendant, therefore, coming up to him, replied, with that arrogant semiclosure of the eyes peculiar to himWhat! is that you, M. Colbert?
children.prevalue: He was right the two lighters held their course as far as Nantes watching each other When the surintendant landed Gourville hoped he should be able to seek refuge at once and have the relays prepared But at the landing the second lighter joined the first and Colbert approaching Fouquet saluted him on the quay with marks of the profoundest respectmarks so significant so public that their result was the bringing of the whole population upon La Fosse Fouquet was completely selfpossessed he felt that in his last moments of greatness he had obligations towards himself He wished to fall from such a height that his fall should crush some of his enemies Colbert was thereso much the worse for Colbert The surintendant therefore coming up to him replied with that arrogant semiclosure of the eyes peculiar to himWhat is that you M Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: To offer you my respects, monseigneur, said the latter.
children.prevalue: To offer you my respects monseigneur said the latter

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Were you in that lighter?pointing to the one with twelve rowers.
children.prevalue: Were you in that lighter pointing to the one with twelve rowers

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Of twelve rowers? said Fouquet what luxury, M. Colbert. For a moment I thought it was the queenmother.
children.prevalue: Of twelve rowers said Fouquet what luxury M Colbert For a moment I thought it was the queenmother

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Monseigneur!and Colbert blushed.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur and Colbert blushed

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: This is a voyage that will cost those who have to pay for it dear, Monsieur l'Intendant! said Fouquet. But you have, happily, arrived!You see, however, added he, a moment after, that I, who had but eight rowers, arrived before you. And he turned his back towards him, leaving him uncertain whether the maneuvers of the second lighter had escaped the notice of the first. At least he did not give him the satisfaction of showing that he had been frightened. Colbert, so annoyingly attacked, did not give way.
children.prevalue: This is a voyage that will cost those who have to pay for it dear Monsieur l Intendant said Fouquet But you have happily arrived You see however added he a moment after that I who had but eight rowers arrived before you And he turned his back towards him leaving him uncertain whether the maneuvers of the second lighter had escaped the notice of the first At least he did not give him the satisfaction of showing that he had been frightened Colbert so annoyingly attacked did not give way

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: I have not been quick, monseigneur, he replied, because I followed your example whenever you stopped.
children.prevalue: I have not been quick monseigneur he replied because I followed your example whenever you stopped

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: And why did you do that, Monsieur Colbert? cried Fouquet, irritated by the base audacity as you had a superior crew to mine, why did you not either join me or pass me?
children.prevalue: And why did you do that Monsieur Colbert cried Fouquet irritated by the base audacity as you had a superior crew to mine why did you not either join me or pass me

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Out of respect, said the intendant, bowing to the ground.
children.prevalue: Out of respect said the intendant bowing to the ground

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Fouquet got into a carriage which the city had sent to him, we know not why or how, and he repaired to la Maison de Nantes, escorted by a vast crowd of people, who for several days had been agog with expectation of a convocation of the States. Scarcely was he installed when Gourville went out to order horses on the route to Poitiers and Vannes, and a boat at Paimboef. He performed these various operations with so much mystery, activity, and generosity, that never was Fouquet, then laboring under an attack of fever, more nearly saved, except for the counteraction of that immense disturber of human projects,chance. A report was spread during the night, that the king was coming in great haste on post horses, and would arrive in ten or twelve hours at the latest. The people, while waiting for the king, were greatly rejoiced to see the musketeers, newly arrived, with Monsieur d'Artagnan, their captain, and quartered in the castle, of which they occupied all the posts, in quality of guard of honor. M. d'Artagnan, who was very polite, presented himself, about ten o'clock, at the lodgings of the surintendant to pay his respectful compliments and although the minister suffered from fever, although he was in such pain as to be bathed in sweat, he would receive M. d'Artagnan, who was delighted with that honor, as will be seen by the conversation they had together.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Fouquet had gone to bed, like a man who clings to life, and wishes to economize, as much as possible, that slender tissue of existence, of which the shocks and frictions of this world so quickly wear out the tenuity. D'Artagnan appeared at the door of this chamber, and was saluted by the superintendent with a very affable Good day.
children.prevalue: Fouquet had gone to bed like a man who clings to life and wishes to economize as much as possible that slender tissue of existence of which the shocks and frictions of this world so quickly wear out the tenuity D Artagnan appeared at the door of this chamber and was saluted by the superintendent with a very affable Good day

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Bon jour! monseigneur, replied the musketeer how did you get through the journey?
children.prevalue: Bon jour monseigneur replied the musketeer how did you get through the journey

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Tolerably well, thank you.
children.prevalue: Tolerably well thank you

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: And the fever?
children.prevalue: And the fever

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: But poorly. I drink, as you perceive. I am scarcely arrived, and I have already levied a contribution of tisane upon Nantes.
children.prevalue: But poorly I drink as you perceive I am scarcely arrived and I have already levied a contribution of tisane upon Nantes

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: You should sleep first, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: You should sleep first monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Eh! corbleu! my dear Monsieur d'Artagnan, I should be very glad to sleep.
children.prevalue: Eh corbleu my dear Monsieur d Artagnan I should be very glad to sleep

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Who hinders you?
children.prevalue: Who hinders you

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Why, you in the first place.
children.prevalue: Why you in the first place

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I? Oh, monseigneur!
children.prevalue: I Oh monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: No doubt you do. Is it at Nantes as at Paris? Do you not come in the king's name?
children.prevalue: No doubt you do Is it at Nantes as at Paris Do you not come in the king s name

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: For Heaven's sake, monseigneur, replied the captain, leave the king alone! The day on which I shall come on the part of the king, for the purpose you mean, take my word for it, I will not leave you long in doubt. You will see me place my hand on my sword, according to the ordonnance, and you will hear my say at once, in ceremonial voice, 'Monseigneur, in the name of the king, I arrest you!'
children.prevalue: For Heaven s sake monseigneur replied the captain leave the king alone The day on which I shall come on the part of the king for the purpose you mean take my word for it I will not leave you long in doubt You will see me place my hand on my sword according to the ordonnance and you will hear my say at once in ceremonial voice Monseigneur in the name of the king I arrest you

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: You promise me that frankness? said the superintendent.
children.prevalue: You promise me that frankness said the superintendent

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Upon my honor! But we have not come to that, believe me.
children.prevalue: Upon my honor But we have not come to that believe me

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: What makes you think that, M. d'Artagnan? For my part, I think quite the contrary.
children.prevalue: What makes you think that M d Artagnan For my part I think quite the contrary

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: I have heard speak of nothing of the kind, replied D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: I have heard speak of nothing of the kind replied D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Eh! eh! said Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Eh eh said Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Indeed, no. You are an agreeable man, in spite of your fever. The king should not, cannot help loving you, at the bottom of his heart.
children.prevalue: Indeed no You are an agreeable man in spite of your fever The king should not cannot help loving you at the bottom of his heart

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Fouquet's expression implied doubt. But M. Colbert? said he does M. Colbert love me as much as you say?
children.prevalue: Fouquet s expression implied doubt But M Colbert said he does M Colbert love me as much as you say

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: I am not speaking of M. Colbert, replied D'Artagnan. He is an exceptional man. He does not love you so much is very possible but, mordioux! the squirrel can guard himself against the adder with very little trouble.
children.prevalue: I am not speaking of M Colbert replied D Artagnan He is an exceptional man He does not love you so much is very possible but mordioux the squirrel can guard himself against the adder with very little trouble

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Do you know that you are speaking to me quite as a friend? replied Fouquet and that, upon my life! I have never met with a man of your intelligence, and heart?
children.prevalue: Do you know that you are speaking to me quite as a friend replied Fouquet and that upon my life I have never met with a man of your intelligence and heart

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: You are pleased to say so, replied D'Artagnan. Why did you wait till today to pay me such a compliment?
children.prevalue: You are pleased to say so replied D Artagnan Why did you wait till today to pay me such a compliment

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Blind that we are! murmured Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Blind that we are murmured Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Your voice is getting hoarse, said D'Artagnan drink, monseigneur, drink! And he offered him a cup of tisane, with the most friendly cordiality Fouquet took it, and thanked him by a gentle smile. Such things only happen to me, said the musketeer. I have passed ten years under your very beard, while you were rolling about tons of gold. You were clearing an annual pension of four millions you never observed me and you find out there is such a person in the world, just at the moment you

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Just at the moment I am about to fall, interrupted Fouquet. That is true, my dear Monsieur d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Just at the moment I am about to fall interrupted Fouquet That is true my dear Monsieur d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I did not say so.
children.prevalue: I did not say so

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: But you thought so and that is the same thing. Well! if I fall, take my word as truth, I shall not pass a single day without saying to myself, as I strike my brow, 'Fool! fool!stupid mortal! You had a Monsieur d'Artagnan under your eye and hand, and you did not employ him, you did not enrich him!'
children.prevalue: But you thought so and that is the same thing Well if I fall take my word as truth I shall not pass a single day without saying to myself as I strike my brow Fool fool stupid mortal You had a Monsieur d Artagnan under your eye and hand and you did not employ him you did not enrich him

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: You overwhelm me, said the captain. I esteem you greatly.
children.prevalue: You overwhelm me said the captain I esteem you greatly

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: There exists another man, then, who does not think as M. Colbert thinks, said the surintendant.
children.prevalue: There exists another man then who does not think as M Colbert thinks said the surintendant

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: How this M. Colbert looms up in your imagination! He is worse than fever!
children.prevalue: How this M Colbert looms up in your imagination He is worse than fever

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Oh! I have good cause, said Fouquet. Judge for yourself. And he related the details of the course of the lighters, and the hypocritical persecution of Colbert. Is not this a clear sign of my ruin?
children.prevalue: Oh I have good cause said Fouquet Judge for yourself And he related the details of the course of the lighters and the hypocritical persecution of Colbert Is not this a clear sign of my ruin

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: D'Artagnan became very serious. That is true, he said. Yes it has an unsavory odor, as M. de Treville used to say. And he fixed on M. Fouquet his intelligent and significant look.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan became very serious That is true he said Yes it has an unsavory odor as M de Treville used to say And he fixed on M Fouquet his intelligent and significant look

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Am I not clearly designated in that, captain? Is not the king bringing me to Nantes to get me away from Paris, where I have so many creatures, and to possess himself of BelleIsle?
children.prevalue: Am I not clearly designated in that captain Is not the king bringing me to Nantes to get me away from Paris where I have so many creatures and to possess himself of BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Where M. d'Herblay is, added D'Artagnan. Fouquet raised his head. As for me, monseigneur, continued D'Artagnan, I can assure you the king has said nothing to me against you.
children.prevalue: Where M d Herblay is added D Artagnan Fouquet raised his head As for me monseigneur continued D Artagnan I can assure you the king has said nothing to me against you

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Indeed!
children.prevalue: Indeed

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The king commanded me to set out for Nantes, it is true and to say nothing about it to M. de Gesvres.
children.prevalue: The king commanded me to set out for Nantes it is true and to say nothing about it to M de Gesvres

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: My friend.
children.prevalue: My friend

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: To M. de Gesvres, yes, monseigneur, continued the musketeer, whose eye s did not cease to speak a language different from the language of his lips. The king, moreover, commanded me to take a brigade of musketeers, which is apparently superfluous, as the country is quite quiet.
children.prevalue: To M de Gesvres yes monseigneur continued the musketeer whose eye s did not cease to speak a language different from the language of his lips The king moreover commanded me to take a brigade of musketeers which is apparently superfluous as the country is quite quiet

children.value: A brigade! said Fouquet, raising himself upon his elbow.
children.prevalue: A brigade said Fouquet raising himself upon his elbow

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Ninetysix horsemen, yes, monseigneur. The same number as were employed in arresting MM. de Chalais, de CinqMars, and Montmorency.
children.prevalue: Ninetysix horsemen yes monseigneur The same number as were employed in arresting MM de Chalais de CinqMars and Montmorency

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Fouquet pricked up his ears at these words, pronounced without apparent value. And what else? said he.
children.prevalue: Fouquet pricked up his ears at these words pronounced without apparent value And what else said he

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Oh! nothing but insignificant orders such as guarding the castle, guarding every lodging, allowing none of M. de Gesvres's guards to occupy a single post.
children.prevalue: Oh nothing but insignificant orders such as guarding the castle guarding every lodging allowing none of M de Gesvres s guards to occupy a single post

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: And as to myself, cried Fouquet, what orders had you?
children.prevalue: And as to myself cried Fouquet what orders had you

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: As to you, monseigneur?not the smallest word.
children.prevalue: As to you monseigneur not the smallest word

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Monsieur d'Artagnan, my safety, my honor, perhaps my life are at stake. You would not deceive me?
children.prevalue: Monsieur d Artagnan my safety my honor perhaps my life are at stake You would not deceive me

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: I?to what end? Are you threatened? Only there really is an order with respect to carriages and boats
children.prevalue: I to what end Are you threatened Only there really is an order with respect to carriages and boats

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: An order?
children.prevalue: An order

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Yes but it cannot concern youa simple measure of police.
children.prevalue: Yes but it cannot concern youa simple measure of police

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: What is it, captain?what is it?
children.prevalue: What is it captain what is it

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: To forbid all horses or boats to leave Nantes, without a pass, signed by the king.
children.prevalue: To forbid all horses or boats to leave Nantes without a pass signed by the king

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Great God! but
children.prevalue: Great God but

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: D'Artagnan began to laugh. All that is not to be put into execution before the arrival of the king at Nantes. So that you see plainly, monseigneur, the order in nowise concerns you.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan began to laugh All that is not to be put into execution before the arrival of the king at Nantes So that you see plainly monseigneur the order in nowise concerns you

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Fouquet became thoughtful, and D'Artagnan feigned not to observe his preoccupation. It is evident, by my thus confiding to you the orders which have been given to me, that I am friendly towards you, and that I am trying to prove to you that none of them are directed against you.
children.prevalue: Fouquet became thoughtful and D Artagnan feigned not to observe his preoccupation It is evident by my thus confiding to you the orders which have been given to me that I am friendly towards you and that I am trying to prove to you that none of them are directed against you

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Without doubt!without doubt! said Fouquet, still absent.
children.prevalue: Without doubt without doubt said Fouquet still absent

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Let us recapitulate, said the captain, his glance beaming with earnestness. A special guard about the castle, in which your lodging is to be, is it not?
children.prevalue: Let us recapitulate said the captain his glance beaming with earnestness A special guard about the castle in which your lodging is to be is it not

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Do you know the castle?
children.prevalue: Do you know the castle

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Ah! monseigneur, a regular prison! The absence of M. de Gesvres, who has the honor of being one of your friends. The closing of the gates of the city, and of the river without a pass but, only when the king shall have arrived. Please to observe, Monsieur Fouquet, that if, instead of speaking to man like you, who are one of the first in the kingdom, I were speaking to a troubled, uneasy conscienceI should compromise myself forever. What a fine opportunity for any one who wished to be free! No police, no guards, no orders the water free, the roads free, Monsieur d'Artagnan obliged to lend his horses, if required. All this ought to reassure you, Monsieur Fouquet, for the king would not have left me thus independent, if he had any sinister designs. In truth, Monsieur Fouquet, ask me whatever you like, I am at your service and, in return, if you will consent to do it, do me a service, that of giving my compliments to Aramis and Porthos, in case you embark for BelleIsle, as you have a right to do without changing your dress, immediately, in your robe de chambrejust as you are. Saying these words, and with a profound bow, the musketeer, whose looks had lost none of their intelligent kindness, left the apartment. He had not reached the steps of the vestibule, when Fouquet, quite beside himself, hung to the bellrope, and shouted, My horses!my lighter! But nobody answered. The surintendant dressed himself with everything that came to hand.
