children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Gourville!Gourville! cried he, while slipping his watch into his pocket. And the bell sounded again, whilst Fouquet repeated, Gourville!Gourville!
children.prevalue: Gourville Gourville cried he while slipping his watch into his pocket And the bell sounded again whilst Fouquet repeated Gourville Gourville

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Gourville at length appeared, breathless and pale.
children.prevalue: Gourville at length appeared breathless and pale

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Let us be gone! Let us be gone! cried Fouquet, as soon as he saw him.
children.prevalue: Let us be gone Let us be gone cried Fouquet as soon as he saw him

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: It is too late! said the surintendant's poor friend.
children.prevalue: It is too late said the surintendant s poor friend

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Too late!why?
children.prevalue: Too late why

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Listen! And they heard the sounds of trumpets and drums in front of the castle.
children.prevalue: Listen And they heard the sounds of trumpets and drums in front of the castle

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: What does that mean, Gourville?
children.prevalue: What does that mean Gourville

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: It means the king is come, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: It means the king is come monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: The king!
children.prevalue: The king

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: The king, who has ridden double stages, who has killed horses, and who is eight hours in advance of all our calculations.
children.prevalue: The king who has ridden double stages who has killed horses and who is eight hours in advance of all our calculations

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: We are lost! murmured Fouquet. Brave D'Artagnan, all is over, thou has spoken to me too late!
children.prevalue: We are lost murmured Fouquet Brave D Artagnan all is over thou has spoken to me too late

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: The king, in fact, was entering the city, which soon resounded with the cannon from the ramparts, and from a vessel which replied from the lower parts of the river. Fouquet's brow darkened he called his valets de chambre and dressed in ceremonial costume. From his window, behind the curtains, he could see the eagerness of the people, and the movement of a large troop, which had followed the prince. The king was conducted to the castle with great pomp, and Fouquet saw him dismount under the portcullis, and say something in the ear of D'Artagnan, who held his stirrup. D'Artagnan, when the king had passed under the arch, directed his steps towards the house Fouquet was in but so slowly, and stopping so frequently to speak to his musketeers, drawn up like a hedge, that it might be said he was counting the seconds, or the steps, before accomplishing his object. Fouquet opened the window to speak to him in the court.
children.prevalue: The king in fact was entering the city which soon resounded with the cannon from the ramparts and from a vessel which replied from the lower parts of the river Fouquet s brow darkened he called his valets de chambre and dressed in ceremonial costume From his window behind the curtains he could see the eagerness of the people and the movement of a large troop which had followed the prince The king was conducted to the castle with great pomp and Fouquet saw him dismount under the portcullis and say something in the ear of D Artagnan who held his stirrup D Artagnan when the king had passed under the arch directed his steps towards the house Fouquet was in but so slowly and stopping so frequently to speak to his musketeers drawn up like a hedge that it might be said he was counting the seconds or the steps before accomplishing his object Fouquet opened the window to speak to him in the court

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Ah! cried D'Artagnan, on perceiving him, are you still there, monseigneur?
children.prevalue: Ah cried D Artagnan on perceiving him are you still there monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: And that word still completed the proof to Fouquet of how much information and how many useful counsels were contained in the first visit the musketeer had paid him. The surintendant sighed deeply. Good heavens! yes, monsieur, replied he. The arrival of the king has interrupted me in the projects I had formed.
children.prevalue: And that word still completed the proof to Fouquet of how much information and how many useful counsels were contained in the first visit the musketeer had paid him The surintendant sighed deeply Good heavens yes monsieur replied he The arrival of the king has interrupted me in the projects I had formed

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Oh, then you know that the king has arrived?
children.prevalue: Oh then you know that the king has arrived

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Yes, monsieur, I have seen him and this time you come from him
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur I have seen him and this time you come from him

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: To inquire after you, monseigneur and, if your health is not too bad, to beg you to have the kindness to repair to the castle.
children.prevalue: To inquire after you monseigneur and if your health is not too bad to beg you to have the kindness to repair to the castle

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Directly, Monsieur d'Artagnan, directly!
children.prevalue: Directly Monsieur d Artagnan directly

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Ah, mordioux! said the captain, now the king is come, there is no more walking for anybodyno more free will the password governs all now, you as much as me, me as much as you.
children.prevalue: Ah mordioux said the captain now the king is come there is no more walking for anybodyno more free will the password governs all now you as much as me me as much as you

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Fouquet heaved a last sigh, climbed with difficulty into his carriage, so great was his weakness, and went to the castle, escorted by D'Artagnan, whose politeness was not less terrifying this time than it had just before been consoling and cheerful.
children.prevalue: Fouquet heaved a last sigh climbed with difficulty into his carriage so great was his weakness and went to the castle escorted by D Artagnan whose politeness was not less terrifying this time than it had just before been consoling and cheerful

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: As Fouquet was alighting from his carriage, to enter the castle of Nantes, a man of mean appearance went up to him with marks of the greatest respect, and gave him a letter. D'Artagnan endeavored to prevent this man from speaking to Fouquet, and pushed him away, but the message had been given to the surintendant. Fouquet opened the letter and read it, and instantly a vague terror, which D'Artagnan did not fail to penetrate, was painted on the countenance of the first minister. Fouquet put the paper into the portfolio which he had under his arm, and passed on towards the king's apartments. D'Artagnan, through the small windows made at every landing of the donjon stairs, saw, as he went up behind Fouquet, the man who had delivered the note, looking round him on the place and making signs to several persons, who disappeared in the adjacent streets, after having themselves repeated the signals. Fouquet was made to wait for a moment on the terrace of which we have spoken,a terrace which abutted on the little corridor, at the end of which the cabinet of the king was located. Here D'Artagnan passed on before the surintendant, whom, till that time, he had respectfully accompanied, and entered the royal cabinet.
children.prevalue: As Fouquet was alighting from his carriage to enter the castle of Nantes a man of mean appearance went up to him with marks of the greatest respect and gave him a letter D Artagnan endeavored to prevent this man from speaking to Fouquet and pushed him away but the message had been given to the surintendant Fouquet opened the letter and read it and instantly a vague terror which D Artagnan did not fail to penetrate was painted on the countenance of the first minister Fouquet put the paper into the portfolio which he had under his arm and passed on towards the king s apartments D Artagnan through the small windows made at every landing of the donjon stairs saw as he went up behind Fouquet the man who had delivered the note looking round him on the place and making signs to several persons who disappeared in the adjacent streets after having themselves repeated the signals Fouquet was made to wait for a moment on the terrace of which we have spoken a terrace which abutted on the little corridor at the end of which the cabinet of the king was located Here D Artagnan passed on before the surintendant whom till that time he had respectfully accompanied and entered the royal cabinet

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Well? asked Louis XIV., who, on perceiving him, threw on to the table covered with papers a large green cloth.
children.prevalue: Well asked Louis XIV who on perceiving him threw on to the table covered with papers a large green cloth

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The order is executed, sire.
children.prevalue: The order is executed sire

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: And Fouquet?
children.prevalue: And Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Monsieur le surintendant follows me, said D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Monsieur le surintendant follows me said D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: In ten minutes let him be introduced, said the king, dismissing D'Artagnan again with a gesture. The latter retired but had scarcely reached the corridor at the extremity of which Fouquet was waiting for him, when he was recalled by the king's bell.
children.prevalue: In ten minutes let him be introduced said the king dismissing D Artagnan again with a gesture The latter retired but had scarcely reached the corridor at the extremity of which Fouquet was waiting for him when he was recalled by the king s bell

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Did he not appear astonished? asked the king.
children.prevalue: Did he not appear astonished asked the king

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Who, sire?
children.prevalue: Who sire

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Fouquet, replied the king, without saying monsieur, a peculiarity which confirmed the captain of the musketeers in his suspicions.
children.prevalue: Fouquet replied the king without saying monsieur a peculiarity which confirmed the captain of the musketeers in his suspicions

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: No, sire, replied he.
children.prevalue: No sire replied he

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: That's well! And a second time Louis dismissed D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: That s well And a second time Louis dismissed D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Fouquet had not quitted the terrace where he had been left by his guide. He reperused his note, conceived thus:
children.prevalue: Fouquet had not quitted the terrace where he had been left by his guide He reperused his note conceived thus

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Something is being contrived against you. Perhaps they will not dare to carry it out at the castle it will be on your return home. The house is already surrounded by musketeers. Do not enter. A white horse is in waiting for you behind the esplanade!
children.prevalue: Something is being contrived against you Perhaps they will not dare to carry it out at the castle it will be on your return home The house is already surrounded by musketeers Do not enter A white horse is in waiting for you behind the esplanade

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Fouquet recognized the writing and zeal of Gourville. Not being willing that, if any evil happened to himself, this paper should compromise a faithful friend, the surintendant was busy tearing it into a thousand morsels, spread about by the wind from the balustrade of the terrace. D'Artagnan found him watching the snowflake fluttering of the last scraps in space.
children.prevalue: Fouquet recognized the writing and zeal of Gourville Not being willing that if any evil happened to himself this paper should compromise a faithful friend the surintendant was busy tearing it into a thousand morsels spread about by the wind from the balustrade of the terrace D Artagnan found him watching the snowflake fluttering of the last scraps in space

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Monsieur, said he, the king awaits you.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said he the king awaits you

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Fouquet walked with a deliberate step along the little corridor, where MM. de Brienne and Rose were at work, whilst the Duc de SaintAignan, seated on a chair, likewise in the corridor, appeared to be waiting for orders, with feverish impatience, his sword between his legs. It appeared strange to Fouquet that MM. Brienne, Rose, and de SaintAignan, in general so attentive and obsequious, should scarcely take the least notice, as he, the surintendant, passed. But how could he expect to find it otherwise among courtiers, he whom the king no longer called anything but Fouquet? He raised his head, determined to look every one and everything bravely in the face, and entered the king's apartment, where a little bell, which we already know, had already announced him to his majesty.
children.prevalue: Fouquet walked with a deliberate step along the little corridor where MM de Brienne and Rose were at work whilst the Duc de SaintAignan seated on a chair likewise in the corridor appeared to be waiting for orders with feverish impatience his sword between his legs It appeared strange to Fouquet that MM Brienne Rose and de SaintAignan in general so attentive and obsequious should scarcely take the least notice as he the surintendant passed But how could he expect to find it otherwise among courtiers he whom the king no longer called anything but Fouquet He raised his head determined to look every one and everything bravely in the face and entered the king s apartment where a little bell which we already know had already announced him to his majesty

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: The king, without rising, nodded to him, and with interest: Well! how are you, Monsieur Fouquet? said he.
children.prevalue: The king without rising nodded to him and with interest Well how are you Monsieur Fouquet said he

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I am in a high fever, replied the surintendant but I am at the king's service.
children.prevalue: I am in a high fever replied the surintendant but I am at the king s service

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: That is well the States assemble tomorrow have you a speech ready?
children.prevalue: That is well the States assemble tomorrow have you a speech ready

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Fouquet looked at the king with astonishment. I have not, sire, replied he but I will improvise one. I am too well acquainted with affairs to feel any embarrassment. I have only one question to ask will your majesty permit me?
children.prevalue: Fouquet looked at the king with astonishment I have not sire replied he but I will improvise one I am too well acquainted with affairs to feel any embarrassment I have only one question to ask will your majesty permit me

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Certainly. Ask it.
children.prevalue: Certainly Ask it

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Why did not your majesty do his first minister the honor of giving him notice of this in Paris?
children.prevalue: Why did not your majesty do his first minister the honor of giving him notice of this in Paris

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: You were ill I was not willing to fatigue you.
children.prevalue: You were ill I was not willing to fatigue you

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Never did a labornever did an explanation fatigue me, sire and since the moment is come for me to demand an explanation of my king
children.prevalue: Never did a labornever did an explanation fatigue me sire and since the moment is come for me to demand an explanation of my king

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Oh, Monsieur Fouquet! an explanation? An explanation, pray, of what?
children.prevalue: Oh Monsieur Fouquet an explanation An explanation pray of what

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Of your majesty's intentions with respect to myself.
children.prevalue: Of your majesty s intentions with respect to myself

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The king blushed. I have been calumniated, continued Fouquet, warmly, and I feel called upon to adjure the justice of the king to make inquiries.
children.prevalue: The king blushed I have been calumniated continued Fouquet warmly and I feel called upon to adjure the justice of the king to make inquiries

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: You say all this to me very uselessly, Monsieur Fouquet I know what I know.
children.prevalue: You say all this to me very uselessly Monsieur Fouquet I know what I know

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Your majesty can only know the things that have been told to you and I, on my part, have said nothing to you, whilst others have spoken many, many times
children.prevalue: Your majesty can only know the things that have been told to you and I on my part have said nothing to you whilst others have spoken many many times

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: What do you wish to say? said the king, impatient to put an end to this embarrassing conversation.
children.prevalue: What do you wish to say said the king impatient to put an end to this embarrassing conversation

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: I will go straight to the facts, sire and I accuse a certain man of having injured me in your majesty's opinion.
children.prevalue: I will go straight to the facts sire and I accuse a certain man of having injured me in your majesty s opinion

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Nobody has injured you, Monsieur Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Nobody has injured you Monsieur Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: That reply proves to me, sire, that I am right.
children.prevalue: That reply proves to me sire that I am right

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Monsieur Fouquet, I do not like people to be accused.
children.prevalue: Monsieur Fouquet I do not like people to be accused

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Not when one is accused?
children.prevalue: Not when one is accused

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: We have already spoken too much about this affair.
children.prevalue: We have already spoken too much about this affair

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Your majesty will not allow me to justify myself?
children.prevalue: Your majesty will not allow me to justify myself

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: I repeat that I do not accuse you.
children.prevalue: I repeat that I do not accuse you

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Fouquet, with a halfbow, made a step backward. It is certain, thought he, that he has made up his mind. He alone who cannot go back can show such obstinacy. Not to see the danger now would be to be blind indeed not to shun it would be stupid. He resumed aloud, Did your majesty send for me on business?
children.prevalue: Fouquet with a halfbow made a step backward It is certain thought he that he has made up his mind He alone who cannot go back can show such obstinacy Not to see the danger now would be to be blind indeed not to shun it would be stupid He resumed aloud Did your majesty send for me on business

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: No, Monsieur Fouquet, but for some advice I wish to give you.
children.prevalue: No Monsieur Fouquet but for some advice I wish to give you

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I respectfully await it, sire.
children.prevalue: I respectfully await it sire

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Rest yourself, Monsieur Fouquet, do not throw away your strength the session of the States will be short, and when my secretaries shall have closed it, I do not wish business to be talked of in France for a fortnight.
children.prevalue: Rest yourself Monsieur Fouquet do not throw away your strength the session of the States will be short and when my secretaries shall have closed it I do not wish business to be talked of in France for a fortnight

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Has the king nothing to say to me on the subject of this assembly of the States?
children.prevalue: Has the king nothing to say to me on the subject of this assembly of the States

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: No, Monsieur Fouquet.
children.prevalue: No Monsieur Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Not to me, the surintendant of the finances?
children.prevalue: Not to me the surintendant of the finances

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Rest yourself, I beg you that is all I have to say to you.
children.prevalue: Rest yourself I beg you that is all I have to say to you

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Fouquet bit his lips and hung his head. He was evidently busy with some uneasy thought. This uneasiness struck the king. Are you angry at having to rest yourself, M. Fouquet? said he.
children.prevalue: Fouquet bit his lips and hung his head He was evidently busy with some uneasy thought This uneasiness struck the king Are you angry at having to rest yourself M Fouquet said he

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Yes, sire, I am not accustomed to take rest.
children.prevalue: Yes sire I am not accustomed to take rest

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: But you are ill you must take care of yourself.
children.prevalue: But you are ill you must take care of yourself

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Your majesty spoke just now of a speech to be pronounced tomorrow.
children.prevalue: Your majesty spoke just now of a speech to be pronounced tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: His majesty made no reply this unexpected stroke embarrassed him. Fouquet felt the weight of this hesitation. He thought he could read danger in the eyes of the young prince, which fear would but precipitate. If I appear frightened, I am lost, thought he.
children.prevalue: His majesty made no reply this unexpected stroke embarrassed him Fouquet felt the weight of this hesitation He thought he could read danger in the eyes of the young prince which fear would but precipitate If I appear frightened I am lost thought he

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The king, on his part, was only uneasy at the alarm of Fouquet. Has he a suspicion of anything? murmured he.
children.prevalue: The king on his part was only uneasy at the alarm of Fouquet Has he a suspicion of anything murmured he

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: If his first word is severe, again thought Fouquet if he becomes angry, or feigns to be angry for the sake of a pretext, how shall I extricate myself? Let us smooth the declivity a little. Gourville was right.
children.prevalue: If his first word is severe again thought Fouquet if he becomes angry or feigns to be angry for the sake of a pretext how shall I extricate myself Let us smooth the declivity a little Gourville was right

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Sire, said he, suddenly, since the goodness of the king watches over my health to the point of dispensing with my labor, may I not be allowed to be absent from the council of tomorrow? I could pass the day in bed, and will entreat the king to grant me his physician, that we may endeavor to find a remedy against this fearful fever.
children.prevalue: Sire said he suddenly since the goodness of the king watches over my health to the point of dispensing with my labor may I not be allowed to be absent from the council of tomorrow I could pass the day in bed and will entreat the king to grant me his physician that we may endeavor to find a remedy against this fearful fever

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: So be it, Monsieur Fouquet, it shall be as you desire you shall have a holiday tomorrow, you shall have the physician, and shall be restored to health.
children.prevalue: So be it Monsieur Fouquet it shall be as you desire you shall have a holiday tomorrow you shall have the physician and shall be restored to health

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Thanks! said Fouquet, bowing. Then, opening his game: Shall I not have the happiness of conducting your majesty to my residence of BelleIsle?
children.prevalue: Thanks said Fouquet bowing Then opening his game Shall I not have the happiness of conducting your majesty to my residence of BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: And he looked Louis full in the face, to judge of the effect of such a proposal. The king blushed again.
children.prevalue: And he looked Louis full in the face to judge of the effect of such a proposal The king blushed again

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Do you know, replied he, endeavoring to smile, that you have just said, 'My residence of BelleIsle'?
children.prevalue: Do you know replied he endeavoring to smile that you have just said My residence of BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Yes, sire.
children.prevalue: Yes sire

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Well! do you not remember, continued the king in the same cheerful tone, that you gave me BelleIsle?
children.prevalue: Well do you not remember continued the king in the same cheerful tone that you gave me BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: That is true again, sire. Only, as you have not taken it, you will doubtless come with me and take possession of it.
children.prevalue: That is true again sire Only as you have not taken it you will doubtless come with me and take possession of it

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I mean to do so.
children.prevalue: I mean to do so

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: That was, besides, your majesty's intention as well as mine and I cannot express to your majesty how happy and proud I have been to see all the king's regiments from Paris to help take possession.
children.prevalue: That was besides your majesty s intention as well as mine and I cannot express to your majesty how happy and proud I have been to see all the king s regiments from Paris to help take possession

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: The king stammered out that he did not bring the musketeers for that alone.
children.prevalue: The king stammered out that he did not bring the musketeers for that alone

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Oh, I am convinced of that, said Fouquet, warmly your majesty knows very well that you have nothing to do but to come alone with a cane in your hand, to bring to the ground all the fortifications of BelleIsle.
children.prevalue: Oh I am convinced of that said Fouquet warmly your majesty knows very well that you have nothing to do but to come alone with a cane in your hand to bring to the ground all the fortifications of BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Peste! cried the king I do not wish those fine fortifications, which cost so much to build, to fall at all. No, let them stand against the Dutch and English. You would not guess what I want to see at BelleIsle, Monsieur Fouquet it is the pretty peasants and women of the lands on the seashore, who dance so well, and are so seducing with their scarlet petticoats! I have heard great boast of your pretty tenants, monsieur le surintendant well, let me have a sight of them.
children.prevalue: Peste cried the king I do not wish those fine fortifications which cost so much to build to fall at all No let them stand against the Dutch and English You would not guess what I want to see at BelleIsle Monsieur Fouquet it is the pretty peasants and women of the lands on the seashore who dance so well and are so seducing with their scarlet petticoats I have heard great boast of your pretty tenants monsieur le surintendant well let me have a sight of them

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Whenever your majesty pleases.
children.prevalue: Whenever your majesty pleases

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Have you any means of transport? It shall be tomorrow, if you like.
children.prevalue: Have you any means of transport It shall be tomorrow if you like

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: The surintendant felt this stroke, which was not adroit, and replied, No, sire I was ignorant of your majesty's wish above all, I was ignorant of your haste to see BelleIsle, and I am prepared with nothing.
children.prevalue: The surintendant felt this stroke which was not adroit and replied No sire I was ignorant of your majesty s wish above all I was ignorant of your haste to see BelleIsle and I am prepared with nothing

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: You have a boat of your own, nevertheless?
children.prevalue: You have a boat of your own nevertheless

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: I have five but they are all in port, or at Paimboeuf and to join them, or bring them hither, would require at least twentyfour hours. Have I any occasion to send a courier? Must I do so?
children.prevalue: I have five but they are all in port or at Paimboeuf and to join them or bring them hither would require at least twentyfour hours Have I any occasion to send a courier Must I do so

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Wait a little, put an end to the fever,wait till tomorrow.
children.prevalue: Wait a little put an end to the fever wait till tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: That is true. Who knows but that by tomorrow we may not have a hundred other ideas? replied Fouquet, now perfectly convinced and very pale.
children.prevalue: That is true Who knows but that by tomorrow we may not have a hundred other ideas replied Fouquet now perfectly convinced and very pale

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: The king started, and stretched his hand out towards his little bell, but Fouquet prevented his ringing.
children.prevalue: The king started and stretched his hand out towards his little bell but Fouquet prevented his ringing

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Sire, said he, I have an agueI am trembling with cold. If I remain a moment longer, I shall most likely faint. I request your majesty's permission to go and fling myself beneath the bedclothes.
children.prevalue: Sire said he I have an agueI am trembling with cold If I remain a moment longer I shall most likely faint I request your majesty s permission to go and fling myself beneath the bedclothes

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Indeed, you are in a shiver it is painful to behold! Come, Monsieur Fouquet, begone! I will send to inquire after you.
children.prevalue: Indeed you are in a shiver it is painful to behold Come Monsieur Fouquet begone I will send to inquire after you

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Your majesty overwhelms me with kindness. In an hour I shall be better.
children.prevalue: Your majesty overwhelms me with kindness In an hour I shall be better

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: I will call some one to reconduct you, said the king.
children.prevalue: I will call some one to reconduct you said the king

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: As you please, sire I would gladly take the arm of any one.
children.prevalue: As you please sire I would gladly take the arm of any one

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Monsieur d'Artagnan! cried the king, ringing his little bell.
children.prevalue: Monsieur d Artagnan cried the king ringing his little bell

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Oh, sire, interrupted Fouquet, laughing in such a manner as made the prince feel cold, would you give me the captain of your musketeers to take me to my lodgings? An equivocal honor that, sire! A simple footman, I beg.
children.prevalue: Oh sire interrupted Fouquet laughing in such a manner as made the prince feel cold would you give me the captain of your musketeers to take me to my lodgings An equivocal honor that sire A simple footman I beg

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: And why, M. Fouquet? M. d'Artagnan conducts me often, and extremely well!
children.prevalue: And why M Fouquet M d Artagnan conducts me often and extremely well

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Yes, but when he conducts you, sire, it is to obey you whilst me
children.prevalue: Yes but when he conducts you sire it is to obey you whilst me

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Go on!
children.prevalue: Go on

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: If I am obliged to return home supported by the leader of the musketeers, it would be everywhere said you had had me arrested.
children.prevalue: If I am obliged to return home supported by the leader of the musketeers it would be everywhere said you had had me arrested

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Arrested! replied the king, who became paler than Fouquet himself,arrested! oh!
children.prevalue: Arrested replied the king who became paler than Fouquet himself arrested oh

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: And why should they not say so? continued Fouquet, still laughing and I would lay a wager there would be people found wicked enough to laugh at it. This sally disconcerted the monarch. Fouquet was skillful enough, or fortunate enough, to make Louis XIV. recoil before the appearance of the deed he meditated. M. d'Artagnan, when he appeared, received an order to desire a musketeer to accompany the surintendant.
children.prevalue: And why should they not say so continued Fouquet still laughing and I would lay a wager there would be people found wicked enough to laugh at it This sally disconcerted the monarch Fouquet was skillful enough or fortunate enough to make Louis XIV recoil before the appearance of the deed he meditated M d Artagnan when he appeared received an order to desire a musketeer to accompany the surintendant

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Quite unnecessary, said the latter sword for sword I prefer Gourville, who is waiting for me below. But that will not prevent me enjoying the society of M. d'Artagnan. I am glad he will see BelleIsle, he is so good a judge of fortifications.
children.prevalue: Quite unnecessary said the latter sword for sword I prefer Gourville who is waiting for me below But that will not prevent me enjoying the society of M d Artagnan I am glad he will see BelleIsle he is so good a judge of fortifications

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: D'Artagnan bowed, without at all comprehending what was going on. Fouquet bowed again and left the apartment, affecting all the slowness of a man who walks with difficulty. When once out of the castle, I am saved! said he. Oh! yes, disloyal king, you shall see BelleIsle, but it shall be when I am no longer there.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan bowed without at all comprehending what was going on Fouquet bowed again and left the apartment affecting all the slowness of a man who walks with difficulty When once out of the castle I am saved said he Oh yes disloyal king you shall see BelleIsle but it shall be when I am no longer there

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: He disappeared, leaving D'Artagnan with the king.
children.prevalue: He disappeared leaving D Artagnan with the king

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Captain, said the king, you will follow M. Fouquet at the distance of a hundred paces.
children.prevalue: Captain said the king you will follow M Fouquet at the distance of a hundred paces

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Yes, sire.
children.prevalue: Yes sire

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: He is going to his lodgings again. You will go with him.
children.prevalue: He is going to his lodgings again You will go with him

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Yes, sire.
children.prevalue: Yes sire

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: You will arrest him in my name, and will shut him up in a carriage.
children.prevalue: You will arrest him in my name and will shut him up in a carriage

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: In a carriage. Well, sire?
children.prevalue: In a carriage Well sire

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: In such a fashion that he may not, on the road, either converse with any one or throw notes to people he may meet.
children.prevalue: In such a fashion that he may not on the road either converse with any one or throw notes to people he may meet

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: That will be rather difficult, sire.
children.prevalue: That will be rather difficult sire

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Not at all.
children.prevalue: Not at all

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Pardon me, sire, I cannot stifle M. Fouquet, and if he asks for liberty to breathe, I cannot prevent him by closing both the windows and the blinds. He will throw out at the doors all the cries and notes possible.
children.prevalue: Pardon me sire I cannot stifle M Fouquet and if he asks for liberty to breathe I cannot prevent him by closing both the windows and the blinds He will throw out at the doors all the cries and notes possible

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: The case is provided for, Monsieur d'Artagnan a carriage with a trellis will obviate both the difficulties you point out.
children.prevalue: The case is provided for Monsieur d Artagnan a carriage with a trellis will obviate both the difficulties you point out

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: A carriage with an iron trellis! cried D'Artagnan but a carriage with an iron trellis is not made in half an hour, and your majesty commands me to go immediately to M. Fouquet's lodgings.
children.prevalue: A carriage with an iron trellis cried D Artagnan but a carriage with an iron trellis is not made in half an hour and your majesty commands me to go immediately to M Fouquet s lodgings

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: The carriage in question is already made.
children.prevalue: The carriage in question is already made

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Ah! that is quite a different thing, said the captain if the carriage is ready made, very well, then, we have only to set it in motion.
children.prevalue: Ah that is quite a different thing said the captain if the carriage is ready made very well then we have only to set it in motion

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: It is readyand the horses harnessed.
children.prevalue: It is readyand the horses harnessed

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Ah!
children.prevalue: Ah

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: And the coachman, with the outriders, is waiting in the lower court of the castle.
children.prevalue: And the coachman with the outriders is waiting in the lower court of the castle

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: D'Artagnan bowed. There only remains for me to ask your majesty whither I shall conduct M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan bowed There only remains for me to ask your majesty whither I shall conduct M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: To the castle of Angers, at first.
children.prevalue: To the castle of Angers at first

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Very well, sire.
children.prevalue: Very well sire

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Afterwards we will see.
children.prevalue: Afterwards we will see

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Yes, sire.
children.prevalue: Yes sire

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: Monsieur d'Artagnan, one last word: you have remarked that, for making this capture of M. Fouquet, I have not employed my guards, on which account M. de Gesvres will be furious.
children.prevalue: Monsieur d Artagnan one last word you have remarked that for making this capture of M Fouquet I have not employed my guards on which account M de Gesvres will be furious

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Your majesty does not employ your guards, said the captain, a little humiliated, because you mistrust M. de Gesvres, that is all.
children.prevalue: Your majesty does not employ your guards said the captain a little humiliated because you mistrust M de Gesvres that is all

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: That is to say, monsieur, that I have more confidence in you.
children.prevalue: That is to say monsieur that I have more confidence in you

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: I know that very well, sire! and it is of no use to make so much of it.
children.prevalue: I know that very well sire and it is of no use to make so much of it

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: It is only for the sake of arriving at this, monsieur, that if, from this moment, it should happen that by any chance whatever M. Fouquet should escapesuch chances have been, monsieur
children.prevalue: It is only for the sake of arriving at this monsieur that if from this moment it should happen that by any chance whatever M Fouquet should escapesuch chances have been monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: Oh! very often, sire but for others, not for me.
children.prevalue: Oh very often sire but for others not for me

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: And why not with you?
children.prevalue: And why not with you

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Because I, sire, have, for an instant, wished to save M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Because I sire have for an instant wished to save M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: The king started. Because, continued the captain, I had then a right to do so, having guessed your majesty's plan, without you having spoken to me of it, and that I took an interest in M. Fouquet. Now, was I not at liberty to show my interest in this man?
children.prevalue: The king started Because continued the captain I had then a right to do so having guessed your majesty s plan without you having spoken to me of it and that I took an interest in M Fouquet Now was I not at liberty to show my interest in this man

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: In truth, monsieur, you do not reassure me with regard to your services.
children.prevalue: In truth monsieur you do not reassure me with regard to your services

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: If I had saved him then, I should have been perfectly innocent I will say more, I should have done well, for M. Fouquet is not a bad man. But he was not willing his destiny prevailed he let the hour of liberty slip by. So much the worse! Now I have orders, I will obey those orders, and M. Fouquet you may consider as a man arrested. He is at the castle of Angers, this very M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: If I had saved him then I should have been perfectly innocent I will say more I should have done well for M Fouquet is not a bad man But he was not willing his destiny prevailed he let the hour of liberty slip by So much the worse Now I have orders I will obey those orders and M Fouquet you may consider as a man arrested He is at the castle of Angers this very M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Oh! you have not got him yet, captain.
children.prevalue: Oh you have not got him yet captain

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: That concerns me every one to his trade, sire only, once more, reflect! Do you seriously give me orders to arrest M. Fouquet, sire?
children.prevalue: That concerns me every one to his trade sire only once more reflect Do you seriously give me orders to arrest M Fouquet sire

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Yes, a thousand times, yes!
children.prevalue: Yes a thousand times yes

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: In writing, sire, then.
children.prevalue: In writing sire then

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Here is the order.
children.prevalue: Here is the order

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: D'Artagnan read it, bowed to the king, and left the room. From the height of the terrace he perceived Gourville, who went by with a joyous air towards the lodgings of M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan read it bowed to the king and left the room From the height of the terrace he perceived Gourville who went by with a joyous air towards the lodgings of M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: That is rather surprising, said D'Artagnan Gourville running about the streets so gayly, when he is almost certain that M. Fouquet is in danger when it is almost equally certain that it was Gourville who warned M. Fouquet just now by the note which was torn into a thousand pieces upon the terrace, and given to the winds by monsieur le surintendant. Gourville is rubbing his hands that is because he has done something clever. Whence comes M. Gourville? Gourville is coming from the Rue aux Herbes. Whither does the Rue aux Herbes lead? And D'Artagnan followed, along the tops of the houses of Nantes, dominated by the castle, the line traced by the streets, as he would have done upon a topographical plan only, instead of the dead, flat paper, the living chart rose in relief with the cries, the movements, and the shadows of men and things. Beyond the inclosure of the city, the great verdant plains stretched out, bordering the Loire, and appeared to run towards the pink horizon, which was cut by the azure of the waters and the dark green of the marshes. Immediately outside the gates of Nantes two white roads were seen diverging like separate fingers of a gigantic hand. D'Artagnan, who had taken in all the panorama at a glance by crossing the terrace, was led by the line of the Rue aux Herbes to the mouth of one of those roads which took its rise under the gates of Nantes. One step more, and he was about to descend the stairs, take his trellised carriage, and go towards the lodgings of M. Fouquet. But chance decreed, at the moment of plunging into the staircase, that he was attracted by a moving point then gaining ground upon that road.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: What is that? said the musketeer to himself a horse galloping,a runaway horse, no doubt. What a rate he is going at! The moving point became detached from the road, and entered into the fields. A white horse, continued the captain, who had just observed the color thrown luminously against the dark ground, and he is mounted it must be some boy whose horse is thirsty and has run away with him.
children.prevalue: What is that said the musketeer to himself a horse galloping a runaway horse no doubt What a rate he is going at The moving point became detached from the road and entered into the fields A white horse continued the captain who had just observed the color thrown luminously against the dark ground and he is mounted it must be some boy whose horse is thirsty and has run away with him

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: These reflections, rapid as lightning, simultaneous with visual perception, D'Artagnan had already forgotten when he descended the first steps of the staircase. Some morsels of paper were spread over the stairs, and shone out white against the dirty stones. Eh! eh! said the captain to himself, here are some of the fragments of the note torn by M. Fouquet. Poor man! he has given his secret to the wind the wind will have no more to do with it, and brings it back to the king. Decidedly, Fouquet, you play with misfortune! the game is not a fair one,fortune is against you. The star of Louis XIV. obscures yours the adder is stronger and more cunning than the squirrel. D'Artagnan picked up one of these morsels of paper as he descended. Gourville's pretty little hand! cried he, whilst examining one of the fragments of the note I was not mistaken. And he read the word horse. Stop! said he and he examined another, upon which there was not a letter traced. Upon a third he read the word white white horse, repeated he, like a child that is spelling. Ah, mordioux! cried the suspicious spirit, a white horse! And, like that grain of powder which, burning, dilates into ten thousand times its volume, D'Artagnan, enlightened by ideas and suspicions, rapidly reascended the stairs towards the terrace. The white horse was still galloping in the direction of the Loire, at the extremity of which, melting into the vapors of the water, a little sail appeared, wavebalanced like a waterbutterfly. Oh! cried the musketeer, only a man who wants to fly would go at that pace across plowed lands there is but one Fouquet, a financier, to ride thus in open day upon a white horse there is no one but the lord of BelleIsle who would make his escape towards the sea, while there are such thick forests on land, and there is but one D'Artagnan in the world to catch M. Fouquet, who has half an hour's start, and who will have gained his boat within an hour. This being said, the musketeer gave orders that the carriage with the iron trellis should be taken immediately to a thicket situated just outside the city. He selected his best horse, jumped upon his back, galloped along the Rue aux Herbes, taking, not the road Fouquet had taken, but the bank itself of the Loire, certain that he should gain ten minutes upon the total distance, and, at the intersection of the two lines, come up with the fugitive, who could have no suspicion of being pursued in that direction. In the rapidity of the pursuit, and with the impatience of the avenger, animating himself as in war, D'Artagnan, so mild, so kind towards Fouquet, was surprised to find himself become ferociousalmost sanguinary. For a long time he galloped without catching sight of the white horse. His rage assumed fury, he doubted himself,he suspected that Fouquet had buried himself in some subterranean road, or that he had changed the white horse for one of those famous black ones, as swift as the wind, which D'Artagnan, at SaintMande, had so frequently admired and envied for their vigor and their fleetness.

their fleetness

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: At such moments, when the wind cut his eyes so as to make the tears spring from them, when the saddle had become burning hot, when the galled and spurred horse reared with pain, and threw behind him a shower of dust and stones, D'Artagnan, raising himself in his stirrups, and seeing nothing on the waters, nothing beneath the trees, looked up into the air like a madman. He was losing his senses. In the paroxysms of eagerness he dreamt of aerial ways,the discovery of the following century he called to his mind Daedalus and the vast wings that had saved him from the prisons of Crete. A hoarse sigh broke from his lips, as he repeated, devoured by the fear of ridicule, I! I! duped by a Gourville! I! They will say that I am growing old,they will say I have received a million to allow Fouquet to escape! And he again dug his spurs into the sides of his horse: he had ridden astonishingly fast. Suddenly, at the extremity of some open pastureground, behind the hedges, he saw a white form which showed itself, disappeared, and at last remained distinctly visible against the rising ground. D'Artagnan's heart leaped with joy. He wiped the streaming sweat from his brow, relaxed the tension of his knees,by which the horse breathed more freely,and, gathering up his reins, moderated the speed of the vigorous animal, his active accomplice on this manhunt. He had then time to study the direction of the road, and his position with regard to Fouquet. The superintendent had completely winded his horse by crossing the soft ground. He felt the necessity of gaining a firmer footing, and turned towards the road by the shortest secant line. D'Artagnan, on his part, had nothing to do but to ride straight on, concealed by the sloping shore so that he would cut his quarry off the road when he came up with him. Then the real race would begin,then the struggle would be in earnest.

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: D'Artagnan gave his horse good breathingtime. He observed that the superintendent had relaxed into a trot, which was to say, he, too, was favoring his horse. But both of them were too much pressed for time to allow them to continue long at that pace. The white horse sprang off like an arrow the moment his feet touched firm ground. D'Artagnan dropped his head, and his black horse broke into a gallop. Both followed the same route the quadruple echoes of this new racecourse were confounded. Fouquet had not yet perceived D'Artagnan. But on issuing from the slope, a single echo struck the air it was that of the steps of D'Artagnan's horse, which rolled along like thunder. Fouquet turned round, and saw behind him, within a hundred paces, his enemy bent over the neck of his horse. There could be no doubtthe shining baldrick, the red cassockit was a musketeer. Fouquet slackened his hand likewise, and the white horse placed twenty feet more between his adversary and himself.

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Oh, but, thought D'Artagnan, becoming very anxious, that is not a common horse M. Fouquet is uponlet us see! And he attentively examined with his infallible eye the shape and capabilities of the courser. Round full quartersa thin long taillarge hocksthin legs, as dry as bars of steelhoofs hard as marble. He spurred his own, but the distance between the two remained the same. D'Artagnan listened attentively not a breath of the horse reached him, and yet he seemed to cut the air. The black horse, on the contrary, began to puff like any blacksmith's bellows.
children.prevalue: Oh but thought D Artagnan becoming very anxious that is not a common horse M Fouquet is uponlet us see And he attentively examined with his infallible eye the shape and capabilities of the courser Round full quartersa thin long taillarge hocksthin legs as dry as bars of steelhoofs hard as marble He spurred his own but the distance between the two remained the same D Artagnan listened attentively not a breath of the horse reached him and yet he seemed to cut the air The black horse on the contrary began to puff like any blacksmith s bellows

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I must overtake him, if I kill my horse, thought the musketeer and he began to saw the mouth of the poor animal, whilst he buried the rowels of his merciless spurs into his sides. The maddened horse gained twenty toises, and came up within pistolshot of Fouquet.
children.prevalue: I must overtake him if I kill my horse thought the musketeer and he began to saw the mouth of the poor animal whilst he buried the rowels of his merciless spurs into his sides The maddened horse gained twenty toises and came up within pistolshot of Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Courage! said the musketeer to himself, courage! the white horse will perhaps grow weaker, and if the horse does not fall, the master must pull up at last. But horse and rider remained upright together, gaining ground by difficult degrees. D'Artagnan uttered a wild cry, which made Fouquet turn round, and added speed to the white horse.
children.prevalue: Courage said the musketeer to himself courage the white horse will perhaps grow weaker and if the horse does not fall the master must pull up at last But horse and rider remained upright together gaining ground by difficult degrees D Artagnan uttered a wild cry which made Fouquet turn round and added speed to the white horse

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: A famous horse! a mad rider! growled the captain. Hola! mordioux! Monsieur Fouquet! stop! in the king's name! Fouquet made no reply.
children.prevalue: A famous horse a mad rider growled the captain Hola mordioux Monsieur Fouquet stop in the king s name Fouquet made no reply

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Do you hear me? shouted D'Artagnan, whose horse had just stumbled.
children.prevalue: Do you hear me shouted D Artagnan whose horse had just stumbled

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Pardieu! replied Fouquet, laconically and rode on faster.
children.prevalue: Pardieu replied Fouquet laconically and rode on faster

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: D'Artagnan was nearly mad the blood rushed boiling to his temples and his eyes. In the king's name! cried he again, stop, or I will bring you down with a pistolshot!
children.prevalue: D Artagnan was nearly mad the blood rushed boiling to his temples and his eyes In the king s name cried he again stop or I will bring you down with a pistolshot

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Do! replied Fouquet, without relaxing his speed.
children.prevalue: Do replied Fouquet without relaxing his speed

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: D'Artagnan seized a pistol and cocked it, hoping that the double click of the spring would stop his enemy. You have pistols likewise, said he, turn and defend yourself.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan seized a pistol and cocked it hoping that the double click of the spring would stop his enemy You have pistols likewise said he turn and defend yourself

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Fouquet did turn round at the noise, and looking D'Artagnan full in the face, opened, with his right hand, the part of his dress which concealed his body, but he did not even touch his holsters. There were not more than twenty paces between the two.
children.prevalue: Fouquet did turn round at the noise and looking D Artagnan full in the face opened with his right hand the part of his dress which concealed his body but he did not even touch his holsters There were not more than twenty paces between the two

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Mordioux! said D'Artagnan, I will not assassinate you if you will not fire upon me, surrender! what is a prison?
children.prevalue: Mordioux said D Artagnan I will not assassinate you if you will not fire upon me surrender what is a prison

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: I would rather die! replied Fouquet I shall suffer less.
children.prevalue: I would rather die replied Fouquet I shall suffer less

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: D'Artagnan, drunk with despair, hurled his pistol to the ground. I will take you alive! said he and by a prodigy of skill which this incomparable horseman alone was capable, he threw his horse forward to within ten paces of the white horse already his hand was stretched out to seize his prey.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan drunk with despair hurled his pistol to the ground I will take you alive said he and by a prodigy of skill which this incomparable horseman alone was capable he threw his horse forward to within ten paces of the white horse already his hand was stretched out to seize his prey

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Kill me! kill me! cried Fouquet, 'twould be more humane!
children.prevalue: Kill me kill me cried Fouquet twould be more humane

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: No! alivealive! murmured the captain.
children.prevalue: No alivealive murmured the captain

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: At this moment his horse made a false step for the second time, and Fouquet's again took the lead. It was an unheardof spectacle, this race between two horses which now only kept alive by the will of their riders. It might be said that D'Artagnan rode, carrying his horse along between his knees. To the furious gallop had succeeded the fast trot, and that had sunk to what might be scarcely called a trot at all. But the chase appeared equally warm in the two fatigued athletoe. D'Artagnan, quite in despair, seized his second pistol, and cocked it.
children.prevalue: At this moment his horse made a false step for the second time and Fouquet s again took the lead It was an unheardof spectacle this race between two horses which now only kept alive by the will of their riders It might be said that D Artagnan rode carrying his horse along between his knees To the furious gallop had succeeded the fast trot and that had sunk to what might be scarcely called a trot at all But the chase appeared equally warm in the two fatigued athletoe D Artagnan quite in despair seized his second pistol and cocked it

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: At your horse! not at you! cried he to Fouquet. And he fired. The animal was hit in the quartershe made a furious bound, and plunged forward. At that moment D'Artagnan's horse fell dead.
children.prevalue: At your horse not at you cried he to Fouquet And he fired The animal was hit in the quartershe made a furious bound and plunged forward At that moment D Artagnan s horse fell dead

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I am dishonored! thought the musketeer I am a miserable wretch! for pity's sake, M. Fouquet, throw me one of your pistols, that I may blow out my brains! But Fouquet rode away.
children.prevalue: I am dishonored thought the musketeer I am a miserable wretch for pity s sake M Fouquet throw me one of your pistols that I may blow out my brains But Fouquet rode away

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: For mercy's sake! for mercy's sake! cried D'Artagnan that which you will not do at this moment, I myself will do within an hour, but here, upon this road, I should die bravely I should die esteemed do me that service, M. Fouquet!
children.prevalue: For mercy s sake for mercy s sake cried D Artagnan that which you will not do at this moment I myself will do within an hour but here upon this road I should die bravely I should die esteemed do me that service M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: M. Fouquet made no reply, but continued to trot on. D'Artagnan began to run after his enemy. Successively he threw away his hat, his coat, which embarrassed him, and then the sheath of his sword, which got between his legs as he was running. The sword in his hand itself became too heavy, and he threw it after the sheath. The white horse began to rattle in its throat D'Artagnan gained upon him. From a trot the exhausted animal sunk to a staggering walkthe foam from his mouth was mixed with blood. D'Artagnan made a desperate effort, sprang towards Fouquet, and seized him by the leg, saying in a broken, breathless voice, I arrest you in the king's name! blow my brains out, if you like we have both done our duty.
children.prevalue: M Fouquet made no reply but continued to trot on D Artagnan began to run after his enemy Successively he threw away his hat his coat which embarrassed him and then the sheath of his sword which got between his legs as he was running The sword in his hand itself became too heavy and he threw it after the sheath The white horse began to rattle in its throat D Artagnan gained upon him From a trot the exhausted animal sunk to a staggering walkthe foam from his mouth was mixed with blood D Artagnan made a desperate effort sprang towards Fouquet and seized him by the leg saying in a broken breathless voice I arrest you in the king s name blow my brains out if you like we have both done our duty

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Fouquet hurled far from him, into the river, the two pistols D'Artagnan might have seized, and dismounting from his horseI am your prisoner, monsieur, said he will you take my arm, for I see you are ready to faint?
children.prevalue: Fouquet hurled far from him into the river the two pistols D Artagnan might have seized and dismounting from his horseI am your prisoner monsieur said he will you take my arm for I see you are ready to faint

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Thanks! murmured D'Artagnan, who, in fact, felt the earth sliding from under his feet, and the light of day turning to blackness around him then he rolled upon the sand, without breath or strength. Fouquet hastened to the brink of the river, dipped some water in his hat, with which he bathed the temples of the musketeer, and introduced a few drop between his lips. D'Artagnan raised himself with difficulty, and looked about him with a wandering eye. He beheld Fouquet on his knees, with his wet hat in his hand, smiling upon him with ineffable sweetness. You are not off, then? cried he. Oh, monsieur! the true king of royalty, in heart, in soul, is not Louis of the Louvre, or Philippe of SainteMarguerite it is you, proscribed, condemned!
children.prevalue: Thanks murmured D Artagnan who in fact felt the earth sliding from under his feet and the light of day turning to blackness around him then he rolled upon the sand without breath or strength Fouquet hastened to the brink of the river dipped some water in his hat with which he bathed the temples of the musketeer and introduced a few drop between his lips D Artagnan raised himself with difficulty and looked about him with a wandering eye He beheld Fouquet on his knees with his wet hat in his hand smiling upon him with ineffable sweetness You are not off then cried he Oh monsieur the true king of royalty in heart in soul is not Louis of the Louvre or Philippe of SainteMarguerite it is you proscribed condemned

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I, who this day am ruined by a single error, M. d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: I who this day am ruined by a single error M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: What, in the name of Heaven, is that?
children.prevalue: What in the name of Heaven is that

children.value: I should have had you for a friend! But how shall we return to Nantes? We are a great way from it.
children.prevalue: I should have had you for a friend But how shall we return to Nantes We are a great way from it

children.value: The white horse will recover, perhaps he is a good horse! Mount, Monsieur d'Artagnan I will walk till you have rested a little.

children.value: Poor beast! and wounded, too? said the musketeer.
children.prevalue: Poor beast and wounded too said the musketeer

children.prevalue: He will go I tell you I know him but we can do better still let us both get up and ride slowly

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: We can try, said the captain. But they had scarcely charged the animal with this double load, when he began to stagger, and then with a great effort walked a few minutes, then staggered again, and sank down dead by the side of the black horse, which he had just managed to come up to.
children.prevalue: We can try said the captain But they had scarcely charged the animal with this double load when he began to stagger and then with a great effort walked a few minutes then staggered again and sank down dead by the side of the black horse which he had just managed to come up to

children.value: We will go on footdestiny wills it sothe walk will be pleasant, said Fouquet, passing his arm through that of D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: We will go on footdestiny wills it sothe walk will be pleasant said Fouquet passing his arm through that of D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Mordioux! cried the latter, with a fixed eye, a contracted brow, and a swelling heartWhat a disgraceful day!

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: They walked slowly the four leagues which separated them from the little wood behind which the carriage and escort were in waiting. When Fouquet perceived that sinister machine, he said to D'Artagnan, who cast down his eyes, ashamed of Louis XIV., There is an idea that did not emanate from a brave man, Captain d'Artagnan it is not yours. What are these gratings for? said he.

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: It was two o'clock in the afternoon. The king, full of impatience, went to his cabinet on the terrace, and kept opening the door of the corridor, to see what his secretaries were doing. M. Colbert, seated in the same place M. de SaintAignan had so long occupied in the morning, was chatting in a low voice with M. de Brienne. The king opened the door suddenly, and addressed them. What is it you are saying?

children.value: Colbert in his calm voice replied, Where does your majesty desire him to be sought for?
children.prevalue: Colbert in his calm voice replied Where does your majesty desire him to be sought for

children.value: Eh! monsieur! do you not know on what I have sent him? replied Louis, acrimoniously.

children.value: Your majesty did not inform me.

children.prevalue: Monsieur there are things that must be guessed and you above all are apt to guess them

children.value: Colbert had not finished these words when a rougher voice than that of the king interrupted the interesting conversation thus begun between the monarch and his clerk.

children.value: D'Artagnan! cried the king, with evident joy.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan cried the king with evident joy

children.prevalue: About M Fouquet s house

children.prevalue: It is humiliating continued the musketeer my soldiers are disgraced I do not command reitres thank you nor clerks of the intendant mordioux

children.prevalue: Well but what is all this about said the king with authority

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: About this, sire monsieurmonsieur, who could not guess your majesty's orders, and consequently could not know I was gone to arrest M. Fouquet monsieur, who has caused the iron cage to be constructed for his patron of yesterdayhas sent M. de Roncherolles to the lodgings of M. Fouquet, and, under the pretense of securing the surintendant's papers, they have taken away the furniture. My musketeers have been posted round the house all the morning such were my orders. Why did any one presume to order them to enter? Why, by forcing them to assist in this pillage, have they been made accomplices in it? Mordioux! we serve the king, we do but we do not serve M. Colbert!

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Monsieur d'Artagnan, said the king, sternly, take care it is not in my presence that such explanations, and made in such a tone, should take place.
children.prevalue: Monsieur d Artagnan said the king sternly take care it is not in my presence that such explanations and made in such a tone should take place

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I have acted for the good of the king, said Colbert, in a faltering voice. It is hard to be so treated by one of your majesty's officers, and that without redress, on account of the respect I owe the king.
children.prevalue: I have acted for the good of the king said Colbert in a faltering voice It is hard to be so treated by one of your majesty s officers and that without redress on account of the respect I owe the king

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The respect you owe the king, cried D'Artagnan, his eyes flashing fire, consists, in the first place, in making his authority respected, and his person beloved. Every agent of a power without control represents that power, and when people curse the hand which strikes them, it is the royal hand that God reproaches, do you hear? Must a soldier, hardened by forty years of wounds and blood, give you this lesson, monsieur? Must mercy be on my side, and ferocity on yours? You have caused the innocent to be arrested, bound, and imprisoned!
children.prevalue: The respect you owe the king cried D Artagnan his eyes flashing fire consists in the first place in making his authority respected and his person beloved Every agent of a power without control represents that power and when people curse the hand which strikes them it is the royal hand that God reproaches do you hear Must a soldier hardened by forty years of wounds and blood give you this lesson monsieur Must mercy be on my side and ferocity on yours You have caused the innocent to be arrested bound and imprisoned

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Accomplices, perhaps, of M. Fouquet, said Colbert.
children.prevalue: Accomplices perhaps of M Fouquet said Colbert

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Who told you M. Fouquet had accomplices, or even that he was guilty? The king alone knows that his justice is not blind! When he says, 'Arrest and imprison' such and such a man, he is obeyed. Do not talk to me, then, any more of the respect you owe the king, and be careful of your words, that they may not chance to convey the slightest menace for the king will not allow those to be threatened who do him service by others who do him disservice and if in case I should have, which God forbid! a master so ungrateful, I would make myself respected.
children.prevalue: Who told you M Fouquet had accomplices or even that he was guilty The king alone knows that his justice is not blind When he says Arrest and imprison such and such a man he is obeyed Do not talk to me then any more of the respect you owe the king and be careful of your words that they may not chance to convey the slightest menace for the king will not allow those to be threatened who do him service by others who do him disservice and if in case I should have which God forbid a master so ungrateful I would make myself respected

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Thus saying, D'Artagnan took his station haughtily in the king's cabinet, his eyes flashing, his hand on his sword, his lips trembling, affecting much more anger than he really felt. Colbert, humiliated and devoured with rage, bowed to the king as if to ask his permission to leave the room. The king, thwarted alike in pride and in curiosity, knew not which part to take. D'Artagnan saw him hesitate. To remain longer would have been a mistake: it was necessary to score a triumph over Colbert, and the only method was to touch the king so near the quick, that his majesty would have no other means of extrication but choosing between the two antagonists. D'Artagnan bowed as Colbert had done but the king, who, in preference to everything else, was anxious to have all the exact details of the arrest of the surintendant of the finances from him who had made him tremble for a moment,the king, perceiving that the illhumor of D'Artagnan would put off for half an hour at least the details he was burning to be acquainted with,Louis, we say, forgot Colbert, who had nothing new to tell him, and recalled his captain of the musketeers.
children.prevalue: Thus saying D Artagnan took his station haughtily in the king s cabinet his eyes flashing his hand on his sword his lips trembling affecting much more anger than he really felt Colbert humiliated and devoured with rage bowed to the king as if to ask his permission to leave the room The king thwarted alike in pride and in curiosity knew not which part to take D Artagnan saw him hesitate To remain longer would have been a mistake it was necessary to score a triumph over Colbert and the only method was to touch the king so near the quick that his majesty would have no other means of extrication but choosing between the two antagonists D Artagnan bowed as Colbert had done but the king who in preference to everything else was anxious to have all the exact details of the arrest of the surintendant of the finances from him who had made him tremble for a moment the king perceiving that the illhumor of D Artagnan would put off for half an hour at least the details he was burning to be acquainted with Louis we say forgot Colbert who had nothing new to tell him and recalled his captain of the musketeers

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: In the first place, said he, let me see the result of your commission, monsieur you may rest yourself hereafter.
children.prevalue: In the first place said he let me see the result of your commission monsieur you may rest yourself hereafter

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: D'Artagnan, who was just passing through the doorway, stopped at the voice of the king, retraced his steps, and Colbert was forced to leave the closet. His countenance assumed almost a purple hue, his black and threatening eyes shone with a dark fire beneath their thick brows he stepped out, bowed before the king, half drew himself up in passing D'Artagnan, and went away with death in his heart. D'Artagnan, on being left alone with the king, softened immediately, and composing his countenance: Sire, said he, you are a young king. It is by the dawn that people judge whether the day will be fine or dull. How, sire, will the people, whom the hand of God has placed under your law, argue of your reign, if between them and you, you allow angry and violent ministers to interpose their mischief? But let us speak of myself, sire, let us leave a discussion that may appear idle, and perhaps inconvenient to you. Let us speak of myself. I have arrested M. Fouquet.

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: You took plenty of time about it, said the king, sharply.
children.prevalue: You took plenty of time about it said the king sharply

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: D'Artagnan looked at the king. I perceive that I have expressed myself badly. I announced to your majesty that I had arrested Monsieur Fouquet.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan looked at the king I perceive that I have expressed myself badly I announced to your majesty that I had arrested Monsieur Fouquet

children.value: You did and what then?
children.prevalue: You did and what then

children.value: Well! I ought to have told your majesty that M. Fouquet had arrested me that would have been more just. I reestablish the truth, then I have been arrested by M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Well I ought to have told your majesty that M Fouquet had arrested me that would have been more just I reestablish the truth then I have been arrested by M Fouquet
