children.value: It was now the turn of Louis XIV. to be surprised. His majesty was astonished in his turn.
children.prevalue: It was now the turn of Louis XIV to be surprised His majesty was astonished in his turn

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: D'Artagnan, with his quick glance, appreciated what was passing in the heart of his master. He did not allow him time to put any questions. He related, with that poetry, that picturesqueness, which perhaps he alone possessed at that period, the escape of Fouquet, the pursuit, the furious race, and, lastly, the inimitable generosity of the surintendant, who might have fled ten times over, who might have killed the adversary in the pursuit, but who had preferred imprisonment, perhaps worse, to the humiliation of one who wished to rob him of his liberty. In proportion as the tale advanced, the king became agitated, devouring the narrator's words, and drumming with his fingernails upon the table.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan with his quick glance appreciated what was passing in the heart of his master He did not allow him time to put any questions He related with that poetry that picturesqueness which perhaps he alone possessed at that period the escape of Fouquet the pursuit the furious race and lastly the inimitable generosity of the surintendant who might have fled ten times over who might have killed the adversary in the pursuit but who had preferred imprisonment perhaps worse to the humiliation of one who wished to rob him of his liberty In proportion as the tale advanced the king became agitated devouring the narrator s words and drumming with his fingernails upon the table

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: It results from all this, sire, in my eyes, at least, that the man who conducts himself thus is a gallant man, and cannot be an enemy to the king. That is my opinion, and I repeat it to your majesty. I know what the king will say to me, and I bow to it,reasons of state. So be it! To my ears that sounds highly respectable. But I am a soldier, and I have received my orders, my orders are executedvery unwillingly on my part, it is true, but they are executed. I say no more.

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Where is M. Fouquet at this moment? asked Louis, after a short silence.
children.prevalue: Where is M Fouquet at this moment asked Louis after a short silence

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: M. Fouquet, sire, replied D'Artagnan, is in the iron cage that M. Colbert had prepared for him, and is galloping as fast as four strong horses can drag him, towards Angers.
children.prevalue: M Fouquet sire replied D Artagnan is in the iron cage that M Colbert had prepared for him and is galloping as fast as four strong horses can drag him towards Angers

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Why did you leave him on the road?
children.prevalue: Why did you leave him on the road

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Because your majesty did not tell me to go to Angers. The proof, the best proof of what I advance, is that the king desired me to be sought for but this minute. And then I had another reason.
children.prevalue: Because your majesty did not tell me to go to Angers The proof the best proof of what I advance is that the king desired me to be sought for but this minute And then I had another reason

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: What is that?
children.prevalue: What is that

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Whilst I was with him, poor M. Fouquet would never attempt to escape.
children.prevalue: Whilst I was with him poor M Fouquet would never attempt to escape

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Well! cried the king, astonished.
children.prevalue: Well cried the king astonished

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Your majesty ought to understand, and does understand, certainly, that my warmest wish is to know that M. Fouquet is at liberty. I have given him one of my brigadiers, the most stupid I could find among my musketeers, in order that the prisoner might have a chance of escaping.
children.prevalue: Your majesty ought to understand and does understand certainly that my warmest wish is to know that M Fouquet is at liberty I have given him one of my brigadiers the most stupid I could find among my musketeers in order that the prisoner might have a chance of escaping

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Are you mad, Monsieur d'Artagnan? cried the king, crossing his arms on his breast. Do people utter such enormities, even when they have the misfortune to think them?
children.prevalue: Are you mad Monsieur d Artagnan cried the king crossing his arms on his breast Do people utter such enormities even when they have the misfortune to think them

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Ah! sire, you cannot expect that I should be an enemy to M. Fouquet, after what he has just done for you and me. No, no if you desire that he should remain under your lock and bolt, never give him in charge to me however closely wired might be the cage, the bird would, in the end, take wing.
children.prevalue: Ah sire you cannot expect that I should be an enemy to M Fouquet after what he has just done for you and me No no if you desire that he should remain under your lock and bolt never give him in charge to me however closely wired might be the cage the bird would in the end take wing

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: I am surprised, said the king, in his sternest tone, you did not follow the fortunes of the man M. Fouquet wished to place upon my throne. You had in him all you wantaffection, gratitude. In my service, monsieur, you will only find a master.
children.prevalue: I am surprised said the king in his sternest tone you did not follow the fortunes of the man M Fouquet wished to place upon my throne You had in him all you wantaffection gratitude In my service monsieur you will only find a master

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: If M. Fouquet had not gone to seek you in the Bastile, sire, replied D'Artagnan, with a deeply impressive manner, one single man would have gone there, and I should have been that manyou know that right well, sire.
children.prevalue: If M Fouquet had not gone to seek you in the Bastile sire replied D Artagnan with a deeply impressive manner one single man would have gone there and I should have been that manyou know that right well sire

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The king was brought to a pause. Before that speech of his captain of the musketeers, so frankly spoken and so true, the king had nothing to offer. On hearing D'Artagnan, Louis remembered the D'Artagnan of former times him who, at the Palais Royal, held himself concealed behind the curtains of his bed, when the people of Paris, led by Cardinal de Retz, came to assure themselves of the presence of the king the D'Artagnan whom he saluted with his hand at the door of his carriage, when repairing to Notre Dame on his return to Paris the soldier who had quitted his service at Blois the lieutenant he had recalled to be beside his person when the death of Mazarin restored his power the man he had always found loyal, courageous, devoted. Louis advanced towards the door and called Colbert. Colbert had not left the corridor where the secretaries were at work. He reappeared.

children.prevalue: What has it produced

children.value: Yes, that I may place it in that of M. d'Artagnan. In fact, M. d'Artagnan, added he, with a smile, turning towards the soldier, who, at sight of the clerk, had resumed his haughty attitude, you do not know this man make his acquaintance. And he pointed to Colbert. He has been made but a moderately valuable servant in subaltern positions, but he will be a great man if I raise him to the foremost rank.

children.value: Sire! stammered Colbert, confused with pleasure and fear.
children.prevalue: Sire stammered Colbert confused with pleasure and fear

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: I always understood why, murmured D'Artagnan in the king's ear he was jealous.
children.prevalue: I always understood why murmured D Artagnan in the king s ear he was jealous

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Precisely, and his jealousy confined his wings.
children.prevalue: Precisely and his jealousy confined his wings

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: He will henceforward be a wingedserpent, grumbled the musketeer, with a remnant of hatred against his recent adversary.
children.prevalue: He will henceforward be a wingedserpent grumbled the musketeer with a remnant of hatred against his recent adversary

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: But Colbert, approaching him, offered to his eyes a physiognomy so different from that which he had been accustomed to see him wear he appeared so good, so mild, so easy his eyes took the expression of an intelligence so noble, that D'Artagnan, a connoisseur in physiognomies, was moved, and almost changed in his convictions. Colbert pressed his hand.

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: That which the king has just told you, monsieur, proves how well his majesty is acquainted with men. The inveterate opposition I have displayed, up to this day, against abuses and not against men, proves that I had it in view to prepare for my king a glorious reign, for my country a great blessing. I have many ideas, M. d'Artagnan. You will see them expand in the sun of public peace and if I have not the good fortune to conquer the friendship of honest men, I am at least certain, monsieur, that I shall obtain their esteem. For their admiration, monsieur, I would give my life.

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: This change, this sudden elevation, this mute approbation of the king, gave the musketeer matter for profound reflection. He bowed civilly to Colbert, who did not take his eyes off him. The king, when he saw they were reconciled, dismissed them. They left the room together. As soon as they were out of the cabinet, the new minister, stopping the captain, said:

children.value: Is it possible, M. d'Artagnan, that with such an eye as yours, you did not, at the first glance, at the first impression, discover what sort of man I am?

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Monsieur Colbert, replied the musketeer, a ray of the sun in our eyes prevents us from seeing the most vivid flame. The man in power radiates, you know and since you are there, why should you continue to persecute him who had just fallen into disgrace, and fallen from such a height?
children.prevalue: Monsieur Colbert replied the musketeer a ray of the sun in our eyes prevents us from seeing the most vivid flame The man in power radiates you know and since you are there why should you continue to persecute him who had just fallen into disgrace and fallen from such a height

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: I, monsieur! said Colbert oh, monsieur! I would never persecute him. I wished to administer the finances and to administer them alone, because I am ambitious, and, above all, because I have the most entire confidence in my own merit because I know that all the gold of this country will ebb and flow beneath my eyes, and I love to look at the king's gold because, if I live thirty years, in thirty years not a denir of it will remain in my hands because, with that gold, I will build granaries, castles, cities, and harbors because I will create a marine, I will equip navies that shall waft the name of France to the most distant people because I will create libraries and academies because I will make France the first country in the world, and the wealthiest. These are the motives for my animosity against M. Fouquet, who prevented my acting. And then, when I shall be great and strong, when France is great and strong, in my turn, then, will I cry, 'Mercy'!

children.value: Mercy, did you say? then ask his liberty of the king. The king is only crushing him on your account.

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Colbert again raised his head. Monsieur, said he, you know that is not so, and that the king has his own personal animosity against M. Fouquet it is not for me to teach you that.

children.value: The king never forgets, M. d'Artagnan. Hark! the king calls. He is going to issue an order. I have not influenced him, have I? Listen.

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: D'Artagnan hung his head in deepest thought, whilst Colbert returned to the king. A quarter of an hour after, the captain received the written order from the king, to blow up the fortress of BelleIsle, in case of resistance, with power of life and death over all the inhabitants or refugees, and an injunction not to allow one to escape.

children.value: Colbert was right, thought D'Artagnan for me the baton of a marechal of France will cost the lives of my two friends. Only they seem to forget that my friends are not more stupid than the birds, and that they will not wait for the hand of the fowler to extend over their wings. I will show them that hand so plainly, that they will have quite time enough to see it. Poor Porthos! Poor Aramis! No my fortune should shall not cost your wings a feather.

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Having thus determined, D'Artagnan assembled the royal army, embarked it at Paimboeuf, and set sail, without the loss of an unnecessary minute.
children.prevalue: Having thus determined D Artagnan assembled the royal army embarked it at Paimboeuf and set sail without the loss of an unnecessary minute

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: At the extremity of the mole, against which the furious sea beats at the evening tide, two men, holding each other by the arm, were conversing in an animated and expansive tone, without the possibility of any other human being hearing their words, borne away, as they were, one by one, by the gusts of wind, with the white foam swept from the crests of the waves. The sun had just gone down in the vast sheet of the crimsoned ocean, like a gigantic crucible. From time to time, one of these men, turning towards the east, cast an anxious, inquiring look over the sea. The other, interrogating the features of his companion, seemed to seek for information in his looks. Then, both silent, busied with dismal thoughts, they resumed their walk. Every one has already perceived that these two men were our proscribed heroes, Porthos and Aramis, who had taken refuge in BelleIsle, since the ruin of their hopes, since the discomfiture of the colossal schemes of M. d'Herblay.
children.prevalue: At the extremity of the mole against which the furious sea beats at the evening tide two men holding each other by the arm were conversing in an animated and expansive tone without the possibility of any other human being hearing their words borne away as they were one by one by the gusts of wind with the white foam swept from the crests of the waves The sun had just gone down in the vast sheet of the crimsoned ocean like a gigantic crucible From time to time one of these men turning towards the east cast an anxious inquiring look over the sea The other interrogating the features of his companion seemed to seek for information in his looks Then both silent busied with dismal thoughts they resumed their walk Every one has already perceived that these two men were our proscribed heroes Porthos and Aramis who had taken refuge in BelleIsle since the ruin of their hopes since the discomfiture of the colossal schemes of M d Herblay

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: If is of no use your saying anything to the contrary, my dear Aramis, repeated Porthos, inhaling vigorously the salt breeze with which he charged his massive chest, It is of no use, Aramis. The disappearance of all the fishingboats that went out two days ago is not an ordinary circumstance. There has been no storm at sea the weather has been constantly calm, not even the lightest gale and even if we had had a tempest, all our boats would not have foundered. I repeat, it is strange. This complete disappearance astonishes me, I tell you.

Here, we are not in France, my dear friend we areI know not where. Oh! I tell you, in full sincerity of soul, and your affection will excuse my frankness, but I declare to you I am not happy at BelleIsle. No in good truth, I am not happy!

children.prevalue: Parbleu Why the orders you have been constantly in and out of season repeating to methat we were to hold BelleIsle against the usurper You know very well

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: That is true! murmured Aramis again.
children.prevalue: That is true murmured Aramis again

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: You see, then, plainly, my friend, that we could not depart and that the sending away of the boats in search of the others cannot prove prejudicial to us in the very least.
children.prevalue: You see then plainly my friend that we could not depart and that the sending away of the boats in search of the others cannot prove prejudicial to us in the very least

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Aramis was silent and his vague glances, luminous as that of an albatross, hovered for a long time over the sea, interrogating space, seeking to pierce the very horizon.
children.prevalue: Aramis was silent and his vague glances luminous as that of an albatross hovered for a long time over the sea interrogating space seeking to pierce the very horizon

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: With all that, Aramis, continued Porthos, who adhered to his idea, and that the more closely from the bishop having apparently endorsed it,with all that, you give me no explanation about what can have happened to these unfortunate boats. I am assailed by cries and complaints whichever way I go. The children cry to see the desolation of the women, as if I could restore the absent husbands and fathers. What do you suppose, my friend, and how ought I to answer them?
children.prevalue: With all that Aramis continued Porthos who adhered to his idea and that the more closely from the bishop having apparently endorsed it with all that you give me no explanation about what can have happened to these unfortunate boats I am assailed by cries and complaints whichever way I go The children cry to see the desolation of the women as if I could restore the absent husbands and fathers What do you suppose my friend and how ought I to answer them

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Think all you like, my good Porthos, and say nothing.
children.prevalue: Think all you like my good Porthos and say nothing

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: This reply did not satisfy Porthos at all. He turned away grumbling something in illhumor. Aramis stopped the valiant musketeer. Do you remember, said he, in a melancholy tone, kneading the two hands of the giant between his own with affectionate cordiality, do you remember, my friend, that in the glorious days of youthdo you remember, Porthos, when we were all strong and valiantwe, and the other twoif we had then had an inclination to return to France, do you think this sheet of salt water would have stopped us?
children.prevalue: This reply did not satisfy Porthos at all He turned away grumbling something in illhumor Aramis stopped the valiant musketeer Do you remember said he in a melancholy tone kneading the two hands of the giant between his own with affectionate cordiality do you remember my friend that in the glorious days of youthdo you remember Porthos when we were all strong and valiantwe and the other twoif we had then had an inclination to return to France do you think this sheet of salt water would have stopped us

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Oh! said Porthos but six leagues.
children.prevalue: Oh said Porthos but six leagues

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: If you had seen me get astride of a plank, would you have remained on land, Porthos?
children.prevalue: If you had seen me get astride of a plank would you have remained on land Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: No, pardieu! No, Aramis. But, nowadays, what sort of a plank should we want, my friend! I, in particular. And the Seigneur de Bracieux cast a profound glance over his colossal rotundity with a loud laugh. And do you mean seriously to say you are not tired of BelleIsle a little, and that you would not prefer the comforts of your dwellingof your episcopal palace, at Vannes? Come, confess.
children.prevalue: No pardieu No Aramis But nowadays what sort of a plank should we want my friend I in particular And the Seigneur de Bracieux cast a profound glance over his colossal rotundity with a loud laugh And do you mean seriously to say you are not tired of BelleIsle a little and that you would not prefer the comforts of your dwellingof your episcopal palace at Vannes Come confess

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: No, replied Aramis, without daring to look at Porthos.
children.prevalue: No replied Aramis without daring to look at Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Let us stay where we are, then, said his friend, with a sigh, which, in spite of the efforts he made to restrain it, escaped his echoing breast. Let us remain!let us remain! And yet, added he, and yet, if we seriously wished, but that decidedlyif we had a fixed idea, one firmly taken, to return to France, and there were not boats
children.prevalue: Let us stay where we are then said his friend with a sigh which in spite of the efforts he made to restrain it escaped his echoing breast Let us remain let us remain And yet added he and yet if we seriously wished but that decidedlyif we had a fixed idea one firmly taken to return to France and there were not boats

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Have you remarked another thing, my friendthat is, since the disappearance of our barks, during the last two days' absence of fishermen, not a single small boat has landed on the shores of the isle?
children.prevalue: Have you remarked another thing my friendthat is since the disappearance of our barks during the last two days absence of fishermen not a single small boat has landed on the shores of the isle

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Yes, certainly! you are right. I, too, have remarked it, and the observation was the more naturally made, for, before the last two fatal days, barks and shallops were as plentiful as shrimps.
children.prevalue: Yes certainly you are right I too have remarked it and the observation was the more naturally made for before the last two fatal days barks and shallops were as plentiful as shrimps

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I must inquire, said Aramis, suddenly, and with great agitation. And then, if we had a raft constructed
children.prevalue: I must inquire said Aramis suddenly and with great agitation And then if we had a raft constructed

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: But there are some canoes, my friend shall I board one?
children.prevalue: But there are some canoes my friend shall I board one

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: A canoe!a canoe! Can you think of such a thing, Porthos? A canoe to be upset in. No, no, said the bishop of Vannes it is not our trade to ride upon the waves. We will wait, we will wait.
children.prevalue: A canoe a canoe Can you think of such a thing Porthos A canoe to be upset in No no said the bishop of Vannes it is not our trade to ride upon the waves We will wait we will wait

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: And Aramis continued walking about with increased agitation. Porthos, who grew tired of following all the feverish movements of his friendPorthos, who in his faith and calmness understood nothing of the sort of exasperation which was betrayed by his companion's continual convulsive startsPorthos stopped him. Let us sit down upon this rock, said he. Place yourself there, close to me, Aramis, and I conjure you, for the last time, to explain to me in a manner I can comprehendexplain to me what we are doing here.
children.prevalue: And Aramis continued walking about with increased agitation Porthos who grew tired of following all the feverish movements of his friendPorthos who in his faith and calmness understood nothing of the sort of exasperation which was betrayed by his companion s continual convulsive startsPorthos stopped him Let us sit down upon this rock said he Place yourself there close to me Aramis and I conjure you for the last time to explain to me in a manner I can comprehendexplain to me what we are doing here

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Porthos, said Aramis, much embarrassed.
children.prevalue: Porthos said Aramis much embarrassed

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I know that the false king wished to dethrone the true king. That is a fact, that I understand. Well
children.prevalue: I know that the false king wished to dethrone the true king That is a fact that I understand Well

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Yes? said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Yes said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: I know that the false king formed the project of selling BelleIsle to the English. I understand that, too.
children.prevalue: I know that the false king formed the project of selling BelleIsle to the English I understand that too

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Yes?
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I know that we engineers and captains came and threw ourselves into BelleIsle to take direction of the works, and the command of ten companies levied and paid by M. Fouquet, or rather the ten companies of his soninlaw. All that is plain.
children.prevalue: I know that we engineers and captains came and threw ourselves into BelleIsle to take direction of the works and the command of ten companies levied and paid by M Fouquet or rather the ten companies of his soninlaw All that is plain

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Aramis rose in a state of great impatience. He might be said to be a lion importuned by a gnat. Porthos held him by the arm. But what I cannot understand, what, in spite of all the efforts of my mind, and all my reflections, I cannot comprehend, and never shall comprehend, is, that instead of sending us troops, instead of sending us reinforcements of men, munitions, provisions, they leave us without boats, they leave BelleIsle without arrivals, without help it is that instead of establishing with us a correspondence, whether by signals, or written or verbal communications, all relations with the shore are intercepted. Tell me, Aramis, answer me, or rather, before answering me, will you allow me to tell you what I have thought? Will you hear what my idea is, the plan I have conceived?
children.prevalue: Aramis rose in a state of great impatience He might be said to be a lion importuned by a gnat Porthos held him by the arm But what I cannot understand what in spite of all the efforts of my mind and all my reflections I cannot comprehend and never shall comprehend is that instead of sending us troops instead of sending us reinforcements of men munitions provisions they leave us without boats they leave BelleIsle without arrivals without help it is that instead of establishing with us a correspondence whether by signals or written or verbal communications all relations with the shore are intercepted Tell me Aramis answer me or rather before answering me will you allow me to tell you what I have thought Will you hear what my idea is the plan I have conceived

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: The bishop raised his head. Well! Aramis, continued Porthos, I have dreamed, I have imagined that an event has taken place in France. I dreamt of M. Fouquet all the night, of lifeless fish, of broken eggs, of chambers badly furnished, meanly kept. Villainous dreams, my dear D'Herblay very unlucky, such dreams!
children.prevalue: The bishop raised his head Well Aramis continued Porthos I have dreamed I have imagined that an event has taken place in France I dreamt of M Fouquet all the night of lifeless fish of broken eggs of chambers badly furnished meanly kept Villainous dreams my dear D Herblay very unlucky such dreams

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Porthos, what is that yonder? interrupted Aramis, rising suddenly, and pointing out to his friend a black spot upon the empurpled line of the water.
children.prevalue: Porthos what is that yonder interrupted Aramis rising suddenly and pointing out to his friend a black spot upon the empurpled line of the water

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: A bark! said Porthos yes, it is a bark! Ah! we shall have some news at last.
children.prevalue: A bark said Porthos yes it is a bark Ah we shall have some news at last

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: There are two! cried the bishop, on discovering another mast two! three! four!
children.prevalue: There are two cried the bishop on discovering another mast two three four

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Five! said Porthos, in his turn. Six! seven! Ah! mon Dieu! mon Dieu! it is a fleet!
children.prevalue: Five said Porthos in his turn Six seven Ah mon Dieu mon Dieu it is a fleet

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Our boats returning, probably, said Aramis, very uneasily, in spite of the assurance he affected.
children.prevalue: Our boats returning probably said Aramis very uneasily in spite of the assurance he affected

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: They are very large for fishingboats, observed Porthos, and do you not remark, my friend, that they come from the Loire?
children.prevalue: They are very large for fishingboats observed Porthos and do you not remark my friend that they come from the Loire

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: They come from the Loireyes
children.prevalue: They come from the Loireyes

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: And look! everybody here sees them as well as ourselves look, women and children are beginning to crowd the jetty.
children.prevalue: And look everybody here sees them as well as ourselves look women and children are beginning to crowd the jetty

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: An old fisherman passed. Are those our barks, yonder? asked Aramis.
children.prevalue: An old fisherman passed Are those our barks yonder asked Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: The old man looked steadily into the eye of the horizon.
children.prevalue: The old man looked steadily into the eye of the horizon

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: No, monseigneur, replied he, they are lighter boars, boats in the king's service.
children.prevalue: No monseigneur replied he they are lighter boars boats in the king s service

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Boats in the royal service? replied Aramis, starting. How do you know that? said he.
children.prevalue: Boats in the royal service replied Aramis starting How do you know that said he

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: By the flag.
children.prevalue: By the flag

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: But, said Porthos, the boat is scarcely visible how the devil, my friend, can you distinguish the flag?
children.prevalue: But said Porthos the boat is scarcely visible how the devil my friend can you distinguish the flag

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: I see there is one, replied the old man our boats, trade lighters, do not carry any. That sort of craft is generally used for transport of troops.
children.prevalue: I see there is one replied the old man our boats trade lighters do not carry any That sort of craft is generally used for transport of troops

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Ah! groaned Aramis.
children.prevalue: Ah groaned Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Vivat! cried Porthos, they are sending us reinforcements, don't you think they are, Aramis?
children.prevalue: Vivat cried Porthos they are sending us reinforcements don t you think they are Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Probably.
children.prevalue: Probably

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Unless it is the English coming.
children.prevalue: Unless it is the English coming

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: By the Loire? That would have an evil look, Porthos for they must have come through Paris!
children.prevalue: By the Loire That would have an evil look Porthos for they must have come through Paris

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: You are right they are reinforcements, decidedly, or provisions.
children.prevalue: You are right they are reinforcements decidedly or provisions

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Aramis leaned his head upon his hands, and made no reply. Then, all at once,Porthos, said he, have the alarm sounded.
children.prevalue: Aramis leaned his head upon his hands and made no reply Then all at once Porthos said he have the alarm sounded

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: The alarm! do you imagine such a thing?
children.prevalue: The alarm do you imagine such a thing

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Yes, and let the cannoniers mount their batteries, the artillerymen be at their pieces, and be particularly watchful of the coast batteries.
children.prevalue: Yes and let the cannoniers mount their batteries the artillerymen be at their pieces and be particularly watchful of the coast batteries

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Porthos opened his eyes to their widest extent. He looked attentively at his friend, to convince himself he was in his proper senses.
children.prevalue: Porthos opened his eyes to their widest extent He looked attentively at his friend to convince himself he was in his proper senses

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: I will do it, my dear Porthos, continued Aramis, in his blandest tone I will go and have these orders executed myself, if you do not go, my friend.
children.prevalue: I will do it my dear Porthos continued Aramis in his blandest tone I will go and have these orders executed myself if you do not go my friend

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Well! I willinstantly! said Porthos, who went to execute the orders, casting all the while looks behind him, to see if the bishop of Vannes were not deceived and if, on recovering more rational ideas, he would not recall him. The alarm was sounded, trumpets brayed, drums rolled the great bronze bell swung in horror from its lofty belfry. The dikes and moles were quickly filled with the curious and soldiers matches sparkled in the hands of the artillerymen, placed behind the large cannon bedded in their stone carriages. When every man was at his post, when all the preparations for defense were made: Permit me, Aramis, to try to comprehend, whispered Porthos, timidly, in Aramis's ear.
children.prevalue: Well I willinstantly said Porthos who went to execute the orders casting all the while looks behind him to see if the bishop of Vannes were not deceived and if on recovering more rational ideas he would not recall him The alarm was sounded trumpets brayed drums rolled the great bronze bell swung in horror from its lofty belfry The dikes and moles were quickly filled with the curious and soldiers matches sparkled in the hands of the artillerymen placed behind the large cannon bedded in their stone carriages When every man was at his post when all the preparations for defense were made Permit me Aramis to try to comprehend whispered Porthos timidly in Aramis s ear

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: My dear friend, you will comprehend but too soon, murmured M. d'Herblay, in reply to this question of his lieutenant.
children.prevalue: My dear friend you will comprehend but too soon murmured M d Herblay in reply to this question of his lieutenant

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: The fleet which is coming yonder, with sails unfurled, straight towards the port of BelleIsle, is a royal fleet, is it not?
children.prevalue: The fleet which is coming yonder with sails unfurled straight towards the port of BelleIsle is a royal fleet is it not

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: But as there are two kings in France, Porthos, to which of these two kings does this fleet belong?
children.prevalue: But as there are two kings in France Porthos to which of these two kings does this fleet belong

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Oh! you open my eyes, replied the giant, stunned by the insinuation.
children.prevalue: Oh you open my eyes replied the giant stunned by the insinuation

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: And Porthos, whose eyes this reply of his friend's had at last opened, or rather thickened the bandage which covered his sight, went with his best speed to the batteries to overlook his people, and exhort every one to do his duty. In the meantime, Aramis, with his eye fixed on the horizon, saw the ships continually drawing nearer. The people and the soldiers, perched on the summits of the rocks, could distinguish the masts, then the lower sails, and at last the hulls of the lighters, bearing at the masthead the royal flag of France. It was night when one of these vessels, which had created such a sensation among the inhabitants of BelleIsle, dropped anchor within cannon shot of the place. It was soon seen, notwithstanding the darkness, that some sort of agitation reigned on board the vessel, from the side of which a skiff was lowered, of which the three rowers, bending to their oars, took the direction of the port, and in a few instants struck land at the foot of the fort. The commander jumped ashore. He had a letter in his hand, which he waved in the air, and seemed to wish to communicate with somebody. This man was soon recognized by several soldiers as one of the pilots of the island. He was the captain of one of the two barks retained by Aramis, but which Porthos, in his anxiety with regard to the fate of the fishermen who had disappeared, had sent in search of the missing boats. He asked to be conducted to M. d'Herblay. Two soldiers, at a signal from a sergeant, marched him between them, and escorted him. Aramis was upon the quay. The envoy presented himself before the bishop of Vannes. The darkness was almost absolute, notwithstanding the flambeaux borne at a small distance by the soldiers who were following Aramis in his rounds.

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Well, Jonathan, from whom do you come?
children.prevalue: Well Jonathan from whom do you come

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Monseigneur, from those who captured me.
children.prevalue: Monseigneur from those who captured me

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Who captured you?
children.prevalue: Who captured you

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: You know, monseigneur, we set out in search of our comrades?
children.prevalue: You know monseigneur we set out in search of our comrades

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Yes and afterwards?
children.prevalue: Yes and afterwards

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Well! monseigneur, within a short league we were captured by a chasse maree belonging to the king.
children.prevalue: Well monseigneur within a short league we were captured by a chasse maree belonging to the king

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Ah! said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Ah said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: Of which king? cried Porthos.
children.prevalue: Of which king cried Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Jonathan started.
children.prevalue: Jonathan started

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Speak! continued the bishop.
children.prevalue: Speak continued the bishop

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: We were captured, monseigneur, and joined to those who had been taken yesterday morning.
children.prevalue: We were captured monseigneur and joined to those who had been taken yesterday morning

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: What was the cause of the mania for capturing you all? said Porthos.
children.prevalue: What was the cause of the mania for capturing you all said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: Monsieur, to prevent us from telling you, replied Jonathan.
children.prevalue: Monsieur to prevent us from telling you replied Jonathan

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Porthos was again at a loss to comprehend. And they have released you today? asked he.
children.prevalue: Porthos was again at a loss to comprehend And they have released you today asked he

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: That I might tell you they have captured us, monsieur.
children.prevalue: That I might tell you they have captured us monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Trouble upon trouble, thought honest Porthos.
children.prevalue: Trouble upon trouble thought honest Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: During this time Aramis was reflecting.
children.prevalue: During this time Aramis was reflecting

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Humph! said he, then I suppose it is a royal fleet blockading the coasts?
children.prevalue: Humph said he then I suppose it is a royal fleet blockading the coasts

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Who commands it?
children.prevalue: Who commands it

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: The captain of the king's musketeers.
children.prevalue: The captain of the king s musketeers

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: D'Artagnan?
children.prevalue: D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: D'Artagnan! exclaimed Porthos.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan exclaimed Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: I believe that is the name.
children.prevalue: I believe that is the name

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: And did he give you this letter?
children.prevalue: And did he give you this letter

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Bring the torches nearer.
children.prevalue: Bring the torches nearer

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: It is his writing, said Porthos.
children.prevalue: It is his writing said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Aramis eagerly read the following lines:
children.prevalue: Aramis eagerly read the following lines

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: Order of the king to take BelleIsle or to put the garrison to the sword, if they resist order to make prisoners of all the men of the garrison signed, D'ARTAGNAN, who, the day before yesterday, arrested M. Fouquet, for the purpose of his being sent to the Bastile.
children.prevalue: Order of the king to take BelleIsle or to put the garrison to the sword if they resist order to make prisoners of all the men of the garrison signed D ARTAGNAN who the day before yesterday arrested M Fouquet for the purpose of his being sent to the Bastile

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Aramis turned pale, and crushed the paper in his hands.
children.prevalue: Aramis turned pale and crushed the paper in his hands

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: What is it? asked Porthos.
children.prevalue: What is it asked Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Nothing, my friend, nothing.
children.prevalue: Nothing my friend nothing

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: Tell me, Jonathan?
children.prevalue: Tell me Jonathan

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: Monseigneur?
children.prevalue: Monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: Did you speak to M. d'Artagnan?
children.prevalue: Did you speak to M d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: What did he say to you?
children.prevalue: What did he say to you

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: That for ampler information, he would speak with monseigneur.
children.prevalue: That for ampler information he would speak with monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: Where?
children.prevalue: Where

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: On board his own vessel.
children.prevalue: On board his own vessel

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: On board his vessel! and Porthos repeated, On board his vessel!
children.prevalue: On board his vessel and Porthos repeated On board his vessel

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: M. le mousquetaire, continued Jonathan, told me to take you both on board my canoe, and bring you to him.
children.prevalue: M le mousquetaire continued Jonathan told me to take you both on board my canoe and bring you to him

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: Let us go at once, exclaimed Porthos. Dear D'Artagnan!
children.prevalue: Let us go at once exclaimed Porthos Dear D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: But Aramis stopped him. Are you mad? cried he. Who knows that it is not a snare?
children.prevalue: But Aramis stopped him Are you mad cried he Who knows that it is not a snare

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: Of the other king's? said Porthos, mysteriously.
children.prevalue: Of the other king s said Porthos mysteriously

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: A snare, in fact! That's what it is, my friend.
children.prevalue: A snare in fact That s what it is my friend

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: Very possibly what is to be done, then? If D'Artagnan sends for us
children.prevalue: Very possibly what is to be done then If D Artagnan sends for us

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: Who assures you that D'Artagnan sends for us?
children.prevalue: Who assures you that D Artagnan sends for us

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Well, butbut his writing
children.prevalue: Well butbut his writing

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Writing is easily counterfeited. This looks counterfeitedunsteady
children.prevalue: Writing is easily counterfeited This looks counterfeitedunsteady

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: You are always right but, in the meantime, we know nothing.
children.prevalue: You are always right but in the meantime we know nothing

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Aramis was silent.
children.prevalue: Aramis was silent

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: It is true, said the good Porthos, we do not want to know anything.
children.prevalue: It is true said the good Porthos we do not want to know anything

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: What shall I do? asked Jonathan.
children.prevalue: What shall I do asked Jonathan

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: You will return on board this captain's vessel.
children.prevalue: You will return on board this captain s vessel

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: And will tell him that we beg he will himself come into the island.
children.prevalue: And will tell him that we beg he will himself come into the island

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: Ah! I comprehend! said Porthos.
children.prevalue: Ah I comprehend said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: Yes, monseigneur, replied Jonathan but if the captain should refuse to come to BelleIsle?
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur replied Jonathan but if the captain should refuse to come to BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: If he refuses, as we have cannon, we will make use of them.
children.prevalue: If he refuses as we have cannon we will make use of them

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: What! against D'Artagnan?
children.prevalue: What against D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: If it is D'Artagnan, Porthos, he will come. Go, Jonathan, go!
children.prevalue: If it is D Artagnan Porthos he will come Go Jonathan go

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: Ma foi! I no longer comprehend anything, murmured Porthos.
children.prevalue: Ma foi I no longer comprehend anything murmured Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: I will make you comprehend it all, my dear friend the time for it has come sit down upon this guncarriage, open your ears, and listen well to me.
children.prevalue: I will make you comprehend it all my dear friend the time for it has come sit down upon this guncarriage open your ears and listen well to me

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Oh! pardieu! I will listen, no fear of that.
children.prevalue: Oh pardieu I will listen no fear of that

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: May I depart, monseigneur? cried Jonathan.
children.prevalue: May I depart monseigneur cried Jonathan

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: Yes, begone, and bring back an answer. Allow the canoe to pass, you men there! And the canoe pushed off to regain the fleet.
children.prevalue: Yes begone and bring back an answer Allow the canoe to pass you men there And the canoe pushed off to regain the fleet

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: Aramis took Porthos by the hand, and commenced his explanations.
children.prevalue: Aramis took Porthos by the hand and commenced his explanations

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: What I have to say to you, friend Porthos, will probably surprise you, but it may prove instructive.
children.prevalue: What I have to say to you friend Porthos will probably surprise you but it may prove instructive

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: I like to be surprised, said Porthos, in a kindly tone do not spare me, therefore, I beg. I am hardened against emotions don't fear, speak out.
children.prevalue: I like to be surprised said Porthos in a kindly tone do not spare me therefore I beg I am hardened against emotions don t fear speak out

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It is difficult, Porthosdifficult for, in truth, I warn you a second time, I have very strange things, very extraordinary things, to tell you.
children.prevalue: It is difficult Porthosdifficult for in truth I warn you a second time I have very strange things very extraordinary things to tell you

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Oh! you speak so well, my friend, that I could listen to you for days together. Speak, then, I begandstop, I have an idea: I will, to make your task more easy, I will, to assist you in telling me such things, question you.
children.prevalue: Oh you speak so well my friend that I could listen to you for days together Speak then I begandstop I have an idea I will to make your task more easy I will to assist you in telling me such things question you

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I shall be pleased at your doing so.
children.prevalue: I shall be pleased at your doing so

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: What are we going to fight for, Aramis?
children.prevalue: What are we going to fight for Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: If you ask me many such questions as thatif you would render my task the easier by interrupting my revelations thus, Porthos, you will not help me at all. So far, on the contrary, that is the very Gordian knot. But, my friend, with a man like you, good, generous, and devoted, the confession must be bravely made. I have deceived you, my worthy friend.
children.prevalue: If you ask me many such questions as thatif you would render my task the easier by interrupting my revelations thus Porthos you will not help me at all So far on the contrary that is the very Gordian knot But my friend with a man like you good generous and devoted the confession must be bravely made I have deceived you my worthy friend

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: You have deceived me!
children.prevalue: You have deceived me

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Good Heavens! yes.
children.prevalue: Good Heavens yes

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Was it for my good, Aramis?
children.prevalue: Was it for my good Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I thought so, Porthos I thought so sincerely, my friend.
children.prevalue: I thought so Porthos I thought so sincerely my friend

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Then, said the honest seigneur of Bracieux, you have rendered me a service, and I thank you for it for if you had not deceived me, I might have deceived myself. In what, then, have you deceived me, tell me?
children.prevalue: Then said the honest seigneur of Bracieux you have rendered me a service and I thank you for it for if you had not deceived me I might have deceived myself In what then have you deceived me tell me

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: In that I was serving the usurper against whom Louis XIV., at this moment, is directing his efforts.
children.prevalue: In that I was serving the usurper against whom Louis XIV at this moment is directing his efforts

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The usurper! said Porthos, scratching his head. That iswell, I do not quite clearly comprehend!
children.prevalue: The usurper said Porthos scratching his head That iswell I do not quite clearly comprehend

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: He is one of the two kings who are contending for the crown of France.
children.prevalue: He is one of the two kings who are contending for the crown of France

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Very well! Then you were serving him who is not Louis XIV.?
children.prevalue: Very well Then you were serving him who is not Louis XIV

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: You have hit the matter in one word.
children.prevalue: You have hit the matter in one word

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: It follows that
children.prevalue: It follows that

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: It follows that we are rebels, my poor friend.
children.prevalue: It follows that we are rebels my poor friend

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The devil! the devil! cried Porthos, much disappointed.
children.prevalue: The devil the devil cried Porthos much disappointed

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Oh! but, dear Porthos, be calm, we shall still find means of getting out of the affair, trust me.
children.prevalue: Oh but dear Porthos be calm we shall still find means of getting out of the affair trust me

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: It is not that which makes me uneasy, replied Porthos that which alone touches me is that ugly word rebels.
children.prevalue: It is not that which makes me uneasy replied Porthos that which alone touches me is that ugly word rebels

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Ah! but
children.prevalue: Ah but

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: And so, according to this, the duchy that was promised me
children.prevalue: And so according to this the duchy that was promised me

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: It was the usurper that was to give it to you.
children.prevalue: It was the usurper that was to give it to you

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: And that is not the same thing, Aramis, said Porthos, majestically.
children.prevalue: And that is not the same thing Aramis said Porthos majestically

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: My friend, if it had only depended upon me, you should have become a prince.
children.prevalue: My friend if it had only depended upon me you should have become a prince

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Porthos began to bite his nails in a melancholy way.
children.prevalue: Porthos began to bite his nails in a melancholy way

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: That is where you have been wrong, continued he, in deceiving me for that promised duchy I reckoned upon. Oh! I reckoned upon it seriously, knowing you to be a man of your word, Aramis.
children.prevalue: That is where you have been wrong continued he in deceiving me for that promised duchy I reckoned upon Oh I reckoned upon it seriously knowing you to be a man of your word Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Poor Porthos! pardon me, I implore you!
children.prevalue: Poor Porthos pardon me I implore you

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: So, then, continued Porthos, without replying to the bishop's prayer, so then, it seems, I have quite fallen out with Louis XIV.?
children.prevalue: So then continued Porthos without replying to the bishop s prayer so then it seems I have quite fallen out with Louis XIV

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Oh! I will settle all that, my good friend, I will settle all that. I will take it on myself alone!
children.prevalue: Oh I will settle all that my good friend I will settle all that I will take it on myself alone

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Aramis!
children.prevalue: Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: No, no, Porthos, I conjure you, let me act. No false generosity! No inopportune devotedness! You knew nothing of my projects. You have done nothing of yourself. With me it is different. I alone am the author of this plot. I stood in need of my inseparable companion I called upon you, and you came to me in remembrance of our ancient device, 'All for one, one for all.' My crime is that I was an egotist.
children.prevalue: No no Porthos I conjure you let me act No false generosity No inopportune devotedness You knew nothing of my projects You have done nothing of yourself With me it is different I alone am the author of this plot I stood in need of my inseparable companion I called upon you and you came to me in remembrance of our ancient device All for one one for all My crime is that I was an egotist

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Now, that is a word I like, said Porthos and seeing that you have acted entirely for yourself, it is impossible for me to blame you. It is natural.
children.prevalue: Now that is a word I like said Porthos and seeing that you have acted entirely for yourself it is impossible for me to blame you It is natural

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: And upon this sublime reflection, Porthos pressed his friend's hand cordially.
children.prevalue: And upon this sublime reflection Porthos pressed his friend s hand cordially

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: In presence of this ingenuous greatness of soul, Aramis felt his own littleness. It was the second time he had been compelled to bend before real superiority of heart, which is more imposing than brilliancy of mind. He replied by a mute and energetic pressure to the endearment of his friend.
children.prevalue: In presence of this ingenuous greatness of soul Aramis felt his own littleness It was the second time he had been compelled to bend before real superiority of heart which is more imposing than brilliancy of mind He replied by a mute and energetic pressure to the endearment of his friend

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Now, said Porthos, that we have come to an explanation, now that I am perfectly aware of our situation with respect to Louis XIV., I think, my friend, it is time to make me comprehend the political intrigue of which we are the victimsfor I plainly see there is a political intrigue at the bottom of all this.
children.prevalue: Now said Porthos that we have come to an explanation now that I am perfectly aware of our situation with respect to Louis XIV I think my friend it is time to make me comprehend the political intrigue of which we are the victimsfor I plainly see there is a political intrigue at the bottom of all this

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: D'Artagnan, my good Porthos, D'Artagnan is coming, and will detail it to you in all its circumstances but, excuse me, I am deeply grieved, I am bowed down with mental anguish, and I have need of all my presence of mind, all my powers of reflection, to extricate you from the false position in which I have so imprudently involved you but nothing can be more clear, nothing more plain, than your position, henceforth. The king Louis XIV. has no longer now but one enemy: that enemy is myself, myself alone. I have made you a prisoner, you have followed me, today I liberate you, you fly back to your prince. You can perceive, Porthos, there is not one difficulty in all this.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan my good Porthos D Artagnan is coming and will detail it to you in all its circumstances but excuse me I am deeply grieved I am bowed down with mental anguish and I have need of all my presence of mind all my powers of reflection to extricate you from the false position in which I have so imprudently involved you but nothing can be more clear nothing more plain than your position henceforth The king Louis XIV has no longer now but one enemy that enemy is myself myself alone I have made you a prisoner you have followed me today I liberate you you fly back to your prince You can perceive Porthos there is not one difficulty in all this

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Do you think so? said Porthos.
children.prevalue: Do you think so said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I am quite sure of it.
children.prevalue: I am quite sure of it

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Then why, said the admirable good sense of Porthos, then why, if we are in such an easy position, why, my friend, do we prepare cannon, muskets, and engines of all sorts? It seems to me it would be much more simple to say to Captain d'Artagnan: 'My dear friend, we have been mistaken that error is to be repaired open the door to us, let us pass through, and we will say goodbye.'
children.prevalue: Then why said the admirable good sense of Porthos then why if we are in such an easy position why my friend do we prepare cannon muskets and engines of all sorts It seems to me it would be much more simple to say to Captain d Artagnan My dear friend we have been mistaken that error is to be repaired open the door to us let us pass through and we will say goodbye

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Ah! that! said Aramis, shaking his head.
children.prevalue: Ah that said Aramis shaking his head

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Why do you say 'that'? Do you not approve of my plan, my friend?
children.prevalue: Why do you say that Do you not approve of my plan my friend

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: I see a difficulty in it.
children.prevalue: I see a difficulty in it

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: What is it?
children.prevalue: What is it

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: The hypothesis that D'Artagnan may come with orders which will oblige us to defend ourselves.
children.prevalue: The hypothesis that D Artagnan may come with orders which will oblige us to defend ourselves

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: What! defend ourselves against D'Artagnan? Folly! Against the good D'Artagnan!
children.prevalue: What defend ourselves against D Artagnan Folly Against the good D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Aramis once more replied by shaking his head.
children.prevalue: Aramis once more replied by shaking his head

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Porthos, at length said he, if I have had the matches lighted and the guns pointed, if I have had the signal of alarm sounded, if I have called every man to his post upon the ramparts, those good ramparts of BelleIsle which you have so well fortified, it was not for nothing. Wait to judge or rather, no, do not wait
children.prevalue: Porthos at length said he if I have had the matches lighted and the guns pointed if I have had the signal of alarm sounded if I have called every man to his post upon the ramparts those good ramparts of BelleIsle which you have so well fortified it was not for nothing Wait to judge or rather no do not wait

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: What can I do?
children.prevalue: What can I do

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: If I knew, my friend, I would have told you.
children.prevalue: If I knew my friend I would have told you

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: But there is one thing much more simple than defending ourselves:a boat, and away for Francewhere
children.prevalue: But there is one thing much more simple than defending ourselves a boat and away for Francewhere

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: My dear friend, said Aramis, smiling with a strong shade of sadness, do not let us reason like children let us be men in council and in execution.But, hark! I hear a hail for landing at the port. Attention, Porthos, serious attention!
children.prevalue: My dear friend said Aramis smiling with a strong shade of sadness do not let us reason like children let us be men in council and in execution But hark I hear a hail for landing at the port Attention Porthos serious attention

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: It is D'Artagnan, no doubt, said Porthos, in a voice of thunder, approaching the parapet.
children.prevalue: It is D Artagnan no doubt said Porthos in a voice of thunder approaching the parapet

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Yes, it is I, replied the captain of the musketeers, running lightly up the steps of the mole, and gaining rapidly the little esplanade on which his two friends waited for him. As soon as he came towards them, Porthos and Aramis observed an officer who followed D'Artagnan, treading apparently in his very steps. The captain stopped upon the stairs of the mole, when halfway up. His companions imitated him.
children.prevalue: Yes it is I replied the captain of the musketeers running lightly up the steps of the mole and gaining rapidly the little esplanade on which his two friends waited for him As soon as he came towards them Porthos and Aramis observed an officer who followed D Artagnan treading apparently in his very steps The captain stopped upon the stairs of the mole when halfway up His companions imitated him

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Make your men draw back, cried D'Artagnan to Porthos and Aramis let them retire out of hearing. This order, given by Porthos, was executed immediately. Then D'Artagnan, turning towards him who followed him:
children.prevalue: Make your men draw back cried D Artagnan to Porthos and Aramis let them retire out of hearing This order given by Porthos was executed immediately Then D Artagnan turning towards him who followed him

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Monsieur, said he, we are no longer on board the king's fleet, where, in virtue of your order, you spoke so arrogantly to me, just now.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said he we are no longer on board the king s fleet where in virtue of your order you spoke so arrogantly to me just now

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Monsieur, replied the officer, I did not speak arrogantly to you I simply, but rigorously, obeyed instructions. I was commanded to follow you. I follow you. I am directed not to allow you to communicate with any one without taking cognizance of what you do I am in duty bound, accordingly, to overhear your conversations.
children.prevalue: Monsieur replied the officer I did not speak arrogantly to you I simply but rigorously obeyed instructions I was commanded to follow you I follow you I am directed not to allow you to communicate with any one without taking cognizance of what you do I am in duty bound accordingly to overhear your conversations

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: D'Artagnan trembled with rage, and Porthos and Aramis, who heard this dialogue, trembled likewise, but with uneasiness and fear. D'Artagnan, biting his mustache with that vivacity which denoted in him exasperation, closely to be followed by an explosion, approached the officer.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan trembled with rage and Porthos and Aramis who heard this dialogue trembled likewise but with uneasiness and fear D Artagnan biting his mustache with that vivacity which denoted in him exasperation closely to be followed by an explosion approached the officer

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Monsieur, said he, in a low voice, so much the more impressive, that, affecting calm, it threatened tempestmonsieur, when I sent a canoe hither, you wished to know what I wrote to the defenders of BelleIsle. You produced an order to that effect and, in my turn, I instantly showed you the note I had written. When the skipper of the boat sent by me returned, when I received the reply of these two gentlemen (and he pointed to Aramis and Porthos), you heard every word of what the messenger said. All that was plainly in your orders, all that was well executed, very punctually, was it not?
children.prevalue: Monsieur said he in a low voice so much the more impressive that affecting calm it threatened tempestmonsieur when I sent a canoe hither you wished to know what I wrote to the defenders of BelleIsle You produced an order to that effect and in my turn I instantly showed you the note I had written When the skipper of the boat sent by me returned when I received the reply of these two gentlemen and he pointed to Aramis and Porthos you heard every word of what the messenger said All that was plainly in your orders all that was well executed very punctually was it not

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Yes, monsieur, stammered the officer yes, without doubt, but
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur stammered the officer yes without doubt but

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Monsieur, continued D'Artagnan, growing warmmonsieur, when I manifested the intention of quitting my vessel to cross to BelleIsle, you demanded to accompany me I did not hesitate I brought you with me. You are now at BelleIsle, are you not?
children.prevalue: Monsieur continued D Artagnan growing warmmonsieur when I manifested the intention of quitting my vessel to cross to BelleIsle you demanded to accompany me I did not hesitate I brought you with me You are now at BelleIsle are you not

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Yes, monsieur but
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur but

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Butthe question no longer is of M. Colbert, who has given you that order, or of whomsoever in the world you are following the instructions the question now is of a man who is a clog upon M. d'Artagnan, and who is alone with M. d'Artagnan upon steps whose feet are bathed by thirty feet of salt water a bad position for that man, a bad position, monsieur! I warn you.
children.prevalue: Butthe question no longer is of M Colbert who has given you that order or of whomsoever in the world you are following the instructions the question now is of a man who is a clog upon M d Artagnan and who is alone with M d Artagnan upon steps whose feet are bathed by thirty feet of salt water a bad position for that man a bad position monsieur I warn you

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: But, monsieur, if I am a restraint upon you, said the officer, timidly, and almost faintly, it is my duty which
children.prevalue: But monsieur if I am a restraint upon you said the officer timidly and almost faintly it is my duty which

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Monsieur, you have had the misfortune, either you or those that sent you, to insult me. It is done. I cannot seek redress from those who employ you,they are unknown to me, or are at too great a distance. But you are under my hand, and I swear that if you make one step behind me when I raise my feet to go up to those gentlemen, I swear to you by my name, I will cleave your head in two with my sword, and pitch you into the water. Oh! it will happen! it will happen! I have only been six times angry in my life, monsieur, and all five preceding times I killed my man.
children.prevalue: Monsieur you have had the misfortune either you or those that sent you to insult me It is done I cannot seek redress from those who employ you they are unknown to me or are at too great a distance But you are under my hand and I swear that if you make one step behind me when I raise my feet to go up to those gentlemen I swear to you by my name I will cleave your head in two with my sword and pitch you into the water Oh it will happen it will happen I have only been six times angry in my life monsieur and all five preceding times I killed my man

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: The officer did not stir he became pale under this terrible threat, but replied with simplicity, Monsieur, you are wrong in acting against my orders.
children.prevalue: The officer did not stir he became pale under this terrible threat but replied with simplicity Monsieur you are wrong in acting against my orders

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Porthos and Aramis, mute and trembling at the top of the parapet, cried to the musketeer, Good D'Artagnan, take care!
children.prevalue: Porthos and Aramis mute and trembling at the top of the parapet cried to the musketeer Good D Artagnan take care

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: D'Artagnan made them a sign to keep silence, raised his foot with ominous calmness to mount the stair, and turned round, sword in hand, to see if the officer followed him. The officer made a sign of the cross and stepped up. Porthos and Aramis, who knew their D'Artagnan, uttered a cry, and rushed down to prevent the blow they thought they already heard. But D'Artagnan passed his sword into his left hand,
children.prevalue: D Artagnan made them a sign to keep silence raised his foot with ominous calmness to mount the stair and turned round sword in hand to see if the officer followed him The officer made a sign of the cross and stepped up Porthos and Aramis who knew their D Artagnan uttered a cry and rushed down to prevent the blow they thought they already heard But D Artagnan passed his sword into his left hand

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Monsieur, said he to the officer, in an agitated voice, you are a brave man. You will all the better comprehend what I am going to say to you now.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said he to the officer in an agitated voice you are a brave man You will all the better comprehend what I am going to say to you now

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Speak, Monsieur d'Artagnan, speak, replied the officer.
children.prevalue: Speak Monsieur d Artagnan speak replied the officer

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: These gentlemen we have just seen, and against whom you have orders, are my friends.
children.prevalue: These gentlemen we have just seen and against whom you have orders are my friends

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: I know they are, monsieur.
children.prevalue: I know they are monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: You can understand whether or not I ought to act towards them as your instructions prescribe.
children.prevalue: You can understand whether or not I ought to act towards them as your instructions prescribe

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: I understand your reserve.
children.prevalue: I understand your reserve

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Very well permit me, then, to converse with them without a witness.
children.prevalue: Very well permit me then to converse with them without a witness

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Monsieur d'Artagnan, if I yield to your request, if I do that which you beg me, I break my word but if I do not do it, I disoblige you. I prefer the one dilemma to the other. Converse with your friends, and do not despise me, monsieur, for doing this for your sake, whom I esteem and honor do not despise me for committing for you, and you alone, an unworthy act. D'Artagnan, much agitated, threw his arm round the neck of the young man, and then went up to his friends. The officer, enveloped in his cloak, sat down on the damp, weedcovered steps.
children.prevalue: Monsieur d Artagnan if I yield to your request if I do that which you beg me I break my word but if I do not do it I disoblige you I prefer the one dilemma to the other Converse with your friends and do not despise me monsieur for doing this for your sake whom I esteem and honor do not despise me for committing for you and you alone an unworthy act D Artagnan much agitated threw his arm round the neck of the young man and then went up to his friends The officer enveloped in his cloak sat down on the damp weedcovered steps

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Well! said D'Artagnan to his friends, such is my position, judge for yourselves. All three embraced as in the glorious days of their youth.
children.prevalue: Well said D Artagnan to his friends such is my position judge for yourselves All three embraced as in the glorious days of their youth

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: What is the meaning of all these preparations? said Porthos.
children.prevalue: What is the meaning of all these preparations said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: You ought to have a suspicion of what they signify, said D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: You ought to have a suspicion of what they signify said D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Not any, I assure you, my dear captain for, in fact, I have done nothing, no more has Aramis, the worthy baron hastened to say.
children.prevalue: Not any I assure you my dear captain for in fact I have done nothing no more has Aramis the worthy baron hastened to say

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: D'Artagnan darted a reproachful look at the prelate, which penetrated that hardened heart.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan darted a reproachful look at the prelate which penetrated that hardened heart

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Dear Porthos! cried the bishop of Vannes.
children.prevalue: Dear Porthos cried the bishop of Vannes

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: You see what is being done against you, said D'Artagnan interception of all boats coming to or going from BelleIsle. Your means of transport seized. If you had endeavored to fly, you would have fallen into the hands of the cruisers that plow the sea in all directions, on the watch for you. The king wants you to be taken, and he will take you. D'Artagnan tore at his gray mustache. Aramis grew somber, Porthos angry.
children.prevalue: You see what is being done against you said D Artagnan interception of all boats coming to or going from BelleIsle Your means of transport seized If you had endeavored to fly you would have fallen into the hands of the cruisers that plow the sea in all directions on the watch for you The king wants you to be taken and he will take you D Artagnan tore at his gray mustache Aramis grew somber Porthos angry

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: My idea was this, continued D'Artagnan: to make you both come on board, to keep you near me, and restore you your liberty. But now, who can say, when I return to my ship, I may not find a superior that I may not find secret orders which will take from me my command, and give it to another, who will dispose of me and you without hope of help?
