children.prevalue: My idea was this continued D Artagnan to make you both come on board to keep you near me and restore you your liberty But now who can say when I return to my ship I may not find a superior that I may not find secret orders which will take from me my command and give it to another who will dispose of me and you without hope of help

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: We must remain at BelleIsle, said Aramis, resolutely and I assure you, for my part, I will not surrender easily. Porthos said nothing. D'Artagnan remarked the silence of his friend.
children.prevalue: We must remain at BelleIsle said Aramis resolutely and I assure you for my part I will not surrender easily Porthos said nothing D Artagnan remarked the silence of his friend

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: I have another trial to make of this officer, of this brave fellow who accompanies me, and whose courageous resistance makes me very happy for it denotes an honest man, who, though an enemy, is a thousand times better than a complaisant coward. Let us try to learn from him what his instructions are, and what his orders permit or forbid.
children.prevalue: I have another trial to make of this officer of this brave fellow who accompanies me and whose courageous resistance makes me very happy for it denotes an honest man who though an enemy is a thousand times better than a complaisant coward Let us try to learn from him what his instructions are and what his orders permit or forbid

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Let us try, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Let us try said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: D'Artagnan went to the parapet, leaned over towards the steps of the mole, and called the officer, who immediately came up. Monsieur, said D'Artagnan, after having exchanged the cordial courtesies natural between gentlemen who know and appreciate each other, monsieur, if I wished to take away these gentlemen from here, what would you do?
children.prevalue: D Artagnan went to the parapet leaned over towards the steps of the mole and called the officer who immediately came up Monsieur said D Artagnan after having exchanged the cordial courtesies natural between gentlemen who know and appreciate each other monsieur if I wished to take away these gentlemen from here what would you do

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: I should not oppose it, monsieur but having direct explicit orders to put them under guard, I should detain them.
children.prevalue: I should not oppose it monsieur but having direct explicit orders to put them under guard I should detain them

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: Ah! said D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Ah said D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: That's all over, said Aramis, gloomily. Porthos did not stir.
children.prevalue: That s all over said Aramis gloomily Porthos did not stir

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: But still take Porthos, said the bishop of Vannes. He can prove to the king, and I will help him do so, and you too, Monsieur d'Artagnan, that he had nothing to do with this affair.
children.prevalue: But still take Porthos said the bishop of Vannes He can prove to the king and I will help him do so and you too Monsieur d Artagnan that he had nothing to do with this affair

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Hum! said D'Artagnan. Will you come? Will you follow me, Porthos? The king is merciful.
children.prevalue: Hum said D Artagnan Will you come Will you follow me Porthos The king is merciful

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: I want time for reflection, said Porthos.
children.prevalue: I want time for reflection said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: You will remain here, then?
children.prevalue: You will remain here then

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Until fresh orders, said Aramis, with vivacity.
children.prevalue: Until fresh orders said Aramis with vivacity

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: Until we have an idea, resumed D'Artagnan and I now believe that will not be long, for I have one already.
children.prevalue: Until we have an idea resumed D Artagnan and I now believe that will not be long for I have one already

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Let us say adieu, then, said Aramis but in truth, my good Porthos, you ought to go.
children.prevalue: Let us say adieu then said Aramis but in truth my good Porthos you ought to go

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: No, said the latter, laconically.
children.prevalue: No said the latter laconically

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: As you please, replied Aramis, a little wounded in his susceptibilities at the morose tone of his companion. Only I am reassured by the promise of an idea from D'Artagnan, an idea I fancy I have divined.
children.prevalue: As you please replied Aramis a little wounded in his susceptibilities at the morose tone of his companion Only I am reassured by the promise of an idea from D Artagnan an idea I fancy I have divined

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Let us see, said the musketeer, placing his ear near Aramis's mouth. The latter spoke several words rapidly, to which D'Artagnan replied, That is it, precisely.
children.prevalue: Let us see said the musketeer placing his ear near Aramis s mouth The latter spoke several words rapidly to which D Artagnan replied That is it precisely

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Infallible! cried Aramis.
children.prevalue: Infallible cried Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: During the first emotion this resolution will cause, take care of yourself, Aramis.
children.prevalue: During the first emotion this resolution will cause take care of yourself Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_106
children.value: Oh! don't be afraid.
children.prevalue: Oh don t be afraid

children.name: Paragraph_107
children.value: Now, monsieur, said D'Artagnan to the officer, thanks, a thousand thanks! You have made yourself three friends for life.
children.prevalue: Now monsieur said D Artagnan to the officer thanks a thousand thanks You have made yourself three friends for life

children.name: Paragraph_108
children.value: Yes, added Aramis. Porthos alone said nothing, but merely bowed.
children.prevalue: Yes added Aramis Porthos alone said nothing but merely bowed

children.name: Paragraph_109
children.value: D'Artagnan, having tenderly embraced his two old friends, left BelleIsle with the inseparable companion with whom M. Colbert had saddled him. Thus, with the exception of the explanation with which the worthy Porthos had been willing to be satisfied, nothing had changed in appearance in the fate of one or the other, Only, said Aramis, there is D'Artagnan's idea.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan having tenderly embraced his two old friends left BelleIsle with the inseparable companion with whom M Colbert had saddled him Thus with the exception of the explanation with which the worthy Porthos had been willing to be satisfied nothing had changed in appearance in the fate of one or the other Only said Aramis there is D Artagnan s idea

children.name: Paragraph_110
children.value: D'Artagnan did not return on board without profoundly analyzing the idea he had discovered. Now, we know that whatever D'Artagnan did examine, according to custom, daylight was certain to illuminate. As to the officer, now grown mute again, he had full time for meditation. Therefore, on putting his foot on board his vessel, moored within cannonshot of the island, the captain of the musketeers had already got together all his means, offensive and defensive.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan did not return on board without profoundly analyzing the idea he had discovered Now we know that whatever D Artagnan did examine according to custom daylight was certain to illuminate As to the officer now grown mute again he had full time for meditation Therefore on putting his foot on board his vessel moored within cannonshot of the island the captain of the musketeers had already got together all his means offensive and defensive

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: He immediately assembled his council, which consisted of the officers serving under his orders. These were eight in number a chief of the maritime forces a major directing the artillery an engineer, the officer we are acquainted with, and four lieutenants. Having assembled them, D'Artagnan arose, took of his hat, and addressed them thus:
children.prevalue: He immediately assembled his council which consisted of the officers serving under his orders These were eight in number a chief of the maritime forces a major directing the artillery an engineer the officer we are acquainted with and four lieutenants Having assembled them D Artagnan arose took of his hat and addressed them thus

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Gentlemen, I have been to reconnoiter BelleIleenMer, and I have found in it a good and solid garrison moreover, preparations are made for a defense that may prove troublesome. I therefore intend to send for two of the principal officers of the place, that we may converse with them. Having separated them from their troops and cannon, we shall be better able to deal with them particularly by reasoning with them. Is not this your opinion, gentlemen?
children.prevalue: Gentlemen I have been to reconnoiter BelleIleenMer and I have found in it a good and solid garrison moreover preparations are made for a defense that may prove troublesome I therefore intend to send for two of the principal officers of the place that we may converse with them Having separated them from their troops and cannon we shall be better able to deal with them particularly by reasoning with them Is not this your opinion gentlemen

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: The major of artillery rose.
children.prevalue: The major of artillery rose

children.name: Paragraph_114
children.value: Monsieur, said he, with respect, but firmness, I have heard you say that the place is preparing to make a troublesome defense. The place is then, as you know, determined on rebellion?
children.prevalue: Monsieur said he with respect but firmness I have heard you say that the place is preparing to make a troublesome defense The place is then as you know determined on rebellion

children.name: Paragraph_115
children.value: D'Artagnan was visibly put out by this reply but he was not the man to allow himself to be subdued by a trifle, and resumed:
children.prevalue: D Artagnan was visibly put out by this reply but he was not the man to allow himself to be subdued by a trifle and resumed

children.name: Paragraph_116
children.value: Monsieur, said he, your reply is just. But you are ignorant that BelleIsle is a fief of M. Fouquet's, and that former monarchs gave the right to the seigneurs of BelleIsle to arm their people. The major made a movement. Oh! do not interrupt me, continued D'Artagnan. You are going to tell me that that right to arm themselves against the English was not a right to arm themselves against their king. But it is not M. Fouquet, I suppose, who holds BelleIsle at this moment, since I arrested M. Fouquet the day before yesterday. Now the inhabitants and defenders of BelleIsle know nothing of this arrest. You would announce it to them in vain. It is a thing so unheardof and extraordinary, so unexpected, that they would not believe you. A Breton serves his master, and not his masters he serves his master till he has seen him dead. Now the Bretons, as far as I know, have not seen the body of M. Fouquet. It is not, then, surprising they hold out against that which is neither M. Fouquet nor his signature.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said he your reply is just But you are ignorant that BelleIsle is a fief of M Fouquet s and that former monarchs gave the right to the seigneurs of BelleIsle to arm their people The major made a movement Oh do not interrupt me continued D Artagnan You are going to tell me that that right to arm themselves against the English was not a right to arm themselves against their king But it is not M Fouquet I suppose who holds BelleIsle at this moment since I arrested M Fouquet the day before yesterday Now the inhabitants and defenders of BelleIsle know nothing of this arrest You would announce it to them in vain It is a thing so unheardof and extraordinary so unexpected that they would not believe you A Breton serves his master and not his masters he serves his master till he has seen him dead Now the Bretons as far as I know have not seen the body of M Fouquet It is not then surprising they hold out against that which is neither M Fouquet nor his signature

children.name: Paragraph_117
children.value: The major bowed in token of assent.
children.prevalue: The major bowed in token of assent

children.name: Paragraph_118
children.value: That is why, continued D'Artagnan, I propose to cause two of the principal officers of the garrison to come on board my vessel. They will see you, gentlemen they will see the forces we have at our disposal they will consequently know to what they have to trust, and the fate that attends them, in case of rebellion. We will affirm to them, upon our honor, that M. Fouquet is a prisoner, and that all resistance can only be prejudicial to them. We will tell them that at the first cannon fired, there will be no further hope of mercy from the king. Then, or so at least I trust, they will resist no longer. They will yield up without fighting, and we shall have a place given up to us in a friendly way which it might cost prodigious efforts to subdue.
children.prevalue: That is why continued D Artagnan I propose to cause two of the principal officers of the garrison to come on board my vessel They will see you gentlemen they will see the forces we have at our disposal they will consequently know to what they have to trust and the fate that attends them in case of rebellion We will affirm to them upon our honor that M Fouquet is a prisoner and that all resistance can only be prejudicial to them We will tell them that at the first cannon fired there will be no further hope of mercy from the king Then or so at least I trust they will resist no longer They will yield up without fighting and we shall have a place given up to us in a friendly way which it might cost prodigious efforts to subdue

children.name: Paragraph_119
children.value: The officer who had followed D'Artagnan to BelleIsle was preparing to speak, but D'Artagnan interrupted him.
children.prevalue: The officer who had followed D Artagnan to BelleIsle was preparing to speak but D Artagnan interrupted him

children.name: Paragraph_120
children.value: Yes, I know what you are going to tell me, monsieur I know that there is an order of the king's to prevent all secret communications with the defenders of BelleIsle, and that is exactly why I do not offer to communicate except in presence of my staff.
children.prevalue: Yes I know what you are going to tell me monsieur I know that there is an order of the king s to prevent all secret communications with the defenders of BelleIsle and that is exactly why I do not offer to communicate except in presence of my staff

children.name: Paragraph_121
children.value: And D'Artagnan made an inclination of the head to his officers, who knew him well enough to attach a certain value to the condescension.
children.prevalue: And D Artagnan made an inclination of the head to his officers who knew him well enough to attach a certain value to the condescension

children.name: Paragraph_122
children.value: The officers looked at each other as if to read each other's opinions in their eyes, with the intention of evidently acting, should they agree, according to the desire of D'Artagnan. And already the latter saw with joy that the result of their consent would be sending a bark to Porthos and Aramis, when the king's officer drew from a pocket a folded paper, which he placed in the hands of D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: The officers looked at each other as if to read each other s opinions in their eyes with the intention of evidently acting should they agree according to the desire of D Artagnan And already the latter saw with joy that the result of their consent would be sending a bark to Porthos and Aramis when the king s officer drew from a pocket a folded paper which he placed in the hands of D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_123
children.value: This paper bore upon its superscription the number 1.
children.prevalue: This paper bore upon its superscription the number 1

children.name: Paragraph_124
children.value: What, more! murmured the surprised captain.
children.prevalue: What more murmured the surprised captain

children.name: Paragraph_125
children.value: Read, monsieur, said the officer, with a courtesy that was not free from sadness.
children.prevalue: Read monsieur said the officer with a courtesy that was not free from sadness

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: D'Artagnan, full of mistrust, unfolded the paper, and read these words: Prohibition to M. d'Artagnan to assemble any council whatever, or to deliberate in any way before BelleIsle be surrendered and the prisoners shot. SignedLOUIS.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan full of mistrust unfolded the paper and read these words Prohibition to M d Artagnan to assemble any council whatever or to deliberate in any way before BelleIsle be surrendered and the prisoners shot SignedLOUIS

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: D'Artagnan repressed the quiver of impatience that ran through his whole body, and with a gracious smile:
children.prevalue: D Artagnan repressed the quiver of impatience that ran through his whole body and with a gracious smile

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: That is well, monsieur, said he the king's orders shall be complied with.
children.prevalue: That is well monsieur said he the king s orders shall be complied with

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The blow was direct. It was severe, mortal. D'Artagnan, furious at having been anticipated by an idea of the king's, did not despair, however, even yet and reflecting upon the idea he had brought back from BelleIsle, he elicited therefrom novel means of safety for his friends.
children.prevalue: The blow was direct It was severe mortal D Artagnan furious at having been anticipated by an idea of the king s did not despair however even yet and reflecting upon the idea he had brought back from BelleIsle he elicited therefrom novel means of safety for his friends

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Gentlemen, said he, suddenly, since the king has charged some other than myself with his secret orders, it must be because I no longer possess his confidence, and I should really be unworthy of it if I had the courage to hold a command subject to so many injurious suspicions. Therefore I will go immediately and carry my resignation to the king. I tender it before you all, enjoining you all to fall back with me upon the coast of France, in such a way as not to compromise the safety of the forces his majesty has confided to me. For this purpose, return all to your posts within an hour, we shall have the ebb of the tide. To your posts, gentlemen! I suppose, added he, on seeing that all prepared to obey him, except the surveillant officer, you have no orders to object, this time?
children.prevalue: Gentlemen said he suddenly since the king has charged some other than myself with his secret orders it must be because I no longer possess his confidence and I should really be unworthy of it if I had the courage to hold a command subject to so many injurious suspicions Therefore I will go immediately and carry my resignation to the king I tender it before you all enjoining you all to fall back with me upon the coast of France in such a way as not to compromise the safety of the forces his majesty has confided to me For this purpose return all to your posts within an hour we shall have the ebb of the tide To your posts gentlemen I suppose added he on seeing that all prepared to obey him except the surveillant officer you have no orders to object this time

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: And D'Artagnan almost triumphed while speaking these words. This plan would prove the safety of his friends. The blockade once raised, they might embark immediately, and set sail for England or Spain, without fear of being molested. Whilst they were making their escape, D'Artagnan would return to the king would justify his return by the indignation which the mistrust of Colbert had raised in him he would be sent back with full powers, and he would take BelleIsle that is to say, the cage, after the birds had flown. But to this plan the officer opposed a further order of the king's. It was thus conceived:
children.prevalue: And D Artagnan almost triumphed while speaking these words This plan would prove the safety of his friends The blockade once raised they might embark immediately and set sail for England or Spain without fear of being molested Whilst they were making their escape D Artagnan would return to the king would justify his return by the indignation which the mistrust of Colbert had raised in him he would be sent back with full powers and he would take BelleIsle that is to say the cage after the birds had flown But to this plan the officer opposed a further order of the king s It was thus conceived

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: From the moment M. d'Artagnan shall have manifested the desire of giving in his resignation, he shall no longer be reckoned leader of the expedition, and every officer placed under his orders shall be held to no longer obey him. Moreover, the said Monsieur d'Artagnan, having lost that quality of leader of the army sent against BelleIsle, shall set out immediately for France, accompanied by the officer who will have remitted the message to him, and who will consider him a prisoner for whom he is answerable.
children.prevalue: From the moment M d Artagnan shall have manifested the desire of giving in his resignation he shall no longer be reckoned leader of the expedition and every officer placed under his orders shall be held to no longer obey him Moreover the said Monsieur d Artagnan having lost that quality of leader of the army sent against BelleIsle shall set out immediately for France accompanied by the officer who will have remitted the message to him and who will consider him a prisoner for whom he is answerable

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Brave and careless as he was, D'Artagnan turned pale. Everything had been calculated with a depth of precognition which, for the first time in thirty years, recalled to him the solid foresight and inflexible logic of the great cardinal. He leaned his head on his hand, thoughtful, scarcely breathing. If I were to put this order in my pocket, thought he, who would know it, what would prevent my doing it? Before the king had had time to be informed, I should have saved those poor fellows yonder. Let us exercise some small audacity! My head is not one of those the executioner strikes off for disobedience. We will disobey! But at the moment he was about to adopt this plan, he saw the officers around him reading similar orders, which the passive agent of the thoughts of that infernal Colbert had distributed to them. This contingency of his disobedience had been foreseenas all the rest had been.
children.prevalue: Brave and careless as he was D Artagnan turned pale Everything had been calculated with a depth of precognition which for the first time in thirty years recalled to him the solid foresight and inflexible logic of the great cardinal He leaned his head on his hand thoughtful scarcely breathing If I were to put this order in my pocket thought he who would know it what would prevent my doing it Before the king had had time to be informed I should have saved those poor fellows yonder Let us exercise some small audacity My head is not one of those the executioner strikes off for disobedience We will disobey But at the moment he was about to adopt this plan he saw the officers around him reading similar orders which the passive agent of the thoughts of that infernal Colbert had distributed to them This contingency of his disobedience had been foreseenas all the rest had been

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Monsieur, said the officer, coming up to him, I await your good pleasure to depart.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said the officer coming up to him I await your good pleasure to depart

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I am ready, monsieur, replied D'Artagnan, grinding his teeth.
children.prevalue: I am ready monsieur replied D Artagnan grinding his teeth

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: The officer immediately ordered a canoe to receive M. d'Artagnan and himself. At sight of this he became almost distraught with rage.
children.prevalue: The officer immediately ordered a canoe to receive M d Artagnan and himself At sight of this he became almost distraught with rage

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: How, stammered he, will you carry on the directions of the different corps?
children.prevalue: How stammered he will you carry on the directions of the different corps

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: When you are gone, monsieur, replied the commander of the fleet, it is to me the command of the whole is committed.
children.prevalue: When you are gone monsieur replied the commander of the fleet it is to me the command of the whole is committed

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Then, monsieur, rejoined Colbert's man, addressing the new leader, it is for you that this last order remitted to me is intended. Let us see your powers.
children.prevalue: Then monsieur rejoined Colbert s man addressing the new leader it is for you that this last order remitted to me is intended Let us see your powers

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Here they are, said the officer, exhibiting the royal signature.
children.prevalue: Here they are said the officer exhibiting the royal signature

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Here are your instructions, replied the officer, placing the folded paper in his hands and turning round towards D'Artagnan, Come, monsieur, said he, in an agitated voice (such despair did he behold in that man of iron), do me the favor to depart at once.
children.prevalue: Here are your instructions replied the officer placing the folded paper in his hands and turning round towards D Artagnan Come monsieur said he in an agitated voice such despair did he behold in that man of iron do me the favor to depart at once

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Immediately! articulated D'Artagnan, feebly, subdued, crushed by implacable impossibility.
children.prevalue: Immediately articulated D Artagnan feebly subdued crushed by implacable impossibility

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: And he painfully subsided into the little boat, which started, favored by wind and tide, for the coast of France. The king's guards embarked with him. The musketeer still preserved the hope of reaching Nantes quickly, and of pleading the cause of his friends eloquently enough to incline the king to mercy. The bark flew like a swallow. D'Artagnan distinctly saw the land of France profiled in black against the white clouds of night.
children.prevalue: And he painfully subsided into the little boat which started favored by wind and tide for the coast of France The king s guards embarked with him The musketeer still preserved the hope of reaching Nantes quickly and of pleading the cause of his friends eloquently enough to incline the king to mercy The bark flew like a swallow D Artagnan distinctly saw the land of France profiled in black against the white clouds of night

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Ah! monsieur, said he, in a low voice, to the officer to whom, for an hour, he had ceased speaking, what would I give to know the instructions for the new commander! They are all pacific, are they not? and
children.prevalue: Ah monsieur said he in a low voice to the officer to whom for an hour he had ceased speaking what would I give to know the instructions for the new commander They are all pacific are they not and

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: He did not finish the thunder of a distant cannon rolled athwart the waves, another, and two or three still louder. D'Artagnan shuddered.
children.prevalue: He did not finish the thunder of a distant cannon rolled athwart the waves another and two or three still louder D Artagnan shuddered

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: They have commenced the siege of BelleIsle, replied the officer. The canoe had just touched the soil of France.
children.prevalue: They have commenced the siege of BelleIsle replied the officer The canoe had just touched the soil of France

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: When D'Artagnan left Aramis and Porthos, the latter returned to the principal fort, in order to converse with greater liberty. Porthos, still thoughtful, was a restraint on Aramis, whose mind had never felt itself more free.
children.prevalue: When D Artagnan left Aramis and Porthos the latter returned to the principal fort in order to converse with greater liberty Porthos still thoughtful was a restraint on Aramis whose mind had never felt itself more free

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Dear Porthos, said he, suddenly, I will explain D'Artagnan's idea to you.
children.prevalue: Dear Porthos said he suddenly I will explain D Artagnan s idea to you

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: What idea, Aramis?
children.prevalue: What idea Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: An idea to which we shall owe our liberty within twelve hours.
children.prevalue: An idea to which we shall owe our liberty within twelve hours

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Ah! indeed! said Porthos, much astonished. Let us hear it.
children.prevalue: Ah indeed said Porthos much astonished Let us hear it

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Did you remark, in the scene our friend had with the officer, that certain orders constrained him with regard to us?
children.prevalue: Did you remark in the scene our friend had with the officer that certain orders constrained him with regard to us

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Yes, I did notice that.
children.prevalue: Yes I did notice that

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Well! D'Artagnan is going to give in his resignation to the king, and during the confusion that will result from his absence, we will get away, or rather you will get away, Porthos, if there is possibility of flight for only one.
children.prevalue: Well D Artagnan is going to give in his resignation to the king and during the confusion that will result from his absence we will get away or rather you will get away Porthos if there is possibility of flight for only one

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Here Porthos shook his head and replied: We will escape together, Aramis, or we will stay together.
children.prevalue: Here Porthos shook his head and replied We will escape together Aramis or we will stay together

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Thine is a right, a generous heart, said Aramis, only your melancholy uneasiness affects me.
children.prevalue: Thine is a right a generous heart said Aramis only your melancholy uneasiness affects me

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I am not uneasy, said Porthos.
children.prevalue: I am not uneasy said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Then you are angry with me.
children.prevalue: Then you are angry with me

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I am not angry with you.
children.prevalue: I am not angry with you

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Then why, my friend, do you put on such a dismal countenance?
children.prevalue: Then why my friend do you put on such a dismal countenance

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I will tell you I am making my will. And while saying these words, the good Porthos looked sadly in the face of Aramis.
children.prevalue: I will tell you I am making my will And while saying these words the good Porthos looked sadly in the face of Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Your will! cried the bishop. What, then! do you think yourself lost?
children.prevalue: Your will cried the bishop What then do you think yourself lost

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: I feel fatigued. It is the first time, and there is a custom in our family.
children.prevalue: I feel fatigued It is the first time and there is a custom in our family

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: What is it, my friend?
children.prevalue: What is it my friend

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: My grandfather was a man twice as strong as I am.
children.prevalue: My grandfather was a man twice as strong as I am

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Indeed! said Aramis then your grandfather must have been Samson himself.
children.prevalue: Indeed said Aramis then your grandfather must have been Samson himself

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: No his name was Antoine. Well! he was about my age, when, setting out one day for the chase, he felt his legs weak, the man who had never known what weakness was before.
children.prevalue: No his name was Antoine Well he was about my age when setting out one day for the chase he felt his legs weak the man who had never known what weakness was before

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: What was the meaning of that fatigue, my friend?
children.prevalue: What was the meaning of that fatigue my friend

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Nothing good, as you will see for having set out, complaining still of weakness of the legs, he met a wild boar, which made head against him he missed him with his arquebuse, and was ripped up by the beast and died immediately.
children.prevalue: Nothing good as you will see for having set out complaining still of weakness of the legs he met a wild boar which made head against him he missed him with his arquebuse and was ripped up by the beast and died immediately

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: There is no reason in that why you should alarm yourself, dear Porthos.
children.prevalue: There is no reason in that why you should alarm yourself dear Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Oh! you will see. My father was as strong again as I am. He was a rough soldier, under Henry III. and Henry IV. his name was not Antoine, but Gaspard, the same as M. de Coligny. Always on horseback, he had never known what lassitude was. One evening, as he rose from table, his legs failed him.
children.prevalue: Oh you will see My father was as strong again as I am He was a rough soldier under Henry III and Henry IV his name was not Antoine but Gaspard the same as M de Coligny Always on horseback he had never known what lassitude was One evening as he rose from table his legs failed him

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: He had supped heartily, perhaps, said Aramis, and that was why he staggered.
children.prevalue: He had supped heartily perhaps said Aramis and that was why he staggered

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Bah! A friend of M. de Bassompierre, nonsense! No, no, he was astonished at this lassitude, and said to my mother, who laughed at him, 'Would not one believe I was going to meet with a wild boar, as the late M. du Vallon, my father did?'
children.prevalue: Bah A friend of M de Bassompierre nonsense No no he was astonished at this lassitude and said to my mother who laughed at him Would not one believe I was going to meet with a wild boar as the late M du Vallon my father did

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Well? said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Well said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Well, having this weakness, my father insisted upon going down into the garden, instead of going to bed his foot slipped on the first stair, the staircase was steep my father fell against a stone in which an iron hinge was fixed. The hinge gashed his temple and he was stretched out dead upon the spot.
children.prevalue: Well having this weakness my father insisted upon going down into the garden instead of going to bed his foot slipped on the first stair the staircase was steep my father fell against a stone in which an iron hinge was fixed The hinge gashed his temple and he was stretched out dead upon the spot

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Aramis raised his eyes to his friend: These are two extraordinary circumstances, said he let us not infer that there may succeed a third. It is not becoming in a man of your strength to be superstitious, my brave Porthos. Besides, when were your legs known to fail? Never have you stood so firm, so haughtily why, you could carry a house on your shoulders.
children.prevalue: Aramis raised his eyes to his friend These are two extraordinary circumstances said he let us not infer that there may succeed a third It is not becoming in a man of your strength to be superstitious my brave Porthos Besides when were your legs known to fail Never have you stood so firm so haughtily why you could carry a house on your shoulders

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: At this moment, said Porthos, I feel myself pretty active but at times I vacillate I sink and lately this phenomenon, as you say, has occurred four times. I will not say this frightens me, but it annoys me. Life is an agreeable thing. I have money I have fine estates I have horses that I love I have also friends that I love: D'Artagnan, Athos, Raoul, and you.
children.prevalue: At this moment said Porthos I feel myself pretty active but at times I vacillate I sink and lately this phenomenon as you say has occurred four times I will not say this frightens me but it annoys me Life is an agreeable thing I have money I have fine estates I have horses that I love I have also friends that I love D Artagnan Athos Raoul and you

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The admirable Porthos did not even take the trouble to dissimulate in the very presence of Aramis the rank he gave him in his friendship. Aramis pressed his hand: We will still live many years, said he, to preserve to the world such specimens of its rarest men. Trust yourself to me, my friend we have no reply from D'Artagnan, that is a good sign. He must have given orders to get the vessels together and clear the seas. On my part I have just issued directions that a bark should be rolled on rollers to the mouth of the great cavern of Locmaria, which you know, where we have so often lain in wait for the foxes.
children.prevalue: The admirable Porthos did not even take the trouble to dissimulate in the very presence of Aramis the rank he gave him in his friendship Aramis pressed his hand We will still live many years said he to preserve to the world such specimens of its rarest men Trust yourself to me my friend we have no reply from D Artagnan that is a good sign He must have given orders to get the vessels together and clear the seas On my part I have just issued directions that a bark should be rolled on rollers to the mouth of the great cavern of Locmaria which you know where we have so often lain in wait for the foxes

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Yes, and which terminates at the little creek by a trench where we discovered the day that splendid fox escaped that way.
children.prevalue: Yes and which terminates at the little creek by a trench where we discovered the day that splendid fox escaped that way

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Precisely. In case of misfortunes, a bark is to be concealed for us in that cavern indeed, it must be there by this time. We will wait for a favorable moment, and during the night we will go to sea!
children.prevalue: Precisely In case of misfortunes a bark is to be concealed for us in that cavern indeed it must be there by this time We will wait for a favorable moment and during the night we will go to sea

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: That is a grand idea. What shall we gain by it?
children.prevalue: That is a grand idea What shall we gain by it

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: We shall gain thisnobody knows that grotto, or rather its issue, except ourselves and two or three hunters of the island we shall gain thisthat if the island is occupied, the scouts, seeing no bark upon the shore, will never imagine we can escape, and will cease to watch.
children.prevalue: We shall gain thisnobody knows that grotto or rather its issue except ourselves and two or three hunters of the island we shall gain thisthat if the island is occupied the scouts seeing no bark upon the shore will never imagine we can escape and will cease to watch

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I understand.
children.prevalue: I understand

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Well! that weakness in the legs?
children.prevalue: Well that weakness in the legs

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Oh! better, much, just now.
children.prevalue: Oh better much just now

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: You see, then, plainly, that everything conspires to give us quietude and hope. D'Artagnan will sweep the sea and leave us free. No royal fleet or descent to be dreaded. Vive Dieu! Porthos, we have still half a century of magnificent adventure before us, and if I once touch Spanish ground, I swear to you, added the bishop with terrible energy, that your brevet of duke is not such a chance as it is said to be.
children.prevalue: You see then plainly that everything conspires to give us quietude and hope D Artagnan will sweep the sea and leave us free No royal fleet or descent to be dreaded Vive Dieu Porthos we have still half a century of magnificent adventure before us and if I once touch Spanish ground I swear to you added the bishop with terrible energy that your brevet of duke is not such a chance as it is said to be

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: We live by hope, said Porthos, enlivened by the warmth of his companion.
children.prevalue: We live by hope said Porthos enlivened by the warmth of his companion

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: All at once a cry resounded in their ears: To arms! to arms!
children.prevalue: All at once a cry resounded in their ears To arms to arms

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: This cry, repeated by a hundred throats, piercing the chamber where the two friends were conversing, carried surprise to one, and uneasiness to the other. Aramis opened the window he saw a crowd of people running with flambeaux. Women were seeking places of safety, the armed population were hastening to their posts.
children.prevalue: This cry repeated by a hundred throats piercing the chamber where the two friends were conversing carried surprise to one and uneasiness to the other Aramis opened the window he saw a crowd of people running with flambeaux Women were seeking places of safety the armed population were hastening to their posts

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The fleet! the fleet! cried a soldier, who recognized Aramis.
children.prevalue: The fleet the fleet cried a soldier who recognized Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: The fleet? repeated the latter.
children.prevalue: The fleet repeated the latter

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Within half cannonshot, continued the soldier.
children.prevalue: Within half cannonshot continued the soldier

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: To arms! cried Aramis.
children.prevalue: To arms cried Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: To arms! repeated Porthos, formidably. And both rushed forth towards the mole to place themselves within the shelter of the batteries. Boats, laden with soldiers, were seen approaching and in three directions, for the purpose of landing at three points at once.
children.prevalue: To arms repeated Porthos formidably And both rushed forth towards the mole to place themselves within the shelter of the batteries Boats laden with soldiers were seen approaching and in three directions for the purpose of landing at three points at once

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: What must be done? said an officer of the guard.
children.prevalue: What must be done said an officer of the guard

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Stop them and if they persist, fire! said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Stop them and if they persist fire said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Five minutes later, the cannonade commenced. These were the shots that D'Artagnan had heard as he landed in France. But the boats were too near the mole to allow the cannon to aim correctly. They landed, and the combat commenced hand to hand.
children.prevalue: Five minutes later the cannonade commenced These were the shots that D Artagnan had heard as he landed in France But the boats were too near the mole to allow the cannon to aim correctly They landed and the combat commenced hand to hand

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: What's the matter, Porthos? said Aramis to his friend.
children.prevalue: What s the matter Porthos said Aramis to his friend

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Nothing! nothing!only my legs it is really incomprehensible!they will be better when we charge. In fact, Porthos and Aramis did charge with such vigor, and so thoroughly animated their men, that the royalists reembarked precipitately, without gaining anything but the wounds they carried away.
children.prevalue: Nothing nothing only my legs it is really incomprehensible they will be better when we charge In fact Porthos and Aramis did charge with such vigor and so thoroughly animated their men that the royalists reembarked precipitately without gaining anything but the wounds they carried away

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Eh! but Porthos, cried Aramis, we must have a prisoner, quick! quick! Porthos bent over the stair of the mole, and seized by the nape of the neck one of the officers of the royal army who was waiting to embark till all his people should be in the boat. The arm of the giant lifted up his prey, which served him as a buckler, and he recovered himself without a shot being fired at him.
children.prevalue: Eh but Porthos cried Aramis we must have a prisoner quick quick Porthos bent over the stair of the mole and seized by the nape of the neck one of the officers of the royal army who was waiting to embark till all his people should be in the boat The arm of the giant lifted up his prey which served him as a buckler and he recovered himself without a shot being fired at him

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Here is a prisoner for you, said Porthos coolly to Aramis.
children.prevalue: Here is a prisoner for you said Porthos coolly to Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Well! cried the latter, laughing, did you not calumniate your legs?
children.prevalue: Well cried the latter laughing did you not calumniate your legs

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: It was not with my legs I captured him, said Porthos, it was with my arms!
children.prevalue: It was not with my legs I captured him said Porthos it was with my arms

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The Bretons of the Isle were very proud of this victory Aramis did not encourage them in the feeling.
children.prevalue: The Bretons of the Isle were very proud of this victory Aramis did not encourage them in the feeling

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: What will happen, said he to Porthos, when everybody was gone home, will be that the anger of the king will be roused by the account of the resistance and that these brave people will be decimated or shot when they are taken, which cannot fail to take place.
children.prevalue: What will happen said he to Porthos when everybody was gone home will be that the anger of the king will be roused by the account of the resistance and that these brave people will be decimated or shot when they are taken which cannot fail to take place

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: From which it results, then, said Porthos, that what we have done is of not the slightest use.
children.prevalue: From which it results then said Porthos that what we have done is of not the slightest use

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: For the moment it may be, replied the bishop, for we have a prisoner from whom we shall learn what our enemies are preparing to do.
children.prevalue: For the moment it may be replied the bishop for we have a prisoner from whom we shall learn what our enemies are preparing to do

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Yes, let us interrogate the prisoner, said Porthos, and the means of making him speak are very simple. We are going to supper we will invite him to join us as he drinks he will talk.
children.prevalue: Yes let us interrogate the prisoner said Porthos and the means of making him speak are very simple We are going to supper we will invite him to join us as he drinks he will talk

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: This was done. The officer was at first rather uneasy, but became reassured on seeing what sort of men he had to deal with. He gave, without having any fear of compromising himself, all the details imaginable of the resignation and departure of D'Artagnan. He explained how, after that departure, the new leader of the expedition had ordered a surprise upon BelleIsle. There his explanations stopped. Aramis and Porthos exchanged a glance that evinced their despair. No more dependence to be placed now on D'Artagnan's fertile imaginationno further resource in the event of defeat. Aramis, continuing his interrogations, asked the prisoner what the leaders of the expedition contemplated doing with the leaders of BelleIsle.
children.prevalue: This was done The officer was at first rather uneasy but became reassured on seeing what sort of men he had to deal with He gave without having any fear of compromising himself all the details imaginable of the resignation and departure of D Artagnan He explained how after that departure the new leader of the expedition had ordered a surprise upon BelleIsle There his explanations stopped Aramis and Porthos exchanged a glance that evinced their despair No more dependence to be placed now on D Artagnan s fertile imaginationno further resource in the event of defeat Aramis continuing his interrogations asked the prisoner what the leaders of the expedition contemplated doing with the leaders of BelleIsle

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The orders are, replied he, to kill during combat, or hang afterwards.
children.prevalue: The orders are replied he to kill during combat or hang afterwards

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Porthos and Aramis looked at each other again, and the color mounted to their faces.
children.prevalue: Porthos and Aramis looked at each other again and the color mounted to their faces

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: I am too light for the gallows, replied Aramis people like me are not hung.
children.prevalue: I am too light for the gallows replied Aramis people like me are not hung

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: And I am too heavy, said Porthos people like me break the cord.
children.prevalue: And I am too heavy said Porthos people like me break the cord

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: I am sure, said the prisoner, gallantly, that we could have guaranteed you the exact kind of death you preferred.
children.prevalue: I am sure said the prisoner gallantly that we could have guaranteed you the exact kind of death you preferred

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: A thousand thanks! said Aramis, seriously. Porthos bowed.
children.prevalue: A thousand thanks said Aramis seriously Porthos bowed

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: One more cup of wine to your health, said he, drinking himself. From one subject to another the chat with the officer was prolonged. He was an intelligent gentleman, and suffered himself to be led on by the charm of Aramis's wit and Porthos's cordial bonhomie.
children.prevalue: One more cup of wine to your health said he drinking himself From one subject to another the chat with the officer was prolonged He was an intelligent gentleman and suffered himself to be led on by the charm of Aramis s wit and Porthos s cordial bonhomie

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Pardon me, said he, if I address a question to you but men who are in their sixth bottle have a clear right to forget themselves a little.
children.prevalue: Pardon me said he if I address a question to you but men who are in their sixth bottle have a clear right to forget themselves a little

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Address it! cried Porthos address it!
children.prevalue: Address it cried Porthos address it

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Speak, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Speak said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Were you not, gentlemen, both in the musketeers of the late king?
children.prevalue: Were you not gentlemen both in the musketeers of the late king

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Yes, monsieur, and amongst the best of them, if you please, said Porthos.
children.prevalue: Yes monsieur and amongst the best of them if you please said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: That is true I should say even the best of all soldiers, messieurs, if I did not fear to offend the memory of my father.
children.prevalue: That is true I should say even the best of all soldiers messieurs if I did not fear to offend the memory of my father

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Of your father? cried Aramis.
children.prevalue: Of your father cried Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Do you know what my name is?
children.prevalue: Do you know what my name is

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Ma foi! no, monsieur but you can tell us, and
children.prevalue: Ma foi no monsieur but you can tell us and

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I am called Georges de Biscarrat.
children.prevalue: I am called Georges de Biscarrat

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Oh! cried Porthos, in his turn. Biscarrat! Do you remember that name, Aramis?
children.prevalue: Oh cried Porthos in his turn Biscarrat Do you remember that name Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Biscarrat! reflected the bishop. It seems to me
children.prevalue: Biscarrat reflected the bishop It seems to me

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Try to recollect, monsieur, said the officer.
children.prevalue: Try to recollect monsieur said the officer

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Pardieu! that won't take me long, said Porthos. Biscarratcalled Cardinalone of the four who interrupted us on the day on which we formed our friendship with D'Artagnan, sword in hand.
children.prevalue: Pardieu that won t take me long said Porthos Biscarratcalled Cardinalone of the four who interrupted us on the day on which we formed our friendship with D Artagnan sword in hand

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Precisely, gentlemen.
children.prevalue: Precisely gentlemen

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The only one, cried Aramis, eagerly, we could not scratch.
children.prevalue: The only one cried Aramis eagerly we could not scratch

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Consequently, a capital blade? said the prisoner.
children.prevalue: Consequently a capital blade said the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: That's true! most true! exclaimed both friends together. Ma foi! Monsieur Biscarrat, we are delighted to make the acquaintance of such a brave man's son.
children.prevalue: That s true most true exclaimed both friends together Ma foi Monsieur Biscarrat we are delighted to make the acquaintance of such a brave man s son

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Biscarrat pressed the hands held out by the two musketeers. Aramis looked at Porthos as much as to say, Here is a man who will help us, and without delay,Confess, monsieur, said he, that it is good to have once been a good man.
children.prevalue: Biscarrat pressed the hands held out by the two musketeers Aramis looked at Porthos as much as to say Here is a man who will help us and without delay Confess monsieur said he that it is good to have once been a good man

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: My father always said so, monsieur.
children.prevalue: My father always said so monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Confess, likewise, that it is a sad circumstance in which you find yourself, of falling in with men destined to be shot or hung, and to learn that these men are old acquaintances, in fact, hereditary friends.
children.prevalue: Confess likewise that it is a sad circumstance in which you find yourself of falling in with men destined to be shot or hung and to learn that these men are old acquaintances in fact hereditary friends

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Oh! you are not reserved for such a frightful fate as that, messieurs and friends! said the young man, warmly.
children.prevalue: Oh you are not reserved for such a frightful fate as that messieurs and friends said the young man warmly

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Bah! you said so yourself.
children.prevalue: Bah you said so yourself

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I said so just now, when I did not know you but now that I know you, I sayyou will evade this dismal fate, if you wish!
children.prevalue: I said so just now when I did not know you but now that I know you I sayyou will evade this dismal fate if you wish

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Howif we wish? echoed Aramis, whose eyes beamed with intelligence as he looked alternately at the prisoner and Porthos.
children.prevalue: Howif we wish echoed Aramis whose eyes beamed with intelligence as he looked alternately at the prisoner and Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Provided, continued Porthos, looking, in his turn, with noble intrepidity, at M. Biscarrat and the bishopprovided nothing disgraceful be required of us.
children.prevalue: Provided continued Porthos looking in his turn with noble intrepidity at M Biscarrat and the bishopprovided nothing disgraceful be required of us

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Nothing at all will be required of you, gentlemen, replied the officerwhat should they ask of you? If they find you they will kill you, that is a predetermined thing try, then, gentlemen, to prevent their finding you.
children.prevalue: Nothing at all will be required of you gentlemen replied the officerwhat should they ask of you If they find you they will kill you that is a predetermined thing try then gentlemen to prevent their finding you

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I don't think I am mistaken, said Porthos, with dignity but it appears evident to me that if they want to find us, they must come and seek us here.
children.prevalue: I don t think I am mistaken said Porthos with dignity but it appears evident to me that if they want to find us they must come and seek us here

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: In that you are perfectly right, my worthy friend, replied Aramis, constantly consulting with his looks the countenance of Biscarrat, who had grown silent and constrained. You wish, Monsieur de Biscarrat, to say something to us, to make us some overture, and you dare notis that true?
children.prevalue: In that you are perfectly right my worthy friend replied Aramis constantly consulting with his looks the countenance of Biscarrat who had grown silent and constrained You wish Monsieur de Biscarrat to say something to us to make us some overture and you dare notis that true

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Ah! gentlemen and friends! it is because by speaking I betray the watchword. But, hark! I hear a voice that frees mine by dominating it.
children.prevalue: Ah gentlemen and friends it is because by speaking I betray the watchword But hark I hear a voice that frees mine by dominating it

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Cannon! said Porthos.
children.prevalue: Cannon said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Cannon and musketry, too! cried the bishop.
children.prevalue: Cannon and musketry too cried the bishop

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: On hearing at a distance, among the rocks, these sinister reports of a combat which they thought had ceased:
children.prevalue: On hearing at a distance among the rocks these sinister reports of a combat which they thought had ceased

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: What can that be? asked Porthos.
children.prevalue: What can that be asked Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Eh! Pardieu! cried Aramis that is just what I expected.
children.prevalue: Eh Pardieu cried Aramis that is just what I expected

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: What is that?
children.prevalue: What is that

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: That the attack made by you was nothing but a feint is not that true, monsieur? And whilst your companions allowed themselves to be repulsed, you were certain of effecting a landing on the other side of the island.
children.prevalue: That the attack made by you was nothing but a feint is not that true monsieur And whilst your companions allowed themselves to be repulsed you were certain of effecting a landing on the other side of the island

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Oh! several, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Oh several monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: We are lost, then, said the bishop of Vannes, quietly.
children.prevalue: We are lost then said the bishop of Vannes quietly

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Lost! that is possible, replied the Seigneur de Pierrefonds, but we are not taken or hung. And so saying, he rose from the table, went to the wall, and coolly took down his sword and pistols, which he examined with the care of an old soldier who is preparing for battle, and who feels that life, in a great measure, depends upon the excellence and right conditions of his arms.
children.prevalue: Lost that is possible replied the Seigneur de Pierrefonds but we are not taken or hung And so saying he rose from the table went to the wall and coolly took down his sword and pistols which he examined with the care of an old soldier who is preparing for battle and who feels that life in a great measure depends upon the excellence and right conditions of his arms

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: At the report of the cannon, at the news of the surprise which might deliver up the island to the royal troops, the terrified crowd rushed precipitately to the fort to demand assistance and advice from their leaders. Aramis, pale and downcast, between two flambeaux, showed himself at the window which looked into the principal court, full of soldiers waiting for orders and bewildered inhabitants imploring succor.
children.prevalue: At the report of the cannon at the news of the surprise which might deliver up the island to the royal troops the terrified crowd rushed precipitately to the fort to demand assistance and advice from their leaders Aramis pale and downcast between two flambeaux showed himself at the window which looked into the principal court full of soldiers waiting for orders and bewildered inhabitants imploring succor

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: My friends, said D'Herblay, in a grave and sonorous voice, M. Fouquet, your protector, your friend, you father, has been arrested by an order of the king, and thrown into the Bastile. A sustained yell of vengeful fury came floating up to the window at which the bishop stood, and enveloped him in a magnetic field.
children.prevalue: My friends said D Herblay in a grave and sonorous voice M Fouquet your protector your friend you father has been arrested by an order of the king and thrown into the Bastile A sustained yell of vengeful fury came floating up to the window at which the bishop stood and enveloped him in a magnetic field

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Avenge Monsieur Fouquet! cried the most excited of his hearers, death to the royalists!
children.prevalue: Avenge Monsieur Fouquet cried the most excited of his hearers death to the royalists

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: No, my friends, replied Aramis, solemnly no, my friends no resistance. The king is master in his kingdom. The king is the mandatory of God. The king and God have struck M. Fouquet. Humble yourselves before the hand of God. Love God and the king, who have struck M. Fouquet. But do not avenge your seigneur, do not think of avenging him. You would sacrifice yourselves in vainyou, your wives and children, your property, your liberty. Lay down your arms, my friendslay down your arms! since the king commands you so to doand retire peaceably to your dwellings. It is I who ask you to do so it is I who beg you to do so it is I who now, in the hour of need, command you to do so, in the name of M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: No my friends replied Aramis solemnly no my friends no resistance The king is master in his kingdom The king is the mandatory of God The king and God have struck M Fouquet Humble yourselves before the hand of God Love God and the king who have struck M Fouquet But do not avenge your seigneur do not think of avenging him You would sacrifice yourselves in vainyou your wives and children your property your liberty Lay down your arms my friendslay down your arms since the king commands you so to doand retire peaceably to your dwellings It is I who ask you to do so it is I who beg you to do so it is I who now in the hour of need command you to do so in the name of M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: The crowd collected under the window uttered a prolonged roar of anger and terror. The soldiers of Louis XIV. have reached the island, continued Aramis. From this time it would no longer be a fight betwixt them and youit would be a massacre. Begone, then, begone, and forget this time I command you, in the name of the Lord of Hosts!
children.prevalue: The crowd collected under the window uttered a prolonged roar of anger and terror The soldiers of Louis XIV have reached the island continued Aramis From this time it would no longer be a fight betwixt them and youit would be a massacre Begone then begone and forget this time I command you in the name of the Lord of Hosts

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: The mutineers retired slowly, submissive, silent.
children.prevalue: The mutineers retired slowly submissive silent

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Ah! what have you just been saying, my friend? said Porthos.
children.prevalue: Ah what have you just been saying my friend said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Monsieur, said Biscarrat to the bishop, you may save all these inhabitants, but thus you will neither save yourself nor your friend.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said Biscarrat to the bishop you may save all these inhabitants but thus you will neither save yourself nor your friend

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: Monsieur de Biscarrat, said the bishop of Vannes, with a singular accent of nobility and courtesy, Monsieur de Biscarrat, be kind enough to resume your liberty.
children.prevalue: Monsieur de Biscarrat said the bishop of Vannes with a singular accent of nobility and courtesy Monsieur de Biscarrat be kind enough to resume your liberty

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: I am very willing to do so, monsieur but
children.prevalue: I am very willing to do so monsieur but

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: That would render us a service, for when announcing to the king's lieutenant the submission of the islanders, you will perhaps obtain some grace for us on informing him of the manner in which that submission has been effected.
children.prevalue: That would render us a service for when announcing to the king s lieutenant the submission of the islanders you will perhaps obtain some grace for us on informing him of the manner in which that submission has been effected

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Grace! replied Porthos with flashing eyes, what is the meaning of that word?
children.prevalue: Grace replied Porthos with flashing eyes what is the meaning of that word

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Aramis touched the elbow of his friend roughly, as he had been accustomed to do in the days of their youth, when he wanted to warn Porthos that he had committed, or was about to commit, a blunder. Porthos understood him, and was silent immediately.
children.prevalue: Aramis touched the elbow of his friend roughly as he had been accustomed to do in the days of their youth when he wanted to warn Porthos that he had committed or was about to commit a blunder Porthos understood him and was silent immediately

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: I will go, messieurs, replied Biscarrat, a little surprised likewise at the word grace pronounced by the haughty musketeer, of and to whom, but a few minutes before, he had related with so much enthusiasm the heroic exploits with which his father had delighted him.
children.prevalue: I will go messieurs replied Biscarrat a little surprised likewise at the word grace pronounced by the haughty musketeer of and to whom but a few minutes before he had related with so much enthusiasm the heroic exploits with which his father had delighted him

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Go, then, Monsieur Biscarrat, said Aramis, bowing to him, and at parting receive the expression of our entire gratitude.
children.prevalue: Go then Monsieur Biscarrat said Aramis bowing to him and at parting receive the expression of our entire gratitude

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: But you, messieurs, you whom I think it an honor to call my friends, since you have been willing to accept that title, what will become of you in the meantime? replied the officer, very much agitated at taking leave of the two ancient adversaries of his father.
children.prevalue: But you messieurs you whom I think it an honor to call my friends since you have been willing to accept that title what will become of you in the meantime replied the officer very much agitated at taking leave of the two ancient adversaries of his father

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: We will wait here.
children.prevalue: We will wait here

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: But, mon Dieu!the order is precise and formal.
children.prevalue: But mon Dieu the order is precise and formal

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: I am bishop of Vannes, Monsieur de Biscarrat and they no more shoot a bishop than they hang a gentleman.
children.prevalue: I am bishop of Vannes Monsieur de Biscarrat and they no more shoot a bishop than they hang a gentleman

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Ah! yes, monsieuryes, monseigneur, replied Biscarrat it is true, you are right, there is still that chance for you. Then, I will depart, I will repair to the commander of the expedition, the king's lieutenant. Adieu! then, messieurs, or rather, to meet again, I hope.
children.prevalue: Ah yes monsieuryes monseigneur replied Biscarrat it is true you are right there is still that chance for you Then I will depart I will repair to the commander of the expedition the king s lieutenant Adieu then messieurs or rather to meet again I hope

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: The worthy officer, jumping upon a horse given him by Aramis, departed in the direction of the sound of cannon, which, by surging the crowd into the fort, had interrupted the conversation of the two friends with their prisoner. Aramis watched the departure, and when left alone with Porthos:
children.prevalue: The worthy officer jumping upon a horse given him by Aramis departed in the direction of the sound of cannon which by surging the crowd into the fort had interrupted the conversation of the two friends with their prisoner Aramis watched the departure and when left alone with Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Well, do you comprehend? said he.
children.prevalue: Well do you comprehend said he

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Ma foi! no.
children.prevalue: Ma foi no

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Did not Biscarrat inconvenience you here?
children.prevalue: Did not Biscarrat inconvenience you here

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: No he is a brave fellow.
children.prevalue: No he is a brave fellow

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: Yes but the grotto of Locmariais it necessary all the world should know it?
children.prevalue: Yes but the grotto of Locmariais it necessary all the world should know it

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Ah! that is true, that is true I comprehend. We are going to escape by the cavern.
children.prevalue: Ah that is true that is true I comprehend We are going to escape by the cavern

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: If you please, cried Aramis, gayly. Forward, friend Porthos our boat awaits us. King Louis has not caught usyet.
children.prevalue: If you please cried Aramis gayly Forward friend Porthos our boat awaits us King Louis has not caught usyet

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The cavern of Locmaria was sufficiently distant from the mole to render it necessary for our friends to husband their strength in order to reach it. Besides, night was advancing midnight had struck at the fort. Porthos and Aramis were loaded with money and arms. They walked, then, across the heath, which stretched between the mole and the cavern, listening to every noise, in order better to avoid an ambush. From time to time, on the road which they had carefully left on their left, passed fugitives coming from the interior, at the news of the landing of the royal troops. Aramis and Porthos, concealed behind some projecting mass of rock, collected the words that escaped from the poor people, who fled, trembling, carrying with them their most valuable effects, and tried, whilst listening to their complaints, to gather something from them for their own interest. At length, after a rapid race, frequently interrupted by prudent stoppages, they reached the deep grottoes, in which the prophetic bishop of Vannes had taken care to have secreted a bark capable of keeping the sea at this fine season.
children.prevalue: The cavern of Locmaria was sufficiently distant from the mole to render it necessary for our friends to husband their strength in order to reach it Besides night was advancing midnight had struck at the fort Porthos and Aramis were loaded with money and arms They walked then across the heath which stretched between the mole and the cavern listening to every noise in order better to avoid an ambush From time to time on the road which they had carefully left on their left passed fugitives coming from the interior at the news of the landing of the royal troops Aramis and Porthos concealed behind some projecting mass of rock collected the words that escaped from the poor people who fled trembling carrying with them their most valuable effects and tried whilst listening to their complaints to gather something from them for their own interest At length after a rapid race frequently interrupted by prudent stoppages they reached the deep grottoes in which the prophetic bishop of Vannes had taken care to have secreted a bark capable of keeping the sea at this fine season

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: My good friend, said Porthos, panting vigorously, we have arrived, it seems. But I thought you spoke of three men, three servants, who were to accompany us. I don't see themwhere are they?
children.prevalue: My good friend said Porthos panting vigorously we have arrived it seems But I thought you spoke of three men three servants who were to accompany us I don t see themwhere are they

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Why should you see them, Porthos? replied Aramis. They are certainly waiting for us in the cavern, and, no doubt, are resting, having accomplished their rough and difficult task.
children.prevalue: Why should you see them Porthos replied Aramis They are certainly waiting for us in the cavern and no doubt are resting having accomplished their rough and difficult task

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Aramis stopped Porthos, who was preparing to enter the cavern. Will you allow me, my friend, said he to the giant, to pass in first? I know the signal I have given to these men who, not hearing it, would be very likely to fire upon you or slash away with their knives in the dark.
children.prevalue: Aramis stopped Porthos who was preparing to enter the cavern Will you allow me my friend said he to the giant to pass in first I know the signal I have given to these men who not hearing it would be very likely to fire upon you or slash away with their knives in the dark

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Go on, then, Aramis go ongo first you impersonate wisdom and foresight go. Ah! there is that fatigue again, of which I spoke to you. It has just seized me afresh.
children.prevalue: Go on then Aramis go ongo first you impersonate wisdom and foresight go Ah there is that fatigue again of which I spoke to you It has just seized me afresh

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Aramis left Porthos sitting at the entrance of the grotto, and bowing his head, he penetrated into the interior of the cavern, imitating the cry of the owl. A little plaintive cooing, a scarcely distinct echo, replied from the depths of the cave. Aramis pursued his way cautiously, and soon was stopped by the same kind of cry as he had first uttered, within ten paces of him.
children.prevalue: Aramis left Porthos sitting at the entrance of the grotto and bowing his head he penetrated into the interior of the cavern imitating the cry of the owl A little plaintive cooing a scarcely distinct echo replied from the depths of the cave Aramis pursued his way cautiously and soon was stopped by the same kind of cry as he had first uttered within ten paces of him

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Are you there, Yves? said the bishop.
children.prevalue: Are you there Yves said the bishop

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Yes, monseigneur Goenne is here likewise. His son accompanies us.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur Goenne is here likewise His son accompanies us

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: That is well. Are all things ready?
children.prevalue: That is well Are all things ready

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Yes, monseigneur.
children.prevalue: Yes monseigneur

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Go to the entrance of the grottoes, my good Yves, and you will there find the Seigneur de Pierrefonds, who is resting after the fatigue of our journey. And if he should happen not to be able to walk, lift him up, and bring him hither to me.
