children.prevalue: Go to the entrance of the grottoes my good Yves and you will there find the Seigneur de Pierrefonds who is resting after the fatigue of our journey And if he should happen not to be able to walk lift him up and bring him hither to me

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The three men obeyed. But the recommendation given to his servants was superfluous. Porthos, refreshed, had already commenced the descent, and his heavy step resounded amongst the cavities, formed and supported by columns of porphyry and granite. As soon as the Seigneur de Bracieux had rejoined the bishop, the Bretons lighted a lantern with which they were furnished, and Porthos assured his friend that he felt as strong again as ever.
children.prevalue: The three men obeyed But the recommendation given to his servants was superfluous Porthos refreshed had already commenced the descent and his heavy step resounded amongst the cavities formed and supported by columns of porphyry and granite As soon as the Seigneur de Bracieux had rejoined the bishop the Bretons lighted a lantern with which they were furnished and Porthos assured his friend that he felt as strong again as ever

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Let us inspect the boat, said Aramis, and satisfy ourselves at once what it will hold.
children.prevalue: Let us inspect the boat said Aramis and satisfy ourselves at once what it will hold

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Do not go too near with the light, said the patron Yves for as you desired me, monseigneur, I have placed under the bench of the poop, in the coffer you know of, the barrel of powder, and the musketcharges that you sent me from the fort.
children.prevalue: Do not go too near with the light said the patron Yves for as you desired me monseigneur I have placed under the bench of the poop in the coffer you know of the barrel of powder and the musketcharges that you sent me from the fort

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Very well, said Aramis and, taking the lantern himself, he examined minutely all parts of the canoe, with the precautions of a man who is neither timid nor ignorant in the face of danger. The canoe was long, light, drawing little water, thin of keel in short, one of those that have always been so aptly built at BelleIsle a little high in its sides, solid upon the water, very manageable, furnished with planks which, in uncertain weather, formed a sort of deck over which the waves might glide, so as to protect the rowers. In two wellclosed coffers, placed beneath the benches of the prow and the poop, Aramis found bread, biscuit, dried fruits, a quarter of bacon, a good provision of water in leathern bottles the whole forming rations sufficient for people who did not mean to quit the coast, and would be able to revictual, if necessity commanded. The arms, eight muskets, and as many horsepistols, were in good condition, and all loaded. There were additional oars, in case of accident, and that little sail called trinquet, which assists the speed of the canoe at the same time the boatmen row, and is so useful when the breeze is slack. When Aramis had seen to all these things, and appeared satisfied with the result of his inspection, Let us consult Porthos, said he, to know if we must endeavor to get the boat out by the unknown extremity of the grotto, following the descent and the shade of the cavern, or whether it be better, in the open air, to make it slide upon its rollers through the bushes, leveling the road of the little beach, which is but twenty feet high, and gives, at high tide, three or four fathoms of good water upon a sound bottom.
children.prevalue: Very well said Aramis and taking the lantern himself he examined minutely all parts of the canoe with the precautions of a man who is neither timid nor ignorant in the face of danger The canoe was long light drawing little water thin of keel in short one of those that have always been so aptly built at BelleIsle a little high in its sides solid upon the water very manageable furnished with planks which in uncertain weather formed a sort of deck over which the waves might glide so as to protect the rowers In two wellclosed coffers placed beneath the benches of the prow and the poop Aramis found bread biscuit dried fruits a quarter of bacon a good provision of water in leathern bottles the whole forming rations sufficient for people who did not mean to quit the coast and would be able to revictual if necessity commanded The arms eight muskets and as many horsepistols were in good condition and all loaded There were additional oars in case of accident and that little sail called trinquet which assists the speed of the canoe at the same time the boatmen row and is so useful when the breeze is slack When Aramis had seen to all these things and appeared satisfied with the result of his inspection Let us consult Porthos said he to know if we must endeavor to get the boat out by the unknown extremity of the grotto following the descent and the shade of the cavern or whether it be better in the open air to make it slide upon its rollers through the bushes leveling the road of the little beach which is but twenty feet high and gives at high tide three or four fathoms of good water upon a sound bottom

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It must be as you please, monseigneur, replied the skipper Yves, respectfully but I don't believe that by the slope of the cavern, and in the dark in which we shall be obliged to maneuver our boat, the road will be so convenient as the open air. I know the beach well, and can certify that it is as smooth as a grassplot in a garden the interior of the grotto, on the contrary, is rough without reckoning, monseigneur, that at its extremity we shall come to the trench which leads into the sea, and perhaps the canoe will not pass down it.
children.prevalue: It must be as you please monseigneur replied the skipper Yves respectfully but I don t believe that by the slope of the cavern and in the dark in which we shall be obliged to maneuver our boat the road will be so convenient as the open air I know the beach well and can certify that it is as smooth as a grassplot in a garden the interior of the grotto on the contrary is rough without reckoning monseigneur that at its extremity we shall come to the trench which leads into the sea and perhaps the canoe will not pass down it

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: I have made my calculation, said the bishop, and I am certain it will pass.
children.prevalue: I have made my calculation said the bishop and I am certain it will pass

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: So be it I wish it may, monseigneur, continued Yves but your highness knows very well that to make it reach the extremity of the trench, there is an enormous stone to be liftedthat under which the fox always passes, and which closes the trench like a door.
children.prevalue: So be it I wish it may monseigneur continued Yves but your highness knows very well that to make it reach the extremity of the trench there is an enormous stone to be liftedthat under which the fox always passes and which closes the trench like a door

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: It can be raised, said Porthos that is nothing.
children.prevalue: It can be raised said Porthos that is nothing

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Oh! I know that monseigneur has the strength of ten men, replied Yves but that is giving him a great deal of trouble.
children.prevalue: Oh I know that monseigneur has the strength of ten men replied Yves but that is giving him a great deal of trouble

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I think the skipper may be right, said Aramis let us try the openair passage.
children.prevalue: I think the skipper may be right said Aramis let us try the openair passage

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The more so, monseigneur, continued the fisherman, that we should not be able to embark before day, it will require so much labor, and that as soon as daylight appears, a good vedette placed outside the grotto would be necessary, indispensable even, to watch the maneuvers of the lighters or cruisers that are on the lookout for us.
children.prevalue: The more so monseigneur continued the fisherman that we should not be able to embark before day it will require so much labor and that as soon as daylight appears a good vedette placed outside the grotto would be necessary indispensable even to watch the maneuvers of the lighters or cruisers that are on the lookout for us

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Yes, yes, Yves, your reasons are good we will go by the beach.
children.prevalue: Yes yes Yves your reasons are good we will go by the beach

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: And the three robust Bretons went to the boat, and were beginning to place their rollers underneath it to put it in motion, when the distant barking of dogs was heard, proceeding from the interior of the island.
children.prevalue: And the three robust Bretons went to the boat and were beginning to place their rollers underneath it to put it in motion when the distant barking of dogs was heard proceeding from the interior of the island

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Aramis darted out of the grotto, followed by Porthos. Dawn just tinted with purple and white the waves and plain through the dim light, melancholy firtrees waved their tender branches over the pebbles, and long flights of crows were skimming with their black wings the shimmering fields of buckwheat. In a quarter of an hour it would be clear daylight the wakened birds announced it to all nature. The barkings which had been heard, which had stopped the three fishermen engaged in moving the boat, and had brought Aramis and Porthos out of the cavern, now seemed to come from a deep gorge within about a league of the grotto.
children.prevalue: Aramis darted out of the grotto followed by Porthos Dawn just tinted with purple and white the waves and plain through the dim light melancholy firtrees waved their tender branches over the pebbles and long flights of crows were skimming with their black wings the shimmering fields of buckwheat In a quarter of an hour it would be clear daylight the wakened birds announced it to all nature The barkings which had been heard which had stopped the three fishermen engaged in moving the boat and had brought Aramis and Porthos out of the cavern now seemed to come from a deep gorge within about a league of the grotto

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: It is a pack of hounds, said Porthos the dogs are on a scent.
children.prevalue: It is a pack of hounds said Porthos the dogs are on a scent

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Who can be hunting at such a moment as this? said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Who can be hunting at such a moment as this said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: And this way, particularly, continued Porthos, where they might expect the army of the royalists.
children.prevalue: And this way particularly continued Porthos where they might expect the army of the royalists

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The noise comes nearer. Yes, you are right, Porthos, the dogs are on a scent. But, Yves! cried Aramis, come here! come here!
children.prevalue: The noise comes nearer Yes you are right Porthos the dogs are on a scent But Yves cried Aramis come here come here

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Yves ran towards him, letting fall the cylinder which he was about to place under the boat when the bishop's call interrupted him.
children.prevalue: Yves ran towards him letting fall the cylinder which he was about to place under the boat when the bishop s call interrupted him

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: What is the meaning of this hunt, skipper? said Porthos.
children.prevalue: What is the meaning of this hunt skipper said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Eh! monseigneur, I cannot understand it, replied the Breton. It is not at such a moment that the Seigneur de Locmaria would hunt. No, and yet the dogs
children.prevalue: Eh monseigneur I cannot understand it replied the Breton It is not at such a moment that the Seigneur de Locmaria would hunt No and yet the dogs

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Unless they have escaped from the kennel.
children.prevalue: Unless they have escaped from the kennel

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: No, said Goenne, they are not the Seigneur de Locmaria's hounds.
children.prevalue: No said Goenne they are not the Seigneur de Locmaria s hounds

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: In common prudence, said Aramis, let us go back into the grotto the voices evidently draw nearer, we shall soon know what we have to trust to.
children.prevalue: In common prudence said Aramis let us go back into the grotto the voices evidently draw nearer we shall soon know what we have to trust to

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: They reentered, but had scarcely proceeded a hundred steps in the darkness, when a noise like the hoarse sigh of a creature in distress resounded through the cavern, and breathless, rapid, terrified, a fox passed like a flash of lightning before the fugitives, leaped over the boat and disappeared, leaving behind its sour scent, which was perceptible for several seconds under the low vaults of the cave.
children.prevalue: They reentered but had scarcely proceeded a hundred steps in the darkness when a noise like the hoarse sigh of a creature in distress resounded through the cavern and breathless rapid terrified a fox passed like a flash of lightning before the fugitives leaped over the boat and disappeared leaving behind its sour scent which was perceptible for several seconds under the low vaults of the cave

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The fox! cried the Bretons, with the glad surprise of born hunters.
children.prevalue: The fox cried the Bretons with the glad surprise of born hunters

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Accursed mischance! cried the bishop, our retreat is discovered.
children.prevalue: Accursed mischance cried the bishop our retreat is discovered

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: How so? said Porthos are you afraid of a fox?
children.prevalue: How so said Porthos are you afraid of a fox

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Eh! my friend, what do you mean by that? why do you specify the fox? It is not the fox alone. Pardieu! But don't you know, Porthos, that after the foxes come hounds, and after hounds men?
children.prevalue: Eh my friend what do you mean by that why do you specify the fox It is not the fox alone Pardieu But don t you know Porthos that after the foxes come hounds and after hounds men

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Porthos hung his head. As though to confirm the words of Aramis, they heard the yelping pack approach with frightful swiftness upon the trail. Six foxhounds burst at once upon the little heath, with mingling yelps of triumph.
children.prevalue: Porthos hung his head As though to confirm the words of Aramis they heard the yelping pack approach with frightful swiftness upon the trail Six foxhounds burst at once upon the little heath with mingling yelps of triumph

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: There are the dogs, plain enough! said Aramis, posted on the lookout behind a chink in the rocks now, who are the huntsmen?
children.prevalue: There are the dogs plain enough said Aramis posted on the lookout behind a chink in the rocks now who are the huntsmen

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: If it is the Seigneur de Locmaria's, replied the sailor, he will leave the dogs to hunt the grotto, for he knows them, and will not enter in himself, being quite sure that the fox will come out the other side it is there he will wait for him.
children.prevalue: If it is the Seigneur de Locmaria s replied the sailor he will leave the dogs to hunt the grotto for he knows them and will not enter in himself being quite sure that the fox will come out the other side it is there he will wait for him

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: It is not the Seigneur de Locmaria who is hunting, replied Aramis, turning pale in spite of his efforts to maintain a placid countenance.
children.prevalue: It is not the Seigneur de Locmaria who is hunting replied Aramis turning pale in spite of his efforts to maintain a placid countenance

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Who is it, then? said Porthos.
children.prevalue: Who is it then said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Look!
children.prevalue: Look

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Porthos applied his eye to the slit, and saw at the summit of a hillock a dozen horsemen urging on their horses in the track of the dogs, shouting, Taiaut! taiaut!
children.prevalue: Porthos applied his eye to the slit and saw at the summit of a hillock a dozen horsemen urging on their horses in the track of the dogs shouting Taiaut taiaut

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: The guards! said he.
children.prevalue: The guards said he

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Yes, my friend, the king's guards.
children.prevalue: Yes my friend the king s guards

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: The king's guards! do you say, monseigneur? cried the Bretons, growing pale in turn.
children.prevalue: The king s guards do you say monseigneur cried the Bretons growing pale in turn

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: With Biscarrat at their head, mounted upon my gray horse, continued Aramis.
children.prevalue: With Biscarrat at their head mounted upon my gray horse continued Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The hounds at the same moment rushed into the grotto like an avalanche, and the depths of the cavern were filled with their deafening cries.
children.prevalue: The hounds at the same moment rushed into the grotto like an avalanche and the depths of the cavern were filled with their deafening cries

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Ah! the devil! said Aramis, resuming all his coolness at the sight of this certain, inevitable danger. I am perfectly satisfied we are lost, but we have, at least, one chance left. If the guards who follow their hounds happen to discover there is an issue to the grotto, there is no help for us, for on entering they must see both ourselves and our boat. The dogs must not go out of the cavern. Their masters must not enter.
children.prevalue: Ah the devil said Aramis resuming all his coolness at the sight of this certain inevitable danger I am perfectly satisfied we are lost but we have at least one chance left If the guards who follow their hounds happen to discover there is an issue to the grotto there is no help for us for on entering they must see both ourselves and our boat The dogs must not go out of the cavern Their masters must not enter

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: That is clear, said Porthos.
children.prevalue: That is clear said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: You understand, added Aramis, with the rapid precision of command there are six dogs that will be forced to stop at the great stone under which the fox has glidedbut at the too narrow opening of which they must be themselves stopped and killed.
children.prevalue: You understand added Aramis with the rapid precision of command there are six dogs that will be forced to stop at the great stone under which the fox has glidedbut at the too narrow opening of which they must be themselves stopped and killed

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: The Bretons sprang forward, knife in hand. In a few minutes there was a lamentable concert of angry barks and mortal howlsand then, silence.
children.prevalue: The Bretons sprang forward knife in hand In a few minutes there was a lamentable concert of angry barks and mortal howlsand then silence

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: That's well! said Aramis, coolly, now for the masters!
children.prevalue: That s well said Aramis coolly now for the masters

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: What is to be done with them? said Porthos.
children.prevalue: What is to be done with them said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Wait their arrival, conceal ourselves, and kill them.
children.prevalue: Wait their arrival conceal ourselves and kill them

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Kill them! replied Porthos.
children.prevalue: Kill them replied Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: There are sixteen, said Aramis, at least, at present.
children.prevalue: There are sixteen said Aramis at least at present

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: And well armed, added Porthos, with a smile of consolation.
children.prevalue: And well armed added Porthos with a smile of consolation

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: It will last about ten minutes, said Aramis. To work!
children.prevalue: It will last about ten minutes said Aramis To work

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: And with a resolute air he took up a musket, and placed a huntingknife between his teeth.
children.prevalue: And with a resolute air he took up a musket and placed a huntingknife between his teeth

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: Yves, Goenne, and his son, continued Aramis, will pass the muskets to us. You, Porthos, will fire when they are close. We shall have brought down, at the lowest computation, eight, before the others are aware of anythingthat is certain then all, there are five of us, will dispatch the other eight, knife in hand.
children.prevalue: Yves Goenne and his son continued Aramis will pass the muskets to us You Porthos will fire when they are close We shall have brought down at the lowest computation eight before the others are aware of anythingthat is certain then all there are five of us will dispatch the other eight knife in hand

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: And poor Biscarrat? said Porthos.
children.prevalue: And poor Biscarrat said Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Aramis reflected a momentBiscarrat first, replied he, coolly. He knows us.
children.prevalue: Aramis reflected a momentBiscarrat first replied he coolly He knows us

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: In spite of the sort of divination which was the remarkable side of the character of Aramis, the event, subject to the risks of things over which uncertainty presides, did not fall out exactly as the bishop of Vannes had foreseen. Biscarrat, better mounted than his companions, arrived first at the opening of the grotto, and comprehended that fox and hounds were one and all engulfed in it. Only, struck by that superstitious terror which every dark and subterraneous way naturally impresses upon the mind of man, he stopped at the outside of the grotto, and waited till his companions should have assembled round him.
children.prevalue: In spite of the sort of divination which was the remarkable side of the character of Aramis the event subject to the risks of things over which uncertainty presides did not fall out exactly as the bishop of Vannes had foreseen Biscarrat better mounted than his companions arrived first at the opening of the grotto and comprehended that fox and hounds were one and all engulfed in it Only struck by that superstitious terror which every dark and subterraneous way naturally impresses upon the mind of man he stopped at the outside of the grotto and waited till his companions should have assembled round him

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Well! asked the young men, coming up, out of breath, and unable to understand the meaning of this inaction.
children.prevalue: Well asked the young men coming up out of breath and unable to understand the meaning of this inaction

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Well! I cannot hear the dogs they and the fox must all be lost in this infernal cavern.
children.prevalue: Well I cannot hear the dogs they and the fox must all be lost in this infernal cavern

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: They were too close up, said one of the guards, to have lost scent all at once. Besides, we should hear them from one side or another. They must, as Biscarrat says, be in this grotto.
children.prevalue: They were too close up said one of the guards to have lost scent all at once Besides we should hear them from one side or another They must as Biscarrat says be in this grotto

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: But then, said one of the young men, why don't they give tongue?
children.prevalue: But then said one of the young men why don t they give tongue

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: It is strange! muttered another.
children.prevalue: It is strange muttered another

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Well, but, said a fourth, let us go into this grotto. Does it happen to be forbidden we should enter it?
children.prevalue: Well but said a fourth let us go into this grotto Does it happen to be forbidden we should enter it

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: No, replied Biscarrat. Only, as it looks as dark as a wolf's mouth, we might break our necks in it.
children.prevalue: No replied Biscarrat Only as it looks as dark as a wolf s mouth we might break our necks in it

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Witness the dogs, said a guard, who seem to have broken theirs.
children.prevalue: Witness the dogs said a guard who seem to have broken theirs

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: What the devil can have become of them? asked the young men in chorus. And every master called his dog by his name, whistled to him in his favorite mode, without a single one replying to either call or whistle.
children.prevalue: What the devil can have become of them asked the young men in chorus And every master called his dog by his name whistled to him in his favorite mode without a single one replying to either call or whistle

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: It is perhaps an enchanted grotto, said Biscarrat let us see. And, jumping from his horse, he made a step into the grotto.
children.prevalue: It is perhaps an enchanted grotto said Biscarrat let us see And jumping from his horse he made a step into the grotto

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Stop! stop! I will accompany you, said one of the guards, on seeing Biscarrat disappear in the shades of the cavern's mouth.
children.prevalue: Stop stop I will accompany you said one of the guards on seeing Biscarrat disappear in the shades of the cavern s mouth

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: No, replied Biscarrat, there must be something extraordinary in the placedon't let us risk ourselves all at once. If in ten minutes you do not hear of me, you can come in, but not all at once.
children.prevalue: No replied Biscarrat there must be something extraordinary in the placedon t let us risk ourselves all at once If in ten minutes you do not hear of me you can come in but not all at once

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Be it so, said the young man, who, besides, did not imagine that Biscarrat ran much risk in the enterprise, we will wait for you. And without dismounting from their horses, they formed a circle round the grotto.
children.prevalue: Be it so said the young man who besides did not imagine that Biscarrat ran much risk in the enterprise we will wait for you And without dismounting from their horses they formed a circle round the grotto

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Biscarrat entered then alone, and advanced through the darkness till he came in contact with the muzzle of Porthos's musket. The resistance which his chest met with astonished him he naturally raised his hand and laid hold of the icy barrel. At the same instant, Yves lifted a knife against the young man, which was about to fall upon him with all force of a Breton's arm, when the iron wrist of Porthos stopped it halfway. Then, like low muttering thunder, his voice growled in the darkness, I will not have him killed!
children.prevalue: Biscarrat entered then alone and advanced through the darkness till he came in contact with the muzzle of Porthos s musket The resistance which his chest met with astonished him he naturally raised his hand and laid hold of the icy barrel At the same instant Yves lifted a knife against the young man which was about to fall upon him with all force of a Breton s arm when the iron wrist of Porthos stopped it halfway Then like low muttering thunder his voice growled in the darkness I will not have him killed

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Biscarrat found himself between a protection and a threat, the one almost as terrible as the other. However brave the young man might be, he could not prevent a cry escaping him, which Aramis immediately suppressed by placing a handkerchief over his mouth. Monsieur de Biscarrat, said he, in a low voice, we mean you no harm, and you must know that if you have recognized us but, at the first word, the first groan, the first whisper, we shall be forced to kill you as we have killed your dogs.
children.prevalue: Biscarrat found himself between a protection and a threat the one almost as terrible as the other However brave the young man might be he could not prevent a cry escaping him which Aramis immediately suppressed by placing a handkerchief over his mouth Monsieur de Biscarrat said he in a low voice we mean you no harm and you must know that if you have recognized us but at the first word the first groan the first whisper we shall be forced to kill you as we have killed your dogs

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Yes, I recognize you, gentlemen, said the officer, in a low voice. But why are you herewhat are you doing, here? Unfortunate men! I thought you were in the fort.
children.prevalue: Yes I recognize you gentlemen said the officer in a low voice But why are you herewhat are you doing here Unfortunate men I thought you were in the fort

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: And you, monsieur, you were to obtain conditions for us, I think?
children.prevalue: And you monsieur you were to obtain conditions for us I think

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I did all I was able, messieurs, but
children.prevalue: I did all I was able messieurs but

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: But what?
children.prevalue: But what

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: But there are positive orders.
children.prevalue: But there are positive orders

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: To kill us?
children.prevalue: To kill us

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Biscarrat made no reply. It would have cost him too much to speak of the cord to gentlemen. Aramis understood the silence of the prisoner.
children.prevalue: Biscarrat made no reply It would have cost him too much to speak of the cord to gentlemen Aramis understood the silence of the prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Monsieur Biscarrat, said he, you would be already dead if we had not regard for your youth and our ancient association with your father but you may yet escape from the place by swearing that you will not tell your companions what you have seen.
children.prevalue: Monsieur Biscarrat said he you would be already dead if we had not regard for your youth and our ancient association with your father but you may yet escape from the place by swearing that you will not tell your companions what you have seen

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I will not only swear that I will not speak of it, said Biscarrat, but I still further swear that I will do everything in the world to prevent my companions from setting foot in the grotto.
children.prevalue: I will not only swear that I will not speak of it said Biscarrat but I still further swear that I will do everything in the world to prevent my companions from setting foot in the grotto

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Biscarrat! Biscarrat! cried several voices from the outside, coming like a whirlwind into the cave.
children.prevalue: Biscarrat Biscarrat cried several voices from the outside coming like a whirlwind into the cave

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Reply, said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Reply said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Here I am! cried Biscarrat.
children.prevalue: Here I am cried Biscarrat

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Now, begone we depend on your loyalty. And he left his hold of the young man, who hastily returned towards the light.
children.prevalue: Now begone we depend on your loyalty And he left his hold of the young man who hastily returned towards the light

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Biscarrat! Biscarrat! cried the voices, still nearer. And the shadows of several human forms projected into the interior of the grotto. Biscarrat rushed to meet his friends in order to stop them, and met them just as they were adventuring into the cave. Aramis and Porthos listened with the intense attention of men whose life depends upon a breath of air.
children.prevalue: Biscarrat Biscarrat cried the voices still nearer And the shadows of several human forms projected into the interior of the grotto Biscarrat rushed to meet his friends in order to stop them and met them just as they were adventuring into the cave Aramis and Porthos listened with the intense attention of men whose life depends upon a breath of air

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Oh! oh! exclaimed one of the guards, as he came to the light, how pale you are!
children.prevalue: Oh oh exclaimed one of the guards as he came to the light how pale you are

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Pale! cried another you ought to say corpsecolor.
children.prevalue: Pale cried another you ought to say corpsecolor

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I! said the young man, endeavoring to collect his faculties.
children.prevalue: I said the young man endeavoring to collect his faculties

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: In the name of Heaven! what has happened? exclaimed all the voices.
children.prevalue: In the name of Heaven what has happened exclaimed all the voices

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: You have not a drop of blood in your veins, my poor friend, said one of them, laughing.
children.prevalue: You have not a drop of blood in your veins my poor friend said one of them laughing

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Messieurs, it is serious, said another, he is going to faint does any one of you happen to have any salts? And they all laughed.
children.prevalue: Messieurs it is serious said another he is going to faint does any one of you happen to have any salts And they all laughed

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: This hail of jests fell round Biscarrat's ears like musketballs in a melee. He recovered himself amidst a deluge of interrogations.
children.prevalue: This hail of jests fell round Biscarrat s ears like musketballs in a melee He recovered himself amidst a deluge of interrogations

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: What do you suppose I have seen? asked he. I was too hot when I entered the grotto, and I have been struck with a chill. That is all.
children.prevalue: What do you suppose I have seen asked he I was too hot when I entered the grotto and I have been struck with a chill That is all

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: But the dogs, the dogs have you seen them againdid you see anything of themdo you know anything about them?
children.prevalue: But the dogs the dogs have you seen them againdid you see anything of themdo you know anything about them

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I suppose they have got out some other way.
children.prevalue: I suppose they have got out some other way

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Messieurs, said one of the young men, there is in that which is going on, in the paleness and silence of our friend, a mystery which Biscarrat will not, or cannot reveal. Only, and this is certain, Biscarrat has seen something in the grotto. Well, for my part, I am very curious to see what it is, even if it is the devil! To the grotto! messieurs, to the grotto!
children.prevalue: Messieurs said one of the young men there is in that which is going on in the paleness and silence of our friend a mystery which Biscarrat will not or cannot reveal Only and this is certain Biscarrat has seen something in the grotto Well for my part I am very curious to see what it is even if it is the devil To the grotto messieurs to the grotto

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: To the grotto! repeated all the voices. And the echo of the cavern carried like a menace to Porthos and Aramis, To the grotto! to the grotto!
children.prevalue: To the grotto repeated all the voices And the echo of the cavern carried like a menace to Porthos and Aramis To the grotto to the grotto

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Biscarrat threw himself before his companions. Messieurs! messieurs! cried he, in the name of Heaven! do not go in!
children.prevalue: Biscarrat threw himself before his companions Messieurs messieurs cried he in the name of Heaven do not go in

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Why, what is there so terrific in the cavern? asked several at once. Come, speak, Biscarrat.
children.prevalue: Why what is there so terrific in the cavern asked several at once Come speak Biscarrat

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Decidedly, it is the devil he has seen, repeated he who had before advanced that hypothesis.
children.prevalue: Decidedly it is the devil he has seen repeated he who had before advanced that hypothesis

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Well, said another, if he has seen him, he need not be selfish he may as well let us have a look at him in turn.
children.prevalue: Well said another if he has seen him he need not be selfish he may as well let us have a look at him in turn

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Messieurs! messieurs! I beseech you, urged Biscarrat.
children.prevalue: Messieurs messieurs I beseech you urged Biscarrat

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Nonsense! Let us pass!
children.prevalue: Nonsense Let us pass

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Messieurs, I implore you not to enter!
children.prevalue: Messieurs I implore you not to enter

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Why, you went in yourself.
children.prevalue: Why you went in yourself

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Then one of the officers, whoof a riper age than the othershad till this time remained behind, and had said nothing, advanced. Messieurs, said he, with a calmness which contrasted with the animation of the young men, there is in there some person, or something, that is not the devil but which, whatever it may be, has had sufficient power to silence our dogs. We must discover who this some one is, or what this something is.
children.prevalue: Then one of the officers whoof a riper age than the othershad till this time remained behind and had said nothing advanced Messieurs said he with a calmness which contrasted with the animation of the young men there is in there some person or something that is not the devil but which whatever it may be has had sufficient power to silence our dogs We must discover who this some one is or what this something is

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Biscarrat made a last effort to stop his friends, but it was useless. In vain he threw himself before the rashest in vain he clung to the rocks to bar the passage the crowd of young men rushed into the cave, in the steps of the officer who had spoken last, but who had sprung in first, sword in hand, to face the unknown danger. Biscarrat, repulsed by his friends, unable to accompany them, without passing in the eyes of Porthos and Aramis for a traitor and a perjurer, with painfully attentive ear and unconsciously supplicating hands leaned against the rough side of a rock which he thought must be exposed to the fire of the musketeers. As to the guards, they penetrated further and further, with exclamations that grew fainter as they advanced. All at once, a discharge of musketry, growling like thunder, exploded in the entrails of the vault. Two or three balls were flattened against the rock on which Biscarrat was leaning. At the same instant, cries, shrieks, imprecations burst forth, and the little troop of gentlemen reappearedsome pale, some bleedingall enveloped in a cloud of smoke, which the outer air seemed to suck from the depths of the cavern. Biscarrat! Biscarrat! cried the fugitives, you knew there was an ambuscade in that cavern, and you did not warn us! Biscarrat, you are the cause that four of us are murdered men! Woe be to you, Biscarrat!
children.prevalue: Biscarrat made a last effort to stop his friends but it was useless In vain he threw himself before the rashest in vain he clung to the rocks to bar the passage the crowd of young men rushed into the cave in the steps of the officer who had spoken last but who had sprung in first sword in hand to face the unknown danger Biscarrat repulsed by his friends unable to accompany them without passing in the eyes of Porthos and Aramis for a traitor and a perjurer with painfully attentive ear and unconsciously supplicating hands leaned against the rough side of a rock which he thought must be exposed to the fire of the musketeers As to the guards they penetrated further and further with exclamations that grew fainter as they advanced All at once a discharge of musketry growling like thunder exploded in the entrails of the vault Two or three balls were flattened against the rock on which Biscarrat was leaning At the same instant cries shrieks imprecations burst forth and the little troop of gentlemen reappearedsome pale some bleedingall enveloped in a cloud of smoke which the outer air seemed to suck from the depths of the cavern Biscarrat Biscarrat cried the fugitives you knew there was an ambuscade in that cavern and you did not warn us Biscarrat you are the cause that four of us are murdered men Woe be to you Biscarrat

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: You are the cause of my being wounded unto death, said one of the young men, letting a gush of scarlet lifeblood vomit in his palm, and spattering it into Biscarrat's livid face. My blood be on your head! And he rolled in agony at the feet of the young man.
children.prevalue: You are the cause of my being wounded unto death said one of the young men letting a gush of scarlet lifeblood vomit in his palm and spattering it into Biscarrat s livid face My blood be on your head And he rolled in agony at the feet of the young man

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: But, at least, tell us who is there? cried several furious voices.
children.prevalue: But at least tell us who is there cried several furious voices

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: Biscarrat remained silent. Tell us, or die! cried the wounded man, raising himself upon one knee, and lifting towards his companion an arm bearing a useless sword. Biscarrat rushed towards him, opening his breast for the blow, but the wounded man fell back not to rise again, uttering a groan which was his last. Biscarrat, with hair on end, haggard eyes, and bewildered head, advanced towards the interior of the cavern, saying, You are right. Death to me, who have allowed my comrades to be assassinated. I am a worthless wretch! And throwing away his sword, for he wished to die without defending himself, he rushed head foremost into the cavern. The others followed him. The eleven who remained out of sixteen imitated his example but they did not go further than the first. A second discharge laid five upon the icy sand and as it was impossible to see whence this murderous thunder issued, the others fell back with a terror that can be better imagined than described. But, far from flying, as the others had done, Biscarrat remained safe and sound, seated on a fragment of rock, and waited. There were only six gentlemen left.
children.prevalue: Biscarrat remained silent Tell us or die cried the wounded man raising himself upon one knee and lifting towards his companion an arm bearing a useless sword Biscarrat rushed towards him opening his breast for the blow but the wounded man fell back not to rise again uttering a groan which was his last Biscarrat with hair on end haggard eyes and bewildered head advanced towards the interior of the cavern saying You are right Death to me who have allowed my comrades to be assassinated I am a worthless wretch And throwing away his sword for he wished to die without defending himself he rushed head foremost into the cavern The others followed him The eleven who remained out of sixteen imitated his example but they did not go further than the first A second discharge laid five upon the icy sand and as it was impossible to see whence this murderous thunder issued the others fell back with a terror that can be better imagined than described But far from flying as the others had done Biscarrat remained safe and sound seated on a fragment of rock and waited There were only six gentlemen left

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Seriously, said one of the survivors, is it the devil?
children.prevalue: Seriously said one of the survivors is it the devil

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Ma foi! it is much worse, said another.
children.prevalue: Ma foi it is much worse said another

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Ask Biscarrat, he knows.
children.prevalue: Ask Biscarrat he knows

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Where is Biscarrat? The young men looked round them, and saw that Biscarrat did not answer.
children.prevalue: Where is Biscarrat The young men looked round them and saw that Biscarrat did not answer

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: He is dead! said two or three voices.
children.prevalue: He is dead said two or three voices

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Oh! no! replied another, I saw him through the smoke, sitting quietly on a rock. He is in the cavern he is waiting for us.
children.prevalue: Oh no replied another I saw him through the smoke sitting quietly on a rock He is in the cavern he is waiting for us

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: He must know who are there.
children.prevalue: He must know who are there

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: And how should he know them?
children.prevalue: And how should he know them

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: He was taken prisoner by the rebels.
children.prevalue: He was taken prisoner by the rebels

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: That is true. Well! let us call him, and learn from him whom we have to deal with. And all voices shouted, Biscarrat! Biscarrat! But Biscarrat did not answer.
children.prevalue: That is true Well let us call him and learn from him whom we have to deal with And all voices shouted Biscarrat Biscarrat But Biscarrat did not answer

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Good! said the officer who had shown so much coolness in the affair. We have no longer any need of him here are reinforcements coming.
children.prevalue: Good said the officer who had shown so much coolness in the affair We have no longer any need of him here are reinforcements coming

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: In fact, a company of guards, left in the rear by their officers, whom the ardor of the chase had carried awayfrom seventyfive to eighty menarrived in good order, led by their captain and the first lieutenant. The five officers hastened to meet their soldiers and, in language the eloquence of which may be easily imagined, they related the adventure, and asked for aid. The captain interrupted them. Where are your companions? demanded he.

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Dead!
children.prevalue: Dead

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: But there were sixteen of you!
children.prevalue: But there were sixteen of you

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Ten are dead. Biscarrat is in the cavern, and we are five.
children.prevalue: Ten are dead Biscarrat is in the cavern and we are five

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Biscarrat is a prisoner?
children.prevalue: Biscarrat is a prisoner

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Probably.
children.prevalue: Probably

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: No, for here he islook. In fact, Biscarrat appeared at the opening of the grotto.
children.prevalue: No for here he islook In fact Biscarrat appeared at the opening of the grotto

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: He is making a sign to come on, said the officer. Come on!
children.prevalue: He is making a sign to come on said the officer Come on

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Come on! cried all the troop. And they advanced to meet Biscarrat.
children.prevalue: Come on cried all the troop And they advanced to meet Biscarrat

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Monsieur, said the captain, addressing Biscarrat, I am assured that you know who the men are in that grotto, and who make such a desperate defense. In the king's name I command you to declare what you know.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said the captain addressing Biscarrat I am assured that you know who the men are in that grotto and who make such a desperate defense In the king s name I command you to declare what you know

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Captain, said Biscarrat, you have no need to command me. My word has been restored to me this very instant and I came in the name of these men.
children.prevalue: Captain said Biscarrat you have no need to command me My word has been restored to me this very instant and I came in the name of these men

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: To tell me who they are?
children.prevalue: To tell me who they are

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: To tell you they are determined to defend themselves to the death, unless you grant them satisfactory terms.
children.prevalue: To tell you they are determined to defend themselves to the death unless you grant them satisfactory terms

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: How many are there of them, then?
children.prevalue: How many are there of them then

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: There are two, said Biscarrat.
children.prevalue: There are two said Biscarrat

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: There are twoand want to impose conditions upon us?
children.prevalue: There are twoand want to impose conditions upon us

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: There are two, and they have already killed ten of our men.
children.prevalue: There are two and they have already killed ten of our men

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: What sort of people are theygiants?
children.prevalue: What sort of people are theygiants

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Worse than that. Do you remember the history of the Bastion SaintGervais, captain?
children.prevalue: Worse than that Do you remember the history of the Bastion SaintGervais captain

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: Yes where four musketeers held out against an army.
children.prevalue: Yes where four musketeers held out against an army

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Well, these are two of those same musketeers.
children.prevalue: Well these are two of those same musketeers

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: And their names?
children.prevalue: And their names

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: At that period they were called Porthos and Aramis. Now they are styled M. d'Herblay and M. du Vallon.
children.prevalue: At that period they were called Porthos and Aramis Now they are styled M d Herblay and M du Vallon

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: And what interest have they in all this?
children.prevalue: And what interest have they in all this

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: It is they who were holding BellIsle for M. Fouquet.
children.prevalue: It is they who were holding BellIsle for M Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: A murmur ran through the ranks of the soldiers on hearing the two words Porthos and Aramis. The musketeers! the musketeers! repeated they. And among all these brave men, the idea that they were going to have a struggle against two of the oldest glories of the French army, made a shiver, half enthusiasm, twothirds terror, run through them. In fact, those four namesD'Artagnan, Athos, Porthos, and Aramiswere venerated among all who wore a sword as, in antiquity, the names of Hercules, Theseus, Castor, and Pollux were venerated.
children.prevalue: A murmur ran through the ranks of the soldiers on hearing the two words Porthos and Aramis The musketeers the musketeers repeated they And among all these brave men the idea that they were going to have a struggle against two of the oldest glories of the French army made a shiver half enthusiasm twothirds terror run through them In fact those four namesD Artagnan Athos Porthos and Aramiswere venerated among all who wore a sword as in antiquity the names of Hercules Theseus Castor and Pollux were venerated

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: Two menand they have killed ten in two discharges! It is impossible, Monsieur Biscarrat!
children.prevalue: Two menand they have killed ten in two discharges It is impossible Monsieur Biscarrat

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: Eh! captain, replied the latter, I do not tell you that they have not with them two or three men, as the musketeers of the Bastion SaintGervais had two or three lackeys but, believe me, captain, I have seen these men, I have been taken prisoner by themI know they themselves alone are allsufficient to destroy an army.
children.prevalue: Eh captain replied the latter I do not tell you that they have not with them two or three men as the musketeers of the Bastion SaintGervais had two or three lackeys but believe me captain I have seen these men I have been taken prisoner by themI know they themselves alone are allsufficient to destroy an army

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: That we shall see, said the captain, and that in a moment, too. Gentlemen, attention!
children.prevalue: That we shall see said the captain and that in a moment too Gentlemen attention

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: At this reply, no one stirred, and all prepared to obey. Biscarrat alone risked a last attempt.
children.prevalue: At this reply no one stirred and all prepared to obey Biscarrat alone risked a last attempt

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: Monsieur, said he, in a low voice, be persuaded by me let us pass on our way. Those two men, those two lions you are going to attack, will defend themselves to the death. They have already killed ten of our men they will kill double the number, and end by killing themselves rather than surrender. What shall we gain by fighting them?
children.prevalue: Monsieur said he in a low voice be persuaded by me let us pass on our way Those two men those two lions you are going to attack will defend themselves to the death They have already killed ten of our men they will kill double the number and end by killing themselves rather than surrender What shall we gain by fighting them

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: We shall gain the consciousness, monsieur, of not having allowed eighty of the king's guards to retire before two rebels. If I listened to your advice, monsieur, I should be a dishonored man and by dishonoring myself I should dishonor the army. Forward, my men!
children.prevalue: We shall gain the consciousness monsieur of not having allowed eighty of the king s guards to retire before two rebels If I listened to your advice monsieur I should be a dishonored man and by dishonoring myself I should dishonor the army Forward my men

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: And he marched first as far as the opening of the grotto. There he halted. The object of this halt was to give Biscarrat and his companions time to describe to him the interior of the grotto. Then, when he believed he had a sufficient acquaintance with the place, he divided his company into three bodies, which were to enter successively, keeping up a sustained fire in all directions. No doubt, in this attack they would lose five more, perhaps ten but, certainly, they must end by taking the rebels, since there was no issue and, at any rate, two men could not kill eighty.
children.prevalue: And he marched first as far as the opening of the grotto There he halted The object of this halt was to give Biscarrat and his companions time to describe to him the interior of the grotto Then when he believed he had a sufficient acquaintance with the place he divided his company into three bodies which were to enter successively keeping up a sustained fire in all directions No doubt in this attack they would lose five more perhaps ten but certainly they must end by taking the rebels since there was no issue and at any rate two men could not kill eighty

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Captain, said Biscarrat, I beg to be allowed to march at the head of the first platoon.
children.prevalue: Captain said Biscarrat I beg to be allowed to march at the head of the first platoon

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: So be it, replied the captain you have all the honor. I make you a present of it.
children.prevalue: So be it replied the captain you have all the honor I make you a present of it

children.name: Paragraph_102
children.value: Thanks! replied the young man, with all the firmness of his race.
children.prevalue: Thanks replied the young man with all the firmness of his race

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: Take your sword, then.
children.prevalue: Take your sword then

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: I shall go as I am, captain, said Biscarrat, for I do not go to kill, I go to be killed.
children.prevalue: I shall go as I am captain said Biscarrat for I do not go to kill I go to be killed

children.name: Paragraph_105
children.value: And placing himself at the head of the first platoon, with head uncovered and arms crossed,March, gentlemen, said he.
children.prevalue: And placing himself at the head of the first platoon with head uncovered and arms crossed March gentlemen said he

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: It is time to pass to the other camp, and to describe at once the combatants and the field of battle. Aramis and Porthos had gone to the grotto of Locmaria with the expectation of finding there their canoe ready armed, as well as the three Bretons, their assistants and they at first hoped to make the bark pass through the little issue of the cavern, concealing in that fashion both their labors and their flight. The arrival of the fox and dogs obliged them to remain concealed. The grotto extended the space of about a hundred toises, to that little slope dominating a creek. Formerly a temple of the Celtic divinities, when BelleIsle was still called Kalonese, this grotto had beheld more than one human sacrifice accomplished in its mystic depths. The first entrance to the cavern was by a moderate descent, above which distorted rocks formed a weird arcade the interior, very uneven and dangerous from the inequalities of the vault, was subdivided into several compartments, which communicated with each other by means of rough and jagged steps, fixed right and left, in uncouth natural pillars. At the third compartment the vault was so low, the passage so narrow, that the bark would scarcely have passed without touching the side nevertheless, in moments of despair, wood softens and stone grows flexible beneath the human will. Such was the thought of Aramis, when, after having fought the fight, he decided upon flighta flight most dangerous, since all the assailants were not dead and that, admitting the possibility of putting the bark to sea, they would have to fly in open day, before the conquered, so interested on recognizing their small number, in pursuing their conquerors. When the two discharges had killed ten men, Aramis, familiar with the windings of the cavern, went to reconnoiter them one by one, and counted them, for the smoke prevented seeing outside and he immediately commanded that the canoe should be rolled as far as the great stone, the closure of the liberating issue. Porthos collected all his strength, took the canoe in his arms, and raised it up, whilst the Bretons made it run rapidly along the rollers. They had descended into the third compartment they had arrived at the stone which walled the outlet. Porthos seized this gigantic stone at its base, applied his robust shoulder, and gave a heave which made the wall crack. A cloud of dust fell from the vault, with the ashes of ten thousand generations of sea birds, whose nests stuck like cement to the rock. At the third shock the stone gave way, and oscillated for a minute. Porthos, placing his back against the neighboring rock, made an arch with his foot, which drove the block out of the calcareous masses which served for hinges and cramps. The stone fell, and daylight was visible, brilliant, radiant, flooding the cavern through the opening, and the blue sea appeared to the delighted Bretons. They began to lift the bark over the barricade. Twenty more toises, and it would glide into the ocean. It was during this time that the company arrived, was drawn up by the captain, and disposed for either an escalade or an assault. Aramis watched over everything, to favor the labors of his friends. He saw the reinforcements, counted the men, and convinced himself at a single glance of the insurmountable peril to which fresh combat would expose them. To escape by sea, at the moment the cavern was about to be invaded, was impossible. In fact, the daylight which had just been admitted to the last compartments had exposed to the soldiers the bark being rolled towards the sea, the two rebels within musketshot and one of their discharges would riddle the boat if it did not kill the navigators. Besides, allowing everything,if the bark escaped with the men on board of it, how could the alarm be suppressedhow could notice to the royal lighters be prevented? What could hinder the poor canoe, followed by sea and watched from the shore, from succumbing before the end of the day? Aramis, digging his hands into his gray hair with rage, invoked the assistance of God and the assistance of the demons. Calling to Porthos, who was doing more work than all the rollerswhether of flesh or woodMy friend, said he, our adversaries have just received a reinforcement.

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Ah, ah! said Porthos, quietly, what is to be done, then?
children.prevalue: Ah ah said Porthos quietly what is to be done then

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: To recommence the combat, said Aramis, is hazardous.
children.prevalue: To recommence the combat said Aramis is hazardous

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Yes, said Porthos, for it is difficult to suppose that out of two, one should not be killed and certainly, if one of us was killed, the other would get himself killed also. Porthos spoke these words with that heroic nature which, with him, grew grander with necessity.
children.prevalue: Yes said Porthos for it is difficult to suppose that out of two one should not be killed and certainly if one of us was killed the other would get himself killed also Porthos spoke these words with that heroic nature which with him grew grander with necessity

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Aramis felt it like a spur to his heart. We shall neither of us be killed if you do what I tell you, friend Porthos.
children.prevalue: Aramis felt it like a spur to his heart We shall neither of us be killed if you do what I tell you friend Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Tell me what?
children.prevalue: Tell me what

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: These people are coming down into the grotto.
children.prevalue: These people are coming down into the grotto

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Yes.
children.prevalue: Yes

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: We could kill about fifteen of them, but no more.
children.prevalue: We could kill about fifteen of them but no more

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: How many are there in all? asked Porthos.
children.prevalue: How many are there in all asked Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: They have received a reinforcement of seventyfive men.
children.prevalue: They have received a reinforcement of seventyfive men

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Seventyfive and five, eighty. Ah! sighed Porthos.
children.prevalue: Seventyfive and five eighty Ah sighed Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: If they fire all at once they will riddle us with balls.
children.prevalue: If they fire all at once they will riddle us with balls

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Certainly they will.
children.prevalue: Certainly they will

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Without reckoning, added Aramis, that the detonation might occasion a collapse of the cavern.
children.prevalue: Without reckoning added Aramis that the detonation might occasion a collapse of the cavern

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Ay, said Porthos, a piece of falling rock just now grazed my shoulder.
children.prevalue: Ay said Porthos a piece of falling rock just now grazed my shoulder

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: You see, then?
children.prevalue: You see then

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Oh! it is nothing.
children.prevalue: Oh it is nothing

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: We must determine upon something quickly. Our Bretons are going to continue to roll the canoe towards the sea.
children.prevalue: We must determine upon something quickly Our Bretons are going to continue to roll the canoe towards the sea

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Very well.
children.prevalue: Very well

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: We two will keep the powder, the balls, and the muskets here.
children.prevalue: We two will keep the powder the balls and the muskets here

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: But only two, my dear Aramiswe shall never fire three shots together, said Porthos, innocently, the defense by musketry is a bad one.
children.prevalue: But only two my dear Aramiswe shall never fire three shots together said Porthos innocently the defense by musketry is a bad one

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Find a better, then.
children.prevalue: Find a better then

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: I have found one, said the giant, eagerly I will place myself in ambuscade behind the pillar with this iron bar, and invisible, unattackable, if they come in floods, I can let my bar fall upon their skulls, thirty times in a minute. Hein! what do you think of the project? You smile!
children.prevalue: I have found one said the giant eagerly I will place myself in ambuscade behind the pillar with this iron bar and invisible unattackable if they come in floods I can let my bar fall upon their skulls thirty times in a minute Hein what do you think of the project You smile

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Excellent, dear friend, perfect! I approve it greatly only you will frighten them, and half of them will remain outside to take us by famine. What we want, my good friend, is the entire destruction of the troop. A single survivor encompasses our ruin.
children.prevalue: Excellent dear friend perfect I approve it greatly only you will frighten them and half of them will remain outside to take us by famine What we want my good friend is the entire destruction of the troop A single survivor encompasses our ruin

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: You are right, my friend, but how can we attract them, pray?
children.prevalue: You are right my friend but how can we attract them pray

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: By not stirring, my good Porthos.
children.prevalue: By not stirring my good Porthos

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Well! we won't stir, then but when they are all together
children.prevalue: Well we won t stir then but when they are all together

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Then leave it to me, I have an idea.
children.prevalue: Then leave it to me I have an idea

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: If it is so, and your idea proves a good oneand your idea is most likely to be goodI am satisfied.
children.prevalue: If it is so and your idea proves a good oneand your idea is most likely to be goodI am satisfied

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: To your ambuscade, Porthos, and count how many enter.
children.prevalue: To your ambuscade Porthos and count how many enter

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: But you, what will you do?
children.prevalue: But you what will you do

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Don't trouble yourself about me I have a task to perform.
children.prevalue: Don t trouble yourself about me I have a task to perform

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I think I hear shouts.
children.prevalue: I think I hear shouts

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: It is they! To your post. Keep within reach of my voice and hand.
children.prevalue: It is they To your post Keep within reach of my voice and hand

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Porthos took refuge in the second compartment, which was in darkness, absolutely black. Aramis glided into the third the giant held in his hand an iron bar of about fifty pounds weight. Porthos handled this lever, which had been used in rolling the bark, with marvelous facility. During this time, the Bretons had pushed the bark to the beach. In the further and lighter compartment, Aramis, stooping and concealed, was busy with some mysterious maneuver. A command was given in a loud voice. It was the last order of the captain commandant. Twentyfive men jumped from the upper rocks into the first compartment of the grotto, and having taken their ground, began to fire. The echoes shrieked and barked, the hissing balls seemed actually to rarefy the air, and then opaque smoke filled the vault.
