children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: You! replied the captain, in a stern voice, you here!oh! madame, I should better have liked to see you decked with flowers in the mansion of the Comte de la Fere. You would have wept lessand they tooand I!
children.prevalue: You replied the captain in a stern voice you here oh madame I should better have liked to see you decked with flowers in the mansion of the Comte de la Fere You would have wept lessand they tooand I

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Monsieur! said she, sobbing.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said she sobbing

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: For it was you, added this pitiless friend of the dead,it was you who sped these two men to the grave.
children.prevalue: For it was you added this pitiless friend of the dead it was you who sped these two men to the grave

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Oh! spare me!
children.prevalue: Oh spare me

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: God forbid, madame, that I should offend a woman, or that I should make her weep in vain but I must say that the place of the murderer is not upon the grave of her victims. She wished to reply.
children.prevalue: God forbid madame that I should offend a woman or that I should make her weep in vain but I must say that the place of the murderer is not upon the grave of her victims She wished to reply

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: What I now tell you, added he, coldly, I have already told the king.
children.prevalue: What I now tell you added he coldly I have already told the king

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: She clasped her hands. I know, said she, I have caused the death of the Vicomte de Bragelonne.
children.prevalue: She clasped her hands I know said she I have caused the death of the Vicomte de Bragelonne

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Ah! you know it?
children.prevalue: Ah you know it

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The news arrived at court yesterday. I have traveled during the night forty leagues to come and ask pardon of the comte, whom I supposed to be still living, and to pray God, on the tomb of Raoul, that he would send me all the misfortunes I have merited, except a single one. Now, monsieur, I know that the death of the son has killed the father I have two crimes to reproach myself with I have two punishments to expect from Heaven.
children.prevalue: The news arrived at court yesterday I have traveled during the night forty leagues to come and ask pardon of the comte whom I supposed to be still living and to pray God on the tomb of Raoul that he would send me all the misfortunes I have merited except a single one Now monsieur I know that the death of the son has killed the father I have two crimes to reproach myself with I have two punishments to expect from Heaven

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I will repeat to you, mademoiselle, said D'Artagnan, what M. de Bragelonne said of you, at Antibes, when he already meditated death: 'If pride and coquetry have misled her, I pardon her while despising her. If love has produced her error, I pardon her, but I swear that no one could have loved her as I have done.'
children.prevalue: I will repeat to you mademoiselle said D Artagnan what M de Bragelonne said of you at Antibes when he already meditated death If pride and coquetry have misled her I pardon her while despising her If love has produced her error I pardon her but I swear that no one could have loved her as I have done

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: You know, interrupted Louise, that of my love I was about to sacrifice myself you know whether I suffered when you met me lost, dying, abandoned. Well! never have I suffered so much as now because then I hoped, desired,now I have no longer anything to wish for because this death drags all my joy into the tomb because I can no longer dare to love without remorse, and I feel that he whom I loveoh! it is but just!will repay me with the tortures I have made others undergo.
children.prevalue: You know interrupted Louise that of my love I was about to sacrifice myself you know whether I suffered when you met me lost dying abandoned Well never have I suffered so much as now because then I hoped desired now I have no longer anything to wish for because this death drags all my joy into the tomb because I can no longer dare to love without remorse and I feel that he whom I loveoh it is but just will repay me with the tortures I have made others undergo

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: D'Artagnan made no reply he was too well convinced that she was not mistaken.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan made no reply he was too well convinced that she was not mistaken

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Well, then, added she, dear Monsieur d'Artagnan, do not overwhelm me today, I again implore you! I am like the branch torn from the trunk, I no longer hold to anything in this worlda current drags me on, I know not whither. I love madly, even to the point of coming to tell it, wretch that I am, over the ashes of the dead, and I do not blush for itI have no remorse on this account. Such love is a religion. Only, as hereafter you will see me alone, forgotten, disdained as you will see me punished, as I am destined to be punished, spare me in my ephemeral happiness, leave it to me for a few days, for a few minutes. Now, even at the moment I am speaking to you, perhaps it no longer exists. My God! this double murder is perhaps already expiated!
children.prevalue: Well then added she dear Monsieur d Artagnan do not overwhelm me today I again implore you I am like the branch torn from the trunk I no longer hold to anything in this worlda current drags me on I know not whither I love madly even to the point of coming to tell it wretch that I am over the ashes of the dead and I do not blush for itI have no remorse on this account Such love is a religion Only as hereafter you will see me alone forgotten disdained as you will see me punished as I am destined to be punished spare me in my ephemeral happiness leave it to me for a few days for a few minutes Now even at the moment I am speaking to you perhaps it no longer exists My God this double murder is perhaps already expiated

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: While she was speaking thus, the sound of voices and of horses drew the attention of the captain. M. de SaintAignan came to seek La Valliere. The king, he said, is a prey to jealousy and uneasiness. SaintAignan did not perceive D'Artagnan, half concealed by the trunk of a chestnuttree which shaded the double grave. Louise thanked SaintAignan, and dismissed him with a gesture. He rejoined the party outside the inclosure.
children.prevalue: While she was speaking thus the sound of voices and of horses drew the attention of the captain M de SaintAignan came to seek La Valliere The king he said is a prey to jealousy and uneasiness SaintAignan did not perceive D Artagnan half concealed by the trunk of a chestnuttree which shaded the double grave Louise thanked SaintAignan and dismissed him with a gesture He rejoined the party outside the inclosure

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: You see, madame, said the captain bitterly to the young woman,you see your happiness still lasts.
children.prevalue: You see madame said the captain bitterly to the young woman you see your happiness still lasts

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The young woman raised her head with a solemn air. A day will come, said she, when you will repent of having so misjudged me. On that day, it is I who will pray God to forgive you for having been unjust towards me. Besides, I shall suffer so much that you yourself will be the first to pity my sufferings. Do not reproach me with my fleeting happiness, Monsieur d'Artagnan it costs me dear, and I have not paid all my debt. Saying these words, she again knelt down, softly and affectionately.
children.prevalue: The young woman raised her head with a solemn air A day will come said she when you will repent of having so misjudged me On that day it is I who will pray God to forgive you for having been unjust towards me Besides I shall suffer so much that you yourself will be the first to pity my sufferings Do not reproach me with my fleeting happiness Monsieur d Artagnan it costs me dear and I have not paid all my debt Saying these words she again knelt down softly and affectionately

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Pardon me the last time, my affianced Raoul! said she. I have broken our chain we are both destined to die of grief. It is thou who departest first fear nothing, I shall follow thee. See, only, that I have not been base, and that I have come to bid thee this last adieu. The Lord is my witness, Raoul, that if with my life I could have redeemed thine, I would have given that life without hesitation. I could not give my love. Once more, forgive me, dearest, kindest friend.
children.prevalue: Pardon me the last time my affianced Raoul said she I have broken our chain we are both destined to die of grief It is thou who departest first fear nothing I shall follow thee See only that I have not been base and that I have come to bid thee this last adieu The Lord is my witness Raoul that if with my life I could have redeemed thine I would have given that life without hesitation I could not give my love Once more forgive me dearest kindest friend

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: She strewed a few sweet flowers on the freshly sodded earth then, wiping the tears from her eyes, the heavily stricken lady bowed to D'Artagnan, and disappeared.
children.prevalue: She strewed a few sweet flowers on the freshly sodded earth then wiping the tears from her eyes the heavily stricken lady bowed to D Artagnan and disappeared

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The captain watched the departure of the horses, horsemen, and carriage, then crossing his arms upon his swelling chest, When will it be my turn to depart? said he, in an agitated voice. What is there left for man after youth, love, glory, friendship, strength, and wealth have disappeared? That rock, under which sleeps Porthos, who possessed all I have named this moss, under which repose Athos and Raoul, who possessed much more!
children.prevalue: The captain watched the departure of the horses horsemen and carriage then crossing his arms upon his swelling chest When will it be my turn to depart said he in an agitated voice What is there left for man after youth love glory friendship strength and wealth have disappeared That rock under which sleeps Porthos who possessed all I have named this moss under which repose Athos and Raoul who possessed much more

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: He hesitated for a moment, with a dull eye then, drawing himself up, Forward! still forward! said he. When it is time, God will tell me, as he foretold the others.
children.prevalue: He hesitated for a moment with a dull eye then drawing himself up Forward still forward said he When it is time God will tell me as he foretold the others

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: He touched the earth, moistened with the evening dew, with the ends of his fingers, signed himself as if he had been at the benitier in church, and retook aloneever alonethe road to Paris.
children.prevalue: He touched the earth moistened with the evening dew with the ends of his fingers signed himself as if he had been at the benitier in church and retook aloneever alonethe road to Paris

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Epilogue.
children.prevalue: Epilogue

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Four years after the scene we have just described, two horsemen, well mounted, traversed Blois early in the morning, for the purpose of arranging a hawking party the king had arranged to make in that uneven plain the Loire divides in two, which borders on the one side Meung, on the other Amboise. These were the keeper of the king's harriers and the master of the falcons, personages greatly respected in the time of Louis XIII., but rather neglected by his successor. The horsemen, having reconnoitered the ground, were returning, their observations made, when they perceived certain little groups of soldiers, here and there, whom the sergeants were placing at distances at the openings of the inclosures. These were the king's musketeers. Behind them came, upon a splendid horse, the captain, known by his richly embroidered uniform. His hair was gray, his beard turning so. He seemed a little bent, although sitting and handling his horse gracefully. He was looking about him watchfully.
children.prevalue: Four years after the scene we have just described two horsemen well mounted traversed Blois early in the morning for the purpose of arranging a hawking party the king had arranged to make in that uneven plain the Loire divides in two which borders on the one side Meung on the other Amboise These were the keeper of the king s harriers and the master of the falcons personages greatly respected in the time of Louis XIII but rather neglected by his successor The horsemen having reconnoitered the ground were returning their observations made when they perceived certain little groups of soldiers here and there whom the sergeants were placing at distances at the openings of the inclosures These were the king s musketeers Behind them came upon a splendid horse the captain known by his richly embroidered uniform His hair was gray his beard turning so He seemed a little bent although sitting and handling his horse gracefully He was looking about him watchfully

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: M. d'Artagnan does not get any older, said the keeper of the harriers to his colleague the falconer with ten years more to carry than either of us, he has the seat of a young man on horseback.
children.prevalue: M d Artagnan does not get any older said the keeper of the harriers to his colleague the falconer with ten years more to carry than either of us he has the seat of a young man on horseback

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: That is true, replied the falconer. I don't see any change in him for the last twenty years.
children.prevalue: That is true replied the falconer I don t see any change in him for the last twenty years

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: But this officer was mistaken D'Artagnan in the last four years had lived a dozen. Age had printed its pitiless claws at each angle of his eyes his brow was bald his hands, formerly brown and nervous, were getting white, as if the blood had half forgotten them.
children.prevalue: But this officer was mistaken D Artagnan in the last four years had lived a dozen Age had printed its pitiless claws at each angle of his eyes his brow was bald his hands formerly brown and nervous were getting white as if the blood had half forgotten them

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: D'Artagnan accosted the officers with the shade of affability which distinguishes superiors, and received in turn for his courtesy two most respectful bows.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan accosted the officers with the shade of affability which distinguishes superiors and received in turn for his courtesy two most respectful bows

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Ah! what a lucky chance to see you here, Monsieur d'Artagnan! cried the falconer.
children.prevalue: Ah what a lucky chance to see you here Monsieur d Artagnan cried the falconer

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: It is rather I who should say that, messieurs, replied the captain, for nowadays, the king makes more frequent use of his musketeers than of his falcons.
children.prevalue: It is rather I who should say that messieurs replied the captain for nowadays the king makes more frequent use of his musketeers than of his falcons

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Ah! it is not as it was in the good old times, sighed the falconer. Do you remember, Monsieur d'Artagnan, when the late king flew the pie in the vineyards beyond Beaugence? Ah! dame! you were not the captain of the musketeers at that time, Monsieur d'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Ah it is not as it was in the good old times sighed the falconer Do you remember Monsieur d Artagnan when the late king flew the pie in the vineyards beyond Beaugence Ah dame you were not the captain of the musketeers at that time Monsieur d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: And you were nothing but undercorporal of the tiercelets, replied D'Artagnan, laughing. Never mind that, it was a good time, seeing that it is always a good time when we are young. Good day, monsieur the keeper of the harriers.
children.prevalue: And you were nothing but undercorporal of the tiercelets replied D Artagnan laughing Never mind that it was a good time seeing that it is always a good time when we are young Good day monsieur the keeper of the harriers

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: You do me honor, monsieur le comte, said the latter. D'Artagnan made no reply. The title of comte had hardly struck him D'Artagnan had been a comte four years.
children.prevalue: You do me honor monsieur le comte said the latter D Artagnan made no reply The title of comte had hardly struck him D Artagnan had been a comte four years

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Are you not very much fatigued with the long journey you have taken, monsieur le capitaine? continued the falconer. It must be full two hundred leagues from hence to Pignerol.
children.prevalue: Are you not very much fatigued with the long journey you have taken monsieur le capitaine continued the falconer It must be full two hundred leagues from hence to Pignerol

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Two hundred and sixty to go, and as many to return, said D'Artagnan, quietly.
children.prevalue: Two hundred and sixty to go and as many to return said D Artagnan quietly

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: And, said the falconer, is he well?
children.prevalue: And said the falconer is he well

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Who? asked D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Who asked D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Why, poor M. Fouquet, continued the falconer, in a low voice. The keeper of the harriers had prudently withdrawn.
children.prevalue: Why poor M Fouquet continued the falconer in a low voice The keeper of the harriers had prudently withdrawn

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: No, replied D'Artagnan, the poor man frets terribly he cannot comprehend how imprisonment can be a favor he says that parliament absolved him by banishing him, and banishment is, or should be, liberty. He cannot imagine that they had sworn his death, and that to save his life from the claws of parliament was to be under too much obligation to Heaven.
children.prevalue: No replied D Artagnan the poor man frets terribly he cannot comprehend how imprisonment can be a favor he says that parliament absolved him by banishing him and banishment is or should be liberty He cannot imagine that they had sworn his death and that to save his life from the claws of parliament was to be under too much obligation to Heaven

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Ah! yes the poor man had a close chance of the scaffold, replied the falconer it is said that M. Colbert had given orders to the governor of the Bastile, and that the execution was ordered.
children.prevalue: Ah yes the poor man had a close chance of the scaffold replied the falconer it is said that M Colbert had given orders to the governor of the Bastile and that the execution was ordered

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Enough! said D'Artagnan, pensively, and with a view of cutting short the conversation.
children.prevalue: Enough said D Artagnan pensively and with a view of cutting short the conversation

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Yes, said the keeper of the harriers, drawing towards them, M. Fouquet is now at Pignerol he has richly deserved it. He had the good fortune to be conducted there by you he robbed the king sufficiently.
children.prevalue: Yes said the keeper of the harriers drawing towards them M Fouquet is now at Pignerol he has richly deserved it He had the good fortune to be conducted there by you he robbed the king sufficiently

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: D'Artagnan launched at the master of the dogs one of his crossest looks, and said to him, Monsieur, if any one told me you had eaten your dogs' meat, not only would I refuse to believe it but still more, if you were condemned to the lash or to jail for it, I should pity you and would not allow people to speak ill of you. And yet, monsieur, honest man as you may be, I assure you that you are not more so than poor M. Fouquet was.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan launched at the master of the dogs one of his crossest looks and said to him Monsieur if any one told me you had eaten your dogs meat not only would I refuse to believe it but still more if you were condemned to the lash or to jail for it I should pity you and would not allow people to speak ill of you And yet monsieur honest man as you may be I assure you that you are not more so than poor M Fouquet was

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: After having undergone this sharp rebuke, the keeper of the harriers hung his head, and allowed the falconer to get two steps in advance of him nearer to D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: After having undergone this sharp rebuke the keeper of the harriers hung his head and allowed the falconer to get two steps in advance of him nearer to D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: He is content, said the falconer, in a low voice, to the musketeer we all know that harriers are in fashion nowadays if he were a falconer he would not talk in that way.
children.prevalue: He is content said the falconer in a low voice to the musketeer we all know that harriers are in fashion nowadays if he were a falconer he would not talk in that way

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: D'Artagnan smiled in a melancholy manner at seeing this great political question resolved by the discontent of such humble interest. He for a moment ran over in his mind the glorious existence of the surintendant, the crumbling of his fortunes, and the melancholy death that awaited him and to conclude, Did M. Fouquet love falconry? said he.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan smiled in a melancholy manner at seeing this great political question resolved by the discontent of such humble interest He for a moment ran over in his mind the glorious existence of the surintendant the crumbling of his fortunes and the melancholy death that awaited him and to conclude Did M Fouquet love falconry said he

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Oh, passionately, monsieur! repeated the falconer, with an accent of bitter regret and a sigh that was the funeral oration of Fouquet.
children.prevalue: Oh passionately monsieur repeated the falconer with an accent of bitter regret and a sigh that was the funeral oration of Fouquet

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: D'Artagnan allowed the illhumor of the one and the regret of the other to pass, and continued to advance. They could already catch glimpses of the huntsmen at the issue of the wood, the feathers of the outriders passing like shooting stars across the clearings, and the white horses skirting the bosky thickets looking like illuminated apparitions.

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: But, resumed D'Artagnan, will the sport last long? Pray, give us a good swift bird, for I am very tired. Is it a heron or a swan?
children.prevalue: But resumed D Artagnan will the sport last long Pray give us a good swift bird for I am very tired Is it a heron or a swan

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Both, Monsieur d'Artagnan, said the falconer but you need not be alarmed the king is not much of a sportsman he does not take the field on his own account, he only wishes to amuse the ladies.

children.name: Paragraph_61

children.value: Ah! said he, looking keenly at the falconer.
children.prevalue: Ah said he looking keenly at the falconer

children.value: The keeper of the harriers smiled, no doubt with a view of making it up with the musketeer.
children.prevalue: The keeper of the harriers smiled no doubt with a view of making it up with the musketeer

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: Oh! you may safely laugh, said D'Artagnan I know nothing of current news I only arrived yesterday, after a month's absence. I left the court mourning the death of the queenmother. The king was not willing to take any amusement after receiving the last sigh of Anne of Austria but everything comes to an end in this world. Well! then he is no longer sad? So much the better.

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: And everything begins as well as ends, said the keeper with a coarse laugh.
children.prevalue: And everything begins as well as ends said the keeper with a coarse laugh

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: Ah! said D'Artagnan, a second time,he burned to know, but dignity would not allow him to interrogate people below him,there is something beginning, then, it seems?
children.prevalue: Ah said D Artagnan a second time he burned to know but dignity would not allow him to interrogate people below him there is something beginning then it seems

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: The keeper gave him a significant wink but D'Artagnan was unwilling to learn anything from this man.
children.prevalue: The keeper gave him a significant wink but D Artagnan was unwilling to learn anything from this man

children.value: Shall we see the king early? asked he of the falconer.
children.prevalue: Shall we see the king early asked he of the falconer

children.prevalue: At seven o clock monsieur I shall fly the birds

children.value: Who comes with the king? How is Madame? How is the queen?
children.prevalue: Who comes with the king How is Madame How is the queen

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: Better, monsieur.
children.prevalue: Better monsieur

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Has she been ill, then?
children.prevalue: Has she been ill then

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Monsieur, since the last chagrin she suffered, her majesty has been unwell.
children.prevalue: Monsieur since the last chagrin she suffered her majesty has been unwell

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: What chagrin? You need not fancy your news is old. I have but just returned.
children.prevalue: What chagrin You need not fancy your news is old I have but just returned

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: It appears that the queen, a little neglected since the death of her motherinlaw, complained to the king, who answered her,'Do I not sleep at home every night, madame? What more do you expect?'
children.prevalue: It appears that the queen a little neglected since the death of her motherinlaw complained to the king who answered her Do I not sleep at home every night madame What more do you expect

children.prevalue: Ah said D Artagnan poor woman She must heartily hate Mademoiselle de la Valliere

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Oh, no! not Mademoiselle de la Valliere, replied the falconer.
children.prevalue: Oh no not Mademoiselle de la Valliere replied the falconer

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: Who then The blast of a huntinghorn interrupted this conversation. It summoned the dogs and the hawks. The falconer and his companions set off immediately, leaving D'Artagnan alone in the midst of the suspended sentence. The king appeared at a distance, surrounded by ladies and horsemen. All the troop advanced in beautiful order, at a foot's pace, the horns of various sorts animating the dogs and horses. There was an animation in the scene, a mirage of light, of which nothing now can give an idea, unless it be the fictitious splendor of a theatric spectacle. D'Artagnan, with an eye a little, just a little, dimmed by age, distinguished behind the group three carriages. The first was intended for the queen it was empty. D'Artagnan, who did not see Mademoiselle de la Valliere by the king's side, on looking about for her, saw her in the second carriage. She was alone with two of her women, who seemed as dull as their mistress. On the left hand of the king, upon a highspirited horse, restrained by a bold and skillful hand, shone a lady of most dazzling beauty. The king smiled upon her, and she smiled upon the king. Loud laughter followed every word she uttered.

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: I must know that woman, thought the musketeer who can she be? And he stooped towards his friend, the falconer, to whom he addressed the question he had put to himself.
children.prevalue: I must know that woman thought the musketeer who can she be And he stooped towards his friend the falconer to whom he addressed the question he had put to himself

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: The falconer was about to reply, when the king, perceiving D'Artagnan, Ah, comte! said he, you are amongst us once more then! Why have I not seen you?
children.prevalue: The falconer was about to reply when the king perceiving D Artagnan Ah comte said he you are amongst us once more then Why have I not seen you

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Sire, replied the captain, because your majesty was asleep when I arrived, and not awake when I resumed my duties this morning.
children.prevalue: Sire replied the captain because your majesty was asleep when I arrived and not awake when I resumed my duties this morning

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Still the same, said Louis, in a loud voice, denoting satisfaction. Take some rest, comte I command you to do so. You will dine with me today.
children.prevalue: Still the same said Louis in a loud voice denoting satisfaction Take some rest comte I command you to do so You will dine with me today

children.value: A murmur of admiration surrounded D'Artagnan like a caress. Every one was eager to salute him. Dining with the king was an honor his majesty was not so prodigal of as Henry IV. had been. The king passed a few steps in advance, and D'Artagnan found himself in the midst of a fresh group, among whom shone Colbert.

children.prevalue: Goodday Monsieur d Artagnan said the minister with marked affability have you had a pleasant journey

children.prevalue: Yes monsieur said D Artagnan bowing to the neck of his horse

children.prevalue: I heard the king invite you to his table for this evening continued the minister you will meet an old friend there

children.value: An old friend of mine? asked D'Artagnan, plunging painfully into the dark waves of the past, which had swallowed up for him so many friendships and so many hatreds.

children.value: Ah! and I shall dine with you at the king's table, said Aramis, smiling. Yes, will you not ask yourself what is the use of fidelity in this world? Stop! let us allow poor La Valliere's carriage to pass. Look, how uneasy she is! How her eyes, dim with tears, follow the king, who is riding on horseback yonder!

children.prevalue: With Mademoiselle de TonnayCharente now Madame de Montespan replied Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: She is jealous. Is she then deserted?
children.prevalue: She is jealous Is she then deserted

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: Not quite yet, but it will not be long before she is.
children.prevalue: Not quite yet but it will not be long before she is

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: They chatted together, while following the sport, and Aramis's coachman drove them so cleverly that they arrived at the instant when the falcon, attacking the bird, beat him down, and fell upon him. The king alighted Madame de Montespan followed his example. They were in front of an isolated chapel, concealed by huge trees, already despoiled of their leaves by the first cutting winds of autumn. Behind this chapel was an inclosure, closed by a latticed gate. The falcon had beaten down his prey in the inclosure belonging to this little chapel, and the king was desirous of going in to take the first feather, according to custom. The cortege formed a circle round the building and the hedges, too small to receive so many. D'Artagnan held back Aramis by the arm, as he was about, like the rest, to alight from his carriage, and in a hoarse, broken voice, Do you know, Aramis, said he, whither chance has conducted us?

children.name: Paragraph_103
children.value: There, in the inclosure. There is a cross, you see, beneath yon little cypress. The tree of grief is planted over their tomb don't go to it the king is going that way the heron has fallen just there.

children.name: Paragraph_104
children.value: Aramis stopped, and concealed himself in the shade. They then saw, without being seen, the pale face of La Valliere, who, neglected in her carriage, at first looked on, with a melancholy heart, from the door, and then, carried away by jealousy, advanced into the chapel, whence, leaning against a pillar, she contemplated the king smiling and making signs to Madame de Montespan to approach, as there was nothing to be afraid of. Madame de Montespan complied she took the hand the king held out to her, and he, plucking out the first feather from the heron, which the falconer had strangled, placed it in his beautiful companion's hat. She, smiling in her turn, kissed the hand tenderly which made her this present. The king grew scarlet with vanity and pleasure he looked at Madame de Montespan with all the fire of new love.

children.name: Paragraph_111
children.value: That evening D'Artagnan was seated at the king's table, near M. Colbert and M. le Duc d'Almeda. The king was very gay. He paid a thousand little attentions to the queen, a thousand kindnesses to Madame, seated at his left hand, and very sad. It might have been supposed that time of calm when the king was wont to watch his mother's eyes for the approval or disapproval of what he had just done.

children.name: Paragraph_112
children.value: Of mistresses there was no question at this dinner. The king addressed Aramis two or three times, calling him M. l'ambassadeur, which increased the surprise already felt by D'Artagnan at seeing his friend the rebel so marvelously well received at court.
children.prevalue: Of mistresses there was no question at this dinner The king addressed Aramis two or three times calling him M l ambassadeur which increased the surprise already felt by D Artagnan at seeing his friend the rebel so marvelously well received at court

children.name: Paragraph_113
children.value: The king, on rising from table, gave his hand to the queen, and made a sign to Colbert, whose eye was on his master's face. Colbert took D'Artagnan and Aramis on one side. The king began to chat with his sister, whilst Monsieur, very uneasy, entertained the queen with a preoccupied air, without ceasing to watch his wife and brother from the corner of his eye. The conversation between Aramis, D'Artagnan, and Colbert turned upon indifferent subjects. They spoke of preceding ministers Colbert related the successful tricks of Mazarin, and desired those of Richelieu to be related to him. D'Artagnan could not overcome his surprise at finding this man, with his heavy eyebrows and low forehead, display so much sound knowledge and cheerful spirits. Aramis was astonished at that lightness of character which permitted this serious man to retard with advantage the moment for more important conversation, to which nobody made any allusion, although all three interlocutors felt its imminence. It was very plain, from the embarrassed appearance of Monsieur, how much the conversation of the king and Madame annoyed him. Madame's eyes were almost red: was she going to complain? Was she going to expose a little scandal in open court? The king took her on one side, and in a tone so tender that it must have reminded the princess of the time when she was loved for herself:

children.prevalue: And who since that unjust exile has endeavored to get himself killed once every day

children.name: Paragraph_126
children.value: Unjust, say you, sister?
children.prevalue: Unjust say you sister

children.name: Paragraph_127
children.value: So unjust, that if I had not had the respect mixed with friendship that I have always entertained for your majesty
children.prevalue: So unjust that if I had not had the respect mixed with friendship that I have always entertained for your majesty

children.name: Paragraph_128
children.value: Well!
children.prevalue: Well

children.name: Paragraph_129
children.value: Well! I would have asked my brother Charles, upon whom I can always
children.prevalue: Well I would have asked my brother Charles upon whom I can always

children.name: Paragraph_130
children.value: The king started. What, then?
children.prevalue: The king started What then

children.name: Paragraph_131
children.value: I would have asked him to have had it represented to you that Monsieur and his favorite M. le Chevalier de Lorraine ought not with impunity to constitute themselves the executioners of my honor and my happiness.
children.prevalue: I would have asked him to have had it represented to you that Monsieur and his favorite M le Chevalier de Lorraine ought not with impunity to constitute themselves the executioners of my honor and my happiness

children.name: Paragraph_132
children.value: The Chevalier de Lorraine, said the king that dismal fellow?
children.prevalue: The Chevalier de Lorraine said the king that dismal fellow

children.name: Paragraph_133
children.value: Is my mortal enemy. Whilst that man lives in my household, where Monsieur retains him and delegates his power to him, I shall be the most miserable woman in the kingdom.
children.prevalue: Is my mortal enemy Whilst that man lives in my household where Monsieur retains him and delegates his power to him I shall be the most miserable woman in the kingdom

children.name: Paragraph_134
children.value: So, said the king, slowly, you call your brother of England a better friend than I am?
children.prevalue: So said the king slowly you call your brother of England a better friend than I am

children.name: Paragraph_135
children.value: Actions speak for themselves, sire.
children.prevalue: Actions speak for themselves sire

children.name: Paragraph_136
children.value: And you would prefer going to ask assistance there
children.prevalue: And you would prefer going to ask assistance there

children.name: Paragraph_137
children.value: To my own country! said she with pride yes, sire.
children.prevalue: To my own country said she with pride yes sire

children.name: Paragraph_138
children.value: You are the grandchild of Henry IV. as well as myself, lady. Cousin and brotherinlaw, does not that amount pretty well to the title of brothergermain?
children.prevalue: You are the grandchild of Henry IV as well as myself lady Cousin and brotherinlaw does not that amount pretty well to the title of brothergermain

children.name: Paragraph_139
children.value: Then, said Henrietta, act!
children.prevalue: Then said Henrietta act

children.name: Paragraph_140
children.value: Let us form an alliance.
children.prevalue: Let us form an alliance

children.name: Paragraph_141
children.value: Begin.
children.prevalue: Begin

children.name: Paragraph_142
children.value: I have, you say, unjustly exiled De Guiche.
children.prevalue: I have you say unjustly exiled De Guiche

children.name: Paragraph_143
children.value: Oh! yes, said she, blushing.
children.prevalue: Oh yes said she blushing

children.name: Paragraph_144
children.value: De Guiche shall return.
children.prevalue: De Guiche shall return

children.name: Paragraph_145
children.value: So far, well.
children.prevalue: So far well

children.name: Paragraph_146
children.value: And now you say that I do wrong in having in your household the Chevalier de Lorraine, who gives Monsieur ill advice respecting you?
children.prevalue: And now you say that I do wrong in having in your household the Chevalier de Lorraine who gives Monsieur ill advice respecting you

children.name: Paragraph_147
children.value: Remember well what I tell you, sire the Chevalier de Lorraine some dayObserve, if ever I come to a dreadful end, I beforehand accuse the Chevalier de Lorraine he has a spirit that is capable of any crime!
children.prevalue: Remember well what I tell you sire the Chevalier de Lorraine some dayObserve if ever I come to a dreadful end I beforehand accuse the Chevalier de Lorraine he has a spirit that is capable of any crime

children.name: Paragraph_148
children.value: The Chevalier de Lorraine shall no longer annoy youI promise you that.
children.prevalue: The Chevalier de Lorraine shall no longer annoy youI promise you that

children.name: Paragraph_149
children.value: Then that will be a true preliminary of alliance, sire,I sign but since you have done your part, tell me what shall be mine.
children.prevalue: Then that will be a true preliminary of alliance sire I sign but since you have done your part tell me what shall be mine

children.name: Paragraph_150
children.value: Instead of embroiling me with your brother Charles, you must make him a more intimate friend than ever.
children.prevalue: Instead of embroiling me with your brother Charles you must make him a more intimate friend than ever

children.name: Paragraph_151
children.value: That is very easy.
children.prevalue: That is very easy

children.name: Paragraph_152
children.value: Oh! not quite so easy as you may suppose, for in ordinary friendship people embrace or exercise hospitality, and that only costs a kiss or a return, profitable expenses but in political friendship
children.prevalue: Oh not quite so easy as you may suppose for in ordinary friendship people embrace or exercise hospitality and that only costs a kiss or a return profitable expenses but in political friendship

children.name: Paragraph_153
children.value: Ah! it's a political friendship, is it?
children.prevalue: Ah it s a political friendship is it

children.name: Paragraph_154
children.value: Yes, my sister and then, instead of embraces and feasts, it is soldiersit is soldiers all alive and well equippedthat we must serve up to our friends vessels we must offer, all armed with cannons and stored with provisions. It hence results that we have not always coffers in a fit condition for such friendships.
children.prevalue: Yes my sister and then instead of embraces and feasts it is soldiersit is soldiers all alive and well equippedthat we must serve up to our friends vessels we must offer all armed with cannons and stored with provisions It hence results that we have not always coffers in a fit condition for such friendships

children.name: Paragraph_155
children.value: Ah! you are quite right, said Madame the coffers of the king of England have been sonorous for some time.
children.prevalue: Ah you are quite right said Madame the coffers of the king of England have been sonorous for some time

children.name: Paragraph_156
children.value: But you, my sister, who have so much influence over your brother, you can secure more than an ambassador could ever get the promise of.
children.prevalue: But you my sister who have so much influence over your brother you can secure more than an ambassador could ever get the promise of

children.name: Paragraph_157
children.value: To effect that I must go to London, my dear brother.
children.prevalue: To effect that I must go to London my dear brother

children.name: Paragraph_158
children.value: I have thought so, replied the king, eagerly and I have said to myself that such a voyage would do your health and spirits good.
children.prevalue: I have thought so replied the king eagerly and I have said to myself that such a voyage would do your health and spirits good

children.name: Paragraph_159
children.value: Only, interrupted Madame, it is possible I should fail. The king of England has dangerous counselors.
children.prevalue: Only interrupted Madame it is possible I should fail The king of England has dangerous counselors

children.name: Paragraph_160
children.value: Counselors, do you say?
children.prevalue: Counselors do you say

children.name: Paragraph_161
children.value: Precisely. If, by chance, your majesty had any intentionI am only supposing soof asking Charles II. his alliance in a war
children.prevalue: Precisely If by chance your majesty had any intentionI am only supposing soof asking Charles II his alliance in a war

children.name: Paragraph_162
children.value: A war?
children.prevalue: A war

children.name: Paragraph_163
children.value: Yes well! then the king's counselors, who are in number sevenMademoiselle Stewart, Mademoiselle Wells, Mademoiselle Gwyn, Miss Orchay, Mademoiselle Zunga, Miss Davies, and the proud Countess of Castlemainewill represent to the king that war costs a great deal of money that it is better to give balls and suppers at Hampton Court than to equip ships of the line at Portsmouth and Greenwich.
children.prevalue: Yes well then the king s counselors who are in number sevenMademoiselle Stewart Mademoiselle Wells Mademoiselle Gwyn Miss Orchay Mademoiselle Zunga Miss Davies and the proud Countess of Castlemainewill represent to the king that war costs a great deal of money that it is better to give balls and suppers at Hampton Court than to equip ships of the line at Portsmouth and Greenwich

children.name: Paragraph_164
children.value: And then your negotiations will fail?
children.prevalue: And then your negotiations will fail

children.name: Paragraph_165
children.value: Oh! those ladies cause all negotiations to fall through which they don't make themselves.
children.prevalue: Oh those ladies cause all negotiations to fall through which they don t make themselves

children.name: Paragraph_166
children.value: Do you know the idea that has struck me, sister?
children.prevalue: Do you know the idea that has struck me sister

children.name: Paragraph_167
children.value: No inform me what it is.
children.prevalue: No inform me what it is

children.name: Paragraph_168
children.value: It is that, searching well around you, you might perhaps find a female counselor to take with you to your brother, whose eloquence might paralyze the illwill of the seven others.
children.prevalue: It is that searching well around you you might perhaps find a female counselor to take with you to your brother whose eloquence might paralyze the illwill of the seven others

children.name: Paragraph_169
children.value: That is really an idea, sire, and I will search.
children.prevalue: That is really an idea sire and I will search

children.name: Paragraph_170
children.value: You will find what you want.
children.prevalue: You will find what you want

children.name: Paragraph_171
children.value: I hope so.
children.prevalue: I hope so

children.name: Paragraph_172
children.value: A pretty ambassadress is necessary an agreeable face is better than an ugly one, is it not?
children.prevalue: A pretty ambassadress is necessary an agreeable face is better than an ugly one is it not

children.name: Paragraph_173
children.value: Most assuredly.
children.prevalue: Most assuredly

children.name: Paragraph_174
children.value: An animated, lively, audacious character.
children.prevalue: An animated lively audacious character

children.name: Paragraph_175
children.value: Certainly.
children.prevalue: Certainly

children.name: Paragraph_176
children.value: Nobility that is, enough to enable her to approach the king without awkwardnessnot too lofty, so as not to trouble herself about the dignity of her race.
children.prevalue: Nobility that is enough to enable her to approach the king without awkwardnessnot too lofty so as not to trouble herself about the dignity of her race

children.name: Paragraph_177
children.value: Very true.
children.prevalue: Very true

children.name: Paragraph_178
children.value: And who knows a little English.
children.prevalue: And who knows a little English

children.name: Paragraph_179
children.value: Mon Dieu! why, some one, cried Madame, like Mademoiselle de Keroualle, for instance!
children.prevalue: Mon Dieu why some one cried Madame like Mademoiselle de Keroualle for instance

children.name: Paragraph_180
children.value: Oh! why, yes! said Louis XIV. you have hit the mark,it is you who have found, my sister.
children.prevalue: Oh why yes said Louis XIV you have hit the mark it is you who have found my sister

children.name: Paragraph_181
children.value: I will take her she will have no cause to complain, I suppose.
children.prevalue: I will take her she will have no cause to complain I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_182
children.value: Oh! no, I will name her seductrice plenipotentiaire at once, and will add a dowry to the title.
children.prevalue: Oh no I will name her seductrice plenipotentiaire at once and will add a dowry to the title

children.name: Paragraph_183
children.value: That is well.
children.prevalue: That is well

children.name: Paragraph_184
children.value: I fancy you already on your road, my dear little sister, consoled for all your griefs.
children.prevalue: I fancy you already on your road my dear little sister consoled for all your griefs

children.name: Paragraph_185
children.value: I will go, on two conditions. The first is, that I shall know what I am negotiating about.
children.prevalue: I will go on two conditions The first is that I shall know what I am negotiating about

children.name: Paragraph_186
children.value: That is it. The Dutch, you know, insult me daily in their gazettes, and by their republican attitude. I do not like republics.
children.prevalue: That is it The Dutch you know insult me daily in their gazettes and by their republican attitude I do not like republics

children.name: Paragraph_187
children.value: That may easily be imagined, sire.
children.prevalue: That may easily be imagined sire

children.name: Paragraph_188
children.value: I see with pain that these kings of the seathey call themselves sokeep trade from France in the Indies, and that their vessels will soon occupy all the ports of Europe. Such a power is too near me, sister.
children.prevalue: I see with pain that these kings of the seathey call themselves sokeep trade from France in the Indies and that their vessels will soon occupy all the ports of Europe Such a power is too near me sister

children.name: Paragraph_189
children.value: They are your allies, nevertheless.
children.prevalue: They are your allies nevertheless

children.name: Paragraph_190
children.value: That is why they were wrong in having the medal you have heard of struck a medal which represents Holland stopping the sun, as Joshua did, with this legend: The sun had stopped before me. There is not much fraternity in that, is there?
children.prevalue: That is why they were wrong in having the medal you have heard of struck a medal which represents Holland stopping the sun as Joshua did with this legend The sun had stopped before me There is not much fraternity in that is there

children.name: Paragraph_191
children.value: I thought you had forgotten that miserable episode?
children.prevalue: I thought you had forgotten that miserable episode

children.name: Paragraph_192
children.value: I never forget anything, sister. And if my true friends, such as your brother Charles, are willing to second me The princess remained pensively silent.
children.prevalue: I never forget anything sister And if my true friends such as your brother Charles are willing to second me The princess remained pensively silent

children.name: Paragraph_193
children.value: Listen to me there is the empire of the seas to be shared, said Louis XIV. For this partition, which England submits to, could I not represent the second party as well as the Dutch?
children.prevalue: Listen to me there is the empire of the seas to be shared said Louis XIV For this partition which England submits to could I not represent the second party as well as the Dutch

children.name: Paragraph_194
children.value: We have Mademoiselle de Keroualle to treat that question, replied Madame.
children.prevalue: We have Mademoiselle de Keroualle to treat that question replied Madame

children.name: Paragraph_195
children.value: Your second condition for going, if you please, sister?
children.prevalue: Your second condition for going if you please sister

children.name: Paragraph_196
children.value: The consent of Monsieur, my husband.
children.prevalue: The consent of Monsieur my husband

children.name: Paragraph_197
children.value: You shall have it.
children.prevalue: You shall have it

children.name: Paragraph_198
children.value: Then consider me already gone, brother.
children.prevalue: Then consider me already gone brother

children.name: Paragraph_199
children.value: On hearing these words, Louis XIV. turned round towards the corner of the room in which D'Artagnan, Colbert, and Aramis stood, and made an affirmative sign to his minister. Colbert then broke in on the conversation suddenly, and said to Aramis:
children.prevalue: On hearing these words Louis XIV turned round towards the corner of the room in which D Artagnan Colbert and Aramis stood and made an affirmative sign to his minister Colbert then broke in on the conversation suddenly and said to Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_200
children.value: Monsieur l'ambassadeur, shall we talk about business?
children.prevalue: Monsieur l ambassadeur shall we talk about business

children.name: Paragraph_201
children.value: D'Artagnan immediately withdrew, from politeness. He directed his steps towards the fireplace, within hearing of what the king was about to say to Monsieur, who, evidently uneasy, had gone to him. The face of the king was animated. Upon his brow was stamped a strength of will, the expression of which already met no further contradiction in France, and was soon to meet no more in Europe.
children.prevalue: D Artagnan immediately withdrew from politeness He directed his steps towards the fireplace within hearing of what the king was about to say to Monsieur who evidently uneasy had gone to him The face of the king was animated Upon his brow was stamped a strength of will the expression of which already met no further contradiction in France and was soon to meet no more in Europe

children.name: Paragraph_202
children.value: Monsieur, said the king to his brother, I am not pleased with M. le Chevalier de Lorraine. You, who do him the honor to protect him, must advise him to travel for a few months.
children.prevalue: Monsieur said the king to his brother I am not pleased with M le Chevalier de Lorraine You who do him the honor to protect him must advise him to travel for a few months

children.name: Paragraph_203
children.value: These words fell with the crush of an avalanche upon Monsieur, who adored his favorite, and concentrated all his affections in him.
children.prevalue: These words fell with the crush of an avalanche upon Monsieur who adored his favorite and concentrated all his affections in him

children.name: Paragraph_204
children.value: In what has the chevalier been inconsiderate enough to displease your majesty? cried he, darting a furious look at Madame.
children.prevalue: In what has the chevalier been inconsiderate enough to displease your majesty cried he darting a furious look at Madame

children.name: Paragraph_205
children.value: I will tell you that when he is gone, said the king, suavely. And also when Madame, here, shall have crossed over into England.
children.prevalue: I will tell you that when he is gone said the king suavely And also when Madame here shall have crossed over into England

children.name: Paragraph_206
children.value: Madame! in England! murmured Monsieur, in amazement.
children.prevalue: Madame in England murmured Monsieur in amazement

children.name: Paragraph_207
children.value: In a week, brother, continued the king, whilst we will go whither I will shortly tell you. And the king turned on his heel, smiling in his brother's face, to sweeten, as it were, the bitter draught he had given him.
children.prevalue: In a week brother continued the king whilst we will go whither I will shortly tell you And the king turned on his heel smiling in his brother s face to sweeten as it were the bitter draught he had given him

children.name: Paragraph_208
children.value: During this time Colbert was talking with the Duc d'Almeda.
children.prevalue: During this time Colbert was talking with the Duc d Almeda

children.name: Paragraph_209
children.value: Monsieur, said Colbert to Aramis, this is the moment for us to come to an understanding. I have made your peace with the king, and I owed that clearly to a man of so much merit but as you have often expressed friendship for me, an opportunity presents itself for giving me a proof of it. You are, besides, more a Frenchman than a Spaniard. Shall we secureanswer me franklythe neutrality of Spain, if we undertake anything against the United Provinces?
children.prevalue: Monsieur said Colbert to Aramis this is the moment for us to come to an understanding I have made your peace with the king and I owed that clearly to a man of so much merit but as you have often expressed friendship for me an opportunity presents itself for giving me a proof of it You are besides more a Frenchman than a Spaniard Shall we secureanswer me franklythe neutrality of Spain if we undertake anything against the United Provinces

children.name: Paragraph_210
children.value: Monsieur, replied Aramis, the interest of Spain is clear. To embroil Europe with the Provinces would doubtless be our policy, but the king of France is an ally of the United Provinces. You are not ignorant, besides, that it would infer a maritime war, and that France is in no state to undertake this with advantage.
children.prevalue: Monsieur replied Aramis the interest of Spain is clear To embroil Europe with the Provinces would doubtless be our policy but the king of France is an ally of the United Provinces You are not ignorant besides that it would infer a maritime war and that France is in no state to undertake this with advantage

children.name: Paragraph_211
children.value: Colbert, turning round at this moment, saw D'Artagnan who was seeking some interlocutor, during this aside of the king and Monsieur. He called him, at the same time saying in a low voice to Aramis, We may talk openly with D'Artagnan, I suppose?
children.prevalue: Colbert turning round at this moment saw D Artagnan who was seeking some interlocutor during this aside of the king and Monsieur He called him at the same time saying in a low voice to Aramis We may talk openly with D Artagnan I suppose

children.name: Paragraph_212
children.value: Oh! certainly, replied the ambassador.
children.prevalue: Oh certainly replied the ambassador

children.name: Paragraph_213
children.value: We were saying, M. d'Almeda and I, said Colbert, that a conflict with the United Provinces would mean a maritime war.
children.prevalue: We were saying M d Almeda and I said Colbert that a conflict with the United Provinces would mean a maritime war

children.name: Paragraph_214
children.value: That's evident enough, replied the musketeer.
children.prevalue: That s evident enough replied the musketeer

children.name: Paragraph_215
children.value: And what do you think of it, Monsieur d'Artagnan?
children.prevalue: And what do you think of it Monsieur d Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_216
children.value: I think that to carry on such a war successfully, you must have very large land forces.
children.prevalue: I think that to carry on such a war successfully you must have very large land forces

children.name: Paragraph_217
children.value: What did you say? said Colbert, thinking he had ill understood him.
children.prevalue: What did you say said Colbert thinking he had ill understood him

children.name: Paragraph_218
children.value: Why such a large land army? said Aramis.
children.prevalue: Why such a large land army said Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_219
children.value: Because the king will be beaten by sea if he has not the English with him, and that when beaten by sea, he will soon be invaded, either by the Dutch in his ports, or by the Spaniards by land.
children.prevalue: Because the king will be beaten by sea if he has not the English with him and that when beaten by sea he will soon be invaded either by the Dutch in his ports or by the Spaniards by land

children.name: Paragraph_220
children.value: And Spain neutral? asked Aramis.
children.prevalue: And Spain neutral asked Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_221
children.value: Neutral as long as the king shall prove stronger, rejoined D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Neutral as long as the king shall prove stronger rejoined D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_222
children.value: Colbert admired that sagacity which never touched a question without enlightening it thoroughly. Aramis smiled, as he had long known that in diplomacy D'Artagnan acknowledged no superior. Colbert, who, like all proud men, dwelt upon his fantasy with a certainty of success, resumed the subject, Who told you, M. d'Artagnan, that the king had no navy?
children.prevalue: Colbert admired that sagacity which never touched a question without enlightening it thoroughly Aramis smiled as he had long known that in diplomacy D Artagnan acknowledged no superior Colbert who like all proud men dwelt upon his fantasy with a certainty of success resumed the subject Who told you M d Artagnan that the king had no navy

children.name: Paragraph_223
children.value: Oh! I take no heed of these details, replied the captain. I am but an indifferent sailor. Like all nervous people, I hate the sea and yet I have an idea that, with ships, France being a seaport with two hundred exits, we might have sailors.
children.prevalue: Oh I take no heed of these details replied the captain I am but an indifferent sailor Like all nervous people I hate the sea and yet I have an idea that with ships France being a seaport with two hundred exits we might have sailors

children.name: Paragraph_224
children.value: Colbert drew from his pocket a little oblong book divided into two columns. On the first were the names of vessels, on the other the figures recapitulating the number of cannon and men requisite to equip these ships. I have had the same idea as you, said he to D'Artagnan, and I have had an account drawn up of the vessels we have altogetherthirtyfive ships.
children.prevalue: Colbert drew from his pocket a little oblong book divided into two columns On the first were the names of vessels on the other the figures recapitulating the number of cannon and men requisite to equip these ships I have had the same idea as you said he to D Artagnan and I have had an account drawn up of the vessels we have altogetherthirtyfive ships

children.name: Paragraph_225
children.value: Thirtyfive ships! impossible! cried D'Artagnan.
children.prevalue: Thirtyfive ships impossible cried D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_226
children.value: Something like two thousand pieces of cannon, said Colbert. That is what the king possesses at this moment. Of five and thirty vessels we can make three squadrons, but I must have five.
children.prevalue: Something like two thousand pieces of cannon said Colbert That is what the king possesses at this moment Of five and thirty vessels we can make three squadrons but I must have five

children.name: Paragraph_227
children.value: Five! cried Aramis.
children.prevalue: Five cried Aramis

children.name: Paragraph_228
children.value: They will be afloat before the end of the year, gentlemen the king will have fifty ship of the line. We may venture on a contest with them, may we not?
children.prevalue: They will be afloat before the end of the year gentlemen the king will have fifty ship of the line We may venture on a contest with them may we not

children.name: Paragraph_229
children.value: To build vessels, said D'Artagnan, is difficult, but possible. As to arming them, how is that to be done? In France there are neither foundries nor military docks.
children.prevalue: To build vessels said D Artagnan is difficult but possible As to arming them how is that to be done In France there are neither foundries nor military docks

children.name: Paragraph_230
children.value: Bah! replied Colbert, in a bantering tone, I have planned all that this year and a half past, did you not know it? Do you know M. d'Imfreville?
children.prevalue: Bah replied Colbert in a bantering tone I have planned all that this year and a half past did you not know it Do you know M d Imfreville

children.name: Paragraph_231
children.value: D'Imfreville? replied D'Artagnan no.
children.prevalue: D Imfreville replied D Artagnan no

children.name: Paragraph_232
children.value: He is a man I have discovered he has a specialty he is a man of geniushe knows how to set men to work. It is he who has cast cannon and cut the woods of Bourgogne. And then, monsieur l'ambassadeur, you may not believe what I am going to tell you, but I have a still further idea.
children.prevalue: He is a man I have discovered he has a specialty he is a man of geniushe knows how to set men to work It is he who has cast cannon and cut the woods of Bourgogne And then monsieur l ambassadeur you may not believe what I am going to tell you but I have a still further idea

children.name: Paragraph_233
children.value: Oh, monsieur! said Aramis, civilly, I always believe you.
children.prevalue: Oh monsieur said Aramis civilly I always believe you

children.name: Paragraph_234
children.value: Calculating upon the character of the Dutch, our allies, I said to myself, 'They are merchants, they are friendly with the king they will be happy to sell to the king what they fabricate for themselves then the more we buy'Ah! I must add this: I have Forantdo you know Forant, D'Artagnan?
children.prevalue: Calculating upon the character of the Dutch our allies I said to myself They are merchants they are friendly with the king they will be happy to sell to the king what they fabricate for themselves then the more we buy Ah I must add this I have Forantdo you know Forant D Artagnan

children.name: Paragraph_235
children.value: Colbert, in his warmth, forgot himself he called the captain simply D'Artagnan, as the king did. But the captain only smiled at it.
children.prevalue: Colbert in his warmth forgot himself he called the captain simply D Artagnan as the king did But the captain only smiled at it

children.name: Paragraph_236
children.value: No, replied he, I do not know him.
children.prevalue: No replied he I do not know him

children.name: Paragraph_237
children.value: That is another man I have discovered, with a genius for buying. This Forant has purchased for me 350,000 pounds of iron in balls, 200,000 pounds of powder, twelve cargoes of Northern timber, matches, grenades, pitch, tarI know not what! with a saving of seven per cent upon what all those articles would cost me fabricated in France.
children.prevalue: That is another man I have discovered with a genius for buying This Forant has purchased for me 350 000 pounds of iron in balls 200 000 pounds of powder twelve cargoes of Northern timber matches grenades pitch tarI know not what with a saving of seven per cent upon what all those articles would cost me fabricated in France

children.name: Paragraph_238
children.value: That is a capital and quaint idea, replied D'Artagnan, to have Dutch cannonballs cast which will return to the Dutch.
children.prevalue: That is a capital and quaint idea replied D Artagnan to have Dutch cannonballs cast which will return to the Dutch

children.name: Paragraph_239
children.value: Is it not, with loss, too? And Colbert laughed aloud. He was delighted with his own joke.
children.prevalue: Is it not with loss too And Colbert laughed aloud He was delighted with his own joke

children.name: Paragraph_240
children.value: Still further, added he, these same Dutch are building for the king, at this moment, six vessels after the model of the best of their name. DestouchesAh! perhaps you don't know Destouches?
children.prevalue: Still further added he these same Dutch are building for the king at this moment six vessels after the model of the best of their name DestouchesAh perhaps you don t know Destouches

children.name: Paragraph_242
children.value: He is a man who has a sure glance to discern, when a ship is launched, what are the defects and qualities of that shipthat is valuable, observe! Nature is truly whimsical. Well, this Destouches appeared to me to be a man likely to prove useful in marine affairs, and he is superintending the construction of six vessels of seventyeight guns, which the Provinces are building for his majesty. It results from this, my dear Monsieur d'Artagnan, that the king, if he wished to quarrel with the Provinces, would have a very pretty fleet. Now, you know better than anybody else if the land army is efficient.

children.name: Paragraph_243
children.value: D'Artagnan and Aramis looked at each other, wondering at the mysterious labors this man had undertaken in so short a time. Colbert understood them, and was touched by this best of flatteries.

children.value: Monsieur d'Artagnan, resumed Colbert, between us two, you will have, I wager, an inclination to lead your musketeers into Holland. Can you swim? And he laughed like a man in high good humor.

children.value: Ah! but there are some bitter passages of canals and marshes yonder, Monsieur d'Artagnan, and the best swimmers are sometimes drowned there.

children.value: It is my profession to die for his majesty, said the musketeer. Only, as it is seldom in war that much water is met with without a little fire, I declare to you beforehand, that I will do my best to choose fire. I am getting old water freezes mebut fire warms, Monsieur Colbert.

children.name: Paragraph_253
children.value: And D'Artagnan looked so handsome still in quasijuvenile strength as he pronounced these words, that Colbert, in his turn, could not help admiring him. D'Artagnan perceived the effect he had produced. He remembered that the best tradesman is he who fixes a high price upon his goods, when they are valuable. He prepared his price in advance.

children.name: Paragraph_257
children.value: Only, repeated D'Artagnan, there lurks in everything the question of interest, the question of selflove. It is a very fine title, that of captain of the musketeers but observe this: we have now the king's guards and the military household of the king. A captain of musketeers ought to command all that, and then he would absorb a hundred thousand livres a year for expenses.

children.name: Paragraph_259
children.value: Eh! monsieur, you have not understood me, replied D'Artagnan, sure of carrying his point. I was telling you that I, an old captain, formerly chief of the king's guard, having precedence of the marechaux of FranceI saw myself one day in the trenches with two other equals, the captain of the guards and the colonel commanding the Swiss. Now, at no price will I suffer that. I have old habits, and I will stand or fall by them.

children.name: Paragraph_264
children.value: Well!

children.value: D'Artagnan became very pale with joy, and in a not very firm voice, People would be very proud of me in my country, said he, if I were a marechal of France but a man must have commanded an expedition in chief to obtain the baton.

children.value: Monsieur! said Colbert, here is in this pocketbook which you will study, a plan of campaign you will have to lead a body of troops to carry out in the next spring.

children.value: Monsieur, said he, we had both a revenge to take, one over the other. I have begun it is now your turn!

children.value: I will do you justice, monsieur, replied D'Artagnan, and implore you to tell the king that the first opportunity that shall offer, he may depend upon a victory, or to behold me deador both.

children.value: On the morrow, Aramis, who was setting out for Madrid, to negotiate the neutrality of Spain, came to embrace D'Artagnan at his hotel.

children.value: And you will, perhaps, never see me again, dear D'Artagnan, said Aramis if you knew how I have loved you! I am old, I am extinctah, I am almost dead.

children.name: Paragraph_282
children.value: Contrary to that which generally happens, whether in politics or morals, each kept his promises, and did honor to his engagements.
children.prevalue: Contrary to that which generally happens whether in politics or morals each kept his promises and did honor to his engagements

children.name: Paragraph_283
children.value: The king recalled M. de Guiche, and banished M. le Chevalier de Lorraine so that Monsieur became ill in consequence. Madame set out for London, where she applied herself so earnestly to make her brother, Charles II., acquire a taste for the political counsels of Mademoiselle de Keroualle, that the alliance between England and France was signed, and the English vessels, ballasted by a few millions of French gold, made a terrible campaign against the fleets of the United Provinces. Charles II. had promised Mademoiselle de Keroualle a little gratitude for her good counsels he made her Duchess of Portsmouth. Colbert had promised the king vessels, munitions, victories. He kept his word, as is well known. At length Aramis, upon whose promises there was least dependence to be placed, wrote Colbert the following letter, on the subject of the negotiations which he had undertaken at Madrid:

children.name: Paragraph_284
children.value: MONSIEUR COLBERT,I have the honor to expedite to you the R. P. Oliva, general ad interim of the Society of Jesus, my provisional successor. The reverend father will explain to you, Monsieur Colbert, that I preserve to myself the direction of all the affairs of the order which concern France and Spain but that I am not willing to retain the title of general, which would throw too high a sidelight on the progress of the negotiations with which His Catholic Majesty wishes to intrust me. I shall resume that title by the command of his majesty, when the labors I have undertaken in concert with you, for the great glory of God and His Church, shall be brought to a good end. The R. P. Oliva will inform you likewise, monsieur, of the consent His Catholic Majesty gives to the signature of a treaty which assures the neutrality of Spain in the event of a war between France and the United Provinces. This consent will be valid even if England, instead of being active, should satisfy herself with remaining neutral. As for Portugal, of which you and I have spoken, monsieur, I can assure you it will contribute with all its resources to assist the Most Christian King in his war. I beg you, Monsieur Colbert, to preserve your friendship and also to believe in my profound attachment, and to lay my respect at the feet of His Most Christian Majesty. Signed,

children.name: Paragraph_285
children.value: LE DUC D'ALMEDA.
children.prevalue: LE DUC D ALMEDA

children.name: Paragraph_286
children.value: Aramis had performed more than he had promised it remained to be seen how the king, M. Colbert, and D'Artagnan would be faithful to each other. In the spring, as Colbert had predicted, the land army entered on its campaign. It preceded, in magnificent order, the court of Louis XIV., who, setting out on horseback, surrounded by carriages filled with ladies and courtiers, conducted the elite of his kingdom to this sanguinary fete. The officers of the army, it is true, had no other music save the artillery of the Dutch forts but it was enough for a great number, who found in this war honor, advancement, fortuneor death.

children.name: Paragraph_287
children.value: M. d'Artagnan set out commanding a body of twelve thousand men, cavalry, and infantry, with which he was ordered to take the different places which form knots of that strategic network called La Frise. Never was an army conducted more gallantly to an expedition. The officers knew that their leader, prudent and skillful as he was brave, would not sacrifice a single man, nor yield an inch of ground without necessity. He had the old habits of war, to live upon the country, keeping his soldiers singing and the enemy weeping. The captain of the king's musketeers well knew his business. Never were opportunities better chosen, coupsdemain better supported, errors of the besieged more quickly taken advantage of.
children.prevalue: M d Artagnan set out commanding a body of twelve thousand men cavalry and infantry with which he was ordered to take the different places which form knots of that strategic network called La Frise Never was an army conducted more gallantly to an expedition The officers knew that their leader prudent and skillful as he was brave would not sacrifice a single man nor yield an inch of ground without necessity He had the old habits of war to live upon the country keeping his soldiers singing and the enemy weeping The captain of the king s musketeers well knew his business Never were opportunities better chosen coupsdemain better supported errors of the besieged more quickly taken advantage of

children.name: Paragraph_288
children.value: The army commanded by D'Artagnan took twelve small places within a month. He was engaged in besieging the thirteenth, which had held out five days. D'Artagnan caused the trenches to be opened without appearing to suppose that these people would ever allow themselves to be taken. The pioneers and laborers were, in the army of this man, a body full of ideas and zeal, because their commander treated them like soldiers, knew how to render their work glorious, and never allowed them to be killed if he could help it. It should have been seen with what eagerness the marshy glebes of Holland were turned over. Those turfheaps, mounds of potter's clay, melted at the word of the soldiers like butter in the fryingpans of Friesland housewives.

children.name: Paragraph_289
children.value: M. d'Artagnan dispatched a courier to the king to give him an account of the last success, which redoubled the good humor of his majesty and his inclination to amuse the ladies. These victories of M. d'Artagnan gave so much majesty to the prince, that Madame de Montespan no longer called him anything but Louis the Invincible. So that Mademoiselle de la Valliere, who only called the king Louis the Victorious, lost much of his majesty's favor. Besides, her eyes were frequently red, and to an Invincible nothing is more disagreeable than a mistress who weeps while everything is smiling round her. The star of Mademoiselle de la Valliere was being drowned in clouds and tears. But the gayety of Madame de Montespan redoubled with the successes of the king, and consoled him for every other unpleasant circumstance. It was to D'Artagnan the king owed this and his majesty was anxious to acknowledge these services he wrote to M. Colbert:

children.name: Paragraph_290
children.value: MONSIEUR COLBERT,We have a promise to fulfil with M. d'Artagnan, who so well keeps his. This is to inform you that the time is come for performing it. All provisions for this purpose you shall be furnished with in due time. LOUIS.
